column2: TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the current controversy over the Forand bill to aid our "elder citizens" what appears to me to be the most important ethical issue involved seems to have been misplaced in the scuffle.

Australia has entered an official challenge for the America's Cup, the symbol of international yachting supremacy defended successfully seventeen times by the United States since its capture more than a hundred years ago.

St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Riverdale, the Bronx, was the scene yesterday morning of the marriage of Miss Nancyle Maria Benziger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Benziger of Riverdale and Spring Lake. N.J., to William J. Connellan of Yonkers.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Administration made clear to Congress today that it was ready to compromise on wheat legislation.
ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today creating a state authority rehabilitate and operate Westchester's antiquated parkways.
LOS ANGELES, April 20 -- Space engineers agreed today that flying laboratories should be circling the earth about 1965.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company stockholders' hopes for an increase in dividends were promptly squelched at yesterday's annual meeting in Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- A celebrated architect warned today that skyrocketing land values in the country's major cities threatened to make the cost of many valuable construction projects prohibitive.

WELLSBORO, Pa., April 20 -- Governor Rockefeller tried a new role today in the Republican political cast -- that of a hard-hitting campaigner for party candidates outside New York. The Governor flew into Pennsylvania for an intensive ten-hour swing through the Seventeenth Congressional District, eight counties in the north-central section of the state.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 20 -- National party ranks were in confusion and disarray in Parliament today following a seeming division in the Cabinet on the future application of apartheid policies.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday.

Trading in commodity futures was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York Exchanges. For most commodities prices drifted aimlessly and closed mixed. Copper, cotton-seed oil and eggs rose; zinc was unchanged, and price movements in potatoes, rubber, sugar, soybean, oil and cocoa were mixed.
The Catholic Teachers Association of the Diocese of Brooklyn has renewed a charge of anti-Catholic bias against The Phoenix, the student newspaper of Queens College.
The State Department of Education, after a long investigation, has directed the Graduate School of Education of Yeshiva University to overhaul its doctoral program.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- The prospect that college presidents would have to spend most of their time in fund raising, much of it door-to-door, was criticized here today by leading Roman Catholic educators.
LONDON, April 20 -- Continuing fears of a credit squeeze again kept buyers out of the stock market here today and prices receded on a wide front.

HICKORY, N.C., April 20 (AP) -- Four Michigan residents were killed near the Hickory Airport today after their small private plane collided with a Piedmont airliner and crashed. Both planes were making landing approaches.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Company has ended its fight against one-way traffic operation on Third and Lexington Avenues, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
Disappointment over the failure of American Telephone and Telegraph to increase its Dividend yesterday brought the sharpest break in New York Stock Exchange prices since March 3.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 20 -- An armed rebellion against the Leftist coalition Government of President Romulo Betancourt broke out today in the western state of Tachira, but quick action by loyal troops confined the revolt to the city of San Cristobal.
NEWARK, April 20 -- A radical change has taken place in the pattern of poliomyelitis infection throughout the country, a Government scientist reported here today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution applauded a resolution today that would line them up solidly behind the House Committee on un-American Activities in defense of the controversial Air Force's reserve training manual.
The ninth annual Mother's Day luncheon and fashion show will be held May 4 in the Sheraton-East for the benefit of the Talbot Perkins Adoption Service.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro's former revolutionary companions are beginning to plot against him in this provincial capital while others are going into the hills to form guerrilla bands to fight his regime.

Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that reporters had misquoted him Monday in Ithaca, N.Y., when they wrote that he said he "wouldn't be surprised" if Communists were behind the sit-in demonstrations in the South.

LONDON, April 20 -- After two and a half years of study the Channel Tunnel Study Group has recommended the construction of three parallel tunnels between Britain and France. Two tubes would be for railway traffic and one, between them, would be a service tunnel.
CABIN CREEK, W. Va., April 20 -- If bobby-soxers could vote, Senator John F. Kennedy would sweep the southern West Virginia coal-field regions, where his political stock with adults is low.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that the problem of land distribution in Latin America should have the "urgent attention" of the Organization of American States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your April 8 editorial "The Chilean Elections" you hailed the results of the municipal elections, calling them most heartening and a renewed mandate for the economic program of President Alessandri, all the more admirable when it is considered that the economic stabilization plan means temporary economic sacrifice for the people.
ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Rockefeller set into motion today a "bold new program" for meeting the "urgent housing needs" of the state's middle-income families.

Electric power production fell in the week ended last Saturday, the fifth consecutive drop, to 13,263,000,000 kilowatt-hours, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the preceding week the figure was 13,494,000,000 kilowatt-hours, and a year ago output was 12,609,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
"The conscientious breeder is always chasing rainbows," Marie J. Leary of Greenwich, Conn., told the monthly meeting of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club at Luchow's Restaurant yesterday.

Manuel Ycaza wrapped up his local affairs with eclat at Aqueduct yesterday. The young jockey from Panama starts a ten-day suspension today and intends to spend the time in his hometown of Panama City.
A series of special children's shows based on the classics will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System next season.

BOZEMAN, Mont., April 20 (UPI) -- Gene Fullmer battled fifteen brutal rounds to a draw tonight with Joey Giardello and retained the National Boxing Association version of the work middleweight championship.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- The report of todays livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE baby who starts walking late, according to Dr. Benjamin Kauth, director of the American Foot Care Institute, often causes "mother to be openly worried, father to be quietly concerned and grandmother to be plain frantic."

The head of the Seafarers International Union told President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic yesterday that the picketing of an Egyptian ship here was a trade union action based on Cairo's denial of freedom of the seas to many United States ship.
Ex-President Harry S. Truman gave ex-President Arthur Hockstader the once-over last evening and then shook hands with him warmly backstage at the Morosco Theatre.
The consumer is often disturbed by the package in which he receives his purchases.
BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP) -- A single by Billy Gardner gave an 8-7 victory to the Washington Senators over Baltimore tonight.
Pierre Etchebaster, the retired world open court tennis champion, made one of his few tournament appearances yesterday in the United States open doubles championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
BOSTON, April 20 -- The Yankees dropped to the .500 mark today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- James J. Wadsworth, chief United States negotiator at the nuclear talks in Geneva, expressed doubt today that an agreement on an atomic test ban could be achieved at next month's summit meeting.
Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon pledged last night that the Western powers would not allow West Berlin to be "sold into slavery" at next month's summit conference.
ALBANY, April 20 -- A group of bills affecting drivers in the state led a list of minor measures signed by Governor Rockefeller today.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 20 -- A few years after Cornell University opened in 1868 a woman applied for admission to the then all-male student body.

Interest centered on the Cuban situation at the annual meeting yesterday of the American Sugar Refining Company at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel. American Sugar has substantial holdings on the island through subsidiaries.
GENEVA, April 20 -- Western diplomats, on instructions from their foreign ministers, are working on a long-shot proposal to ease the disarmament deadlock.
PARIS, April 20 -- A draft convention for forming a new Atlantic economic organization to stimulate and coordinate Western economic growth and development aid was published here today.

The City Housing Authority yesterday put 125 deteriorating tenements in its new program to seize and refurbish buildings in which thousands of desperately poor families are packed into squalid single rooms.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Army and Air Force leadeirs told Congress today that they had an "immediate and critical" need for more improved types of transport planes to meet possible war requirements.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make-up and printing was won today by The Emporia (Kan.) Gazette.

"THE WATERS OF KRONOS," by Conrad Richter, is a strange, compelling, felicitously written story of a man's return to his own past. Anyone who has ever toyed with that idea will find here an imaginative view of the difference between trying to carry it out and being content with the when-I-was-young form of conventional anecdotage.
DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company reported today first-quarter earnings of $143,100,000, a rise of more than $8,000,000 from the 1959 level.
SEOUL, Korea, April 20 (Reuters) -- Following, in an official translation, is the text of a statement today by President Syngman Rhee:

LIKE the daring young man on the flying trapeze, Frank Lane loves to take chance. If, through some oversight, the Indians fail to win the pennant this year, vengeful Cleveland fans will cut loose his safety net and let him land on his concrete head. Then they'll pick him up, dust him off and chase him clear out of town.
MILWAUKEE, April 20 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, paced by the hitting of Roy McMillan, pushed across five runs in the tenth inning today and downed the Milwaukee Braves, 10 -- 5.
The bond market functioned with assurance yesterday for the first time this week, especially in the Treasury securities section.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., had the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 30, according to the annual report yesterday of Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, and Ralph Lazarus, president.
Allowable oil production in Texas for May was slashed to the lowest point in almost two years by the Texas Railroad Commission yesterday.
A tie-up of the major piers in the Port of New York was called yesterday for 7 A.M. today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 20 -- A reorganization of the Outlet Company, owners of Rhode Island's largest department store and radio station WJAR and television station WJAR-TV, was effected today. Stockholders at a meeting enlarged the board, which in turn named Joseph S. Sinclair president.

Mutual savings banks were first organized in this country in 1816 to give persons with small incomes a place to keep their funds. The names of some of the institutions attest to that: the Emigrant, the Seamen's, the Hibernia, the People's.
NEW YORK may be breeding a race of apartment-conditioned families who cannot live in houses.

Proceeds from a public auction of fifty paintings and sculptures at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, next Wednesday will benefit the Thirtieth Anniversary Fund-Raising Drive for the Museum of Modern Art.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- The grain futures market mustered a few firm spots today, but it was mostly steady to weak with rye and soybeans losing a cent or more on some contracts.

As long as Dr. Willard Uphaus remains in jail, the conscience of many Americans will rest uneasily. This 69-year-old "Christian pacifist" was sentenced last December to a year's imprisonment for contempt of court. He had refused to disclose to New Hampshire's Attorney General, an ultra-zealous un-American-activities investigator, the names of guests at a "World Fellowship" summer-conference center.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A campaign to eliminate bias from employment in Government construction slowed down today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- The sea research ship Explorer concluded today a seventy-nine-day, 8,000-mile voyage that produced evidence of mineral treasure off the west coast of Central America and an unsuspected "drowned atoll" in the Caribbean.
LOS ANGELES, April 20 -- The possible saving of "thousands" of years in one key line of atomic research is envisioned by leading scientists who are planning underground atomic explosions.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- Paul Seymour was named coach of the St. Louis Hawks tonight, succeeding Ed Macauley.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20. -- On the basis of its own long experience in maintaining an international arbitration center for business disputes, the International Chamber of Commerce today supported proposals for parallel machinery under United Nations auspices.
Philadelphia borrowed $29,260,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewerage, airport and other public improvements.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter will give Senators an up-to-the-minute report on developments in South Korea tomorrow morning, it was reliably reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today brought court action against Equity Corporation, a non-diversified, closedend investment trust, to force it to divest itself Of two subsidiaries.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Attorney General William P. Rogers on the new civil rights legislation:

LONDON, April 21 -- Soviet scientists have discovered a path into outer space that future space ships will be able to use to escape a dangerous radiation zone, the Soviet press agency Tass reported tonight.

Kim Stanley has been set to star in the name role of "Taffy." In Anna Marie Barlow's multiple-scene drama. Miss Stanley will undertake two characterizations. She will portray a woman of 32, who returns to her Louisiana home and finds herself confronted with the problems that troubled her as a girl of 16
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House adopted Senate amendments to the civil rights bill today and sent the measure to the President:

Four pianists and a tenor will make their Lewisohn Stadium debuts in the summer. Lorin Hollander, David Bar-Illan, John Browning and Renato Premezzi are the pianists and Giuseppe Di Stefano ia the tenor.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following are the texts of the speeches given today before the American Society of Newspaper Editors by two Democratic contenders for the Presidential nomination -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri -- and the prepared text of a third contender, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota:
ROBERT PRESTON scored impressively last night in "Years Ago," Ruth Gordon's play about her girlhood decision to follow the theatre forty-seven years ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- The academic and bureaucratic features of the architectural profession were gently derided today by C. Northcote Parkinson, the British humorist.
DALLAS, April 21 (AP) -- Fay Crocker, Wiffi Smith and Jo Ann Prentice tied for the first-round lead in the $10,000 Dallas open golf tournament today with 2-under-par 69's.

Some thirty-five subway passengers suffering from shock and smoke poisoning were taken to the hospital early today after their train was stalled near a smoky fire in the East Side IRT line 1,000 feet south of Astor Place.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President de Gaulle comes to Washington tomorrow to consult with President Eisenhower in the last round of Western preparations for next month's summit conference.

TURIN, Italy, April 21 -- The editors of the two British bridge magazines -- Capt. Ewart Kempson of Bridge Magazine and The London Star and Terence Reese of British Bridge World and The London Observer -- are unremitting rivals in professional life, but lately they have been allied in a campaign against American bidding methods.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 22 -- President Syngman Rhee was reported today to have summoned some elder statesmen to the Presidential Palace for a conference on the crisis precipitated by Tuesday's mas uprising in Seoul and elsewhere.
Three young instrumentalists put together a pleasant and accomplished program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
The T-shirted members of the Kips Bay Boys Club chorus sang to a full house last night in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on the occasion of the eighth annual Kips Bay Dinner Dance.

The Appellate Division up-held the subpoena powers of the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York yesterday, ruling that it could inspect the records of Manhattan Water Works, Inc.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- May wheat and soybeans were fairly broad swingers today on the Board of Trade, one stopping just short of the season's high and the other only a fraction from the season's low.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following is the text of the Civil Rights Act of 1960, as sent to the President today :
Net earnings of the Corn Products Company in the first quarter increased about 14 per cent, to $8,738,213, or 80 cents a shore on 10,909,056 common

A new schedule of Saturday afternoon radio programs will be carried on WCBS starting tomorrow. The new shows, some of which replace the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts that ended for the season last week, include the following recorded musical programs:

There was a rather wheezy and somewhat peevish "zpee, zpee, zpee" overhead suddenly in The Ramble in Central Park yesterday morning. It was both golden music and sudden drama for sixty-five bird-watchers.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 -- India has protested to the Chinese Communist Embassy here against "interference" with an Indian sentry at the Chinese trade agency in Kalimpong, northeastern India. The Embassy has lodged a counter-protest with India.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- In his bold and eloquent speech to the American Newspaper Editors today Senator John F. Kennedy made several extremely useful and one or two very odd statements.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Three correspondents told the American Society of Newspaper Editors today that the United States should not invoke sanctions -- economic or military -- against the Cuban Government of Dr. Fidel Castro.

New York bookmakers provide the bulk of the revenue of a Delaware telephone service that does a $500,000-a-year business providing on-the-spot results from race tracks, tine State Investigation Commission was told yesterday.

BOZEMAN, Mont., April 21 (UPI) -- The National Boxing Associations middleweight champion, Gene Fullmer, left no doubt today that a rematch with Joey Giardello was far down on his list of future projects.
LONDON, April 21 -- The downward slide in equity prices continued in the stock market here today. The sentiment was affected by yesterday's fall on Wall Street.

Morse G. Dial, chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, reported yesterday record first-quarter sales and earnings. But, he told the annual meeting, results for the second quarter and first half may not equal the 1959 levels, reflecting a general "leveling out" in the economy.
YESTERDAY (April 21, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Returned to Washington from Augusta (Ga.) vacation. THE SENATE Held routine session. Adjourned at 3:23 P.M. until noon Monday.
MILWAUKEE, April 21 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored twice in the seventh inning today and blanked Cincinnati, 2 -- 0. Carl Willey mastered the Reds with a brilliant four-hitter.

London is the source of a hard-to-believe development affecting international trade and credit. At the same time that the British Council of Bondholdera was declaring that Communist Czechoslovakia had "destroyed" its credit, officials of the British and Czechoslovak Governments signed a new agreement on trade quotas.

Opportunities for Jews in the country's top economic positions have been "drastically limited compared with their Christian fellow students of equivalent scholastic levels," the executive head of the American Jewish Committee said yesterday.

Wage increases and other improvements were granted yesterday to 700 nonprofessional employes of University Hospital in a letter sent by New York University to Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union.
BRASILIA, April 21 -- Brazil inaugurated her new capital today in the heartland of the nation.
BERLIN, April 21 -- A thick queue of people, ill at ease in their Sunday-best clothes, shuffied impatiently in the spring sunshine at the Marienfelde refugee reception center this morning.

Pierre Etchebaster, the retired world open court tennis champion, and Frederick S. Moseley, an amateur, were beaten in the United States open doubles championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 21 -- The American Association of Advertising Agencies (4A's) elected Harry Harding as its new chairman today. Mr. Harding is an executive vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc.
The Appellate Division reinstated yesterday the indictment against Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
Somewhat tardily, New York's baseball season will have its official opening today when Casey Stengel sends his Yankees against the Baltimore Orioles at 2 o'clock.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 21 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson definitely indicated today that he would accept the Democratic nomination for President.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, in a massive assault on the religious issue in politics, today told a convention of newspaper editors:...
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The American press was sharply criticized tonight by two women authors for contributing to a debasement of public taste.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today an unusually broad investigation of the plight of Capital Airlines, including the possibility of breaking it up, merging it with another, or reconstructing it.

AN hour-long documentary account of Dr. Thomas Dooley's encounter with cancer -- his thoughts before the extent of the disease was known, the actual surgical operation on his chest wall and the resumption of his career -- was presented last night on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2.

The Louisville and Nashville Railroad sold $7,980,000 of fifteen-year equipment trust certificates yesterday to investment bankers led by Salomon Bios. Hutzler, who bid 98.4487 for certificates bearing 4 1/2 per cent interest coupons.

MADISON, N.J., April 21 -- Dr. George J. Fisher, deputy chief scout executive of the Boy Scouts of America from 1919 to 1943, died last night at the Royal Oak Nursing Home here after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Father Thurston Davis in his letter in The Times of April 13 does not actually deny a single fact contained in my letter published March 31, summarizing the situation respecting religious, literary and political censorship in Spain.
Angry charges -- and denials of racial discrimination in automobile, liability insurance punctuated a five-hour hearing on the subject here yesterday.
Milady and News of Finance It is in some ways encouraging that, these days, while one hand rocks the cradle the other may be holding the morning paper's financial pages.

That a labor dispute involving only ninety clerical workers who have nothing whatever to do with the loading of ships resulted in the paralysis of longshore operations in the entire Port of New York is as outrageous as it is bizarre. It should never have happened, and no such thing should ever happen again. Primary blame clearly rests on Local 153 of the Office Employes Union, which precipitated all the trouble.

Domination of the world by the "white, aryan group" is finished, Mrs. Sophia Yarnall Jacobs, retiring president of the New York chapter of the National Urban League, told a luncheon gathering of 480 members yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, April 21 (AP) -- Lionel Hebert of Lafayette, La., and three professionals who have known little success on the golfing tour clipped five strokes from par today and shared the first-round lead in the $27,000 Greater New Orleans open.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that it would consolidate its pilot-training program. It will close civilian contract schools and change the use of several bases to fit into the new instruction system.

The Appellate Division in a unanimous decision has reinstated the indictment against Hulan E. Jack, Borough President of Manhattan, which charged conspiracy to obstruct justice and violation of the City Charter. It thus overturned dismissal of the indictment and, in a sense, supported the view of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who had been "astounded" by General Sessions Judge Gerald P. Culkin's opinion finding the indictment faulty.
LONDON, April 21 -- The critics were lavish in their praise of Frank Loesser's "The Most Happy Fella" and the first-night audience at the Coliseum tonight wanted more -- even after three hours.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 21 -- Bill Douglas, a senior from Abington, Pa., pitched a no-hitter today as Princeton's baseball team scored an 8-0 victory over previously unbeaten Manhattan.

A SMALL and interesting booklet on the drinking and service of wines has just been published by the National Committee for the Wines of France. Titled simply "French Wines," it is authored by Fernande Garvin and is available for the asking.
A Federal Jury began deliberating the Government's income tax case against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. at 1 P.M. yesterday and nine hours later reported it was "dead-locked" on a verdict.

The Weavers Club, Inc., a luncheon group for members of the textile industry, has leased a floor in 111 West Fortieth Street, overlooking Bryant Park, and will occupy it in August. The Durand Taylor Company negotiated the lease, which is for twenty years with renewal options.
BOSTON, April 21 -- It took the Yankees just 2 hours 23 minutes to put themselves back in business today.

THE long and short of summer ganing is well in hand at Elizabeth Arden. The new lingerie collection, shown to the press this week, goes from brief, bloomer pajamas, with the innocent guile of lollipops to svelte, floor-length robes and culottes suitable for dining at home.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Congress sent to the White House today the Civil Rights Act of 1960.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 19 points (95 cents a bale) up yesterday. The old July contract showed the most strength.

National Lead Co. Earnings of National Lead Company for the first quarter rose to $12,071,897, or 99 cents a share, from $11,745,684 and 96 cents last year, it was announced at the annual meeting in Sayreville, N.J. Sales climbed to $132,555,151 from $122,128,289.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Rail and truck freight loadings last week were below levels of last year. Rails were well above -- and trucks were well below -- figures for the preceding week of this year.

ARCHIE MOORE has always had such an affinity for the dramatic that he can slip into an acting role as easily as he can slip into a pair of boxing gloves. The ageless wonder of the ring did precisely what every pugilistic expert expected he would do yesterday at a preview of the movie, "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn." He stole the show, Natch.

The name of the President of France, who arrives in Washington today, has a legendary ring. In English it would be "Charles of Gaul.' One would not, because of his name, think of Charles de Gaulle in terms of Julius Caesar except that it was Caesar, in his eight glorious campaigns, who defined the frontiers of Gaul between the ocean and the Rhine.
Time, Inc., publisher of six magazines, changed its board chairman and president yesterday in a major shift involving fifteen top executives.

THE Cote d'Azur is no further away than Bergdorf Goodman. With the arrival of the new Tiktiner collection from Nice, the third floor Country and Casual Shop is splashed with bright Mediterranean color geared to casual summer living.

GENEVA, April 21 -- The West presented today its first rough, sketch of the machinery needed to check on any agreement to cut down the armed forces of the United States and the Soviet Union. The Russian reaction was politely icy.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The United States Government was reliably reported today to be urging President Syngman Rhee of South Korea to undertake a broad range of political reforms, including a new election for the Vice Presidency.
Post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples will attend the April Ball next Friday at the Sheraton-East.
Plans to double production of color television sets were announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.
BALDWIN, L.I., April 21 -- A citizens' committee to advise the School Board will be established in this school district.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Treasury is highly likely to try out its new refunding method when it announces a $6,000,000,000 financing next week.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee refused today to clear for a floor vote a $251,000,000 area redevelopment bill.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that the prime objective of the Western powers at the summit meeting would be to discover whether the Soviet Union, sincerely wished to ease tensions.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- After complicated, divergent and occasionally heated discussions of the status of the artist in yesterday's meeting of the Congress of Artists and Writers, Naum Gabo drew laughter when he concluded:
Former Gov. Charles Poletti urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to approve a flat rate of $250 a month to be paid for nursing home patients sent by the Welfare Department.
A dudgeon or angry young painters and an umbrage of angry older painters have opened attacks against two prominent museums of contemporary art.

Members of Actors Equity met yesterday with representatives of various youth groups to discuss the possibilities of a co-operative program for developing cultural activities in the city's underprivileged areas.
SPRING is the time for lamb, but only if the food budget can bear a little stretching. Right on cue, the new crop is available, but prices are high.
Mayor Wagner is going upstate tomorrow to meet ten Democratic county chairmen, most of whom are strongly supporting Senator John F. Kennedy for President.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 21 -- Connecticut's policy of summarily suspending the licenses of convicted speeders was contested in court today for the first time.
A nine-hour waterfront walkout here yesterday penalized the nation's busiest port at the rate of $100,000 an hour.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Secretary of Defense said today that recent cutbacks in air defense programs had been based chiefly on information that the Soviet bomber threat was not growing so rapidly as originally believed.

Loans to business at fifteen large New York City banks declined $77,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. That compared with a decline of $54,000,000 in the 1959 week.
GENEVA, Switzerland, April 21 (Reuters) -- Disagreements were reported today among delegates seeking a twelve-mile limit on territorial waters at the eighty-eight-nation sea law conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 21 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will go to London May 12 to begin talks there with South African authorities over their policy of racial segregation, it was reliably reported here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Exactly twenty-five years ago, on April 20, 1935, the House of Representatives passed the bill which later that year became the Social Security Act. When that law's constitutionality was upheld by the Supreme Court of the United States, Justice Cardozo declared:

The approach of another pleasure-boat season has prompted skippers to think of new safety devices for their cruisers. The coming National Safe Boating Week in early summer gives renewed importance to anything that can, prevent explosions, fires, tragedies.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 21 (Reuters) -- The America's Cup, symbol of international yachting supremacy, moved nearer to Australia today in the eyes of this country's confident yachtsmen.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Liberal and labor spokesmen have privately expressed concern to the competing Presidential candidates in West Virginia that their contest there might cripple the liberal forces in the Democratic party.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A dilemma was posed for the Eisenhower Administration today by scientific testimony that the inspection system for an atomic test ban agreement would not work as planned.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., April 21 -- The principal of an elementary school has submitted his resignation to the school board here in the midst of an educational crisis that has split the community.
CHICAGO, April 21 (UPI) -- Ted Kluszewski singled home the winning run in the eleventh inning today as the Chicago White Sox scored a 6-5 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
KYOTO, Japan, April 21 -- In a number of New York movie theatres that specialize in foreign films coffee is served. When you attend the Miyako Okori, or Cherry Dance, here you get tea.

SCOTTSBLUFF, Neb., April 21 -- Terry Carpenter, who created "Joe Smith" at the Republican Convention in 1956, plans to nominate Governor Rockefeller for President at the convention in Chicago July 25.

PASADENA, Calif., April 21 (AP) -- William Howard Taft, 38 years old, an executive of the Aerojet-General Corporation, described as a distant relative of the United States President, was found bludgeoned to death in his bed today.

Volume fell and the market narrowed but prices rose on the New York Stock Exchange yeserday. Motors, electronics and business machines led the small rally that developed in the final ninety minutes of trading.
The Air Force Chief of Staff replied, "Not so!" yesterday to the charge by the former head of the Army's missile program that the nation is risking disaster by pursuing a philosophy of "overkill."

TRANSFORMING a rented summer house into a comfortable home need not entail great expense or expenditure of energy. Here are ten suggestions that, landlord permitting, may help to give a fresh, cool look to the decor.

ALICIA ALONSO last night made her first appearance of the season as guest artist with the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House in "Giselle." She was not scheduled for the role until next week, but she stepped in for an extra performance to replace that other guest artist, Alicia Markova, who is ill in London.

WASHINGTON. April 21 (UPI) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield urged Congress today to approve President Eisenhower's requests for a postal rate increase to meet what he called the "urgent national necessity" of reducing postal deficits.

Financial problems are nothing new for Capital Airlines, Inc. But the present demand of the company's British creditors that it get up the $34,000,000 it owes for a fleet of sixty Viscount turbo-prop planes "or else" is a drast innovation in the company history.
WASHINGTON, April 21 The State Department said today that the picketing of the Egyptian ship Cleopatra by seamen in New York was "embarrassing" the conduct of United States foreign relations.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 21 -- The revolt against the Government of President Romulo Betancourt ended today with the surrender of Fort Bolivar, in San Cristobal near the Colombian border.
The Democratic and Republican Presidential nominees will be invited to appear "side by side" on a series of pre-election television programs and answer questions by reporters.
Magistrate Evelyn Richman yesterday told Jacob Brown-stein, a lawyer before her as a defendant, that "one time when a case came up before me you came into my chambers to try to fix a case."

NEW HAVEN, April 21 (AP) -- Three religious leaders, two Protestants and a Roman Catholic, agreed today that a movement for world Christian unity might be threatened by controversy over the religion of Senator John F. Kennedy.

Activity in United States Government securities slackened yesterday as the nation's investment marketplace began to get ready for the next Treasury financing -- a $6,000,000,000 refunding for which terms are expected to be made known next week.

Mayor Wagner's proposal to increase tha take-home pay of 105,000 city employes by having the city pay part of their contributions to pension systems was denounced yesterday by leading business and civic organizations.
A 1905 Pierce Arrow is attracting almost as much attention at the fourth International Automobile Show as its collateral descendants of 1960.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 21 -- Smart Set became the first horse to win five straight races at Roosevelt Raceway this season by taking the feature tonight.

After ten months of negotiations, which often had cloakand-dagger aspects, Ingemar Johansson of Sweden and Floyd Patterson of New York yesterday signed for their world heavyweight championship return bout.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. indicated today that the United States did not regard two nuclear explosions as qualification for French admission to the "nuclear club."
HAVANA, April 20 -- The Cuban Government is moving thousands of city dwellers from miserable slums to comfortable, modern homes.

AMERICAN hunters who are used to bagging only two grouse or none at all in a day of hard walking should talk with Jack Walsh of Mamaroneck, a contractor who accepted a casual invitation to a partridge shoot in Spain.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- George R. Shoals, managing editor of The Rochester (N.Y.) Democrat and Chronicle, died tonight of a heart attack in Washington Hospital Center. He was 56 years old.
PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- Consumption of aluminum during 1960 in this country will be 10 per cent higher than last
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- Earl C. Corey, a former official of the Agriculture Department, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The House authorized today foreign aid expenditures of up to $4,038,500,000 during the fiscal year starting July 1. This was $136,500,000 below the spending ceiling sought by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare ended lengthy conferences today with national organizations interested in medical care of the aged.

The president of the Fire Officers Association said yesterday he had received assurances that Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. would support the union's efforts to obtain overtime pay for extra duty.

DURING his flamboyant career as the boy scourge of American Communists, Roy Marcus Cohn drove the opinionated to heights and depths of verbal extravagance. "There is only one man the Communists hate more than Roy Cohn and that is J. Edgar Hoover," said Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Cohn's friend and mentor, in 1953.
Robert Moses described New York last night as a town that was modest and self-effacing about its virtues, but that ballyhooed its faults and problems.

Copper futures moved sharply upward on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Quotations rose 15 to 45 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in moderately active trading of 391 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot).
LONDON, April 21 -- An agreement to disagree about West Berlin's future now appears to British diplomats as a likely outcome of discussions on this topic at the summit conference in May.

Following is the text of the Appellate Division's unanimous decision yesterday reinstating the indictment against Borough President Hulan E. Jack on one count of conspiracy and three counts of accepting illegal gratuities:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- There are times when the relationship between movies and television here is that of two pythons, mouth - to - tail, each trying to devour the other.
Specialists in New York have turned to Africa in the search for ways to fight cancer more effectively a report yesterday indicated.
Yeshiva University said yesterday that it had already taken steps, and would take others, to correct weaknesses in the Graduate School of Education, which has come under criticism by tin state.

CARACAS, April 21 -- A contract for a foreign loan of $200,000,000 to Venezuela was officially signed today on behalf of the Venezuelan Government by Dr. Jose Antonio Mayobre, Minister of Finance. The loan has already been approved by the Venezuelan Congress and signed by President Betancourt.

Staretta, owned by Leonard P. Sasso, and Genteel Maid of the Circle M Farm were the main winners at Aqueduct yesterday. Each took a division of the feature event, the Wading River Purse for 3-year-old fillies.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 21 -- Foreign Minister Eric H. Louw said today he had instructed the South African Ambassador in Washington to exert pressure on sponsors of a television reporter, Chet Huntley, to "calm down" Mr. Huntley's comments on the South African racial crisis.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 21 (AP) -- Hudson County detectives said today that a woman had bought a 2-year-old boy for $45 and that she had resold him for $2,100.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., April 21 -- The Garden State Women's Golf Association's opening tournament of the season resulted in a tie today on the wind-swept lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club today.
The third annual Lenox Hill Hospital dinner dance was given last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court upheld today the convictions of four men, including two former members of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, of conspiracy to defraud the commission of $19,500,000.
The arrangement announced on Wednesday for one-way traffic on Third and Lexington Avenues was attacked as "phony" by the Transport Workers Union yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A top defense official told the Daughters of the American Revolution convention tonight that "in the coldest calculation of our own self interest" military aid "has been a wise and profitable venture."
The Customs Bureau auctioned, cut and polished gem diamonds for $1,061,580 yesterday after rejecting an offer at the start of the sale for $1,500,000. The diamonds had been appraised at $956,000.
GENEVA, April 21 -- The Soviet Union offered today to join in setting up the trans-Atlantic economic organization planned by the West.

During the smash-through of Hitler's army in Yugoslavia, a German corporal and three members of his squad ambushed a van they found to be filled with solid gold ingots. The gold vanished and those who knew of it kept silent.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, and a fifty-man task force of faculty and adminstrative staff members, undertook here today to give Chicago area alumni a first-hand report on what the university is doing in teaching and research.

Convinced that Sino-Soviet imperialism will continue to drive for world domination irrespective of the outcome of next month's summit meeting, the Western nations are stepping up efforts to supplement their military power with a new economic arm to meet the Communist economic challenge.

Net income of Republic Steel Corporation for the first quarter climbed to $28,239,545, or $1.80 a share, from $26,844,585 and $1.71 last year, the company disclosed yesterday. Sales of the nation's third largest steel company rose to $375,578,000 from $322,657,000.

Former President Harry S. Truman, who has frequently described his decision to send American troops to South Korea as his most challenging one, said yesterday he was "very sorry indeed" to read of the recent violence and bloodshed there.
PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates wallopad the Philadelphia Phillies, 11-5, tonight with fifteen 'hits that included three home runs.

The American Federation of Musicians announced another victory yesterday in its effort to promote mergers of Negro and white locals. Herman Kenin, president of the parent union, said its racially segregated locals in Denver had agreed to amalgamate their memberships and property rights in "equal co-partnership."
BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP) -- Dan Dobbek hit a three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning as the Washington Senators scored a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 18 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham will return to Madison Square Garden on Oct. 7 for a three-day evangelistic campaign aimed specifically at New York's Spanish-speaking residents.
Spring may be bursting out all over but at least in the Ramble in Central Park, man's uncollected litter is giving it tough competition.
Although the program was short, the progress of a composer was traced yesterday at a late afternoon concert in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Former President Harry S. Truman met yesterday with former Mayor William O'Dwyer, but both said it was only a courtesy call. Mr. Truman and Mr. O'Dwyer conferred for about ten minutes in the former President's suite in the Carlyle Hotel, and then went to the lobby to pose for pictures.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan suspended himself from office yesterday for the second time in ninety days.

DENVER, Colo., April 23 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson tossed his Texas hat into the West beyond Fort Worth today. He also added "geography" and "distances from Wall Street" to religion as unfair criteria in the choice of candidates for public office.

CAIRO, April 22 (Reuters) -- A boycott will be clamped on United States ships in all Arab ports if picketing of an Arab liner in New York is not stopped within a week, leaders of labor unions throughout the Arab world threatened tonight.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 (AP) -- C.V. Whitney's Tompion lived up to his role as the favorite for the May 7 Kentucky Derby when he defeated seven other Derby eligibles in the seven - furlong Forerunner Purse at Keeneland today.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt presided over a meeting here yesterday to draw up recommendations for a civil rights plank in the platform of the Democratic National Convention.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 22 (AP) -- The Air Force successfully fired an Atlas missile from a new launching complex today. It then declared the set-up operational.

LONDON, April 22 -- Most sec- tions of the stock market here finished the twenty-one-day account period on a disappointing note. A batch of good company results plus the recovery on Wall Street yesterday brought in a few buyers in early dealings but this soon p tered out.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Two top officials of Princeton University said today that the aim of education must be to teach man to think for himself. They described some of the fallacies and lesser goals that arise to cloud that basic objective.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Congressional committee reached the general conclusion today that it would not be possible in the next several years to develop a reliable system for detecting underground explosions the size of the Hiroshima atomic bomb.

George Tabori, whose play ''Brouhaha" opens at the 175 East Broadway Theatre on Tuesday, was saying the other day that generally it would be "a great mistake to write a play for an actress or an actor."
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals battered six Los Angeles pitchers for fifteen hits tonight and an 11-7 triumph. It was the Cards' second straight victory after five losses.

THE New York Public Library is a good place to go for suggestions on what to serve for supper or to find the recipe for almost any kind of dish. Each of the eighty branches has a good selection of cookbooks, most in English, some in foreign languages.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Government today to stop improvising its world leadership to meet the threats to freedom. The challenge to be met, the New York Governor said, demands a bold new approach, one that can give all the world the same tangible hope for the realization of freedom that our forefathers gave to a single nation two centuries ago.
The winning entry in the fourth annual Maritime Industry Poster Contest will go on display over the country on the sides of mail trucks and in post offices for two weeks beginning May 16.
ATLANTA, April 22 -- Inquiries into the segregation of Negroes at polling places in three Georgia counties have been conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 22 -- The killers of Paul-Emile Chabert, a United Nations primary education specialist, were reported today to have acted in the belief that he was an American. He was a Frenchman.

The Borg-Warner Corporation in the first quarter of this year realized a 7.1 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 8.2 per cent over those of last year. The improved results were achieved despite cancellations and deferred delivery by many customers when business that was over-optimistically forecast at the beginning of the year did not materialize, stockholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.

HAVANA, Saturday, April 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro, in a talk during the night, flatly accused the United States of planning an act of aggression against Cuba and more specifically of stimulating a counter-revolution here to overthrow his regime. He charged the United States with fascist policies in its treatment of Cuba.

MIAMI BEACH, April 22 (AP) -- Len Matthews of Philadelphia and Doug Vaillant, a 20-year-old Cuban, fought to a ten-round draw tonight. Two of the three officials called it even and the third gave it to Vaillant.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Newspaper editors were urged today to join the radio and television industry in an effort to demolish Government barriers to the obtaining of information.

"GOLK,"* by Richard G. Stern, is a lightly scribbled spoof of the television world. You will find it both thoughtful and enjoyable. For 'Mr. Stern has cast his novel in an offhand, slapdash style to entertain you while he advances his ideas on such matters as loyalty, credulousness and vainglory.

ANYONE who loves antique pewter should make a dash for Bloomingdale's Men's Boutique on the ground floor near the Third Avenue entrance. Just unwrapped after their trip from England are such unusual one-of-a-kind pieces as a pewter wine can ($75), a snail-shaped spoon warmer ($29.50) and an ice bucket ($85) in the shape of a Welsh hat.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- A crusade is needed to free Roman Catholic education from mediocrity and conformity and produce more scholars, the fifty-seventh annual convention of the National Catholic Educational Association was told today.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Washington welcomed President de Gaulle with a flourish today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Administration turned down today a Democratic compromise to give the nation's aged an option between higher cash benefits or hospitalization in- surance under the Social Security program.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it would continue to use the subway equipment involved in a fire that sent forty-one persons to the hospital earlier in the day.

Prof. George J. Keller is looking for a man who wants to buy $35,000 worth of trouble for only $15,000. The profressor has had enough of danger-set-to-music and is ready to sell his wild-animal circus act. He wants to get out of the cage and back to the classroom.
Only two big ifs stand between the new American Football League and the televising of its Sunday games next season on the American Broadcasting Company network.

A major propaganda campaign in the Soviet Union reached its climax yesterday when that country celebrated the ninetieth anniversary of Lenin's birth. No mere mortal could have all the virtues which have been attributed to the founder of the Soviet state in this campaign.

HONG KONG, April 22 -- Communist China has bluntly declared its opposition to any agreements that "tie the hands" of the Communist bloc. This was interpreted as an allusion to the possibility of accords at the summit conference in Paris next month.
Contrary to general belief baseball enthusiasm in New York hasn't died. Neither have the Yankees.

Members of the Royal Thames Yacht Club of England notified the New York Yacht Club yesterday that they were interested in an America's Cup series in 1962. The message came in the wake of an Australian challenge announced Wednesday.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, April 23 -- President Syngman Rhee was authoritatively said today to have agreed to a Government reorganization and the establishment of a new system of "Cabinet responsibility" in which the President's office would become a more or less ceremonial position.
A rapid increase in mental and emotional problems in many countries was reported here yesterday by Dr. John R. Rees, a London psychiatrist and director of the World Federation for Mental Health.

In his spirited and eloquent address to the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington Senator Kennedy has looked squarely at the religious issue and appealed to the American people to take it out of the Presidential campaign. Furthermore, he has criticized the press for magnifying this issue, promoting it and thereby exacerbating it, with especial reference to the recent Wisconsin and to the current West Virginia primary.
WELLESLEY, Mass., April 22 -- Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, canvassing in a Wellesley College fund-raising campaign, has found that charity begins at home.

KANSAS CITY, April 22 (AP) -- Norm Siebern and Bob Cerv hit consecutive home runs today and started the Kansas City Athletics toward a 4-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians in this city's American League opener.
The election of Octave Blake, Haim Beyer and John T. Romano as directors of the Federal Pacific Electric Company was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Marion A. Wright, vice president of the Southern Regional Council, assailed pupil-assignment laws today. He called them "legalistic horseplay" to keep Negro children out of white schools.

TURIN, Italy, April 22 -- The first wholly international tournament in contract bridge begins here tomorrow with twenty-five countries entered, including four United States teams and one Canadian. At the same time, women's teams of fourteen countries including the United States will play a separate contest.

The suspended principal of a city elementary school pleadge guilty yesterday to falsely denying past membership in the Communist party on two applecations he had filed with the Board of Education in 1949.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution urged the Senate today not to ratify the Antarctic treaty.
NEW DELHI, India, April 22 -- India and Communist China appeared to have reached a bargaining stage tonight in the dispute over their common frontier.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, this city's only morning newspaper, announced today the purchase of The Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, a Hearst publication issued evenings and Sundays.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- Vic Wertz' first home run of the season enabled the Boston Red Sox to score a 5-4, eleven-inning victory over the Washington Senators tonight before a crowd of 16,707.
The World's Fair Corporation submitted to Mayor Wagner yesterday the text of a proposed lease under which the corporation would take over Flushing Meadow Park in Queens for the fair in 1964 and 1965.
ALBANY, April 22 -- Legislation designed to preserve the Liberal party as a political entity in the state outside New York City was approved today by Governor Rockefeller.
Prices of Treasury securities generally declined by slight fractions of a point in another inactive trading session yesterday.

A Surinam mission of top political leaders has begun three weeks of conferences in the Netherlands after exploratory visits to Washington and New York. Its conferences and talks are related to revision of the former Dutch colony's ten-year plan for economic development.

A horse race that is essentially New York's "spring classic" -- the $75,000 added Wood Memorial -- will be contested today at Aqueduct. It is likely that the largest crowd of the season, 50,000 fans, will be at hand for the thirty-sixth running of the event.

The fifteenth game of the world chess championship match in Moscow between Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, the champion, and Mikhail Tal of Latvia ended in a, draw yesterday, according to Soviet news sources.

PARIS, April 22 -- A petition asking that all trade barriers in the North Atlantic community be eliminated was presented here today to twenty governments of the projected Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

A Walt Disney version of one of Mary Pickford's silent films, an adaptation of a Broadway comedy by Garson Kanin and a Russian production of a play by William Shakespeare have been booked into local motion-picture theatres.

Michigan is planning the sale of $25,000,000 of highway bonds in June. The last sale was on March 18, when $18,600,000 of obligations were sold for the Grand Rapids Expressway at an interest cost of 4.124 per cent.
GEN. JESUS MARIA CASTRO LEON, who tried and failed to engineer a revolt in Venezuela, is a small, mild-looking man, whom one would hardly consider the prototype for an arch-revolutionist.

A group of stockholders in the Industrial Rayon Corporation filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to block a proposed merger of the Texas Butadiene and Chemical Corporation into Industrial Rayon.

Despite the beautiful weather for the Yankees' home opener yesterday, there was an extraordinary scarcity of political brass at Yankee Stadium. In fact, the only important political figure who could be spotted from the press coop was James A. Farley, a former Haverstraw first baseman.
The boll weevil, showing increasing immunity to insecticides, is plaguing the nation's cotton crop, according to a message carried to a Congressional subcommittee.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 22 -- Senator Frost today ruled the 2-1 choice for the first $25,000 trot of the season at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

ALBANY, April 22 -- A statewide organization of city and village officials strongly urged Governor Rockefeller today to veto a bill that it charged would strip towns and villages of important zoning powers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies were outhit by Cincinnati tonight but made the most of ten safeties and six walks in turning back the Reds, 10 -- 7, and breaking a two-game losing streak.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22 -- The world was a far sweeter place in 1959 than it was in 1949, Sugar made the difference.

BONN, April 22 -- The West German Government appealed to world opinion today to pay attention to the "increased violation of human rights" in the current East German drive for total economic collectivization.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants slammed five homers today in defeating the Chicago Cubs, 10 -- 8. A crowd of 26,753 saw the Cubs become the only National League club to drop its home opener.
The Federal jury that heard the income tax case against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. reported yesterday that it was unable to agree on a verdict and was discharged.

LONG ISLAND fishermen probably will do most of their business this week-end with flounder, though they may just possibly run into some brisk transactions with striped bass, pollock and cod. Jersey anglers, beginning at Sandy Hook, ought to do somewhat better with the stripers.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Tiros I weather-eye satellite, in its three weeks in space, has discovered an unexpected spiral pattern in many of the cloud formations over earth.

ANYONE susceptible to marvelous scents should follow her nose to Stern's new second floor lingerie department. A special fragrance counter is heaped with sachets, perfumed hangers, scented lingerie cases and all of the fragrant, dainty boudoir accessories that make one enjoy being a woman.
Imports of steel products increased slightly during February, but there are indications that they may taper off, the Department of Commerce said yesterday.
Non-recurring expenses involved in starting new product lines at recently acquired subsidiaries and severe winter weather held first-quarter sales and

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (UPI) -- Roberto Clemente clubbed a two-run homer and Hal Smith drove in a pair of runs on a triple and a double tonight in pacing the Pittsburgh Pirates to their third straight victory, 6 -- 2, over the Milwaukee Braves.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22 (UPI) -- Gov. Michael V. DiSalle after a week of ordeal today spared the life of Frank Poindexter although he was convinced that Poindexter was guilty of murder.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 22 (AP) -- Gov. Cecil H. Underwood accused Senators Kennedy and Humphrey today of conducting a "political feast" on West Virginia's poverty.
Dr. Syngman Rhee, the 85-year-old, soft-spoken but iron-willed President of Korea, seemed today about to assume a new, less commanding role in the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 120 per cent of their 1947-49 average, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The patient-centered projects sponsored by the Women's Volunteer Service Corps of St. Barnabas Hospital will receive continued support with the proceeds from the group's annual card party next Friday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday.
THE PRESIDENT Named special emergency board to investigate threatened national railroad strike; welcomed French President de Gaulle and gave a dinner for him and Mme. de Gaulle.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 22 -- Forty-three Negro college students charged with trespassing on the sidewalks of a privately owned shopping center here were freed today in Superior Court. The decision was based on a United States Supreme Court finding in 1946 that "ownership does not always mean absolute dominion."

KUMASI, Ghana, April 22 -- Dr. Joseph B. Danquah, Presidential candidate of the Opposition United party, said today he had formally requested the postponement of tomorrow's voting in this area because of a "widespread campaign of terror and intimidation" against his followers.
BERLIN, April 22 -- Things were slow today at the Blankenfelde migrant reception camp, where those who leave West Germany are welcomed into Communist East Germany.
James Dunn, the head professional at the Philadelphia Racquet Club, and William I. Forbes, a member of that club, won the United States open court tennis doubles championship yesterday.

To nobody's surprise Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana, is running far ahead of the opposition candidate for the Presidency and is also gaining approval of the electorate for the proposed new constitution under which his country will become a republic within the Commonwealth on July 1.

THE America that Mark Twain knew and influenced was the subject of last night's "Project 20" series on Channel 4. In the uncanny animation of still photographs and drawings, the narration read by Howard Lindsay and the score of Robert Russell Bennett, the program was a rewarding hour of history.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A House subcommittee investigating withholding of government information from the public received today a document that it had demanded unsuccessfully for months. Whether the document will resolve the controversy with the Department of the Interior remains to be seen.
Police Commissioner Charles R. Thom of Suffolk County said yesterday that syndicated gambling had invaded his county and upset its morals.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 22 -- The backers of Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts reached quick agreement today on the ground rules for an hour-long television debate here May 3, 4 and 5.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- Preservation of the human scale wag held today to be the chief need in architecture and planning.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The grain futures market held a generally steady course today in sluggish dealings on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Eisenhower established today an emergency board to inquire into the wage dispute between eleven railroad unions and the railroad industry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: American education lost a powerful friend when Beardsley Rural left us. Throughout his career he served education well -- as a teacher, a university dean, a foundation officer and a trustee. His contributions have been especially significant, however, in the last half-dozen years, when he gave his almost undivided attention to a search for fresh solutions to the critical problems confronting our schools and colleges.

THE Museum of Modern Art's hopes are justifiably high for the success of next Wednesday evening's auction, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, of fifty modern paintings and pieces of sculpture for the benefit of the museum's Thirtieth Anniversary Fund.
Commodity prices moved mostly downward yesterday in dull trading on the New York Exchanges. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
ELATH, Israel, April 14 -- By the end of June, Israel expects to be pumping crude oil through a sixteen-inch pipeline from this port on the Gulf of Aqaba to Haifa, her port on the Mediterranean Sea.
Charlie Pratt built a substantial lead over five decathlon rivals yesterday as the sixth annual Queens-Iona Relays opened in warm, bright weather at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

Scientists must find a way of conveying the "enormous delight of scientific work" to nonscientists to overcome a false impression that the scientist is the opposite of a human being, Dr. Margaret Mead said yesterday.

A seven-year study of Protstant teaching materials, made it the Yale Divinity School, disposed a number of them contained negative and distorted references to other faiths, the American Jewish Committee heard yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The appointment of Jerome S. Adlerman as general counsel to the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was announced today by Senator John L. McLellan, Democrat of Arkansas, the chairman.

Five scenes from Shakespeare's plays selected by a special committee headed by Sir Laurence Olivier and Sir John Gielgud, will be presented by noted actots at An Evening with Shakespeare, a benefit dinner.

PARIS. General de Gaulle's stature has never been higher abroad than it is today, nor has any foreigner visited the United States in recent years who can speak with as much personal prestige. He has successfully re-created a myth of France's grandeur and this, combined with his lofty character, enables him to approach the President of the greatest Western power as an equal, something no other Frenchman has done in more than two decades.
DETROIT, April 22 (AP) -- Record production of compact cars will help raise this week's United States auto output an estimated 9 per cent over last week's, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

Acting Corporation Counsel Leo A. Larkin formally notified the Tax Commission yesterday that it would be illegal for it to grant tax valuation reductions to property owners who had not asked for the reductions.

The futility of the prolonged negotiations for new railroad wage agreements is bound to add to the doubts about the effectiveness of collective bargaining that were stirred by last year's costly steel strike.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A former executive of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has invented an unusual way of shipping methane and other dangerous liquefied gases in tank vessels.

IN a day when "great" auction sales have become almost a commonplace, however uncomman their contents, an event such as the auction next week of the English furniture collection of Walter P. Chrysler Jr. generates an unusual degree of interest.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows;
Stocks moved lower again yesterday, completing the widest loss for any week since the beginning of March.

Directors of Wieboldt Stores, Inc., and Mandel Bros., Inc., yesterday authorized negotiations looking for a possible merger of the two department store companies. The announcement was made joinly by James F. Tobin, president of Wieboldt Stores and Col. Leon Mandel, chairman of Mandel Bros.
The port of New York was back to normal yesterday following a nine-hour tie-up on Thursday precipitated by a dispute involving thirty white-collar workers.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Following are excerpts from speeches delivered to the American Society of Newspaper Editors here today by Robert Moses, Dr. Frank Stanton and Adlai E. Stevenson:
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter started his second year in office today by presiding quietly over the policy aspects of President de Gaulle's visit.

LONDON, April 22 -- The Right Rev. Ambrose Reeves, Bishop of Johannesburg, related today how he and his family in South Africa had for weeks received anonymous telephone calls and letters threatening their lives.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 22 (UPI) -- Victor Paz Estenssoro withdrew from the Presidential race tonight six hours before the deadline for candidates to file.
GENEVA, April 22 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of coming to the negotiating table wrapped in an "aggressor's cloak" of secrecy that was preventing disarmament.

Mesabi Iron Company stockholders yesterday approved a settlement between the company and Reserve Mining Company by a vote of 1,043,861 to 970. Reserve is owned by the Armco Steel Corporation and Republic Steel Company.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 22 (AP) -- American Lutherans, who avow mutual beliefs but who have maintained a multiplicity of denominations through the years, today combined three of them into one.

HAVANA, April 22 -- There are growing indications that the Cuban Government may have bitten off more than it can now chew in its haste to change the country's economy to state control and to expand it.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 22 -- Charles H. Brower, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, called on advertisers today to create a climate of greatness in their profession that would usher in a new era of creativity.
Prizes were awarded last night for the outstanding entries in the American Film Festival at a banquet held in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The comment following your April 10 article on homeopathy in the Soviet Union infers that homeopathy is dying in the United States, which is far from the truth.

The one-story industrial building containing 9,000 square feet of space at 4343 Park Avenue, near East 180th Street, the Bronx, has been leased by Trio Investors to the Dorisin Distributing Corporation. The Joseph G. Platzner Company, industrial brokers, negotiated the lease.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told a gathering of newspaper editors here today that he did not expect to take over the political leadership of this country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: M.S. Handler, correspondent of The New York Times to Warsaw, when describing in the April 4 issue the new trade agreements between the Soviet Union and the East-Central European countries, writes that "These trade agreements emphasized once again the magnitude of Soviet economic assistance to Eastern Europe.
A Swedish scientist explained here yesterday why he had spent the last two years disentangling individual nerve cells from ones that surround them in the brain.
GENEVA, April 22 -- The eighty-eight-nation Conference on the Law of the Sea neared its final showdown tonight over the twin issues of the width of territorial seas and fishing rights.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 22 -- An uneasy lull has decended on Turkey following the establishment Monday of an extraordinary investigation commission composed of fifteen members of the ruling Democratic party.

Ruthven Todd, at the request of the trustees of the Dylan Thomas estate, has undertaken to write a biography of the late poet. An intimate friend of Thomas since the Nineteen Thirties, Mr. Todd will have access to many of his previously unpublished letters.
Augusta Redman, the owneroperator of thirty blighted ten ementa and rooming houses spent most of yesterday in Housing Court being sentenced by Magistrate Evelyn Richman in thirty-three cases.

ROGER O. HIRSON fashioned a set of gripping and upsetting characters for his drama about mental health on Channel 2's "Playhouse 90" last night. His play, "Journey to the Bay," was the story of six people who participate in a group psychotherapy experiment at a state mental hospital.
THINGS took a decided turn for the better at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, where the American Ballet Theatre provided the best evening of its season thus far.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission was urged by its own counsel today to set aside the 1957 award of Boston television Channel 5 to WHDH, Inc., to end "speculation, whispering doubt" about influence peddling in the case.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 22 -- The sale of the Zions First National Bank to Utah and Midwestern business interests by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints was announced here today. A price of $9,818,314 was involved, with the Mormon Church selling 146,542 shares of bank stock at $67 a share.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 22 -- Jesus Maria Castro Leon, the retired air force general who led Wednesday's futile revolt against the Government, was captured today near the Colombian border.

POINT MUGU, Calif., April 22 -- The Navy fired a small dummy missile from ten feet of water today in a demonstration of Project Hydra, a proposed system for launching solid propellant rockets from the sea.

WHITE PLAINS, April 22 -- After years of discussion, the Westchester County Realty Board has begun a campaign to outlaw all real estate transactions on Sunday. The 1,190member board announced today that it was sending pleas to leaders over the state to endorse the plan.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 22 -- The Government said today that 1,575 persons had been jailed under emer- gency regulations.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- Plans are beign completed by the Association of the New jersey Neuropsychiatric Instiute for the April Annual. The day-long fund-raising party will take place in Smalley Hall on the Institute grounds on Tuesday suiting at 10:30 A. M.

MOSCOW. A STROLLER down Gorky Street late the other night would have witnessed a strange but happy sight. Two young couples were swinging down a broad sidewalk, swaying rhythmically as they sang la la la to the melody of "I Could Have Danced All Night."

ANTIOCH, Turkey -- This ancient city, which long ago learned the secrets of survival, is now making a strong bid to become a stopping point on the itineraries of present-day world travelers. Until recently, travel to this area in the northeast corner of the Mediterranean was not encouraged by the Turkish authorities for military-security reasons.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 21 -- Finland's business men are smiling broadly these days, but her politicians are frustrated and bitter.

HOW many wives should a husband have -- at the same time, that is? This novel topic was the major question before the Congress of the Women of the African West not long ago in Bamako, the capital of the new Sudan Republic, one of the dozen semidependent countries carved out of France's African possessions.

ATLANTA, April 23 -- Southern students are being recruited for an "interracial action institute" to be conducted at Miami in August. Applications now being distributed say that participants will receive "training in action" and that "evaluation will be based on actual successes and failure experienced in direct, nonviolent action projects."
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 23 -- John W. Elwood, a former National Broadcasting Company executive and a pioneer in radio, died today at a rest home here of a stroke. He was 64 years old.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 23 -- Rebounding from its stunning setback at the hands of Army in the indoor heptagonal championships, Yale's track and field team overpowered the Cadets, 97-43, in a dual meet today.
Jewish learning and knowledge have been "the answer to Jewish survival," the Rev. Dr. William Berkowitz said yesterday in his sermon to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.

TWO years ago Marek Hlasko, an exile from his native country, wrote "The Eighth Day of the Week," a grim, oppressive, competent novel about life in Warsaw. "Next Stop -- Paradise" finds Mr. Hlasko a still angrier young Pole.

CONSIDERING its flavor, it is scarcely surprising that the strawberry has held the attention of some notable people over the years. Perhaps the most memorable comment about this delectable morsel is attributed to William Butler, the sixteenth-century English court physician and obviously a philosopher as well.

HOMEOWERS who have a drab looking fireplace can easily transform it into a handsome decorative unit by covering the front with colorful ceramic mosaic tile. New adhesives make these tiles easy to apply, and the handyman can purchase them in sheets which are laid out to form ready-made patterns.

CHANGING ALUMNUS -- College alumni in the past often paid little attention to the education offered by their alma mater until after they had been graduated. Then their voices were raised whenever the college thought academic changes necessary.

AMURAL of the sea and a five-foot steering wheel from an old whaler will set the theme "The Seven Seas," for the fourteenth annual Gramercy Park Flower Show. The show can be seen from 2 to 10 P. M. on Wednesday, and from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. on Thursday at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South.
