In recent years a number of financing plans have been devised for home owners contemplating modernization jobs, such as remodeling kitchens or finishing basements and attics.

MANY picturesque Victorian family types, it has been noticed, have vanished from the scene, ironed out by mid-twentieth-century conformity. The wicked uncle, the permanent invalid, and the fallen daughter just aren't what they used to be.

A series of annual events is being planned to promote better understanding among Americans of the work of Robert College and the American College for Girls, American-operated institutions in Istanbul, Turkey.

TO the screen Editor In his dispatch published in The Times regarding the warm reception given by appreciative Muscovites to three "sneak preview" showings of the American film "Roman Holiday," your correspondent, Mr. Osgood Caruthers, includes some distressing news.
TO THE EDITOR: Re C. Northcote Parkinson's article on the value to corporations of efficiency experts "A Hard Look at Efficiency Experts" (April 3):
TOKYO, April 23 -- The conservative Government of Preimier Nobusuke Kishi is in difficulties over the Japanese-United States security treaty, which is now before the Diet for ratification.

For Ages 12 to 16. THIS sentimental journey through the French Revolution includes many famous persons and events connected with the family of General Lafayette. Anastasia, the general's elder daughter around whom the story centers, is a truly romantic figure, and Miss Malvern makes the most of her charm, beauty and tragic situation.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- A group of newspaper editors expressed the opinion in a poll today that the Republican party would win the Presidency next November. The vote was 45 -- 42.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 -- A group of pioneering communities that have cured a nation-wide municipal headache will celebrate five years of urban bliss this week.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Vice President Nixon laid down a broad program, of what he called "progressive conservatism" before the American Society of Newspaper Editors today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration's hopes of achieving a nuclear test ban treaty at Geneva and then winning Senate ratification were severely Jolted this week.
A newly built dry-cargo vessel was added to this country's merchant fleet last month for the first time in five years, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported last week.

"THE definition of the dandy begins with a particular point in time, a special milieu and a man by the name of George Bryan Brummell," declares Ellen Moers in the opening sentence of her study. "The Dandy: Brummell to Beerbohm."

GARDENING in the city presents many challenges. On a rooftop there may be too much soot, wind or sun, while the back yard is apt to be too shady. Yet all problems can be solved if met with common sense.

TURIN, Italy -- For more than a year, American experts almost wlthout exception have been complaining about the method by which American international teams are selected, but this seems to be a universal rather than a national custom.

THE practical book continues to dominate photographic literature. Among recent publications, one that will appeal the most to the darkroom worker is Dr. O. R. Cray's "The Complete Art of Printing and Enlarging" (London: Focal Press; New York; Amphoto. 254 pp. $5), now in its sixth edition.

LAKE NEMI in the Alban Hills, during Mussolini's heyday, was ordered drained, to recover from its bed a Roman pleasure-galley. It proved to be modeled after a naval vessel. Planked with larch and pegged with treenails, it was 450 feet long, 192 feet on the beam and 51 feet deep from top deck to keel.

GERALDINE TROTTA'S novel is concerned mainly with sex, fashions and martinis. Her female characters are forever changing their lovers and their clothes, but the martinis -- whole oceans of them-remain constant and very dry.

TO a large number of television viewers, Paul Ford, an ample, jib-nosed character actor currently contributing a good deal of flapfooted charm to several roles in "A Thurber Carnival," will always be Phil Silvers' commanding officer on the Sergeant Bilko shows.
Gifts to Catholic colleges and universities in the United States rose by 40 per cent last year over the previous year. A total of $49,132,286 was given to 182 institutions.

KUMASI, Ghana, April 22 -- Police reinforcements were brought into the Ashanti region today as voters went to the polls in the second stage of an election for President and a plebiscite on a new Constitution proposed by the Government, to make Ghana a republic.

TO THE EDITOR: It seems regrettable to me Uiat so much of the criticism [of apartheid] is of the sterile kind. I feel that we, the outsiders in the conflict, should devote more thought to the nature of the problem.

TO THE EDITOR: The article by C. Northcote Parkinson left me with mixed emotions -- all of them uncharitable. Judging from his rabid viewpoint regarding our profession, the professor seems to have allowed it to become a Parkinson's Disease.
NEW DELHI, India, April 23 -- Parliament gave final approval today to legislation that will slice India's largest state in two.

Shortly after noon on Marcn 30 a "buy flash" went out to all forty-four offices of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis. It suggested purchases of nine "romance stocks," those with high rates of growth.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 24 -- President Syngman Rhee announced today that he is severing all ties with his ruling Liberal party to "seek to serve the nation solely as chief executive."
TO THE EDITOR: Congratulations for the excellent articles in the issue of April 3: "The Gifted Child" by Dorothy Barclay, and the beautiful quotations by Edward Murphy, "Children."
HUTCHINSON, Kan., April 23 -- The Kansas Republican Convention found farm woes very much on the minds of the 1,111 delegates today.

AFTER building a reputation as a brilliant avantgarde movie critic, the late James Agee went to Hollywood and wrote the scenario for "Face to Face," a Western. More recently, Frank Davis Adams published his first Western novel after teaching English at three universities.
Leaders of organized labor and organized medicine, long bitter antagonists, are making quiet efforts to find areas of agreement and improved understanding.

WASHINGTON. April 23 -- Following is the text of questious find answers at a news conference held by President de Gaulle at the National Press Club today, with the official translation of General de 'Gaulle's remark. supplied by the French Embassy as a more precise version than the one provided at the conference and broadcast over radio and television:

To the Screen Editor: It was with dismay that I read Murray Schumach's article about Walter Wanger's proposed filming of Lawrence Durrell's "Alexandria Quartet." As a devoted and admiring reader of Mr. Durrell's novels and poetry, I was aghast at the idea that any Hollywood producer should imagine that he could make a film out of the tetralogy.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- A new series of Rockefeller Public Service Awards, honoring "truly outstanding" public servants, has been established at Princeton University. In announcing the program today, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of the university, said five awards would be presented annually, beginning early next year.

General de Gaulle ON the first page this morning is a review of General de Gaulle's "Salvation." In France this morning, that same author is regarded as one of her better literary stylists -- as well as best seller.

A CENTURY from now, if all goes well, scholars may take from the Library of Congress a dusty book titled "Fallout," run through its yellowed pages and wonder how it felt to live in the Nineteen Sixties under the threat of nuclear war.

BY late April, even in a spring as slow as this one, gardeners in the Northeast can plant hardy annuals outdoors, either by sowing seed or setting out plants. Tender annuals are best left until May 10 or later.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 23 -- Governor General Sir Oliver Goonetilleke dissolved the thirty-four-day-old Ceylonese Parliament today and ordered general elections to be held July 20.
The New York Philharmonic Young People's Concerts came to a stirring close yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with a concert performance of Aaron Copland's "The Second Hurricane."

The city school system will get about $4,500,000 in additional state aid that it did not expect -- or know about until a few days ago. About half the sum will be used to augment the $13,800,000 already allotted in the proposed 1960-61 city budget for increasing the salaries of teachers and others in the system.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 23 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd met with a member of his Cabinet today for the first time since the attempt on his life two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- In the rush of all the Presidential aspirants, led by Senator John F. Kennedy, to support as continuing United States policy the Anglo-American-Soviet agreement for a protracted suspension of all nuclear weapons testing while an inspection system was being worked out, the obligatory "show me" function of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy was temporarily obscured.

MANY gardeners are all too familiar with the ridges and mounds caused by the tunneling activities of moles. In a lawn, these tunnels are not only unsightly but also cause grass roots to dry out and die.
MADRID, April 21 -- The Spanish Government has begun a campaign of praise for Britain.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23 -- With a fine show of sustained driving power against a head-wind, Navy's varsity eight defeated Princeton by two and half lengths on the Severn River today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 23 (AP) -- Candidates accompanied by pipers playing shrill bamboo flutes stumped villages and towns today in the last day of Laos' general election campaigning.

The American Civil Liberties Union recently demanded a "nation-wide review" of the effect, on the freedom of colleges and universities of foundation and Government grants for research projects. A few weeks ago, Harvard announced that it will undertake a detailed study to examine the effect of Government money on the university's academic health.

When a new building is given an address, the number selected is more than just a matter of fancy or whim. When one building has more than one possible address, a lot of thinking is usually lavished on deciding which to use.

ORIENTAL cherries, peaches and crabapplea are grown for their beautiful springtime flowers, and not for fruit. Because they do not require continuous, costly spraying, they are proving increasingly popular in home gardens and parks.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23 -- Five Yale crews swept to victory in as many races on the Housatonic today.
The Board of Estimate will begin its consideration of Mayor Wagner's proposed 1960-61 expense budget of $2,338,857,547 in an executive session at City Hall tomorrow morning.
TURIN, Italy, April 23 -- Play began today in the contract bridge tournament for the world championship.
BABYLON, L.I., April 23 -- Charlie Dunn of the Centerport Yacht Club gained the lead today in the two-day district regional championship Penguin regatta.

SINCE Joseph Mitchell is an unselfconscious writer, readers of "The Bottom of the Harbor" are never distracted from the subject matter of his book. He is discussing and describing the natural phenomena of the waters around New York -- fish, clams, oysters and lobsters, and the natives who are equally indigenous.

IT is interesting indeed to investigate the different positions sport occupies in the lives of people of varying backgrounds and standards of living. For purposes of convenience, let us consider three basic kinds of society.

LAST Tuesday was a somewhat exceptional day even for Arthur Penn, a 37 - year - old Philadelphian who should be getting fairly used to the exceptional. On that day Mr. Penn found that a play he directed, "Toys in the Attic," by Lillian Hellman, won the coveted New York Drama Critics Circle award as the best American drama of the 1959-60 season.
ROME, April 23 -- President Giovanni Gronchi made another effort today to solve the Italian Cabinet crisis, now in its ninth weak, by confirming the present caretaker Government in power.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 23 -- Dennis D'Oca, Hofstra's star southpaw, hurled a five-hitter in pitching the Flying Dutchmen to an 8-0 triumph over New York University today.

DETROIT, April 23 -- For several decades the suburban Grosse Points along Lake St. Clair, east, of this city, have provided a residential symbol of social success. An address along one of the tree-lined streets of old mansions and more modern brick colonials in one of the five communities has been regarded by many people as a mark of status and economic achievement.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : We are nearing the date of the summit conference. Different subjects have been mentioned by those who are in charge of the preparation of this important Paris meeting, but here is a total silence concerning the problem of Eastern Europe.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- Soviet music-lovers are playing warm and gracious host to two widely divergent American performances, and the reception visitors from the United States have been accorded has been nothing short of fabulous.

Mrs. Samuel P. Pryor of Greenwich, Conn., will head the Connecticut women's committee for the United Negro College Fund for the third successive year. The goal for the 1960 appeal, scheduled through June, is $2,250,000.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 23 -- Five eight-oared shells were swamped and the remaining one was beached today as the annual James H. Hughes Memorial Cup rowing regatta ended in a fiasco that might have had tragic consequences.
DALLAS, April 23 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs took a five-stroke lead in the Dallas Civitan women's open tournament today with a two-under-par 211.

The Arthur Kudner Award for "excellence in creative writing for institutional advertising" was presented on Friday at the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies to Pat Steel of Young Rubicam, Inc.

IN one year, approximately 12,000,000 persons patronize Broadway's array of stage offerings. In one week, half that number of people, divested of the cares of scampering for choice seat locations and of the concern for high ticket tariffs, sit before their television sets to watch "The Play of the Week."

LONDON, April 23 (Reuters) -- Third-place Burnley today moved another point closer to wresting the English League first-division soccer title from the defending champion Wolverhmpton Wanderers and second-place Tottenham Hotspur.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) -- A rookie catcher, Jim Coker, hit a double to center in the thirteenth inning today and fave the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-2 victory over Cincinnati.
The strong favorite, Francis S. of the Harbor View Farm, registered an easy victory in the thirty-sixth running of the Wood Memorial yesterday.
HANOVER, N. H., April 23 -- John Thomas, Boston University's indoor high jump record holder, soared 7 feet 1/2 inch today, breaking the National Collegiate mark and tying the American outdoor mark.

ALTHOUGH most plants follow a common pattern of appearing in the spring, there are a few of them that prefer to "sleep late." A few perennials are so alow to stir in spring that they are often injured or unintentionally destroyed in the early weeks of garden clean-up.

FOR THIS WEEK: Keep up with planting chores. ... Finish clean-up of all borders. . . . Stow away winter protection shields and stakes safely for next year.... Do not wait too long to start mowing the lawn. ... Tie down a light mulch on slopes before planting groundcovers...., Cut faded daffodils, hyacinths and early tulips off stalks to prevent seed formation. ... Wait until mid-May to move the geraniums outdoors.

JOHANNESBURG. IN the middle of Johannesburg stands a large, ornate department store known as the "O.K. Bazaars." Recently, between its tall Corinthian columns, elaborate decorations have been erected to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the Union of South Africa on May 31.

IN "Windows for the Crown Prince" Elizabeth Gray Vining gave us a memorable account of her experiences as tutor to Prince Akihito of Japan from 1946 to 1950. Since then she has made two return visits to that country: the first in 1957 to attend the Congress of International P. E. N. in Tokyo and the second in 1959 as the only non-Japanese guest to be invited to the Crown Prince's wedding.
Department store sales in the nation in the week ended April 16 rose 18 per cent from the 1959 level, tbe Federal Reserve Board has reported. The difference in Easter dates was a big factor.

The consistency of retail buying is doing much to offset disappointments in other sectors of the economy, As predicted, Easter purchases finished up strong and retailers did quite well in the following week. For the week ended with Easter, department stores showed a gain of 18 per cent over the comparable 1959 week, which was three weeks after Easter.

RABAT, Morocco, April 23 -- The Moroccan Government firmly opposed today French "interposition" in the application of the bilateral agreement with the United States on the evacuation of American military bases here.

Flowering shrubs -- spicebush, forsythis, early azaleas and rhododendrons -- form colorful frames for the daffodils, grape hyacinths and bluets. Motorists also will find blossoms open on the early cherry trees and magnolias along roadsides in the metropolitan area.

SEVILLE, Spain, April 23 -- The first important fiesta of the season will explode here Tuesday. It will run to May l. There will be costume parades, dancing in the streets, fireworks, races among waiters balancing loaded trays at shoulder level or above, plenty of drinking and very little sleeping.

The head of the American Jewish Committee expressed concern last night over what he said was the failure of the United States to utilize "its prestige and power" for achieving peace between the Arab nations and Israel.

AREADY-mixed paste which is made of real steel hardens in two hours to form a tough metallic material which is useful in many kinds of home and auto repairs. Packaged in a squeeze tube, this material adheres to most surfaces (wood, metal, plastics, concrete, etc.) and will not rust when dry.

REEL or rotary lawn mowers, like any other cutting instrument, give peak performance only with sharp blades. Keeping them sharp is a major but often overlooked part of mower upkeep.

NEW DELHI, April 23 -- This is the hot season here but the political climate was decidedly chilly as Premier Chou En-lai flew in from the northeast for talks with Prime Minister Nehru on a sharp dispute between India and Communist China.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 23 -- In their struggle for economic, social and political rights South Africa's 10,000,000 Africans have the support of the country's small Asian population of 441,000.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., April 21 -- Islanders here on Martha's Vineyard and on neighboring Nantucket have their backs up over a strike that has tied up ferry service to the mainland.

IF garden shrubs were listed on a stock exchange, the rhododendrons surely would make up the group referred to as "blue chips." These evergreen plants are suited to every garden "investor," small budget or large.

MARTHA GRAHAM will bring her company into the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre tomorrow evening for a two-week season under the auspices of the B. de Rothschild Foundation. It has been just two years since her last Broadway season, which was at this same theatre and under these same auspices.

ON a tract of land south of Los Angeles, Jessamyn has created a self-contained microcosm of American society. The year is 1916. The land is new. These are the last of the pioneers, the final wave of migration.
NEW DELHI, India -- The last free lions in Asia are luring tourists to a 500-square-mile jungle in western India.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 23 -- Dr. David Magie, Professor Emeritus of Classics at Princeton University, died last night of a heart and bronchial ailment at his home at 101 Library Place. He was 83 years old.

SOME quaintly normal moviegoers have meekly complained that they have felt a little soiled by too close exposure to some recent films made from Tennessee Williams' plays. Several reported leprous symptoms after "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof."
DETROIT, April 23 -- The Detroit Tigers ran their unbeaten streak to four games with a 6-2 triumph over the Chicago White Sox today.

THE Nine O'clock Theatre lives on. Producer Alexander H. Cohen, who invented it when he opened at the John Golden last Oct 8 with "At the Drop of a Hat" (Flanders and Swann), now has a second edition set.

Spring is here, and so are annual meetings. This year stock-holders are attending in the usual droves and appear as hungry as ever for news about their companies, for higher dividends and for those box lunches so often provided.

SOME 30,000 tulips will present their dazzling annual display of colorful blooms in the Hershey Rose Garden, Hershey, Pa., during the three-week period beginning today. For tourists and other motorists on the Pennsylvania Turnpike with a couple of hours to spare, the gardens, which are on the grounds of the Hershey Hotel, are easily reached about twelve miles along U.S. 422 from the Harrisburg East interchange of the toll road.
NEW DELHI, India, April 23 -- An uneasiness enveloped New Delhi today over the four-day-old visit of Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China.

A new program intended for school people and others who want to increase their professional competence without necessarily studying for advanced degrees, has been introduced at Teachers College, Columbia University.

ABOUT eighty-five miles southwest of New York, as the crow flies, is a Pennsylvania Dutch farming community that has gone its unchanging way since before 1720. This is the country around Boyertown that sent food to New York and Philadelphia for Washington's armies.
TOKYO, April 23 (AP) -- Korean demonstrators, angered by police violence in their homeland, kicked and manhandled Ambassador Yiu Tai Ha in his office today and forced from him a promise to resign.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 23 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson today offered the Democrats party ten "challenges" of the next decade.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa. -- With new attractions on display and additional innovations being planned, Longwood Gardens, one of the nation's most important horticultural showplaces, is preparing for a record number of visitors this year.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP) -- Johnny Logan's second error of the game led to the winning the game led to the winning run today as the Pirates posted a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
Morgan State captured three varsity relay titles and New York University bagged two yesterday as the sixth annual Queens-Iona Relays concluded at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The American Philosophical Society ended today a three-day conference at the society's headquarters on Independence Square with the presentation of three awards for outstanding achievement.

An unusual private psychiatric hospital in Manhattan, which treats both the mind and the body and takes its patients as they come, reports it had 1,087 patients in its first year of operation. The average stay was 23.9 days.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Almost three years ago a new House subcommittee with an odd name began work on an assignment that seemed unlikely to cause much public stir. The group was the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight, its job to investigate the working of the Federal regulatory agencies.

HOLLYWOOD. IN the present uncertain state of the movie industry here, the film companies are caught between the terror of being destroyed by devotion to the status quo and the fear of utter failure by risky ventures.

LIME ROCK, Conn., April 23 -- Phil Cade of Winchester, Mass., and Bill Kimberly of New Milford, Conn., won the feature races as the sports car season opened here today. There were 120 cars entered in six events. Three races went ten laps over the mile-and-a-half course and three ran fifteen laps.
Edward P. May of 327 West Forty-second Street, who retired in 1954 as Superintendent of Sewers in Manhattan, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 85.

Concern for children might, unite East and West quicker than diplomacy, a mental health authority said here yesterday. He said he had already made a small scale test of the theory in the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Governor Rockefeller signed two bills today granting state welfare officials the authority to place homeless children in foster homes in neighboring states.
The nation's shipbuilding industry faces a grim future, L. R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, reported last week.
TOKYO, April 23 (UPI) -- Japan accused the Soviet Union today of employing "malicious propaganda" in its protests against the new United States-Japanese security pact.
PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- This venerable city is rich in Colonial treasures and, therefore, makes an ideal stopover point for motorists driving to New England now in search of summer camps and cottages.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 23 -- The annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies closed here today with its outgoing chairman urging those people involved in advertising to find and eliminate the factors that make the public critical of advertising.

AN intelligent job of grass cutting depends on the lawn owner's knowledge of why, when and how to do it properly. His careful observance of other important lawn maintenance chores can be largely negated by improper mowing practice.

ONE of the better flops in the business world of late has been the vain attempt to bring back Granny's Old Rocking Chair -- which may now be considered a gone goose. It seems a couple of furniture makers, seeing the American people go for hulahoops and sports cars, thought maybe the rocker would take.

FRANKLY, I do not see how a man can write fourteen crime novels in a little over ten years without ever repeating himself in any way -- consistently coming up with fresh characters in a fresh scene, with a fresh theme and startlingly fresh plot-construction.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 18 -- Iraq's faltering economy is probably the most serious problem confronting Premier Abdul Karim Kassem today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Architects, who have done much to shape the nation's cityscapes, are becoming profoundly disenchanted with what they have wrought.

The events in South Korea, where President Rhee is struggling with a crisis precipitated by anti-Government riots, call renewed attention to the difficulties of the new democracies that have emerged from the two World Wars. Their development, and the collapse of some of them, again demonstrate that democracy is never born full-grown, like Athena from the head of Zeus, but is rather the product of a long and often painful evolution.

At least one segregationist argument against school desegregation has been partly destroyed, a group of psychiatrists said here this week. Segregationists feared that Negroes, in gaining power, would use violence to retaliate against whites.
Edwin Joel Thomas, chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, registers an emphatic dissent to the growing forebodings regarding 1960 business.
SYRACUSE, April 23 -- Former President Harry S. Truman came to Syracuse University today on his crusade to explain the United States Government to young persons.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- A new way of life is beckoning to growing numbers of aging persons in the Far West.

EDWARD R. MURROW, who returned to this country last week after nine months of meditating and sight-seeing in foreign lands, gets back into the area of crucial issues next month with a report on school integration in Georgia.
HAVANA, April 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared last night that his revolution was making great strides in improving the island's economy. He assured the people their sacrifices were "not in vain."

"I AM sure," the mother of a teen-age boy wrote this department recently, "that many parents of teen-agers would benefit from reading the opinions of authorities on this problem: What action, if any, is desirable when an intelligent but immature boy is seeing a lot of an even younger girl, whose mother deliberately encourages what amounts to steady dating?
VIENNA, April 23 - Reports of recent developments in Hungary indicate that the Communist regime has embarked on a somewhat more liberal domestic policy.
A product that is often considered the ugly duckling of the oil business has been stirring up an unusual amount of excitemcnt lately.

THIS first novel by a young Norwegian has created a considerable stir in his own country. When the book appeared there in 1954, one reviewer described it as "a volcanic outburst of original creative power."

ST. LOUIS, April 23 -- The St. Louis Cardinals made it three straight today. Ken Boyer's five runs batted in on two homers and a double and Bob Duliba's tight relief pitching paced a 9-5 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
THE records attest that mail was transported in the American Far West by mustangs in 1860 when the newly established Pony Express Service operated between St. Joseph, Mo., and the Pacific Coast.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was accused yesterday of treating his men like robots.
The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday dissociated itself from an attack on James R. Hoffa, teamster union leader, by another maritime labor official.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 -- News in the steel industry last week was dull. It showed further declines in backlogs and shipments and no significant pick-up in the volume of new steel orders. About the only good news was the further sharp drop in steel order cancellations which had reached a peak about three weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (UPI) -- Jim Coker, a rookie, hit a grand-slam homer to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 9-5 victory over Cincinnati in the first game of a double-header today. The Reds won the second game, 10 -- 4, and snapped a string of four losses.
NEWARK, April 24 -- The Ukrainian Nationals routed the Polish Falcons, 7 -- 3, in an American Soccer League game today. Stan Dlugosh tallied three times for the winners and Miguel Noga twice.

PERUSAL of "The Flavor of France" inspires two appetites -- one for traveling and one for eating. It is difficult to know which is stronger, and perhaps the easiest compromise is a trip to the kitchen stove.
Import of Secretaries A recent news item in this newspaper stated that the owner of a London employment agency had come to New York to offer executives a chance to hire secretaries from England.
SEOUL, Korea, April 24 (UPI) -- Following is the text of President Syngman Rhee's statement today on the Government crisis:
The Kennecott Copper Corporation has elected C. Harry Burgess as vice president-exploration, it was announced over the week-end by Charles R. Cox, president.
NEW ORLEANS, April 24 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald shot a 69 in the final round to win the $27,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Unemployment now exceeds four million. A recession in 1961 is a very real possibility. If it occurs, unemployment may rise to over six million.
NEW DELHI, India, Monday, April 25 -- Talks between leaders of India and Communist China intensified yesterday, but several Indian newspapers said today that a complete stalemate was indicated.

PARIS. The United States is convinced that an ideological and political gap is widening between Russia and China, the two Communist behemoths, and for this reason current troubles in South Korea have a par- ticularly disturbing significance.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 24 -- The three-day constituting convention of the American Lutheran Church ended today with an appeal to end housing discrimination here, the group's headquarters city.
Week Ended April 22, 1960 British pound sterling was firm in foreign exchange trading last week. Canadian dollar was irregular. Volume of business transacted was heavy at times.
LONDON, April 24 -- Rumors of imminent bank deposit controls designed to curb lending capacity sent another wave of depression through the stock market last week.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The odds are shifting on the procedure the Treasury will use for its financing this week.
Richard Kay, who has given a number of cello programs here in recent years, gave a Town Hall recital last night that gave evidence of substantial artistic growth.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $76,116,303,061. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
Traffic was blocked by de-dates on modern art yesterday as young painters picketed the Museum of Modern Art at 11 West Fifty-third Street to protest its preference for abstract works.
The Rev, Dr. Pierre van Paassen declared yesterday that the United States had made its "biggest mistake" in the rearmament of West Germany, thus "making it almost impossible for Russia to negotiate."
A Jesuit editor has asked Protestant scholars to take a fresh look at Biblical texts concerning the theological role of Mary the mother of Christ.
BOSTON, April 24 -- The Boston area, which was once the huh of intellectual life in this country, was a busy musical center this week-end.

THE National Broadcasting Company managed somehow last night to fill an hour with details of the forthcoming marriage of Princess Margaret and Antony Armstrong-Jones. The network was under an obvious strain for things to do, but the presentation presumably met the essential test of providing a framework for commercials for refrigerators.

A permanent no-strike pledge, the first of its kind in any hospital contract, has been tentatively agreed to by negotiators for Trafalgar Hospital in Manhattan and the Drug and Hospital Employes Union, Local 1199.
Charles Laughton and Walter Slezak have been named to star in two different television dramas that are scheduled for the month of May.

FOR the sixth consecutive year more than 4,000,000 babies were born in 1959. With one newcomer arriving about every seven seconds, manufacturers of baby products may have to work overtime, especially since experts predict that in 1970 about 6,500,000 babies will be arriving each year.

The New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation's program of research, clinics, rehabilitation projects and patient services will benefit from a Celebrity Cocktail Party to be held May 23 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
BERLIN, April 24 -- A tiny but spirited Social Democratic party clings to a precarious existence in the heart of Communist East Berlin.

WHEN "Lasso Round the Moon,"* a promising first novel by Agnar Mykle, was published in Norway in 1954 it enjoyed only a modest success. Three years later Mr. Mykle's second novel, a sequel called "The Song of the Red Ruby," suddenly made him the most notorious of living Scandinavian writers.
Public utilities stocks proved to be "just what the doctor ordered" for mutual funds during the first quarter.

The refusal of members of the International Longshoremen's Union to unload the Egyptian freighter Cleopatra, and why they are doing it, raise a lot of complicated issues that badly need clarification -- and possibly call for legal re- straints. What has happened is as simple as the results are complex and far-reaching.

PARIS, April 24 -- Jacques Soustelle, dismissed from the Government in February for having sided with European insurrectionists in Algeria, opened an offensive today against the leaders of the Gaullist Union for the New Republic, which he helped to found.
Educational television will help to revolutionize school construction, the Educational Facilities Laboratories, Inc., predicted yesterday.

Elma Adams, pianist, played a debut performance at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. A native New Yorker, Miss Adams is a graduate of the Juilliard School of Music, where she studied with Alton Jones.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Sixteen top scientists proposed today a high priority research effort -- possibly costing $100,000,000 -- to develop an inspection system capable of detecting small underground nuclear tests.
The national death rate from cancer of the uterus has been cut almost in half in a generation, the American Cancer Society said yesterday.
Mayor Wagner's "Direct Line" television program on which he answers citizens' questions brought direct action yesterday in the form of a police raid that netted four arrests.
DETROIT, April 24 (AP) -- Chrysler Corporation has announced another shift in advertising agencies, this one involv ing its Canadian company, Chrysler of Canada, Ltd.

LONDON, April 24 -- The closest coordination of United States and British policies toward new African nations during their expected phase of "temporary tyranny" is being urged by influential members of the British Government.

HOUSTON, April 24 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay scored a 7-5, 6-3, 6-4 victory today over Neale Fraser, the world's top-ranked amateur in the final of the twenty-sixth annual River Oaks invitation tennis tournament.
The Protestant faith does not oppose all forms of confession, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell asserted yesterday.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 22 -- A Protestant Episcopal Bishop and a creek-baptizing preacher agreed here this week -- for different reasons -- that they would rather not vote for a Roman Catholic for President.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Senate investigators charged today that the Navy's active reserve was top-heavy with what they called armchair admirals, improperly trained for any war emergency.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Eisenhower and President de Gaulle declared today that they were in agreement on "how we should proceed at the summit meeting."

CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs knocked the San Francisco Giants out of the National League lead today when they scored seven runs with two out in the eighth inning for a 9-4 victory. The triumph ended a five-game losing streak.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 24 Mr. and Mrs. W.R. Ballard's bay gelding, Windsor Castle, won all four casses today and annexed the open jumper championship of the thirtyeighth Boulder Brook Club Spring Horse Show with 26 points.
ATLANTA, April 24 (UPI) -- The Council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association indicated today that infractions by member colleges would be on the agenda of its regular spring meeting.
DALLAS, April 24 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs withstood a spirited stretch drive by Mickey Wright to win the Dallas Civitan women's open today by five strokes with a 72-hole total of 281.

Unless pronounced long-term trends are reversed, the states of New York and New Jersey will probably each cast 25 per cent more votes in this year's Presidential election than they did in their last state elections for Governor.

EDWIN MILBY SAWYER, a one-time biology professor at Ithaca College, set a major league record this season. He managed the Philadelphia Phils in their opening game. It was such a soul-searing experience that Eddie reached for his tranquilizers and the telephone in the same motion. He called Bob Carpenter, the owner of the ball club, and resigned.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- With the civil rights bill gone at last to the White House, Congress will turn this week to legislation toward which President Eisenhower is less favorably disposed.

Mayor Wagner has selected William Reid, chairman of the New York Housing Authority, and Jacob Lutsky, legal aide to the Mayor, for appointment to the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Some showmen here are beating the drums for religion these days, and taking a beating from some religious leaders.
When the musicians took their seats for the second half of yesterday afternoon's chamber concert at the New School there was no music on their stands.

"Listen to the Mocking Bird," a play by Robert Penn Warren, Pulitzer Prize novelist and poet, has been acquired by the Theatre Guild. The drama was derived from the fourth chapter of "All the King's Men," Mr. Warren's novel that brought him the Pulitzer Prize.
The cornerstone of Ebbets Field was battered and pried open yesterday before about 300 sentimentalists who looked on with the expectancy of archaeologists before a Pharaoh's tomb.

IS America becoming a nation of tea drinkers? To judge by B. Altman Co.'s Delicacy Shop, it is. Two years ago, teas occupied one modest shelf section in the department. Since that time the selection has expanded to fill an area three times as large.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Washington rallied for an 11-10 victory over Boston today. The Senators scored four runs in the eighth inning and survived a ninth in which Bobby Thomson and Lou Clinton hit homers for the Red Sox.
NASSAU, Bahamas, April 24 -- A Florida skipper was slain today on a Bahamas island rescue mission. The castaways who shot him fled to Cuban waters in his boat.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The staff of the Senate Commerce Committee has proposed three devices for further improvement of the United States balance of international payments, going beyond the program that the Administration has undertaken already.

SEOUL, Korea, April 24 -- Walter Patrick McConaughy, the United States Ambassador in Seoul, has a reputation for being calm in any crisis. The current unrest in South Korea, which has caused more than 100 deaths and forced a drastic revamping of the Government, finds the soft - spoken Alabaman as imperturbable as he has been in numerous other emergencies in foreign lands through most of his twenty-nine years in the diplometic service.

MURMANSK, U.S.S.R., April 12 -- An era of harsh and rugged pioneering is transforming this bleak Arctic harbor and the forbidding territory around it into a vital cog in the machinery of the Soviet economy.

The New York suburban are has a special taxing district whose sole function is the operation of a moving stairway at a railroad station. There is another special taxing district that operates a ferryboat. There is at least one district responsible for the operation and maintenance of parking facilities.

AMSTERDAM, April 24 -- Stock market interest early last week was centered on Philips and Unilever. On Tuesday these shares rose 53 and 34 points respectively to new post- war highs of 954 and 847, thereby pushing the general share index up to nearly 371 points, from 365.
A program of excerpts from operas and operettas at Carnegie Hall last night was remarkable chiefly for the singing of a young tenor named Jerry LoMonaco.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- The American Civil Liberties Union called today for "maximum effort" to abolish the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
The Yankees treated a crowd of 19,460 yesterday to one of their most explosive batting performances in years in beating the Baltimore Orioles, 15 to 9.
EUGENE, Ore., April 24 (AP) -- "I think I can go considerably faster," Dyrol Burleson said today.

The Turkish Government's suspension of nor- mal political activities has raised grave fears in the minds of Turkey's friends. With the rioting in South Korea fresh in their minds, they cannot avoid drawing a parallel between the two situations.

One evening several years ago an agitated Western correspondent handed a dispatch to a young lady at the censor's office in Moscow. A new Soviet sputnik had rocketed into orbit and an impatient world wanted to know the details. But the Soviet miss said coldly, "I can't understand all this excitement. Why do we have to climb to the sky when there is so much to be done on this earth?"
Three members of college debating teams agreed yesterday with an expert on constitutional law that Congress had adequate, if time-consuming, means of reversing Supreme Court decisions.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- School boards of the nation were advised today to move beyond their local spheres into the national arena if they were to influence general school policy.
The American Export Lines newest passenger ship, the 18,000-ton economy class line Atlantic, will make a special forty-one day Mediterranean cruise in October, the line announced yesterday.

BILOXI, Miss., April 24 (AP) -- Mayor Laz Quave pleaded with residents in this Gulf coast resort tonight to comply with a police order to stay off the streets. The move was an attempt to curb racial tension. Bars were ordered closed.
The Museum of the City of New York turned back the clock fifty years on upper Fifth Avenue yesterday.
Among the missing at Yankee Stadium yesterday was Gus Mauch, the Yankee trainer.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended April 23:

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 24 -- Hundreds of thousands of Laotians, many wearing the distinctive costumes of their tribes, trooped into Buddhist temple courtyards today to cast their ballots for a new National Assembly.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 17 -- An American recently blundered into the printing shop of a Communist newspaper here and asked, in faltering Arabic and gestures, how to find party headquarters.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 25 -- Opposition spokesmen in the National Assembly demanded today President Syngman Rhee's resignation and the holding of new elections. They also asked immediate drastic changes in the South Korean Government to deprive the President of most of his executive powers.

KANSAS CITY, April 24 (AP) -- Woody Held drove in four runs with two homers and Gary Bell pitched a six-hitter today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 7 -- 0. It was the Indians' first victory of the season.
A pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman asking support for the 1960 Bishops' Relief Fund was read yesterday at all masses in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

THERE are times in every woman's life when she feels unappreciated because she actually is. There are all sorts of solutions to this problem, but one of the nicest is to walk away from it all and put yourself in the hands of Charles of the Ritz salon on Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street adjacent to the Ritz Towers.
Newspaper publishers arriving here for annual Press Week meetings generally agreed yesterday that news was being well and fairly presented to the nation's readers.

A Roman Catholic educator and a Protestant spiritual leader called yesterday for a conference of religious leaders to explore means of reducing religious tensions arising from the Presidential campaign.

A publicity man who has been linked to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was arrested yesterday and charged with attempting to bribe a Life magazine employe to gain access to Life's confidential files on James A. Hoffa, the union's president.

LANGHORNE, Pa., April 24 -- A.J. Foyt, a 25-year-old driver from Houston, scored another victory today by capturing a thrilling 100-mile test on Langhorne's famous dirt mile. He was first at Reading, Pa., last week.
Gamal Abdel Nasser made clear yesterday that Communist Chinese volunteers would not worry him if they showed up in Algeria to help out in the Moslem nationalists' fight for independence.
Work will start Wednesday on the last major traffic link between the Brooklyn Bridge and Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn.

In 1882 Frank G. Carpenter, then 27 years age age, was sent to Washington by The Cleveland Leader as its correspondent. His Washington letters made him a popular and "mostquoted" writer. They told of the goings-on in the city and commented on the curiosities, characters and cranks in the administrations of Presidents Arthur, Cleveland and Harrison.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The grain future market generally was stalled on dead center most of the time last week, but some contracts ran fairly consistently toward strength and some toward weakness.

The Internal Revenue Service is sending out invitations to a number of taxpayers these days to come into the district director's office for a chat. One in twenty-six Federal taxpayers eventually will be asked to explain their filing rationale.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Supporters of Vice President Nixon released today the results of a poll indicating that he will run behind Senator John F. Kennedy in the Indiana Presidential preference primaries on May 3.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 24 -- Martin Gainabrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board said yesterday that an increased investment in advertising could serve to play an increasingly important role in warding off cyclical recession.
ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP) -- Home runs by Ken Boyer and Stan Musial sparked the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-2 victory today and a sweep of their three-game series with the Los Angeles Dodgers.
ALBANY, April 24 -- A bill making it a misdemeanor to threaten anyone over the telephone or to use obscene language to a woman over the phone has been signed by Governor Rockefeller.
ROME, April 24 -- Opus Dei, the young and ambitious lay order of the Roman Catholic Church, formally opened an international training center on Rome's outskirts today.

THE New York City Ballet closed its season at the City Center with two performances yesterday that constituted a brilliant finish. Last night saw what might be almost termed an official presentation of this season's new ballet, "The Figure in the Carpet," created in honor of the Fourth International Congress of Iranian Art and Archaeology, which opens in New York this week.

Two distinguished gentlemen buzzing from Gettysburg, Pa., yesterday to Camp David, Md., thence back to Washington, were accompanied in a second helicopter by their two personal physi- cians. This was a sensible precaution, for both President Eisenhower and President de Gaulle will arrive at the age of 70 next fall.

DETROIT, April 24 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers rapped Early Wynn for six runs in the first inning today and scored a 12-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox, sweeping a three-game series from the American League champions.
ALBANY, April 24 -- A sharp decline in juvenile delinquency throughout the state was reported today by the State Youth Commission.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 24 -- In a serene sequel to the tempestuous happenings of yesterday, Iona College won the James H. Hughes Memorial Cup rowing regatta cross Long Island Sound this morning.
The typical compact car buyer is as much a myth as the "average man."
CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI) -- The body of Federal Judge W. Lynn Parkinson was found today within a half mile of where he was last seen six months ago.

A simple method of screening out airline and other civilian pilots who are mentally unfit to fly is being sought by the Federal Aviation Agency as part of a new research program on pilot mental health.

Judge Samuel R. Pierce Jr. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday acclaimed the progress of human dignity in an address at the fourth annual communion breakfast of the St. George Association of the city's Department of Health.

Mount St. Michael captured the team title yesterday in the fourth annual All Hallows track and field games at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. More than forty Catholic high schools from the metropolitan area and New Jersey competed.

Former President Harry S. Truman has disclosed that to issued a virtual ultimatum to Premier Stalin in 1946, warning the Russian that if he did not withdraw Soviet troops from Iran, the President would "move the fleet as far as the Persian Gulf."
The Antoinette Perry theatre awards went last night to "The Miracle Worker," among the plays for last year, and to two musical productions, "Fiorello!" and "The Sound of Music."
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 -- A clear pattern of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination emerged today.

A large space in the eighteen-story office building being constructed by the Jarcho-Landau Corporation at 770 Lexington Avenue, the northwest corner of Sixtieth Street, has been leased by Cross Son, architects.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 565 Park Avenue between Sixtysecond and Sixty-third Streets has been purchased by June Nelson, a realty investor, who plans to alter it into small suites.

GENEVA, April 24 -- The Swiss stock markets closely mirrored the movements on the New York Exchange last week. While the influence of the dealings in New York affected more particularly the quotations on foreign stocks, Swiss values also reflected the general trend.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 24 -- A significant shift in emphasis has occurred in the last two weeks in comments by the Government radio on South Africa's racial crisis.
Cotton futures prices moved irregularly last week in quiet trading.

Not enough is known about strontium 90 for any public agency to map a course of protective action, the city's Department of Health asserted yesterday.
THE following dinner menu is a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in coat. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey opened the door yesterday wide enough to admit a draft for the Democratic nomination for either President or Vice President.
Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald has proposed that the public schools be closed next Sept. 22 and 23 for Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.
HOUSTON, April 24 (AP) -- Sonny Liston, who has developed an impressive string of knockouts, takes on defensive-minded Roy Harris tomorrow night in a ten-round heavyweight match.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Alex Rose has attempted to explain, in a letter published April 13, his party's nomination of Tammany Congressman Teller in spite of the Democratic primary contest being waged against him in his West Side district by reform candidate William Fitts Ryan.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The great American game is baseball. The great Cuban game is needling.

TURIN, Italy, April 24 -- At the end of the second round in the world championship bridge tournament here tonight, three of the four United States teams remained undefeated and two were leading their, sections.
BOSTON, April 24 -- Louis M. Lyons, curator of the Nieman Fellowships for Journalism at Harvard University, was honored at a dinner tonight by some 300 newspaper men and educators.

A study by the National Bureau of Economic Research finds that the tax immunity of local government bonds is no longer the big money saver for borrowing states and municipalities that it came to be during the Great Depression of the Ninetee Thirties and the era of rising Federal income taxes that followed.

BABYLON, L.I., April 24 -- Charles Dunn of the Centerport Yacht Club sailed his Screaming Mimi to victory in the five-race series for the Penguin Class regional championship, which was staged by the Babylon Y.C. yesterday and today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Committee on Housing of the Community Service Society urges public support of the budget for the Department of Buildings which is now before the Board of Estimate for approval. The department faces a gigantic task in carrying out its public responsibility.
TUNIS, April 24 -- Tunisia charged today that French troops and bombers had violated Tunisian territory.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would ask the Board of Estimate to start condemnation proceedings this week for construction of the proposed $25,683,000 wholesale fruit and produce market in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.
Awards totaling $1,400,000 to finance study by 303 scholar and artists in many fields were announced today by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, said today he would continue his efforts to pare down what he considered the exorbitant economic price Chancellor Adenauer was ready to pay for France's political friendship.
PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) -- Elroy Face checked a Milwaukee rally in the ninth inning today and the Pittsburgh Pirates pulled out a 7-3 victory.
HAVANA, April 25 -- Cuban naval authorities captured a stolen yacht today and arrested two American castaways who are wanted for murder.
SEOUL, Tuesday, April 26 (UPI) -- Uncontrolled rioting raged in Seoul today as more than 100,000 persons defied troops and tanks in anti-Government demonstrations near the mansion of President Rhee.

AT first sight the gleaming white sculptures by Lyman Kipp (Parsons Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street) look like an architect's fantasy of a North African city. These structures, mounted on stands and seen from above, are, however, sculptures, and it is the nuance of difference between an architect's model and an independent work of art that makes them interesting.

PAUL OSBORN'S "Morning's at Seven" was one of the author's earlier plays and structurally not one of his soundest; the comedy of the four sisters and their families living very close together and feeling the pressures of the sunset years tends to be richer in promise than fulfillment.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a frightening experience for pedestrians to cross streets in New York City. When the lights are green, automobiles are allowed to make a turn and thus cross the pedestrian's path at the same time.
NEWARK, April 25 -- Superior Court Judge David A. Pindar today struck the words "Protestant" and "gentile" from a will that set up a scholarship loan found at Amherst College.
Twenty-eight Soviet tourists from Tiflis in Georgia, uniformly armed with cameras and souvenirs to give away, visited the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and Columbia University yesterday.

Louis E. Wolfson, the Florida industrialist who a few years ago tried unsuccessfully to take over Montgomery Ward Co., offered yesterday to step out of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation picture. But Mr. Wolfson tied a long string to the offer.

NOTHING is more tiresome than foot troubles unless it is the tedious job of finding shoes that fit properly. Since 1919, the Tree Mark Shoe Stores, which now number three, have made it their business to cope with foot difficulties.
Lee Higginson Corporation and C.E. Unterberg, Towbin Company and associated investment bankers are offering to the public today 208,460 common shares of Mill Factors Corporation at $11 a share.

A revue that will be devoted to a commentary on the manners and mores of Greenwich Village life as it is lived today is being prepared for off-Broad-way presentation next September. Entitled "Greenwich Village, USA," it will be sponsored by Allen Hodshire.

In the Manhattan telephone directory, there are 1,500 company names containing the word "United" as part of their corporate or business title. There are also 500 registered trademarks in which the word is used.
Steel production this week is scheduled to show a slight increase for the second consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The six-story apartment building at 624 East 222d Street in the Bronx has been sold by the 624 East 222nd Street Realty Company to Irving Byron, real estate operator. The sale was negotiated by Leonard, Levites, Schiller, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Treasury announced today that it would stick to established procedure in refinancing $6,400,000,000 of debt that matures on May 15 -- that is, it would offer a new issue, or issues, of securities to holders of the old.

One of the last large loft buildings constructed in Manhattan has been acquired by the Estate Securities Company, of which Alvin A, Levy and Irving Magot are executive officers. The property, at 338-40 West Thirty-ninth Street, near Ninth Avenue, was sold by clients of Abraham Slifka, broker in the transaction.
Business news remained uninspiring yesterday and the stock market had another heavy day, losing almost $3,200,000,000 of New York Stock Exchange market value and closing just above the lows.
CHICAGO, April 25 -- Gov. William F. Quinn of the State of Hawaii urged the nation's school boards here today to train leaders to follow and defend democracy.
Lalan Parrott, pianist, who studied with Rosina Lhevinne at the Juilliard School of Music, played a debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night that reflected credit on both pupil and teacher.
A split between two landlords' associations threatened to widen yesterday as the city pressed its drive to seize and rebuild tenements in which families were packed into single rooms.

GENEVA, April 25 -- Western diplomats, with the United States Congress peering questioningly over their shoulders, resumed negotiations with the Soviet Union today on a treaty to end tests of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to look into a complex legal tangle that developed from efforts of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to get a ten-million-dollar loan to repair equipment damaged by 1955 hurricanes.
The way was paved yesterday for eventual transfer of control of the nation's fourth largest mutual fund group.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Scientists proposed a new theory today on how the elements of the universe are created. The theory is that they are manufactured in nuclear cauldrons of giant, dying, stars.
The city sweltered yesterday in temperatures that the Weather Bureau said rose to a high of 85.6 degrees. Many home thermometers however, registered 90 or more.
COLRAIN, Mass., April 25 -- Something happened to spring last week-end around here, and for trout fishermen it was not especially good. What happened was rain, raw weather and rising water.

Commission house buying, short covering and new buying raised cocoa prices yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market closed near the highs of the day. Importer and dealer selling supplied the contracts.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, April 26 -- President Syngman Rhee announced today that he would resign "if the people desire" following a night of frenzied display of public anger against his regime.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- United States officials appeared tonight to welcome the news from Seoul of the apparent capitulation of President Syngman Rhee. They expressed the hope that any transition in the make-up of the South Korean Government would take place without weakening its status as a democratic outpost in Northeast Asia.
FOUR dogs lived a human's life yesterday. They were fitted for raincoats to be modeled in a fashion show today.
HOLLYWOOD. Calif., April 25 -- An enormous movie honor roll, with some 1,000 notables of filmland history, will not include Charlie Chaplin.
A proposal to endorse Judge Samuel R. Pierce Jr. for the General Sessions bench was voted down, 47 to 14, by the Tammany executive committee yesterday.

The Municipal Art Society came out yesterday against a sidewalk cafe for Central Park and noted that if other worthy schemes had been accepted in the past, the park would long since have been crowded out of existence.
Two leading Protestant churchmen said yesterday in an article in the magazine Look that they would feel "uneasy" if a Roman Catholic was elected President.
EXETER, N.H., April 25 -- Four out of every five eggs shipped abroad for breeding stock in the broiler industry bear the label of Nichols, Inc., a New England-based chicken farm operation.

NEW DELHI, India, April 25 -- The largest Indian economic project to be financed exclusively with United States funds was announced today. It will provide northeastern India with a 250,000-kilowatt electric power plant.

A new automatic tenpin bowling machine has received temporary sanction from the New Equipment Committee of the American Bowling Congress. This device, the third such to gain this much recognition by the A.B.C., probably will be in general use within a year.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that a charge of unfair labor practice might not be brought after a statutory six-month limit fixed by the National Labor Relations Act even when the asserted offense was a continuing one.
ST. LOUIS, April 25-More than 1,000 intensely political women descended on this sw tering city today from all parts of the nation to talk about practically everything but partisan politics.
The Federal court trail of a $500,000 damage suit by an electrician who has come, in contact with radioactive cobalt-60 ended here in a "hopelessly deadlocked' jury at 10:55 P.M. yesterday.

Net income of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) in the quarter ended on March 31 declined to $5,066,000, or $1.01 a common share, from $5,096,000, or $1.02 a share, in the 1959 period, Charles E. Spahr, president, reported at the annual meeting in Cleveland yesterday.
TURIN, Italy, April 25 -- France defeated the United States' Spingold Two team, 41 -- 34, overcoming an early Spingold Two lead.

The New York Young Republican Club heard an optimistic report on the state of the nation's defenses last night. Murray Snyder, Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs, told the club the United States was not slipping behind the Russians.

TRENTON, April 25 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, with seventy-one votes, outscored other Democratic and Republican candidates as the write-in choice for President in last Tuesday's primary election in Mercer County.
MADRID, April 25 -- The world's loudest noise?
Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers are expected to share the city's welcome today to President de Gaulle of France.
BILOXI, Miss., April 25 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People denied today a civic leader's charge that it had inspired racial riots here over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Citizens Foreign Aid Committee assailed the foreign aid program today as illegal and asked that President Eisenhower's $4,175,000,000 aid requests be slashed to $2,000,000,000.
DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- The Ford Falcon has moved into fourth place among all domestic cars in 1960 calendar year production and now trails third-place Rambler by fewer than 5,000 units.

A research project now under way at Brooklyn College may shed light on the mystery of why ducks, even those newly hatched, follow their mother. If so, the study also may give psychologists new insight into the effect of early experience on later behavior.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Heavy general selling of old crop soybean futures sent the May contract to its lowest price of the season today in a generally weak market.
GENEVA, April 25 -- The United States urged the eighty-eight-nation Conference on the Law of the Sea tonight to bring its six-week session here to a "successful and constructive conclusion" tomorrow.
The market for United States government securities scored a modest improvement yesterday, but for reasons not related to the Treasury's decisions about the pending $6,000,000,000 financing.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- House investigators began closed hearings today on the business dealings of Dick Clark, television disk jockey. The public will be allowed to listen in beginning tomorrow.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., April 25 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota campaigned across economically hard-hit areas of West Virginia today earning against rich men who night try to buy elections.

NEW DELHI, India, Tuesday, April 26 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Premier Chou En-lai issued a joint communique last night, indicating that their talks on the border dispute between India and Communist China had ended in a deadlock.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller today signed the second of two bills passed by the 1960 Legislature to crack down on motorists who drive while under the influence of alcohol.

Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that the United States should not agree to end nuclear test explosions unless the Russians demonstrated that they could be trusted to observe such an agreement.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- American business men were told today that it was their responsibility, not the Government's, to wipe out United States deficits in the balance of payments in foreign trade.

The traditional spring spate of corporate annual meetings will reach somewhat of a climax today. About eighty major companies will stage stockholder sessions, reporting on the last year's accomplishments or lack thereof and the outlook for the future.
About 600 oh-ing and ahing youngsters, many of whom had never seen a circus before, were guests yesterday at Madison Square Garden for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 25 -- The "L.B.J. All The Way" outriders are about to blanket seventeen Western states with Lydon B. Johnson for President Volunteers.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 25 (AP) -- A state official charged today that the National Broadcasting Company had "staged and directed" racial demonstrations involving Negro college students in Montgomery.

JEAN VERDIER, France's most important policeman, came to this country shortly before the arrival of President de Gaulle last Friday. The police official had an extremely important role in General de Gaulle's visit, but his presence here caused hardly a ripple as far as the public was concerned.

TRENTON, April 25 -- The State Senate and Assembly approved and rushed to Gov. Robert B. Meyner tonight a bill that would permit and finance the relocation of New York City's Washington Market to the Jersey City Meadows.

There are conditions under which a city employe may, under the Code of Ethics, buy property from the city at public auction and dabble in real estate, the Board of Ethics ruled yesterday.
LONDON, April 25 -- One of Britain's most important labor leaders vehemently assailed today Communist attempts to gain control of unions.

The apparel manufacturing trades are witnessing a revolt against the demand of retailers for undue price concessions and advertising allowances, Bertram L. Reinitz, executive director of the industrial council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., asserted last night.
PARIS, April 25 -- France called upon President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia today to maintain order in his country and protect French nationals living there.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 25 -- More than 200 dead, mostly women and children, were recovered from the wreckage of the earthquake-shattered town of Lar today.
The recipients of eighteen awards by the National Institute of Arts and Letters for 1960 were named yesterday. The awards, $1,500 each, are given annually to artists, writers and composers.

The Allied Chemical Corporation seems likely to set a new earnings record this year, Kerby H. Fisk, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company hall, 60 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Dr. Hans A. Bethe accused opponents of an atomic test ban tonight of having raised "most unlikely technical difficulties" in an attempt to defeat an agreement with the Soviet Union.

LAST evening at the 41st Street Theatre, Maria Fein, a red-haired woman wearing a black gown, pearls and a toothy smile, seated herself at a table decorated with flickering candles and covered with a red velvet cloth.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The program under which United States agricultural surpluses are sent abroad for free distribution to needy populations has run into abuses in some countries, with charges ranging to theft and black marketing, Congress has been told.

The Greater New York Fund opened its 1960 campaign yesterday with a goal of $11,000,000 to support 425 health, medical and welfare agencies. The sum represents the amount the agencies cannot raise by their own efforts but must have to continue their services.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : As a parent fast approaching 80 I am in a position to reply to the proposal of Joseph P. Frary, as made in his letter published April 21.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A Defense Department consultant testified today that the Pentagon was ill-organized to exploit modern weapons. He also said the State Department was inadequately geared to military problems and strategy.

WASHINGTON, April 2o -- Elwood R. Quesada, Federal Aviation Agency administrator, said tonighte that inspection of all Electra airliners supported his agency's finding that the planes were safe under current speed restrictions.

WILLIAMSON, W. Va., April 25 -- Senator John F. Kennedy carried his bid for support in the West Virginia primary May 10 into the economically depressed counties of the south-western part of the state today. Here unemployment and economic stagnation appeared to override questions of religious faith.

STRATFORD, Conn., April 25 -- A young man who had never before set foot in a legitimate theatre came out of the first performance of the American Shakespeare Festival's school season here this afternoon with a favorable report:
KANSAS CITY, April 25 -- The big issue in the Midwest in the Presidential campaign will be farm discontent, Paul M. Butler said today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Jim Gentile smashed a three-run homer in the first inning tonight to help the Baltimore Orioles snap a five-game losing streak with a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators.
A PLAY presented in a church always seems to have an extra dimension of solidity and pageantry.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of April 20, commending Negro student protestors, you have pointed out that fairminded Americans are aroused as never before by the injustice of racial segregation. Through sit-in demonstrations these courageous young people have made countless Americans understand that equality and justice are not abstractions, but as elementary as food and drink when you are hungry and thirsty.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to pass on the constitutionality of Sunday blue laws.
Fifty-five plainclothes policemen will be transferred to new squads today in the Police Department's drive against gambling.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President de Gaulle, in an address before a joint session of Congress, declared today that the "last moment" had been reached for an East-West agreement to avoid nuclear disaster."
Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. said here yesterday that the United States was approaching the summit meeting next month with real strength.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands, April 25 (Reuters) -- World shipping lagged "disappointingly" behind the favorable development of the world's business cycle last year, according to the 1959 report of the Royal Netherlands Shipowners Association, published here today.

Mr. Izenour is research associate at Yale's School of Drama and director of the school's Electro-Mechanical Research Laboratory.
The Federal courts refused yesterday for the third time this month to halt the picketing of the United Arab Republic ship Cleopatra. The ship has been idle here since April 13.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 25 -- The voters of Laos appear to have dealt smashing defeats to most pro-Communist candidates in yesterday's elections for the National Assembly.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller authorized today an increase in the maximum benefits provided by the state's three social insurance programs. He also approved the extension of two of them to include 100,000 more workers.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Deputy Attorney General Lawrence E. Walsh announced today the entry of a consent judgment at Memphis, Tenn., to end voting discriminations against Negroes in Fayette County, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana warned fellow Democrats today to steer clear of "a synthetic struggle" over religion lest they defeat themselves in the November Presidential election.
Resident buying offices reported summer merchandise was moving well last week. Demand was particularly brisk in both men's and women's cool and washable clothes.

Public financing of the $24,990,000 Carmen-Smith hydroelectric project is being planned for this summer by the Eugene Water and Electric Board of Eugene, Ore., according to an announcement yesterday by L. W. Trommlitz, president of the board.
PARIS, April 25 -- Jacques Soustelle, once one of President de Gaulle's most powerful supporters, was expelled tonight from the Gaullist Union for the New Republic.

Private preparatory schools are following the lead of colleges in solving a problem common to both of them: how to get the qualified student who has been turned down by the school of his choice to the school that still has openings to fill.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Consumer Price Index inched up to a record last month, primarily because food prices began the upward movement that is customary in this season.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- One of the world's leading astronomers urged today that the United States build a radio telescope almost a half mile across -- dwarfing any existing or planned.

Armstrong Cork Co. First-quarter estimated earnings of the Armstrong Cork Company dipped slightly compared with the 1959 period despite a small sales gain. Stockholders were told this yesterday at the annual meeting in Lancaster, Pa., by C.J. Backstrand, president.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A committee of mayors including Mayor Wagner of New York urged President Eisenhower today to reappoint William R. Connole to the Federal Power Commission.

MOSCOW, April 25 -- Premier Khrushchev sternly warned the Western powers today that they would "lose the right of entry into West Berlin by air, water or land" under a Soviet-East German peace treaty.
HOUSTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Charles (Sonny) Liston stopped Roy Harris at 2:35 in the first round tonight.
Onondaga Lake at Syracuse has been chosen as the site of the United States Olympic rowing trials.

Many well known persons entertained guests last night at the dinner dance given for the Laubach Literacy Fund in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East. Members of the diplomatic corps in Washington and the United Nations were among the distinguished guests.

The New York Titans of the new American Football League disclosed a seven-game home schedule for their first season at a luncheon here yesterday. There will be two Sunday afternoon games, four Friday night games and an afternoon contest on Thanksgiving Day.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- An experimental device, known as Alice, is being built to see if temperatures greater than those of the sun can be sustained in the laboratory.

Record sales and an increase of 19 per cent in net income were reported for its fiscal year ended Jan. 30 by the City Stores Company. The organization includes Franklin Simon. Oppenheim Collins and Hearn's stores in its retail chain.
RABAT, Morocco, Tuesday, April 26 -- The evacuation of United States military installations in Morocco hit a new snag today because of the presence of French troops on early warning radar sites.

LONDON, April 25 -- A proposal for an agreement with the Soviet Union on an arms embargo for new nations in Africa is part of Britain's program for the summit conference next month, qualified diplomatic sources said today.
