WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Four Democratic Senators introduced legislation today to permit voluntary confessions to be admissible as evidence in Federal criminal trials. This would affect a Supreme Court ruling.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 25 -- The police are making an Island-wide search for Antonios Pharmakides, editor of the Greek Cypriote newspapers, who was attacked and kidnapped this morning.

Mayor Wagner and Liberal party leaders agreed yesterday to maintain close liaison during the Democratic National Convention in July. Mr. Wagner will keep the Liberal leaders informed on the sentiment and developments within the 114-vote New York State delegation.
TRENTON, April 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called today for a 1-cent-a-pack increase in the 5-cent state tax on cigarettes.

Trout fishing de luxe, sans the usual discomforts of early rising, a long ride to a mountain stream and hip boots will be a feature of the Community Service Society's outdoor family fair in Rockefeller Plaza on May 21 and 22.
MARTHA GRAHAM brought her company back to the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre last night to open a two-wek season of repertory.

A Liberal party study has found that sales of Manhattan real estate averaged 44.3 per cent higher in price for the first six months last year than the city's assessed valuations for tax purposes. The gap was said to have increased steadily since 1950.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 25 -- The Long Island Sound team of International One-Design Class sailors was badly beaten by the Bermuda Yacht Club team in the first race of the Amorita Cup series today.
LONDON, April 25 -- The cloud that has been hovering over the stock market here for the last three weeks darkened today and virtually every section finished lower.

In yesterday's listing of newly published books, "But Not For Love," a novel about life in a Long Island art colony, by May Natalie Tabak, was mistakenly credited to the wrong publisher. Its correct publisher is Horizon Press.

KANSAS CITY, April 25 (AP) -- Three-hit pitching by Bud Daley and a five-run inning gave the Kansas City Athletics a 6-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

Mike Sorrentino, a 30-year-old jockey from Baldwin Harbor, L.I., was the riding star before 28,634 fans at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-foot, 111-pound rider rode three winners and accounted for both ends of the $168.10 daily double.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 to 19 points (35 to 95 cents a bale) up yesterday.

Maurice Evans and Juditt Andersen will co-star in a twohour television production of "Macbeth," to be filmed in color "on location" in Scotland and England this summer.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 27 -- The resignation of President Syngman Rhee was regarded by officials in Washington as a necessary step in ending the political crisis in South Korea.
Martin and Gordon Schulman, brothers who trade in Greenwich Village real estate, were accused of speculation and profiteering yesterday as they appeared in separate court actions.
Two oddities of nature were puzzling officials of the Bronx Zoo yesterday. One is a fourteen-foot python with the hic-cups; the other is a pair of tigers that like people but try to kill each other.
The Phillips Petroleum Company of Bartlesville, Okla., is starting the largest advertising campaign in its history to introduce a new gasoline and motor oil -- New Flite-Fuel and New Trop-Artic.

The American Civil Liberties Union, which has been at 170 Fifth Avenue for twenty years, will move to 156 Fifth Avenue at Twentieth Street. The new quarters about triple the space now used and will be occupied in June.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season yesterday with the playing of interclub team matches. More than 600 golfers from Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island competed.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 26 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion urged the world's socialist leaders tonight to concern themselves less with class warfare and more with a struggle to achieve the equality of nations.

BOSTON, Wednesday, April 27 -- Massachusetts voters of both parties gave Senator John F. Kennedy, a Democrat and a native son, encouraging support for the Presidential nomination yesterday in a primary marked by light balloting.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President de Gaulle said good-by to President Eisenhower and Washington today. This ended a state visit that brought no great change in international relations but lighted up the road to the summit.

Like a mighty feat of leger-demain, the center ring of the Greatest Show on Earth was transported early yesterday from Madison Square Garden to a small, gaily decorated ball-room at the Belvedere Hotel.

Eddie Arcaro, who has ridden in the last sixteen Kentucky Derbies and has won the race five times, said at Aqueduct yesterday that he had no definite commitment for the running of the May 7 Churchill Downs fixture.
LONDON, April 26 -- Uncertainty continued to inhibit demand on the stock market here today. However, the steels, motors and oils finished higher as did several individual industrials.
Roger M. Blough, chairman of United States Steel Corporation, yesterday placed himself in the ranks of undaunted optimists.
GENEVA, April 26 -- A six-week effort by an eighty-eight-nation conference to resolve differences over the territorial sea and fishing rights failed here today by one vote.
Executives of United Press International said yesterday that 1959 had been the biggest and one of the best of the news agency's fifty-three years.

JACK PAAR'S second excursion into prime evening television, which occurred last night over Channel 4, had some highly enjoyable sequences of light variety. It also contained recorded excerpts from previous Paar late-night shows, including another reference to his celebrated farewell and return, which fared less well.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The National Education Association predicted today a continuation of the national short-age of 135,000 qualified teachers. The forecast came in the group's annual report on "Teacher Supply and Demand" issued today.

NEWARK, April 26 (AP) -- A meeting of 350 members of the Essex County Democratic Committee ended in a near-riot tonight, with one faction claiming victory and another claiming that there never was an election and threatening to take the matter into court.
ALBANY, April 26 -- Governor Rockefeller signed four ils today to curb reckless otorboat operators on the ate's waterways.

More than a thousand representatives of parishes, parochial schools and religious organizations in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York met yesterday to learn effective ways of combating the distribution of obscene material.
The New York Madrigal Society presented Jeannetta New, soprano, and Virginia - Gene Shankel, violinist, winners of its annual Debut Award, in a joint recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

The combination of mild January and February, raised operating expenses and additional shares outstanding caused declines in net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. for the three and twelve months ended on March 31, the company reported yesterday.

Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy reserved decision yesterday on a petition to enjoin a stockholders' meeting in Cleveland on Friday to vote on a proposed merger between the Industrial Rayon Corporation of Cleveland and the Texas Butadiene and Chemical Corporation of Channelview, Tex.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra closed its New York season last night in Carnegie Hall to the rousing climax of some 200 young voices fervently chanting "Hac in hora, sine mora, corde pulsum tangite ***" The music was, of course, Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana," as sung by the Rutgers University Choir and helped by a vocal trio consisting of Janice Harsanyi, Rudolf Petrak and Harve Presnell.

Coach Al Stubbins of the New York American Soccer Club demonstrated yesterday that he can make a quick decision. Ten minutes after the first tryout of his team at Randalls Island, he selected ten United States players.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 26 (AP) -- Bill Nicks, a 36-year-old road builder from Los Angeles, ousted the medalist, Herb Durham of Dallas, 1 up, today in first-round match play in the North and South amateur golf tournament.
AT the end of the first half of "Brouhaha," which opened last evening at the 175 East Broadway Playhouse, David Hurst hurls himself on stage as a Russian envoy, O.O. Protopopoff, naturally.

DETROIT, April 26 (AP) -- Vie Power's two-cut single in the twelfth inning resulted in a 2-1 Cleveland Indian victory over the Detroit Tigers today. The loss was Detroit's first in six games this season.

MEXICO CITY, April 26 -- The American-owned Impulsora de Empresas Electricas, second largest privately operated electric manufacturing and distributing company in Mexico, was sold to the Mexican Government today.
IN her twenty-nine years of marriage Mme. Yvonne de Gaulle has never given her illustrious husband any competition, for the limelight.

Stockholders of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad elected J.R. Thorne to the board at their annual meeting in Richmond, Va., yesterday. Mr. Thorne, executive vice president of the carrier, succeeds the late Fred G. Boyce Jr. of Baltimore.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26 -- Harvard University was picked tonight to win the Ivy League football championship this year by the sports information directors of the eight colleges in the group.
Following are some of the figures prominent in the current crisis in South Korea:
Justice George Postel of the Domestic Relations Court was designated yesterday as the Democratic organization candidate for General Sessions Judge.

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the challenger in the world chess championship match in Moscow, defeated Mikhail Botvinnik in the seventeenth game yesterday after forty-one moves, according to a report from the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Communist agents are infiltrating the United States more than ever and are showing an "insatiable" appetite for information, an official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- A program of twenty-seven pictures that include films starring Danny Kaye, Frank Sinatra and John Wayne was announced today by Paramount for the next eighteen months. The schedule includes four pictures already in production and some announced previously.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Dick Clark, disk jockey, was accused today of having paid others in his field to play records in which he had an interest.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- A bizarre story of attempted bribery of the chief witness in a narcotics conspiracy trial was unfolded today in the Supreme Court.
Labor-management cooperation to stop a trend toward fewer newspapers and management action to keep the press free of payola were proposed here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown said today he was constitutionally prohibited from extending clemency in the Caryl Chessman case, "barring unexpected developments of a truly critical nature."
ATLANTA, April 26 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Atheletic Association voted today against honoring suspensions imposed on college athletes by the Amateur Athletic Union.
PRETORIA, South Africa, April 26 (Reuters) -- The police raided more African townships today, arresting more than 200 persons.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced the award of a contract today for building a 300-pound payload to be landed on the moon next year.

LONDON, April 26 -- Diplomatic sources said today the British Government was convinced that Premier Khrushchev would avoid aggressive, dramatic action on the question of West Berlin at the summit conference or immediately thereafter.
The newly constituted board of directors of The Associated Press, at its annual meeting yesterday, re-elected Benjamin M. McKelway, editor of The Washington Star, as president of the A.P.
PARIS. Western policy for next month's summit meeting is based on the following maxim: "Put your trust in God, my boys, and keep your statesmen in orbit."

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- In what may have been a surprise to him, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson received posies today instead of the usual brickbats from Senators reviewing his agency's spending.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 27 -- Incomplete returns indicated early today that yesterday's Pennsylvania Presidential preference primary had produced only one surprise.
LONDON, April 26 (UPI) -- Brian London, the former heavyweight champion of the British Empire, knocked out Pete Rademacher in the seventh round tonight.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 26 -- Developments in the International Race Week sailing today indicated that the Amorita Cup would remain in these islands another year.

It is impossible for a New Yorker to think of the visit of a great French general to our city without thinking of those memorable days in August, 1824, when General Lafayette came ashore in New York on his last visit to the United States. Nothing could be more natural and nothing more apropos, even though we sincerely hope and believe that this is by no means a farewell visit for President Charles de Gaulle.

James Daly has become the third performer to be announced for the role of Mark Twain in the author's autobiography, Roughing It," a pending television production that has been rough road for Robert Saudek associates.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Despite accolades for the nation's high school system, it is still in the "horse and buggy stage" of organization and management, the convention of the National School Boards Association was told today.
GENEVA, April 26 -- The West built political positions today for the summit meeting by formally presenting to the Communist nations its basic conditions for total disarmament.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26 -- The United Nations is making plans to send a team of experts to help prepare Ruanda-Urundi, an African trust territory, for independence in 1961.

In a particularly poignant tragedy for all concerned, South Korea, created under United Nations auspices as a free and democratic state, is now in the throes of a full-fledged revolution which has toppled the regime of President Syngman Rhee and has left the country for the moment without effective government in the face of the continued Communist menace from the north.

TURIN, Italy, April 26 -- European players continued to dominate the world championship tournament as the fourth and fifth rounds were completed today. American teams were struggling to qualify for the finals.
A Philadelphian told fifty officials of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut municipalities yesterday how to go about getting better commuter railroad service at reduced fares.

CUSTARDS in their infinite variety are among the best desserts for springtime meals. Plain or fancy, baked or stirred, they are delicious eating. They also supply high quality protein to round out menu deficiencies that often result when hearty winter meals are replaced by the more appealing warm weather types.
New York's French colony saluted President de Gaulle yesterday with a great outpouring of cheers and champagne.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Late last week a high official of the Soviet Government slipped quietly into Washington on a "private" mission. He talked to several officials here without creating any stir, and flew out of Idlewild tonight as quietly as he arrived.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The National Academy of Sciences elected thirty-five new members today and named Lloyd V. Berkner treasurer.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The company that bought the drug Orinase to this country for diabetes sufferers denied today that it wielded monopolistic powers over its sale, or that the price was excessive.
CAIRO, April 26 -- Trade union leaders here announced today that an Arab boycott of United States vessels would begin at midnight Friday unless picketing of the Cleopatra in New York was halted.
The major steel producers and the United Steelworkers of America are completing arrangements for a joint committee to seek more peaceful long-term relationships.

Fordham's baseball team mounted a fourteen-hit attack and beat Manhattan, 7-5, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. The loss was the first in seven Metropolitan Conference games for the league-leading Jaspers, who made five errors in the game.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. ordered the military services today to hold publication of manuals to the minimum. He also ordered that the services make sure those they did publish were needed, accurate and in "good taste."

The Banshees, a New York newspaper men's club, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary here yesterday with a luncheon in honor of 2,000 editors, publishers and guests attending the convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The Franklin Corporation, an affiliate of the Franklin National Bank of Long Island, filed a registration statement yesterday for an issue of 1,000,000 shares of common stock at $10 a share. Franklin Corporation is a closed-end, non-diversified management company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 and a licensee under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- For the second day in a row a three-run homer by Jim Gentile of the Orioles defeated the Senators.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 26 -- Railroads can easily handle all engineering problems of commuter transportation if the people correct the old-fashioned thinking of public officials, suburban leaders were told today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Clarence N. Sayen, president of the Air Lines Pilots Association, accused the Federal Aviation Agency today of imposing a 60-year age limit on commercial jet pilots to help certain airlines get rid of their older fliers.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Eisenhower officially approved today plans for a series of labor-management conferences on broad economic issues.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having just returned from a month's visit to Argentina I am amazed to read the comments of several American newspapers, and especially The New York Times, in connection with the outcome of the Argentine elections.
New York City's Salute to Japanese garden on the steps of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The two five-story buildings at 29 and 31 East Sixty-sixth Street, which were sold recently by Cassini Brothers to clients of Walter Scott Co., have been resold to investing clients of David Fischoff, lawyer. The houses are on a plot of 34 by 100 feet.

Securities of a utility, a shoe manufacturer, an automobile upholstery maker and a car and truck rental concern were offered to the public yesterday. The securities were valued at more than $36,000,000.

The writer of the following letter is a former Justice of the Municipal Court and an officer of the American Civil Liberties Union. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your wiretapping editorial of April 16 is timely and excellent -- as far as it goes.

FIFTEEN years ago most Americans believed that most Japanese were bloody-minded barbarians, fanatical militarists, benighted worshipers of a divine Emperor. Today most Americans who think about the Japanese at ail seem to believe that most of them are quaint and charming members of a delightful civilization with esthetic perceptions and traditions rarer and finer than anything the West can claim.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Investment abroad by American business typically does not "export jobs," a Congressional inquiry was told today.
KEYSER, W. Va., April 26 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota spoke bitterly today of the advantages of wealth that he attributed to Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
France's First Lady, Mme. Yvonne de Gaulle, and New York met for the first time yesterday. Both seemed to enjoy it.

CINCINNATI, April 26 (UPI) -- Del Crandall's eleventh-inning homer, his first of the season, gave the Milwaukee Braves a 4-3 victory over the Reds tonight. Warren Spahn went the route to his first victory of the season.
Cotton futures moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

KANSAS CITY, April 26 (UPI) -- Bob Shaw became the first Chicago White Sox pitcher to last more than five innings tonight, ending Chicago's four-game losing streak with an 8-0 shutout of the Kansas City Athletics.

FASHIONS from two continents had one of the biggest nights out in years at last night's gala dinner honoring Gen. Charles de Gaulle at the Waldorf-Astoria, followed by the glittering April in Paris Ball at the Astor Hotel.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Anthony J. Accardo, so-called elder statesman of organized crime in Chicago, was arrested today on a Federal indictment accusing him of having falsified his income tax returns for 1956, 1957 and 1958.

Most of the experienced rallyists in the East are entered for the ninth annual Yankee Monte Carlo Rally, to be run Friday, Saturday and Sunday by the Connecticut Sports Car Club. The event has been sanctioned by both the New York and the New England Regions of the Sports Car Club of AmerCar Club, Long Island Center.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 26 -- Connecticut's right to suspend summarily the licenses of convicted speeders was upheld in Superior Court here today.
MONTREAL, April 26 -- The Labor Congress will join a world-wide boycott next Sunday of South African consumer goods.
A cloud no bigger than a baseball catcher's mitt hovered yesterday over the proposed stadium for Flushing Park, Queens.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 26 -- Dr. Fazil Kutchuk asserted today that Cypriotes of Greek and Turkish origin were in closer harmony than they had been for five years.
SEOUL, Wednesday, April 27 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Huh Chung announced today that President Rhee had sent his formal resignation to the Cabinet Secretariat to be relayed to the National Assembly.

The efforts of Southern Negroes to attain full civil rights were described yesterday by Edward P. Morgan, the radio news commentator, as "a momentous cause which should be supported by all Americans."

THE American Ballet Theatre presented last night the second premiere of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House. This was Herbert Ross' "Dialogues (Serenade for Seven)," set to Leonard Bernstein's "Serenade for Violin Solo, Strings and Percussion," with decor and lighting by Jean Rosenthal and costumes by Florence Klotz.

SHUSHAN, N.Y., April 26 -- Okey Butcher is getting his ciscoes smoked, now that the Battenkill is a little high for his kind of trout fishing. These are the ciscoes he caught through the ice of Hedges Lake in Jackson Township during the winter.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 26 -- Only six pacers were named today for Saturday night's $25,000 free-for-all at Roosevelt Raceway.
ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals routed Sam Jones with a four-run outburst in the first inning tonight, and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, alerted 200 officials of his union across the nation today to attend his Federal Court trial opening tomorrow and report to rank-and-file union members.

The 1959-60 appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought a record total of $557,701.89. This total, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the fund, compares with $493,736.09 for the 1958-1959 appeal and $449,286.11 for the 1957-58 appeal.

Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, said at the annual meeting yesterday that first - quarter share earnings about equaled those of last year, that the outlook for the future was "optimistic" and that the corporation had placed privately $32,000,000 of twenty-year notes at 5 per cent.
Market indicators disagreed yesterday, leaving speculators in doubt whether stocks had gone up 0.33 per cent or down 0.11 per cent.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, April 27 -- President Syngman Rhee resigned today "out of respect to the resolution of the National Assembly yesterday."
Twelve more persons were injured in automobile accidents here last week than in the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. The total injured last week was 987.
CHICAGO, April 26 (UPI) -- Don Drysdale held the Chicago Cubs to four hits today and the Los Angeles Dodgers registered an 8-1 decision.

George Abbott, Broadway's perennial promoter of hits and burgeoning talents, has been named winner of the Barter Theatre Award for this season. He was cited for his work as co-author and director of the prize-winning musical comedy, "Fiorello!"
PARIS, April 26 -- The French Parliament began its spring session today and, like Pandor opened the box of France's domestic troubles.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Vice President Nixon will represent the United States at the summit conference in Paris if President Eisenhower has to return to Washington at the end of a week because of "domestic requirements."

Paris came to Broadway last night in the form of the ninth annual April in Paris Ball. Some 1,000 brilliantly dressed persons paid $150 for the privilege of attending what is considered the most spectacular party of the New York social season.

The marketable debt of local governments was the chief interest in the bond market yesterday. The successive sales of large new issues brought buyers and sellers together in the busiest session for municipal securities in many weeks.

The active May potato position fell in early trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Liquidation and stop-loss selling followed Monday's sharp decline. The position staged a strong rally later in the session on trade buying and short covering.

At an A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting in Chicago Secretary of Labor Mitchell stated some of the facts of life bearing on survival of the railroads. tie remarked that the Federal Government subsidizes shipbuilding and losses of American flag lines; it deepens and develops inland waterways; it subsidizes airlines through construction of terminals and mail-carrying; it has subsidized truckers through building public roads.

SEOUL, Korea, April 27 -- Huh Chung, one of the few South Koreans who had dared oppose Syngman Rhee, succeeded him today as head of the Government. A legal attempt to lift at once the two-week old picket line established by American maritime unions against the United Arab Republic ship Cleopatra failed yesterday.
THE PRESIDENT Held news conference; greeted the King and Queen of Nepal, and gave White House dinner for them.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower welcomed King Mahendra and Queen Ratna of Nepal to the United States today.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower denied today that the United States Government had interfered in the political crisis in South Korea or had helped to incite disturbances in that country.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 27 -- A stockholders' battle for control of one of the richest properties of its kind in the world -- the $100,000,000 Santa Anita race track -- comes to a showdown here tomorrow.

In a televised auction sale here last night, fifty paintings and sculptures were sold to buyers in New York, Dallas, Los Angeles and Chicago for a total of $871,850. The money went to the Museum of Modern Art.
THE following dinner menu is a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

The National Steel Corporation had record profits in the first quarter of this year, George Humphrey, chairman, told the annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday. But he said, profits in the second quarter would fall below the first period's level.
ROCKY POINT, L.I., April 27 -- A powerful tractor tripped the legs from under two stately, 400-foot antenna towers here this afternoon.

The nation's privately owned public utility companies have been stepping up their financing activities this year. In the first quarter of 1960, they raised $959,899,000, or 10.2 per cent more than the $870,911,000 of financing completed during the 1959 period.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Labor Secretary James P. Mitchell proposed today that railroad labor and management work together for gradual elimination of Government subsidies to airlines, truckers and shipping lines.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 2 -- Of the $112,108 wagered in the win pool for the fourth race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, $3,948 backed Masland Hanover. This meant that the 6-year-old bay gelding went off at odds of 23-1, the outsider in the field of eight Class B-3 pacers.
NEWARK, April 27 -- Dennis Carcy's claim to the chairmanship of the Essex County Democratic Committee may face court test.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 -- President de Gaulle was acclaimed today on his arrival in the Paris of the West.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy amassed votes of unusual proportions in Pennsylvania's Presidential preference primary yesterday.

Sales of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., were the highest in its history in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. Earnings were the second best on record, according to the results issued for publication today by Bruce A. Gimbel, president.

A group of minority stockholders in the Industrial Rayon Corporation lost an action yesterday in Federal Court here to block a special stockholders meeting to vote on the proposed merger of Industrial Rayon and the Texas Butadiene and Chemical Corporation.
GENEVA, April 27 -- The West said today that it was willing to have the United Nations give its political judgment on the opposing Communist and Western approaches to disarmament.

George Roy Hill will direct Tennessee Williams' play, "Period of Adjustment," instead of Elia Kazan. Mr. Kazan asked to be relieved because of his involvement as producer-director of William Inge's impending film, "Splendor in the Grass."
Richard Praeger, like every loyal son of Flatbush, spent much of his childhood suffering as the Brooklyn Dodgers moved up and down (usually down) in the National League standing.

LONDON, April 27 (Reuters) -- Burnley became the favorite to win the English League's First Division soccer championship tonight when it beat Birmingham City, 1 --0, and rose to second place in the standing.

Short covering and heavy stop-loss buying raised potato prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Practically all the volume was in the May position, which was strongest. The May contract goes off the board on May 13.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, April 28 -- Vice President-elect Lee Ki Poong, his wife and two sons died in a suicide pact in a bungalow in the Presidential compound early today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 27 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., who races Sno Sus, won the Mamaroneck Frostbite Association sailing championship with a percentage of 93.531, according to official statistics announced by the regatta committee today.

The electric utility industry expects to add this year 12,000,000 kilowatts of new generating capability, raising the total to 170,500,000 k.w., according to the twenty-seventh semi-annual electric power survey released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- House payola investigators produced their first evidence today on the financial entanglements of Dick Clark, disk jockey.
ALBANY, April 27 -- A measure to help New York City landlords improve slum dwellings through loans was signed today by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower warned Premier Khrushchev gently today not to expect the United States to give up its legal rights to remain in Berlin.

The American Federation of Arts' fiftieth anniversary program will benefit from American Art, 1910-60. The display will open with a patron's preview on June 7, at M. Knoedler Co., Inc., at 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Production of electric power dipped last week to 13,213,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 13,263,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago output was 12,538,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

The Irish setter numerically is in twenty-seventh place among the 113 breeds registered by the American Kennel Club. "And we are perfectly satisfied with our standing," said Dr. Wolfgang A. Casper, a physician from Staten Island and a former president of the Eastern Irish Setter Association.

NEARLY three thousand youngsters -- from 8 to 18 years old -- recently gave their frank opinions about "tough" teachers versus easy ones, parental neglect, careers, important family decisions, hobbies, friends and money.
KATMANDU, Nepal, April 27 -- The Premiers of Communist China and Nepal flew today into the shadow of mighty Annapurna to discuss the strained relations between their countries.

CAIRO, April 27 (AP) -- All Arab ports on the Mediterranean and Red Seas will cut radio contact with American ships from midnight Friday unless the New York picketing of the freighter Cleopatra is stopped, the newspaper Al Goumhovriah said today.
Earnings of the General Motors Corporation for the first three months of 1960 climbed to a first-quarter record of $323,625,516 from $293,482,419 in the 1959 period, the company disclosed yesterday.

The Amateur Athletic Union said yesterday "a chaotic condition will prevail in amateur sport in the United States" if the National Collegiate Athletic Association refuses to recognize A.A.U. suspensions and disqualifications.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- One Federal judge disqualified himself from presiding over the trial of James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union. A second judge took over and quickly rejected a move by Mr. Hoffa to delay the case.

TORONTO, April 27 (Canadian Press) -- Shareholders of International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., approved today a proposal to split the company's shares on a two-for-one basis at their annual meeting.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, April 28 -- Huh Chung, who became Acting President when President Syngman Rhee resigned yesterday, turned today to the task of curing the ills that led to the overthrow of the Rhee Government.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- After three earlier failures within the last two weeks, the May wheat futures today finally broke through its previous high for the season on two strong buying surges.

The nicest kind of birthday celebration a composer could wish for was given Wallingford Riegger in the Caspary Auditorium of the Rockefeller Institute last night.

TRENTON, April 27 -- New Jersey and Connecticut officials plan to meet early in May to discuss the imposition of special taxes on nonresidents employed in the two states.

Graduates of foreign medical schools fared poorly in an eight-hour examination last March 16 to determine whether they qualified as internes or residents in United States hospitals. The test was given here and in sixty-five countries abroad.
