TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are valid arguments on the side of Southerners in their fight against desegregation. As reflected in their letters to The Times, however, they seem to be missing most of them.

GILBERT HIGHET'S "The Powers of Poetry" is a book of splendid prejudices and controlled enthusiasms in the rocking world of verse. It is salted with wit and learning. You will not find a better introduction or a more informing companion to poetry anywhere.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- Secretary Mitchell's speech followed by a day a White House call for American business and labor to arrange a series of peace conferences to aim for better relations and assure the nation's economic growth.
LONDON, April 27 -- Prices again receded on the stock market here today.
AFTER going over the country once lightly, "West Side Story" has come home to the Winter Garden, where it reopened last evening.

Tests given in recent years to 160,000 elementary school pupils here have shown that the youngsters exceeded the national average scores for their age groups in reading and arithmetic and in some instances did better than older children on the same grade levels.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- State Department sources withheld comment tonight on the death of Lee Ki Poong, Vice President-elect of Korea, and his two sons and mother in an apparent suicide pact at Seoul.
Burgess Schuster, a righthander, limited City College to two hits yesterday as New York University tripped the Beavers, 8 to 0, in a Metropolitan Conference baseball game at Ohio Field in the Bronx.
The United Federation of Teachers voted last night for an indefinite work stoppage to begin May 17.

DENVER, April 27 -- Following are excerpts from the 20,000-word episcopal address presented tonight to the quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Church. A "state of the church" message, it bears the signatures of the seventy-four active and retired Methodist Bishops.

Sixteen families fighting eviction from their Greenwich Village tenement rejected yesterday a court proposal that they give up their court battle and accept their landlord's offer of more time to get out.

THE New York Chamber soloists opened their program at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night with a work inspired, in somewhat roundabout fashion, by America's great philosopher-gadgeteer Benjamin Franklin.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Exports zoomed in March to a level not reached for three years, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Aware that the Senators never -- well, hardly ever -- beat Whitey Ford, Casey Stengel let the Yankee left-hander pitch to one more batter in the eighth inning yesterday.

CREENFIELD, Mass., April 27 -- No final conclusions can be drawn yet from the Deerfield River trout reclamation project, which other states ought to be watching closely, but there are indications even now of significant success.
SIGHTS and sounds of Paris and London were brought to the television screen in two appealing programs last night.
A major revision of the Moore Commission's operations is in prospect to enable it to concentrate on preparing a new charter for New York City.
Professional basketball is going to the West Coast.
CHICAGO, April 27 -- Merit Scholarships valued at more than $4,000,000 were announced here today for 830 high school seniors.
NEWMARKET, England, April 27 (AP) -- Martial, owned by Reginald N. Webster, a New York financier, scored Ireland's first victory in the 152-year-old 2,000 Guineas stakes today.
The nation's stocks of residual fuel oil continued to decline last week, reaching the lowest level in almost three years.

Three new officers have been elected in the Colgate-Palmolive Company. George H. Lesch was elected president, it was announced yesterday by Edward H. Little, chairman and chief executive officer, following the board meeting.
CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves downed the Cincinnati Reds, 8-5, tonight in a 3-hour-12-minute marathon and completed a sweep of their two-game set.

Young memfcers of churches and synagogues in mid-Manhattan will come clothed as children from foreign lands for an international fair Saturday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The church is at Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.
The proposed 55,000-seat $15,000,000 sports stadium to be built in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, was informally approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate in executive session. The vote was 20 to 2.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Senator Humphrey, campaigning in West Virginia against Senator Kennedy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was invoking what in rhetoric is classified as the "suggestive" when he said to an audience yesterday:
Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street was atinkle with the samisen and aclash with the gong last night.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 27 -- Arrests of Africans mounted today as the Government continued the reimposition of strict controls on their lives.
LONDON, April 27 -- Britain envisages a joint space program with European, and Commonwealth governments based on the Blue Streak rocket, Duncan Sandys, Minister of Aviation, disclosed tonight.
Frank Capra, who returned to film production after an eight-year absence with last season's successful "A Hole in the Head," is planning an active schedule for the Nineteen Sixties.

ONE day last winter Charlie Conerly, a cotton farmer from Mississippi, wandered into the offices of the New York Football Giants. His timing was off. Jack and Wellington Mara, the owners of the team, were at the winter meeting of the National Football League in Florida, leaving only the office staff to hold the fort.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower confirmed today that William R. Connole would be dropped as a member of the Federal Power Commission.
For ninety minutes last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel an audience of 1,500 sat enthralled through a spoken and visual record of the last quarter-century.
Details of the sixteenth game of the world chess championship match in Moscow between Mikhail Botvinnik, the titleholder, and Mikhail Tal were received yesterday.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., April 27 -- Gus Salerno of Hampshire and Mario Laureti of the Darien Country Club scored a best-ball 31, 31 -- 62 for a four-stroke victory in the pro-and-pro event that opened the Westchester Professional Golfers Association tournament season today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 27 -- The Inter-American Congress for Democracy and Freedom closed today with no mention of the explosive Cuban issue.
A pageant of ceremonies and dances of the Orient will be presented the evening of May 11 in the ballroom of the Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today new international air fares across the North Atlantic.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
KANSAS CITY, April 27 (AP) -- Ray Herbert scattered six hits tonight to help the Kansas City Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 1.

Golden Fleece and National Coin Week When Jason and his companions set out aboard the ship Argo in quest of the Golden Fleece the facts of history and fancies of mythology were less carefully distinguished, but there seems now to be reason to believe that a sheep-skin washed in certain mountain streams might have taken on a pale yellow, metallic sheen from the presence of electrum in the water.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare announced the "heartening" news today that the amount of strontium 90 in the American diet did not represent a public health hazard.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (UPI) -- Vernon Law scored his third straight triumph tonight, as the Pittsburgh Pirates added to their National League lead with a 3-2 victory over the Phillies.

GROTON, Conn., April 27 -- A warning that Soviet submarines are being observed "farther and farther from their home bases" was sounded today at the launching of the Navy's first nuclear-powered hunter-killer submarine.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 27 -- Expulsion of the Dutch Reformed denominations of South Africa from the World Council of Churches because they support apartheid is not being contemplated now, Dr. W.A. Visser 't Hooft, the council's general secretary, said here today.
DENVER, April 27 -- The 10,000,000 Methodists in this country were reminded by their Bishops tonight that the Christian Church has no room for racial discrimination or enforced segregation.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Pioneeer V, the space vehicle shot into an orbit around the sun last March 11, has given a minimum dimension of 5,000,000 miles to a phenomenon that many have thought was centered on the earth.

MARTHA GRAHAM last night offered the first change of program in her season at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, substituting for the full-evening "Clytemnestra" three short pieces. Two of them were familiar -- "Night Journey" and "Seraphic Dialogue" -- but the third was brand new.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 to 7 points (5 to 35 cents a bale) off yesterday. The near May contract showed the only gain, up 1 point.
ONE of the most carefully guarded secrets in the British Empire these days is what Princess Margaret will wear on her wedding day.
"Yes, I got a nice raise, but I wish Jack Mara had told em about the advance ticket sale before I signed my contract."
LAR, Iran, April 27 -- The threat of disease hangs over survivors of the earthquake that shattered the center of Lar into gray dust Sunday afternoon.

The stage was set at Aqueduct yesterday for a contest between class and speed in the twenty-seventh running of the $27,700 Jamaica Handicap. But a 15-1 shot, Rare Rice, took the first money of $17,705.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday the appropriation of $10,500,000 for a pilot program to demonstrate how India's food output can be increased.
The city is considering a surcharge on industries that dump toxic chemical wastes into intercepting sewers.

Investment bankers managed by Johnston, Lemon Co. and Auchincloss, Parker Redpath are offering today the first public shares of Greater Washington Industrial Investments, Inc., a small business investment company.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27 (AP) -- Tompion, the early Kentucky Derby favorite, and Victoria Park, the pride of Canada, meet as half the field in tomorrow's $25,000-added Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to charges that he had accepted illegal gratuities and conspired to obstruct justice.
The Great South Bay Shopping Center on Montauk Highway, southwest corner of Saxon Avenue in Bay Shore, L.I., has been sold by Alexander Muss, the builder.

IN keeping with the changing face of Manhattan, one of the town's most revered culinary landmarks moved this week to sleek and spacious new quarters at 937 Second Avenue (near Forty-ninth Street). It is the bit of Scandinavia known as Nyborg Nelson, for nearly forty years purveyors of fine table delicacies from Sweden, Norway and Denmark.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Assertions that the Administration was trying to bolster Vice President Nixon's popularity with voters by identifying him with vital foreign-policy actions were made by prominent Senate Democrats today.

Russ Stewart will assume the chairmanship of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, and Jack Tarver will become vice chairman. They were elected to the bureau posts Tuesday.
HINTON, W. Va., April 27 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts interrupted his Presidential primary campaign here today and returned to Washington to vote on a mine safety bill.
BALTIMORE, April 27 (UPI) -- Arnie Portocarrero held the Boston Red Sox to six hits tonight in pitching the Baltimore Orioles to their third straight victory, 8 -- 3.
"Small World," Edward R. Murrow's venture in international cross-talk, will not be back next season.

Stockholders of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., elected three new directors at the annual meeting at the Commodore Hotel yesterday. They are John T. Dorrance Jr., Dr. Richard G. Folsom and August J. Thoma.
Traffic bottlenecks are invading once-speedy Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Another manual is troubling the Air Force. This one suggests that the Russians may have hoodwinked the United States into wasting money on useless planes.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- Following is the tranacript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
AT a $3.95 top, "Finian's Rainbow," which opened the new musical season at the City Center last night, is still pretty much of a bargain.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Three angry physicians seated side by side and a fourth one behind them argued today in a Senate hearing over whether a new anti-diabetic drug was dangerous.
Columbia College will permit able students to complete most of their work toward a master's degree while they are still undergraduates.

Gross operating revenues for the first quarter rose, but so did the net loss, the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey reported yesterday. Revenues reached $13,080,925, up from the 1959 period's $12,765,659. The deficit rose to $1,640,871 from $1,531,040.
Wall Street found itself with a shortage of enthusiasm in mid-afternoon yesterday and the stock market turned from a good gain to a moderate decline.

Allied Products Corp. Net income of Allied Products Corporation, automobile and appliance parts maker, in the first quarter totaled $70,577, or 9 cents a share, on sales of $4,598,721, it was announced at the annual meeting in Detroit yesterday.
LOME, Togo, April 27 -- Togoland today became Togo, the world's newest independent state.

A couture crisis boiled up at Barnard College yesterday as word spread through campus and corridor that skirts would be the only proper classroom attire from now on and that orders were being drafted to ban slacks and shorts.

The debt securities or local government continued to take the position of major interest in the bond market yesterday. Dealers holding large inventories made substantial placements of the new issues that came to market this week.
UMTATA, South Africa, April 27 -- "The Bantu are happy here," a government spokesman assured foreign visitors on a tour of the Transkei, South Africa's biggest "living space" for Negroes.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Democratic Congress broke out of the spring doldrums today and joined election-year battle with the White House on a broad political and legislative front.

"Captain of the Ile," the autobiography of Raoul de Beaudean, will be published May 9 by McGraw-Hill. Captain de Beaudean commanded the Ile de France on the night in July, 1956, when the Andrea Doria and the Stockholm collided at sea.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Administration is determined to curb corruption and inefficiency in the aid program in Korea. State Department officials who described the corrupt practices said today that two reform measures were under consideration.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Federal agents swarmed into the hidden bookmaking and numbers rooms of nearly fifty cities in a score of states today -- looking for gamblers without tax stamps.

TWELVE antique cars, photographs and art work make up an exhibit, "Come Away With Me Lucille -- The Gay Days of Motoring, 1897-1912," at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

New York City borrowed $75,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, the acquisition of equipment for the transit system and other improvements. The cost of the borrowing was 3.85612 per cent.
Charles Shapiro, builder, has purchased two corners on Third Avenue for improvement with apartment houses.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., April 27 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington urged tonight Federal action to guarantee equal opportunity in housing, employment and education for all.

The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday that recent radio and television scandals had proved the newspapers' wisdom in keeping news, editorials and advertising in "separate airtight compartments."

CHICAGO, April 27 -- The General Electric Company's stock option plan for key executives was described here today as "immoral" by James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

With all the spirit and drive of a general sending his forces forth to do battle, the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday mapped its selling plans for the year ahead.
Do municipal stadiums such as the $15,000,000 ballpark now projected for Flushing Meadow Park pay their way?

After more than four months of exploration and maneuvers by Secretary of Labor Mitchell, President Eisenhower has officially set the ball rolling for labor-management summit meetings to discuss common basic problems. He has asked President Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who originally suggested such get-togethers, to name three top representatives of the federation to serve on a joint committee on arrangements, and Mr. Meany has accepted.

The Detroit reports of changes in top executive titles were confirmed yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation. The company also reported that first quarter earnings dropped 28.3 per cent below those in the 1959 period on a 34 per cent sales gain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- The decision of Jack Lemmon to co-produce and star in a Broadway play next season has highlighted the increasing affinity between the legitimate theatre and the movie industry.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 29 -- Huh Chung, acting head of the South Korean Government since Wednesday, has begun naming a Cabinet that is described as above politics. The Cabinet will supervise drastic changes in the country's political complexion, he indicated in an interview.

Judy Jump-Up, a brown 5-year-old mare by Oil Capitol, staged a game performance in taking the $7,500 Next Move Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday by half a length from the fast-closing King Ranch mare Chistosa.

The May Department Stores Company showed substantially larger sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended Jan. 31 than those of the preceding year, Morton D. May, president, reported yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

A young bacteriologist challenged yesterday the popular concept that a high degree of natural resistance protects most persons against infection by staphylococci in an environment laden with those germs.
ATLANTA, April 28 -- An eleven-man majority of a legislative study commission recommended today a local option plan to comply with the United States Supreme Court's school desegregation ruling.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Every election year about this time one party accuses the other of playing politics with American foreign policy.
KANSAS CITY, April 28 (AP) -- Dick Hall, a right-hander gave four hits tonight, pitching the Kansas City Athletics to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
The Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut were both cool yesterday to proposals for nonresident income taxes in retaliation against New York.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Aides of theh Controller General testified today that more than $3,000,000 had been wasted in the design of special mobile air conditioners for the Air Force's new supersonic B-58 bombers.

PEIPING, April 28 (Reuters) -- About 600,000 Chinese gathered in a square before Peiping's Gate of Heavenly Peace today for a demonstration in support of the overthrow of Syngman Rhee's South Korean regime.

YESTERDAY (April 28,1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council; saw King Mahendra of Nepal and they issued a joint communique; named Welfare Secretary Flemming U.S. delegation chairman to World Health Assembly convention in Geneva.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 28 -- C.V. Whitney's Tompion ran as calmly as if he were going through a workout as he won the Blue Grass Stakes today at Keeneland.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 28 -- The plight of persons jailed under South Africa's emergency regulations was indicated today in a case that came before the Supreme Court here.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Four Interior Department officials were accused by House investigators today of having accepted free or special-rate board at a California resort while it was involved in a "million-dollar" land deal with the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, disclosed tonight that a voluntary program of health insurance for the aged involving income tax credits or outright Federal grants was among the several Administration approaches under consideration.

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company sold $30,000,000 if thirty-year first mortgage bonds yesterday to investment bankers managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and Lehman Brothers, on a bid of 101.079 for obligations bearing 5 per cent interest coupons.
Differences between the State Banking Department and some savings bankers boiled to the surface yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted three persons today for conspiracy to Shield James R. Hoffa and other union leaders from a Senate investigation of rackets in labor and management.
The student demonstrations yesterday in Istanbul, Turkey's largest city, are only the outward manifestation of longsuppressed and widespread discontent with the Government.
Mayor Wagner publicly described Carmine G. De Sapio last night as "my friend" in what appeared to be an attempt to set at rest reports of political friction between them.

PARIS, April 28 -- Leaders of the Gaullist party defended tonight the policy of fidelity to President de Gaulle that led to the recent exclusion of Jacques Soustelle, one of the founders of the party.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., April 28 (AP) -- The former Episcopal Bishop of West Virginia says he would have no hesitancy in voting for Senator John F. Kennedy, a Roman Catholic, in the Presidential campaign.
DENVER, April 28 -- The Methodist Church gave convincing evidence today of its intention to retain in its organizational structure the racially segregated Central Jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 4 per cent above the year-ago level. It is noted, however, that during April changes from a year ago reflect in part the fact that last year Easter was on March 29, while this year it was on April 17.

Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, the world chess champion, made a strong bid in the eighteenth game of his title match with Mikhail Tal of Latvia yesterday in Moscow, but the five-hour session failed to bring a decision.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 28 (AP) -- Two Presbyterian leaders said tonight that marital sexual relations without the purpose of procreation was not a sin, that racial discrimination had no place in the church and that every effort should be made to reduce the possibility of war.
The Columbia Broadcasting system said yesterday that it would not televise a West Virginia debate between two aspirants for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Organized medicine has not "the faintest intention of compromising" on any Government operated health programs, the head of the American Medical Association declared today.
LONDON, April 28 -- Worried by signs of inflationary pressures, the Government took steps today to limit bank lending and installment buying.
The Board of Estimate authorized the city last night to start action to save Carnegie Hall. It also approved a new wholesale produce market for the Bronx.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, April 28 (UPI) -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina said last night his Government had proposed lifting its ban on Communists and Jehovah's Witnesses.

MONTREAL, April 28 (Canadian Press) -- Aluminium Ltd's net earnings for the first quarter of 1960 are estimated at $9,000,000, or 30 cents a share, compared with $2,300,000, or 8 cents a share, in the 1959 quarter.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Nine New York corporations, including several Wall Street banks, have withdrawn or are considering withdrawing from sponsorship of a Conference on African Resources planned for September at New York University.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 28 (AP) -- The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reported today first-quarter earnings of $2,801,639, equal to 42 cents a share, compared with $7,754,991, or $1.20 a share, in the first quarter of 1959.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 28 (AP) -- The Diamond National Corporation posted a 27 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings and may raise the dividend this year, William H. Walter, president, told the annual meeting here today.

BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles collected six two-baggers tonight and Steve Barber, a rooki southpaw pitcher, rode them to this first major league victory -- a 6-1 decision over the Boston Red Sox.
ST. LOUIS, April 28 -- The League of Women Voters agreed today to examine the country's foreign trade and aid policies during the next two years. The vote was almost 3 to 1.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 18 -- The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club completed a successful deense of the Amorita Cup for International One-Design Class team sailing today. The home side beat Long Island Sound for the fourth successive time on windblown Great Sound.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 28 -- The New York Central, the Baltimore and Ohio and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroads are thinking of becoming one. This was learned here today following the annual stockholders' meeting of the Cheasapeake and Ohio.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Treasury offered today a 4 3/8 per cent one-year certificate and a 4 5/8 per cent fiveyear note to holders of $6,400,000,000 of securities maturing May 15.

Dr. Sidney Farber, scientific director of the Children's Cancer Research Foundation, urged yesterday that Congress appropriate $300,000,000 more than President Eisenhower requested for medical research in the 1960-61 budget.
Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer's reputation in General Sessions of being a hard worker won support yesterday when it was learned that on Wednesday he had begun three trials.
NEW ORLEANS, April 28 -- This historical capital of French culture in America gave a warm welcome tonight to President de Gaulle. The proceedings were enlivened by the antics of Gov. Earl K. Long.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Rep. John B. Bennett, Republican of Michigan, said today it had been shown that Dick Clark accepted payola "the same as many other disk jockeys but on a much larger scale."

PINEHURST, N.C., April 28 (AP) -- Peter Green, a 19-year-old University of North Carolina sophomore, defeated Dale Morey on the twentieth hole today and joined Dr. Edward Updegraff, Charles Smith and Glenn Johnsen in the semi-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

Alice, who had to run awfully fast just to stay in the same place in Wonderland, apparently is having even worse trouble in Central Park. George T. Delacorte, donor of the park's Alice in Wonderland statue, said yesterday that children loved to climb all over the statue and that it was beginning to show some signs of wear.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Nuclear propulsion for merchant shipping will not be commercially competitive "within the foreseeable future," a special conference of the Atomic Industrial Forum was told today.

Increased investment of pension funds in the housing mortgage market was urged yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt. He also suggested greater participation by the Federal Government in programs designed to stimulate the construction of middle - income apartment houses.
LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 5, in the Coliseum tonight before a crowd of 33,313.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
The Board of Estimate approved and sent to the City Council yesterday a record expense budget of $2,345,483,576 for the fiscal year starting July 1.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, April 28 -- Prof. Ludwig Erhard told the Christian Democratic Union today that it must engender a sense of social purpose to combat a growing mood of uneasiness among West Germans.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 28 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, smiling and confident, slowed down today his campaign in the West Virginia Presidential primary popularity contest.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A new window has been opened on the solar system with the taking of X-ray photographs of the sun. They were made last week with a battery of six special cameras, mounted on a rocket.

When Princess Margaret is married to Antony Armstrong-Jones in Westminster Abbey next Friday the ceremony will be broadcast to many parts of the world in languages including Hausa, Swahili and Somali.
SINCE "Christine" is set in India it is fortunate that Bhaskar is in the cast.
FAIRMONT, W. Va., April 28 -- Senator Robert S. Byrd has challenged the West Virginia voters to vote against him in the May 10 primary if they dislike his opposition to Senator Kennedy for President.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva, a shy, slender little King in dark glasses, has caught Washington's fancy.
BONN, Germany, April 28 -- The United States has demanded that the six countries of the European Economic Community cut their planned high common tariff on United States tobacco.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company took title yesterday to 40 Wall Street, the world's fourth - tallest office building.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Soviet bloc has mobilized its radio propaganda apparatus to exploit South Korea's riots.
WARSAW, April 28 -- The police clashed yesterday with citizens in the Polish steel manufacturing city of Nowa Huta, near Cracow, reliable sources reported here today.

Net income of the St. Regis Paper Company in the first quarter of 1960 rose to $5,951,696 from $5,794,081 in the 1959 period, William R. Adams, president, reported at the annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

In reply to Premier Khrushchev's latest threat to oust the West from Berlin under cover of a separate "peace treaty" with his East German puppet regime, President Eisenhower has delivered an answer that is both a warning and an inquiry which could affect the status of the whole summit meeting.

Buying interest and activity returned to the market for United States Government securities yesterday as questions related to the Treasury's May refunding of $6,000,000,000 of maturing debt receded into the the area of subordinate interests.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The first-place Pittsburgh Pirates extended their winning streak to seven games tonight by beating the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 0. Bob Friend permitted only four hits and struck out eleven batters in posting his third consecutive victory.

Commission House liquidations touched off light stop-loss selling and dropped copper futures yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. Prices fell 8 to 30 points (hundreds of a cent a pound) on the heavy volume of 531 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot).

Stockholders attending the H.L. Green Company's annual meeting here yesterday criticized the management but voted in favor of it in preference to the Maxwell H. Gluck group, which failed to gain control of the variety chain for the second time.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I write to protest the attack on the Congressional record of my esteemed colleague, Representative Ludwig Teller, in the letter of James H. Scheuer published April 25. The reference made to the alleged absenteeism of Congressman Teller is wholly false and is based on a politically inspired juggling of statistics with complete disregard of the realities of the Congressional process.

IF the weather favors outdoor entertaining this week-end, homemakers should shop around for specially priced steaks. Some stores offer porterhouse for as low as 85 cents a pound, and sirloin steaks may be found for 79 cents a pound.

Broadway showcases already have been farmed out to Robert Fryer and Lawrence Carr for their joint productions of "Midgie Purvis" and "Advise and Consent." First to arrive will be "Midgie Purvis," starring Tallulah Bankhead, at the Lyceum on Oct. 12.
Newspaper publishers heard a report from a labor-relations expert yesterday that savings in production costs from new equipment were being nullified by "waste" of labor.

WHAT began as a restaurant review turns out to be an obituary. This is a verbal wreath for one of the finest restaurants ever to open in New York. Barring a miracle of sorts, Felix Young's Restaurant at 475 Park Avenue (near Fifty-seventh Street) will close tomorrow night.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 28 -- University students demonstrated against the Government of Premier Adnan Menderes today and were fired on by the police. Martial law and curfews were proclaimed in Istanbul and Ankara.
The city's proposed $15,000,000 sports stadium won Board of Estimate approval by a vote of 20 to 2 yesterday, but it was immediately threatened with a taxpayer's court challenge.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 28 -- Navy's baseball team snapped its three-game losing streak by blanking Fordham, 9 -- 0, today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A theory was presented today that the powerful cosmic rays bombarding earth had been created by giant shock waves triggered by stars exploding with the force of billions of hydrogen bombs.

Superintendent of Insurance Thacher has set June 13 as the date for a public hearing on the application of the Associated Hospital Service for a Blue Cross rate increase averaging 37.3 per cent. The hearing will be held at 14 Vesey Street, beginning at 10 A.M.
Dr. Wernher von Braun announced here last night that all eight engines of the new Saturn super-rocket would be test-fired on the ground for the first time in "a day or two."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The White House said today that "very material assistance" had been provided by the Federal Government to destitute children and families in West Virginia and throughout the country.
An immediate 50 per cent expansion of the Upper Bay's deep-draft anchorages was urged yesterday by the shipping and harbor committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce.
Rebellious artists who took the Whitney Museum of American Art to task for favoring nonobjective and abstract art, received an open letter in reply yesterday denying any favoritism.

Loans to business by fifteen large New York City banks fell $21,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $17,000,000 in the 1959 week.
Stocks yesterday wiped out the small remaining margin over the 1960 lows and dipped to the worst levels in seventeen months. The drop in the market was the eighth in the last nine trading days.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 28 -- A population authority asked the country's churches today to help provide a "new balance" of food and people in under-developed countries through technical assistance in agriculture and family limitation.
Chairmen and committee members will meet at Mrs. Howeth Townsend Ford's home at 7 Gracie Square on Monday afternoon to finish plans for the Maytime Cocktail Dance.

GENEVA, April 28 -- The Western leaders will go to next month's summit meeting prepared to urge Premier Khrushchev to sidestep the deadlocked debate on complete disarmament and give priority to three or four concrete steps toward disarmament.
KATMANDU, April 28 -- Premier Chou En-lai made a strong appeal today for Nepal's friendship.
DOVER, Del., April 28 (AP) -- Frank Pace Jr., chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, sketched a generally rosy outlook for the company at the annual meeting today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with some surprise your editorial of April 23 making criticism of the New York City Transit Authority and the Wagner administration for what you refer to as "too many breakdowns, too many delays."

WHAT is the best way for a writer to convey his characters' unspoken thoughts? For several millenniums most writers have just stated bluntly: "John thought Mary looked particularly pretty that night." But people think about themselves and their own problems and emotions as well as about other people.
HOUSTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer and Bill Collins, a pair of long-ball hitters, today carded six-under-par 66's to take the first-round lead in the $35,000 Houston Classic golf tournament.
An editor of an upstate newspaper was accused here yesterday of having used his reporters to check for a bookmaker on whether law-enforcement officials were investigating him.

MADISON, W. Va., April 28 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. zigzagged across the West Virginia coal fields today trying to revive the political magic of his father to the benefit of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
GENEVA, April 28 -- The West said today its projected Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development was a private trade club with rules that barred Soviet membership.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $37,000,000 to $524,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Reserves held in excess of requirements, increased on average by $78,000,000 to $442,000,000.
LONDON, April 28 -- The stook market threw off part of its recent depression here today and rises predominated in most of the principal sections.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court reversed a decision yesterday that would have given $227,500 in back pay to seventeen present and former Municipal Court justices.
The National Urban League called on Vice President Nixon last night to crack down on the continued exclusion of qualified Negro electricians from Government construction jobs in Washington.

WHAT all started in Bermuda as bicycling comfort is ending up at Barnard as dead couture. Bermuda shorts, long a uniform worn at Eastern girls' colleges, were outlawed yesterday by Mrs. Millicent McIntosh, president of the college.
THE answer to those questions about the shad in the Connecticut River is: The run is not yet in progress but it should be any day. The fish have entered the lower river.

APPROVAL of the Flushing Meadows sports stadium by New York City's Board of Estimate unquestionably got the Continental League off the launching pads. But the delicate mechanism that triggers the other stages of Branch Rickey's rocket will have to function with exactitude before the third major league moves into orbit.
ALBANY, April 28 -- Governor Rockefeller signed seven bills today that, he said, constituted the nucleus of a "new and dynamic approach" in the state's drive on juvenile delinquency.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 28 (AP) -- A Baptist missionary-explorer expressed the belief today that the long-lost cities of Sodom and Gomorrah had been found by American divers on the bottom of the Dead Sea.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia has decided that the United States balance of payments problem will not tie Federal Reserve hands in fighting the next recession.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- State Department officials could only speculate today whether the Turkish student riots in Istanbul were a transitory flare-up or the portent of popular revolt against the Government of Premier Adnan Menderes.

A Junior committee has been formed for the Spring Dance to be held at the Parish House of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, on May 11. The dance will serve to open the church's annual Spring Festival, to be held in the parish house May 12-13.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday improved sales and earnings for the first quarter of this year, but A.B. Homer, president, said the company's operating rate would decline in the second and third quarters.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Senate overrode Administration opposition tonight to write into President Eisenhower's $4,145,600,000 foreign aid bill an amendment aimed at the United Arab Republic's blockade of Israeli shipping.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., April 28 -- A bit of Long Island's vanishing "Gold Coast," will be opened as a public park and museum here next Sunday.
THE good news about last night's performance by the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was that Erik Bruhn was back in action for the first time since the opening night.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa's attorneys cited the new laborreform law, repeatedly critized by Mr. Hoffa, as an argument today in trying to halt a court attempt to oust Mr. Hoffa as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Herold Radio and Electronics Corporation said yesterday that 78,000 unregistered shares of its stock allegedly sold in violation of Federal securities laws belonged to three Herold officers who pledged the stock as collateral for a $175,000 loan to Herold by Austin Associates, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Dozens of recommendations were presented to the Democratic National Committee today for inclusion in the party's 1960 platform.
EDWARD DUGMORE has not exhibited for several years. In the interim, his already vigorous abstract style has gained strength and dimension.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 -- James M. Gerstley, president of the United States Borax and Chemical Corporation, denied tonight that the company was involved with the Department of Interior in a giveaway deal in Death Valley.

Changes in the top management of the world's largest oil company have been announced by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). They result from the impending retirement of Eugene Holman as chairman, chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 28 -- In a move to combat growing Communist sabotage and political and terrorist activity in South Vietnam, the Government has begun a large-scale regrouping of the rural population.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 28 -- The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church has refused a request by the Bishop of the Alabama Diocese to "repudiate" a document expressing sympathy for the Negro sit-in movement.
Automation has been a major factor in eliminating 10,000 production and maintenance jobs in the last year, a steel union leader reported yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 28 -- John J. O'Rourke, vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four other defendants being tried or charges of juke-box racketeering, were freed on a directed verdict of acquittal in County Court here today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The right of a state bank to operate branches acquired by merger was upheld today by the Federal Court of Appeals in a landmark case that may be outmoded by pending bank merger legislation.

About this time every year, concerts by college choruses figure heavily in the musical fare of New York. Few of these events, however, compare in quality with the program offered in Town Hall last night by the Laurentian Singers of St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Al Smith got three straight singles, extending his hitting streak to eight straight before being stopped, and scored all of Chicago's runs tonight as the White Sox tripped Cleveland, 3 -- 1.
Several major steamship lines moved against the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday by preparing damage suits of the waterfront walkout of 15,000 dock workers last week.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The House of Representatives passed a billion-dollar "emergency" housing bill today in a calculated election-year challenge to the Eisenhower Administration. The vote was 214 to 163.
"THE RACE FOR SPACE" blasted off successfully on Channel 11 last night.

"The Kate Smith Show" will be discontinued by the Columbia Broadcasting System after the telecast of July 18. Effective June 13, the musical variety series will present repeat shows for the remainder of its run.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a white South African I shall be described as a quisling or traitor in some circles for writing this letter. That is a risk which I must take because I believe that the soul of my country is at stake and that silence would be greater treachery.

Following is the text of a address given here last night by Dr. Wernher van Braun, director of the development and operations division of the Army Ballistic Missile Agency, at the annual dinner of the Bureau a Newspaper Publishers Association:

The Sacramento Municipal Utility District, Calif., borrowed yesterday $30,000,000 in the public market to further the development of the $109,000,000 Upper American River storage reservoir and electric energy generation project.

Australia's challenge for an America's Cup match in 1962 was accepted yesterday by the New York Yacht Club. At the same time, the door was left open for England to race again for the cup under the same challenge, but only with Australia's consent.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- There is a well-known law of politics the what is recognized in off-election years as normal, responsible government procedure becomes a "sly or "sinister" trick in the year of Presidential election. Only the work ing of this law could account for the Democratic uproar over President Eisenhower's public announcement that, if his duties call him home from the summit conference in May, Vice President Nixon will sit in for him.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- About half the grain futures contracts finished unchanged or with minimum fractions of previous closes on the Board of Trade today although a few ranged from firm to weak.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 19 points (95 cents a bale) up yesterday. The distant months showed the most strength.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Rail and truck freight loadings last week indicated a slack in general business activity, according to reports by both industries today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The office of Arthur Kline, Federal Power Commissioner, was ransacked during the week-end.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Shooting paper clips out of an office window with a rubber band can be properly considered associated with the job of an otherwise unoccupied messenger boy, the Court of Appeals held today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- King Mahendra of Nepal stated his country's policy of "nonalignment and nonentanglement" before a joint session of Congress today.
Many swatches and patches of cloth and bits and pieces of yarn have been inserted in magazines since some advertisers decided that customers like to feel the merchandise.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 28 (UPI) -- A Russian who suddenly went berserk today exploded a hand grenade aboard a Venezuelan airlines DC-3, sending the plane plummeting to earth near Calabozo, 100 miles southeast of here.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 28 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain tried to reassure the Soviet Union's southern neighbors today by outlining Western objectives at the summit meetng next month.

AS it was elsewhere in the city this week, the news at George Tanier is French. A collection of modern French furniture and lamps, along with some Swiss chairs, are now in residence at the Tanier showroom, 521 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Japan has formally protested the suggestion that United States national security might be jeopardized if Japanese locomotives were purchased for use along the Panama Canal.

LONDON, April 28 -- Some Britons who take a philosopherhistorian's view of the international situation see progress toward a treaty banning nuclear tests and the gentle application of Western ideals on the new governments of Africa and Asia as the most important objectives of the times.
KATMANDU, Nepal, April 28 (AP) -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China said today his country was willing to accept joint ownership of Mount Everest with Nepal.
The City Council received yesterday a proposed local law that would impose fines and jail terms for illegally dumping toxic wastes into city sewers.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 28 -- Two telephone calls, at an outlay of 20 cents, saved Billy Haughton $50 tonight. The odds were the best on the card at Roosevelt Raceway.

TURIN, Italy, April 28 -- Hopes of the American bridge players here to qualify three teams for the finals in the olimpiad world bridge tournament were weakened, but not killed, when the United States Vanderbilt One team unexpectedly lost a match to Iceland today by 62 to 46 international match points.

What used to be a sprawling swamp in the East Bronx is rapidly being converted into an animated history book in which cowboys will soon fret, stagecoaches will be robbed, and Chicago will burn -- every twenty minutes.
The city's public schools will close next fall for the Jewish holy days of Rosh ha-Shanah.

TORONTO, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- In the coming decade the free world is expected to increase its consumption of petroleum products by 1,000,000 barrels a day, J.R. White, president of Imperial Oil, Ltd., said today at the company's annnual meeting.

NOWA HUTA, Poland, April 29 (Reuters) -- Steel-helmeted policement patrolled the streets of this steel-manufacturing town today in the uneasy calm following Wednesday's riot against the removal of a cross from a site that had been earmarked for a church.
Aqueduct has all the ingredients of a top-grade horse race in today's $70,000 Grey Lag Handicap at one mile and an eighth, with eleven campaigners in the feature.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 29 (AP) -- Gov. Cecil H. Underwood told the National Broadcasting Company today that the Citizens of West Virginia were outraged by what he called its "rigged" television report of conditions in the state.
GENEVA, April 29 -- The East-West disarmament conference ended its first stage today in a complete deadlock, but with both sides holding out some hope that it might be loosened at the summit.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board indicated today that it might grant to the airlines a general increase in fares.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Pioneer V has shaken the foundations of scientific concepts that have stood for half a century.

Charles A. Buckley, the Democratic leader in the Bronx, gave special recognition yesterday to Puerto Rican voters in the southeast part of the borough, where his organization's newest member of Congress faces a primary fight.
Johnny Dio, the labor racketeer, was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $5,000 yesterday on his conviction for income-tax evasion and fraud.

Monday, May 2 Eastern States Antiques Fair, Westchester County Center, White Plains. Although antiques of all kinds will be shown at this semiannual fair, the displays of antique garden furniture and outdoor dining accessories are particularly timely.
Stocks failed to hold gains made in the first full week of trading in April and ended lower for the month.
LONDON, April 29 -- Aleksandr A. Soldatov, the Soviet Ambassador to Britain, denied today that his Government's policy toward Germany and West Berlin constituted a threat.
Philip Herman obeyed an impulse that thousands of New Yorkers have restrained -- barehanded, he forced a bus that had passed him up to stop for him.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation is in no position at this time to establish its proposed pay-as-you-see television system, the Government has been told. The company itself agreed.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 29 -- Western church missions are giving way to indigenous churches in Asia, but they are not doing it fast enough, a Burmese theologian told churchmen here today.
A hearing into the citizenship application of Dr. Edward V. Sittler, 43-year-old former radio broadcaster for the Nazis, land his wife Margaret ended yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah., April 29 -- The Delhi-Taylor Oil Corporation and Texas Gulf Sulphur Corporation announced plans yesterday for potash operations at Bartlett Mesa, northeast of Moab. Utah, with production due to begin in 1961.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 29 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter assured the Foreign Ministers of Iran, Turkey and Pakistan today they would be consulted before any decision affecting their countries was taken at the summit conference next month.

MILWAUKEE, April 29 -- The Food and Drug Administration has compelled Lakeside Laboratories of Milwaukee to withdraw the drug Imferon from the market. The drug is administered chiefly to pregnant women and children to combat anemia.
The Grass, Alas, Alas One of the most frustrating occupations known to mankind is the nurture of grass. But take heart. Science can soon promise us no more mowing, no more weeds, no more crab grass.
Bond flotations increased in April while public stock issues showed a decline.
Luis Ferre carried his campaign for the Governorship of Puerto Rico to upper Madison Avenue this week.

PARIS. It is precisely fifteen years since Hitler killed himself, announcing untruthfully in his political testament, "I die with a happy heart." He left as a final instruction: "The aim must still be to win territory in the East for the German people."
Church membership in the United States, as a whole, is steadily losing ground in a race to keep up with the expanding population, according to a recent interdenominational survey.
Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday a net loss of $640,039 for the first quarter. This was

NEW ORLEANS, April 29 -- President de Gaulle declared tonight on his departure from the United States that his talks with President Eisenhower "have been very useful for peace and for the future of the world."

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 29 -- Archbishop Makarios asserted today that the two military bases Britain would retain in Cyprus must revert to the independent republic of Cyprus when the British feel they no longer need them.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- Caryl Chessman lost a new bid for survival today in the State Supreme Court. He is scheduled to die in the San Quentin gas chamber at 10 A.M. Monday.
With two months still left in the 1959-60 theatre season, Off Broadway already has put on about sixty-five productions, as compared with the seventy-five for the entire 1958-59 season.
LONDON, April 29 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada urged today that the Commonwealth conference opening here Tuesday should not become "judge and jury" over South Africa's racial policies.
The State Investigation Commission said yesterday that public apathy and inadequate law enforcement were responsible for widespread illegal gambling in the state.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Eisenhower coined a Republican watchword today -- "one-third and one," the vote required in either house of Congress to sustain a veto. His remark, indicating that he may be trying to promote the votes he would need to back his disapproval of some piece of legislation, was made informally as he said good-by to a group of sixteen Republican Senators after a White House breakfast.
DENVER, April 29 (UPI) -- A storm buried towns and ruined fruit crops with up to twenty-three inches of snow today in Rocky Mountain states from Wyoming to New Mexico.

Louis Sullivan, the architect whom the late Frank Lloyd Wright called "beloved master," is the subject of a biography by Willard Connely. "Louis Sullivan as He Lived" tells of his interest in architecture in his teens, of his being a partner in the firm of Adler Sullivan in his twenties, of his artistic triumphs and of his personal tragedies.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 29 -- Turkish troops dispersed crowds in Istanbul and Ankara today that were shouting demands for Premier Adnan Menderes' resignation.
Led by Mrs. Marge Mason, the Ridgewood Country Club took the lead yesterday in the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches.
ALBANY, April 29 -- Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today giving the State Dental Society authority to set up a statewide nonprofit health insurance plan for dental care.
The downward trend in the number of freshman engineering students is expected to halt next fall, the Engineering Manpower Commission of the Engineers Joint Council reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Dick Clark swore to House investigators today that he had never taken payola, but the Congressmen were skeptical.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 29 -- President Romulo Betancourt delivered his annual message to Congress today, presenting an ambitious four-year plan for the rest of his term.
ALBANY, April 29 -- New York State's participation in a new tri-state commission to study traffic laws in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut was authorized today by Governor Rockefeller.
ROME, April 29 -- Eight neo-Fascists joined with 117 Christian Democrats and three independents today to give Premier Fernando Tambroni and his Government a vote of confidence in the Senate.
The idea of mixing in a little jazz with a long-hair concert piece has tempted many, but few have succeeded in getting the combination to work.

A BOOK publisher assured parents recently that television has elevated their children's literary tastes, broadened their cultural horizons, and served as an intellectual tonic. Bennett Cerf, president of Random House, told a meeting sponsored by the Library Associates of Columbia University's New York School of Social Work:
A tall, ruddy-faced New Yorker of Irish descent who is known in postal circles as "Mr. Foreign" because of his vast knowledge of international mail will retire today after fifty years of service.
GILBERT and Sullivan were put to the severe test of survival last night over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate Aeronautical and Space Sciences Committee approved a $55,000,000 increase today in the Administration's authorized space budget. The increase is designed to give the space agency greater flexibility in exploiting breakthroughs and meeting setbacks.
Plans for two afternoon tours of twelve private gardens have been completed by the City Gardens Club of New York. The first tour will take place Tuesday and the second on the next Tuesday.

Even though the Board of Estimate on Thursday night authorized a program to try to save Carnegie Hall, eviction proceedings were begun yesterday against some of the artists and esthetes who have long lived in the studios above the old music hall.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Department of the Interior accused the chairman of a House investigating subcommittee today of "deliberately misrepresenting" the contents of the files of his panel. The department's target was Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., April 29 -- Voters here will be asked to decide in a referendum July 16 whether to appropriate up to $70,000 to finance a study of local school affairs.

TURIN, Italy, April 29 -- Three United States teams qualified for the finals in the Olympiad world bridge tournament today. One United States team "backed in," for it lost its last match, but survived because a Swedish team, its closest competitor, also lost.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The planet Jupiter has been found to emit tremendous pulses of energy -- each equal to the explosion of ten large hydrogen bombs -- with machine gun-like rapidity.

DURBAN, South Africa, April 29 -- The Most Rev. Denis Eugene Hurley, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Durban, predicted today that new racial violence would sweep South Africa after a period of calm lasting about two months.

Earnings of the Sharon Steel Corporation spurted to $2,241,477, or $2.03 a share, in the first quarter from $590,853 and 54 cents in the 1959 period, it was reported yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Sharon, Pa.
HAVANA, April 29 -- The police announced early today the arrest of leaders of what they called a conspiracy to overthrow the Castro regime.
The City Housing Authority yesterday invited applications from sponsors of nonprofit cooperatives to take over eight housing developments being built under the city's no-cash-subsidy program.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Four-hit pitching by Early Wynn and Turk Lown carried the Chicago White Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

RABAT, Morocco April 29 -- The Moroccan Federation of Labor has expressed its solidarity with the Arab Trade Union Federation's protest against the picketing of the Cleopatra in New York but has not joined the federation's boycott of American ships to go into effect at midnight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 29 -- Roscoe Poe, the driver of the truck that crashed into a bus last Oct. 9 killing eleven college girls and a history professor, received a oneyear jail term and was fined $1,000 today in Middlesex County Court.

THE New York Philharmocic is in the throes of what it calls a Spring Festival of Theatre Music. Yesterday afternoon the series was inaugurated with a program of music for the ballet Leonard Bernstein conducted.

The Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the Waterfront Com- mission's penal powers in re- voking the licenses of four brothers. The bi-state agency had found that they had used "force, threats and intimida- tions" to control cargo-checking on a Brooklyn pier.
ALBANY, April 29 -- A Special Court on the Judiciary sat for the first time in the state's history today and heard arguments on a motion to dismiss removal proceedings against two Brooklyn judges.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of the killed-virus vaccine against poliomyelitis, reported to President Eisenhower today on the five years of progress resulting from his research.
THE mysterious powers of the universe, personified in the gods, never ceased to haunt the classical Greek mind.
The development of regional master plans to coordinate hospital services and hold down costs is recommended in the two-year state study of Blue Cross hospitalization programs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Michigan bagged the only major varsity relay title at stake today as the sixty-sixth annual University of Pennsylvania relay carnival opened in warm, sunny weather at Franklin Field.
A newly discovered aspect of the body's natural defenses was described by a Government scientist here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The House Appropriations Committee drastically altered President Eisenhower's defense budget today without significantly changing his appropriations request of more than $39,000,000,000.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Samuel Goldwyn revealed today that he was negotiating to make many of his movies available on television.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 29 (AP) -- Australia will build its America's Cup challenger in strictest secrecy.

NEWMARKET, England, April 29 (AP) -- Roger Poincelet hung on grimly to a slipping saddle today, but rode the American-owned Never Too Late to victory in the One Thousand Guineas for 3-year-old fillies.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 29 (UPI) -- A group of armed rebels has invaded southern Paraguay from Argentina and seized the small village of Mayor Otano, the Government announced tonight.

A recently discovered document, believed to the earliest one written in New York to be found, may solve a riddle that has eluded historians and may cause historians to change the chapters on the first Dutch settlers here.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 29 -- The Government announced today the start of a slow demobilization of army reserve units called up to deal with racial violence during South Africa's state of emergency.
MILWAUKEE, April 29 (UPI) -- Juan Pizarro turned in six innings of hitless relief pitching while the Milwaukee Braves took advantage of mistakes by the Phillies to post a 5-3 victory.
Business news had a gloomy tone yesterday, with the result that stocks made a general retreat.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The grain storage industry broke off negotiations with the Agriculture Department today on a proposed new contract for sorting Government-owned surplus grains. The contract called for a reduction in rates that would lower the Government's storage costs by more than $100,000,000 a year.

FISHING in these parts, both fresh and salt, took a convulsive jump in the last couple of days, leading wise old heads to take a view that the State Department calls guarded optimism. It is not too guarded, at that.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 29 -- The issue of religion was raised directly today in the campaign for the West Virginia Democratic Presidential primary.
How memory is laid down in molecules, cells and nerve networks in the brain was discussed by authorities in several fields here yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals erupted for a ten-run eighth -- the biggest inning in the major leagues this season -- and routed the Chicago Cubs, 16 -- 6, despite a pair of three-run homers by Ernie Banks.
LOUISVILLE, April 29 (AP) -- Bally Ache, one of the top Kentucky Derby contenders, will race over the Churchill Downs' strip tomorrow when the track opens its nineteen-day meeting.

JAMES WINES, a gifted 28-year-old sculptor having his first one-man show at Fine Arts Associates, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, has the good fortune to work in Rome, where bronze-casting facilities are easily available.
CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- -- Short-covering for the weekend along with light mill and export buying lifted the grain futures market into a firm to strong range today after a slow and mixed start.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 29 (AP) -- A Toledo University professor announced today that he had isolated a filterable agent from human leukemia with which he has produced the disease in white mice.
The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday the election of a new chairman and president.
CLEVELAND, April 29 (AP) -- Woody Held drove in four runs with two homers tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 5-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

ROSE CUMMING'S shop is one of Madison Avenue's landmarks. Crammed with fabulous antiques, art objects and fabrics, it occupies one of the choicest sites in the decorator market in the East Fifties -- a corner of Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued today a pamphlet aimed at misleading guarantee claims in advertising.
The Democrats hope to display TV togetherness on the party's Channel 5 telethon here May 21 and 22.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Federal Housing Administration lowered minimum down payments today on houses costing $15,000 or more.

Meyer, Strong Jones, engineers, have leased 15,000 square feet of space in 230 Park Avenue, at Forty-sixth Street. S. Harold Appel and Ralph Joseph Helmsley-Spear, Inc., were the brokers. The lease will enable the tenant to consolidate on one floor the offices it now occupies on twelve floors in 101 Park Avenue, at Fortieth Street, where the firm has been for forty years.

THOSE familiar with Alice Marks' second floor window at 36 East Fifty-seventh Street are in for a surprise. Heretofore filled only with furniture and accessories, it has suddenly burst into bloom. This is because of a merger with Judith Garden, a concern known for its arrangements of fake and fresh flowers.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29 (AP) -- A mid-meet downpour that cleared almost all of the 8,500 fans from the stands spoiled the opening of the fifty-first Drake Relays today.

THE CRIMSON once said that Charles Townsend Copeland "personalized Harvard education." No doubt Professor Copeland appreciated that -- up to a point. He dearly loved a compliment, and a compliment was, murkily, intended. But he loved good English more. He might toy with the notion that anyone who used "personalized" -- a hallowed barbarism -- deserved to be hanged from a limb in Harvard Yard.

LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- Transport Minister Ernest Marples said last night that he did not consider the way the United States subsidized its shipping could be reconciled with declarations for "free and international trade."

Allegheny Ludlum Steel The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the first quarter topped last year's levels but that the second quarter could he the poorest of the year.

Dresser Industries, Inc., maker of oil, gas and chemical equipment, cut the quarterly dividend by 10 cents with the declaration yesterday of 30 cents a share, payable on June 15 to holders of record of June 1. Shareholders had received 40 cents in the three preceding quarters.

DETROIT, April 29 (UPI) -- Auto manufacturers in the United States turned out more cars this month than in any other April since 1955, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 11 points (55 cents a bale) up to 2 points (10 cents a bale) off yesterday.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., April 29 -- The Long Island State Park Commission and the Nassau County Police Department were involved in a head-on collision today. The site was at the junction of a westbound exit of the Southern State Parkway and Corona Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate found itself unexpectedly embroiled today in the politics of the Arab-Israeli dispute over the Suez Canal.

HONOLULU, April 29 (AP) A report from an amateur radio operator in Texas sent Coast Guard planes searching tropic islands today for Peter Gluckmann, unaccounted for on an attempted 8,885 non-stop flight from Tokyo to New York.
A Columbia University architect charged the Port of New York Authority yesterday with double-decking the George Washington Bridge to bring more automobiles into Manhattan.
LOGAN, W. Va., April 29 -- The Hubert H. Humphrey campaign rolled today through what his supporters called "Humphrey country."

Controller Lawrence E. Ge- rasa yesterday rejected Magis- trate Anthony B. Maglio's claim for $35,000 to cover "reasonable counsel fees and ex- penses" incurred in defending himself in ouster proceedings based on charges of unjudicial conduct.

LONDON, April 29 -- A broad advance in prices here today signaled the stock market's relief that the uncertainty was over and that the credit squeeze announced by the Government yesterday wouldn't hurt so much as had been feared.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Crane Company, Chicago, today denied Federal Trade Commission charges that it had violated antitrust laws by acquiring an interest in five competitors. It asked dismissal of the complaint.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, April 30 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee gave every appearance in an interview yesterday of enjoying the prospect of spending his remaining days away from the turbulent Korean political scene, which has occupied most of his 85 years.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Prices of farm products, continuing their 1960 upturn, rose nearly 1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Prices of farm products, continuing their 1960 upturn, rose nearly 1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April.

David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said yesterday that he hoped that a joint labor-management committee now, being formed would prevent future shut-downs in the basic steel industry.

A 26-year-old publication executive was accused of homicide yesterday in the slaying of a man he said had forced his way into his Brooklyn apartment and demanded money. The police said the suspect had admitted the slaying.

THE PRESIDENT Saw group of Republican Senators; met with Cabinet; saw Dr. Jonas E. Salk and Secretary Flemming on fifth anniversary of polio vaccine development; attended dinner given by the King and Queen of Nepal.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Experts in the State Department on the Middle East expressed displeasure today over the apparently uncompromising position taken by Premier Adnan Menderes toward the student demonstrations against the Turkish Government.

The American Motors Corporation operated in high gear in the quarter ended on March 31 with sales and earnings setting records for the period. Directors raised the quarterly dividend to 25 cents at the board meeting yesterday.

Harry Nystad, realty operator, has sold the three-story brownstone dwelling at 216 East Thirtieth Street to Dr. Douglas Torre in a deal negotiated by Judith Simmons, broker. The house, which is assessed at $19,000, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $36,000.

BALTIMORE, April 29 -- The Yankees still were moving in reverse tonight, and a feeling of uneasiness began creeping through the ranks. For that is the way things went exactly a year ago after a brisk start.

Just as the Senate had ultimately to take responsibility for the outrages committed in its name by the late Senator McCarthy, so the House is responsible for the actions of Representative Walter's Un-American Activities Committee.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 29 (AP) -- A Maritime Administration official said today that operation of United States flag steamship lines between the Great Lakes and overseas ports since the St. Lawrence Seaway opened "does not lend itself to much optimism."
HACKENSACK, N.J., April 29 -- Bergen County was ordered today to refund the $192,912 in property taxes it had levied against Ridgefield Park for 1959.

Despite the erratic sales trend of the first four months, there is justification for expecting a moderate increase in sales of underwear this year, A.W. Zelomek, president, International Statistical Bureau, Inc., said yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 29 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored eight unearned runs in the fifth inning tonight and routed the San Francisco Giants, 10 -- 2, before 46,159 fans.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A motorist in California who backs into a parking meter may indirectly be helping a weekly newspaper publisher in Dunellen, N.J.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Metropolitan New York's delegation, which swept the card last year, drew first blood in the schoolboy phase of the Penn Relays today.
