KATMANDU, Nepal, April 29 -- Premiers Chou En-lai and B.P. Koirala declared today that "friendly relations" between Communist China and Nepal had entered "a new phase."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On April 19 you carried another editorial opposing Huntington Hartford's Central Park cafe and noting that you were in favor of preserving every square inch for "this greenstarved city." I think that you are altogether missing the purpose of the Hartford eaterie.

RABAT, Morocco, April 29 -- Morocco will inaugurate a short-wave radio program tomorrow over the Voice of America transmitter in Tangier. The broadcast will be based on material provided by the Algerian Nationalist Provisional Government and beamed to the Middle East and eastern Algeria.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 29 -- Bermuda's yachtsmen completed the downfall of those from Long Island Sound today by winning another trophy in the International One-Design Class.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The Illinois Supreme Court showed law students today how it operates on the anatomy of the law.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At this period in our national and international life I think it well that we stopped criticizing the Department of State and complaining that they have no interest in helping the private citizen. Only the prejudiced can speak of "pink tea diplomacy."
WESTBURY, L.I., April 29 -- Bye Bye Byrd, the speedy pacer owned by Rex Larkin of Chicago, will try to make it two in a row in the $25,000 Monitor Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

DENVER, April 29 -- The quadrennial general conference of the 10,000,000-member Methodiat Church rejected overwhelmingly here today efforts to hasten the abilition of the church's all-Negro Central Jurisdiction.
Hungary joined Poland and the seeded favorites -- Italy, France, Britain and Spain -- yesterday in the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis tournament, the Associated Press reported.

UNSEEN by anyone but a profitable percentage of what are often described as the homemakers of America, shut-ins, children on the lam from school and an occasional beady-eyed critic, television's daytime serials meander from year to year.
Mrs. Alva Bernheimer Gimbel, wife of Bernard F. Gimbel, head of the department-store chain, has her own particular flair for big business. Hers is the business of philanthropy.
MOSCOW, April 30 -- The Soviet Union donned scarlet bunting today in preparation for one of its biggest May Day celebrations tomorrow.

BOSTON, April 30 -- Runscoring singles by Vic Wertz and Bobby Thomson in the eighth inning resulted in a 2-1 Boston Red Sox victory over Camilo Pascual and the Washington Senators at Fenway Park today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Navy is opposed to efforts to build up tourist trade on Vieques, an island east of the main island of Puerto Rico.

TUXEDO, N.Y. OVER a million tulips, daffodils and hyacinths star as the first floral attraction for the official opening of Sterling Forest Gardens today. The 125-acre garden nestles in the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains, six miles north of Tuxedo, N.Y. and thirty-five miles north of New York City.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Indian Ambassador here said today that the International Court of Justice had been reduced to "a mockery" by United States restrictions on its jurisdiction.
For three hours and fortyfive minutes, New York University and Fordham battled in a Metropolitan Conference baseball game at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday. The Violets finally won, 7 -- 4.

EASTERN colleges, apparently fearing that modern educated man is growing effete, are paying more and more attention to making him strong and hardy, in an outdoor sort of way. The twelfth annual Woodsman's Weekend, to be held next Saturday and Sunday at Rutland, Mass., ought to further this aim noticeably.
The second and final installment of Walter P. Chrysler Jr.'s collection of antique English furniture will be auctioned at 1:45 P.M. Friday and Saturday at the Park-Bernet Galleries.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Eisenhower has donated the papers of his office to the public and been greatly praised for his generosity. The act raises an important question of public policy that ought not to be brushed aside merely because the records of the Presidency have once again been saved from destruction, dispersal, concealment or, perhaps, untimely publication.

A world-wide communications blackout caused by sunspots cut off the United States from most areas in Europe and the Far East yesterday. Communications supervisors described atmospheric disturbances as "the worst we've had in recent years."
The Police Athletic League will benefit at a theatre party at the June 23 performance of the British Royal Tattoo and and Military Tournament. The event will take place at Madison Square Garden.

BONN. THE post-war question was: will Germany rise again? It has been answered. Political and economic power has been regained. The question now, at the turn of the decade, is: what will Germany do with its resurrected might and vitality?
NEW ORLEANS, April 30 -- Parents of this city's 91,846 public school students were asked this week whether the schools should be closed if necessary to prevent desegregation.

TO THE EDITOR: The merits of Sir Herbert Read's polemic for abstract art are largely nullified by his introductory attempt to blanket the case with: "In spite of the high esteem which abstract art enjoys among collectors, and the fantastic prices paid for it in the salesrooms, the man in the street remains bewildered, sometimes angry, often indifferent."
BALTIMORE, April, 30 -- It took the Yankees less than half an hour today to serve notice on their American League rivals that they still were a long way from having passed out.
TOKYO. AN American actor would feel at home in a Japanese television studio. But before the "On Air" sign had dimmed he might be amazed by some of the departures from the American medium.

LOS ANGELES, April 30 -- Union contract negotiations covering about 175,000 airplane and rocket workers from coast to coast are proceeding in a generally serene atmosphere with five of the leading aircraft companies.

A PROPOSAL to conduct a two-year test of ultrahigh-frequency television in New York, which could have a profound influence on the future course of the home medium nationally, appears to have a good chance of passing Congress.

OBSERVERS of the local dining scene say that there may be a trend toward Mexican cuisine in the making. Manhattan is soon scheduled to have two new resturants with Central American menus, and the sales of such canned items as tortillas, refried beans and green chilies reportedly have shown marked increases in recent months.

The inmates in the Women's House of Detention will be aided and their return to society facilitated as a result of a tea Friday at the Tavern on the Green. The Friendly Visitors, Inc., is holding the event, its second annual benefit, to raise funds for the program it conducts at the House of Detention.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- California, the state of startling contrasts, reaches some sort of epitome in the Mission-and-Missile Belt of Santa Barbara County.
A two-week seminar primarily for publishers, editors and executives of newspapers with a circulation under 50,000 will open tomorrow at the American Press Institute of Columbia University.
RICHWOOD, W. Va., April 30 -- The Humphrey-Kennedy political struggle became a name-calling contest today.

WHEN the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra embarks on its third overseas tour in October, its repertory will include a number of scores commissioned and composed for first performances in the United States.

WASHINGTON -- The State Department's Passport Office today closes out precisely five years under the direction of Miss Frances G. Knight, and she and her colleagues are purring with self-satisfaction.

NO resolutions were passed at last week's Congress of Artists and Writers sponsored by the Washington Institute of Contemporary Arts. WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The dramatic events of recent days in Korea, and the role the United States Government played in them, are still too fresh to permit any final evaluation of their significance. No more can one fairly judge a play by its first scene.

Stocks declined every day last week. And so April bowed out marking the fourth straight month during which the market showed a loss. Earlier last month there were some good gains and hopes rose of a real spring rally.

IT looks as though Sean O'Casey, the world's greatest neglected living playwright, is in danger of being paid too much attention next season. Paul Shyre is readying his adaptation of "Drums Under the Windows," the third volume of O'Casey's six-volume autobiography, for October production, and the Phoenix Theatre is planning to open its 1960-61 season, also in October, with a revival of O'Casey's "The Plough and the Stars."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 -- Harvard's varsity crew set a course record on the Charles River today and also won thirty-six shirts.

LONDON -- Greenwich (pronounced "Grennidge") is a cool-looking, white, spacious and perfectly proportioned group of palatial buildings set in a park on the bank of the Thames, less than five miles crow-flight southeast of St. Paul's.

Mother's Day goods were big sellers last week, according to reports from resident buying offices. Stores were requesting millinery items, lingerie and housecoats. Better priced costume jewelry, particularly pearls, was a big favorite.

CITY gardeners will be putting out the welcome mat this week as the annual round of May tours begins. The City Garden Club's two-day spring showing of gardens and penthouse terraces is slated Tuesday and May 10.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 30 -- Three-hit pitching by Capt. Ned Leroy broke Williams' six-game losing streak as the Ephmen defeated Wesieyan, 2 -- 0, in baseball today. Leroy, who struck out ten, walked only four men and was in serious trouble only in the eighth inning, when the Cardinals loaded the bases with one out.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Dissolution of a seventeen-year-old arrangement under which four theological schools have operated with a single faculty at the University of Chicago has been announced by Chancellor Lawrence A. Kimpton.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates has galvanized the decision-making process of Government by the simple expedient of making decisions. Last December Mr. Gates announced that he would join the meetings of the Joint Chiefs of Staff whenever matters on which they disagreed were under discussion.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- A low-budget Florida vacation that has grown by leaps and bounds in popularity is camping in state parks. Of 3,260,129 persons who visited the state parks in the past fiscal year, 173,156 were campers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30 -- In Ohio's primary election next Tuesday Gov. Michael V. DiSalle is challenging what he calls the "rule of ruin" methods of Ray T. Miller, Democratic boss of the state's most populous county -- Cuyahoga.

Dona Felisa Rincon de Gautier, Mayor of San Juan, P.R., is expected to attend "A Night in Old San Juan," the ninety-first anniversary ball for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. The event will be held at the Sheraton-East on Friday night.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, April 30 -- The issue of Federal versus private construction and operation of electric transmission lines in five states is posing major financial, engineering and philosophical worries for Westerners, Administration officials and Congressmen.

Many persons have already subscribed to the Allergy Foundation of America's benefit theatre party to "Greenwillow" at the Alvin Theatre on May 23. The organization has taken seats in the orchestra and mezzanine.

BOSTON. IN a Tryout Town, the drama critic has his own peculiar problems and his own special rewards. HOME owners who are annoyed by warped, poorly fitting garage doors can replace them with a new, easy working overhead model. Though an installation of this kind usually calls for the services of an expert, a new do-it-yourself door just introduced enables the home handyman to tackle the job himself -- and to complete the entire project in a single afternoon.

LAUREL, Md., April 30 (AP) -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Idolater, declared out of the Kentucky Derby after finishing ninth in last week's Wood Memorial, was back in the 3-yearold classic picture today after his easy victory in the $15,000added Maryland Derby.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 30 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea has never been one of the more popular Asian leaders. Many Asians have admired his stubborn, courageous nationalism and uncompromising opposition to communism, but most knowledgeable Asians have deplored his actions as President and condemned his regime as brutal, corrupt and undemocratic.

TURN, Italy, Sunday, May 1 -- Britain defeated Italy early today in the first round of the finals in the Olympiad world bridge tournament here. The score was 66 to 58 international match, points in the match between the teams rated the strongest in the tourney by most observers.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Officials of Independence National Historical Park are searching for two white marble mantelpieces that disappeared nearly half a century ago.

OTTAWA -- This capital of Canada, glistening with snow so many months of the year, is now a floral spectacle of radiant color, with more than a million blooms already spreading along forty-five miles of parkway and in the spacious flower beds around public buildings and monuments, and more to come in the city's annual Tulip Festival.

SEVILLE, Spain, April 30 -- Ten thousand pairs of hands seem to be clapping in soft, insistent rhythm here these nights. The wailing songs of gypsies and the drumbeats of their heels on wooden floors keep the city alive till dawn.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Governmental bureaucracy must be kept under constant watch to prevent "harshness," Viscount Kilmuir, Lord High Chancellor at Britain, said tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, April 30 -- Dr. Melvin B. Goodman resigned today as director of the Westchester Community Mental Health Board to protest restraint of his authority over psychiatric services in WestChester.

President Gamal Abdel Nasser approved their vow that they would neither repair nor unload United States vessels at Alexandria, Port Said or Suez.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30 Pennsylvania's varsity crew won the Childs Cup for the third successive year today on Carnegie Lake.

THE romance between Don Blasingame, the Giant second baseman, and Sarah Cooper, a finalist a few years ago in the Miss America contest, has flowered to the point where their engagement has been announced. GIAN CARLO MENOTTI, who is said to be the most consistently successful writer of operas of our day, has been commissioned by the Columbia Broadcasting System to write a "play with music."
TO THE EDITOR: The implication in Hamilton Fish Armstrong's article that the Fria company and other Western industrial enterprises there are threatened with nationalization is quite misleading.

It's widely believed that factoring -- one of the oldest forms of financing -- originated in the textile industry. Not so. Factoring actually began with the growth of foreign trade. As such, its history dates back several hundred years.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Policy-makers of the United States Chamber of Commerce affirmed today the organization's support of liberal trade policies, despite demands by some local chambers and industry affiliates for curbs on imports.

For decades the Wheeler Yacht Company has been a builder of wooden boats exclusively. The wood has been good, heavy planking -- no plywood in the hulls.

A few years ago, when educational television was in its infancy, a professor turned down an invitation to lecture in front of the cameras. A TV lecture, he said, would force him to rearrange his notes. Last week Harold B. Gores, president of the Ford Foundation's Educational Facilities Laboratories, predicted that educational television would rearrange not only the teachers' notes but the architects' ideas of school buildings.

AFTER reading press story about chemical residu in foods, home growe may be wondering if a insect or disease-killing chemicals can be used safely in vej table gardens this year. T answer is yes -- and with complete safety.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 30 -- Senator John F. Kennedy's brothers are back oh the campaign trail in West Virginia, but his mother and sisters are not.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Segregation is still needed to control leprosy, a World Health Organization expert contends in a letter published in the current issue of the American Medical Association Journal.
The Little Board is getting bigger every day.
A Soviet authors analysis of the causes of marital discord has drawn Communist party fire.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 30 -- Claiming races, long accepted in thoroughbred racing, are to be tried in harness racing. Effective Monday night, any trotter or pacer 5 or more years old and still in Class C will compete only in claiming events here at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Edward K. Mills Jr. has a conflict-of-interest dilemma. It highlights the whole conflict-ofinterest theory.

TIME was when the English missionary sallied forth, top hat on head and Bible in hand, to bring the consolations of religion to the black man, in whatever parts of the earth he was to be found, and with them the benefits of civilization.

PARIS, April 30 -- The foreign ministers of the fifteen member states of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be asked next week to endorse a policy of no retreat on Berlin at the summit conference in mid-May.

ON a high point of Manhattan Island, close to Columbia University, is International House, a ten-story building dedicated to the sentiment chiseled above its entrance: "That Brotherhood May Prevail." Here a unique experiment in human relations, backed by John D. Rockefeller Jr., was started thirty-five years ago.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 30 -- Delegates to the General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church rejected today a proposal that, on moral grounds, the denomination dispose of its financial holdings in the tobacco industry.
SOUTH EGREMONT, Mass., April 30 -- Fantastically low scores marked the early phases of the ninth annual Yankee Monte Carlo sports car rally last night and today.
The Judson Health Center will benefit from the Cherry Blossoms Dinner Dance, to be held Tuesday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

BILOXI, Miss., April 30 -- The last state with a prohibition law on its books may soon follow Oklahoma into the wet column. This would not only bring an end to the "great experiment," but also to one of the most startling cases of legal schizophrenia on record.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 30 -- The primitive, mountainous Asian kingdom of Laos, which has gone from one crisis to another during the last ten years, appears today to be again at the brink of crisis.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 30 -- Jack Sutphen of Larchmont Y.C. won the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound frostbite dinghy championship today. He became the first skipper to capture the title twice in the inter-club regatta that closes the winter sailing season on the Sound.

GARDENS that recall a fabled era on Long Island's North Shore will open today for their second public season. Dedicated last year as an arboretum and horticultural exhibit, Old Westbury Gardens were first opened to the public one Sunday each month.

FOR THIS WEEK: Re-shape scraggly shrubs after their early flowers fade. . . . Keep after tent caterpillars with DDT or lead arsenate. . . . Start planting gladiolus, but it is too early for dahlias; wait until mid-May. . . . It may be too late to apply pre-emergent crab grass controls. Use postemergent sprays after the weed appears later this month.
An airline flight engineer who flew through Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary last month found those countries fifteen years behind the United States in equipment for airline navigation and maintenance.

BRAHMS: Symphony No. 3; Tragic Overture; Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, Lorin Maazel conducting (Deutsche Grammophon). Mr. Maazel, who began conducting as a child prodigy at the age of 10, is now beyond the prodigy age and, this record suggests, is also worthy of notice as a conductor of talent.
Two June garden parties have been arranged to honor patronesses and members of the post-debutante committee for the 1960 Tiara Ball.

Food delicacies and staples from many lands will be displayed at the World Trade Fair. Virtually every country in Europe, and several in Latin America, Asia and the Middle East have provided thousands of items, many of which are indigenous only to their areas.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 30 -- The Central Treaty Organization's Ministerial Council today denounced Soviet propaganda campaigns against Iran and Pakistan as "inconsistent with the declared purpose" of a relaxation of international tensions.
F. Lawrence Babcock of 39 1/2 Washington Square South, a writer and former editor, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 54 years old.

BELFAST. TODAY, the O'Malleys, who have had a lot of fun with their Lyric Players Theatre, believed to be the only family playhouse in the United Kingdom, turn their project over to a non-profit association.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- Bally Ache flew away from his opposition in taking the seven-furlong Stepping Stone at Churchill Downs today. The consistent colt owned by Leonard Fruchtman scored by more than three lengths over the Sunny Blue Farm's Venetian Way while covering the course in 1:22 3/5. With the victory, Bally Ache established himself as one of the strongest candidates for next Saturday's Kentucky Derby.

The first of May finds the spring garden a mass of color and fragrance. Double Japanese cherry and peach blossoms stud the tree branches while daffodils, tulips and anemones sparkle on the ground. The New York City botanical gardens report that early lilacs, azaleas, quince, redbuds and crabapples are worth seeing, too.

ON four different occasions during last year's world series Walter Alston, the manager of the Dodgers, ambled from dugout to mound and beckoned to Larry Sherry in the Los Angeles bullpen. Into each game came Sherry with a swift, defiant swagger, almost as if he couldn't wait to quell the White Sox batters in his role as relief pitcher.

Two patrolmen who were exposed to meningitis Friday were quarantined in their homes yesterday for a ten-day observation period. Both men had returned to their families Friday evening after unknowingly exposing themselves to the disease.
Columbia displayed superior stamina in posting two victories in three lightweight crew races on the Harlem River yesterday with strong finishes.

THERE are several schools of thought about introducing very young children -- under 3 years of age -- to the pleasures of songs and stories and good music on records. One parent wants the child to begin by listening to Hindemith, Ives and Cage right off the bat, on the same theory that says it's easy for a 2-yearold to speak French (if his parents are and he lives in Paris).

YONKERS, April 30 -- Westchester District Attorney Joseph F. Gagliardi said today he was investigating possible violations of the law by one or more officers of Local 137 of the International Union of Operating Engineers.

A NUMBER of subjects appear to be forbidden to fiction: happy families and conjugal love; the career of a decent, average, optimistic business man who is neither a Titan nor a lustful, callous status-seeker; a playful dinner party with its disconnected small talk and its ingenuous mundane hypocrisy.
David Vardi, the Israeli actor, had good reason yesterday to keep company with the memory of days long past.
ALBANY, April 30 -- Legislation designed to turn drivers in accidents into good Samaritans was vetoed reluctantly by Governor Rockefeller today.
A farmer in South Africa developed an apple tree which yields fruit every month of the year.
ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- Twenty-nine private hospitals in St. Louis have banded to resist efforts of a labor union to organize their lower-salaries, nontechnical workers.

The human heart takes its cues from natural electrical impulses. These imperceptible little shocks, conveyed through a band of muscle and nerve tissue called the "bundle of His" (after the German researcher who identified it), maintain the heart's proper rhythm.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 30 -- The May 10 West Virginia primary hung like a big question mark this week over the future campaign plans of all the Democratic Presidential hopefuls.

Edward Steichen, director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, is directing a search for photographs of faces that dramatize the multiracial character of America, under sponsorship of the National Urban League.

Business of Moving The recent news that a firm of New Jersey builders has hired a full-time community coordinator to help new arrivals in a suburban development to adjust to their new area suggests an intensified interest in the sociology of that universal phenomenon, moving.

OBSERVATION CENTER, Monument Valley, Ariz. -- Surrounded by some of the most photographed mesas and buttes in the South-western desert country, Navajo tribal officers, Federal official and the Governors of four state will meet here next Friday to dedicate an unusual structure open a big park and hail a new idea in park management.

OMAHA, Neb., May 1 (AP) -- The Strategic Air Command said today it planned to send aloft aerial command posts to avoid the possibility of a knock-out blow on its headquarters from enemy missiles or planes.
Herbert Hoover hailed yesterday "the generation after generation of devoted Americans" who have helped underprivileged children in the Boys Clubs of America.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A United States program to provide Atlantic pact allies with a modern arms industry is proceeding quietly but swiftly.

SOME of the problems of this Summer's political conventions have nothing to do with selecting a Presidential candidate. Common to all women with a role in the conventions is the problem of planning a wardrobe that will stand up to the day-into-evening rigors of the midsummer schedule.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 1 -- Fred Orlofsky, a. 23-year-old Southern Illinois freshman from North Bergen, N. J., took top honors in the Olympic gymnastic team trials tonight that cut the men's squad to twelve and the women's to ten.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 1 -- Premier Adnan Menderes declared tonight that he had given an order to use force if necessary to end outbreaks in Istanbul and Ankara.
A new system to improve the safety of harbor navigation in periods of low visibility will be put-into effect in a few weeks by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

One of the most extraordinary theatre, pieces ever created under the heading of opera was given its premiere on Saturday night in the "Music In Our Tune" program at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
PARENTS who pale at their teen-age child's request to date a friend of another faith are not necessarily old-fashioned or narrow minded, some teen-age panelists conceded recently.

A "serious crisis" exists in American justice because of the "stubborn persistence of segregation" in the South and discrimination in the North, the head of the New York Board of Rabbis warned yesterday.

Directors of Minerals and Chemicals Corporation of America, Philipp Brothers, Inc., and Philipp Brothers Ore Corporation, have recommended a three-way merger. Stockholders will be asked to vote on the proposals on dates to be announced.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A display of the fine art of cutting a budget without actually cutting it is now getting under way in Congress. The art is not exclusive. Any party can play, and does. One by one, the appropriations bills are being reported out by sub-committees and committees, and worked over by the House and Senate.

LONDON, May 1 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, told a May Day rally in Leeds tonight that the party was reconsidering its support for the policy of maintaining an independent nuclear deterrent.

A HALF - HOUR drama without visible, actors or spoken words was presented yesterday afternoon on the Columbia Broadcasting System's ''Television Workshop" over Channel 2 While neither Actors Equity nor, the Dramatists Guild need "indulge in apprehension over increased unemployment, the experiment in faceless and speechless video was highly intriguing.
ALBANY, May 1 -- Governor Rockefeller approved a record number of new laws -- 1,089 -- during the annual four-month legislative period, which ended officially at midnight last night.

Queens College has had some distinguished composers as professors of composition and last night's concert at the Ninety-second Street Young Women's Hebrew Association, gave some good aural evidence of this.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Governor Rockefeller urged today that the United States take the lead in advancing civil rights both at home and in countries being developed abroad. But he warned against showing "pretensions of superiority" in doing so.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- Steel producers last week continued to show reduced order backlogs and shipments. Customers were reported ordering on a hand-to-mouth basis with no sign that they intended to step up their volume of new business to any great extent.

A Federal law halving the 20 per cent night club entertainment tax went into effect yesterday and owners predicted more work for musicians and waiters and more fun for customers. Some said that the tax cut would mean more revenue for the United States Government as people rediscovered night - clubbing and caused profits to climb.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 1 -- A recent upsurge of Communist violence in this area appears to represent a shift in the Reds' military and sabotage activity from Laos to South Vietnam.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 23 -- On the prairie, about twenty-five miles northwest of town, the Air Force is hurriedly finishing work on a cluster of white structures that look, for the most part, like innocuous warehouses misplaced on the range.
HAVANA, May 1 -- Premier Fidel Castro whipped up a crowd of 250,000 May Day demonstrators today into a frenzy of anger against the United States and a vociferous rejection of elections.

LONDON, May 1 -- The stock exchange reacted buoyantly last Friday after finding that the credit squeeze measures announced by the Government the day before were considerably milder than it had expected.

LONDON, May 1 -- "The course of true love never did run smooth," wrote Shakespeare in "A Midsummer-Night's Dream." The royal family, although not notably addicted to his works, must realize nowadays that on this topic the Bard knew what he was writing about.

SEVEN ambitious young composers from Juilliard who call themselves the Contemporary Composers Commission gave a second concert of their music Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall and made it a big step forward.

Twenty-five American financial men are flying to Tokyo this week for a conference on possible Japanese investments. TOKYO, May 1 -- When Alan Hovhahess stepped from the plane at Tokyo on Feb. 13 he was greeted by a battery of news photographers and a number of reporters who had come to interview him.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 1 (AP) -- Navy won thirteen of the twenty dinghy races this week-end for a narrow victory in the Mid-Atlantic Intercollegiate Sailing Association championship elimination regatta.

A major revision of New York City's Charter with far-reaching political implications was brought nearer over the week-end. But it still faces difficult political hurdles that could accentuate the cleavage within the city between reform and "good-government" Democrats on the one side and party regulars on the other.
A new jetliner, built by an American manufacturer -- the Convair 880 -- was approved yesterday for commercial operation by the Federal Aviation Agency.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A political week lies ahead for Congress, with both international and domestic issues at stake.

LONDON, May 1 -- The Prime Ministers of India and, Ghana served notice today that they intended to raise the question of South Africa's racial policies at the Commonwealth conference that begins here Tuesday.

The Gruen Watch Company has leased two floors containing about 25,000 square feet of space for its administrative, sales and service departments in 20 West Forty-seventh Street. The lease contains an option on two additional floors.

The two announced candidates for Moderator of the United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. have issued a joint statement affirming the ideal of a "non-segregated church in a non-segregated society."

Traffic fatalities in the city were reduced in the first four months of this year for the first time in ten years. Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Administration sources said today that President Eisenhower would sign an agreement Wednesday selling 17,000,000 tons of surplus grain to India for $1,300,000,000, to be paid largely in Indian rupees.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Maybe the Soviet fishing trawler that the Navy photographed sixty miles south of Long Island last Tuesday was only after stripers and just happened to turn up during the Polaris submarine tests.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The prayers Roman Catholic priests are required to say each day outside the daily mass will be cut about in half soon, the National Catholic Welfare Conference said today.
TRENTON, May 1 -- GOV Robert B. Meyner will ask the Legislature tomorrow to enact an income tax on all persons who commute from New Jersey to New York and from New York to New Jersey.

Techniques have been devised at the Columbia Law School to reduce congestion in the courts by predicting what lawsuits will take the most time and should, therefore, be singled out for special treatment.

Zionist and Jewish spiritual leaders and Government officials yesterday hailed the strong democratic character of Israel on the eve of that country's twelfth anniversary as a nation. Their messages were delivered at meetings throughout the city.
CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -- A grand-slam homer by Roberto Clemente and the tight pitching of Vern Law led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 13-2 victory over Cincinnati today.

Fountain House, which helps former mental patients to bridge the gap between Institutional and normal living, will be the beneficiary of a party called "On the Riviera" on Friday in the ballroom of the Pierre.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Legislation guaranteeing private and parochial school pupils the same free transportation provided for those attending public schools has been approved by Governor Rockefeller.
A syndicate headed by Ehrlich-Corso, Inc., New York realty investors, has purchased and taken title to 24 to 82 Beacon Hill Drive, Dobbs Ferry, in Westchester County.

THE Golden Twenties represented a glamorous period in sports that has not been matched. It was an era of supermen -- Babe Ruth, Jack Dempsey, Red Grange, Bill Tilden, Paavo Nurmi, Bobby Jones. It had a superhorse in Man o' War and a human fish in Johnny Weissmuller.

AMSTERDAM, May 1 -- A downward tendency prevailed on the Amsterdam stock market last week, partly reflecting a decline in foreign interest. The business background remained good, however, and helped to keep losses to modest proportions.

Despite objections by four civic organizations, some newspapers and individual citizens, Park Commissioner Robert Moses is going ahead with his plan to build Huntington Hartford's gift restaurant in Central Park.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- The performance of Bally Ache in the Stepping Stone yesterday prompted his trainer, Jimmy Pitt, to talk optimistically today about the colt's immediate future.

John Thomas and Bill-Nieder remained on the road to Rome with Impressive performances Saturday in two important track meets leading to the Olympics. And each, feels he can do better, United Press International reported yesterday.
A soft-spoken former college professor will begin today to reorganize the Greater New York Safety Council from top to bottom.

DENVER, May 1 -- Drew University, the only Methodist institution of higher learning in the New York metropolitan area, is about to embark on a $25,000,000 development program. This became known here today during the quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Church.
CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., May 1 -- As the result of a fair exchange, Capt. Joseph C. Austin, who is stationed at near-by Stewart Air Force Base, is New York Military Academy's new lacrosse coach.
Dr. Edward D. Re, a member of the city's Board of Higher Education urged yesterday that Roman Catholics take an active role in community activities.

Wandering around its maze of corners, it is possible to consume an oyster or buy a string of pearls have a shoe shine or invest in a new hat; have clothes mended or cleaned or Commission a pastel portrait.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- Caryl Chessman will be executed tomorrow unless his attorneys and supporters win appeals for clemency.

An important milestone in the industrialization of the young and troubled Republic of Guinea will be marked today with the first export shipment of alumina from the $150,000,000 bauxite mining and refining complex known as "Fria."

PRINCETON, N. J., May 1 -- A convincing argument that a college education of high quality could be had at other than prestige colleges was offered today by the Woodrow Wilson Nationa Fellowship Foundation.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 29 -- Not even the Judas shrubs, brushing the mountains with lavender snow, or the yellow pollen of the bee trees filling the air with perfume could hide last week the economic and social problems that beset West Virginia.
Prices of domestic cotton futures turned firmer last week. At the close Friday, contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 45 points (25 cents to $2.25 a bale) higher than a week earlier.

HOUSTON, May 1 (AP) -- Bill Collins of Crystal River, Fla., shot a 4-under-par 68 today to take a two-stroke lead in the $35,000 Houston Classic golf tournament.

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Sparkling relief pitching by Gerry Staley in the first game and by Frank Baumann in the second today helped the Chicago White Sox post 6-3 and 5-2 decisions over the Detroit Tigers.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 1 -- Geoffrey Craig'a Wishful Thinking won the open working hunter championship and Paula Pfister's King Muttle took the green working hunter title at the Stratford Farms Horse Show today.

SELDOM has the forthcoming publication of a novel aroused as much advance interest as that of "The Leopard,"* by Giuseppe di Lampedusa. For months now anyone with his ear close to the literary ground could have heard the vibration of the trumpets and the clatter of international applause.
ALBANY, May 1 -- The state today stripped New York City of its power to require dating of milk and cream containers.
Gov. Ryotaro Azuma of Tokyo Metropolis attended an East-meets-West rally here yesterday, opened a Shinto shrine at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and accepted the key to the city from Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A National Heart Institute grant of $1,917,275 will start this nation's second monkey colony for long-range studies of chronic diseases.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 1 -- Southern churchmen were told today that each had a responsibility to create in his community an atmosphere favorable to compliance with the school integration law.

MALCOLM FRAGER, the pianist from St. Louis and Columbia University who capped earlier distinctions by winning the Leventritt Award last October, received the prize yesterday afternoon of a Carnegie Hall appearance with Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.
