TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Through the years The New York Times has been a good friend to all the social service and civic agencies in our community. Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc., as one such agency, is warmly appreciative and considers itself indeed fortunate to have your voice of community conscience at its side.
CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- Two Cleveland rookie pitchers, Wynn Hawkins and Dick Stigman, turned back the Kansas City Athletics, 6 -- 4 and 3 -- 1, today. Each hurled nine innings.
Brazil joined fourteen other nations in the second round of the Davis Cup European zone tennis competition yesterday without playing a match.
BALTIMORE, May 1 -- The Orioles settled a score today and they did a thorough job of it while a crowd of 11,474 chortled.
MOSCOW, May 1 -- The Soviet Union paraded atomic cannon and tactical rockets through Red Square today as part of the traditional May Day demonstration.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Monday, May 2 -- A mother, two of her sons and a house guest died when, fire swept, a home here yesterday. Another son died early today. A fourth son and aether house guest were injured in the fire.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 1 -- Warner M. Willcox, at the helm of Stardust, the 1959 International Class season champion, was victorious in the tune-up regatta that began spring sailing activity on Long Island Sound today.

GENEVA, May 1 -- The Swiss stock markets tended to discount during the past week the gloomier outlook of the New York exchange, whose influence mainly affected the foreign markets whose prices are closely tied to it.

Buyers and retailers from all parts of the nation and many foreign countries arrived in the city yesterday for their semiannual buying of fall and winter shoe lines. The occasion was the opening day of the twenty-fourth Popular Price Shoe Show of America.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 1 -- The foreign ministers of the Western Big Three agreed today on how to present their basic summit policies to the North Atlantic Council meeting opening here tomorrow.
Joseph H. Murphy, New York State Tax Commissioner, questioned yesterday whether the commuter tax that Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey is proposing would Be constitutional.

In his farewell sermon as associate minister of Broadway Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, the Rev. Joseph D. Huntley voiced yesterday his belief that New York is sometimes closer to God than is any individual church.

Raymond Rouleau, the French director who was to stage a television play starring Ingrid Berginan, has been replaced by Jack Clayton, the British director who gained prominence for the motion picture, "Room at the Top."
FRANKFORT, Ky., May 1 (AP) -- Kentucky State College dismissed two teachers and expelled twelve students today.

PARKERSBURG, W. Va,. May 1 -- Senator John F. Kennedy took a politician's risk as he hit the campaign trail in Sabbath-conscious communities of the mid-Ohio Valley today. The results pleased even his most apprehensive local boosters.

SEOUL, Monday, May 2 (AP) -- Acting President Huh Chang today appointed Yoo Ang Soon, 42, as director of the Office of Supply and Vice Minister of Reconstruction. The Office of Supply handles the use of American aid funds in cooperation with the United States aid office here.

The net income of the Sinclair Venezuelan Oil Company in the first three months of the year declined to $3,037,892, or 75 cents a share, from $3,895,330, or 97 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1959.
CHICAGO, May 1 -- Vice President Nixon said today the Administration would present to Congress this week a health insurance bill providing for a limited Federal subsidy.

Communist agents in Central and South America are working under direct orders from the Soviet Union to incite revolutions Allen W. Dulles director of the Central Intelligence Agency, told 2,500 New York policemen yesterday.

PARKERSBURG, W. Va., May 2 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey spent a day of frustration and misadventure today in his effort to get his message across to the voters of Wood County and this bustling city on the Ohio River.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Industry's highest paid executives received fatter salary and bonus checks in 1959 than ever before.

The concern of a Puerto Rican lawyer and financial leader for his fellow islanders who have migrated to slum housing and high rents here has resulted in the formation of a financial insitution to provide mortgage credit for Puerto Rieans in New York City.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 2 -- A preliminary hearing began here today in a treason case involving thirteen members of the Rastafari Cult. Terrorism and African nationalism form the background of the charges.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- Caryl Whittier Chessman's death today in San Quentin's gas chamber ended a twelve-year battle for survival -- a largely single-handed battle that stirred world-wide controversy.
BALTIMORE, May 2 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles converted seven of ten bases on balls into runs tonight, and walked their way to an 11-6 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
The pre-season game between the New York Giants and the Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League, scheduled for Montreal Aug. 29, will be played in the United States instead.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Premier Chou En-lai is regarded here as having killed any lingering hopes that United States newsmen might soon be admitted to Communist China.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower appealed to the people tonight to protect his $4,175,000,000 foreign-aid program from Congressional groups bent on cutting it by 25 per cent.
Benjamin Oren gave the second of three piano programs at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night.
Transactions related to the Treasury's $6,400,000,000 refunding received most of the attention in the bond market yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Supreme Court set narrow limits today on the antitrust exemptions given to agricultural cooperatives.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told the United States Chamber of Commerce today that world peace and stability depended on the soundness of the American dollar.

For the first quarter of this year corporate earnings pushed a modest 8 per cent ahead of the level of the fourth quarter of 1959. The First National City Bank of New York, which keeps a running count of earnings, has totaled up $3,396,893,000 for the nation's leading corporations in the latest three-month period, compared with $3,158,420,000 for the final three months of last year.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector). May 2 -- Israel celebrated today the twelfth anniversary of her proclamation of independence with prayer, dancing in the streets and a display of her military strength.

The House of Representatives is scheduled to begin today debate on the national security budget for the next fiscal year. To this critically important subject we propose to devote three editorials -- the first of which, dealing with the space program, we publish today.

DETROIT, May 2 -- A real estate broker in suburban Grosse Point described at a public hearing today the screening process by which persons considered undesirable are kept from purchasing property in that area.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday increases in gross and net income for the twelve and three months ended on March 31. The quarterly report pointed out that colder than normal weather during the quarter kept gas deliveries high and was a factor contributing to the increases.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Space experts cautioned today that returning space ships might bring back microbes of other planets that would become "pervasive nuisances" on earth.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : A number of letters have recently appeared in this column commenting on the merits of $3350, the voluntary health insurance for the aged bill introduced by eight Senators, including Senator Javits and myself.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- Tuberculosis infections that disappear but do not really go away can be produced in a high proportion of laboratory mice, according to a report today to a meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Thank you very much. Mr. Vice President, Mr. Johnston, Dr. Bush, Your Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen of this distinguished audience.
LONDON, May 2 -- Apart from British Government securities, which went ahead smartly, the stock market turned dull here today.

Salvatore Caruso's Ali Wing won the featured $6,000 Springfield Purse before 29,428 fans at Aqueduct yesterday. The thoroughbred that created the most stir among horsemen, however, was Leonard P. Sasso's expensive Globemaster.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (AP) -- Mike McCormick of the Giants hurled his second shut-out of the season tonight and beat the Milwaukee Braves, 5 -- 0. The victory put San Francisco a game behind league-leading Pittsburgh.
The New York Telephone Company is in the midst of an experiment to help man communicate on impulse.

THE perfection that Vivien Leigh brings to the theatre is equally apparent in her personal dress. After an eight years' absence, the British actress, who first captured America's imagination as Scarlett O'Hara in 1939, has returned to fresh triumph in the new hit play "Duel of Angels."
Corrosion, a costly problem for operators of oil tankers, can be substantially halted, the annual tanker conference of the American Petroleum Institute was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- A group of Capital Airlines employe-stockholders, warning that the company faced bankruptcy in seven days, called today for an immediate meeting of all stockholders to overthrow the present board of directors.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 119.8 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended Tuesday, April 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The Union News Company yesterday ordered its newsstand managers in, the city to remove copies of The New York Times and The World-Telegram and The Sun from front-counter display.

There will be a special entertainment during a cocktail reception in the Terrace Room of the Plaza preceding a benefit dinner dance in the hotel's Grand Ballroom on Thursday. Proceeds of the event will go to the Boys Club of New York.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 2 (AP) -- Ralph Dupas used his speed and boxing skill to win a decision over Rudell Stitch tonight in a twelve-round bout between the American welter-weights.

RYE, N. Y., May 2 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the host Westchester Country Club, shot 42, 40 -- 82 today for a three-stroke victory in the opening tournament of the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association season.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : As general counsel to the Seafarers International Union of North America, Atlantic and Gulf District, A. F. L. C. I. O., involved in the protest against the policy of the United Arab Republic in blacklisting American vessels which touched Israeli ports and mistreating American seamen aboard "suspect" American vessels, I suppose I would naturally be expected to differ with your April 25 editorial on the subject.

LIKE a woman who-has redecorated the living room, Stern's is all aglow about its second floor's overhauling. The opening of the Midtown Shops yesterday marked the completion of the store's reorganization of this floor to simplify shopping.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower appointed two members to the politically sensitive Federal Power Commission today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 2 -- A referendum later this year on transforming South Africa to a republic was approved tonight by the House of Assembly, the lower chamber of Parliament, in Capetown.

Alien Drury's best-selling novel of Washington political life, "Advise and Consent," and the musical play "Fiorello!", based on the life of the late Mayor La Guardia of New York, were selected yesterday as Pulitzer Prize winners for 1960.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 2 -- The Missouri Democratic convention endorsed Senator Stuart Symington today for the party's Presidential n mination.

ONE of George Bernard Shaw's less sturdy works -- "Captain Brassbound's Conversion" received a relentlessly earnest but never very scintillating or gay revival last night on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4.

ALAS, nothing has ever appeared to replace The Dial, a literary and art magazine of the Twenties, which not only took a serious view of literature, but also took just as serious a view of painting and sculpture.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The United States Government has no intention at present of involving itself in the Turkish anti-Government outbreaks in the way it did in the student uprising in South Korea.

MOSCOW, May 2 (UPI) -- The newspaper Ukrainian Pravda announced today that Col. Gen. Pyotr K. Koshevoi had been appointed commander of the Kiev military district, one of the key Soviet military areas.

MIAMI, May 2 -- The American Nurses Association will be asked to expel the Georgia State Nurses Association this week for failure to comply with the National association's policy of admitting all qualified professional nurses.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 2 -- Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, set forth the blueprint for "a new decade of progress" before 1,200 stockholders at the company's annual meeting here today.

HOUSTON, May 2 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer, the Masters, champion, banged in two birdies on the last four holes today to tie Bill Collins, a former Marine, for first place in the $35,000 Houston Classic golf tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- Stanley Kramer, the producer-director, vowed today to resist pressure by organizations such as the American Legion in his fight for the right to hire anyone he wishes to work on movies.
Following are brief sketches of the winners of the Pulitzer prizes:

MOSCOW, May 2 (Reuters) -- Marshal Vasily D. Sokolovsky, one of the Soviet Union's top soldiers, who commanded Soviet forces in Berlin during the 1943-49 blockade, has retired, informed sources said here today.

THE American Ballet Theatre last night opened the final week of its anniversary engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House with a program that included two ballets not previously in the repertory this season.
TURIN, Italy, May 2 -- All three United States teams lost by large margins to their European opponents today in the third round of the play-offs for the world championship.
The king and queen of a tall country saw the city of tall buildings yesterday through dark glasses.
WASHINGTON, May 2 --The Government's short-term borrowing costs dropped again this week.

The southwest corner of Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street, a parcel with about 85 feet of frontage on Broadway and about 103 feet on the side street, has been sold by the estate of John Downey after an Ownership of fifty-five years.
President Eisenhower hailed John D. Rockefeller Jr. in a message from the White House in connection with a dinner here last night marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of International House.
LONDON, May 2 -- The Prime Minister of the Federation of Nigeria said today that South Africa should be barred from "the club" unless she abandoned her racial segregation policy of apartheid.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate tabled tonight and thus kitted an amendment by Senator Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, to the foreign-aid bill concerning the United Arab Republic:
THE following dinner menu is a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
The appointment of five men to major posts created under recently enacted state legislation was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
National Maritime Day will be celebrated here May 24 with a parade of merchant marine cadets, a display of steamship company flags and a precision military drill.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 2 -- At least twelve persons were killed during a three-hour street battle that developed as policemen and troops tried to break up a clash between Communists and nationalists yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Three eastern railroads filed exceptions today to an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's report recommending approval of a proposed merger of the Erie and Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads.
For the second time within a week, authorities in the field of labor and transportation have proposed the elimination of Federal transportation subsidies.

A 'CERTAIN amount of random information that few strong, hardy outdoorsmen can afford not to know about' has come in from the press agents of various states. Few can afford not to know about it because it is free.
Sales of the eight major New York department stores and their metropolitan branches in April surged 19 per cent above those in the 1959 month, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

BALTIMORE, May 2 -- The Alleghany Corporation, holding company, is considering making "several large-scale investments" in United States corporations with important European interests. This was disclosed here today at the company's annual meeting in the Southern Hotel.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The discovery of a new immunological disease was reported here today.

The May potato contract rose sharply in early trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Supplies of potatoes were light in many sections of Maine and cash prices climbed. Trade and commission-house buying, short covering and stop loss purchasing raised the May position as much as 41 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) during the session.

BONN, Germany, May 2 -- The August Thyssen Huette, one of West Germany's biggest steel companies, has scrapped its two-year-old plan to merge with another big Ruhr steel maker rather than submit to strict supranational controls.

DENVER, May. 2 -- The quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Church rejected overwhelmingly today a proposal that the church cut off financial support from seminaries that refused to admit Negro students.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- If Thomas Jameg Donegan, whom the President appointed to the Federal Power Commission today, has any special qualification for his new job, even Mr. Donegan does not know what it is.
TRENTON, May 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner moved swiftly today to implement his proposed income tax on all persons who commute between New York and New Jersey.

The proposed merger of the Texas Butadiene and Chemical Corporation into the Industrial Rayon Corporation was called off yesterday. At the same time, plans for a proxy fight to oust the present management of Industrial Rayon at the annual meeting were announced by a group of dissident stockholders.
A married couple that operates a television service and repair company was accused yesterday of criminally receiving 100,000 stolen television tubes with a retail value of $270,000.

The one-volume American edition of Margherita Guarducci's two-volume work about the archaeological finds under the Vatican was scheduled for publication in April, but has been postponed by Hawthorn Books until June 3. Called "The Tomb of St. Peter: The New Discoveries in the Sacred Grottoes, of the Vatican," the work traces all that is known of the Apostle Peter and of the research in the excavations beneath. St. Peter's.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 2 -- Turkish troops pushed back 2,000 demonstrators bent on shouting anti-Menderes slogans in the ears of ministers arriving for the opening session of the North Atlantic Treaty Organiation meeting here today.

Newbold Morris, the city's incoming park commissioner, held out a slim possibility last night that the final decision whether to build Huntington Hartford's gift restaurant in Central Park was yet to come.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed the foreign aid bill tonight:
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- The grain futures market ended in a steady to weak range today with May wheat leading in the setbacks after posting another peak price for the season in early dealings.

A cutback in offerings of Government-backed mortgages for purchase by the Federal National Mortgage Association has seen viewed by the agency's head as indicating that home buyers can look forward to a more favorable mortgage money market.
Sixteen jubilant Greenwich village families won an important skirmish yesterday in intricate court battle against viction from their apartments t 40 and 42 MacDougal treet.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The statements made by Senator Fulbright, supported by Senator Cooper and Under Secretary of State Dillon, in his unsuccessful effort to induce the Senate to modify a foreign aid bill amendment by Senator Douglas that it previously had approved, merit the serious consideration of all citizens who don't want to see foreign policy shaped -- as much domestic policy is -- by pressures of ethnic and religious groups in this country.
CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs, near defeat after the Philadelphia Phillies had taken a two-run lead in the ninth inning, rallied today for three runs and an 8-7 victory.

WHEN the Yankees rebounded violently from their sorry showing during spring training and performed with high competence during the first week of the season, there was much jubilation among the Bronx Bombers. They won five of their first six with slick pitching, timely hitting and smart fielding.
DETROIT, May 2 (AP) -- Auto production this month is expected to be slightly higher than in May of 1959 when 547,397 cars were produced.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 2 -- The General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church rejected as "bigotry" today a resolution to have the denomination officially oppose the election of a Roman Catholic to the Presidency.
The president of the Association on American Indian Affairs denounced the Government's handling of Indians last night.

The city's mosquito-control program will start in about two weeks, the Department of Health said yesterday. The three-pronged attack will involve helicopters, spraying by truck and a campaign to enlist the efforts of city residents.
AS everyone knows, Topsy had a curly head and grew and grew. But this description applies equally well to asparagus. This delicate vegetable may shoot up as much as ten inches in twenty-four hours.
HACKENSACK, N. J., May 2 -- A Bergen County grand jury said today that there was "a desperate need for more intensive and, if necessary, prolonged treatment of sex deviates."

BERLIN, May 2 -- Willy Brandt laughted today when a visitor to the City Hail remarked that some of his recent speeches sounded more like those of a candidate for Chancellor than of a West Berlin Mayor.

Stocks held their ground stubbornly most, of yesterday, but crumbled in the final hour to close near their lows. Every important group on the New York Stock Exchange was lower and the aggregate market value slipped about $1,350,000,000.
YESTERDAY (May 2, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Named Thomas J. Donegan and Paul A. Sweeney to Federal Power Commission.

LONDON, May 2 -- Despite the leak about Princess Margaret's wedding dress reported in a trade paper, or perhaps because of it, lips at Clarence House are sealed tighter than ever. Not only at Clarence House is mum the word, but every royal warrant holder as well has clammed up until Friday.

JOHN PATRICK DOUGLAS BALFOUR, third Baron Kinross of Glasclune, is a British newspaper man, broadcaster and intrepid explorer. He has written a book about America. It is called "The Innocents at Home" and is hereby recommended as a cheerful critique of our restless folkways.
More than a fourth of the city's junior high school pupils are two and a half years or more retarded in reading, a study has found.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 2 -- Caryl Chessman was executed today.

ST. LOUIS, May 2 (UPI) -- Roy Face walked in the winning run with the bases filled and none out as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated Pittsburgh, 4 -- 3, tonight. The loss snapped the Pirates' winning streak at nine straight.
Operation Alert-1960, a nation-wide Civil Defense training exercise, will be held today, tomorrow and Thursday.
A Lufthansa cargo plane left at 11:15 last night for Europe with eleven horses; four Olympic riders and Nautical.

Governor Rockefeller told a union convention yesterday that he hoped to double or triple the $500,000,000 loan fund authorized by the Legislature to promote, private construction of middle-income housing.
Mortgage funds will be increasingly plentiful in the coming months for home building and all kinds of construction, according to the president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Gary Bell's six-hit pitching and Johnny Temple's single in the seventh inning enabled the Cleveland Indians to score a 3-2 victory tonight over the Washington Senators. It was the sixth straight one-run game for the Senators.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The House of Representatives voted 275 to 0 today to express its "hope" that President Eisenhower would seek at the summit conference a restoration of "fundamental freedoms" for the Soviet Union's "captive satellites."
ALBANY, May 2 -- New York City's suburbs will develop in the next ten years into more than bedroom communities for commuters working in the cities, Frank C. Moore predicted today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 2 -- President Eisenhower urged today the "uniting and strengthening" of the North Atlantic community of nations for the coming summit conference and other challenges that will follow.
ARCH OBOLER'S "Night of the Auk" received an enormously convincing performance on Channel 13's "Play of the Week" last night.

Visitors from the Past If a citizen of Periclean Athens, a Roman merchant of the first century A. D. or a neolithic hunter were miraculously plucked from his own epoch and deposited in the world of I960 A. D. he might well deny that modern man belonged to the human race at all.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- For most of the owners and trainers concerned, tomorrow's Derby Trial won't decide much. Unless a colt comes through with a sparkling performance in the one-mile event, there is every chance all the Trial horses will be in the barns when the Kentucky Derby is run on Saturday.
A business group here warned yesterday against drastic legislation that would bar "proper informal contacts" between utilities and regulatory agencies.

The Seaboard Air Line Railroad sold $6,720,000 of equipment trust certificates yesterday to an investment banking syndicate managed by Halsey, Stuart Co. The certificates were awarded on a bid of 98.616 for obligations bearing 4 5/8 per cent interest coupons.
Earl W. Kintner, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said yesterday that he had noted "significant improvements in the tone of current advertising."

"Lock Up Your Daughters," the musical from London, is encountering some difficulties in its pre-Broadway travels. As a result, it may arrive at the Ambassador Theatre one or two weeks later than the announced date of May 18.
The performance of "Bye Bye Birdie" on the evening of May 18 at the Martin Beck Theatre has been arranged as a benefit for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
AT least four French dresses will be included in Princess Margaret's trousseau for her marriage Friday.
Automobile production last month dipped almost 11 per cent below the March level but rose slightly from that of April, 1959.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 2 -- Two trial races will be required to determine the starters in The Lady Maud Pace at Roosevelt Raceway May 13.
GENEVA, May 2 -- The story of the reluctant host dominated the East-West talks on a treaty to end nuclear tests today.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the Down Town Association of the City of New York was a business men's luncheon social club and thus not exempt from the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on dues.
Close to 50,000 tons of United States agricultural surplus destined for United Arab Republic ports were ordered rerouted to other Mediterranean ports, maritime sources reported here yesterday.
SEVILLE, Spain, May 2 -- Most Spanish fiestas are violent things. They explode all about you. The one here, which ended yesterday, seemed ta c artificial by comparison.
Near May cotton eased 1 point (5 cents a bale), while the other contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady to 11 points (55 cents a bale) up yesterday.
"Talent Scouts," a summer retread rather than a rerun, will be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System for nine weeks, beginning Aug. 1. It will be televised on Mondays from 9 to 9:30 P. M.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reds capitalized on Los Angeles errors tonight to score five unearned runs, three on Ed Bailey's double in the eighth inning and defeated the Dodgers, 6 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Senate approved tonight new foreign aid spending authority of $1,405,500,000 for the fiscal year starting July 1. The vote was 60 to 25. The Administration, which has budgeted foreign aid spending totaling $4,175,000,000 for the coming year, got most of what it had asked in new authorization.
B. Edson DecKer, the freshman rowing coach at Columbia, has been named acting head coach, for the remainder of the 1860 season, succeeding Don Rose.
LONDON, May 2 (UPI) -- The execution of Caryl Chessman today caused a wave of revulsion in many parts of the world that developed into anti-American outbursts in some countries.
IN "The Shape of the River," last night's "Playhouse 90" drama on Channel 2, play-wright Horton Foote reconstructed the later years of the life of Samuel Clemens (Mark Twain).

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 3 -- President Syngman Rhee's resignation was accepted today by the Korean National Assembly. The action formally ended nearly twelve years of virual one-man rule by the 85-year-old pioneer of the Korean freedom movement.

The Detroit Edison Company recorded a 5.3 gain in revenues in the first quarter and the trend is expected to continue throughout the year, Walker L. Cisler, president, told yesterday's annual meeting at its corporate headquarters at 60 Broadway.
LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- Burnley, playing its last game of the season, tonight defeated Manchester City, 2-1, and won the English Soccer League championship.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Dick Clark testified today that American Airlines had paid him $7,150 to plug the airline on television over a period of weeks.
TRENTON, May 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner gave a green light today for the establishment of a massive wholesale produce market in the Jersey City Meadows.
PARIS, May 1 -- Finance Minister Wilfrid Baumgartner confirmed today earlier indications that France had turned a $1,150,000,000 profit on the world scene in 1959 after three years of net losses.

CHARLESTON West Va., May 2 -- The Kennedy-Humphrey battle for West Virginia entered its final week today amid signs of mounting personal bitterness threatening to inflict deep and slow-to-heal, wounds in Democratic ranks.

Ronnie Cohen, a New Rochelle lightweight, scored his twelfth straight knockout last night. He stopped Al King of Bristol, Conn., in the eighth round of a scheduled ten-rounder at the St. Nicholas'Arena.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Thirteen prominent Protestant clergymen declared today that anti-Catholicism in the Presidential primary campaign posed "a serious danger that the forces of hate and uninformed hostility may be loosed upon our people."

CINCINNATI, May 2 -- Josef Krips brought down his baton; orchestra, chorus, soloists and audience broke into the "Star-Spangled Banner," and the forty-third biennial May Festival opened tonight at the Music Hall.

At the invitation of The New York Times, two business-civic groups of Birmingham, Ala., have submitted a statement expressing their criticism of, and replies to, two articles by Harrison Salisbury on racial tension that appeared in The Times on April 12 and 13.
DENVER, May 3 -- Four new Methodist bishops will bo elected in Washington next month at the quadrennial meeting of the church's Northeastern Jurisdiction, it became known here today.
FOR many families, asking a decorator to "do" a room for them is like buying something in a paper bag. When the bag is open, i.e., the room finished, will they like what is inside?

TUNIS, May 3 - Ahmed Tlili, head of the Tunisian Labor Federation, sent a telegram of solidarity today to the Arab League expressing the sympathy of Tunisian labor for the Arab position in the Cleopatra boycott.

ELISABETHVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 3 -- A male nurse and a bankrupt trader are seeking to become the first African political boss of Katanga, the richest province of the Belgian Congo, when the Congolese attain independence June 30.

QUEENS Following is the list of contests for Queens Democratic district leaderships for which primary petitions were on file with the Board of Elections yesterday. Incumbents are indicated by an asterisk.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 3 -- Tribal discipline has been instituted against a Tuscarora Indian chief for the first time in more than a century as the result of a land transaction with the State Power Authority.
The Sheltering Arms Children's Service will benefit from an all-day preview visit to Freedomland on June 18.

NEW ORLEANS, May 3 (AP) -- The medalist, Polly Ann Riley of Fort Worth, and the defending champion, Judy Eller of Old Hickory, Tenn., moved up today in the first round of the women's Southern amateur golf tournament.
TRENTON, May 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner urged the Legislature today to adopt his proposed income tax on New York-New Jersey commuters so the levy could go into effect without delay.
MOSCOW, May 3 (AP) -- Moscow buzzed excitedly today about a poem that took up a full page of Pravda.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Thirty corporation executives met here yesterday to rally support for an African trade and investment conference scheduled for September at New York University.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Consumer installment credit, seasonally adjusted, rose by $408,000,000 in March, or about the same rise as in, January and February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
In this, the second of three editorials on the subject of national security, we consider the question of the so-called "missile gap."
Securities of the Baltimore Paint and Chemical Corporation valued at $3,272,500 are being offered to the public today by underwriting groups headed by P.W. Brooks Co., Inc.

Thirty per cent of 1,000 teenaged boys questioned "in depth" during a two-year survey voiced strong opinions against being drafted into the armed forces, it was reported yesterday. The survey was conducted by the Boys Clubs of America in 100 United States communities.

Charles R. Cox, president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, told the annual meeting yesterday that results for the second quarter should exceed those of the first and that the outlook for the year as a whole was "satisfactory."
Salary increases of $300 a year for beginning teachers and $400 for those now at maximum pay are being considered by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- A New Jersey commuter group's request for Federal funds to help modernize commuter railroads drew a sharp rebuff today from a Mississippi Congressman.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 3 -- Soviet propaganda attacks upon the Western Allies appeared tonight to be a likely topic for discussion at the coming summit conference.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Administration will propose to Congress tomorrow a new program of "catastrophic" health insurance for elderly persons with low incomes.

Plans were announced yesterday for a twenty-one-story hotel overlooking the Hudson River at Twelfth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Construction is expected to start in July and be finished next summer.

WITH the arrival of ''The Rikisha Man" at the Fifth Avenue Cinema yesterday comes refreshing, literally colorful, proof that the Japanese movie-makers are not solely devoted to Samurai, ancient ritualistic drama and flower arrangements.
BOSTON, May 3 (AP) -- Norm Siebern's throwing error on a tenth-inning bunt by Pete Runnels let in the winning run today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 4-3.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 3 -- France complained to the United Nations Security Council today that Tunisia had permitted bases in her territory from which Algerian rebel troops had committed "more and more attacks" against French troops in Algeria.
LONDON, May 3 -- Weakness pervaded the whole of industrial stock market here today and losses of a shilling (14 cents) or more were common. Very few issues went against the trend.

The active May potato position fluctuated sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market was firm early in the day on short covering, but prices closed near the lows on long liquidation. Stop-loss orders were touched off on both the rise and decline.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- A fairly active late demand cancelled nearly all losses in grain future, today and left the market generally steady to strong.
TURIN, Italy, May 3 -- The last American team in the running for the world championship was eliminated tonight when Spingold One defeated Spingold Two by 85 to 69 International Match Points.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- A clearer picture of the kinds of weapons and counter-measures this nation is developing against the threat of germ warfare is beginning to emerge from scientific meetings such as one being held here this week.
AMES, Iowa, May 3 (AP) -- Dick Wilson completed a sweep of the United States Olympic free-style and Greco-Roman 114.5-pound honors tonight.

Columbia Gas System, Inc., announced yesterday changes in the top executive level of the system, the election fo a new director and the sale of 1,400,000 shares of common stock to a group of underwriters.
MIAMI BEACH, May 3 -- A nurse may occasionally find herself breaking the law because her work is outgrowing its legal definitions, an educator told the American Nurses Association here today.

Mickey Solomone, the up-and-coming 17-year-old apprentice, rode four winners at Aqueduct yesterday. Included on the list was Top Lea, who took the feature, the Home Life Purse, by three-quarters of a length.
Music Makers, Inc., producers of music for radio and television commercials, have leased two floors in 6 West Fifty-seventh Street, which will be renamed the Music Makers Building.
LONDON, May 3 -- The trousseau and the wedding dress are still much of a mystery, but news is leaking out of what Princess Margaret's guests will wear.
GENEVA, May 3 -- The East-West negotiations on ending tests of nuclear weapons moved a step forward today.

The writer of the following letter, Dean of the Faculty of Princeton University, served on the staff of the Committee on Economic Security which in 1934-35 developed the Social Security Act. He was chairman of the Advisory Council on Social Security, 1938-39.

YOUNG women with stout hearts and correspondingly padded figures take courage Lane Bryant's Chubby Department has a collection of summer clothes made to order for campfire cookouts and for movie dates as well.

LONDON, May 3 (Reuters) -- A naturalized American renounced his citizenship in Rome and many persons wore black in Lisbon today as the world reacted in shock and sorrow to the execution of Caryl Chessman.
DETROIT, May 3 -- The Ford Motor Company invited its 152,000 employes in the United States today to contribute to the political party of their choice.

An occasion significant in New York City's educational, cultural and civic life took place yesterday with cornerstone ceremonies for Fordham University's first building on its new midtown campus at Lincoln Square. The School of Law, first of the Fordham complex which will be neighbor to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, will be ready for use within a year and a half.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 3 -- Gov. William G. Stratton asked the Illinois Legislature today to remove the scandal-shaken Chicago Police Department from the jurisdiction of the Chicago Civil Service Commission. Chicago's Mayor Richard J. Daley favors eventual establishment of such a system.
The State of Minnesota borrowed $48,820,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of state buildings.
HAVING won a lot of admirers with a short version of "The Fantasticks," Tom Jones has expanded it for the production that opened at the Sullivan Street Playhouse last evening.

Record first-quarter sales and earnings for the Radio Corporation of America were reported here yesterday at the annual meeting by John L. Burns, president. He said that net income would have been even higher were it not for substantial expenditures on development of computers and other electronic data processing equipment that as yet is returning no profit.
PRINCETON, May 3 -- Rutgers, playing errorless baseball, defeated Princeton, 3 -- 1, today at University Field.

The "Startime" television series will be canceled May 31, a month earlier than originally planned. The series, sponsored by the Ford Motor Company, had been scheduled to run through June 28 over the National Broadcasting Company network.
How do managers get thrown out of ball games? Jimmie Dykes of the Tigers supplied one answer at the Stadium yesterday.

EXHIBITIONS open today at both the Whitney Museum and the Museum of Modern Art. At the former are restrospectives surveying the work of two major contemporary conservative sculptors, Jose de Creeft and Hugo Robus, while the latter digs among its treasures to produce "Portraits From the Museum Collection."

PARIS. Never, in their long and brilliant history, have the Turks had what we would call democracy. Democracy is a rather rare flower. It tends to flourish best in states with relatively stable frontiers, good living standards, high literacy rates and a tranquil political history.
A mathematics professor at Cornell University said yesterday that even in the use of computers there was a big difference between the United States and Russia -- freedom.

The new American Football League, which hasn't fielded a team yet, announced yesterday that Atlanta and Chicago would become members in 1961. This would increase the league membership from eight to ten teams.

Designers intent on getting the last bauble into place in just the right way mixed with laborers moving potted plants and other scenery yesterday as opening time neared for the United States World Trade Fair.

YESTERDAY (May 3, I960) THE PRESIDENT Sent special message to Congress urging action on his legislative program; flew to Fort Benning, Ga. for afternoon, to witness Army infantry maneuvers; returned to White House:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3 (AP) -- Most Democratic national convention delegates pledged to Gov. Michael V. DiSalle as favorite-son stand-in for Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts were leading tonight in a slow count of Ohio's primary elections.
The writer of the following letter is president of the International Union, United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America.
The Yorkville Ball, a dance for the benefit of the Yorkville Youth Council, will be held May 20 in the Sheraton-East.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Administration received important support for its defense policies today as debate opened in the House on a $39,337,867,000 military appropriations bill.

Shipbuilding prices at European yards have reached the lowest level at which they can continue to operate, according to Erich R.F. Maier, president of Maierform of Geneva, one of the world's largest marine-engineering and naval-architecture concerns.
Relatively little taxpayer resistance to proposed school budgets developed in annual school-district elections last night in New York suburban counties.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- The appointment of a twenty-member farm policy advisory committee headed by Gov. Herschel C. Loveless of Iowa was announced today by the Democratic National Chairman, Paul M. Butler.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Once again events in Korea exert their effect in Turkey, and again we are involved in these reverberations. Turks and Americans recall with pride the performance of Turkish soldiers during the Korean war. That performance demonstrated Turkey's fidelity to her anti-Communist alliance with the United States, and her fitness for full participation in the Western alliance and NATO.
BUCHANAN, N.Y., May 3 -- The nuclear-fueled electric generating plant being built beside the Hudson River here by the Consolidated Edison Company received its atomic heart today.
The state committee race in Manhattan's First Assembly District poses a problem for reform Democrats. Whatever the outcome, they will win -- and still lose.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 4 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota appeared early today to be winning over Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon in the District of Columbia's Democratic Presidential primary.
The Wagner Administration will soon seek to legislate the principle of nondiscrimination into the rental, leasing and sale of more of the city's private housing.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 3 -- Regardless of results, the West Virginia primary election next Tuesday will not decide the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 President Elsenhower asked Congress today to act promptly on his legislative program without undue attention to election-year politics.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Thomas G. Corcoran received $102,203.21 from the Tennessee Gas Transmission Corporation and a subsidiary last yer in legal fees and expenses, the companies have reported to the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The charter for the billion-dollar International Development Association is in serious trouble in the House Banking Committee. The reason is the question of free navigation of the Suez Canal.

Ashland Oil and Refining The directors of the Ashland Oil and Refining Company have declared a 2 per cent stock dividend on the common, payable on Aug. 1 to holders of record of June 27. The company, which paid a 3 per cent stock dividend last June, also declared the regular quarterly cash dividend of 25 cents a share, payable June 25 to holders of record of May 16.
Mayor Wagner was urged yesterday to see to it that there was "less talk and more action" in making Third and Lexington Avenues one-way.
Robert Moses promised last night that there would be "no patronage, no favoritism and no waste" in the New York World's Fair of 1964, of which he is to be the president.

TYLER, Tex., May 3 (AP) -- Venezuela is developing a new national oil policy based on conservation and wise investment of oil income, according to Dr. Juan P. Perez Alfonso, Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons.

Directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation declared a 2 per cent stock dividend on the capital shares yesterday, to be distributed on or before July 25 to holders of record of May 20. Shareholders had received cash dividends of 30 cents a quarter, the last of which was paid on March 11.

Today is the last day for holders of marketable Treasury debt due this month to exchange it for new 4 3/8 and 4 5/8 per cent obligations due in one and in five years, respectively. The Government bond houses said yesterday that the transactions were already all over but the shouting.

LONDON, May 3 -- When the Commonwealth conference opened here today the world's attention was focused on the question of apartheid, the South African policy of strict racial segregation. But events save conspired to force a larger issue upon the British Government and people: the choice between the Commonwealth and Europe.
A deluge of twenty-two hits helped Columbia crush City College, 23 to 3, at Baker Field yesterday. It was the highest score of the year for the Lions' baseball team.

A COUPLE of big bluefish showed up in the pound nets off Point Pleasant, N.J., yesterday, exciting an already overexcited Jersey salt-water fishing population. These people have been shaken up pretty badly by the best spring striped bass fishing that anybody can remember and by fast mackerel fishing.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 3 -- Six days after demonstrations against the Government of Premier Adnan Menderes broke out in Istanbul, Turkey is tense, nervous and abuzz with rumors.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Civil Rights Commission has started a study of discrimination in employment created by Federal grants and activities.

Advocate of tolls on the nation's inland waterways, led by the railroads, have opened their strongest campaign in fifty years, Braxton B. Carr, president of the American Waterways Operators, Inc., told a regional luncheon meeting of that group yesterday in the Whitehall Club.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Ken Walters, a rookie outfieider, hit his first major league home run today and enabled the Philadelphia Phillies to gain a 10-9 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Walters' drive, which went over the left-field screen, was made with one out in the ninth.

Buying and attendance at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America are running at last year's record rates, according to officials of the exhibit. The five-day show at the New Yorker and Sheraton-Atlantic Hotels and the New York Trade Show Building ends tomorrow.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 3 -- The remote kingdom of Nepal is striving to develop a strong democracy after centuries of lagging behind the rest of the world.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company had record sales in the first quarter and earnings slightly larger than in the first three months of last year, E.J. Thomas, chairman, announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 3 -- The Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference opened today and promptly disposed of its most pressing issue -- South Africa's race policy -- by agreeing to discuss it only informally.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 3 -- West Virginia backers of Senator John F. Kennedy stirred new political controversy today by reporting they were $2,500 in debt. They also said that they had spent 20 per cent, less so far than supporters of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has been singing the financial blues.
INDIANAPOLIS, Wednesday, May 4 -- Vice President Nixon won a substantial victory yesterday in his popularity contest with Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts in the Indiana primary election.
Labor peace in the city's voluntary hospitals depends on an "ambitious union leader," Dr. Arnold A. Karan, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said yesterday.
The Union News Company continued yesterday to relegate The New York Times and The World-Telegram and The Sun to back-of-counter positions on news stands in the city and suburbs.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 -- Treatment with anti-cancer drugs has produced encouraging results against two baffling diseases in which the body attacks its own tissues, a specialist reported here today.
BONN, Germany, May 3 -- France and West Germany concluded an agreement in Bonn today for the establishment of West German supply, training and weapons testing bases in France.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 3 -- The Most Rev. Celestine J. Damiano was installed today as the third Bishop in the twenty-two-year history of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Camden.

IN "A Sea Symphony," Ralph Vaughan Williams undertook, to match the boldness, spaciousness and noble reach of Walt Whitman's poetry. The work, which is the composer's first symphony, has a generosity of proportion and scope that is worthy of Whitman.
Twisting the tail of one their foremost 1959 torturers the Yankees subjected the Tigers to a 10-3 trimming at the Stadium yesterday. The defeat was the seventh in a row for the stalled Detroiters.
Ferris Booth Hall -- Columbia College's new student center -- was opened yesterday for public inspection.

FOR the last ten years, John W. Aldridge, a tall young man of 37, has been writing literary criticism of singular ferocity. His savage denunciations of numerous contemporary novelists have won him a reputation as a wit and have presumably left lasting scars. Now Mr. Aldridge has dared to write a novel himself, "The Party at Cranton, and one can almost hear the knives being sharpened.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A corporate tax authority told the United States Chamber of Commerce today that tax rates would not be cut until management took the lead by giving up some of its tax advantages.

The nation's railroads carried 130,900,000 passengers last year, a new low for any year of this century. But, despite this slim, business, their operating loss declined to $543,800,000 on the traffic, according to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The passenger count is exclusive of commuters.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 3 -- Belgium is trying to supply the Congo with the civilian equivalent of the "ninety-day wonders" -- the United States officers who received rush training during World War II.

At the ceremonial unveiling of a Fordham University School of Law cornerstone in Lincoln Square yesterday Chief Justice Earl Warren said that freedom and tyranny in the United States seldom confronted each other now in "naked conflicts."
Stocks checked a long decline yesterday with a rally that added about $4,000,000,000, or 1 1/4 per cent, to the market value of the New York Stock Exchange list.
For the seventh time, the nation went through an annual Civil Defense drill yesterday afternoon to be prepared for a threat it hopes may never become a fact -- that of nuclear war.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today:
BALTIMORE, May 3 (UPI) -- Billy Pierce continued his mastery of the Baltimore Orioles tonight, pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 5-3 victory over Steve Barber, a rookie.
The National Cash Register Company yesterday introduced what it called the first computer capable of reading an ordinary business document.

May 4 (AP) -- Doyle E. Carlton Jr., a moderate on the racial question, and Farris Bryant, strong advocate of state's rights, wound up in a runoff for the Democratic nomination for Governor in yesterday's primary.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Every day or so now the public is handed what purports to be the real lowdown on the inner inner thoughts of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
Mortgage bankers were told yesterday that they could look forward this year to a possible reduction of 25 per cent, and perhaps more, in the purchase of mortgage loans by savings banks.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Judge F. Dickinson Letts of the United States District Court has denied a motion to replace Godfrey P. Schmidt as counsel for the rank-and-file dissident members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The Collegiate Chorale, under the direction of Mark Orton, sang a Town Hall concert last night that offered capable performances of great choral works not heard so often as one would wish.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 3 -- The fifth edition of The Messenger Stake, harness racing's richest event, which will be paced at Roosevelt Raceway the night of May 14, today attracted fifteen 3-year-old pacers.

Going directly to the people, President Eisenhower has in effect appealed to them to keep Congress from weakening an arm of our national defense that is designed to stop Communist imperialism without war. This arm is the Mutual Security Program, miscalled "foreign aid."

LOS ANGELES, May 3 (AP) -- Home runs by Frank Robinson and Dutch Dotterer sparked the Reds to a 5-3 victory over the Dodgers tonight. The game was marked by a complaint that Stan Williams of the Dodgers was pitching beanballs.

NEWARK, May 3 -- New Jersey's law restricting Sunday sales is "discriminatory" and in violation of the constitutional guarantees of religious freedom, a special three-judge Federal Court was told here today.
Primary contests for Democratic district leaderships in Brooklyn and Queens blossomed yesterday like dandelions after a spring rain.

ROME, May 3 (AP) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, was extended to four sets in winning a first-round match with Eduardo Soriano of Argentina in the Rome tennis tournament today. The scores were 7-9, 6-3, 6-2, 6-0.
Pablo Casals said yesterday that Generalissimo Francisco Franco would not be able to pass the Spanish Government on to a king.

HOUSTON, May 3 (AP) -- Bill Collins of Crystal River, Fla., defeated Arnold Palmer of Ligonier, Pa., by two strokes in the Houston Classic golf tournament play-off today. Collins shot a three-under-par 69.
SEOUL, Korea, May 3 -- South Korea's new Government abolished the militant Student Defense Corps today in another move to end the regimentation built up under former President Syngman Rhee.

THE Very Rev. Laurence Joseph McGinley, rector and president of Fordham University since 1949, was once described by no less a layman than James A. Farley as an "ideal Jesuit." His qualifications for this epithet are many.

Herbert Ross, choreographer, and Nora Kaye, ballerina, will form a new ballet company under the auspices of the Belgian impresario, Henriques Pimentel. It will begin its operations with a European tour opening at the Nervi Festival in Italy late in August.

HILLSDALE, Mich., May 3 (AP) -- Friends, angry at the Government's Federal crop price support program, banded together today to keep a 68-year-old farmer from losing his $22,000 farm in a $310 tax sale.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Merged labor charged today that Congress had achieved a "record of failure," with adjournment only two months off.

DETROIT, May 3 (UPI) -- A real estate broker testifed today that the late Dr. Albert Einstein or Dr. Ralph J. Bunche would have no trouble buying a home in the Grosse Pointe suburban area but he was not so sure about Rocky Colavito, the baseball player.
Following are the candidates nominated as delegates and alternates to the Democratic and Republican national conventions in primary petitions on file with the Board of Elections.

Leon A. (Chief) Miller, a Cherokee Indian who was a team-mate of Jim Thorpe's at Carlisle (Pa.) Indian School and a member of the 1912 Olympic team, retired yesterday as City College's lacrosse coach.

Shelley Winters, whose porrayal of a self-centered refugee matron in "The Diary of Anne Frank" brought her an Academy Award, will further exhibit her maternal qualifications in roles as a dope addict, an unwed beatnik, a slovenly adulteress and as the mother of Lolita.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Government of Premier Fidel Castro has asked the State Department to accept Dr. Jose Miro Cardona as the new Cuban Ambassador to the United States.
Following is the text of the address yesterday by Chief Justice Earl Warren at the unveiling of the cornerstone of the Fordham University School of Law:
The General American Transportation Corporation had a net income of $5,070,825 in the first quarter, compared with 3,870,844 in the 1959 period, according to a report by Sam Laud, chairman.
All television stations in the United States -- a total of 5661 -- were closed for a half hour yesterday afternoon for the Conelrad emergency broadcast test.
WASHINGTON. May 3 -- Proceeds of the huge wheat and rice deal the United States and India will conclude tomorrow are to be used to help provide a long-term solution to India's age-old food problem.

The first winner of the Putnam Awards is a novel by William Mulvihill called "The Sands of Kalahari." Scheduled for publication by Putnam in August, the story tells about six persons who survive a plane crash in the great desert of Southwest Africa.
Fifty-four United Nations delegates learned yesterday that lions are polygamous, orangutans are undiplomatic, and that flamingoes coexist peacefully in public -- but practice segregation in private.
The cotton futures market declined 1 to 17 points yesterday, with the distant months the weakest. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was generally quiet.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4 (UPI) -- States Rights candidates took an early lead tonight in Alabama's Democratic pritmary for Presidential elector.

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,059 persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week. This was a decline of 111 from a year ago. The bureau reported a total of 1,801 accidents in that period.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight ended its hearings on payola in broadcasting today and prepared to produce corrective legislation.

THE big day in the lives of thousands of children here is the day they go to the circus. Local youngsters have two shows to choose from -- the Ringling Brothers and Bailey circus at Madison Square Garden and the Hunt Brothers circus at Palisades Amusement Park.

Amerada Petroleum Net earnings of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation in the first quarter were $1.02 a share, against $1.01 a share in the 1959 period, A. Jacobsen, chairman, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Lenny Green's one-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning shoved across the winning run tonight as Washington beat the Cleveland Indians, 7-6. The Tribe had tied the score for the second time in the top of the ninth.

BAGELS, because they have a hole in the middle, are of oftn compared with doughnuts, although in terms that are no exactly complimentary. Sometimes bagels are called varnished doughnuts. They also are known as doughnuts with rigor mortis.

A blackout of Broadway legitimate theatres, as well as of other playhouses in such tryout cities as Boston, Philadelphia and New Haven, looms as a strong possibility, unless progress is made in. current negotiations between producers and actors.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Senate investigators were told will have developed irreversible hearings had frightened some diabetes patients into giving up all medication.
The Government may be critical of advertising every now and then. But when trouble brews that same Government recognizes advertising as one of the best weapons in its arsenal.

COLUMBUS, Ga., May 3 -- President Eisenhower watched a live demonstration of the Army's deadliest weapons today and said it proved the error of those who asserted that "America has become soft and incapable of defending itself."
MASSENA, N.Y., May 3 (AP) -- A retired general said today yearly losses of $887,000 in shipping on the Great Lakes would result from additional water diversion sought by Illinois.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The International Longshoremen's Association received official warning today that it faced ouster from the merged labor federation unless it ended its defiance of federation policy by August. The pier union was reinstated only six months ago after a six-year exile on charges of racket domination.
The nation's banks are doing an increasingly better job of meeting the threat of lone bandits, who account for four out of five attempts at bank hold-ups.

Followng is a list of candidates for party nominations to public office for whom designating petitions had been filed, with the Board of Elections up to last, night's closing hour. In cases where more than one name was submitted for a single vacancy a primary contest is indicated. Incumbents are denoted by an asterisk.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 3 -- Southern Presbyterian churchmen have declined to support a resolution that would have strengthened the Inand of ministers who find their pastorates jeopardized because they have spoken out for fellowship between the races.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- The sun was shining brightly on many an old Kentucky home today. It wafted down with the caressing warmth of a summer's day, glinting off the twin spires at ancient Churchill Downs and giving a chlorophyll glow to the green of the infield grass.
WILLIAM J, who is an uninhibited creator of hats on Fifty-seventh Street, has a message with his madness:
Jail sentences were imposed yesterday in Bronx County Court on ten Bronx youths who had pleaded guilty in the gang murder of 16-year-old John Guzman last September on the steps of Morris High School.

No so many years ago, four or five perhaps, the recognized experts in sports car rallying were usually mathematical geniuses loaded down with stop watches and various shapes of slide rules and books of tables. They enjoyed a supremacy over the average person because no average person could ever hope to cope with these devices effectively.

Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to solve the problem of "recruiting and training an ever-increasing available supply of skilled workers to help the city maintain its role as the leading metropolitan center of the world."

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The White House appealed directly to labor's high command today to seek a formula for ending the picketing of the United Arab Republic ship Cleopatra in New York. The union boycott of the vessel has led to a counter-boycott of United States shipping in Arab ports.

Labor and management for railroad-marine operations jointly notified the National Mediation Board in Washington yesterday that a threatened strike of more than 2,000 marine railroad workers here had been postponed pending the outcome of mediation proceedings.

The Treasury's $6,400,000,000 May refunding was finished smoothly yesterday. There was little activity in the trading market, which had been kept busy on Monday and Tuesday with the buying and selling of the maturing securities and the new issues that took their place.
EVERYTHING has been done in the most impeccable taste in "Ernest in Love," which was sung and acted at the Gramercy Arts Theatre last evening.

Eichberg Co., diamond importers and cutters since 1860, have leased office space in 608 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-ninth Street, for executive and sales headquarters. The space was leased through A. Sheldon Jaffe, broker. It will be occupied July 1.

Plans to tape a ninety-minute television play starring Ingrid Bergman have been postponed by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The network had announced earlier the show would be taped in London and Monte Carlo next month.
MOSCOW, Thursday, May 5 -- The Soviet Communist party and Government went through a major shake-up today.
LONDON, May 4 -- Tens of thousands of tourists, cameras at the ready, streamed through the center of London tonight as preparations for Princess Margaret's wedding entered their final feverish stage.
Following are biographical sketches of some of the key figures in yesterday's shake-up in the Soviet party and Government leadership:

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Motors Insurance Corporation, reported yesterday a net income of $21,187,924 for the first three months of 1960, compared with $10,998,789 a year before.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Thursday, May 5 -- For the first time in almost three decades L.M. Ericsson becomes today an almost fully Swedish-owned telephone company.

LoUISVILLE, May 4 -- The police squad car jolted to a stop in front of Bally Ache's stall this morning. The front doora flew open. Two patrolmen stepped out. Each instinctively patted the bolstered pistol at his hip. They approached the stall and stared appraisingly at the big bay. Just then Jimmy Pitt, the cheerful trainer, came pin-wheeling around the corner.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Miss Mary E. Switzer, director of the Office of Vocational Rehabilitation, announced today the formation of a Medical Advisory Committee with Dr. Howard A. Rusk as chairman.

THE upgrading yesterday of Frol Romanovich Kozlov from the high post of a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union to the secretariat of the Communist party puts the spotlight on a man who had already become known in the West as the "Crown Prince" of the Krem- lin.
Senator Albert Gore said yesterday that he thought Governor Rockefeller, would make a stronger run for the Republicans in the Presidential election than Vice President Nixon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The apartheid policy of South Africa brings to mind an aphorism attributed by H.L. Mencken to Madame Bertin, the milliner of Marie Antoinette, "There is nothing new save that which we have forgotten."

Motorists drained 2,028,000 barrels from the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies of 219,524,000 barrels, compared with 221,552,000 a week earlier and 209,593,000 barrels a year before.

FIT for a queen is the gleaming mahogany banquet table, sumptuously set for twenty-four guests, on Black Starr Gorham's second floor. The reason for this regal setting is the arrival of the Furber Collection, a magnificent dinner service of sterling silver and 24-karat gold, which, it is said, is on display in its entirety for the first time.

The most ambitious and extensive program of free tennis Instruction for boys and girls ever undertaken in this city was projected yesterday at a luncheon given by the Eastern Tennis Patrons at the Hotel Manger Vanderbilt.
Cotton futures moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 17 points (85 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The Mataon Navigation Company announced yesterday that t had petitioned the United States Supreme Court for review of a case involving freight service betwen the West Coast and Hawaii.

HAVANA, May 4 -- Although there has been no let-down in the officially inspired Cuban propaganda against the United States, some diplomatic observers said today that Dr. Castro might wish to explore the possibility of arriving at a form of understanding with Washington.

In its first change of ownership in forty years, the twelve-story and penthouse commercial building at 6 and 8 West Forty-eighth Street, adjoining the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue, has been sold by the 6 8 West Forty-eighth Street Corporation.

The entry for the 1960 United States Open golf championship set a record yesterday. When the closing deadline was reached at 5 P.M. at the United States Golf Association headquarters here, the number was 2,480.

LAST night's program by the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House has as its item of particular interest Lupe Serrano's first appearance here in the central role of Agnes de Mille's "Fall River Legend."
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Government announced today that it would pay up to $8.02 a barrel to cranberry growers hurt when sales were halted last fall.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 -- The United States Embassy issued today an official denial of reports that Ambassador Fletcher Warren had conferred in Ankara with Premier Adnan Menderes.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call by which the House passed, 201 -- 184, a bill for redevelopment in depressed areas:

CHARLESTON, W.Va., May 4 -- Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and John F. Kennedy met in face-to-face debate tonight, but generated little controversy except over their individual aspirations for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (UPI) -- Cal McLish finally gained his first victory of the season today. He also halted Willie Mays hitting streak at sixteen games. The former Cleveland ace pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 3-2 triumph over the San Francisco Giants, allowing only four hits.

Mr. and Mrs. Maynard K. Drury of Locust Valley, L.I., have five children, two more than the Darlings in "Peter Pan." Because of the amount of milk the children drank, the Darling family had to be content with one Newfoundland, prim Nana, whom they engaged as nursemaid.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of a communique issued at the end of a conference of the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization members:
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Rational Academy of Sciences, fitter taking a new look at the potential dangers of atomic radiation, has concluded that there is reason for caution but not concern.

A FEW days ago Bob O'Byrne of New York stepped into a trout stream near Bennington, Vt, where a dozen wormers and spin fishermen were catching nothing. He tried worms for half an hour and couldn't stir a fish.
Michigan is planning to offer $25,000,000 of nighway revenue bonds to competitive bidding on June 14, the state announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, May 4 -- Beau Purple, the surprise winner of the Derby Trial yesterday, won't let to the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. The colt was withdrawn when he came up with bucked left front shin today.

Borg-Warner Corp. The Ingersoll Products division of the Borg-Warner Corporation has acquired the Elgin Metalformers Corporation, Elgin, Ill., Roy C. Ingersoll, chairman of Borg-Warner, has announced.

SHOPPING as exciting and varied as that of a world traveler awaits visitors to the foreign bazaar on the fourth floor, of the Coliseum during the United States World Trade Fair. The fair continues to May 14.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Harold Johnson, a top lightheavyweight title contender, gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Clarence (Tiger) Floyd tonight in a bout best described as a master boxer against a clown. Johnson, the boxer, weighed 178 pounds; Floyd, 171.
NEW ORLEANS, May 4 (AP) -- Judy Eller of Old Hickory, Tenn., defeated Mrs. Mark McGarry, 7 and 6, in the second round of the women's Southern amateur golf tournament today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (UPI) -- Caryl Chessman was the father of a 17-year-old daughter, George T. Davis, Chessman's attorney, revealed today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Senator Barry Goldwater told an enthusiastic assembly of business men today that "Congress has still to come to grips with the real evil in the labor field."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Congressman Emanuel Celler's letter published on April 29 he purports to "set the record straight" concerning absenteeism on the part of his colleague in the House, Representative Ludwig Teller. However, Mr. Celler needs a little setting straight himself in so far as the record goes.

A sharp campaign against certain bishops and priests of the Roman Catholic Church has begun in the Government-controlled press in the Dominican Republic.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Army published today an analysis of Soviet military strategy in which it said the Russians were not undertaking to build the force needed to carry out a surprise nuclear attack on the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A Senate investigation of the safety of the new diabetes medicine Diabinese ended today with new accusations and denials.
CHICAGO, May 4 (UPI) -- Dick Ellsworth, a 20-year-old bonus southpaw just up from the Houston farm club, scattered five hits today and pitched the Cubs to a 5-1 Victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
ALBANY, May 4 -- A state inquiry into school conditions in Harlem has pointed to the need for improvements in the programs and facilities of the predominantly Negro schools.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 5 -- The new South Korean Govemment and the United States Aid Mission have formed a joint high-level group to climinate corruption and inefficiency in the $236,000,000 United States economic assistance program.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Washington Senators downed the Cleveland Indians, 7 -- 6, tonight with Jim Lemon's two-run homer in the seventh inning providing the winning margin.
Somewhere in midtown there appears to tie an inexhaustible tank of gasoline that is gushing about 500 gallons a day into an excavation for the $19,000,000 addition to the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
Twenty-seven local government housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $133,410,000 in the bond market yesterday for the permanent financing of low-rent projects.

TUNIS, May 4 -- North African sentiment, as expressed by leaders of the region, is swinging away from, the United States toward the East. The trend is clearly discernible at official levels and is viewed by many observers here as resulting in part from President Eisenhower's recent endorsement of President de Gaulle's policy for Algeria.
PARENTS who cannot say "no" to a child often rear offspring who have contempt for authority, a psychiatrist observed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Merged labor decided today to make a new effort to tackle what its leaders regard as the chief menace to its future economic strength. It will seek a formula for overcoming the dip in union membership resulting from factory and office automation.

The sale last month of 126,000 shares of the common stock of the Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation by Columbia University was reported this week to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the trustees of Columbia.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Labor's high command rebuffed today an Administration plea to halt picketing of the United Arab Republic ship Cleopatra in New York.

DENVER, May 4 -- The Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Church endorsed overwhelmingly today the organization known as Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State.

TURIN, Italy, May 4. -- France won the world contract bridge championship today as the world bridge tournament came to an end after twelve days of play. An American team, the one called Spingold Two in this tournament, clinched the victory for France by holding Great Britain to a draw, while France had piled up an insurmountable lead over Italy.

New York welcomed the fourth United States World Trade Fair as an old friend yesterday.
The Moore Commission divided itself yesterday into two subcommittees -- one to formulate proposals for a new charter for New York City and the other to work out revisions of city fiscal policy.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The New York University Medical Center was named today as one of eight institutions in a new system of clinical research centers under the National Institutes of Health.

NORWALK, Conn., May 4 -- The Standard News Company, wholesale newspaper distributors, cut off deliveries last light and today of New York lewspapers to a large section of ower Fairfield County. Among the newspapers affected was the New York Times.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A seldom-used House rule was employed today to force passage of a $251,000,000 Democratic distressed areas bill that the Administration had tried for more than a year to kill. The vote on final passage was 201 to 184.

A former gold-mining company is faced with a proxy fight. The company is the Goldfield Consolidated Mines Company, a 54-year-old concern, with headquarters in Reno, Nev. North Atlantic marina terminal operators heard an appeal by a railroad executive yesterday for cooperation to offset the loss of business to the St. Lawrence Seaway.

CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- With the National League season only twenty-three days old, the Chicago Cubs today had Charlie Grimm trade jobs as club manager with Lou Boudreau, a baseball commentator and former American League manager.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- An extremely sensitive technique for studying blood flow through the heart has demonstrated characteristic differences in the responses of athletes and inactive persons to sudden exercise, a noted scientist reported here today.
The annual Playhouse Ball has been arranged for June 11 on the grounds of the Sharon (Conn.) Playhouse. The event will benefit the Sharon Creative Arts Foundation.

BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -- Marty Kutyna mowed down the Red Sox left-handed power hitters and preserved a 5-3 victory for Kansas City over the Red Sox today. It was the first road-game triumph for the Athletics in eight tries.
