WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today he would introduce legislation he described as designed to break up dog-in-the-manger hoarding of baseball talent by major league clubs.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 4 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that nobody could persuade him to run for Vice President.

Governor Rockefeller thanked civil defense workers yesterday for their labors "in an area which has not been understood by the public." He spoke on the second day of the nation-wide Operation Alert, 1960, exercises.
PARIS, May 4 -- Robert Abdesselam, a prominent Algerian Deputy, narrowly escaped assassination today by an Algerian. The latter, presumed to be a Moslem terrorist, was captured.

BONN, Germany, May 4 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, disclosed today a West German plan to head off a threatened economic division of Western Europe.

ALBANY, May 4 -- The State Lottery Commission announced today the revocation of the bingo licenses of a church and an American Legion post. The licenses of two other churches and four other organizations were suspended.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The scientific committee of the Democratic Advisory Council entered a sweeping indictment today of the Administration's space program. It charged that the program had been characterized by repeated failures, lack of priority, insufficient funds and organizational confusion.

DETROIT, May 4 (AP) -- Three United States auto makers reported record sales today and two more said they also were doing very well.

The near rubber positions climbed sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Aggressive short covering and new buying was influenced by strength in London and Singapore. Profit taking and dealer hedge selling supplied the contracts.

PARIS, May 4 -- President de Gaulle returned from a seventeen-day North American tour today with his international prestige reinforced to face familiar domestic problems -- farmers' discontent and continuing warfare in Algeria.

The knitted outerwear industry in 1959 shipped merchandise valued at $1,000,000,000, according to Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association. Shipments, he said, were about 15 per cent above those in 1958.

The Fairbanks Whitney Corporation cleared $465,000, or 4.3 cents a common share in the first quarter of 1960, after preferred dividends, on sales of 136,715,000. In the 1959 quarter, the company had a net income and special credit of $131,000 and sales of $36,256,000.

CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- The grain futures market swung into fairly general weakness today as liquidation, some of it for profit cashing, stalled a slightly higher early trend.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 4 -- George A. Bowling was sad today as he roamed the sunny fields and wooded hills of Strathglass Farm, which he manages. His "family" of 200 head of registered brown-and-white Ayrshire cattle is to be put on the auction block.

Amerada The Amerada Petroleum Corporation in the first quarter had a net income of $6,473,337, or $1.03 a share, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $6,382,705, or $1.01 a share, in the 1959 period.

WILBURTON, Okla., May 5 -- At least twenty-three persons were killed by tornadoes that slashed across eastern Oklahoma tonight. At least eleven were killed and scores injured in this college town.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Bill Virdon's two-run pinch triple with two out in the ninth inning lifted the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 9-7 victory that ruined Lou Boudreau's debut as the Chicago Cubs' manager today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- Roy Sievers, the former Washington slugger, hit a two-run homer in his first appearance here since his trade to Chicago to pace the White Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Senators tonight.
PARIS, May 5 (UPI) -- The French Lawn Tennis Federation made formal proposals today to give official status to so-called amateur tennis players who receive financial aid.
LONDON, May 5 -- British officials took a calm view of the "tough" speech delivered by Premier Khrushchev to the Supreme Soviet today.

Seven yachtsmen, several of them well known in North Jersey, are starting across the Atlantic this week in Donald C. Stone's new German-built fifty-five-foot ketch-rigged Rolling Stone V.

MOSCOW, May 5 -- Premier Khrushchev proclaimed a complex fiscal reform today. The changes will bring a new and more costly ruble into Soviet circulation next year and an abolition of most personal income taxes by 1965.

TURIN, Italy, May 5 -- Perhaps the most noteworthy and least noticed aspect of the world bridge tournament that ended here last night and was won by France in a photo finish with Great Britain is the respect in which American bridge and bridge players are still held by the other bridge players of the world.

Kenny Davidoff of the Hebrew Educational Society and Carl Obert of the New York Athletic Club gained the final of the National Amateur Athletic Union one-wall handball championship last night at the Hebrew Educational Society of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The United States export surplus rose to an annual rate of $2,700,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Ford Motor Company has signed an agreement to acquire for $2,300,000 most of the assets of Sherman Products, Inc., makers of power diggers, backhoes, transmissions and industrial loaders for tractors.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The National Association of Manufacturers designated today the heads of three relatively small companies to represent employers in making arrangements for the labor-management summit conference initiated by President Eisenhower.

Dr. Frank R. Kille, Associate State Education Commissioner, said yesterday that the state's recent action against the Yeshiva University Graduate School of Education had been misinterpreted by some segments of the public.

Kremlin politics resemble an iceberg, since what is visible is far less than what is hidden from view. Major changes in Soviet leadership, such as that which has just taken place, are announced without warning and without explanation to the Soviet people. And both the Soviet people and we can only speculate as to what factional intrigues or policy differences lie behind the rise and fall of individual leaders.

Production of lumber dipped in the week ended Saturday to 253,474,000 board feet from 259,688,000 board feet the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the output was 248,622,000 board feet.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points off to 15 up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

ONE fashion show that invariably draws a first night audience of industry professionals, will take place next Tuesday evening when the Parsons School of Design presents its thirty-sixth, annual showing of the costume design students' work.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promoted eleven high-ranking officers yesterday. Three rose to the rank of assistant chief inspector, four to deputy chief inspector and four to inspector.

LONDON, May 6 -- Margaret's wedding day was glorious. Both the crowd and the guests were dressed in summery fashions.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- Herb Score, a former American League strikeout king, tonight gained his first victory since last July 3. He pitched three-hit ball for six innings as the Chicago White Sox beat the Washintgon Seantors, 3 -- 0.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 6 (AP) -- Jerry Barber, the oldest and smallest player in the field, shot a 6-under-par 66 today to take the lead in the $42,400 Tournament of Champions with a total of 135.
The Board of Education is hoping to go ahead with its plans for an administrative reorganization of the school system despite its recent failure to obtain enabling legislation.
Rensselaer County, N.Y., is planning the sale of $2,028,500 of serial improvement bonds on May 19. The issue will come due from 1960 to 1988.
Laws on gambling and obscenity are inherently equivocal and have created a "disgust for all law" in the public mind, District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens said yesterday.

More than 40,000 restaurateurs from this country, Asia and Europe will meet next week on the Navy Pier in Chicago for the forty-first annual convention and exposition of the National Restaurant Association. About 1,200 exhibitors' booths will occupy almost seven linear miles on both sides of the pier during the four-day event.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 6 -- Hundreds of students stormed the Dutch diplomatic compound today in protest against the Netherlands' plans to strengthen military forces in Dutch New Guinea.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Key union leaders have drafted a labor platform to guide the Democratic party in the Presidential campaign.

PARIS, May 6 -- Chancellor Adenauer will arrive here May 15 for last-minute consultations with the Western Big Three heads of government before their meeting starting the next day with Premier Khrushchev.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- The shortcomings of college courses in motion picture and television work were discussed today at the eighty-seventh semi-annual convention of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Government has grounded for fifteen days all foreign-based U-2 weather observation planes of the type believed to have been downed over the Soviet border last Sunday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 -- Leading maritime powers will open a month-long conference on safety of life at sea May 17 in London.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that his plan to visit the Soviet Union next month was subject to change.
BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored seven runs in the fourth inning tonight and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The administration has decided on a greatly accelerated program of research into improved methods of detecting underground nuclear explosions.
THE pageantry and spiritual solemnity of the wedding of Princess Margaret and Antony Armstrong-Jones were brilliantly reported yesterday by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (AP) -- The three Willies -- Mays, McCovey and Kirkland -- hit home runs and Sam Jones pitched a three-hitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants scored a 5-to-1 victory over Pittsburgh. The loss shaved the Pirates' National League lead to one game over the Giants.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 6 -- A golfer with a short swing went a long way today. Ed Neu, a 45-year-old member of the Southward Ho Club in Bay Shore, won the medal in the William D. Richardson memorial tourney with a 68.
PARIS. Russia's political billboard system usually points to the men most likely to inherit future power. This does not mean they will hold such power but merely that they will gain it.

Guests in Spanish costumes or with mantillas stepped back into the mid-nineteenth century last night for "A Night in San Juan," theme of the ninety-first anniversary ball for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital.

Spring will bloom most of the year round in the city's newest brokerage office, and probably its most colorful. Richard J. Buck Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, opened a new office yesterday in the Wall Street area west of Trinity Church, at 4 Albany Street.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- Following is the text of the United States note delivered to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today:

LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies survived a fifteen-strikeout performance by Sandy Koufax, broke through for five runs in the tenth inning and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6 -- 1, tonight before 20,165 fans.
A threat to strike voluntary hospitals that refuse "immediate negotiations for union contracts" has been renewed by Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union.
The twenty-six men of the Richmond Engine Company on Staten Island will soon doff their fire helmets and expel the smoke of many blazes from their lungs -- but not their memories.

The twenty-six men of the Richmond Engine Company on Staten Island will soon doff their fire helmets and expel the smoke of many blazes from their lungs -- but not their memories.
LONDON, May 6 -- Margaret of Windsor, princess of an ancient house, and Antony Armstrong-Jones, a middle-class photographer, were married today.
Columbia recorded its tenth baseball victory of the season by defeating Manhattan, 16 -- 6, with the help of four home runs at Baker Field yesterday.
A Presbyterian commission holding nearly $100,000 worth of common stock in the F.W. Woolworth Company has been urged to protest the company's racial policies "in certain parts of our nation."
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The State Department intervened successfully today in the dispute over the picketing of the United Arab Republic ship Cleopatra to end the boycott against the vessel.
Royal Native, who brought a price of $252,500 on March 16, makes her season debut at Aqueduct today against six rivals in the $27.450 Bed O'Roses Handicap.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The House Appropriations Committee proposed today a new approach to the farm problem as it approved a bill appropriating $3,964,781,500 to finance the Agriculture Department in the fiscal year starting July 1.

Twenty-six men and women who pleaded guilty of refusing to take shelter in Tuesday's airraid drill were sentenced yesterday to serve five days in jail. A twenty-seventh who was convicted after a trial will be sentenced Monday.

JUAN-LES-PINS, France, May 6 -- The tournament held at this Riviera resort each spring at about this time is traditionally the most international of all bridge competitions even though no official championship is at stake.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 6 -- Former President Ismet Inonu, leader of the embattled Turkish Opposition, predicted today that Turks would reject "the oppressive regime" of Premier Adnan Menderes.

A SPECIAL Mother's Day "flower show" is open on Gimbels' main floor. Outstand are the ready-made fake floral arrangements at $3.95 each. In the gift department on the fifth floor there is a guest expert on hand to demonstrate the art of arranging plastic blooms.
The capture of a pawn by Mikhail Tal of Latvia enlivened play in the eighteenth game of his world championship chess match with Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, according to Soviet news sources.

Premier Khrushchev waited four days to tell the world that Russian gunners had shot down an American plane with what Foreign Minister Gromyko subsequently defined as a "remarkable rocket." Mr. Khrushchev did not in the interim publicly address questions to any American air base in Turkey or elsewhere or to Washington. He did not say what had happened to the pilot of the lost plane.
American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Walter Hochschild, 59, as chairman and chief executive officer and Frank Coolbaugh, 51, as president.

LONDON, May 6 -- The trend was undecided in the stock market here today. A little bearishness on the last day of the three-week account period and modest investment demand lifted selected stocks, but the movement soon petered out and most of the early gains were either reduced or eliminated.

THERE were no chestnuts on the program Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic devoted to opera at Carnegie Hall yesterday. Grave aspects of the lyric theatre were represented by excerpts from works by Boito and Hindemith, while the lighter side had Lukas Foss and Virgil Thomson as its minstrels.
BONN, Germany, May 6 -- West Germany decided today to oppose any extension of the statute of limitations dealing with crimes committed under the Nazis.

CINCINNATI, May 6 (AP) -- Jim O'Toole, a left-hander, pitched a four-hitter tonight for the Cincinnati Reds and shut out the St. Louis Cardinals, 1 -- 0. It was the fifth straight victory for Cincinnati.
In Central Park last week, workmen tore down a fifty-year-old arbor, the decaying host to five wisteria vines. This, in the view of John C. Georgi, was horticultural homicide.

Kansas City, which took the field with five former Yankees in the line-up and six more on the bench, made the resident Yankees work overtime yesterday. Or perhaps the resident Yankees had themselves to blame for the extra toil it took to post an 8-7 victory over the Athletics, a team that has facetiously been termed their Western branch.
A project to build two gigantic "cafeteria-style" ocean liners for trans-Atlantic service will be pressed in talks with the West German Government later this month.
LONDON, May 6 -- Friends, loyal countrymen, well-wishers from all parts of the Commonwealth and heads of state have showered Princess Margaret and Antony Armstrong-Jones with wedding gifts.
New York State Electric Gas Corporation expects "within the next few months" to file for higher gas rates, Joseph M. Bell Jr., president, told the annual meeting yesterday at
MOSCOW, May 7 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, a 54-year-old Communist party functionary, was chosen today to succeed 79-year-old Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov as titular chief of state of the Soviet Union.

Miss Ann McCauley is chairman of a group of debutantes of the 1960-61 season who have volunteered to assist as teatime hostesses at the annual Spring Party for new contributing members of the Girls Club of New York.

Shipyard workers are busy preparing the liner France, future monarch of the French merchant fleet, for her launching at Saint Nazaire on Wednesday.

One of the newest and fastest growing boat builders in New Jersey is Sica Industries in Toms River. In the little more than six months that the company has been producing Sica Skiffs, an improved version of the famous Jersey Sea Skiffs, Sica Industries has expanded to the point where it now has fifteen franchised dealers on the East Coast and a large backlog of orders.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- The Springfield stable's Troubadour II, a 24-1 shot, set a Pimlico grass course record today in winning the $17,800 Riggs Handicap.

LAST year, when Joe Alex Morris was writing this biography, there was a strong possibility that Nelson Rockefeller would be a serious contender for the Republican nomination. It is not the author's fault that this prospect fadedalthough by no means completely disappeared -- before the book was published.

SIDI BEL-ABBES, Algeria, April 30 -- The Foreign Legion, which lost almost 14,000 men in Indochina and more than 2,000 so far in Algeria, interrupted the war long enough today to honor a handful of Legionnaires who died nearly a hundred years ago.

THE exotic, self-contained world of the legitimate theatre is the target for Mr. Morgan's fourth novel. Here he exposes the mental workings of a playwright, an actor, a director and three actresses embroiled in the delicate sculpting of a Broadway play.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 (UPI) -- Norm Sherry's home run in the bottom of the eleventh inning tonight lifted the Los Angeles Dodgers and his brother, Larry Sherry, to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

One of the key props under the nation's economy -- construction -- has proved to be surprisingly shaky so far this year. That, in turn, helps to explain why the much-anticipated Big Boom of 1960 just hasn't materialized even though business conditions are generally good.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Elsenhower announced today a six-fold expansion of the United States program to improve the detection of underground nuclear explosions. The President said that the expanded program, known as Project Vela, would involve a series of underground nuclear explosions of various sizes in different kinds of geological formations.
OMAHA, Neb., May 7 -- Senator Stuart Symington urged tonight that Congress pass and President Eisenhower sign legislation to make more effective use of farm surpluses at home and abroad.
Several New York savings bankers have renewed an assault on the interest-dividend ceiling on their deposits imposed last year by the State Banking Department.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Premier Khrushchev jubilantly reported today the capture of the pilot of a United States plane that he said had been shot down on May Day. He said the American had admitted attempting to carry out a photo-reconnaissance mission all the way across the Soviet Union from Pakistan to Norway.
AMES, Iowa, May 1 -- Farmrs in the Midwestern Corn Belt rant more money to keep their rich land idle and prevent the build-up of surplus feed grains.
NOW that "The Fugitive Kind" has been launched with indications that it will be Sidney Lumet's first major commercial success, the director is enjoying, in his own words, "a feeling of vindication."

The public airings of some phases of city inquiries into violations of the Fair Housing Practices Law is under, consideration. The publicity, it is believed, would help bring greater obedience to the law.

Farrell's noted "Studs Lonigan" trilogy into a ninety-six-minute feature, which should be released by United Artists here on or about July 15, the pair now intend to do a comprehensive film version of Rabelais' famed works, "Gargantua" and "Pantagruel."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 7 -- Rutgers rowed to a two-length victory over the Boston University varsity crew on a new Raritan River course today.

SIX months -- and more than half a million paid admissions -- after the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum opened its plate-glass doors on Fifth Avenue to a fanfare of publicity, the controversy it set off continues to rage. The Guggenheim, final, flamboyant gesture of the late Frank Lloyd Wright, has been hailed as a masterpiece, attacked as an atrocity, called the finest museum of all time and denounced as no museum at all.

THERE is an occasional complaint -- understandable though injudicious -- that contemporary fiction deals far too much with sordid characters and unhealthy situations. "Tippy Locklin" seems a novel accidentally designed to put an end to all such loose generalization.

VIVIEN LEIGH is entertaining the idea of making her American television drama debut in "Camille," a role she never has played in any medium. Obviously the British actress believes in double accomplishments with a single effort.

Economists who have been worried about this nation's gold loss in recent years can fret a little less this year because the rate of outflow has leveled off. TRIPS that branch out from the well-covered tourist routes are gaining in favor. Because of the jet, far-away places, with their strange and unusual scenes, have swung into the vacation orbit. The Presidential primaries of past years have produced a mixed bag of results. They have materially helped some candidates, such as Dwight Eisenhower in 1952. BLACK-AND-WHITE exposure indexes have been officially doubled in speed as the result of an approved new American standard just published by the American Standards Association. The new standard also includes a simplified new method of designating film speeds.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 7 (UPI) -- Jerry Barber, a master putter for the third day in a row, increased his lead in the $45,000 Tournament of Champions to two strokes today. He shot his second straight 66 for a 54-hole total of 201.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 7 (AP) -- Emil Dolce's Manassa Mauler triumphed under Bill Boland today in the $25,000-Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park.

To the Screen Editor: With all due respect to your past achievements in the art of criticism, I find myself highly indignant over the esthetics and moral values by which you judge Tennessee Williams' "The Fugitive Kind".

TO THE EDITOR: Two letters printed on April 24 criticized Alan Paton's article on South Africa ("As Blind as Samson Was," April 10) on the grounds that it did not provide a "constructive" alternative to apartheid -- an alternative that would be equally successful in protecting the property of the white South Africans.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (UPI) -- Gary Bell pitched a five-hitter today and led the Cleveland Indians to a 3-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles before 11,133 fans.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., May 7 -- Mascha vom Stuhri-Gau, a 4 1/2-year-old female owned by John H. Wilkins Jr. of Remington, Va., was named best in show at the twelfth annual German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island fixture today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 6 -- Three University of Michigan social scientists, who have just completed a twelve-year study of the American voter, cited today factors that point toward a Democratic victory in the November general election.

TO THE EDITOR: Mr. Gould'a article is very puzzling to us here. [Mr. Gould said that "one of the better Hops in the business world of late has been the vain attempt to bring back Granny's Old Rocking Chair." -- Editor.]

WHEN a television actor journeys between the East and West Coasts these days he is most likely to use jet aircraft. If he is coming to New York he may be expected to check in at a fashionable midtown hotel.

The financial affairs of the United Mine Workers Union, publicly disclosed for the first time in reports required by the Landrum-Griffin Act, show an organization of great wealth, not only a labor union but highly successful in a purely business way. There could be no better example of the capitalistic unionism so characteristic of this country.

Dr. Leo Kanner, noted American child psychiatrist, will receive the first annual award of the National Organization for Mentally Ill Children at a ball to be given by the organization at the Plaza on May 17.

CINCINNATI, May 7 (UPI) -- Eddie Kasko drove home three runs with a double and a triple as the Cincinnati Reds ran their winning streak to six games today with a 6-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7 -- Harvard's 150-pound crew clipped nearly two seconds off the Lake Carnegie lightweight record in defeating Princeton and Penn today. The Crimson won by more than three lengths.
A sharp rise in the number of complaints about the home-improvement industry has prompted the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York to open a special campaign to combat abuses.

THE big news in the record business these days -- as well, one presumes, as in all walks of life where the future of music is a matter of concern -- is that Elvis Is Back! That, as the bold-faced type is supposed to indicate, is also the title of Elvis Presley's first post-Army disk for Victor.
MORE than 500 of the tired but fulfilled-looking visitors in town today are members of the National Committee on Art Education, who arrived here Thursday for their Eighteenth Annual Conference.

IN his Rede Lecture for 1959, "The Two Cultures and the Scientific Kevolution," C.P. Snow showed how very seriously he takes his unique and now really commanding position in Anglo-American letters. He is the only major novelist who knows intimately the worlds of the physical sciences, big business and public administration, and who has himself exercised power as one of the "new men" of the nuclear age.
PRINCETON, May 7 -- Harvard's heavyweight crews won all three races in the twenty-fourth Compton Cup regatta today.

IF any person in our contemporary world is entitled to a hearing it is Wilhelm Roepke; if anyone, as a result of education and accomplishment, is capable of making out a case for conservative doctrine, it is he Roepke, German born and trained, was embarked on an honorable career as economist, university teacher and public servant, when Hitler's triumph compelled him to flee his country.

IN our time of creeping concrete, the nature book is a perennial flower. And for children the spring flow of books on the outdoors stirs a sense of wonder which deserves thoughtful cultivation by parents.

If today is a typical Sunday in the United States, every thirty-five minutes a child between the ages of 1 and 15 will be killed by accident. Since it is spring and most youngsters will be out of doors, fatalities will probably be higher today than most days.

THE decision by the New York Philharmonic's board of directors to dispense with boxes in its new hall at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts was made several weeks ago. It became a matter of public knowledge despite Philharmonic officials.
Ralph Terry brightened the Yankees' pitching picture yesterday by downing the Athletics, 4-1, with a five-hitter before a Ladies' Day gathering of 20,156 at the Stadium.

Four commuters on the 7:43 from New Canaan discussed an idea in 1952. Today four seats on the same train from the Connecticut suburb to New York serve as the board room for the directors of a fast-growing real estate concern.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y -- Somewhere along the line, the Catskill Mountains seem to have acquired the reputation of being a group of posh resort hotels, golf courses and comedians somewhat separated by highly civilized hills.
DERBY, Conn., May 7 -- Pennsylvania's undefeated varsity crew won the Blackwell Cup today for the first time since 1955.

HEBER, Utah -- Just a half-dozen miles from U.S. 40, the transcontinental route that links Denver and Reno, via Salt Lake City, an advance guard of vacationists is launching boats and wetting fishing lines in the 2,900-acre Deer Creek Reservoir.
HONOLULU -- Sight-seeing in the Hawaiian Islands by freighter is an economical, relaxing and unhackneyed way of exploring the nation's newest state. We have just returned from such a jaunt.
The Port of New York lost less than 2 per cent of its general-cargo business to the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1959, the first year of the waterway's operation.

WASHINGTON. ANY thoughtful American must admit that our Presidential campaigns have got completely out of hand. When it comes to the method of choosing our principal administrative officer, we rank at the bottom of the the list of democratic countries.

TEN New Jersey garden clubs have received awards of $100 each to either start or to advance their favorite horticultural projects. Earlier this year the Sears Roebuck Foundation made a grant of $1,000 to the Garden Club of New Jersey to encourage community beautification programs.

The outlook for useful discussions at the summit, which was not very encouraging to begin with, has taken a turn for the worse as a result of the threatening speeches by Premier Khrushchev in Baku and Moscow.

MIAMI BEACH -- The curtain has risen again on Act II of "The Miami Beach Story" and the producers, in this case the hotel operators, are hopefully confident that their predictions of another hit will come true.

AT the opening of this book Kathy O'Farrell, who rose from honky-tonk dancer to screen siren and then went to hell in a handbasket, is lying drunk in the rain in a New York gutter, outside the theatre housing the Ed Sullivan show.

City terraces and patios that were designed for a colorful spring show should be at their best this week-end. Early lilacs, rhododendrons, azaleas, dogwood and tulips are now flowering in the New York area. NEW YORK CITY Channel Gardens (Rockefeller Center) -- 350 azaleas and rhododendrons.

HISTORY seems to be without any record of Harry Talvace. Born of noble parents in the vicinity of Shrewsbury, a refugee from justice and an apprentice mason in Paris during the early years of the thirteenth century, he returned to England -- so this novel tells us -- to build an unusual church near the Welsh marshes, and was finally executed by his former patron about 1215.

THE summer-flowering bulbs are versatile. They can be used alone or in mixed plantings for dramatic color accents and are particularly valuable for camouflaging spring bulbs and out-of-bloom perennials.
The first of a new line of missiles that are expected to prolong the life of current bombers will be ready for duty early this summer.

AUTOMOBILE stories for young people seem now to nave shaken down into two main groups -- one concerning the hot-rod driver with personal problems and the other about the young man with the big race to win.
All problems in marine transportation of liquefied petroleum gas can be surmounted, the annual tanker conference of the American Petroleum Institute was told last week.

Retail sales last week in this area continued at a strong pace. For several weeks now sales have bettered year-ago levels by more than 10 per cent Last week was far from the exception. Merchants estimated the gain at 19 per cent from 1959.
POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., May 5 -- The familiar sound of the calliope of the showboat Majestic was heard here for the last time yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 6 -- A spokesman for Euratom said today it was "strange" that his organization had not been asked to send a representative to the meeting at Bellagio.
HAVANA, May 6 -- Premier Fidel Castro will become a regular weekly television attract in Cuba beginning next Friday night.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah -- Despite "certain historical inaccuracies, including a lack of slim horsemen and the prevalence of paved roads in the once Wild West," visitors to eight western and midwestern states this summer are promised "a major memorial event of the 1960 vacation season."
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- An imaginative $3,500,000,000 program for the Philadelphia of tomorrow was outlined this week by the City Planning Commission.
The inventor of a labor- and material-saving Machine in a lithographing process gave credit yesterday to his unionized workers for helping to perfect his invention.

DENVER, Colo. -- There was mean laughter in this mile-high state capital some months ago when residents learned that a Sky Deck for tourists was being built on top of the new twenty-eight-story First National Bank Building.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. -- The massive redevelopment of the Niagara Frontier's power-parks-parkways potential at a cost exceeding $800,000,000 will pay its first dividends next month. Visitors to Niagara's state parks will be the beneficiaries.

GSTAAD, Switzerland -- Even without the diversified special events that are scheduled for the next few months, including the Yehudi Menuhin Festival in August, Gstaad should be one of the major tourist attractions in Switzerland this summer.

Durability of Satire Satire's durability, which has been proved over and over again since the days of the Greek playwrights, is currently being impressed upon us on West Fifty-fifth Street, where the leprechaun of "Finian's Rainbow" once more is at large on the stage of the City Center.
A real estate broker has labeled as a myth the general belief that the city's newly built office space is being absorbed by corporations that are new-comers to the city.

TRENTON, May 7 -- From Sandy Hook to Delaware Break-water around the bay and far north into the murky Delaware River, marinas, boatyards, docks, wharfs and bulkheads were swarming this week with pleasure boats.

If results for Mother's Day prove to be as good as those for Easter, the retail picture will continue to grow stronger this month. This is the consensus of most retailers who have found that there was no falling off after the Easter holiday.

TRENTON, May 7 -- Voters in sixteen New Jersey communities will go to the polls Tuesday to elect local officials. The municipalities involved have commissioner, council-mayor, or council-manager governments.

IN the spring of 1910, just fifty years ago, the world awaited the arrival of a visitor from outer space. It had a fiery visage and news of its coming set up a frontal wave of excitement: the ignorant were struck with man's age-old fear of the unknown; scientists were keyed up by the chance of finding out more about a most remarkable phenomenon.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- Five months ago the New York State Traffic Commission, acting on pleas from hotel owners in ullivan County, increased from 50 to 60 miles an hour the speed mit on the Route 17 Quickway.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 7 -- The groundwork is being laid here for what may develop into a test of Texas laws designed to thwart school integration. The showdown, if it develops, would center on a 1957 statute which prohibits the granting of state financial aid to school districts which integrate classes without approval of the district's residents.
NEW ORLEANS, May 7 -- White parents here have voted overwhelmingly in a School Board poll to close the public schools rather than accept even token desegregation.

A GOOD picture book views the world for children through a magnifying glass. It focuses on a single theme, enlarging it to the point where the image or lesson is sharp and clear to the child's eye and thus readily grasped by his mind.

WITH an easily installed time switch or timing control, homeowners can now arrange to have their lights, appliances and sprinkler systems turned on or off automatically at any predetermined hour -- and in any given sequence.

SEVERAL, excellent introductions to archaeology for young readers are on the market, so "Good Digging" is by no means a pioneer work; it is, however, the best and most comprehensive of the lot. Rand McNally, using the know-how gained from the production of variegated atlases and associated reference works, has produced the book by offset lithography and a helpful distribution of pictures and maps throughout the text.
Andrew Jackson captured the team championship in the thirteenth annual interscholastic track and field games at Brooklyn College yesterday. Sixty public and ten parochial schools competed.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 7 -- Betting Time and Major Goose won the Messenger Stake trials at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
BOSTON, May 7 -- Bill Mon-bouquette held Detroit hitless today after giving a double to the second batter of the game. The Boston right-hander pitched a 5-0 victory.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States statement today on the plane downed in the Soviet Union contained the first official Government disclosure that this country was engaged in aerial intelligence efforts.
Reinforced concrete is rapidly replacing steel as the dominant material for the framework of tall apartment buildings being built in New York.
Systems utilizing the heat from people, lights and business machines to help warm entire office buildings in northern climates may become widespread in the next ten years.
The waning metropolitan art season still has enough life in it to offer a number of interesting exhibitions.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Vice President Nixon reshaped his campaign plans today on the theory that Senator John F. Kennedy would win the West Virginia primary Tuesday and go on to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 7 -- The single point of agreement between rival politicians in Turkey is that the Army has so far maintained its traditional aloofness from Turkish politics.
Seven small businesses, with combined volume of more than $60,000,000 a year, have formed a pool to capture military contracts of $10,000,000 and more.

TO THE BOATING EDITOR: Can you give information where I may learn of public launching ramps and their locations on Long Island, both on the Sound (north shore) and on Great South Bay (south shore)? 10 High Street, Port Washington, N.Y.

WHEN the first warm breezes of spring are wafted through an open window, there are probably always a few city dwellers poring over the travel pages, who murmur, "Maybe we ought to try something different for a vacation this year.
WOULD-BE homeowners scanning the classified - advertising sections of newspapers for leads to possible houses are by now quite familiar with notices like the following:
A sales executive was fatally injured yesterday in the second hit-and-run automobile accident in the city within six hours.

With a suddenness that has astonished even the experts Premier Khrushchev has drastically changed the climate of international affairs. The manner in which he has employed the airplane incident has sent the international political thermometers plummeting lower than anything since November, 1956, when Soviet troops crushed the Hungarian revolution.
ROME, May 6 -- The Italian National Committee for Nuclear Research expressed astonishment and indignation today at not having been invited to participate to a conference in Italy on nuclear research.
One thing is sure about the spring fitting-cut chores that give your pleasure boat a facelifting and a new lease on lift for another season. It must have a shake-down cruise.

Sour THE British sometimes can be mean, real mean. Our own Vermont "Folk Medicine" was published over there the other day, Dr. Jarvis' little book which stresses the beneficial properties of apple-cider vinegar and honey.

LISSE, Holland. THE star of tulip time in the Netherlands this year is the new race of greigi hybrids -- the tulips of tomorrow. A few of these new hybrids may be found on select lists for planting this fall.

As the preconvention campaigns for the Presidential nominations enter the home stretch it is becoming unmistakably clear that public opinion polls and the pollsters who take them are enjoying more influence than ever before in American politics.

AMONG the peculiar madnesses that beset Americans during the Nineteen Twenties was the belief that S.S. Van Dine wrote great detective stories. It was part of what H.L. Mencken called the American Credo that the cases of Philo Vance existed on a somehow higher cultural level than any other murder mystery -- although Dorothy Sayers, Anthony Berkeley and Dashiell Hammett had all begun to write before Van Dine.

ATLANTIC CITY -- New Jersey shore officials, from the historic village of Cape May north to Raritan Bay, predict a record influx of visitors during the next three months. Their optimism is not unfounded.

Hofstra College retained first place in Metropolitan Conference baseball by defeating City College of New York, 5 -- 3, yesterday at Babe Ruth Field. It was the Flying Dutchmen's ninth straight victory.

To THE BOATING EDITOR: I intend to rent a boat from the American Yachting System for two weeks from July 3 to July 17. Please recommend a route or tour for my family. I have no previous boating experience. I am a landlubber.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 7 -- Mason Sears of the United States, back from his ninth African visit, has urged that the United Nations play a more forceful role in Africa.

SOME years ago a reviewer, angered by a book of mine which had undertaken to survey the recent course of American literature and to venture a few prophecies as to its immediate future, took his cue from the title ("The Shape of Books to Come") and chose, for his punch-line, to observe that "unfriendly readers may think that what he chiefly knows about books, past, present, and to come, is their shape."
LOUISVILLE, May 7 -- The Sunny Blue Farm's Venetian Way was all by himself at the finish of the mile-and-a-quarter Kentucky Derby today.

WITH thoughtful planning and selection of plant material in spring, the garden should have an abundance of color all through the difficult summer season. A number of excellent perennial plants can be counted on.

APODDLEY, in case you don't get around, is an odd little green fellow "about a foot high in a pith helmet and a white nightgown with a numbered star pinned on it, a long inquisitive nose, and a pleasant expression."
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon said today the Administration's healthcare plan for the aged was "superior" in five major respects to the Forand bill advocated by the Democrats.
WASHINGTON. THE I960 Presidential campaign may be of interest to historians for any number of reasons, but this observer will remember it as the Tear of the Image in politics.
A total of 2,311 oceangoing vessels entered or left the port of New York last month, according to the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
ROME. THE most lively topics of conversation for Americans doing Rome this cloudy spring have been the execution of Caryl Chessman and an extraordinary new Italian film.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. -- Here in the North Country, the venerable York State name for the Adirondacks, which are also the North Woods -- equally venerable name for the Adirondack forests-a great specialty is the air. It is so clear and fresh, so free of the pollens to which hay fever Is attributed, that thousands of susceptible folk summer here every year, mostly to escape the sniffles and the migraine.

MOUNTAINHOME, Pa. -- It was just about fifty years ago when vacacationists were beginning to arrive in large numbers in this heartland area of the Pocono Mountains. The railroads were running as many as three or four extra sections, and the crowds came to stay at their favorite boarding house or hotel for weeks, months or even the whole summer.

THE late Ignace Jan Paderewski, Polish pianist, composer, statesman and humanitarian, will be postally honored by Washington this year. Four-cent and 80 stamps hailing him as a "Champion of Liberty" have been added to the schedule by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7 -- Yale's track team crushed Princeton, 118 -- 22, today. Only a record Princeton heave of 233 feet 1 inch by Ed Thurber in the javelin and a tie in the high jump kept Yale from sweeping very first place.

SEOUL, Korea, May 7 -- Army troops invaded a Buddhist temple compound today to break up the first open move to form a moderate Leftist opposition party in South Korea since Dr. Syngman Rhee relinquished the Presidency last week to an independent "caretaker" Government.
A study charging that the United States Employment Service and state groups affiliated with it are usurping the functions of private employment agencies was distributed here yesterday.

One of the more curious corporate merger proposals of recent years was called off abruptly last week. It was to have remarried two companies that were divorced a decade ago but contrived to remain essentially within the same family, anyway.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Tourists coming to Florida by automobile this spring and summer will encounter many visible evidences of what the State Road Department calls "the greatest era of highway construction in the history of Florida."

MARTHA GRAHAM'S season, which closes today at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, has been an occasion for jubilation, not only because of its profound esthetic satisfactions, but also for its sorely needed reassurance about the status of art in America.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 7 (Reuters) -- The International Court of Justice has concluded hearings on Liberia's and Panama's claims to seats on the Maritime Safety Committee of the Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 7 -- Indonesia expressed "official regrets" to the Netherlands today for the destructive anti-Dutch demonstrations by students here yesterday, an acting Foreign Ministry spokesman announced.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States admitted tonight that one of this country's planes equipped for intelligence purposes had "probably" flown over Soviet territory.
A new Moore-McCormack Cargo vessel is scheduled to slide down the ways in Los Angeles next month. She is the first major ship to be built in that port city and surrounding area since World War II.

THE worst part about a summer trip to deep West Indies Islands, judging from my experience, is the trouble you have with friends before you leave home. It was Just about a year ago that I suffered with my friends who looked unanimously aghast when I revealed my holiday plans.

A public hearing on the repeal of Hospital Code provisions that permit many private nursing homes to operate without meeting the code's structural standards will be held Thursday. Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, made the announcement yesterday.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, has sold the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, a group of old four-story tenement houses fronting 101 feet on the avenue and ninety feet on the street.

HUY, Belgium, May 7 -- The Rev. Dominique Georges Henri Pire, a Belgian priest who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1958, will fly to the United States tomorrow, to seek supporters for an organization dedicated to "peace and fraternity among mankind."

One young American faced his "moment of truth" about 65,000 feet over the Soviet Union a week ago yesterday. He apparently decided that life was better than death and his instinctive reaction produced an international incident of unpredictable consequences.

ALBANY, May 8 -- The Federal Government has asked New York to take the lead in a new Federal-state program that allows the states to assume some responsibilities for the peaceful uses of atomic power.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it was modernizing its West Sixtieth Street freight yard to provide more efficient service to New York shippers.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner's proposed commuter benefit tax has fascinating political, social, legal and administrative ramifications. These could affect the outcome of this year's New Jersey elections for the United States Senate and for some House seats, as well as for places in the Legislature.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 8 -- Peddie School's baseball team is still seeking its first victory after nine games, and Tommy Shuman, the Gold and Blue's captain, is sending out the emergency call. He's asking Walter C. Black to attend next Wednesday's game with the Hun School in Princeton.

LIBERTY, N.Y., May 8 -- An authority on human resources warned here tonight that Judaism in this country was confronted with "a serious threat to its vitality and growth" because of the misuse of its rabbinical manpower.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 8 -- Sunday Jump, a grey gelding owned by the Thomas School of Horsemanship at Huntingdon, L.I., and ridden by Linda Thomas, captured the open jumper championship of the three-day Junior Essex Troop horse show tonight.
New York State physicians were urged yesterday to stand united against the advance of socialized medicine.
LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- Judge Simon H. Rifkin's preliminary finding in the Colorado River litigation was one of the worst jolts official California has received in years.

HAVANA, May 8 -- Diplomatic sources expressed the fear today that the forthcoming reopening of a Soviet Embassy here would see Cuba becoming the principal center of Communist propaganda activities in Latin America.

Eugene O'Neill's The Hairy Ape" will be revived off Broadway next January by Paul Shyre and Sara Arlen. One of O'Neill's early, successes -- it followed within two years "The Emperor Jones" and the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Anna Christie" -- the play has not been seen professionally in New York since its original production in 1922.
Announcers, disk jockeys, producers and news writers struck radio station WNEW at 12:05 A.M. today.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., May 8 -- The Democratic political cannonading that has volleyed across West Virginia's rugged mountains and valleys for nearly a month neared an end today with every surface political sign pointing to a "victory" for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, of Minnesota.
IT is good to be all washed up at Sulka's -- if you are a shirt. Not even a satin-skinned infant is bathed more solicitously.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 8 -- A spokesman today privately confirmed reports that one United States concern had agreed to buy 1,500,000 bags of coffee for cash as the Government concentrated its official attention and publicity on an agreement with Russian envoys on shipcents of 330,000 bags in barter this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Chessman execution has created a contradiction between the logic of reasonable men in a democratic society and the illogic of Communist propaganda. That such should be is not cause for concern, but that the free world is ideologically seduced is.

The romantic appeal of far-away places is often surpassed by their appeal to hard-headed business men interested in foreign profits that can be protected from the deep cut of the United States tax axe.
COMMUNITY work or civic projects may be important to many parents, but playing chess or checkers with their own youngsters should come first, according to Dr. Randle Elliott.

SOMETIMES one work stands out on a program of new music and dominates it by virtue of its invention and vitality. William Sydeman's Concerto da Camera for Violin and Chamber Ensemble did that at last night's Music in Our Time program at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 8 -- Senator John F. Kennedy made tonight one of his firmest statements on separation of church and state.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Southern legal efforts to hold the pace of school desegregation to a crawl have been dealt a blow by two Federal court rulings.

TRENTON, May 8 -- After a short judging session, Ch. Crikora Commotion, a stylish miniature poodle from the kennels of Mrs. J. Donald Duncan of New York, was named best in show of the Trenton Kennel Club's thirty-first all-breed event today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) -- Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, said today that if Senator John F. Kennedy failed to win the Presidential nomination at the party convention this year, he would come under strong pressures to accept the Vice Presidential spot.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 8 -- The Turkish Government disclaimed tonight any responsibility for the invasion of Soviet airspace by the United States plane.
SEOUL, Korea, May 8 -- South Korean officials are preparing to ask the United States, in effect, to pay the costs of the overthrow of the Syngman Rhee Government.
LONDON, May 8 -- Embarrassment, concern and dismay were common reactions in Western Europe to the shooting down of a United States information-gathering plane in the Soviet Union.
CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) -- Cincinnati's Reds scored a 5-2 victory over St. Louis today, behind the four-hit pitching of Cal McLish and Bill Henry.

Bight persons were injured yesterday on the lower East Side when a 70-year-old woman accidentally stepped on the accelerator of a stopped car. The car shot wildly along Second Avenue between Second and First Streets.
PARIS, May 8 -- President de Gaulle and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru met for the first time today. They held two hour-long talks.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 6 -- Dealings during the last holiday-shortened week were quiet. International issues were irregular. Royal Dutch was weak in sympathy with the trend on Wall Street and also because the annual report failed to attract investment support.
Archbishop Molloy of Queens won the tenth Fordham Prep relays at Van Cortiandt Park Stadium, the Bronx, yesterday, on a wet track.
CHELAN, Wash., May 8 (AP) -- The speed boat Miss Thriftway won the annual Apple Cup race on Lake Chelan today, taking the final heat easily after two battles with Wahoo.

A STUDY of Germany's economic recovery since the war and its re-emergence as a potentially formidable military power was analyzed Saturday night in a documentary presented on "World Wide 60" over Channel 4.

Shakespeare buffs gave Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare. Festival a helping hand last night.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane said yesterday that a 75-25 pension ratio was in sight for city employes next year.
British pound sterling showed a fairly steady undertone in foreign exchange trading last week. Canadian dollar turned to the weak side in heavy dealings.

Mayor Wagner declined to say yesterday whether he would support Carmine G. De Sapio for re-election as Democratic national committeeman. But he said he preferred Mr. De Sapio as a political leader to someone who would try to interfere with the running of City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- An expert of the International Monetary Fund (world fund), after a lengthy analysis of the potential use of gold or currency manipulation by the Soviet Union, has concluded that the Soviets can cause no important harm to the West by such devices.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The officials of two museums will toss coins soon for paintings valued at millions of dollars.
ROME, May 8 -- Pope John XXIII gave a strong impulse to the propagation of the faith in distant lands by consecrating fourteen missionary Archbishops and Bishops in St. Peter's Basilica today.

The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday that it opposed a resolution directing Congress to pass upon amendments to the interstate compact under which the Port of New York Authority operates.

The American Broadcasting Company has obtained radio rights to the Ingemar Johansson-Floyd Patterson heavyweight championship boxing match at the Polo Grounds on June 20. Bids had been sought from all networks.

The public has nominated 242 persons for this year's election to the Hall of Fame for Great Americans at New York University. From these a maximum of seven may be elected by the shrines college of electors.

NEWARK, May 8 -- In an American Soccer League game at Ironbound Field today, the Newark Portuguese downed the Philadelphia Uhriks, 2 -- 1. George Wilson and Dave Nicol tallied for the victors, while Sigmund Jung scored for the Uhriks.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Congress published today testimony that National Security Council procedures were ponderous and were handicapped by a "strong inertia against initiating new policies."

ORLEANS, Ind., May 8 -- Another new farming method is helping Midwestern farmers beat the cost-price squeeze. It is a tillage technique that saves a father-son farm team near here $3 to $5 an acre in the production of corn.
