Odetta, who is billed as a folk singer, is much more than that term usually implies.
At least one mutual fund plan sponsor shows a leaning toward Shakespeare.

PANAMA, May 8 -- Scattered returns in the general election here today have given former President Ricardo M. Arias Espinosa a slight lead in the Presidential race, according to the Electoral Tribunal.
A wide range of opinion on the incident of the United States plane downed over the Soviet Union was brought out yesterday in interviews with about 100 men and women in four midtown locations.

With Western unity restored for the summit meeting, the West German Government is taking steps to avert a new split and a possible trade war by suggesting a slow-down of the proposed speed-up in the tariff adjustments of the European Economic Community that have prompted outcries of discrimination from the rival European Free Trade Association led by Britain.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy submitted a pessimistic appraisal today of the present feasibility of policing a ban on underground atomic tests.

A bazaar, garden party and tea May 17 will benefit An Association for the Relief of Reapectable Aged Indigent Females in the City of New York. The event will be held at the beneficiary at 891 Amsterdam Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 8 -- The American Assembly called today for the establishment of a Federal Council of Advisers on Education in the President's office and a joint Congressional committee on education.
A quiet struggle for survival is being waged -- and almost certainly lost -- by wildlife on Staten Island.
Unless the furor over the intelligence-gathering plan shot down in the Soviet Union causes a change in plans, the United States will try to launch its first reconnaissance satellite early this fall.
Officials of the Continental League and organized baseball will have their innings at Washington next week on the controversial Kefauver Sports Bill.

Business continues generally good, according to the latest monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. But the buying executives agree that it is not as good as the "overly optimistic" estimates made at the beginning of the year.
Cotton futures again held a narrow range on the New York Cotton Exchange this week. They closed 50 cents a bale lower to 60 cents a bale higher.

PARIS AS the first hot shafts of summer sun warm the Paris pavements, the shop windows are magically transformed into a gally colored panorama of cotton dresses, straw bags, hats and sandals, giving a momentary impression of an overcrowded Italian summer resort.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 8 -- The $750,000,000 Upper Colorado River storage project, in which four major dams and eleven related irrigation systems are to be built, is progressing peacefully.
SYRACUSE, May 8 -- Navy's undefeated heavyweight varsity crew defeated Cornell and Syracuse in a delayed and shortened Goes Trophy Race on the Seneca River today.
A lawsuit against an independent tanker men's labor organization has added fuel to a bitter controversy between the independent group and an international maritime union.
A plan for easing the traffic congestion in the Garment Center was advanced yesterday by Anthony J. Donargo, chief engineer of the Manhattan Borough President's office.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday that Protestants "might well give increasing recognition" to Mary the mother of Jesus. But he said that "at the same time Roman Catholics would do well to curb the excesses in their devotions."

THE Brooklyn College Chorus and Chamber Orchestra, under the direction of Robert Hickok, presented a concert in the college's Walt Whitman Auditorium on Saturday evening. It marked the opening of its fourth annual Festival of Baroque Choral Music.
JERSEY CITY, May 8 -- This city started its second 300th anniversary celebration today. The first was held thirty years ago.
The United States Lines has announced a revision in its ten-year program for the replacement of forty-six of its fifty-three cargo vessels.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 7 -- More than 100 years ago the Danish economy veered sharply from dependence upon grains as primary exports, and toward dairy products. Since then, Denmark has been one of the worlds leading purveyors of butter, bacon and eggs.
PARIS. Napoleon understood China. "Let China sleep," he advised. "When she awakens the world will be sorry."

Ed Bertram and Pat Gilligan of St. Pascal's Academy gained the doubles semi-finals of the Fordham invitation tennis tournament yesterday. They defeated William Bickel and Tom Harrington of St. Mary's of Manhasset, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.
LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP) -- Jim Colter's three-run homer, the big drive of a sixth-inning rally, led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today before 20,756 fans.

The International Longshoremen's Association will meet with 100 employer groups today in an effort to raise 10,000 Great Lakes dock workers' wage scales to the $2.92 average paid on the East Coast. This means increases of 40 cents to $1.14 an hour.
Is rock 'n' roll a form of American culture and is it here to stay?

PALERMO, Sicily, May 8 -- Beautifully driven by Yoakim Bonnier, a small silver Porsche from West Germany outsped sixty other machines over the rugged Sicilian countryside today in the forty-fourth running of the Targa Florio.

LONDON, May 8 -- Pakistan plans to lodge a strong protest with the United States if it is confirmed that the American plane shot down by the Soviet Union May 1 stopped over in Peshawar before making its last flight.
Earnings of the Anaconda Company for the first quarter declined to $12,950,000, or $1.21 a share, from $16,250,000, or $1.52 a share, in the 1959 period, it was announced over the weekend.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, looking like a frantic high school team, committed seven errors today and the result was a 13-1 victory for the San Francisco Giants.

LOUISVILLE, May 8 -- Unless Venetian Way goes on to win the Preakness and the Belmont, thereby achieving the Triple Crown, yesterday's running of the Kentucky Derby can be dropped into the file-and-forget folder. It was too low in dramatic content, as if it were trying to fit unobtrusively into the setting of a bleak day and did not dare provide excitement.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The 150-member Advisory Committee to the White House Conference on Aging has been called into work sessions here Thursday and Friday of this week. The conference itself will be held next January.

Vice President Nixon's ideas on important issues, domestic and international, will appear June 21 in a volume titled "The Challenges We Face." To be published by McGraw-Hill, the book has been compiled and edited by the concern's editors and members of Mr. Nixon's office.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Tornadoes strike with such sudden fury and are gone so quickly that weather men, scientifically speaking, have never had a good look at one.

GENEVA, May 6 -- The tendency was generally irregular on the Swiss stock markets last week with sharp moves an exception. The absence of any important economic pointers encouraged Swiss operators to take a wait-and-see attitude.

DALLAS, Tex., May 8 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson won a near sweep of Texas Democratic precinct conventions for the Presidential nomination yesterday. The three top state candidates and the six representatives in Congress who had opposition were nominated in the Democratic primary.

"I'm All Right, Jack," the British-made comedy starring Peter Sellers, Ian Carmichael, Terry-Thomas and Margaret Rutherford, now in its premiere local engagement at the Guild Theatre, has been acquired for distribution in the United States by Columbia Pictures.

Reader's New Importance Some years back a subscriber to a magazine was simply a person who liked to read that magazine and took out a subscription because it coat him less over the long haul than the newsstand price or because it was easier to have the magazine brought to his door than it was for him to forget to buy it on the way home.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Anger, dismay and demands for investigation marked Congressional reaction today to the State Department's admission that the United States aircraft shot down by the Soviet Union had been on an intelligence-gathering mission.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The all-purpose credit card has made only a small addition to the volume of consumer credit outstanding.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 8 -- The second portion of a Finn Monotype week-end series at the Larchmont Yacht Club, one of several pre-Olympic trial events, was canceled because of an easterly wind that ranged from twelve to eighteen knots today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Viewed from experience gained over the years in City Hall and at the Capitol in Albany, I believe that people of New York City at this time have an unmatched opportunity to obtain a new Charter geared to the needs of their government.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Influences in the grain futures market last week were generally of a minor nature, with most interest centering on notices of intention to deliver on May contracts in the pits.

G. Schrimer, Inc., music publisher, has leased the ground floor, basement, mezzanine and sixth floor in the K.L.M. Building, 609 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-ninth Street, and will move its retail store and executive offices from the building at 3 East Forty-third Street.

THE fair of face have a definite advantage in this world. Even foods often are selected for their appearance, or for the appearance of the package in which they are offered. Small wonder, therefore, that the squid is so little appreciated -- at least by Americans.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- The Soviet Government gave indications today that the capture of an American reconnaissance flier deep inside Soviet territory last Sunday would become the focus of a major campaign to embarrass the West on the eve of the summit conference.

Stockholders in Loew's Theatres, Inc., at a special meeting on May 26 will vote on increasing the minimum number of directors from the present six to nine and the maximum from the present ten to fifteen. Should shareholders approve the amendment, a state of five additional directors will be submitted at the same meeting for shareholder approval.

AN interesting and informative survey of Polish-American musical activity in the early part of the nineteenth century was presented in Hunter College Playhouse yesterday afternoon by the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America.
GENEVA, May 8 -- The East-West nuclear negotiations will resume here tomorrow confronted with an unexpected controversy that may delay the signing of a treaty banning explosions of nuclear weapons.
LONDON, May 8 -- The stock market was depressed last week by disquiet over the effects of the Government's credit squeeze and the possibility that further restrictions might be imposed.

Stockholders in Loew's Theatres, Inc., at a special meeting on May 26 will vote on increasing the minimum number of directors from the present six to nine and the maximum from the present ten to fifteen. Should shareholders approve the amendment, a state of five additional directors will be submitted at the same meeting for shareholder approval.
If the Americans want Africa to adopt democracy, they must act now, an authority on Africa said yesterday.
CHARLESTON, May 8 -- Senator Humphrey's headquarters charged Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. tonight with having degraded his father's name by serving as a "hatchet man" for Senator Kennedy.
LOUISVILLE, May 8 -- Most of the talk at the Churchill Downs barns today was in question form. "Who's going to beat Venetian Way in the Preakness?" was the gist of it.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Pioneer V, the United States' artificial planetoid, began using its loud voice -- a 150-watt transmitter -- today to send information back to earth.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- An election-year test of strength between President Eisenhower and the Democratic Congress may come this week.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 -- Steel demand last week showed no significant change in its slow downward trend. Opertaions were declining a little faster as consumption and steel ordering came closer into balance. It may be another month or so before most steel mills find their new orders geared properly to actual consumption of steel.

Chicago's champion White Sox, as bouncy as ever in their first New York appearance o 1960, replaced the Yankees at the top of the American League standing at drizzle-drenched Yankee Stadium yesterday.
The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale charged yesterday that modern Protestantism had become "so broad that it is shallow."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 -- There has been so much emphasis on why people can't read that the study of normal reading has been largely neglected, a psychoanalyst told the American Psychoanalytic Association's annual meeting here today.
A special master appointed by the United States Supreme Court has proposed that it give Arizona clear title to Colorado River waters that she has claimed in a long and bitter feud with California.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A curb on successive rate increases on natural gas rates, while decisions on cases are pending, was proposed today by Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan.
LAS VEGAS, May 8 (AP) -- Jerry Barber of Los Angeles today shot a 5-under-par 67 for a 72-hole score of 268 and won the $10,000 top prize in the $42,400 Tournament of Champions.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The shooting down of an "information-gathering" U-2 plane over the Soviet Union has called attention to the history of this country's intelligence activities.
Attorney General Louis, J. Lefkowitz went on record yesterday in favor of a referendum on the question of legalizing off-track betting in New York City.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- What are the weary politicians doing for relaxation these days?
Spectators at Yankee Stadium yesterday were fascinated by, and generally in favor of, Bill Veeck's novel idea of labeling the White Sox players for easier identification.
Prompt revival of the city's slum clearance and housing program was urged yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- A woman has entrenched herself in the executive echelons of the movie industry, where it is traditional to grovel before women at the box office but to discourage them from policy-making offices.
The first snag in the way of President Eisenhower's top-level conference to promote industrial peace was cleared yesterday.
LONDON, May 9 -- A dribble of small selling brought back prices on the stock market here today. Losses generally were limited to a few pence.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Tustice Department has decided against trying to block a proseries of television deals the National Broadcasting Company.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- A warning against the "graduates" of three-day courses on hypnosis that are widespread across the country was issued here today by a leading psychiatrist.
After repeatedly conducting experiments -- on command -- millions of miles in space, Pioneer V appears to have shot its bolt, scientifically.
A utility workers' union picketed the offices of the National Labor Relations Board here yesterday, demanding a decision on union representation for 750 Consolidated Edison powerhouse employes.

The Administration's program of health insurance for those over 65 has laid the main issues right on the line. They are: first, the use of the Federal Social Security mechanism vs. state administration with Federal subsidies and, second, "compulsion" vs. freedom of choice.

Joseph Papp, the man who brought free Shakespeare to Central Park, castigated Broadway yesterday as a "talent-destroyer" that treated its actors in a "barbaric" fashion. He also pleaded for the public to support "continuity" in the American theatre.

California has designated May 25 as the date for the sale of $50,000,000 of serial bonds. The offering will be the fourth market borrowing this year by California, and the second since the decision was made to discontinue the practice of selling some, $100,000,000 of bonds four times a year and, instead, to borrow smaller amounts more frequently.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 9 -- A month ago, at the annual American Bowling Congress convention, a major step was taken to change the format of the A.B.C. tournament, annually the largest bowling tourney in the nation.

J.D. Ellis, 133 1/2 pounds, of Trenton, scored a technical knockout over Samuel (Chico) Rollins, 132 1/2, of New York, in the ninth round of the scheduled ten-round fight last night at St. Nicholas Arena. A deep gash on Rollins' left eyebrow prompted Joe Pushkal, the referee, to halt the bout.

No one has succeeded in describing adequately what nature has done at Niagara Falls and words are likewise unequal to convey the magnitude of what man is doing there now in construction of the $720,000,000 hydroelectric power project and related improvements to enhance visitor enjoyment of a trip to the falls. Old battles give way to new.
Three face(t)s of Ernst Krenek were on view at last night's Composers' Showcase at the Circle in the Square.
Two plays dealing with the Nazi annihilation of the Warsaw ghetto in World War II are scheduled for next season.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Hearings on ocean freight practices have turned up more than sixty possible violations of law, the head of a House investigating committee said today.
WHITE PLAINS, May 9 -- Westchester's Board of Elections ruled today that the petitions for two Liberal party candidates on the June 7 primary ballot had been improper.

FRANCESCO SOMAINI, the 34-year-old Italian sculptor who last fall won the Best Foreign Sculptor prize at the V Bienal of Sao Paulo, Brazil, is having his first American -- North American, that is -- exhibition at the Italian Cultural Institute, 686 Park Avenue, between Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth.

RYE, N.Y., May 9 -- Members of the Bryn Mawr Alumnae Club of Westchester hope to fill the 950 seats in the Rye High School Auditorium on Saturday, May 21, at 8:15 P.M. The club will present two jazz groups from Yale University in a Jazz Jamboree.

LONDON, May 9 -- Premier Khrushchev has informed the British Government that he still hopes for a successful meeting at the summit. A. personal message from the Soviet leader to Prime Minister Macmillan arrived today, qualified sources disclosed. Mr. Macmillan is expected to answer it tomorrow.

Edward C. Werle, a partner in the firm of Scheffmeyer, Werle Co., won reelection yesterday to a third one-year term as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. The chairman of the exchange is the stock brokers' broker and it is his job to administer the organization's trading rules.
LOUISVILLE, May 9 (UPI) -- At least one of Venetian Way's Kentucky competitors, Tompion, will not make an issue of it in the Preakness May 21.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities published testimony today that Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the committee, said "confirms and reiterates the overwhelming evidence of widespread Communist espionage on American soil, conducted under the guise of legitimate diplomatic activity."

TRENTON, May 9 -- The State Supreme Court dismissed today a suit by Bergen County designed to prevent the Port of New York Authority from leasing tax-exempt land at Teterboro Airport to a private concern.
First-quarter sales and earnings

NEWARK, May 9 -- A $6,000,000 injunction suit brought by The Newark Morning Ledger Company against six newspaper unions and sixteen of their officers and members was dismissed today by Federal Judge Mendon Morrill "with prejudice but without cost."
OMAHA, May 9 -- It will be Senator John F. Kennedy of Masachusetts against a blank line in Nebraska's primary election tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter indicated today that the United States would continue intelligence-gathering flights unless there was a marked change in Moscow's attitude toward measures guaranteeing the world against Communist aggression.
The deans of the state's ten law schools have agreed to form a committee to aid the state's Judicial Conference, Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond of the Court of Appeals announced.
CHARLESTON, W.Va., May 9 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today wound up his campaign in this state's Democratic Presidential preference primary with a plea for voters to judge him on his record.

BURBANK, Calif., May 9 -- The designer of the U-2 single-engine jet plane expressed doubt today that the Soviet Union had shot down one of the craft. He charged that photographs the Soviet Union had said were of the plane were faked.

TRENTON, May 9 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today ruled that automobile manufacturers and dealers were liable for defective cars, despite their standard warranty, which seeks to absolve them of responsibility.
Representatives of WNEW and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists will meet with a state mediator at 10 A.M. today in an effort to settle the strike against the radio station.
A jet airliner's landing gear buckled after the plane had touched down at New York International Airport yesterday, and flames burst from two of the four engines as they scraped the concrete runway.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Camilo Pascual snapped a three-game losing streak for the Senators by pitching a three-hitter and stopping the Kansas City Athletics, 8 -- 1, tonight.
Organized labor predicted yesterday that any Presidential or Congressional candidate who upheld a Presidential veto of the Forand bill would be defeated in the November elections.

"IT'S been a peculiar season, said Alfonso Ramon Lopez, the Happy Hidalgo who manages the White Sox. "It's been rough on the starting pitchers and it's given us an unusual number of long winning streaks and long losing streaks."

Women are more pessimistic than men about the business outlook. Consumers with incomes of more than $10,000 are less hopeful than those with lower incomes. And persons in the Midwest have more optimistic buying plans than those in other areas of the country.
The United Arab Republic ship Cleopatra became a "working ship" yesterday for the first time since April 13.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 9 -- Billy Farrell, a Baltusrol pro, earned the biggest share of a $3,000 pot today in a proamateur golf tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Two Civil Aeronautics Board attorneys have recommended that Pan American World Airways be allowed to fly passengers and cargo between New York and the Orient with stopovers in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Eisenhower nominated Robert A. Bicks today as the Government's chief trust-buster.

The first Naomi Lehman Memorial Awards for outstanding service to Jewish children were conferred last night on the late Mrs. Adele Rosenwald Levy, a philanthropist and social service leader, and Mrs. Martha K. Selig, a professional social worker.

A collection of exotic musical instruments made of bamboo, gourds, silk, gut, vine, animal's horns and tusks, tortoise shell, skin and even a human thigh bone went on display at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday.

MANY persons who have never heard a shot fired in anger or even mild displeasure write about war with authority. We all tend to hold quite positive views on history and art and politics. Some are experts. Most are not. That doesn't dam the flow of opinion, does it? Nor will any such limitations stop us from enjoying any new book that presents its subject in a lively and informing way.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Administration moved today to use its new powers under the Civil Rights Act of 1960.

The city's Art Commission gave unanimous preliminary approval yesterday of the design for the Huntington Hartford Pavilion to be built in Central Park. It is planned as a side-walk cafe at Fifty-ninth Street near Fifth Avenue.
The New York State Athletic Commission put its final seal of approval yesterday on the return heavyweight championship fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 10 -- The National Assembly voted unanimously today to accept President Eisenhower's request to address the legislators on his visit June 22. The session to hear the President may cause a postponement in the new elections originally planned for about the middle of July.
An unrepresentative "labor organization" that had gained a foothold in the growing bowling alley industry has been put out of business by a decision of the State Labor Relations Board.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Voice of America is citing the U-2 story in its news broadcasts to the world.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Employers at Chicago and other Great Lakes ports rejected today a union proposal that dock contracts be extended for fifteen days to permit discussion of a Lakes-wide master contract.
GENEVA, May 9 -- The Soviet Union politely objected today to the White House announcement that the United States would conduct nuclear tests for research this year.
Many persons gave cocktail parties before the May Festival Ball, which was held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night as a benefit for Just One Break, Inc. (J.O.B.)
The president of City College took an hour from his presidential routine yesterday to lecture students on his philosophy of life.

LIBERTY, N.Y., May 9 -- Two leaders of Conservative Judaism declared here tonight that the rabbinate was in a key position to guide the American Jewish community in resolving vexing Jewisn religious, cultural and communal problems.

With every passing month the crisis in American education becomes more acute. This is true at every level: primary and secondary, which we hear most (and do least) about, and at the higher levels too, where colleges and universities are more hard-pressed between rising demands, rising needs and rising costs than ever before in American history.

The New Jersey Supreme Court cleared the way yesterday for extensive investigation by the Waterfront Commission of criminals and the International Longshoremen's Association on the New Jersey waterfront.

GENEVA, May 9 -- Marcus Daly, a New Jersey business man with a flashing smile and a flashing temper, found himself a couple of years ago the boss of one of the most intricate and delicately functioning international organizations in the world -- the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration.

A family of naturalized Americans whose $50,000,000 industrial empire in Czechoslovakia was confiscated in 1942 by the Nazis lost a move yesterday to recover more than $350,000 in United States income taxes.
LIVINGSTON MANOR, N. Y., May 9 -- It has been raining almost all day long here on the upper Beaverkill and fishing has been slow, which brings something, bitterly to mind.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 9 -- Present holders of junior operator licenses will not be affected by a new prohibition on their use in Nassau County after Oct. 1, State Senator Edward J. Speno of East Meadow said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a former staff member of President Truman's Commission on Migratory Labor, allow me to say what a first-rate performance Abe Raskin did in his article on America's migrants, "For 500,000 -- Still 'Tobacco Road" in your issue of April 24.

PANAMA, May 9 -- An official blackout was imposed on Presidential election returns here today as the Opposition candidate, Dr. Roberto F. Chiari, appeared to be emerging somewhat ahead of the Administration party candidate, Ricardo Manuel Arias Espinosa.

LINDEN, N.J., May 9 -- The development of a new process for making polypropylene, a versatile plastic material, was announced here today by the Esso Research and Engineering Company, research affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
The Medical Society of the State of New York urged Congress yesterday to take no legislative action on financing health care for the aged until the problem had been studied completely.
YESTERDAY May 9, 1960 THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council on espionage plane incident.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- The Republican National Chairman and West Virginia's Governor tonight accused the two Democratic rivals in tomorrow's Presidential primary of exaggerating the state's plight in their efforts to win votes.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Until and unless the pilot of the United States U-2 plane can give specific and credible answers to certain fundamental questions which were raised by his spying mission over Soviet Russia and its debacles, a final over-all judgment will not be reached by fair and sensible people, including critics at home and abroad who merit the description.

Steel production was expected to continue to decline this week despite reports by some industry executives that business was firming, figures released by the American Iron and Steel Institute indicated yesterday.
"Ground rules" will help to govern the Olympic track and field trials at Palo Alto, Calif., on July 1 and 2. However, the rules will not be established until shortly before the trials.

Tickets still are available for the May 19 performance of "Greenwillow," musical at the Alvin Theatre. The alumnae of the Ethel Walker School have arranged a theatre party that evening to benefit the scholarship program of the school in Simabury, Conn., through the alumnae educational fund.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP) -- More new cars were registered in the United States in March than in any month since December, 1955, official figures showed today.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., converted its first quarter loss of a year ago into a profit this year and expects to show "a modest profit" for the first half as well, John E. McCarthy, president, told about 100 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The two major sections of the mutual thrift industry -- savings banks and savings and loan associations -- are at odds on the future course of the Industry's expansion. The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, which began its fortieth annual convention at the Shoreham Hotel here today, is hopeful of getting Congressional authorization for a capital loan fund of its own.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today participation by the United States in the International Development Association.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming rejected the idea today that the Government ban cigarettes under its program of protecting consumers from anything that might cause cancer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times of April 30 reported on a speech, by Professor James Marston Fitch before the Academy of Political Science which revealed such a misunderstanding of the facts concerning the Port Authority's construction of the second deck of the George Washington Bridge that it needs prompt correction lest it mislead your readers.
Governor Rockefeller has been invited informally to serve as either keynoter or permanent chairman of this year's Republican National Convention in Chicago.
Jack Dempsey has revealed for the first time that he was afraid to fight the late Sam Langford.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Treasury bill rate, continuing its recent erratic course, moved upward this week, the Treasury reported tonight.
There is a widening horizon for advertising in which new devices are being called upon in great variety to capture the attention of the public.

As expected, the Soviet Union and Cuba are going to restore the diplomatic relations broken in 1952. No one can question Cuba's right to do so. Mexico, Uruguay and Argentina have long had relations with Russia. As was recognized at the American Assembly's Caribbean meeting in March, "it would be fruitless to seek to prevent official or private relationships between Latin-American and Communist nations, and the United States public must recognize this fact."

An account of the formative period of the American Communist pary, 1923-29, is given by Theodore Draper in "American Communism and Soviet Russia." To be published next Monday by Viking, the book is based on private documents, interviews with party leaders and a study of published material.

NAPLES, which contributed the pizza to American cookery, is also the originator of cafe espresso. That strong, black brew, although it has not yet taken over the country to the extent that pizza has, is rapidly gaining popularity.
LOS ANGELES, May 9 (AP) -- Charley Neal's three-run homer in the ninth inning bought the Los Angeles Dodgers a 7 -- 4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates before 23,417 fans tonight.

The seven-story apartment house at 2245 Barker Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the Barker Avenue Corporation to the Barker Company for cash over a mortgage of $410,000. Henry Lobell of Norman Associates and Leonard, Levites, Schiller were the brokers in the deal.
TRENTON, May 9 -- The State Supreme Court upheld the validity today of a Paramus ordinance banning the sale of certain items on Sunday.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- Premier Khrushchev's vague but unmistakable promise of vastly increased production of consumer goods has impressed both Soviet and foreign observers as the most important new domestic political development here.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 9 -- A week-end raid by Congolese troops against a suburban tribal village has provoked brawls between soldiers and Leopoldville policeman sympathetic to the tribesmen.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your account of John Reed Kilpatrick on May 8 gives a fine picture of this outstanding citizen. I would like to add a footnote showing how, as head of Madison Square Garden, he carried out his important responsibility of deciding who could "hire a hall."

GROSSINGER, N.Y., May 9 -- For sixty minutes -- with little pause for a breathing spell -- Ingemar Johansson threw righthanded punches today against sparring partners and heavy and light bags with a resounding effect.

A HIGH school student from Bridgeport, Conn., who would rather sew than dance, yesterday was presented with the 1960 Young Homemaker of the Year Award at Gracie Mansion. Seventeen-year-old Frances "Cookie" Stone, tall, pretty and a bit shy, received the scroll from Mrs. Robert F. Wagner.
Harry S. Truman gave his version yesterday of the cause of the increasing coolness between himself and General Eisehhower, who succeeded him is President.
IN the program of Arthur Schnitzler's "La Ronde," which opened at the Theatre Marquee last evening, one remark is particularly pertinent: "Only the shock is worn off."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 9 -- With its 100,000 members, the American Contract Bridge league is the largest of its kind in the world, but in proportion to population it is far behind Sweden and the Netherlands.
LOS ANGELES, May 9 -- A combination of Saturn vehicles appears to be the United States' best chance to put two astronauts on the moon between 1970 and 1975.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The diplomatic, repercussions of the spy-plane case began arriving at the State Department today and they were all bad.
The date for the retirement of Robert Moses as city Park Commissioner was set officially yesterday for May 23. He will give up the post after twenty years, three months and twenty-three days.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 9 -- Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and John F Kennedy of Massachusetts campaigned to the final hour tonight for the support of Democrats in tomorrow's West Virginia Presidential preferential primary.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Short-covering and reinstatement of long positions raised the May wheat future 5/8 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade after a succession of fairly steep declines last week. Oats and rye posted small advances while corn and soybeans were weak.

Pennsylvania Electric Company sold $12,000,000 of thirtyyear first mortgage bonds yesterday to an investment banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at a net interest cost to the company of about 4.93 per cent.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 7 points (35 cents a bale) up yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Observers here were studying the contrast between what Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today about the President's directives and what President Eisenhower himself said about espionage flights at a news conference Feb. 10,1959.

A LISTENER at last night's debut recital by Eileen di Tullio, coloratura soprano, wondered how long, if ever, since Town Hall had resounded to the strident whistles usually associated with basketball games.
Four city Democratic candidates for the Legislature received belated Liberal endorsements yesterday after promising to reconsider their support of a relief residency law.

A varied and diverting program of American vocal music was presented in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the Composers Laboratory. Of twenty-nine items included in the program, ten were by Charles Ives and two were by John Cage.
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., May 9 -- Senator John F. Kennedy handpumped his way along the Ohio River today on the last mile of a campaign from which he does not expect more than a minority victory.

LONDON, May 9 -- Reginald Maudling, President of the Board of Trade, declared today that Britain would give "a positive and forthcoming response" to any move by the European Economic Community for negotiations with the seven-nation European Free Trade Association.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. expects a 5 per cent increase, or better, in sales this year over the record figure of $4,036,153,139 rung up in the last fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1960, Fowler B. McConnell, retiring chairman, told stockholders today.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa warned yesterday that he would oppose any new drive for a $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction unless the Board of Education "can prove that it actually needs this money."
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Following is the text of the statement issued today by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter on the shooting down of a United States plane in the Soviet Union:

International news developments gave the stock market an uncertain tone yesterday. After opening down, prices climbed until noon and then receded quietly. Gains had generally been reduced by the close.
Following is the text of remarks by Premier Khrushchev at a reception in the Czechoslovak Embassy in Moscow yesterday, as provided in English in New York by Tass, the official press agency:
ABERDEEN, Wash. (AP) -- Harbor Playwood Corporation has agreed to sell all operating properties and inventories to Aberdeen Plywood Veneers, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA READING The Philadelphia Reading Corporation again is seeking a merger with a chemical company, Howard A. Newman, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- Premier Khrushchev warned today that Soviet rockets would be used to retaliate against bases in countries that permitted United States planes to take off on intelligence missions over the Soviet Union.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, said today that a healthy and thriving coal industry was of vital importance to the nation, but the Government should not restrict free economic choice by consumers of the fuel they want.

NAPLES, Italy, May 9 -- A 10-year-old Latvian boy who was born in a refugee camp left today for Munich en route to the United States. He is the millionth person resettled by the Intergovernmental Committee of European Migration.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Many communities are reluctant to begin new public housing projects because of requirements that they be racially integrated, the acting United States Commissioner of Public Housing said today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- How did the United States come to issue a false statement about the loss of a U-2 observation plane over the Soviet Union?
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Representative Peter F. Mack Jr., Democrat of Illinois, urged Congress today to ban the payment of additional Federal subsidies to domestic trunk airlines.

Sales of Beatrice Foods Company set a record in the twelve months ended on Feb. 29. William G. Karnes, president, reported to stockholders yesterday, in the sixty-second annual report. "Earnings rose for the eighth year in a row.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon said today that President Eisenhower's decision to build up the Vice-Presidency had given him "a head start" in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- Sky's Attraction gained his rth victory in a five-start r at Pimlico today. He the Coldspring Purse, returning $7.80 for $2.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's choice as Democratic nominee to the Interstate Commerce Commission said today he probably would vote for Vice President Nixon in a Presidential election.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 9 -- A source close to the Soviet delegation said today that the Kremlin was debating whether to ask the Security Council to take action on the United States plane incident.

The bond market continued strong yesterday. Dealers in both Government and corporate obligations continued to bid with confidence in the secondary market to replenish inventories threatened with depletion by a visibly livelier demand on the part of investing institutions.

PALERMO, Sicily, May 9 -- Since 1926, the Grand Prix of Germany has been one of the feature motor races on the European calendar. In recent years it has counted in the drivers' world championship competition. Sometimes victory in it has been enough to win the championship.
Three years ago, Modie J. Spiegel, the owner of a Chicago mail order house, purchased a yearling for $8,000. Picking a name was easy. He called the horse Mail Order.

A Change in the Journalist Two new textbooks for journalism students that have crossed this desk are noteworthy for the emphasis they place on the growing stature of newspaper men as citizens contributing to understanding.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and Alien W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, sought today to quiet the U-2 incident with a ninety-minute secret briefing for leaders of both parties.

THE constant construction going on all over town, which keeps the streets even more choked with traffic than usual, is reflected in the seemingly endless amount of hammering and pounding in department stores.

TRENTON, May 9 -- The State Assembly voted today to double the state tax on inheritances to provide funds for a 15 per cent salary increase for teachers in eight New Jersey institutions of higher education.

Proceedings are expected to begin in Housing Court today to put Irving Zelkowitz, former landlord of 380 Riverside Drive, back in jail to serve the twenty-five days remaining on a thirtyday sentence for violations of the multiple dwelling laws.

ROME, May 9 (AP) -- Luis Ayala of Chile advanced to the final of the Rome international tennis tournament today and Giuseppo Merio of Italy upset Neale Fraser, Australia's No. 1 player, in a quarter-final match.
Columbia University has agreed with the University of Buenos Aires to establish a new academic relationship between them.
LONDON, May 9 -- The Commonwealth Prime Minister's conference agreed today to admit the Federation of Nigeria to the Commonwealth after the territory becomes independent Oct. 1.

The six British members of the New York Americans, who arrived here Saturday, joined the team's ten American soccer players yesterday in a light workout at Randalls Island. Coach Al Stubbing plans another practice tonight.

Four new playwrights and the revival of Sophie Treadwell's "Machinal" received the Vernon Rice Memorial Awards yesterday. The awards are given annually for "outstanding achievement" in the off-Broadway theatre.
The High School Teachers Association has rejected a bid by the United Federation of Teachers to support a city-wide walkout called for next Tuesday.
ATLANTA, May 9 -- A Federal judge delayed desegregation here today until 1961 to give the next Legiature "just one chance" to save Georgia's public education system.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 9 -- Glenville, a 4-year-old bay son of Knight Dream, scored a length victory over Luca's Luck tonight in the Bellerose Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
Thousands of Westchester commuters were delayed up to fifty minutes yesterday morning on the New York Central Railroad's Hudson and Harlem Divisions.

THE current attraction on "The Play of the Week" is a brooding study of two Bronx couples suffering the combined trials of the depression of the Nineteen Thirties, deep personal tragedies and unhappy marriages.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 9 -- Federal Judge J. Joseph Smith reserved decision today on a request for a temporary in-junction that would force the Standard News Company, Inc., of Mount Verrnon, N.Y., to resume deliveries of New York newspapers to newsstands in lower Fairfield County.
A TELEVISION announcer who forbids his five children to watch weekday television is the breadwinner of New York State's entry in the second annual "All-American Family Search."

LIBERTY, N.Y., May 10 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America took the initiative today toward the establishment of an over-all Jewish organization that "would make policy and speak for the American Jewish community" on problems here and overseas.
Mayor Wagner received official recognition last night as the city's No. 1 sports fan.

Mayor Wagner said some things that needed saying yesterday, reaffirming with enthusiasm his utter confidence in the future of New York City. We are a people with a talent for self-criticism, often too ready, perhaps, to take a dark view. Occasionally we need to be shaken with a confident expression of optimism.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, May 10 -- The big question arising from the Olympiad world tournament is "What happened to the Italians?"
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas condemned today as a "price-fixing scheme" a bill before Congress to increase Federal taxation of mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman told a West Side audience last night that New York was being "short-weighed and short-changed" in its Democratic representation in Albany and Washington.

HIS friends bade farewell to Maj. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick yesterday. They filled St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church to overflowing in tribute to a man who had been outstandig in everything he did as athlete, soldier, executive, humanitarian and public figure.

The estimated cost of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has climbed well above $100,000,000. However, only $59,177,219 has been pledged so far toward a $75,000,000 fundraising goal, which was initially expected to cover virtually all costs.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The world's largest submarine, the nuclear-powered U.S.S. Triton, surfaced off the Delaware coast just before dawn today after a submerged voyage around the world.
Dr. Charles Muzzicato, a former State Senator, was named yesterday as the Republican candidate for Congress in the Eighteenth District, which covers East Harlem and parts of Yorkville.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 (AP) -- The Giants, helped by three Philadelphia errors, whipped the Phillies, 4 -- 2, tonight. The San Franciscans thereby maintained their one-and-a-half-game lead in the National League.

The newest machine in international automobile racing, the Formula Junior, will be seen in the revived Vanderbilt Cup race at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., on June 18 and 19. The car, created in Europe as a means of developing Grand Prix drivers, has had a sensational rise in interest since its advent little more than a year ago.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court denounced today proposals for the photographing and broadcasting of trials.
Mayor Wagner served notice yesterday on opponents of the proposed new zoning law that the statute was long overdue and should be enacted.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics crushed the Batimore Orioles, 10 -- 0, tonight. Dick Hall gained his third straight victory with a six-hitter. The 6-foot 6-inch right-hander struck out six and walked none.
Forty first-class passengers who arrived on the Queen Elizabeth yesterday were off the pier, with their baggage, thirty minutes after the ship docked at Pier 90.
The foreign exchange privileges of eight Turkish students here have been rescinded by the Turkish educational attache, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- The scheduled airlines set records last year in every category except profits, a survey revealed today.
The West German economic! boom is continuing virtually unabated, Berthold Beitz, second in command of the Krupp industrial empire, said on his arrival here yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 10 -- The Russians are anxiously following all pronouncements on the downing of a United States reconnaissance plane and are lining up to buy newspapers each morning and evening.
Hofstra, defeated Fordham, 7 -- 2, at Jack Coffey Field yesterday and virtually clinched the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball title.

A Mexican motion picture about the Monterrey baseball team that won the Little League world series in Williamsport, Pa., in 1957 will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on June 14 from 8:30 to 10 P.M.
LAST night's performance of the B Minor Mass at Carnegie Hall reflected little credit either upon Bach or the Dessoff Choirs, who performed the work under Paul Boepple's direction.
Plans are being formulated for the first Stratford International Film Festival, to be presented during the week starting July 13 at the Stratford (Conn.) Theatre.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Old crop soybean futures were under stiff selling pressure again today and ran their losses for two days to about 2 1/2 cents a bushel. They closed at or near their lows for the season.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -- Some parents contribute to, and foster, delinquency in their offspring, researchers told the American Psychiatric Association here today.

The landing gear of a jet airliner that skidded in on its engine pods, in flames here Monday did not collapse, the airline conceded yesterday. Instead the gear was being retracted by the pilot, who planned to circle the airport for another landing try.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The United States has photographed Soviet jet planes on aerial reconnaissance over Western military bases all over the world, Pentagon authorities said today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A party advisory committee proposed today that the Democrats campaign for farm votes this year on a promise to restore price supports at 90 per cent of parity and establish rigid crop production controls.
Brush Fire, a 3-year-old colt owned by the Charter Oak Stable, won the $7,500 Singing Wood at Aqueduct yesterday. His time for the six furlongs was 1:09 3/5. The track record is 1:09 2/5.

The lack of adequate knowledge, understanding and contacts between the United States and the nations of Latin America is common knowledge. We do not print enough news about Latin America in our press; we do not teach enough about the area in our schools; we do not have a large enough exchange of persons, and the lack of interest shown by many of our Congressmen in Latin America is shocking.

A new salary schedule for teachers was proposed yesterday by Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools. It is intended to put the city school system in a better position to attract and retain staff members.
Moscow continued to make political and psychological capital out of the U-2 plane incident yesterday, but it paid a price.
The Ford Motor Company will introduce its 1961 autos and trucks during the week of Sept. 12 in a southern Illinois city of 5,255 persons.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The tragedy of President Eisenhower in the spy-plane case is that he and his colleagues have created almost all the things he feared the most.

The New York County grand jury that investigated the use of ghost writers by college students urged yesterday that the state's educational authorities and colleges and universitie "adopt positive, direct and aggressive measures to combat dishonesty in our educational institutions."
This decade will see great strides toward successful transplants of tissue from one person to another, a specialist predicted here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Too much of the money allotted for traffic research is being spent "unwisely," a police traffic expert told the eighth Highway Transportation Congress today.
LONDON, May 10 -- The United States, Britain and France still intend to ask the Soviet Union to support a joint declaration of principles and interests at the summit conference.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Two of the nation's largest railroads -- the Pennsylvania and the New York Central -- asked Congress today for help in saving rail passenger service.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- One of the important scientific objectives of the round-the-world trip of the U.S.S. Triton was to determine what hapenes to men when they were submerged for eighty-four days.

MOSCOW, May 10 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a Soviet note today to the United States on the downing of an American plane, as translated by the United, States Embassy, and of a note from the Embassy to the Soviet Union:

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The chairman of the Federal Power Commission defended himself today against charges of having been swayed by influence-peddlers and of having neglected consumer interests in favor of natural gas companies.
PARIS, May 10 -- France began today to revise her Constitution to take account of the evolution toward independence in Africa.
LONDON, May 10 -- South Africa's continued membership in the Commonwealth was put in doubt today.

Jacksonville, Fla., received bids yesterday on $30,000,000 of electric revenue bonds due serially from 1962 to 1980 and callable in 1970. The best bid, an interest cost of 3.4815 per cent, was submitted by a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation, Shields Co., Lehman Brothers and C.J. Devine Co.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, May 11 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts won a smashing upset victory in yesterday's West Virginia's Presidential preferential primary.

When the Grand Kabuki Company, Japan's several-centuries-old classical theatre, opens a limited run at the City Center on June 2, individual receivers carrying a running commentary in English will be made available for the audiences.

Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., investment bankers and brokers, have leased a floor containing 38,000 square feet of space in the new forty-story building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street.
BAYTOWN, Tex., May 10 -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) moved into the plastic business today with the formal dedication of a new polypropylene plant here.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The United States pledged today to help defend its allies if they were attacked by Soviet missiles.
Investors listened to Russian threats yesterday and reacted nervously. Save for the aircrafts, which put up a brave front, the major groups on the New York Stock Exchange moved downward.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest, expects 1960 to be only "a fair year," shareholders were told here today at their annual meeting in the Sheraton Hotel.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 10 -- Two men were accused today of having charged $10,000 for the delivery of $5,000 worth of road construction materials to the village of Babylon in 1956.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The chairman of the House Antitrust subcommittee filed a strong protest today against the Justice Department's decision not to oppose new television station acquisitions by the National Broadcasting Company.

First-quarter net income of Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company and subsidiaries fell to $9,440,000, or 48 cents a common share, from $11,145,218 and 57 cents in the 1959 period. Last year's figures were adjusted to include results of the Suntide Refining Company, which was merged into the company in the fourth quarter of 1959.
JUNE, a month of scudding white clouds and billowing bridal veils, is not far off. Soon a number of brand-new homemakers will be striving to prove that they really can bake a cherry pie.
The influx of leading soccer players to these shores continued yesterday with the arrival of the Manchester United team from England.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission refused today to recommend any change in the duty-free status of imported typewriters.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 10 -- Burwell Hanover, a pacer that is not a particularly fast starter, has drawn the No. 1 post position in the $142,786.15 Messenger Stake, harness racing's richest single-heat event, Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) up to 5 points (25 cents) off yesterday.
A huge apartment house development costing more than $100,000,000 is to be constructed on a forty-acre plot in Elmhurst, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Following are excerpts from the log kept by Capt. Edwin L. Beach during the submerged trip around the world by the U.S.S. Triton. The times shown art local times and are given in naval style, with 1300 being 1 P.M., for example.

THE PRESIDENT Met with Republican legislative leaders; announced details of visit to Japan and Korea June 19-23; conferred Legion of Merit on Capt. Edward L. Beach, commanding officer of the nuclear-powered submarine Triton, which traveled around the world in eighty-four-day underwater voyage; met with Secretary of State Herter and Vice President Nixon.
A little, gray blockhouse in which scientists hope to produce natural gas economically from coal had its public debut yesterday at Columbia University.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 10 -- Lunch counters were desegregated today in six department and variety stores in downtown Nashville.

ALBANY, May 10 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 424 applicants had passed of 933 who took the written bar examinations on March 9 and 10. The board is composed of John T. DeGraff of Albany, John A. e of New York City and Stanley G. Falk of Buffalo.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10 (UPI) -- Gov. John Patterson, of Alabama called Attorney General William P. Rogers an "outright liar" today. The Governor promised to fight any inspection aimed at investigating alleged violations of Negro voting rights in Wilcox County.

A tour of ten houses in the Long Island South Shore communities of Hewlett, Woodmere, Cedarhurst and Lawrence, including the historic Rock Hall Museum, will be held on Saturday. The proposed South Shore General Hospital will benefit.
It is getting so that every time New Yorkers see a new fountain in town they throw coins into it for good luck.

AS soon as any period in art history is scanned closely and without preconceptions, convenient categories tend to break down. The eighteenth century, for instance is still widely regarded as The Age of the Rococo exclusively.
The Pan Pacific and Southeast Asia Women's Association (PASEAWA) will present a pageant, Modes and Mores of the Orient, in the Grand Ballroom of the Roosevelt tonight.
IN a time of crumbling empires, there is at least one that holds the line. This is the maternity collection at Lane Bryant.
The city's tenement children will be able to romp legally under 1,000 cooling street showers in the hot summer months.

De Witt Clinton's Gary Gubner, with a record throw in the shot-put, and Boys High's first team victory of the year provided the highlights yesterday in the nineteenth annual Brooklyn Automotive track and field games at McCarren Park, Brooklyn.
The City Council took a first step yesterday toward seeking to restore to the city the power to require milk dealers to stamp the pasteurization date on all milk containers.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -- Promising results were reported today in the treatment of mice with vegetable oil injections after the animals had been exposed to radiation.
THE Right Rev. Horace William Baden Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, is a calm and patient shepherd of his flock. But occasionally the calmness cracks.

Measures were taken yesterday by the League of New York Theatres, the organization of Broadway producers and theatre operators, to prepare itself against a threatened strike by Actors Equity on May 31, when the agreement between both groups will expire.
ROME, May 10 (AP) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, defeated Giuseppe Merlo of Italy, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, today in a semi-final of the Rome tennis championships.

The top officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority have a busy day ahead on Thursday, courtesy of Lehman Brothers, their financial advisers. After a 10:45 A.M. press conference, Brig. Gen. H.D. Vogel (Ret., U.S.A.), chairman of T.V.A., and his associates will proceed to a Municipal Forum luncheon at noon in the Downtown Athletic Club.

Milwaukee System Stockholders of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad were told yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, chairman, that studies concerning the road's possible merger with the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad were "progressing rapidly and we expect they will show savings and benefits beyond those originally contemplated."
WELL, by gosh and by jeez, that sure is a mighty slick production of "Tobacco Road" they brung down to the old Cricket Theatre for a revival last night.
The Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company announced yesterday at its annual meeting that it was entering the steroid drug field and doubling its research facilities.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Republican Congressional leaders told President Eisenhower today he had little chance of getting a $554,000,000 increase in postal rates this year.

VISITORS to the new Gracie Towers model apartments, which open tomorrow at 180 East End Avenue, should not mind being locked in the bathrooms or closets. For such details as "leopard"-curtained bathtubs, floral designs on doors and grass-green carpeting teamed with bright green trellis wallpaper, give a new, livable feeling to these oft neglected areas.
Only one district title changed hands as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches were concluded yesterday. Apawamis took the Westchester crown.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Congress engaged in a pre-summit display of unity today in response to the Soviet Union's protests against aerial espionage by the United States.

The ten-story penthouse office building at 667 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Sixty-first Street, has been sold by Harphil Realty, Inc., to an investing client of Netter Netter, lawyers. The seller was represented by Jack Newton Lerner.

Portable oxygen tanks weighing a little more than a pound have been installed in the Kings County District Attorney's office, the five county courts in Brooklyn and in the grand jury room to be administered to witnesses suffering sudden heart attacks.
A machine that can translate Russian literature, from newspapers and novels to scientific texts, into rough but meaningful English has been developed by United States scientists and engineers.

Botany Industries, Inc. which last June acquired a 41 per cent interest in Premier Industries, Inc., another holding company, may some day have a 100 per cent interest in Premier, A.M. Sonnabend, chairman of both companies, told the annual meeting of Botany shareholders at the Roosevelt Hotel here yesterday.

A "COLOR PIANO," with which children can make ''chords" that are combinations of colors, is one of the attractions of an exhibit, "Art Education for Every Child," at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fiftythird Street.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois said today that President Eisenhower would "almost certainly" veto the $251,000,000 distressed areas bill this week.

A decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission has enabled Seatrain Lines, Inc., to maintain its New York-to-Savannah and Savannah-to-New Orleans service, John L. Weller, president of the company, announced yesterday.

LUXEMBOURG, Wednesday, May 11 -- The six European Common Market nations agreed yesterday to start building a uniform tariff wall by Jan. 1, 1961. That is a year ahead of the time planned for this action in the treaty that formed the bloc, but six months later than an earlier speed-up proposal.

Fletcher Flora of Leavenworth, Kan., has won the second annual Macmillan Cock Robin Award of $2,500 for his "Killing Cousins." The book will be published in October. Although this will be Mr. Flora's first hard-covered book, he is the author of eleven paperback novels and many magazine stories.

The Wisconsin Telephone Company sold $20,000,000 of thirtyfive year 4 7/3 per cent debentures yesterday to investment bankers led by Morgan Stanley Co., on a bid of 100.479, setting a net interest to the company of 4.85 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 -- The United States plans to launch seventy-five to 105 major missiles in the next three years and expects thereby to overtake the Soviet Union in the space race.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to break a lance for the State Department, with which I do not always agree, and possibly also for the Central Intelligence Agency, which in the past has made a few blunders I found unnecessary. Permit me to speak in defense of both, as a long-time intelligence officer, before, during and after World War II.

United States Government securities lost a bit of their recent price gains in a quiet trading session yesterday, but other fixed-income securities were generally in enough demand to register gains for the day.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Following is the text of the statement in the Senate today by the majority leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, on the U-2 plane incident:
MOSCOW, May 10 -- The Kremlin told the United States today that it would bring to trial an American pilot shot down over the Soviet Union on May 1 while on a reconnaissance mission.
TOKYO, May 10 -- In Japanese, "rodo" means labor and "ongaku" means music. The two words, shortened to "ro on," stand for what must surely be the world's largest Concert-of-the-Month Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It has long been recognized that world diplomacy is often conducted on a level far removed from ethical, moral and democratic considerations. What has been substituted is chauvinism, expediency, brinkmanships and attempts to derogate one's adversary.
For the second game in succession, tenth-inning lightning struck the Yankees. The Indians unleashed the bolt, much in the manner of the White Sox here last Sunday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10 -- Fifty-two white persons jailed under South Africa's emergency regulations have threatened a hunger strike.

The chairman of the Community Services Committee of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations denounced the country's hospitals yesterday for accepting "our dollars but not our opinions."
ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 10 (AP) -- Stockholders of Hoover Ball and Bearing Company and Universal, Inc. of Bedford, Ohio, ratified a merger agreement, effective on May 31.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 10 -- A pair of Detroit teammates, Therm Gibson and Billy Golembiewski, were the only undefeated contestants in the American Bowling Congress Masters tournament after the fifth round of match play at the Sports Arena tonight.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., May 10 -- Some big trout would have been caught today if a wild turkey gobbler had been willing to mind his own business. His meddling passion beguiled a couple of anglers out of two hours of sunlight during which fish were bound to have been feeding.
The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, told churchgoers yesterday that religion had no part in the Presidential election of 1960.

Stockholders of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad were told yesterday that they could not expect resumption of dividends before 1962 even if the merger with the Erie Railroad were accomplished this year.
OMAHA, Neb. May 10 -- Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon demonstrated today that they had impressive popular support in Nebraska.
A large red velvet heart adorned the doorway of the Waldorf-Astoria's Sert Room last night for the fifth annual Heart of America Ball.
MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., May 10 (AP) -- A forlorn but hopeful wife sat quietly on her mother's lawn today and declared that her flier husband was not a spy as had been charged by the Soviet Union.

The Transit Authority has not received a "satisfactory answer" to its protest to the Union News Company concerning the display of newspapers, Charles L. Patterson, the chairman, said yesterday. He said he would continue to press the matter.

Trading in most New York commodity futures markets was dull and featureless yesterday. Prices closed irregularly higher. Sugar, eggs, wool, rubber and hides rose; cocoa, lead and copper declined; and price movements for potatoes, coffee, cottonseed oil and pepper were mixed.

MOSCOW, May 10 (AP) -- An article in the leading Soviet army publication said today Francis Gary Powers had indicated he believed an explosion of his jet engine halted his May Day spying flight over the Soviet Union.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates ended a four-game losing streak tonight by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3 -- 2, on home runs by Bill Mazeroski and Hal Smith.
New York University yesterday almost eliminated Manhattan from the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball race by downing the Jaspers, 9 -- 3, at Ohio Field in the Bronx.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 11 -- The agitation for drastic political and economic reforms following the downfall of President Syngman Rhee's administration has penetrated to an unexpected level of the Korean social order, the porters of Seoul.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., May 10 -- Students and teachers at Sewanhaka High School here worked as professional models to help raise a cash award for an original, unpublished choral composition for the school's annual music festival next week.

The annual meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night unanimously recommended the renomination and re-election of seven sitting judges. It also elected Orison S. Marden, son of the late Dr. Orison Sweet Marden, author and editor, as president of the association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: ln the presence of common danger we expect, and have historically achieved, the strength of solidarity. Perhaps this is the spirit in which your editorial of May 8 "Behind Khrushchev's Wrath" is written. Intelligence and covert operation are part of the game, you seem to say, and this everyone should know.

PARIS. On the eve of the summit the sky is black with platitudes coming home to roost. One hears anxious talk that, unfortunately, the cold war is now likely to continue and cannot, as had been hoped, be replaced by peaceful coexistence.
