LOS ANGELES, May 11 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for five runs in the last two innings tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-3, before 27,926 fans in the Coliseum.

Forty-four years ago -- on March 1, 1916 -- an itinerant shoe salesman billed a Cornell University student for $9.50 for a pair of shoes. A few days ago, a check for that amount was received here in full if longdeferred payment.
Dr. Malcolm C. Moos, Administrative Assistant to President Eisenhower in charge of speech-writing, will be the host of an educational television series titled "Hats in the Ring."
A MOTHER who spurned her 3-year-old daughter's request to help on a routine household chore was cautioned by her own mother:
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 1 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 12 -- Israeli archaeologists have discovered at least seven letters of Bar Kochba, the leader of the Jewish rebellion against the Romans from A.D. 132 to 135.

A. Mosbacher Sons, Inc., textile converters, have leased the store, mezzanine and basement at 109 West Thirty-eighth Street. They will move from 345 West Thirty-fifth Street, where they have been since they started in business thirty-five years ago.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson tonight assailed the United States reconnaissance flight over the Soviet Union as a blunder in timing. He added, however, "No one questions the necessity of gathering intelligence for our security."

LONDON, May 12 -- The "Play of Daniel," a liturgical drama based on a transcription of a thirteenth-century manuscript, will be presented in Westminster Abbey beginning June 6 by The New York Pro Musica ensemble.
"Our business is not to amuse, but if we take ourselves too seriously in our advertising, our friends will become bored with us rather quickly."
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The dean of the University of Michigan College of Pharmacy testified today that fewer than 1 per cent of the drugs now on the market received Federal inspections.
An agreement was reached yesterday by The New York Times and two railroads for the rental of space to sell copies of the newspaper at six locations in Grand Central Terminal.

A memoir or Dr. Albert Schweitzer by Norman Cousins, based on a visit to the doctor's jungle clinic in Africa, will be published June 8 by Harper. Called "Doctor Schweitzer of Lambarene," the book has an appendix of two statements by the doctor on the danger of atomic weapons and contamination by radioactivity and the futility of war.

Don Poggio, the Argentine-bred who runs in the silks of Gustave Ring, enjoyed the benefit of a good ride by Mickey Solomone and won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The event, a one-mile purse called the Knickerbocker, attracted a field of seven.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 12 (AP) -- With the 1959 champion, Deane Beman of Silver Springs, Md., absent, many experts here rate Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L.I., as the leading American threat in the British Amateur golf championship.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Edward K. Mills Jr. has asked President Eisenhower to withdraw his nomination to the Federal Communications Commission.

Governor Rockefeller and his four brothers announced yesterday that they intended to sell their 19 per cent interest in the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains, the second largest bank in the County. Most of the holding will be offered to other shareholders of the bank.
FORT WORTH, May 12 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell shot a threeunder-par 67 today to take the first-round lead in the $30,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.

"Be security conscious" is the New York Police Department's caution to boat owners as the season of 1960 is beginning. Its spokesman for yachtsmen, Lieut. Charles Meyer, commanding the Riverfront Squad, is trying to reduce losses to skippers from pilferage and vandalism.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $3,000,000 to $549,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements increased $172,000,000 to $500,000,000.

Bye Bye Byrd and Widower Creed, ace American pacers, were named yesterday to represent the United States against performers from New Zealand, Australia and Canada in Yonkers Raceway's $150,000 International Pace series next month.

California Electric Power Company yesterday sold $12,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to a Kidder, Peabody Co. Investment banking syndicate on a bid of 99.569 for bonds bearing 5 1/8 per cent interest coupons.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service stepped into negotiations today between twenty-three Chicago marine warehousing and stevedoring companies and Local 19 of the International Longshoremen's Association.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- No one is sane enough to be executed, Dr. Karl Menninger, physchiatrist, said here today in presenting the psychiatrist's view of capital punishment.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The deluge of threats and Pecksniffian pieties which Premier Khrushchev has been emitting ever since he caught the United States air-spying over Soviet territory is beginning to encourage the hope that once more the Kremlin can be relied on to lose a propaganda battle it has won.
The International Union of Operating Engineers has won exclusive bargaining rights from the American Dredging Company of Philadelphia.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 12 (AP) -- The Air Force attempted to launch an Atlas missile on a 9,000-mile flight today but failed. A rocket engine was cut off after being ignited.
Earl W. Kintner, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said last night that he detected signs of improvement in the tone of advertising.
Violent oscillations that destroyed a wing were cited by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation yesterday as the cause of two Electra airliner crashes. Lockheed manufactures the Electra.

MADISON, Wis., May 12 (AP) -- Attorney General John W. Reynolds Jr. ruled today that Wisconsin's twenty Democratic convention delegates pledged to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey had been automatically freed by the Minnesotan's withdrawal as a candidate.

Proprietors of nursing homes and city officials clashed yesterday at a public hearing on the proposed repeal of Hospital Code provisions that permit some nursing homes to operate without meeting all the code's requirements.

An attack In a West Side playground where two 16-year-old boys were knifed to death last August was planned at a "council of war" a few hours before the killings, a General Sessions jury was told yesterday.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 12 -- A million-dollar art show for charity will open tomorrow night for a ten-day run in the big indoor tennis court on the former Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney estate here.

The apartment house at 45 West 110th Street, where Borough President Hulan E. Jack lives, figured in Housing Court proceedings yesterday. The managing agent, Oscar Schlesinger, was charged with sixty violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The spy-plane case, in addition to everything else, may have cost the Administration the "peace issue" in the forthcoming Presidential campaign. And this was the best issue it had a week ago.

LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) -- Fallowing is an account, issued today by Toss, Soviet press agency, of the informal news conference held yesterday in Moscow by Premier Khrushchev, incorporating a transcript of the questions and his replies:
THE recent liberation from the Army of Elvis Presley may have been one of the most irritating events since the invention of itching powder.
Thirty-one police officials were transferred yesterday in another mass reshuffling by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy. The Bronx was the only borough not affected.
The postman this week carried letters of acceptance or rejection by the Ivy League Colleges to thousands of anxious high school seniors over the country.
Almost every major group on the New York Stock Exchange joined in a sweeping advance yesterday, accomplished on the heaviest volume in more than a month.
GENEVA, May 12 -- Two Soviet Embassy aides in Bern who were arrested Tuesday for espionage activities left Switzerland today.

BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon conceded today that he was "part of a stop-Kennedy movement" and predicted that Adlai E. Stevenson would be the Democratic Presidential nominee for the third time.
GENEVA, May 12 -- The United States asked today that within six years after a ban on nuclear weapons tests goes into force the projected control system be installed and fully operational.
MILWAUKEE, May 12 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews hit his third homer within twenty-four hours and his sixth of the season to lift the Milwaukee Braves to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

THE formation of a young sculptor, exposed to a multitude of twentieth-century innovations, usually takes a lot more time than was needed by 29-year-old Edward Higgins, who is making his exhibition debut at the Castelli Gallery, 4 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Great Northern Ry. Stockholders of the Great Northern Railway were cautioned yesterday at their annual meeting in St. Paul of the possibility that a proposed merger of the carrier with the Northern Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroads might not prove feasible.

North Electric Company, producer of telecommunications and automatic control equipment, has acquired control of the Power Equipment Company, manufacturer of power supplies for computers and other electronic-electrical systems.

Itek Corp. The directors of the Itek Corporation and the Hermes Electronics Company have agreed in principle to merge, Richard S. Leghorn, president of Itek, and Malcolm M. Hubbard, president of Hermes, announced yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 12 -- A $5,000,000 grant has been made to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation in New York for basic research in the physical sciences.

BOSTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Pete Runnels singled off the left-field wall with the bases loaded in the last of the ninth inning today, enabling Tom Brewer of the Boston Red Sox to post a 1-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent hearings before the Joint Commission on Atomic Energy, like much earlier discussion, suggest the presence of a strikingly unrealistic attitude toward an agreement on halting atomic tests. I do not suggest that this attitude is universal; but it does seem sufficiently common to merit comment.

New Jersey and Connecticut representatives warned yesterday of the prospect of strife if the New York Legislature failed in 1961 to remove certain provisions of the tax law aimed at nonresidents working in New York.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Library of Congress announced today the acquisition of a rare Augustine Herrman map of Virginia and Maryland in 1673.
JERSEY CITY, May 12 -- An integrated ten-year plan for the rehabilitation and redevelopment of Jersey City's blighted areas will be presented to members of the City Commission next Tuesday.
A joint union-management drive to defeat a proposed city tax on trucks was started last night by the trucking industry and Joint Council 16 of the Teamsters Union.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Disregarding Administration opposition, the Senate approved today a bill to have the Federal Treasury reimburse states and localities for the tax revenues lost when the Government acquired property within their boundaries.
HAVANA, May 12 -- Premier Fidel Castro caught two fish today in the Hemingway marlin tournament. One was a 46.5pound sailfish and the other was a fifty-four-pound marlin.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A Republican member of the House said today that a conversation between the chairman of the Federal Power Commission and Thomas G. Corcoran had been "foolhardy and indiscreet."

DENVER, May 12 -- The head of the American Council for Judaism declared here tonight that American Jews were becoming increasingly aware that they and their organizations "have been skillfully engulfed by the Zionist political machine."

Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman, realty investors, announced yesterday that they had acquired full ownership of the land and the thirty-four-story office and showroom building at 1441 Broadway, a block south of Times Square.

The first underwater circumnavigation of the globe is a triumph of human prowess and engineering skill, a feat which the United States Navy can rank as one of its bright victories in man's ultimate conquest of the seas.
HUDSON, N.Y., May 12 (AP) -- A single picket and scattered boos were the only signs of protest tonight when a Russian diplomat arrived for a speech.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 12 -- A 300-pound pregnant sow that was killed on a highway eight months ago was the subject of sober deliberation in State Supreme Court here today.

Dr. Robert S. Lynd, author of two classic sociological studies, gave his final lecture yesterday at Columbia University, where he has been Professor of Sociology in the Graduate School for almost thirty years.

HAVANA, May 12 -- An American flier was shot and killed as he landed his two-engine Piper Apache plane on a highway ten miles west of Havana today. The pilot was identified as Matthew Edward Duke, 45 years old, of Palm Beach, Fla. Four men and a woman waiting near by on the highway were arrested.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Rail and truck freight loadings last week indicated, as they have during the last few weeks, a general slack in business activity.
Alexander King said yesterday that he liked the theatre but loathed show business.
LONDON, Friday, May 13 -- The dissension-ridden Labor party suffered severe losses in the polling yesterday for members of Borough Councils in the cities and towns of England and Wales.
UNION, N.J., May 12 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, the New Jersey Association, champion, won low gross in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today.

CONNECTICUT groups, impressed by the apparent success of Pennsylvania's "fishing for fun" trout policy on the Left Branch of Young Woman's Creek, are beginning to raise an outcry for some of the same.
Senator John F. Kennedy was enthusiastically acclaimed last night as he brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination into New York.
A series of resolutions likely to be adopted by the International Chamber of Shipping attracted the fire of American steamship interests yesterday.

The Tennessee Valley Authority, since 1933 a financial ward of the United States Government, made its first public bid in the financial district yesterday for a blue-chip ranking in the investment world.
A pioneer project aimed at Stimulating the rehabilitation of twenty blocks of rundown buildings on the upper West Side won the unanimous support of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The foreign aid authorization bill was sent to the White House today as both houses of Congress approved $1,366,200,000 in new spending and a Senate committee opened hearings on the appropriations bill.

Bond prices fell back yesterday in an inactive trading session dominated by the bidding retreat of market professionals disturbed by Washington announcements bearing on business and financial affairs.

MATSUYAMA, Japan, May 12 -- There were two interesting encounters here yesterday. The Boston Symphony had its first taste of the warmth and friendliness of provincial Japan and this city had its first contact with a major American orchestra.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 12 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club, the champion of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association, captured low gross honors today in the association's oneday tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May -- Sammy Cahn, one of the leading lyrics writers of Tin Pan Alley, Hollywood and Broadway, was trying to find words to explain a strange sort of economics that Frank Sinatra has brought to television.
CHESTER, Pa., May 12 -- The cargo ship Mormacbay was launched here today. She is especially equipped so that her overseas services can be extended to the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence Seaway.

LIBERTY, N.Y., May 12 (AP) -- Members of the Rabbinical Assembly of America were asked today to urge their congregations to support the struggle for racial and religious freedom "wherever it is taking place."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary Thomas S. Gates Jr. today ordered all long-distance communications services of the Defense Department pulled into a single communications agency under the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- The Federal Government must act to save portions of the nation's lake and ocean shore line for recreational purposes before this land is taken over by industry or real estate subdivisions, Senator Paul H. Douglas declared here today.

A record school construction and capital improvement program was proposed to the Board of Education yesterday by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools. The program called for the expenditure of $124,350,000 in 1961 and more than $625,000,000 in the next six years.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- The grain futures market built up a general recovery today, with advances gaining speed during the final few minutes of transactions on the Board of Trade.

Most companies are usually responsive to the wishes of large stockholders. An exception is the United States Envelope Company, which apparently chooses to disregard the feelings of its leading stockholder, the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd urged President Eisenhower today to tell the people what he knows about a neutron bomb that is said to emit a death ray.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 12 -- Cold-weather gear, including one ski cap, dominates the wardrobe of the United States women's international golf team. The seven Curtis Cup players, who will leave by plane for England tomorrow evening, are taking plenty of heavy clothing with them.
DETROIT, May 12 -- An economist and a leader of the United Automobile Workers suggested today that the Government should play a more positive role in planning the nation's economic growth.
PARIS, May 12 -- Aly Khan, whose son is the spiritual leader of 20,000,000 Mosiems, was killed tonight in an automobile accident in suburban Suresnes. He was 48 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The General Accounting Office reported today that a study of commercial warehouses had disclosed profits ranging from 12 to 265 per cent on storage of Government-owned surplus grain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Virtually every newspaper in this city, including The New York Times, has editorially commended our union and the trustees of Trafalgar Hospital for including a "never-strike" pledge in a collective bargaining agreement which eliminates the possibility of a strike in that hospital for all time.

Utica, N.Y., borrowed $1,093,632 in the public market yesterday on improvement bonds backed by the general taxing power. The securities were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company.
Evidence has been found that early modern man lived side by side with Neanderthal man in an area now known as the middle East.

OMAHA, May 12 (AP) -- Two Strategic Air Command bomber crews have completed fifteen-day simulated space flight performance tests in a laboratory space ship. They emerged somewhat fatigued but enthusiastic.

Three visitors walked into two of the world's busiest places yesterday and found themselves clasping the hands of strangers, receiving mementoes, performing for photographers and making sudden plans to travel free.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 14 points (25 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday in the most active trading in months.
Steel output during April dropped to 9,771,000 tons from 11,564,683 in March and 11,281,920 during April, 1959, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
Shifts in top executive posts at the Industrial Rayon Corporation were announced yesterday as insurgent stockholders moved to unseat management.

The Yankees still haven't found the knack of winning extra-inning games. They lost another, their third in a row, to the Indians at the Stadium yesterday. Russ Nixon decided the overtime contest, 3 -- 2, with an eleventh-inning homer.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The court-appointed board of monitors of the Teamster Union went through another shake-up today.
State Senator William Steelman Mathis of New Jersey was acquitted yesterday in Special Sessions Court on a charge of drunken driving in midtown Manhattan last December.

Profit taking and liquidation dropped cocoa prices yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market recovered part of the losses on hedge lifting and manufacturer buying for price fixing. Final quotations declined 8 to 25 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 314 lots of 30,000 pounds each.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals made it easier today for small banks to fend off competition from new branches of larger banks. Its ruling was in litigation involving an application by the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit to operate a branch bank in Clinton Township, Macomb County, Mich.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 12 (AP) -- The Brookfield Farm's Inside Story, hustled into the lead at the start by Joe Culmone, scored by five and a half lengths in today's feature race at Garden State Park.
ATLANTA, May 12 -- The tides of Southern politics appeared today to be turning against Senator Lyndon B. Johnson in the Democratic Presidential race.
CHICAGO May 12 -- Following is the text of a speech by Adlai E. Stevenson to the Conference an World Tensions tonight at the University of Chicago:

IF Friday the thirteenth prove to be an unlucky day, what about lobster as a palliative dinner? This succulent shellfish may be purchased in two chains for the modest sum of 69 cents a pound. However, if the budget runs to this price only if there is no waste involved, choose a swordfish steak or, for 10 cent less, halibut steak or sea scallops.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Government on the recent U-2 plane incident:
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Marion B. Folsom today advised business executives lawyers and professors to accept politcal appointments in the Government.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission began proceedings today against an American Stock Exchange firm accused, in effect, of violating its function as a specialist in several actively traded stocks.
Attempts to bolster patients' resistance to advanced cancer with an experimental vaccine continue to show promise, a specialist from Roswell Park Memorial Institute, Buffalo, said here yesterday.
A tract of land on Route 110 at Northern State Parkway in Huntington, L.I., has been purchased by Jesse Sakoloff and Louis Marberg of Jamaica, Queens, for improvement with a shopping center.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Friday, May 13 -- The six-nation European Economic Community agreed today on a long-discussed plan to speed the creation of internal tariffs and the reduction of the bloc's common external tariff.

A CHAFING dish can add to the pleasure of entertaining at home. Used with a sure, dramatic flourish, it can provide not only a piping hot and savory dish, but also a moment of excitement to the festive meal.

Manlio Brosio, Italian Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday that the sixnation European Common Market would always be ready to reduce frictions that its free-trade development might cause the rest of Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The United States Government told Moscow today that it had sent aerial survey flights over Soviet territory for "purely defensive purposes."

LONDON, May 12 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said tonight that talks with the Soviet Union and the United States on the last barriers to a treaty banning nuclear tests would be the "most hopeful and most important" matters to be discussed in Paris.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 12 -- Members of the North Shore Junior Service League are at work on plans for the third annual Jazz Jamboree. The event will be held June 17 at the Whitney Polo Field in Manhasset as a benefit for the league's community trust fund.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 12 (AP) -- Lieut. (j.g.) Robert L. Beck of the Navy won individual honors, and the United States "red" entry took the team competition as the fifth annual modern pentathlon ended today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (UPI) -- Jack Sanford pitched a two-hitter today as the leagueleading San Francisco Giants scored a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. It was the sixth straight triumph for the Giants.
LONDON, May 12 -- The stock market was active here today and widespread gains were recorded in all sections.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Two suits by the nation's charter air carriers against the railroads were settled out of court today for token amounts.
PARIS, May 12 -- Premier Khrushchev is scheduled to arrive in Paris Saturday morning. This posed the possibility today that he would seek week-end bilateral meetings with the Western Big Three.

WHEN the draw was to be made for post positions for the big race, the assignment was given to Norman Woolworth. Since he is related, although distantly, to the five-and-dime store founder, he naturally plucked from the box the numbers of 5 and 10 for his own two entries, Muncy Hanover and Bright Knight.
The board of directors of Mack Trucks, Inc., announced yesterday that the company would continue to operate its plant in Allentown, Pa., under the terms of a new labor agreement.
ROANOKE, Va., May 12 (UPI) -- Stuart T. Saunders, president of the Norfolk and Western Railway, said today the line should know "fairly soon" whether a merger with the Nickel Plate Road was feasible.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The success of smaller cars poses a threat to road financing, the Highway Transportation Congress was told today.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 12 -- Eleven 3-year-old filly pacers will race tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway in the Lady Maud Stake.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 12 -- Anger over the United States-India grain agreement led today to the resignation of Thailand's Foreign Minister and a threat of an "agonizing reappraisal" of the nation's membership in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and of her relations with the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Some diplomats in Washington who are friendly to the United States have expressed irritation over what they considered the irresponsibility, ineptitude and confusion in the case of the U-2 plane downed in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Mrs. Helen Witt of Grundy, Va., is a stanch defender of her high-school classmate, Francis Gary Powers. "People keep wondering why he would confess all those things to the Russians," she says.

Net income of the Sunbeam Corporation in its fiscal year ended on March 26 rose to $11,865,850, or $3.80 a share, from $10,308,832 and $3.32 in the preceding year, the company reported yesterday. Net sales of the manufacturer of electrical
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12 (AP) -- Strong consumer demand will carry business through 1960 without a recession -- but with only minor gains in production.

NOBODY knows how many novels have been written about the emotional crises of adolescence, but surely there have been enough to make a pile as large as Cheops' pyramid. In fact, so many such novels are published every year that I am thinking of establishing an annual award to be given to every novelist who manages to write as many as four books without any of them containing a protagonist under the age of 21.

Sales and earnings of the Hammond Organ Company in the fiscal year ended on March 31 rose to record highs with sharp increases above the preceding year's figures, according to the annual report to be issued today.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, scoring seven runs in the first inning and six in the second, recorded their eighth straight victory by trouncing the Chicago Cubs, 14 -- 1, today.
THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with seventeen Republican House members; met with Cabinet; sent condolence messages to family of John D. Rockefeller Jr.

SEOUL, Korea, May 12 -- The popularity of the United State in South Korea, at its peak during the upheaval that overturned President Syngman Rhee's repressive regime, seem to be losing a little of its bloom in some quarters.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 12 -- Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, declared today that the nation's security depended on a continued and substantial export surplus.

The rate of business borrowings at Chicago banks continued to push ahead of those at New York City institutions in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
In recognition of their "ragsto-riches" careers, eight business leaders received the fourteenth annual Horatio Alger Awards yesterday at a ceremony in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Mayor Wagner sought yesterday to avert a blackout of the Great White Way when the present contracts between the League of New York Theatres and Actors' Equity Association expire May 31.

MADRID, May 12 -- Spain was one of the first countries to know and use playing cards and some Spanish scholars maintain that cards first reached Europe through Spain. This was in the middle of the fourteenth century and at first cards were used only for fortune-telling.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The merged labor movement told Congress today that a slowdown in housing "threatens to help pull the country down into the morass of another economic recession."
RAGUSA, Sicily, May 12 -- Southeastern Sicily's progress is due to the Ragusa oil field.

Union delegates to a conference called by the American Medical Association on voluntary health insurance expressed the hope last night that the session would open the way for new experiments in the organization and financing of medical care.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said tonight in a tribute to Prince Aly Khan:

A 42-year-old violinist, whose "facetious" remark yesterday morning caused a bomb scare aboard a Bermuda-bound jetliner at New York International Airport, was arraigned later before United States Commissioner Max Schiffman.
Bill Shea said yesterday the Continental League would be faced with extinction or all-out war with organized baseball if Congress failed to pass the controversial Kefauver sports bill.

MIAMI, Fla., May 12 (AP) -- Thirteen persons, including two stewardesses, were injured today when a Delta Air Lines jet plane, flying nonstop from Chicago, ran into turbulence thirty miles out of Miami.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- After twenty-four hours of deliberation, the Soviet Government made public today the transcript of Premier Khrushchev's impromptu news conference in which he expressed disappointment in President Eisenhower and warned that future invasions of Soviet air space could lead to war.

TOM BRIGANCE is a changed man. The designer, famous for striking playclothes in dizzying patterns and colors, has turned to more silken pastures. His new summer collection includes seventy graciously mannered day and evening dresses that would look as out of place on a sand dune as a bunch of violets.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- Former President Harry S. Truman endorsed Senator Stuart Syming ton today as "without doubt the best qualified man" for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen was enjoined yesterday by Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson from striking or causing a work stoppage against the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company tomorrow at 7 A.M.
The parents of distraught New England college students are being offered a chance to comfort them with apples.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- Rioting disrupted a hearing by a House Un-American Activities subcommittee here today. The subcommittee is investigating alleged Communist activities in northern California.

The committee on floor transactions of the American Stock Exchange favors the suspension of the registration of Jerry A. Re and Gerard F. Re as specialists in various securities in which they are registered.

PARIS, May 13 -- A Western intelligence agency has received information that a conflict over defense policies has arisen between Premier Khrushchev and senior officers of the Soviet armed forces and may stiffen the Soviet Union's position on Berlin at next week's summit conference here.

ARNE MARKUSSEN, tenor from Long Island who in 1957 sang the title role in Britten's "Albert Herring" here, offered an interesting and unusual program of Norwegian songs at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

Astonishment and dismay must be provoked by the report yesterday of this newspaper's education editor, Fred Hechinger, of the haphazard and chaotic conditions reigning in this year's admissions decisions by Ivy League colleges. Harvard, for instance, has acknowledged that the difficulties are so great that another committee doing the same job "might well have made different decisions in a good many cases."
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Cuba traded Tony Taylor and Cal Neeman to the Philadelphia Phils for Don Cardwell and Ed Bouchee today.
It may sound curious to describe an instrumentalist as the world's best avant-garde flute player, but the distinction is no mean one.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 (AP) -- The league-leading San Francisco Giants won their seventh straight game on Mike McCormick's six-hitter, beating the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight, 3 to 0. It was the Giants' hird shutout in a row.

LONDON, May 13 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan said today that Pakistan would protest to the United States if she found that the U-2 plane shot down in the Soviet Union had used a Pakistani airfield as a base for spying.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Apawamis team of five won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub championship at the Knollwood Country Club course today.
The cruise of the liner Nassau was canceled at midnight last night after a majority of her Italian crew of 285 men walked off the ship demanding that a new union represent them.

Some manufacturers of newsprint are converting newsprint machines to "more profitable grades of paper," the Newsprint Information Committee, representing a group of Canadian producers, said on Thursday.

On the fiftieth anniversary of Mark Twain's death, the famous American humorist appears to be more alive in the mind of the public than ever before. This season has seen several television programs inspired by the life of the Missourian, whose real name was Samuel Langhorne Clemens, and last year.
La Guardia Airport is getting ready to put on a new face -- out only on one side.

The National Bank of Westchester, White Plains, announced yesterday that it planned to acquire the Rye National Bank. The announcement came on the heels of a decision by Governor Rockefeller and his four brothers to sell their 19 per cent interest in the National Bank of Westchester, second largest in the country.

Three gunmen used the stolen automobile of a State Court of Appeals judge as a getaway car yesterday. They had taken 2,000 from fifteen employes of a Brooklyn manufacturer. One person was shot in the hold-up.

"The World of the Mind," a three-volume work edited by Gardner and Lois Murphy, is planned for publication by Knopf. It will bring together explorations of the human mind by great thinkers throughout the ages, emphasizing ths investigations of recent years in psychology and psychiatry.
Most prices on New York commodity exchanges decline yesterday. Evening of position prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume. Trading was dull.

Within the next few months a number of executives of the Chemstrand Corporation will be quietly relieved of their managerial responsibilities. From all indications, they'll be delighted by the change.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 13 -- The Messenger Stake, harness racing's richest event, is expected to attract 40,000 fans to Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The race has a gross value of $142,786.15, half of which will go to the winner.

For the last several days the eyes of the world have been focused on the disturbing events resulting from the flight of a United States airplane over Soviet territory.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 14 -- Francis Henry Bloeth, the 27-year-old ex-convict accused of slaying three robbery victims on a nine-day crime spree last summer, was convicted today of first-degree murder and robbery.
The large number of group exhibitions dominates this week's art scene, as the season wanes.

ALTHOUGH old brownstone flats are fast disappearing in New York's remodeling and rebuilding boom, they can still be found by persistent effort. Such quarters are worth the search, for they usually have spacious rooms and interesting architectural details.

THE Eastern States Championships, annual regional tournament of this district, will begin Friday. Except for national events it is the biggest tournament held in the East, its annual entry being exceeded only by the corresponding Pacific Coast regional tournament called "Bridge Week."

LONDON, May 14 -- Mohammed Ikramullah, career head of the Pakistani Foreign Ministry, reported today that an investigation showed that no aircraft had taken off early this month from Peshawar, Pakistan, "in the direction of the Soviet Union."

Outlook Clouded The long-awaited conclave that begins in Paris tomorrow is billed as the summit conference of the Big Four. Actually there will loom over the four, as they gather around the conference table in the Palais de l'Elysee, the shadow of a fifth man, Francis Gary Powers.
SILVERSTONE, England, May 14 (AP) -- Innes Ireland of Britain drove a new Lotus racing car to victory today in the 150-mile main event of the International Trophy race meeting.
BOSTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles rallied for five runs in the ninth inning today to beat the Red Sox, 5 -- 2. The defeat ended a five-game Boston winning streak.

GOLD is back in the headlines after twenty years of obscurity in the financial pages. Even though the outflow has recently been cut from a flood to a trickle, America's tremendous gold hoard is still shrinking, as foreigners use some of their newly gained wealth to buy back from us a small portion of the gold they shipped here during the dark days before the war.

Birchcroft, a colony of fifteen custom-built homes on Annette Court, off Wyckoff Avenue, in Wyckoff, N.J., has been opened by Harvey J.E. Milkon, builder. The dwellings will range in price from $32,500 to $50,000.
Governor Rockefeller gave firm notice yesterday that he would not attend the Republican National Convention.

TO THE EDITOR: OSCAR HANDLIN, in his review of "To the Golden Door" by George Potter, writes that the author "is all too ready to blame all the woes of the island [Ireland] on its British rulers forgetting that comparable tribulations were driving the emigrants out of Germany and Scandinavia, where there was no foreign domination."
EDWARD HIGGINS (Castelli): A young sculptor showing for the first time is bold and original in his monumental use of welded metal filled with plaster.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The United States Government protested to Cuba today over a Cuban patrol boat's firing on a United States submarine on May 6.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Vice President Nixon's "bandwagon is rolling and rolling hard at the grass roots level." This assertion was made today by Mr. Nixon's press secretary, Herbert G. Klein. Behind the statement was an obvious effort to suggest that Senator John F. Kennedy, who won a sweeping victory in West Virginia's Democratic primary this week, was not the only candidate with a bandwagon on the road.

IN Peru, everything, or almost everything, anteceded the Incas, for as a people and as a culture they arrived late. More than twenty centuries before their advent other Peruvian tribes were making a culture of cities.

The International Garden Club will commemorate forty-five years of administrative effort in behalf of the Bartow Mansion and its formal gardens in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, at a May Garden Party and Fashion Promenade to be held there Wednesday.

ALMOS, Sonora, Mexico -- It becomes harder and harder to find an old, unspoiled Mexican town. But now, easily accessible some thirty miles off the new West Coast Highway (Mexico Route 15) and at the end of a road that has just been improved lies this town of Alamos, one of the most beautiful and interesting of all Colonial settlements.

AMARILLO, Tex. -- Trans-continental motorists passing through here on the southwestern route to Los Angeles can enjoy a heady foretaste of the great canyon country of New Mexico and Arizona long before they reach it.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 (AP) -- Premier Rashid Karame's Government resigned today. A caretaker Cabinet headed by Ahmed Daouk, former Premier and Ambassador to France, was installed to prepare for parliamentary elections beginning June 12.

THE space age is not even three years old, but it already has its heroes, its dedicated servants, and a heavy stock of Complex ideas and information for the younger reader to absorb. The stock is growing every day and if those who have had the privilege of seeing the age born want to keep up with it, they had better start reading now.

In a biography of John D. Rockefeller Jr., Raymond B. Fosdick wrote: "What concerned him was the hard, practical problem of how to dispose of his wealth in ways that would advance the public good." On Wednesday Mr. Rockefeller, son of the builder of the Standard Oil empire, died at 86 after a lifetime devoted to giving away his wealth.

THE home handyman who longs for a convenient, well-equipped workshop can easily build one inside his garage. The shop illustrated here includes two work benches, and has plenty of storage space for all tools and materials.
A New York rabbi proposed yesterday that a chaplain trained in youth guidance be assigned to every public school faced with the problem of juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Less concentration on communicable diseases and more on environmental health problems in future inter-American health projects was stressed in a Congressional report issued here today.
Three Long Island trade unions have agreed to invest a substantial part of their welfare funds in Government-backed mortgages to help ease the tight money situation in the area.

PARIS, May 14 -- The outlook for the East-West summit conference beginning Monday improved slightly today but remained far short of optimistic. This was the consensus of most Western diplomats and observers.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 14 -- Marlin G. Geiger of 1005 East Kimball Avenue, executive vice president of W.R. Grace Co., died yesterday of a heart attack in a chartered plane while returning from a business trip to Baltimore.

AMONG the plants that practically take care of themselves are cushion chrysanthemums. They are low growing -- about ten to twelve inches high -- and develop mounds or cushions of bloom that almost completely hide the foliage.
Ever since she was a little girl, Mrs. Garret J. Garretson 2d always wanted to collect something. She never found anything she wanted to collect until three years ago, "when I found this China."
PARIS, May 13 -- Despite widespread protests from physicians and dentists, the French Government set ceilings on medical and dental fees, today as part of a social security reform.

BALTIMORE, May 14 -- The ten-round tune-up fights scheduled in Memorial Stadium for the former middleweight champion, Ray Robinson of New York, and Don Jordan, the welterweight titleholder from Los Angeles, were postponed tonight until Monday evening.

HAVANA, May 14 -- Rising hostility to the United States in Cuba exploded during the last few days into mass meetings, screaming headlines in the Government press and speech by frenzied orators on television and radio.

The formation of an International Academy of Astronautics, with both American and Soviet scientists among the members, was announced yesterday.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts wound up his Maryland campaign tonight with new potshots at Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri for having shunned Presidential preferential primaries.

TOKYO, May 14 -- The presence of the controversial United States U-2 high-altitude reconnaissance jet in Japan has become a key issue in the national debate over ratification of the new mutual security treaty between Tokyo and Washington.

TAXCO, Mexico A HEAVILY loaded vehicle presently going under the title '"Pepe" stopped briefly in this silver-lined tourist hamlet. The picture company spent four days shooting a five-minute sequence.

AFTER a venture into the procedural police story ("A Matter of Fact," 1956), Herbert Brean now returns, in one of his too infrequent novels, to the kind of crime-fantasia in which he first made his mark -- the grandly improbable and apparently impossible situation, with seeming overtones of the supernatural or at very least the paranormal.

GUATEMALA, May 14 -- Guatemalan armed forces will conduct continuous guerrilla warfare training maneuvers until further notice, President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said today. General Ydigoras observed maneuvers along the Caribbean area yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A half day's drive inland from San Francisco, or a day's drive north from Los Angeles, is the Yosemite Valley. This massive, glacier-carved opening in the west wall of the towering Sierra Nevada forms the center of Yosemite National Park, and is among the most popular outdoor wonderlands in the country.

FATHER was the world's funniest man, but life with father was not, for Charles Chaplin Jr., a lot of laughs. Perhaps that is because it was, so much of the time, life without father. Charles Jr. was a year and a half old, his brother Sydney eight months, when the brief and bitter marriage of their parents exploded in December, 1926.

FEW men in history have had a second career so fabulous as that of Lieut. Col. John Masters. Awarded the D.S.O. and O.B.E. in the Indian Army (where he was known as "the perfect Infantry Officer"), he soon thereafter received honors and decorations from the Book-of-the-Month Club, best-seller lists and Hollywood.

PARIS WITHOUT much question the most important exhibition of French painting organized anywhere since the war, the Poussin exhibition, which has just opened at the Louvre, includes 120 of the seventeenth-century master's 180 known paintings.

FRESNO, Calif., May 14 (AP) -- Upsets marked tonight's West Coast Relays, Doug Smith of Occidental College beat Ray Norton in the 100-yard dash and an Oregon State javelin thrower, Gary Stenlund, was voted the meet's outstanding collegiate performer.

The concept of a kitchen as an arrangement of cabinets and work counters around a number of appliances is beginning to give way. The new idea is that food preparation calls for a system of service centers.

THE Fourth Annual Camera Cruise, co-sponsored by the New York Guild of Photographic Dealers and a group of camera manufacturers, will be held Sunday, May 22. The $3.95 fare includes a full day's sail along the Hudson River and a program of performances, lectures, seminars, demonstrations and dancing.

FORTY years ago in China there raged a many-sided intellectual controversy that had widespread social and political consequences. Out of it grew the modern literary movement, strong currents of social reform, a re-evaluation of Chinese culture, a critical attack upon traditional ethics, a vitalized nationalism and the beginnings of communism.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 14 -- Political circles here are discussing the likelihood of a woman's becoming the next Prime Minister of Ceylon.

Determined but pessimistic, the United States delegation to the forthcoming International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea will strive to persuade other maritime countries to bring their sea-safety standards up to the level required by law on United States passenger, ships.

THE recent opening to the public of the Old Westbury,L.I., Gardens comes appropriately at the start the picture-taking season. The seventy acres of private park on the John S. Phipps estate offer amateurs a widely assorted array of picture subjects.

ONLY memories remain for Brooklyn Dodger fans but it's obvious that they guard them jealously. That's all that Walter O'Malley left them when he moved the beloved Brooks to Los Angeles. WEST CHESTER, Pa., May 14 -- Ch. Black Tommy of Huguenot, a 4-year-old bloodhound owned and handled by E. Edward Simon of Chatham, N.J., was named best in show tonight for the second time at the Chester Valley Kennel Club show.
VIENNA, May 14 -- A prosperous and stable Austria celebrated today the fifth anniversary of her new sovereignty and the fifteenth anniversary of her liberation from the Nazis.

THE New York Philharmonic has had another good season. It has done excellent business, although it will have, in the inescapable way of musical enterprises, the inevitable deficit. It has worked hard and productively.

The New York Housing Authority is planning to sell $4,950,000 of temporary loan notes on May 24. The notes will be dated June 21, 1960, and will come due on Jan. 11, 1961. PARIS, May 17 -- Western diplomats here expressed the belief today that Premier Khrushchev's break with President Eisenhower signaled a major change in Soviet policy. One Frenchman suggested that this tended toward a "warmed-up cold war."
BALTIMORE, May 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy won a landslide victory in Maryland's Democratic primary today to enlarge his claim to the Presidential nomination.
PARIS, May 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower paid a surprise call today on an old friend, the mayor of a French village that made the President an honorary citizen a few years ago.

MARSEILLES, France, May 17 -- No cobblestones were hurled by a riotous public as shooting began here today on Joshua Logan's American film production of "Fanny," based on three of Marcel Pagnol's plays and films.
LONDON, May 17 -- The recovery of stock market prices that had accurred in the last few days, was halted today. Small losses predominated in most of principal lists.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Senate investigators were told today that Dr. Henry Welch, head of the Food and Drug Administration's Antibiotics Division, had received $287,142 since 1953 for his outside activities on drug publications.

PARIS, May 17 -- Some East Europeans in Paris said today that the latest friction between the United States and the Soviet Union would make life in the Soviet satellite states more dreary, more fearful and more nerve-racking.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 18 -- Sales of the F.W. Woolworth Company came to $271,973,882 for the first four months of this year, an increase of $28,820,305, or 11.85 per cent, over the level of the 1959 period, Robert C. Kirkwood, president, reported to stockholders at their annual meeting here today.
CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP) -- Ed Bailey's single drove in the winning run as the Cincinnati Reds edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 -- 4, in twelve innings tonight.
TRENTON, N.J., May 18 (AP) -- In fifty years New Jersey will be bulging with 10,716,000 people, almost double its present population, the State Conservation Department forecast today.

LONDON, May 18 -- The immediate reaction of investors to the breakdown of the summit conference was to adopt a wait-and-see policy when the stock market opened today. However, Wall Street's firmness to the news, added to a good crop of company results helped sentiment, and near midday prices began to rise.

WOLFGANG Hollegha, a young Austrian painter showing at French Co, Madison Avenue at Seventy-sixth Street, stretches thin a painting idea that seems to be gaining ground. The idea is to use enormous surfaces as physical equivalent to enormous spaces.
LONDON, May 18 -- Three Western statesmen voiced hope here today that efforts to relieve international tension would continue despite the fiasco of the summit conference.
A wildcat strike on the Hoboken waterfront went into its fourth day today. Mediation efforts on four fronts failed, and the number of striking dock workers rose to 800 from 300 on Tuesday.
The jurisdiction of the State Supreme Court in a jurisdictional labor dispute was challenged yesterday by the International Maritime Workers Union.

Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc. The directors of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., declared a quarterly dividend of 22 cents on the new common stock yesterday. It is payable June 24 to holders of record of June 3. A five-for-one split of the old common was approved earlier this month.

"Sacco-Vanzetti: The Murder and the Myth," by Robert H. Montgomery, a Boston lawyer, is planned for publication in September by Devin-Adair. The author knew many of the principals in the 1921 trial and the final review in 1927.

The spirit of the Gay Nineties will be recaptured at A Night in Old Tuxedo Park, an evening of dancing and entertainment, to be held May 28 at the old race track in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Mrs. Lester Owen Naylor and Mrs. John H. Griffin are co-chairmen for the event, which is being sponsored by the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital Auxiliary for the benefit of the hospital.

ALGIERS, May 18 -- Algerian nationalist gun emplacements on Tunisian territory were submitted to "vigorous" shelling by French planes and artillery yesterday, a French Army spokesman announced tonight.
Two new films will open today.
ROD SERLING and "Playhouse 90," perhaps the most consistently fruitful partnership in television theatre, scored again last night with a drama of searing tragedy and nobility over Channel 2.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway took a long step toward a merger yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, May 18 -- The president of the Southern Baptist Convention said here today that before Roman Catholic groups "cry out against persecution and bigotry in America" the Catholic Church must "repent her own sin in the field of religious persecution" and declare that religious freedom is for all men.

The Hasty Exit It's not the manners; it's the mores. Have you noticed that the final curtain in the theatre and the last chord in the concert hall act on some members of the audience like the starter's gun at a track meet?

The State of Maine borrowed $7,250,000 yesterday in the bond market -- $3,950,000 to finance general improvements, and $3,300,000 for the University of Maine. Both issues were secured by full-faith-and-credit obligations of the state.
NEW ORLEANS, May 18 -- The International Longshore- men's Association has rejected a demand that it revoke immediately a charter granted a few weeks ago to a dock local in the Dominican Republic.

ROME, May 18 -- Yesterday's Vatican condemnation of "the absured split of conscience between the believer and the citizen" was binding on Roman Catholics throughout the world, churchmen said here today.
NEWTOWN, Conn., May 18 -- Joe Louis, the former world heavyweight champion, today predicted Floyd Patterson would regain the championship by a knockout.

"DEVILS IN WAITING,"* by Mary Motley, is a remarkably revealing memoir of life in French Equatorial Africa many years ago. At least, it seems many years ago, since the time is somewhere in the Nineteen Thirties when dictatorial changes in Europe held the world stage and few truly foresaw the present African renaissance.
The 59-year-old operator of a sixty-ton mechanized shovel was trapped in the cab for thirty minutes yesterday when the machine toppled on its side after a ramp collapsed.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson told the Senate today that there was "growing reason to suspect" that the Soviet Union had placed a man in space and would shortly attempt to recover him. The Washington Democrat said his statement had been based on information supplied to him by "reliable sources" within the Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy gained North Dakota's eleven Democratic national convention votes today as a result of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's withdrawal from the Presidential contest.

To THE EDITOR or THE NEW YORK TIMES: The 30th Street Association, which has always aligned itself with those who have sincerely sought a solution to the problem of midtown traffic congestion, sympathizes with Robert Moses' reported concern for the effects of midtown traffic strangulation on future generations.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 19 -- Mrs. Harold Kilpatrick of the Country Club of New Canaan and Mrs. Robert M. Ganger of Siwanoy triumphed in the oneday tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association at Bonnie Briar C.C. today.
Signs of stability appeared in the bond market yesterday after a succession of nervous trading sessions.

The novel idea of saving possibly four years in making City Charter reform effective, by putting proposed revision to referendum in a special election next spring, is certainly worthy of consideration by the Moore Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York. On such a timetable the general election of Nov. 7, 1961, would be filling offices as established under the new Charter approved about six months earlier.
Subscribers to Blue Shield (United Medical Service, Inc.) received a total of 556,527,410 in benefits last year in the New York area, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Eddie Machen of Portland, Ore., will box Alex Miteff of Buenos Aires at Madison Square Garden tonight. The heavyweights are scheduled to meet over the ten-round route in the Eighth Avenue arena and before a national television audience starting at 10 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Dr. Henry Welch, chief of the Division of Antibiotics of the Food and Drug Administration resigned his $17,500-a-year job today at the request of the Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 19 (AP) -- Gardner Dickinson carded a five-under-par 65 and took the first-round lead in the Sam Snead Golf Festival today.
ALBANY, May 19 -- Revised equalization rates for thirty-seven cities and 675 towns were announced today by the state Board of Equalization and Assessment.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, May 19 -- Four mountain climbers lay severely injured and a fifth was reported seriously ill today high on Mount McKinley, North America's tallest peak.

EXHIBITIONS of fine prints have become so lamentably rare in New York that when a large selection like that at the Peter Deitsch Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, turns up, it is something of an occasion.

Hulan E. Jack and his supporters moved last night to counteract two uprisings by disudent Democrats that have threatene Mr. Jack's position as leader of the western part of the Fourteenth Assembly District.

The American Guild of Musical Artists criticized yesterday some of the particulars of the agreement reached on April 5 by the heads of the Metropolitan Opera of New York, the Lyric Opera of Chicago, and the San Francisco Opera.

Two well-mannered horses munched carrots daintily and quietly, unperturbed by 200 celery-chewing humans, yesterday at a luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel. The horses were honored guests.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A combination of cuts in steel production and other economic factors in specific areas last week produced a marked decline in freight and truck loadings, it was reported today.
BALTIMORE, May 19 (UPI) -- The Maryland State Athletic Commission tonight indefinitely suspended Sugar Ray Robinson for failure to fulfill a fight contract in Baltimore last Monday night.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- The expiring May wheat future broke by the allowable limit of 10 cents a bushel for a single day in the final seconds of transactions today on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Republican members of a House investigating panel denounced Thomas G. Corcoran today for his visits to the Federal Power Commission and his performance as a witness.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 19 -- Bright Knight, driven by Earle Avery, scored a length victory tonight in the final of the May Class B pacing series at Roosevelt Raceway.
Forty actors got some batting practice yesterday afternoon as the Broadway Show League's softball season began at Central Park.
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- Nations throughout the nonCommunist world saw rays of nope through the summit wreckage yesterday despite omens of new "cold war" tensions.

ROME, May 19 -- Concern about the possibility of war spread over Italy today after the failure of the summit conference in Paris. It was the subject of almost all conversations heard in the streets and shops.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 19 -- Eight dwellings of eighteenth century origin, most of them predating the American Revolution, have been chosen by the Stamford Historical Society for a tour. The event on Sunday, from 1 P. M. to 5 P. M., will be in observance of Settlers' Day and the founding of Stamford in 1641.

Dr. James L. Dixon, an educator and Queens Democratic leader, collapsed and died Wednesday night in front of the Kew-Porest School, Inc., 119-17 Union Turnpike, Forest Hills, Queens, where he had been headmaster since 1941.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (UPI) -- Richie Ashburn tripled and scored the lead run in the eighth inning and then batted in a good-measure run in the ninth tonight as the Chicago Cubs beat Philadelphia, 4 -- 2.
Bill Haberman, the left fielder, hit three singles, scored three runs and drove in one yesterday, pacing Fordham to a 9-5 baseball victory over Rutgers at the Rams' field in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper defended Vice President Nixon today against Democratic charges of using the summit collapse for political advantage.

Plans were announced yesterday for a development of 6,000 homes In Middlesex County, N.J. The tract embraces 2,500 acres about seven miles south of South Amboy, near Spotswood, and extends into Monroe and Madison Townships.

The fourth day of a wildcat strike by dock workers on the Hoboken waterfront led to the threat of imprisonment last night for two officials of the International Longshoremen's Association for their refusal to answer questions of the Waterfront Commission.
THIS is a great week for beef -- by courtesy of several leading chain stores. They are offering a wide variety of beef cuts at attractively low prices.

TOKYO, May 19 (AP) -- A radio report said today that a Soviet - Chinese mountaineering team had reached the top of Mount Everest from'the northern slope, a route to the world's highest peak never before taken successfully by man.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 19 -- The Security Council will meet Monday afternoon to debate a Soviet demand that it "take the necessary measures" to stop flights of United States aircraft over Soviet territory.
There's a tempest brewing in the coffee world.
Service and maintenance employes of the Chrysler Building struck yesterday morning and did not return until 4:45 P.M., but nobody had to walk up or down the building's seventy-six flights of stairs.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 -- Oregon's low-keyed Presidential primary election cmpaign rolled to a finish tonight with a lively accompaniment.
DETROIT, May 19 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today the development of a new process for making open hearth steel that cuts production time in half.

AT this time of year, many a bride-to-be is probably regarding kitchen stoves in an effort to determine a friend rather than a foe. And, with so many new developments taking place on the range, a number of homemakers of some years' standing also may be considering the purchase of an up-to-date model.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 19 -- The remains of one of the earliest human creatures have been found in Israel, on the west bank of the Jordan River at Afiqim, two miles south of the Sea of Galilee.
YESTERDAY (May 19, 1960) THE PRESIDENT In Lisbon. THE SENATE Completed action on $290,000,000 San Luis (Calif.), reclamation bill.

WRITE about what you know." It's the oldest and the soundest of literary maxims. Most novelists, except writers of suspense thrillers and science-fiction, abide by it instinctively. Conrad, the former ship's master, wrote novels about seafaring men. James, the expatriate, wrote about international society. In the most pop- ular novel of the last year, "Advise and Consent," Allen Dury, a reporter assigned to cover the Senate by this newspaper, wrote about the Senate.

LONDON, May 19 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that he hoped the events of the last few days were "an episode, an unhappy episode, and not the first step toward a serious deterioration in the situation."

Alberta Municipal Financing Corporation is planning to offer $30,000,000 in sinking fund debentures due in 1985, according to a registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The First Boston Corporation and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc. are named as managing investment bankers.

LINDRICK, England, May 19 (AP) -- Rain tonight increased the belief that the British team would keep the Curtis Cup is the women's golf competition against the United States. Play opens tomorrow with three foursomes matches.
The Pennsylvania Railroad was hit yesterday by scattered work stoppages from here to St. Louis by about 10,000 maintehance employes.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick testified today that a bill proposing drastic curbs on organized baseball would turn the major leagues into a farce.

PARIS, May 19 -- The official line of the United States Government on the summit conference is almost as surprising as the conference itself. For the White House theme, put out nightly by James C. Hagerty and his aides at official briefings, is that United States officials won a victory here over Nikita Khrushchev and solidified the Western alliance.
Prices of cotton futures or the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 17 points yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

THOMPSONVILLE, Conn., May 19 -- The shad were running fine in the Connecticut River below Enfield Dam today, and catching them was educational.

ALBANY, May 19 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen. president of Princeton University, called on American colleges tonight to do a better job of screening and placing Asian and African students to insure them a better education here.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A third major network offered today to make free television time available this fall to the major parties' candidates for President and Vice President.
Two long-time rival railroads forgot their differences yesterday and agreed to become one.
The New York police waited all day yesterday for nonexistent demonstrators to lay a wreath that did not materialize at a statue that is not there.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The long-planned union-management conference, designed to reduce industrial tension, got off to a limping start today.

The twelve-story office building at 320 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-second Street, has been sold by the Mosler Holding Corporation, representing the Mosler Safe Company, to Jack Brause, realty investor.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The rapid growth of the Roman Catholic school system in the nation has made it the largest private school system in the world, according to a report published today.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A committee of outside experts called in by the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended today a 1961 budget of $664,000,000 for medical research. This is $264,000,000, or 65 per cent, more than the Administration asked.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- There are occasions when a political party's interest and that of the nation coincide and the result is an act of constructive statesmanship. The latest instance was the telegram of support which four Democratic leaders sent to President Eisenhower Tuesday afternoon when Western efforts were continuing in Paris to persuade Soviet Premier Khrushchev not to sabotage the summit conference.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Capt. Charles D. Mott of the Bureau of Weapons scored two victories today in the Armed Forces championship chess tournament.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 19 -- A feeling of relief is apparent in Arab comment about the failure of the summit conference.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $6,000,000 to $555,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $36,000,000 to 462,000,000.
The recently captured whale at the city's Aquarium at Coney Island has turned up her nose iat all sorts of goodies.
Boat builders have been accomplishing amazing things with their new designs for small dinghies.

GOING to one of Alan Freed's rock 'n' roll musicales has always been something like having an aisle seat for the San Francisco earthquake. His favorite art form has caused ricts in Boston, been banned in New Haven and broken all marks for drawing customers to the Brooklyn Paramount.

Five radio disk jockeys, including Alan Freed, were arrested yesterday on charges that they had accepted payola. A former program director and two former record librarians were also arrested on the charges.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that the Continental Baking Company of Rye, N.Y., violated the antitrust laws when it acquired a rival bakery.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 19 -- Industrial activity in the world surged to a new postwar high in 1959, the United Nations Statistical Yearbook reported today. At the same time, global exports attained a new peak of $100,000,000,000, 1 per cent above the previous 1957 record.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday a move toward getting the city its long-sought television station.

The director of the General Instrument Corporation and the General Transistor Corporation yesterday agreed in principle on a merger of the companies. Their combination would place the resulting concern among the nation's five largest producers of semi-conductors, with sales exceeding $65,000,000 a year.
CLEVELAND, May 19 -- A Negro minister from New York was named today Vice Moderator of the General Assembly of the 3,000,000-member United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Gen. Thomas D. White, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, advocated today the strengthening of United States military forces "to meet the possibility of irrationality."
THE network television coverage of Premier Khrushchev's press conference, which ran until about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, was a first-rate job.

Objections are increasing in European maritime nations to United States legislation under which half of our foreign aid cargoes must be carried in United States ships. If this pressure continues, it might result in a drive by United States shipping interests to ship all United States Government aid cargoes in American vessels.

Premier Khrushchev -- as was predicted here many days ago -- is squeezing every last drop of propaganda value out of the U-2 incident, and his demand for an urgent session of the United Nations Security Council to discuss it is fully explicable in that context.

"BEAUTIFUL, refreshing, one of the best Dior-New York collections I have seen" was the remark of one New York store buyer. Enthusiastic comments, as effervescent as bubbles from a glass of cold champagne, burst forth from all those leaving the fall Dior-New York collection late yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, May 19 -- The Court of Appeals upheld a ruling today that dismissal was too severe a punishment for a subway change-maker who told six passengers to enter through an exit gate and then pocketed the 90 cents in fares they had given her.
The head of a hospital workers' union warned last night that nonprofessional, technical and clerical employes in ten voluntary hospitals were "either going to get collective bargaining or strike."

LISBON, Portugal, May 19 -- President Eisenhower arrived here today and declared that the failure of the summit conference must make the free world tighten its belt and "work a little harder for the great cause of peace with justice and freedom."
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower wall receive a courtesy call from Seisaku Ota, chief of the Ryukyu Islands Government, during his visit to Japan next month, the White House said today.

The old mahogany drum, used for the past seventy-five years in picking jurors, has been made to look as primitive as the horse-drawn hansom cab. This has come about by one of several recent moves to reduce the burden of jury service in New York County and to improve the system.
Stocks advanced yesterday for the seventh straight session. Trading slackened notably after Wednesday's turbulent market when more than 5,000,000 shares changed hands.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company has won its fight for control of the United States Envelope Company.
A special program to be introduced at City College next fall will enable superior students to devote more time to advanced work in their major fields.

PARIS, May 19 -- President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev turned their backs today on the wreckage of the summit and flew away from a city that was still groping with the feeling of political nightmare.
THERE might be some women who do not detest a long, hot trance under a hair dryer, but to most customers of any beauty salon the dryer is a relic of the Dark Ages.
After turning out all those off-beat plays, Eugene Ionesco believes he deserves a change of pace. He is writing the book of an untitled musical, his first attempt in that field.
Indications mounted yesterdays that Anastas I Mikoyan might have lost out in a Kremlin clash over policy toward the United States just before the summit conference.

A score of speakers examined various aspects of the economy yesterday at a gathering of business leaders and joined in outlining a bright future for this country and for the world. Such qualifications as there were hinged mainly on the clouds of international tension darkening the horizon.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 19 -- The Connecticut College Alumnae Club of Westchester will raise additional funds for the college's fiftieth anniversary fund by sponsoring a house and garden tour here, in Port Chester and in Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House Ways and Means Committee reached what appeared to be an impasse today on the issue of medical care for the aged.
BOSTON, May 19 -- The Institute of Contemporary Art, the first permanent structure in the Metropolitan Arts Center, opened tonight on the banks of the Charles River.
The election of William S. Vaughn as president of the Eastman Kodak Company was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The directors of Capital Airlines rehired one of their former members to serve as chairman today and removed their biggest stockholder from two positions of authority.
HONG KONG, May 19 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China said tonight it was "by no means fortuitous" that the summit conference was sabotaged by the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A $975,000,000 school-aid bill, partly shaped to escape President Eisenhower's veto, was cleared today for a House debate next week.

CHEESEQUAKE STATE PARK, N.J., May 19 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority was host today to seventeen of the eighteen children who have been born on the Garden State Parkway since it was opened on July 1, 1955.
"THANK heaven for little boys, for little boys get bigger every day" is the paraphrased version of the popular song boys' wear buyers and manufacturers are singing these days.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Court of Appeals directed the Civil Aeronautics Board today to investigate charges of improper approaches to the agency in a New York-San Francisco route case.

A Fire Department official testified yesterday that the safety laws had been used by a tenement landlord to try to get the city to order a building vacated. The official said he believed the landlord wanted to get the tenants out so he could get higher rents.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- Mexican censorship of American movies made there was attacked here today by an American who recently completed a movie in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- Investigators from the House called on the Justice Department today to consider criminal prosecution of Army officers and contractors involved in the construction of a costly housing project.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $69,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
BONN, Germany, May 19 -- Western diplomats here are saying that the statesman who came out best from the summit debacle in Paris is Chancellor Adenauer.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Bob Cerv, the outfielder the Yankees sold to the Kansas City Athletics in the fall of 1956, returned to the Bombers today. The solidly built slugger rejoined his former team in an even swap for Andy Carey, a third baseman who had seen little action with the New Yorkers this season.
