The Automobile Club of New York called yesterday for an underground garage as a part of the proposed cafe in Central Park.
TOKYO, Friday, May 20 -- Japan's House of Representatives approved a new mutual security treaty with the United States today after fist-swinging opposition by Leftists.
A wrangle over top Jobs yesterday wrecked plans for a forced merger of the Americar Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in New Jersey.
CHICAGO, May 19 -- Adlai E. Stevenson asserted tonight that Premier Khrushchev had wrecked the summit conference but that the United States had handed him "the crowbar and sledgehammer" to do it.
PARIS, May 19 -- The North Atlantic treaty alliance moved solidly into line today behind the Western Big Three in the dispute that led to the collapse of the summit conference.
An arbitration board has denied pay claims by printers Who were temporarily out of work when publication of nine major newspapers here was suspended during the December, 1958, deliverers' strike.

HAVING vaulted from the pages of Eleanor H. Porter's novel into our lexicon and, with the aid of Mary Pickford, on to the silent screen back in 1920, "Pollyanna," voluble this time and cheerful as ever, has arrived on the Music Hall's impressive screen.

Outgiving, the 4-year-old colt owned by Georgiana Foster, made a warm impression on the crowd of 24,300 at Aqueduct yesterday. The colt was backed into even-money favoritism for the $6,000 sprint that served as the feature race and he came through admirably.
BERLIN, May 19 (AP) -- following, in unofficial translation, is the text of a speech by Premier Khrushchev on his arrival today in East Berlin:

CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP) -- Vada Pinson tripled off the scoreboard with two out in the ninth inning tonight to score Eddie Kasko as the Cincinnati Reds gained a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. As a result, the Reds moved into third place ahead of Milwaukee, which was idle.

MASSENA, N.Y., May 19 (UPI) -- Robert Moses, chairman of the New York State Power Authority, said today that the St. Lawrence Power Project that was built jointly by the authority and a Canadian agency was a monument to American-Canadian accord.
Five thousand persons marched through Times Square to the United Nations last night in a demonstration for a "sane nuclear policy."

Wolstan Crocker Brown, retirea economist and adviser to athletes on how to keep in good physical condition, died Wednesday at his home, 336 Hillside Avenue, Douglaston, Queens, after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
New issues totaling $50,500,000 of leasehold revenue bonds of Pennsylvania's state agencies are scheduled for public sale next month.

Irving Gitlin, creator and developer of informational programs, has resigned from the Columbia Broadcasting System to join the National Broadcasting Company. The change in his affiliation is effective Monday.
The state is cooperating with settlement houses in a new move to curb juvenile delinquency through the establishment of a special youth employment service.
RINGGOLD, Ga., May 19 (AP) -- Dynamiters blasted a Negro home here early today, killing the mother and injuring her husband and baby son. A preliminary inquiry turned up no racial motive.
PITTSBURGH, May 19 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates whipped the St. Louis Cardinals, 8 -- 3, tonight and took sole possession of first place in the National League.
MOSCOW, May 19 -- The first poll of public opinion ever conducted in the Soviet Union suggests that 96.8 per cent of the Russians believe mankind can avert another war.
Gov. J. Caleb Boggs of Delaware said yesterday that the collapse of the summit conference would increase the consideration of peace as a campaign issue in the national election.

Heavy speculator liquidation, light hedging and stop-loss selling of cocoa futures closed prices at the lows of the session yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The deferred months were weakest, narrowing the differentials.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 19 -- The police used tear gas today to break up two demonstrations in Ankara. Witnesses reported no mob unruliness.

An expense budget of $2,345,483,576, the largest in the city's history, was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council for the fiscal year beginning July 1. It is the second successive budget of more than $2,000,000,000.

Four and one-half acres on Soundview Avenue, between Belts and Husson Avenues, the Bronx, have been, bought by the Parkchester Beach Club Corporation from the Bradish Johnson estate. The cash sale was negotiated by Charles Rubinstein, broker.
PARIS, May 19 -- Cyrus S. Eaton, Ohio industrialist, told Premier Khrushchev the story of George Washington and the cherry tree today in a hurriedly arranged conversation at Orly Airport.

IT is to be hoped that Bally Ache doesn't get any hifaluting ideas and scorn the $121,000 that will go to the winner of the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico tomorrow. If he's acquired any delusions of grandeur in the past week, he might sneer at this loot as being piddling, now that he's the most expensive animal wearing racing silks.
On May 29 the American Can Company is going to advise 13,000,000 American families that they should be drinking more milk.

MIAMI BEACH, May 19 -- The head of the Southern Baptist Convention was criticized here today for expressing "vague and generalized doubts and suspicions" concerning heretical teachings by professors in the denomination's seminaries.
SINCE Artur Schnabel's death in 1951, a group of the great pianist's disciples and admirers has worked to keep alive the memory of his musical ideals and accomplishments.
A marriage of the fluoroscope with television, portending a revolution in the art of looking inside the human body, was described here yesterday.
A bill to reimpose the requirement that milk sold here be marked with the date of its pasteurization was voted yesterday by the City Council.

PARIS, May 19 (AP) -- Orlando Sirola of Italy scored an upset in the French clay court tennis tournament by defeating eighth-seeded Roy Emerson of Australia, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, in the third round today.
DETROIT, May 19 -- Henry Ford 2d said today that the Ford Motor Company was prepared to meet new and revolutionary changes in the automobile market.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Friday, May 20 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics scored five runs in the eighth inning to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 7 -- 4, in a contest delayed an hour and twenty-five minutes by rain. The game ended early this morning.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Latin-American experts in the State Department noted today an apparent "build-up" in the Cuban press and radio of Raul Castro, Premier Fidel Castro's younger brother.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., ended its centennial year on Feb. 27 with sales exceeding $5,000,000, 000 for the second successive year. Ralph W. Bnrger, chairman and president of the nation's largest food chain, said sales and earnings were the largest for any fifty-two-week fiscal year.

The state courts were ruled yesterday to have jurisdiction over a dispute between the International Maritime Union and the Incres Line in the case of two cruise ships, the Victoria and the Nassau. They are immobilized in the port.
John D. Rockefeller Jr., who died on May 11 at the age of 86, left an estate valued at $150,000,000 in securities, real estate and works of art.

LONDON, May 19 -- The urban Briton's standard armorbowler hat and black suit looking as stiff and somber as his rolled umbrella -- was hacked to pieces today by a spokesman for the British clothing industry.
LONDON, May 19 -- Most share prices declined in the stock market today. Early mark-downs did not forestall selling, which was heavier than it was yesterday.

"THE GAMBLER, the Nun and the Radio," on Channel 2 last night, was an adaptation of an unusual short story by, Ernest Hemingway. It was a sentimental tale of faith, love and kindness, sprinkled liberally with sentiment.
BALBOA, C.Z., May 20 -- The number of ship transits, the cargo hauled and the tolls collected on the Panama Canal in April exceeded all previous Aprils on the waterway's history.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, warned the nation today against "jumping too rapidly at the Russian bait" in considering steps to meet the Soviet Union's economic challenge.

THE newest "must" for the American home seems to be the swimming pool. In 1959, the number of residential pool installations was 46,200, raising the total of home pools in the country to 171,100, according to the National Swimming Pool Institute.
CLEVELAND, May 20 -- The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. gave its approval today to the formation of a Council of the New York Metropolitan Area.
A reconstruction of Queens Boulevard that would cost more than, $17,100,000 during the next four years was proposed yesterday by Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens.
Eddie Machen of Portland, Ore., handed a sound beating to Alex Miteff of Buenos Aires in their ten-round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
A New Haven Railroad consultant denied yesterday a charge that the line had "greatly exaggerated" its deficit on commuter operations.

PARIS. Our experience with two post-war summit meetings emphasizes how difficult it is to practice personal diplomacy with dictators. Five years ago, at Geneva, we learned to our dismay that precisely while the Soviet boss was preaching peace he was negotiating an Egyptian arms deal which pushed the Middle East to the brink of war.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- Edwin C. Johnson predicted today that the new Continental Baseball League would seek help from the courts, if necessary, rather than fight organized baseball as an outlaw league.
LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union charged today that United States planes based in Japan had invaded Soviet airspace on spying missions.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- If ever anyone hit an electrifying home run, Ted Kluszewski did it tonight at Comiskey Park. Big Klu's third-inning, two-run blast off Whitey Ford led the league-leading White Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Yankees, and quite possibly led to a big scare for half the state of Illinois.

American Liberary in Paris The fragile fabric of Franco-American relations has suffered many strains and has been pulled in many directions in the long years between Lafayette's services to our Revolution and General de Gaulle's recent visit.
Former Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov has emerged from enforced obscurity to address a public mass meeting in Outer Mongolia, a Chinese Communist press agency reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 20 (UP) -- Herb Elliott of Australia, making his first United States appearance in two years, coasted to a 10-yard victory in the 1,500-meter race tonight at the Coliseum Relays. The time was 3 minutes 45.4 seconds.
ALBANY, May 20 -- The Court of Appeals has unanimously reversed the conviction of a New York City landlord for violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20 -- Diplomatic sources forecast today a sharp refusal by the Security Council to condemn United States reconnaissance over the Soviet Union as "aggressive" acts that might lead to war.

David Storey, a 27-year-old English writer, has received the second annual $7,500 Macmillan Fiction Award for his novel, "This Sporting Life." To be published in August, the story tells about a professional athlete who can express himself only in terms of muscular power and achievement.

LONDON, May 20 -- Britain and the West must be prepared to meet "new threats and new dangers" in the harsher international situation arising from the failure of the summit conference, Prime Minister Macmillan said today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- An election-year farm money bill providing nearly $5,000,000,000 for Federal farm programs was approved today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 20 -- A 23-year-old college sophomore who is a musician, photographer and insect collector will demonstrate tomorrow a model of one of his inventions -- a bulk-cargo ship that unloads itself.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 20 -- A tiny reddish bug with eight legs is invading new homes in western Suffolk and eastern Nassau Counties.
Stocks got off to a brisk advance yesterday but then lost most of their zip in late trading and closed with only modest gains. On average, prices were down but there were more advances than declines.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- The United States was warned today that failure of leadership and lack of clearcut ideals could send the nation from crisis to crisis, "putting off all problems" until "they explode beneath our feet."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- A leading sociologist today described the birth rate among the American Jewish populations as "disturbingly low."

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A bipartisan delegation of New York housing officials called today for the creation of a Federal mortgage corporation to stimulate private construction of homes for middle-income families.
CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -- A bases-filled single by Jim Piersall led the Cleveland Indians to a 2-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

TRENTON, May 20 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner's proposed income tax on New York-New Jersey commuters may reach the floor of the State Assembly for a final vote on Monday. The measure has not yet been introduced in the Senate.

Many parties, picnics and social gatherings will be held in connection with the thirteenth annual race meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association. The event, a benefit for the Boys Club of New York, will take place next Saturday at the Blind Brook Club Course in Purchase, N.Y.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 20 (AP) -- It is thought likely that Premier Khrushchev knew of the emergency landing when he spoke to a mass meeting in East Berlin today.

James E. (Sunny Jim) Fitz-simmons, the 85-year-old trainer, has named a three-horse entry of Irish Jay, Sarcastic and Warlike for the $61,235 Acorn Stakes today at Aqueduct. The sixteen 3-year-old fillies in the mile race will carry 121 pounds apiece.
The cotton futures market opened quiet with no sales made on the opening call, and the close was 6 points higher to 23 points lower than on Thursday.
THOMPSONVILLE, Conn., May 20 -- Shad fishing took a sharp upturn on the Connecticut River today, though it has been good right along for a week or more.
ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals regained their home winning touch by beating the Cincinnati Reds, 6 -- 1, tonight behind Larry Jackson's six-hitter.
A taxpayer's suit has been threatened to prevent the building of the proposed cafe in Central Park. The threat comes from Henry Morgan, the television performer.
The first union contract assuring a voluntary hospital here of protection against a strike was signed yesterday by Trafalgar Hospital.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 20 -- A teen-age dance orchestra, formed three years ago at St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church here, will entertain United States servicemen abroad this summer.

I WOULD like to have a recipe for eggplant cuviar. In the one I have in mind, the vegetable is baked with the skin still on, then peeled and mixed with the seasonings. The large eggplants available in my neighborhood are almost impossible to bake in my small oven so I wonder if you could also tell me where to find the small to medium-sized ones that I understand European cooks use.

Following are the texts of the address President Eisenhower made to the welcoming throng yesterday on his arrival at Andrews Air Force Base, as recorded by The New York Times, and the remarks he made on leaving Lisbon, Portugal, as reported by The Associated Press:
Lexington, Ky., is planning the sale of $4,750,000 of sanitary sewer revenue bonds on June 2. The issue will come due from 1962 to 1989.
LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Macmillan's statement to the House of Commons today on the breakdown of the summit conference:
The Lehigh Valley Railroad, which hasn't made a profit since 1956, expects to be in the black this year, thanks mostly to a big "boom" in 1916.

LONDON, May 20 -- In one of the season's largest sales in London of impressionist and post-impressionist works, a small painting by Henri Matisse today brought the top price of 20,000 guineas ($60,000).

LONDON, May 20 -- Industrial shares were much steadier than yesterday in the stock market today. Selective demand balanced a dribble of end-account selling. Changes were too small and irregular to show a definite trend.

CANNES, France, May 20 -- Federico Fellini's controversial Italian film, "La Dolce Vita," was awarded the Golden Palm, the highest award at the closing ceremonies of the thirteenth annual Cannes Film Festival tonight.
YESTERDAY (May 20, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Returned from summit meeting, saw Ambassador Lodge; blocked threatened strike against Pennsylvania Railroad by creating emergency fact-finding board.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a sharp revision of policy to undertake close supervision of radio and television programs.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The nuclear reactor is going to college. The Atomics International division of North American Aviation, Inc., received a patent this week for a laboratory model carrying a price tag within a university's budget.

The property formerly occupied by the Dock Street Builders Supply Company on Dock Street, 100 feet south of East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Eljam Mason Supply, Inc. It has dock space on Westchester Creek and will be used by the buyer as a depot for sand, gravel, cement and other mason supplies.

Fourteen thousand men and women from the armed forces and patriotic organizations will step off down Fifth Avenue today from Eighty-eighth to Sixty-Second Street, beginning at 2:00 P.M. The parade will be held to observe the eleventh annual Armed Forces Day.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I be permitted as a friend of Dr. Jose I. Rivero, editor of the Diario de la Marina, one of the four most respected newspapers of Latin America, to comment upon your editorial of May 12 "The Press in Cuba."

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The International Monetary Fund (World Fund) announced today an unusual transaction whereby Brazil will be permitted to draw $47,700,000 in various currencies, with repayment due in six months.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 20 (AP) -- Dave Marr shot another 67 today and took the midway lead in the Sam Snead Golf Festival.
ALGIERS, May 20 -- The French administration lifted censorship of newspapers in Algeria tonight for the duration of the campaign for the departmental elections May 29.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 20 -- General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it would offer small compact versions of the Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac this year.
GLEN ROCK, N.J., May 20 -- Sixth-grade pupils in the Richard E. Byrd School here recently backed with cash their moral support of a plan to rehabilitate the Statue of Liberty.
THE group shows that spring up in so many galleries at this time of year are necessarily a mixed lot and serve a number of different purposes, chiefly that of reviewing the last season's highlights.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The political truce over foreign policy was nearing collapse today even as President Eisenhower received a warm welcome home from his Paris summit trip.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A gas-company executive told House investigators today that his concern would have suffered over the years if he had not made personal contacts with members of the Federal Power Commission.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 20 (UPI) -- Alabama's Attorney General obtained a state injunction today to prevent Federal agents from examining voter registration records in Wilcox County.

BALTIMORE, May 20 -- Venetian Way of Isaac Blumberg's Sunny Blue Farm is the big horse in the Preakness tomorrow. This easy winner of the Kentucky Derby is expected to be the even-money favorite to beat five others in the eighty-fourth running of the Pimlico stakes that occupies the second tier of racing's triple crown for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Cuba has protested to the United States over alleged mistreatment of Cuban consular officials by the New York City police during a clash last Saturday between 200 supporters and opponents of Premier Fidel Castro.
Following are excerpts from the address in East Berlin yesterday by Premier Khrushchev as made available in English in New York by Tass, Soviet press agency:

Shampan Shampan, architects, and A.B. and B.B. Block, realty investors, have sold the five-story business building at 829 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Sixty-ninth Street, after an ownership of six years.
Tax experts said yesterday that the taxes on the $150,000,000 estate of the late John D. Rockefeller Jr. would probably be small compared with the size of the estate.

TALKEETNA, Alaska, May 20 -- A bush pilot picked up Mrs. Helga Bading, an ailing mountaineer, from the upper slopes of Mount McKinley this afternoon. Four injured men in another climbing party were still awaiting rescue at the 18,300-foot level of the mountain.

Copper prices advanced sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Trading was heavy, amounting to 831 lots, the largest since March 7 of this year when 964 lots changed hands. Each lot is equivalent to 50,000 pounds.

CHARMING little gifts that should keep the children happy for several hours have arrived at Bloomingdale's from Spain and West Germany. For small boys there is a package of three wooden cars with bright red and green wheels (89 cents), a sentry with five wooden soldiers ($1.25) and a group of three colorful sailboats ($1.49).
A Dane named Dr. Svend Smith put a small rubber gadget to his lips yesterday, blew through it, and immediately began sounding like a mosquito singing "Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes."
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Congress was urged today to create an extensive system of regional clinical centers to speed the application of medical discoveries to human beings.

BONN, Germany, May 20 -- A United States military transport plane lost on a flight from Copenhagen, Denmark, to Hamburg has made a forced landing in East Germany, it was announced tonight by the East German radio.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Two nudist publications, Sunshine and Health and Sun Magazine, won another victory today over Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, who rocketed from second-division obscurity to the top of the baseball world last season, still were streaking in reverse tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted 19 to 18 today to provide $58,000,000 next year to push development of a nuclear-powered plane.

Major league expansion was discussed at the club owners' closed meeting at Chicago earlier this week, with the possibility of the National and American Leagues going to nine clubs each by 1962, informed sources told The Associated Press yesterday.

Negotiators met for several hours yesterday at the Manhattan Hotel and failed to make any appreciable progress in the formulation of a new actors' contract. The current three-year pact expires May 31.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 (AP) -- The first-place Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for two runs in the twelfth inning tonight and edged San Francisco, 5 -- 4. The victory increased the Pirates' lead over the Giants to one and a half games.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- Congressional auditors accused the Air Force today of having let control of its $2,000,000,000-a-year intercontinental ballistic missile program slip into private hands.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Republican Platform Committee, charged today that Adlai E. Stevenson had made an "inflamatory" speech last night that played into Premier Khrushchev's hands.
A $265,000 award by a Federal Court jury to a merchant seaman who became partially paralyzed after an operation at a Government hospital wag approved yesterday by Judge Gus Solomon.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Ch. Cappoquin Little Sister, a 3-year-old black toy poodle belonging to Florence Michelson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., became best of breed early this evening in the twenty-eighth specialty of the Poodle Club of America.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The United States team that will compete in the world student chess championship was named today.

Bowser, Inc. The two-month-old proxy fight for control of Bowser, Inc., ended yesterday with a victory for the group headed by Robert J.C. Damon, which elected 10 directors at the reconvened annual meeting in a Fort Wayne, Ind., Federal court room.

MIAMI BEACH, May 20 -- Thirteen thousand Southern Baptists unanimously adopted a resolution here today expressing strong fears about electing Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, or any other Roman Catholic as President of the United States.
Mount St. Michael captured the Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championship yesterday with 47 points at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

THE Eastern States Championships, largest bridge tournament in the East, opened yesterday at the Statler Hilton Hotel with a field of record size competing for the first two titles. There were 116 pairs in the women's pair contest and 162 pairs in the men's pair contest.
BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson was cleared today to meet Paul Pender here on June 10 despite the former champion's suspension by the Maryland Boxing Commission.

Immovably loyal to its traditions, the City Council has again approved without the minutest change Mayor Wagner's $2,345,483,576 expense budget to operate New York City's government for the fiscal year 1960-61. "Council Approves Budget Unchanged" could be a standing headline held ready in every newspaper shop for use year after year.
Permision to operate a "commuter" air service at discount fares between New York and Washington was sought yesterday by Allegheny Airlines before the Civil Aeronautics Board.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- Premier Khrushchev seemed to strengthen the morale of his people today when he indicated in Berlin that channels of communication and negotiation with the West would remain open.
Bond prices improved slightly again yesterday as echoes of the collapse of the Paris summit talks faded.
The New York County Republican organization got off yesterday to an unusually early start on preparations for the fall campaign for local offices.
DETROIT, May 20 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers scored three runs in the ninth inning to post a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

MOSCOW, May 20 -- Something went wrong with the guidance system of the experimental Soviet "space ship" and it slipped into a larger orbit during an attempt to change its course downward by remote control, Tass reported today.

TOKYO, May 20 -- About 300 radical students broke through a police line into the grounds of Premier Nobusuke Kishi's official residence today to protest against passage of the new United States-Japanese security treaty in the lower house of the Diet (Parliament).
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., May 20 -- Gov. LeRoy Collins of Florida is expected to be named permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 20 -- Elizabeth's population has lagged in the last ten years while that of its suburbs has grown 5 to 208 per cent, according to preliminary results of the 1960 census released today.
ALBANY, May 20 -- State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. today upheld the New Rochelle Board of Education in its selection of a site for a new elementary school.
The role of the Protestant churches will be the subject of an eight-week Sunday discussion series on "Frontiers of Faith" starting May 29.

Lamson Sessions Co. Directors of the Lamson Sessions Company voted yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 35 cents. The latest dividend is payable on June 10 to holders of record of May 31.
PREMIER ANTONIO DE OLIVEIRA SALAZAR, the dictator of Portugal, pays himself about $130 a week, wears no medals, avoids parades, and says he does not care about staying in power -- or getting out.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 20 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts won Oregon's Presidential primary tonight.
Challenge-round matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team series were played in all three districts yesterday.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20 -- A wave of strikes culminating in a call for a national copper strike next week has brought the Government and unions to a showdown on wages.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Air Force fired an intercontinental ballistic missile more than one-third the distance around the earth today in a deliberate but belated demonstration of United States missile prowess.
PARIS, May 20 -- President de Gaulle called today for an "independent, united and cohesive" France to face the international uncertainties resulting from the collapse of the summit conference.

The value of all the goods and services produced in a year in this country may rise from the present $500,000,000,000 to $800,000,000,000 over the next ten years the National Industrial Conference Board forecast yesterday.
BONN, Germany, May 20 -- Chancellor Adenauer said tonight that Premier Khrushchev seemed to have put off his threat to Berlin for the time being.
LINDRICK, England, May 20 (AP) -- America's women golfers withstood a remarkable British comeback today and took a 2 -- 1 lead in their attempt to recover the Curtis Cup.
Marine insurers paid $1,228,000 in claims on losses in St. Lawrence Seaway operations last year, Miles F. York, president of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters, announced yesterday.
Several large issues of tax-exempt securities will dominate the otherwise lackluster week lying ahead in the new capital market.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Premier Khrushchev announced today that the Soviet Union would not attempt to change the "existing" situation in Germany or West Berlin at least until after the United States elections in November.
PEIPING, May 20 (Reuters) -- A mammoth rally roared its approval today at the denunciation of President Eisenhower as "a blood-stained butcher and bandit ringleader."

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- The range of grain futures prices widened in late dealings today and at the close of the Board of Trade they spread from strong on corn to weak on oats. New crop soybeans also were weak.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eisenhower came home today from his disappointing mission to the summit with a warning that East-West tensions were likely to become worse before they got any better.

The United States Conference for the World Council of Churches has made a direct appeal to the eight Protestant denominations in the Union of South Africa because "we face similar problems of tension."

RABAT, Morocco, May 20 -- With the country's first nation-wide elections only nine days away, Premier Abdallah Ibrahim was abruptly dismissed tonight by King Mohamed V. The ouster of the Premier emphasized the deep split between the royal palace and the leftist Government and its supporters.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The American Social Health Association reported today an alarming rise in venereal disease in many parts of the United States. The increase reached down to the ranks of sub-teen-agers.
LISBON, Portugal, May 20 -- President Eisenhower ended his twenty-four-hour visit to Portugal today with praise for the "real progress" achieved under the Salazar Government.
"YEARS IN AMBUSH," by Roger Grenicr, is a French novel about war's victories and a lost lady. It is particularly recommended for its fresh account of the 1944 liberation of Paris.
Three new features have been booked as attractions at local theatres. "The Apartment," starring Jack Lemmon, Shirley MacLaine and Fred MacMurray, will follow the current film at the Astor Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that to the best of their recollection, this was the first time the Russians had admitted that "anything of this magnitude" had gone wrong with any of their space vehicles.
A ship's captain testified yesterday that the Italian seamen who have immobilized two Incres Line cruise ships in New York could not be considered either mutineers or deserters.

Privately owned American-flag merchant ships carried only 10.9 per cent of the 22,800,000 tons of foreign trade the nation moved by sea during December of 1959, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute. December is the latest month for which such totals are available.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that she was in complete agreement with the declaration by Adlai E. Stevenson that the Democratic party had an obligation to expose errors of the Eisenhower Administration in foreign affairs.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 20 -- Senator Frost and Tie Silk, two of the leading trotters in North America, will meet tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway in the $27,531 United States Harness Writers' Trot.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Officials in Washington read Premier Khrushchev's speech in East Berlin today and breathed a cautious sigh of relief.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20 -- The largest fleet in the six-year history of Larchmont Yacht Club's springtime overnight race headed out slowly from Larchmont Breakwater tonight.

PARIS. THE French haute couture's ready-to-wear collections are now established seasonal events. Shown for the third year, these clothes, designed by Carven, Gres, Guy Laroche, Jacques Griffe, Jacques Heim, Jean Desses, Lanvin-Castillo, Madeleine de Rauch, Maggy Rouff, Michel Goma and Nina Ricci, fill a long wanted need to judge from the enormous crowd of international buyers they attract.

WARSAW, May 20 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic Bishop of Kielce, reported in February to have left his office in the interests of Church-state harmony, has been performing his duties all along, his office said today.
BUENOS AIRES, May 21 -- Argentina, Brazil and Chile are stering clear of the movement among Latin American countries to break diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic.
Table talk is varied at the Robert M. Klein home, but no matter where it starts, Mr. Klein says, it invariably ends with a discussion of "Y" problems.

A new buying season got under way last week. Throngs of buyers were in the city to preview the fall collections of clothes that will begin appearing in stores throughout the nation in late July or early August.

Retail sales in this area last week fell below the 1959 level. Leading merchants estimated that volume was off as much as 5 per cent from last year. Two days of unfavorable weather contributed to the decline in sales.

THOSE of us who cannot spend a year in the South Seas must take the second-best treat of reading about people who can, like the British family in this tantalizing book by Bengt Danielsson, a member of the Kon-Tiki Expedition.

IT is painful for high-school senior Peggy Dewey to imagine the separation from her twin sister Pat which will occur shortly after graduation, when Pat enters a convent. And, just when it seems that first love has come to lessen the threat of loneliness, the girl has a new shock.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 21 -- A racial integration problem that has vexed this suburban city of fashionable homes and large Negro neighborhoods for thirty years will be submitted to the voters on Tuesday.
COME summer, families shed more than winter wardrobes and heating bills. In the big move to the outdoors, they also abandon the formal rituals of dining and entertaining.

GROTON, Mass., May 21 -- The bell high in the gray Gothic tower of St. John's Chapel tolled the long hour at noon today, as it had last night at midnight. Each time it called sons of Groton School from events in the celebration of the school's seventy-fifth anniversary.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 21 -- For the last three years Colorado has had an unusual medical plan for its aged, one that many observers feel points to an acceptable national program.
GENEVA, May 21 -- Non-European countries have expressed fear this week that world trade policies will be dictated at their expense.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- It now appears unlikely that completely unfettered participation by the United States in the International Development Association will be approved by the House of Representatives.

MAHLER has come in for his share of attention from the record companies this year, and the reason is not altogether a result of the celebrations of the centenary of his birth. Those, of course, play a part.
HOLLYWOOD THE tall young man with the dark, curly hair, smoothed down his soldier's uniform, rose from the bar stool and walked glumly below bright lights, out among the crowded night-club tables.

The harvesting of another bumper wheat crop in the United States is just getting under way. At a time when the international political situation appears to be approaching a crisis, this may prove to be most fortunate to the free world.

EXETER, N.H. -- Rivers and waterfalls were so important to the industrial development of New England that few of the cities and towns that sprang up could develop without the accompanying blight of water-powered factories and other functional architecture.

THERE have been many books written by people who have hand-reared wild animals, and then kept them around the house in a state of semi-domestication. But, interesting though these accounts often are, one gets the feeling that there is something lacking.

IT takes a lot of hand tools to do all the garden chores. An easily built caddy (such as the one shown above) is a simple way to mobilize them for transporting to work areas. When day is done the tools go back into their proper places and the caddy is trundled to the garage or utility room.

CRATER LAKE, Ore. -- The seasons pay little or no attention to the calendar here in Crater Lake National Park. Summer arrives in the valley country a few miles away several weeks before the season changes at this lake high in the mountains.

SANDS POINT, L.I., May 21 -- Mr. Stevenson declined tonight to comment on Mr. Farley's remarks. But he held to his position that the United States had given Premier Khrushchev the "pretext" to wreck the summit conference.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy has decided not to advocate during his campaign for the Presidency that the independence of the Federal Reserve System be ended or diminished.
TO THE EDITOR: I AM very grateful for the review of my book "The Lovely World of Richi-san." However, Earl Miner's contradictory processes of critical thought in his review leave me rather confused.

The Russian announcement last Sunday that it has launched a 10,000-pound satellite carrying a dummy space man with all the necessary equipment for a manned space flight, together with the statement by a Soviet astrophysicist that "possibly the great moment of man's flight into space will come before this year is out," marked another important step in the race toward space, with the United States and Russia as the princpal contestants.
A new ranch model priced at $28,900 has been opened at Bar Harbour, on Larch Lane in Massapequa, L.I., a colony being built by Willfred Stewart.
HONG KONG, May 13 -- A Westfield, N.J., minister has brought a fresh approach to the problem of Hong Kong's refugees from Communist China.

A Police Department helicopter patrolling the harbor last Thursday sighted an object that had all the appearances of a whale. It had the mammal's slow, lazy roll as it coursed along with just a few inches of skin showing above the water.

THE gigantic rhododendrons of yesteryear, which graced the large estates reminiscent of England's sprawling manors, are being replaced with neater, scaled-down evergreen shrubs. This new class of rhododendrons, with growth measured in inches rather than feet, is far better suited to the smaller suburban plot.
Economic repercussions of the summit debacle were open to wide speculation last week except for one fairly obvious effect, reduced Western trade with the Soviet Union.

IT was Kansas, circa 1929, in the heart of the asphalt jungle. Only the food was entirely real in the small roofless house with removable walls. Overhead, an American Gothic pendant, a leaded-glass chandelier, lighted the little family and their meal of roast veal, squash, cole slaw and pickled peaches.
Ponce de Leon Jr. THOUGHT on how to cut down on worry, thus remain young, by Robert Frost, who now is 86 -- "Don't try to keep up with, or keep track of, your great-great-grandchildren."
ALGIERS, May 21 -- French officials feel they have won the first round of an important political contest with Moslem nationalists and European extremists.
RABAT, Morocco, May 21 -- King Mohamed V sought today to form a "Government of National Union around the Throne."

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. commended President Eisenhower today for his "honest and persistent efforts" to ease world tension in the face of "hostility and provocation."
LINDRICK, England, May 21 -- America's women golfers stunned the British today with a display of power that restored the Curtis Cup to the United States after a four-year quest.

Rocket Race In August, 1957, the Russians announced they had successfully shot their first intercontinental ballistic missile -- the Soviet T-3 -- over the full course and into a designated target area. Fifteen months later the United States fired its first Atlas successfully at full range -- 6,325 miles.

To The Screen Editor: I have seen most of Tennessee Williams' work in movie form and I'm beginning to decide I'd better just read or, if possible, see the plays and forget about the movies. The prime reason? "Suddenly, Last Summer."

MOSCOW, May 21 -- Premier Khrushchev returned home today from Paris and Berlin. He was publicly silent on the momentous events of the week, but entertained a welcoming crowd with a report in pantomime.

A CLINIC for rose exhibitors will be held at 2 P.M. on Saturday in the rose garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. Exhibitors and prospective rose judges will be taught how to select the best blooms on the bush, how to condition and groom them for shows and how to transport and stage roses to best advantage.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21 -- The Asian-African bloc, which has been experiencing symptoms of growing pains, has embarked quietly on a self-improvement program.
New Yorkers were assured yesterday of a continued supply of fresh-water fish at the Fulton Street Market.
NURBURGRING, Germany, May 21 -- The rain is pouring down tonight and all is not nearly ready for tomorrow's 1,000-kilometer (620-mile) race -- a world championship event for sports cars.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra's programs for the 1960 Berkshire Festival include fourteen compositions never performed there before. Only four of the works are by contemporary composers, and nearly all are standard repertory pieces.

SCHOOL OF TOMORROW -- A group of parents and teachers in Weston, Mass., got together last year to study and suggest revisions in the education program for a new local high school. Result: national attention from educators, publication of the committee's "Accordion Plan," and a $100,000 grant to the Weston Public Schools by the Fund for the Advancement of Education for implementation of certain phases of the program.

IT would seem that as long as there have been cheese and cake there have been cheesecakes. Although the origin of this noble dessert has been lost in antiquity, it is known to have been popular among the ancient Greeks. In fact, we are told that the favorite revenge of Socrates' wife, Xanthippe, was to stamp on her husband's favorite dessert -- cheesecake -- when they had a row.

The problem of the small business that is displaced when its premises are demolished has been tackled by a building concern about to start a new office building. In the course of its development of Third Avenue properties, the Durst Organization has found that there are many business enterprises, notably hi the design and decorative arts fields, that have for years been regarded as indigenous to Third Avenue.

LUCREZIA BORI'S second career with the Metropolitan Opera, which occupied so much of her time, energy and thought since her retirement from singing in 1936, was a dedication to its sustenance and growth.

VISITORS to Japan can be overwhelmed with a multiplicity of handbooks on almost every Japanese art -- kabuki, the classic theatre; ikebana, flower arrangement; bonsai, miniature tree culture; and so on and on -- except on one of the most mysterious and intriguing Japanese cultural institutions of all, the geisha.
Al Stubbins, the lithe, red-haired coach of the New York American Soccer Club, has only two major concerns at the moment.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 21 (UPI) -- Young Dave Marr of Houston rallying with a cluster of birdies, fired his third successive 67 today and held the lead after the third round of the Sam Snead Golf Festival.

DINOSAUR NATIONAL MONUMENT, Utah -- The work of bringing to light fossil remains of the world's most monstrous primeval creatures, dinosaurs o various fantastic species that lived and died in this region 140,000,000 years ago, goes on here under conditions spectacularly viewable by the public.

MR. INGEMAR JOHANSSON, now ensconsed en famille at Grossinger's, the Catskills resort, sometimes seems the most exotic heavyweight champion of this century -- a sort of Swedish Gentleman Jim Corbett. While others live like caged animal in abandoned barns in the woods, Ingo acts on television and in the movies, keeps his secretary-fiancee hovering ornamentally about, and never, never goes to night clubs except when wearing a well-cut tuxedo.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 21 (UPI) -- Finnegan, part of a three-horse entry from the Neil S. McCarthy Stable, raced to victory by more than a length today in the $54,450 Los Angeles Handicap at Hollywood Park.

The annual competition among high school boys and girls for summertime employment has begun. Both the state and Federal Labor Departments issued advice last week to the young job seekers and their prospective employers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The Times reported on May 19 that the Czechoslovak Government, demanded an apology from Secretary of State Herter for a remark made recently to the effect that the Czechoslovak Communists in February, 1948, seized power in that country by force.

EARLY next month New York audiences will have their first opportunity to discover the Grand Kabuki, one of the world's great theatres. A large troupe of actors, musicians and stage assistants will re-create at the City Center the dramatic excitement that has fascinated Japanese audiences for over 350 years.

TOKYO, May 21 -- With flag-waving crowds shouting "Yankee, go home!" in front of the United States Embassy here today, doubts arose in Japanese circles concerning the political wisdom of President Eisenhower's proposed visit to Japan next month.
Mayor Wagner took a direct step yesterday to head off an actors' strike on the Broadway stage.
George Tyler Townley, a specialist in newspaper law, died of a heart attack yesterday while shopping in a hat store at 255 Park Avenue. His age was 58.

THE next few months will find Louis de Rochemont and his group of independent film-makers, now represented on Broadway by "Man on a String," as busy as any in the movie field, with no fewer than three features before the cameras here and abroad.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 21 -- Sightless players have indicated they can enjoy golf. During the national invitation blind tournament today at the Seawane Harbor course, they demonstrated that they receive satisfaction from what is generally considered a perplexing sport.

STOCKHOLM SWEDEN, Norway and Finland are the latest recruits to Europe's television network. Eurovision, as it is called, now embraces thirteen countries of the non-Communist world, stretching from the land of the midnight sun above the Arctic Circle to southern Sicily.

VENICE, Italy -- North Italy is a convenient jumping-off point for a cruise down the Dalmatian Coast to Yugoslavia and the isles of Greece. The extent of the trip depends solely on the time the traveler has available and the size of his purse.

A Japanese descendant of a line of Shinto priests that served the imperial household for a thousand years took over the pulpit of an Orthodox synagogue here yesterday and told why he had become a Jew.

NEW HAVEN, May 21 -- New Haven's population declined 15,520 to 148,923 in the last decade, according to initial census figures released here this week. The population of the New Haven metropolitan area roso 87,566 to 457,922.
SINGAPORE, May 21 -- A Western business man, deeply worried a year ago about Singapore's future, said today with a happy sign:
A floating lobby, enabling a hotel guest to be lifted to his room while still in his automobile, has been designed by a Dallas hotel man.

The commodity markets are becoming inured to diplomatic brinkmanship. While the debacle at the summit meeting in Paris last week firmed the "war" commodities, the advances were minor and short-lived. Volume was light.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- Two brothers whose disappearance prompted an all-night search here were discovered early today, tearful but unharmed, in the bathroom of an abandoned warehouse 100 yards from their home.

SUMMIT COLLAPSE VIEWS ON KHRUSHCHEV If there is any balm in the otherwise painful survey of the summit ruins it is in Premier Khrushchev's squandering of his own propaganda advantage. We are told that insofar as the European press was concerned, President Eisenhower went into the conference under a distinct handicap.

Wilfrid Van Nest Powelson, a retired naval officer and public utilities executive, died Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived at the University Club here.

EDIE, as readers of E.C. Spykman's "A Lemon and a Star" and "The Wild Angel" are unlikely to forget, is the fourth of the Cares children, those un- inhibited, nonconformist youngsters of the early Nineteen Hundreds.
NEWARK, May 21 -- The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark will expand its program of special education for blind children in September, Archbishop Thomas A. Boland announced today.

Premier Khrushchev's outbursts in Paris were a terrible warning, if any was needed, against the dangers inherent in face-to-face encounters between the world's most powerful men. The latest Soviet peace offensive, which got into full swing last September, when Mr. Khrushchev was President Eisenhower's guest at Camp David, has thus come to a disagreeable end. With the abandonment of the summit meeting, the cold war is back at the United Nations.
NEW ORLEANS, May 20 -- One of the most ambitious transport-improvements programs in any port city of the nation is progressing here.
LONDON, May 21 -- "When we are in a storm, we at least stand by our ship." Home Secretary R.A. Butler told a Conservative audience today.

THE title leads us to expect an atmosphere of evening melancholy and a musical poem that will render the correspondence among flowers diffusing their fragrance, toe playing of a violin, and the swirling motion of impressions received from nature.

House hunting can be an enjoyable or a frustrating experience, depending on the way in which a family goes about it. All too often, brokers contend, home seekers fail to buy a house they really like because of some insurmountable obstacle in their dealings with the seller -- an obstacle they themselves created.
PHILADELPHIA -- For the first time since the mid-Nineteen Twenties, river-boat pleasure cruises between Philadelphia and Baltimore will be revived this summer on a regularly scheduled basis.

DURING the past few years, as more and more professors and other academic persons have taken up writing fiction, we have been favored with a surprising number of novels concerned with academic life. And here is another, by a teacher and writer who has until now busied herself chiefly with literary criticism.
Murals cut into cement-based wall surfacings have been found to be an economical way to decorate lobbies, reception rooms and auditoriums in almost any kind of institutional or commercial structure.

PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- Neale Fraser of Australia, the world's top-ranked amateur, had a close call today but gained the quarter-finals of the French tennis tournament with a 6-1, 1-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-0 victory over Billy Knight of Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The political complexion of the House of Representatives for the next decade may be decided in this year's contests for state legislatures throughout the nation -- even more than in the Congressional elections themselves.

Chartering ocean-going yachts for a cruise to the Caribbean or even the Mediterranean has been no great trick. This has been possible since the days of steam yachts with crews of thirty or forty. All that was needed was a millionaire's checkbook and a good reliable yacht broker who could arrange to charter almost any- body's 300-foot pleasure ship.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (UPI) -- Jim Perry and Johnny Klippstein collaborated for a four-hitter today and the Cleveland Indians capitalized on Jerry Casale's wildness to hand the Boston Red Sox their seventh straight defeat, 6 -- 1.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent, Russell Baker, in reporting (edition of May 18) the views or statements of Senators Lyndon Johnson and Mike Mansfield on the failure of the recent effort to hold a summit meeting, describes these statements as reflecting the view that "to permit a great national debate at this point might strengthen Premier Khrushchev's indictment of the United States Government and further embarrass President Eisenhower."
The eleventh annual meeting of the National Council on Community Foundations was a useful public reminder of a rapidly growing section of American philanthropy.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 21 -- The Little Rock School Board plans to assign no more than twelve Negroes to formerly all-white high schools for the next school year, it was revealed today.
TREBINJE, Yugoslavia, May 12 -- Imagine a landscape filled with vast mountains of broken rock. Only a few scattered, scrubby plants lend a touch of green to the bleak and sterile expanse.
Two top officers on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth -- one on the bridge and the other in the engine room -- recalled last week that coal dust was a factor in their choice of ship jobs.

Mandatory retirement of workers at age 65 is still a part of many private pension plans, but in recent years a greater number of pension programs have incorporated provisions for deferment of retirement for employes at that age.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- One of the hottest behind-the-scenes battles the House of Representatives has experienced for many years is nearing a climax.

LAWNS are approaching their severest trial time -- summer. When temperatures are high the usual lawn grasses do not grow vigorously no matter how much stimulation is provided. Routine maintenance, plus repelling unexpected troubles is the course to follow.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 21 -- Drum beaters for the West took a look this week at the West's problems. They were the Governors of Western states, including Alaska and Hawaii, meeting here at the annual Western Governors Conference.

JEREZ DE LA FRONTERA, Spain -- This is the region made world famous by the Jerez wines -- "sherry" in English -- but the Jerezanos pride themselves also on the beauty of their women, their horses, their homes and their flowers.

THE local season is just about at an end. Maria Theresa still has one recital left in her series, on June 5, and Paul Swan has announced no termination for his weekly studio series. Salvatore Guida resumes his Monday one-man pantomimes tomorrow at the St. Marks Playhouse.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 21 -- Roosevelt Raceway, self-styled Taj Mahal of harness racing, closed its best spring meeting tonight in a burst of cash and glory.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 21 -- Senator Stuart Symington called tonight for a "whole new initiative in our foreign policy."

ANKARA, Turkey, May 21 (AP) -- Tough young cadets from the Turkish Army War College marched through the streets of Ahkara today in support of youth demonstrations against the Government of Premier Adnan Menderes.
An almost-capacity crowd of 17,988 left Madison Square Garden disappointed last night. Its hero, Antonino Rocca, failed to triumph in the feature event of the wrestling show.
Members of the patrons committee for the spring ball of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association have been announced. The event will be held Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L.I.

KINGS POINT, L.I., May 21 -- George Dempster and Jack Hildebrand knocked in three runs in the twelfth inning for an 8 -- 5 victory by Hofstra over the United States Merchant Marine Academy. Hofstra has won sixteen of nineteen games.
Eight hundred trout pitted themselves against men and boys yesterday in the Prometheus fountain at Rockefeller Plaza, The fish won.

CERTAIN areas of the world folk-song preserve have provided abundant hunting grounds for record makers in recent months. The season's catch from Israel, Spain, the Far East, the American' West and Eastern Europe has been especially heavy.
JIM THORPE, Pa. -- The Packer Mansion, a wisteria-covered, Colonial-style residence said to rank among the most unusual homes ever built in America, will be opened as a public museum on Memorial Day.

FOR thirty years, from around 1870 to 1900, local colorists dominated American fiction and virtually took over the short story. For the last thirty years the term "local color" has been a term of contempt; no body of writing is so out of fashion. This collection of stories, edited by Claude M. Simpson, Professor of English at Ohio State University, revives the odor of musty crinoline.

IF wishing can make it so, every man will be his own political expert this year. The wishing seems to come from the publishers and a host of hopeful authors who in the last six months have dumped a greater poundage of campaign biographies and primers of political science on the reading public than this reviewer can remember in any other election year.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 21 -- James and Barbara Bickham of Upper Sandusky, Ohio, won the Virginia Reel national sports-car rally today for the second year in a row.
ST. LOUIS, May 21 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer's bases-filled ninth-inning single for the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Cincinnati Reds, today, 6 -- 5.

NEWARK, May 21 -- The validity of a conspiracy indictment against five building contractors has been upheld by Superior Court Judge Alexander P. Waugh. The indictment concerned a $5,000,000 repair job for the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission.

SANTA FE, N.M., May 21 -- The vote of the Spanish-speaking citizens of New Mexico has been strong since Territorial days. Last week's primary election showed it to be still strong -- within the Democratic party, at least.

ATLANTA, May 18 -- The lines have been drawn in New Orleans for the first test of school desegregation in the Deep South. In a brief order to education officials there last Monday, Federal District Judge J. Skelly Wright called for an end to discrimination on the first grade level in September.

BOLOGNA, Italy, May 21 (AP) -- Italian riot policemen, swinging clubs, broke up a rally of 20,000 Communists and supporters tonight after a Communist .Parliamentary Deputy charged that Italy and the United States had committed aggression against the Soviet Union.
A United States Air Force station -- whose mission is strictly peaceful -- seems to be headed straight toward Siberia.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., May 21 -- Residents of the Middle Island Central School District, formed last year from six independent districts, will vote Tuesday on whether to authorize a proposed $5,100,000 building program.

Most spring gardens are at peak bloom, with rhododendrons, peonies, wistaria and azaleas forming brilliant color patterns. Rock gardens and wall plantings add gay accents, too. The horse chestnuts, mountain ash and English hawthorns display their blossoms on high.
BERLIN ARRANGEMENTS have been completed for a return appearance of the East German Berliner Ensemble at the Paris International Theatre Festival June 6-20.
Frank Lloyd Wright's Guggenheim Museum, widely ridiculed and frequently damned ever since it began to take shape on Fifth Avenue opposite Central Park, has won an architectural award.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 21 -- Pennsylvania set six Taylor Field records today in defeating Rutgers and Lehigh in a triangular track meet. Penn scored 91 points, Rutgers 49 1/2 and Lehigh 28 1/2.
DETROIT, May 21 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams is reported ready to support Senator John F. Kennedy for the Democratic nomination for President.
It will take many years for factory automation to supplant one tight group of hand craftsmen in this country.

THE second exhibition of "Photography in the Fine Arts, which opened last week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is twice as big as last year's, occupies about three times the space, and is much better displayed and illuminated.

HARTFORD, May 21 -- The Republican Progress Committee, which is preparing a set of principles for the 1960 election campaign in this state, has reached tentative agreement on a proposal for a large increase in state aid to education.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The rise of the huge supermarket food chains was charted today in a special Federal Trade Commission study.
Dr. Leo Kanner, one of the founders of child psychiatry in the United States, paused here last week to pick up an award and to talk briefly about progress in childhood mental illness.

THE recent great debate over the adequacy of American military forces centered on differing interpretations of secret intelligence estimates of Soviet military power. The downing of an American U-2 aircraft while on an espionage mission deep within the Soviet Union, has focused the public spotlight with unprecedented glare upon the secret intelligence system of the United States.
MEXICO CITY, May 21 -- Pressures were put on the Mexican Government this week to force the United States out of a planned missile-tracking site in the State of Sonora.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 21 -- Army clinched the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League title today, defeating Cornell, 8 -- 4. The victory was the eighth in a row for the cadets in league competition.

ANCHORANGE, Alaska, May 21 (AP) -- A daring helicopter-airplane relay lifted another injured climber from Mount McKinley today. Then a storm closed in, halting a massive rescue operation that had claimed two lives.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- John Thomas soared to a world outdoor high jump record today with a leap of 7 feet 1 3/4 inches.

HANOVER, N.H., May 21 -- Wisconsin's heavyweight crew, the Intercollegiate Rowing Association champion, defeated Dartmouth by a length and a half today on the Indians' two-mile Connecticut River course.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21 -- The first finisher in the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixth annual Six-Mile Reef distance race for the Edlu Trophy was still awaited tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The California winegrower is awaiting his 1960 crush -- of tourists. They will be exclaiming over his hillside or valley-floor vineyard, his Ivy-grown cellar, his aging vats and his bottling room.
HOBOKEN, N.J., May 21 -- Three nonagenarians returned to the scenes of their college days today at the Stevens Institute of Technology annual alumni reunion.

Monitors for TV The Federal Communications Commission is empowered to grant licenses to radio and television broadcasters on the basis of "public interest, convenience or necessity." Since the F.C.C. was set up in 1934 it has made little effort to supervise broadcast practices except through the remote possibility that it might refuse to renew a license.

BALTIMORE, May 21 -- Bally Ache could have run all day today. The sadly named colt, now owned by the Turfland syndicate, thrilled a crowd of 30,659 fans at Pimlico by taking the eighty-fourth running of the Preakness with ease.

Since home developers on Long Island ventured into the business of building homes on filled land on a large-scale basis a little more than two years ago, the production of suburban colonies on South Shore waterfront sites has become a significant segment of the metropolitan housing market.
WESTPORT, Conn., May 21 -- The chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission today assailed public apathy over a proposed $20,000,000 long-range capital improvement program for the town.

WHEN Philip Marson Joined the faculty of Boston Latin School in 1926, he thought it "the most widely respected public school in the nation." IT to a long-established literary axiom that poetry, in whatever language, defies translation. MORE than a mile of lobsters, if lined up claw to tail, will greet visitors to the fourteenth annual Seafoods Festival at Rockland, Me., Aug. 5-7. Three giant-sized lobster kettles will cook the ten tons of lobsters for what officials of Maine's Department of Sea and Shore Fisheries estimate will be a record crowd of more than 35,000 people.

The political and diplomatic debacle at the Paris summit meeting last week produced no violent repercussions in the stock market. The initial shock caused some nervousness among traders, but it was short-lived and stock prices scored gains on average four out of five days.

THE early-spring enthusiasm for vegetable growing often tapers off by late May. Many gardeners apparently are unaware that later plantings -- succession sowing -- will yield excellent crops well into the fall.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- Alert Russians flinched the moment the radio readings began last Monday night.

SANTA CLARA, Cuba, May 14 -- The full moon shone gently in the sky of the spring night as young men and girls in groups strolled round and round the monument in the center of Vidal Park.

EAST LANSING, Mich., May 21 -- With George Kerr, a senior from Jamaica, West Indies Federation, winning the 440 and 880 yard runs and anchoring the successful mile relay team, Illinois overwhelmed Michigan, 61 1/2 to 45, today and took its third straight Big Ten outdoor track and field title.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Pfc. Arthur Feurstein of New York and Capt. John A. Hudson of Chenault Air Force Base, La., finished in a tie for the Armed Forces chess championship today.

CANNES THE jury that will decide the winners of the thirteenth annual Cannes Film Festival is still out as this is being written, so the final determination of the merits of the films in competition -- twenty-nine features and twenty-eight shorts -- will have to be given consideration in these columns next week.

TRENTON, May 21 -- New Jersey and Connecticut have agreed on the reciprocal revocation of offenders' driving licenses. The agreement, which becomes effective June 1, provides that when a resident of one state has his license revoked in the other state he shall suffer an identical penalty in his home state.

Intensification of the cold war might make a difference in planning of production and distribution for the near period ahead, but most business men agreed that a drastic revision of schedules was not called for.

Colder Cold War The summit conference, nearly eighteen months in the making, died in three hours last week, even before it had formally begun. The great surprise was not that the summit proved futile; that had been expected.

CUTTING through the middle of the lives of the black people of South Africa is one of the swiftest and sharpest breaks in the history of any race. It is the crossing from the placid, Stone-Age existence of the tribal reserves to the bustling, twentieth-century cities of modern South Africa -- Johannesburg, Durban or Capetown.

JOE LOUIS dropped in for a visit the other day. He'd just returned from a high-level strategy conference with Floyd Patterson, whose burning ambition is to regain the heavyweight championship from Ingemar Johansson at the Polo Grounds on June 20. The large and amiable Louis dutifully reported that it could be done.

Capital Airlines, Inc., with a creditor ready to foreclose on all its planes, is having the most dramatic troubles of the generally troubled domestic airline industry. But the difference is only one of degree.

IN his first novel, "The Plantation," Ovid Pierce drew a true and affecting picture of North Carolina life in the region lying near Virginia between Warrenton and his native Weldon. "On a Lonesome Porch" tells how the remnant of a family returned to the same area to rehabilitate an almost deserted plantation in June and July, 1885.

An Egyptian oceanographer wants to part the waters of the Red Sea with an immense power dam. The project would be unique among existing hydroelectric stations not only in size but also in concept, for it would be driven by the sun.

Right at Home The twenty-five American financiers who have been conferring in Japan with her investment leaders no doubt have found themselves right at home. For in addition to the forest-clad mountains, the rural shrines, the lovely gardens and the picturesque resort-dotted seacoasts that for years have charmed visitors to the island country, these particular visitors have seen at first-hand an example of "the people's capitalism" even more rampant than in their own country.

Eisenhower, President of the United States, and Nikitia Sergeyevich Khrushchev, Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union.
