TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your May 18 editorial "No Teachers' Strike" properly states that "New York City will not attract the best teachers in sufficient numbers until it makes the best money offer, and its schools will not be the best until it gets the beat teachers."
The Celanese Corporation of America is broadening its plastics packaging product line through the purchase of Plastic Horizons, Inc. The transaction involved several million dollars in cash.
THE glorious improbability that is New York City is lovingly interpreted to children and their parents in a combination Baedeker, history book and fan magazine.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- Eleven labor leaders, including Harold J. Gibbons, executive vice president of the Teamsters Union, accepted an invitation today to visit the Soviet Union in July.
CHICAGO, May 22 -- When it comes to conventions Chicago is nonpartisan.
Week Ended May 20, 1960 The Canadian dollar continued weak in the foreign exchange market during the past week. British pound sterling recovered some of the loss incurred in early setbacks.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The Washington Senators beat the Chicago Wihte Sox twice today, 7 -- 5 and 3 -- 2, and shaved the American League champions' league lead to a half-game.
Drastic changes in college guidance and admission policies were predicted yesterday by the College Entrance Examination Board.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (UPI) -- Jim Hurtubise of Lennox, Calif., today smashed all qualifying records for the 500-mile Memorial Day auto race.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers put on their best hitting show of the season today and scored a double victory over the punchless Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 2 and 5 -- 2, running the Boston losing streak to nine.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Vice President Nixon moved today to stave off threatened fund cuts in foreign aid in the face of the summit conference collapse.

BERLIN, May 22 -- United States officials were still awaiting tonight a Soviet answer to their request for the return of an Air Force transport plane that strayed into East Germany Friday and for the release of the nine Americans aboard.
A total of 2,350 golfers will compete in fifty-four cities today in the first of two qualifying teats for the United States Open championship.

BERLIN, May 22 -- Giovanni Paisiello's "The Barber of Seville," the rage of Europe until Rossini came along with his "Barber of Seville," is a charming opera. History and Rossini's genius have been unkind to it, but tonight's new production at the Komische Oper in East Berlin provided a measure of restitution.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 22 -- A tidal wave hit a small village near the South Chilean port of Ancud today, and 130 persons were missing and presumed drowned.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The accelerating pace of the nation's space program is in danger of being curbed by unexpected costs and economy reins imposed by the Administration and Congress.
Out of the welter of statistic that have been produced in increasing quantity in recent years by public opinion research organizations, there has come a good deal of confusion.
THE Federal Communications Commission finally has entered the Nineteen Sixties; it has decided to watch television.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 22 -- Walter J. Tuohy, president of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, has asked for representation on the board of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for himself as well as three other Chesapeake and Ohio executives.
Cotton futures contracts moved into firmer ground last week, especially the distant months.

The sudden lessening of international tension in the German crisis has resulted in the postponement of an Edward R. Murrow television report, "Ber lin: End of the Line." It wa; to be televised on Friday from 10 to 11 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 22 (UPI) -- Bill Coffins won his second major golf tournament in three weeks today. With rounds of 68 and 69, he posted a thirteen-under-par 275 in the $20,000 Hot Springs open.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 22 -- Roman Catholics were told at masses in St. Aloysius Church today that the Young Men's Christian Association was basically a "Protestant religious organization" and that they were not allowed to join it or contribute to its fund drives.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. said today he ordered on his own initiative the world-wide alert test of United States armed forces that startled many citizens May 16.

Recent criticisms of Mayor Wagner's administration by former Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt are suspected of having a basically political purpose. This purpose is to bring pressure on the Mayor to lend his prestige and power to the reform faction's campaign to oust Carmine G. De Sapio as New York's Democratic national commiteeman.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 -- Sir Claude Corea, a. mild-mannered Ceylonese with a devotion to moderation, has become a pivotal figure in the angry conflict between the Soviet Union and the United States.

The New York State Harness Racing Commission has leased space for new main offices in the building at 801 Second Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-third Street, through Melvin D. Wolf and Richard Zausner of Julien J. Studley, Inc., brokers.
The recent slide in stock prices -- and the accompanying tumble of mutual fund assets -- has probably prompted some fund investors to look at their shares and ask: "What have you done for me lately?"

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he wanted charter revision, "as fast as possible." But he added that a new commission would have to be set up by the Legislature to review proposals by the Moore commission.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Securities and exchange Commission is running a test case on stock option plans. Middle South Utilities, Inc., wants to adopt a stock option plan for some of the officers and employes in the Middle South system.
The threat of war, heightened by the collapse of the summit conference in Paris last week, arouses "a most salutary fear" in many people, the Rev. Oscar V. Lynch said yesterday.
Nine new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
MONTAUK, L.I., May 21 -- Lobster suppliers on Long Island busy today preparing for that they expect to be one of their busiest seasons.

Lawberne Estates, Inc., has sold the five-story building containing forty-eight apartments and occupying a plot 105 by 100 feet at 3120 to 3130 Kingsbridge Avenue, northeast corner of Naples Terrace, the Bronx. The property was bought for cash over mortgages of $187,500 by the Benfren Realty Company.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 22 -- Martial-law restrictions in Ankara were tightened today in the wake of an anti-Government demonstration here yesterday by army cadets.
LONDON, May 22 -- The stock market reacted quietly and cautiously last week to the turbulence in Paris.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower heard a Gettysburg minister urge his congregation today to heed the President's own message of faith and encouragement to the West.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that fourteen policemen would receive medals for acts of conspicuous bravery during 1959.

Actors Equity has had "a few overtures", from producers interested in signing independent agreements with the union in order to avoid shutting down their attractions on June 1. In the event that Equity and the League of New York Theatres, which represents producers and theatre operators, fail to settle their differences over a new contract by May 31, the theatres will be closed.
The Elizabeth (N.J.) Juniors defeated the Eintracht Juniors, 2 -- 1, yesterday at Eintracht Oval, Astoria, Queens, to gain the final round of the United States Junior Soccer Challenge Cup.

YONKERS, May 22 -- John J. Kelley, the 29-year-old school teacher from Groton, Conn., won the National Amateur Athletic Union marathon for the fifth consecutive year today. He won with his strongest performance over the hills and flats of the Westchester County Road course.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 -- E.W. (Skip) Etchells of Old Greenwich, Conn., a former world champion in the class, won the Western Long Island Sound Star Fleet invitation spring series, which ended today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the advent of the jet plane the departure site of the International Airport at Idlewild, never an agreeable place, has become a torture chamber for an unfortunate minority.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your commendable opposition to the proposed Hartford pavilion in a Central Park setting where emphasis is on the elite reminds me of the support your newspaper gave some forty years ago to the opponents of a plan to convert the old Arsenal Building in the park into a museum of safety by virtue of a lease by the city to the Safety Institute of America.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights is investigating the Post Office practice of intercepting mail from abroad that it considers Communist or subversive.
ABOUT this time every year man begins to wonder why his ancestors ever left the trees How much easier it would be to sit on a branch that does not rust than to park under it in a chair that does.
The nation is "humbugging" itself if it says that the Soviet Union is wholly at fault for the international crisis, the minister of Riverside Church said yesterday.

Not long ago, a man called the Internal Revenue Service to say that a neighbor of his had bragged that he reported $10,000 of income last year but earned much more. The informant also ticked off apparent tax irregularities such as deductions taken for a personal car, "convention" trips with his family, and a posh apartment maintained for occasional use in New York City.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 -- Tia Maria, a Block Island-40 fiberglass yawl that Morton Engel of the Beach Point Yacht Club in Mamaroneck chartered only while awaiting delivery of his new boat, won the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixth annual Six-Mile Reef distance race today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- A Republican Senator called today for an accounting by the Eisenhower Administration of what went wrong in the chain of events prior to the summit conference collapse.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Caroline Kennedy is 2 years old. Her father is a United States Senator. Her mother reports that her first three words were "plane," "good-by" and "New Hampshire" and that she has learned more recently to say "Wisconsin" and "West Virginia."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The possibility of new Comnuinist moves in the Far East nominated informal discussions today among military advisers to the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization arriving here for their, first formal conference in the United States.
A CONCERT of liturgical works by Herman Berlinski, composer and faculty member of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, was presented last night at the Juilliard School.
Yonkers Raceway opens its spring meeting tonight with a resurfaced track and twice as many air-conditioners as last year.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

"Luisa Miller," the opera that Verdi fashioned from Schiller's "Kabale und Liebe," was performed at Town Hall by the Amato Opera Theatre Saturday evening. It may be supposed that this gave many in the audience their first opportunity to hear a live performance of the work.
A group of Negro leaders here was urged yesterday to seek couples in their community willing to adopt children.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Americans increased their burden of public and privatie debt by a record of $66,500,000,000 last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

THE Cookery, 21 University Place, at the corner of Eighth Street, is a charming place to eat on a bright spring day. The outdoor dining space on the sidewalk is shaded from the sun in the daytime, heated by infra-red rays on chilly evenings.

ONCE upon a time there was a man who lived for nineteen years in a cemetery. His name was Jonathan Rebeck and he had been a bankrupt pharmacist before he established secret residence in a dilapidated mausoleum in the Yorkchester Cemetery in the northern Bronx. Rebeck's quarters were far from luxurious and must have been a mite chilly in winter.
After three undefeated appearances in Canada, Hearts of Midlothian, the soccer champion of Scotland, came to Randalls Island yesterday to keep its date with Manchester United of England.
A call to bring social science research back to the world of action and policy was voiced yesterday by the director of the Twentieth Century Fund.
New York City's Puerto Rican community paid tribute yesterday to Dennis Chavez of New Mexico, the only United States Senator of Spanish ancestry.

The nation's leading biologists are preparing a complete revision of the methods of teaching biology in high schools in an effort to eliminate obsolete methods and modernize the entire teaching approach.
MILWAUKEE, May 22 (UPI) -- Juan Pizarro pitched a seven-hitter and Joe Adcock hit a two-run homer today to lead the Milwaukee Braves to a 3 -- 1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

Birthday for bifocals Spectacles are no longer among the exclusive insignia of age and infirmity. They have become fashionable accessories to mark the intellectual, the man of affairs, the business woman and, with certain decorative styles, they challenge exotic hats and hair-dos in sophistication.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 -- Visitors to the United Nations will stand little chance tomorrow of witnessing the Security Council debate over the U-2 plane incident.
Five Puerto Rican students appearing on the New York Times Youth Forum program yesterday indicated that they wanted Puerto Rico to remain associated with the United States.

The first shipment of crude rubber to be brought directly into a Great Lakes port by steamship has arrived at Toronto after a two-month voyage from Singapore, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 22 -- The Government of Premier Adrian Menderes ordered all colleges and universities in Turkey tonight to remain closed until next fall because of continuing anti-Government student demonstrations.
MOSCOW, May 22 -- The last traces of respect for President Eisenhower as a man, as a general and as President of the United States vanished today from the pages of the Soviet press.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Democratic Advisory Council denounced today the Eisenhower Administration's handling of the U-2 spy plane episode. A strongly worded statement said the Administration's foreign policy had "collapsed" during the first two weeks of this month.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The issue of separation of church and state loomed today is another possible obstacle to passage of a bill providing Federal aid for school construction.

Theatre achievements off Broadway were recognized last night with the fifth annual presentation of prizes, known as "Obies." They were distributed at the Village Gate, 185 Thompson Street, by the newspaper The Village voice.

NURBURGRING, Germany, May 22 -- Stirling Moss of Britain and Dan Gurney of California won the 1,000-kilometer (621-mile) race for sports cars today. Among the beaten was an Italian driver who lost a $15,000 Ferrari and nearly lost his life.

CLEVELAND, May 22 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles hammered Gary Bell for four runs in the first inning, including lackie Brandt's two-run homer, and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 7 -- 6, today in a gams limited to five innings by rain.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- Rex Harrison stepped briskly into the room, determined to put a good face on what he considers a necessary evil -- posing for publicity pictures.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- Daryl Spencer hit a home run off Bill Henry's first pitch in the ninth inning, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-4 victory today, but the Cincinnati Reds salvaged the second game of a double-header, 5 -- 3, behind Don Newcombe with Jim O'Toole's help in the ninth.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that a Youth Employment Service had been established to help the state fight juvenile delinquency. The new agency will try to help youths between 16 and 18 years old who are out of school and unemployed to find jobs in private business and industry.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 22 -- Amid cries of fraud and intimidation -- and the somewhat less familiar allegation of improper influence by witch doctors -- the national Congolese elections ended today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 22 -- The Duffy Stables' chestnut gelding, Navy Salute, from Armonk, N.Y., ridden by David T. Kelley, scored 9 point and won the open jumper championship at the Sands Point Horse Show today.
DR. LEO SZILARD, an atomic physicist who played a major role in the development of the first atomic bomb, is now a cancer patient at New York's Memorial Hospital.

WHAT are usually called opera workshops have come to occupy go large a place in the musical life of this country that it seems strange that New York has never harbored much in the way of a permanant professional enterprise of this type.
An early observance of Memorial Day began here yesterday under lowering skies as veterans' groups assembled to remember the nation's war dead.
TOKYO, May 22 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi is facing the most severe political crisis among many in his turbulent three years and three months in office.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- Soviet Embassy officials applied to the State Department tonight for permission to send the trawler Mosalsk to sea until her ailing crewman was well enough to reboard her.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 22 -- Heavy selling of Dutch international shares by American investors was a feature of the market this week, following failure of the Paris summit conference.

Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, said yesterday that he would ask public officials of the Great Lakes area to meet soon to discuss the picketing of ships flying so-called flags of convenience.

The United States will have to rely increasingly on its minority workers to meet the demand for experienced men in the labor market of the Nineteen Sixties, an official of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said here yesterday.
Bad weather canceled most of a large-scale Armed Forces Week demonstration at Coney Island yesterday, but the Army's Rangers saved the day with a vigorous demonstration of postgraduate violence.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 -- The expected slight pick-up in steel order volume has not materialized and steel makers look for a series of declines in operations. This trend may be affected temporarily toy summer seasonal factors.

Readers of this newspaper's business and financial section yesterday found its front page dominated by articles dealing with the impact of last week's dramatic events in Paris upon the national economy. This was a natural reflection of the intimate relationship between political developments on the international scene and the economic forces at work in the most varied areas of our national life.
Joseph Papp, redoubtable purveyor of free-Shakespeare-in-the-park and crusader for a noncommercial art theatre, has a proposal that he thinks can avert a strike by Actors Equity Association.

KANSAS CITY, May 22 -- With so many familiar faces on both clubs, the Yankees and the Athletics changed their signs before today's game at Municipal Stadium. Before long it was evident that the Athletics had not changed all their old habits, especially the one of losing consistently to the New Yorkers.
HAVANA, May 22 -- President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado flew to South America today to seek support for Cuba in her conflict with the United States and to spread the revolutionary gospel.
LOS ANGELES, May 22 -- The 1960 Democratic National Convention, whether or not it picks a winner in the Presidential contest, should help to put the party on its financial feet.

Steve Kuk, Blair Academy's football and baseball coach for eighteen years, will be at Cheshire (Conn.) School next season. The former Colgate University star will coach football at Cheshire to begin with. But his assignment to baseball is expected to follow.
CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Northern and Southern Presbyterians will join next fall in opening the first new Presbyterian college in more than fifty years.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 (AP) -- Hal Smith stroked a pinch single with the bases filled in the eleventh inning at rain-soaked Forbes Field today, giving the National League-leading Pittsburgh Pirates an 8-7 victory over second-place San Francisco.
RABAT, Morocco, May 22 -- The third day of the Moroccan Government crisis ended tonight with no new Cabinet in view and with a promise that King Mohamed V would address his people tomorrow by radio.
PARIS. In the absence of any International law defining outer space and territorial air limits, this week's Security Council debate on the U-2 incident must inevitably be loaded with paradox.

TALKEETNA, Alaska, May 22 (UPI) -- Two brothers, injured five days ago in a fall on Mount McKinley, staggered down the snow-swept slope of North America's tallest peak today to the safety of a rescue camp at the 10,000-foot level.
Following is the text of the recommendations issued by the State Investigation Commission as a result of its recent hearings on gambling:

A Norwegian crew rowed itself to a Viking victory yesterday. The eight-man team from the steamship Stavangerfjord captured permanently the Millard G. Gamble Trophy after rowing a 3,500-pound lifeboat over a mile-long course in the Narrows in 12 minutes 33 seconds.

TOKYO, May 22 -- A relatively obscure young athlete emerged from the shadow of a renowned stable-mate today to win the Emperor's Cup, symbolic of the championship in sumo wrestling, Japan's popular tradiional sport.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 22 -- The Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Convention unanimously commended Adlai E. Stevenson today "for his bold and forthright stand on the Administration's mishandling of the U-2 plane incident and consequent breakdown of the summit talks."
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 22 -- An Irish setter who qualified for best in show at Garden, City, L.I., yesterday but missed, came through handsomely for the award today.

MANY youngsters who do not go away to camp will be looking for summertime activities to add interest to the warm-weather months. In lieu of a cool lakeside camp many educators, teachers and parents from Schenectady to San Diego have devised interesting plans and projects to ward off the boredom of long summer days that the children will face.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Following is the text of "The Summit Failure in Perspective -- Where Do We Go From Here?" a statement by the Democratic Advisory Council, adopted today:

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Week-end selection of delegates increased the lead of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts for the Democratic Presidential nomination, giving him 329 1/2 votes, 43.3 per cent of the 761 needed.
STOCKHOLM, May 22 -- Form sheets were tossed aside here today as Sweden's ninth annual international trotting race was run off at unusual speed.

The march of African countries to political independence is being accompanied by a move toward business independence as well. In many cases, American companies are providing assistance and training to make this possible.
The stock market had a "breathing spell" yesterday. After recent gains, prices drifted down in slow trading. There was a modest loss on average.
Prices of the cotton futures on the New York Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) up to 7 points (35 cents a bale) off yesterday.

A change has been made in the sponsorship of "Invitation to a March." The Arthur Laurents play, in which Shelley Winters and Eileen Heckart will be seen, is to be put on by the Theatre Guild alone. Originally, Leland Hayward was to have been co-sponsor.
Governor Rockefeller called yesterday for a national debate, devoid of political partisanship, on the reasons for the failure of the summit conference at Paris.

The Soviet Union, in the first year of mass inoculations, has given poliomyelitis vaccine to a third of its population. The United States, by contrast, has inoculated about half its population in five years.

The results of Panama's Presidential election, belatedly announced two weeks after election day, marks the return to power after eleven years of the Liberal party. The President-elect, scheduled to take office in the fall, is 55-year-old Roberto F. Chiari. Whether he will be able to command a majority in the Assembly is not yet clear; indeed, he owes his election to a four-party coalition, known as the National Opposition Union.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- It is unreasonable to expect children to work hard at school if parents use period leasure to "twiddle the TV dial for twaddle," the head of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers sail today.
LONDON, May 23 -- The Government is planning a new deal for British lovers of horse racing, with bookmakers meeting the bill.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- The head of the American Legion declared today that his organization is neither a censor nor a watchdog of the movie industry.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Following is the text of a statement issued by Governor Rockefeller yesterday, urging the need for plain speaking on the failure of the summit conference last week:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Eisenhower will report to the nation Wednesday night on the failure of the summit conference and on his objectives in foreign Affairs for the remainder of his Administration.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Gardiner Symonds, a natural-gas company executive, said today that off-the-record approaches to members of the Federal Power Commission were accepted practice in the industry.

The Harbor View Farm's Quiz Star again proved that he not only likes to eat grass, but that he also likes to run on it. Yesterday at Aqueduct the 4-year-old colt outclassed a seven-horse field as he captured the $10,000 Port Washington Purse.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Soviet agent picked up in Massachusetts last fall while Premier Khrushchev was in the United States tried to persuade a young American to spy for the Soviet Union.
THE PRESIDENT At Gettysburg. White House announced President would report to country Wednesday on summit failure.
METUCHEN, N.J., May 23 -- Millburn High won the New Jersey high school golf team championship today at the Metuchen Golf Club.
Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan refused yesterday in Federal court to dismiss the indictment for income-tax evasion against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and denied a motion for acquittal.

The Business Mail Foundation, which is battling against increases in rates for third class mail, will experiment tomorrow with a limited newspaper advertising campaign aimed at promoting the mail as a public service rather than as a self-supporting government function.

CLEVELAND, May 23 -- A report made today to the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. declared that religious faith was playing an increasingly important role in the healing of the sick.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers blanked the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates, 1 -- 0, tonight on one hit. The loss cut the Pirates' lead over the second-place San Francisco Giants to one game.
SCRANTON, Pa., May 23 -- St. John's University of Brooklyn was selected today for the National Collegiate District baseball playoffs at Cooperstown, N.Y., next Friday and Saturday.

TOKYO, May 23 (AP) -- After the clash at Premier Kishi's house the students joined various Left-Wing groups in snake-dance demonstrations through the streets. Chanting anti-Government slogans and singing the Communist "Internationale," the youths were seeking dissolution of the Diet (Parliament) and the immediate resignation of Mr. Kishi and his pro-Western Cabinet.

The bulk of the estate of Lucrezia Bori, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, will eventually go to the Lucrezia Bori Foundation as a tribute to the people of the United States and elsewhere who made possible her singing career.

Prices of copper futures declined early yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. Profit taking reflected weakness in London. Later in the session prices rallied here on speculator buying. Dealer selling supplied the contracts.

Bloodshed in May Few plants in these temperate climes display their new vitality each spring with more persistence than rambler roses. With increasing hours of sunshine and a reasonable amount of moisture, the blackest and least lively looking stems among the survivors of winter put forth fresh shoots of green that race against each other toward the supporting bars of the trellis.
Steel production this week is scheduled to take its sharpest drop in more than a month.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- Minor tidal waves from the Chilean earthquake ripped through California harbors from San Diego to Crescent City today. Los Angeles-Long Beach Harbor suffered damage estimated at $500,000.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate's bipartisan foreign policy truce in the interest of national unity blew up in charges of "appeasement" and "irresponsibility" today.
HEAVEN may protect the working girl, but increased moral support from her husband has improved her disposition.

Publishers and editors from twelve foreign countries and the United States reported yesterday that the press of the non-Communist world was doing well in keeping the people informed in these days of crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Administration adopted a cautious attitude today on the question whether the failure of the summit conference would lead to a collapse of the atomic test-ban talks in Geneva.
LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Communist party published a bitter attack on Yugoslavia today in Kommunist, the party's ideological organ.
McKesson Robbins, Inc., attained record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31, according to preliminary results released for publication today by George Van Gorder, chairman.
Mineola, L.I., a place noted for horse races, had a banking race on its hands yesterday.

SPORTING life is picking up speed now that the warm weather is at hand. The great migration of cars choking the highways from Friday to Monday is symptomatic of New Yorkers' desires to soak up the sun at beaches, lakes and in suitably rural surroundings.

EFFORTS in Congress to compel the Department of Agriculture to curtail its wide use of pesticides because of their effects on fish and wildlife appear to have the executive branch of the Government lined upon one side and conservation organizations on the other.

One of the anomalies of the midtown real estate market is the existence of substantial, and often available, showroom space existing alongside an acute shortage of such space in so-called specialty buildings. In those buildings members of a particular industry are the only tenants with showroom facilities.

Stockholders of the Hammond Organ Company approved yesterday an increase in authorized shares from 2,000,000 to 4,000,000 shares, paving the way for the 100 per cent stock distribution voted by directors in February.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- Albert Goldman, former legal adviser to Leon Trotsky, died at cancer today in the Garden View Convalescent House. He was 63 years old.

Robert E. Kintner, president of the National Broadcasting Company, testified in Supreme Sourt here yesterday in a pretrial examination for a $750,000 libel suit against the network, the Jack Paar show, and others.

Mack Trucks announced yesterday the creation of a wholly owned subsidiary for the purpose of taking over all of the truck producer's installment credit operations. The new company will be known as Mack Financial Corporation.

The Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America outdoor track and field championships, to be held Friday and Saturday at Villanova, were the subject of most of the talk at the track writers' luncheon yesterday at Leone's restaurant.
PARIS, May 23 (AP) -- Neale Fraser, Australia's top tennis player, today was knocked out of the singles of the French International Tournament by an attack of leg cramps.
Forming professional sports leagues seems to be the latest fad for some entrepreneurs. Bowling has grown to a point where business men feel a league of inter-city rivalries would be just fine.

Diversa, Inc. Gerald C. Mann, chairman of Diversa, Inc., announced yesterday that Diversa had acquired 80 per cent of the stock of the Texas Electronic Products Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 23 (UPI) -- Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L.I., conquering rain and wind that helped send ten of his countrymen to the sidelines, led four drenched Yanks into the second round of the British amateur golf championship today on the Royal Portrush course.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 23 -- Four Rhode Island men were killed here this morning then their single-engined plane crashed on Orient Way, three blocks from the center of this residential community.
LONDON, May 23 -- Hugh Gaitskell declared today that advocates of Britain's nuclear disarmament and reliance on the United States for a nuclear deterrent were guilty of "the basest hypocrisy."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 23 (AP) -- The United States-operated Robert College was closed today by Istanbul's military commander after about 150 Turkish students had demonstrated without violence against Premier Adnan Menderes.
To see "The Ignorants Abroad," which opened at Theatre East last evening, is to wonder why it is not genuinely funny on the stage.

The United States and Russia faced each other in another dramatic confrontation yesterday when the Soviets attempted to arraign this country before the United Nations Security Council on charges of "aggressive" acts endangering world peace.
The city Department of Health will emphasize again that employes of school lunch-rooms must adhere to sanitary procedures as a result of food poisoning last week at Jamaica High School.

NURBURGRING, Germany, May 23 -- The first Grand Prix of the United States motor race was held at Sebring, Fla., last December. Only a few thousand persons attended and the thing was a flop financially, although it decided the drivers' world championship.
LISBON, Portugal, May 21 -- President Eisenhower's brief visit here has encouraged Portugal's leaders at a time of growing concern about developments in the Portuguese Empire.
At the New York Coliseum yesterday the "world's toughest" polyethylene bag broke, a self-conscious armadillo threw a tantrum and a small computer started writing a big book.

Consolidated net income of $1,061,166, or $1.86 a share, were reported yesterday by Seeman Brothers, Inc., for the eight months ended on Feb. 27, 1960, the end of the company's latest fiscal year. Sales were $83,306,056.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is heartening to secondary school counselors who toil at the opposite end of the same vineyard to read the thoughtful and helpful letter from Dean Albert I. Dickerson of Dartmouth College regarding Ivy League admissions.
Trustees of the New York Savings Bank have petitioned the State Banking Board for permission to advertise and pay 4 per cent interest on deposits, it was learned yesterday.

Frank Oliver Howard is a superman in flannels. Last year, when he was playing for Victoria in the Texas League, a ball he hit landed 650 feet from home plate. They said that was to be expected of a man who is 23 years old, 6 feet 7 inches, 245 pounds and wears a size 50 sports coat.

When President Eisenhower speaks to the American people tomorrow on the collapse of the summit conference he will be doing himself and the nation a disservice if he attempts to ignore or to gloss over the criticism arising out of the fiasco at Paris and especially out of his Administration's handling of the U-2 incident.
Mayor Wagner made some slight headway yesterday in his efforts to avert a strike of actors on Broadway.
Harry S. Truman concluded in 1956 that Adlai E. Stevenson would be an ineffectual President because of a lack of decisiveness.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The National Education Association's Defense Commission deplored today what it called the forced resignation last year of Dr. Herman L. Shibler as Superintendent of Schools in Indianapolis.

PARIS, May 23 (AP) -- The Paris-Presse L'Intransigeant, quoted Mr. Stevenson on May 14 as having said "the present situation in Berlin cannot be maintained" and "an agreement must be sought with Russian guarantees" to solve the problem.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of May 17 "Case Study of Automation" properly commends the Bureau of Labor Statistics for studying the impact of automation. Your conclusions, however, are more optimistic than is warranted by the Government agency's study of the experience of introducing electronic computers into the offices of twenty large companies.

THERE are moments in a woman's life when a car no longer means motion as much as the mood of an occasion. No bride wants to go to her wedding in a taxicab that smells of old cigars. A girl sailing to Europe for the first time wants to arrive at the pier in style.

"THE PLAY OF THE WEEK," which in several of its recent productions has not matched the level of its earlier brilliance, this week is commendably aspiring to richer fare. It is a revival, which started last night, of "Mary Stuart," with Eva LeGallienne as Elizabeth of England and Signe Hasso as Mary Queen of Scots.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 23 (AP) -- The toll from Chile's three-day ordeal of quakes and tidal waves soared tonight to 400 dead and 800 missing, a government spokesman reported. Thousands of others are injured and homeless.
Eight hundred dock workers returned yesterday to the American Export Lines piers in Hoboken, ending temporarily the wildcat strike that tied up three of the company's cargo ships last week.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board blocked temporarily today fare increases proposed by four major airlines and announced it would deal with higher passenger fares on an industry-wide basis.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The Army announced contract awards totaling $103,000,000 today, mostly for Diesel-powered tanks.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- An authority on aviation safety urged today that Congress act immediately to relieve the financial plight of the domestic airlines.

Golfers hoping to gain a place in the sun as well as in the United States Open championship went through a dismal trial yesterday. In three areas of the metropolitan district, rain, hail and mist surrounded players who sought forty-seven berths in the first of two qualifying tests for the game's big event.

Jose Gonzales of the Bronx and Guy Sumlin of Prichard, Ala., fought to a ten-round draw last night in the main event at St. Nicholas Arena, but the biggest excitement of the evening came with the announcement of the decision.

LONDON, May 23 -- The British are accustomed to being blamed when things go wrong for the West. But they objected vehemently today to attempts by some Americans to make Prime Minister Macmillan a scapegoat for the summit fiasco.
Two bear cubs, very friendly and very young, went on public display yesterday in the lion house at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn.

LONDON, May 23 -- Industrial share prices advanced briskly on the stock market here today, although profit-taking clipped some of the gains. Many leaders scored net rises of a shilling (14 cents) or more. There was no appreciable expansion in turnover.

Three hundred volunteers of Cancer Care of the National Cancer Foundation will attend a benefit garden patty and tour on June 7 at Beechwood, Scarborough, N.Y., home of Frank A. Vanderlip Jr., the organization's president.

COMPRESSED in the space of forty-five minutes was as extraordinary a sequence of track and field performances as this ancient sport ever has known. It happened at Michigan's Ann Arbor athletic plant during the Big Ten championships twenty-five years ago tomorrow, an episode of such matchless grandeur that it would be unforgivable to let it pass unnoticed.
The sixteenth annual spring book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association got off to a wet start yesterday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz used an old law for a new purpose yesterday in his campaign against slum landlords.

BONN, Germany, May, 23 -- Chancellor Adenauer warned today that the international situation had become more serious as a result of the collapse of the summit conference -- and, for a change, there was no politician who cared to challenge his gloomy analyses.
The Kayser-Roth Corporation plans to expand its line of hosiery, gloves and lingerie through the proposed acquisition of A. Stein Co.
WESTBURY, May 23 -- The start of Yonkers Raceway's sixty-ninth spring meeting was delayed forty-two minutes tonight by a strange parlay -- two days of rain and a balky grader.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 -- Following are the texts of draft resolutions presented to the Security Council today by the Soviet Union and by Argentina, Geylon, Ecuador and T:

A contract to purchase the west blockfront of Second Avenue between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets has been made by the Grace Institute, which plans to erect a school building on the site. The 20,000-square-foot property is being sold by the New York Life Insurance Company.
KANSAS CITY, May 23 -- A over the league the Yankees are respected for their power. But power had nothing to do with the ninth-inning run that beat the Athletics, 4 -- 3, today.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- John A. Barr, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., today reported "disappointing first quarter results" to his stockholders meeting but expressed hope for improvement barring a marked weakening in the economy.

IT would seem almost impossible that a most appealing and relatively abundant salad green could be available in New York and yet be relatively unknown. But there is one, and it leads to the suspicion that there may be more.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- The latest developments in textile machinery designed to enable American textile mills to meet the challenges of the Nineteen Sixties were put on display here today in Convention Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Mayors of St. Louis, Atlanta and Seattle told Congress today that a long-range, adequate urban renewal program, with reasonably permanent financing provisions, was greatly needed now.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon warned tonight against cuts in President Eisenhower's foreign-aid requests at a time when the Soviet Union was "threatening rocket attacks."

Following are the texts of addresses before yesterday's session of the United Nations Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times, except for the address by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, which was distributed in English by the Soviet delegation:
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The ten-year-old Government antitrust suit against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will go through one more round in the Supreme Court.
BUENOS AIRES, May 23 -- Argentina is believed to be ready to make a decisive break with an economic pattern of state ownership and controls.
Floyd Patterson doesn't want Ruby Goldstein to referee his return bout June 20 with Ingemar Johansson. That was the word yesterday from Joe Louis, who is Patterson's adviser.
Chile's earthquakes of the last few days are manifestations of a mysterious process that involves the entire perimeter of the Pacific Ocean.
ALGIERS, May 23 -- The French Army has opened a drive to get out the vote for the coming departmental elections.
TRENTON, May 23 -- The State Senate passed and sent to the Assembly tonight a bill that would provide for contracts between New Jersey and the railroads for the continuance of commuter services.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 24 -- Vicious tidal waves generated by the Chile earthquakes dealt a heavy toll of death and destruction the length of the Japanese islands without warning today.

EUROPE has given Zoltan Kemeny a whirlwind courtship, crowning him with highest critical honors in a very short time. The Hungarian-born artist lived in Paris from 1930 to 1942, then moved to Zurich, and invented the hybrid form of metal construction for which he has become famous only recently.

RABAT, Morocco, May 23 -- King Mohamed V resolved Morocco's four-day-old government crisis by announcing tonight that he would take over administrative power and exercise it through his son as "intermediary."

THE Eastern States contract bridge tournament at the Statier Hilton Hotel continued last night with forty-eight teams playing in the first of six sessions for the Reisinger Cup open team-of-four championship.
MANACAS, Cuba, May 14 -- The harsh realities of revolutionary priorities in refashioning Cuba's rural life are impeding the hopes of the peasants for a better lot.
Harold A. Felix, city Labor Commissioner, urged the head of a hospital workers union yesterday to temper his threats of a strike against ten voluntary hospitals.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 23 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion announced today that Adolf Eichmann, the S.S. colonel who headed the Gestapo's Jewish Section, was under arrest in Israel and would stand trial for his life.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- Mrs. Sarah McClendon, news correspondent for daily newspapers in Texas and New England, was elected president tonight of the American Newspaper Women's Club.
Two amateurs and a professional at La Jolla, Calif., set the pace for the nation's golfers yesterday in preliminary qualifying trials for the United States Open Golf Championship.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- The Soviet trawler Mosalsk weighed anchor at 8:55 A.M. today, emitted a whistle blast and slipped quietly out of Absecon Inlet, escorted by two Coast Guard vessels.
A British educator who left for home last night after five week as a lecturer in this country described the textbook yesterday as "one of the plagues" of the American system of higher education.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A group of mayors appeared here today to plead before Senate and House subcommittees for Federal aid for commutation and housing.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- With the return to Washington of United States officials who were in Paris when Soviet Premier Khrushchev stifled the embryo of the 1960 summit conference, it is possible to assemble the background of the Sunday, May 15, order for the limited "alert" of the American armed forces.
District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens began yesterday to investigate a rumor that a $10,000 campaign contribution had been offered in return for a judgeship in the Rockaways.
For the record, it was the end of an era yesterday: After twenty-six years' service, Robert Moses retired as Commissioner of Parks. But there never was a less retiring man than Mr. Moses.
Moscow's attack on Marshall Tito followed closely the lines of a Chinese Communist party denunciation of Yugoslavia.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 -- An appeal for calm from a Ceylonese diplomat and some cool air were used in the Security Council today in eftorts to control tempers and temperature.

THE Critic on the Hearth thought he would be both judge and jury when the case of "The Annotated Alice"* came to trial. But neither Alice nor the Mad Hatter nor the White Knight nor the White Rabbit nor the King and Queen of Hearts nor the Gryphon nor anyone else allowed him to dominate the disorderly proceedings.
Net income of Litton Industries, Inc., in the nine months ended on April 30 rose to $5,441,000 from $4,226,000 a year before, Charles B. Thornton, president and chairman, re-
The new frontiers of allergy research offer a great potential for progress against cancer, a specialist told the board of trustees of the Allergy Foundation of America yesterday.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman disclaimed yesterday any ulterior motive for his recent criticism of Mayor Wagner's administration.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- Two literal religious denominations, the American Unitarian Association and the Universalist Church of America, will merge in May, 1961, into the Unitarian Universalist Association.

After forty years of marching in one direction a turnabout can be a difficult maneuver. The Treasury discovered this late in April when it announced that the taxpayers would no longer be allowed the long-standing deduction for fees paid employment agencies for obtaining jobs for them.
CRUGERS, N.Y., May 23 -- A colonial mansion on a knoll overlooking the Hudson River here received preliminary endorsements of Cortlandt officials today for conversion to a Town Hall.
HONOLULU, May 23 (AP) -- A series of surging tidal waves killed at least twenty-seven persons in Hilo today, the police said. They reported twenty-six others were missing.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs continued on their zig-zag course today, declining by about one-third of the amount they had risen last Monday.
The Health Department's drive on rats in Manhattan buildings, begun last November, has reduced infestation and haled nearly 1,000 landlords into court, according to statistics made public yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, May 23 -- The use of acreage zoning by some suburbs as a way to exclude families of modest income was criticized today before the American Society of planning Officials as "ivy league socialism."

The Town School has chosen the Oct. 7 performance of "The Sleeping Beauty" by the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House for its autumn scholarship fund benefit. The school is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary this year.
HAVANA, May 23 -- The United States and British-owned petroleum refineries in Cuba are being required by Premier Fidel Castro's regime to refine Soviet crude oil, according to reliable sources.

Gregory Peter XV Cardinal Agagianian, Pro-Prefect of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith, said at Fordham University yesterday that the age of the Catholic mission activities "is very far from being over."
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 24 -- Fifteen hundred stone-throwing students clashed with 2,000 policemen yesterday outside the residence of Premier Nobusuke Kishi.
BERLIN, May 23 (AP) -- Soviet and East German sources promised today that there would be a statement on the nine Americans and the Air Force transport that strayed into East Germany Friday.

THE business fortunes of Henry Gardiner Symonds nave risen with a whoosh since he became head of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company in 1943. The genial, heavy-set man in short socks who testified yesterday before the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight directs a $1,500,000,000 industrial empire.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) -- George Altman's second home run of the season lifted the Chicago Cubs to a thirteenth-inning victory over Cincinnati tonight, 7 -- 6.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 23 (AP) -- Lee Thompson, State Agriculture Commissioner, today ordered Tropicana Products Inc. to suspend operations for thirty days beginning June 10. The company admitted adulterating orange juice with sugar syrup.
An expansion of more than 50 per cent was forecast last night for the next ten years of the printing industry in the New York area.
A new about-face in the Treasury bill market, the postponement of a major utility offering and a general quiet tone dominated trading in fixed-interest securities yesterday.

A new revised edition of Sir Stanley Unwin's "The Truth About a Publisher" will be issued June 13 by Macmillan. It is the autobiography of the present chairman of the board of directors of George Allen Unwin, Ltd., of London.

New York City's largest medical organization was unable to raise a quorum of 100 out of its 7,000 members yesterday to decide its policy on medical insurance for the aged. Only seventy-eight members were present.

American Crystal Sugar Co. The American Crystal Sugar Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a common share payable on June 30 to shareholders of record of June 15. This is five cents more than was disbursed in previous quarters.
DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- domestic auto makers apparently are going to build about 100,000 more cars in the une quarter than they had originally scheduled.
TOKYO, May 23 -- Jose Becerra of Mexico retained his world bantamweight title tonight with a split decision over Kenji Yonekura of Japan, the champion of the Orient.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs was honored yesterday as he relinquished his twenty-eight-year job as president of United Neighborhood Houses of New York. Frederick F. Greenman, senior partner in the law firm of Greenman, Shea Zinet, was elected to succeed him.

The International Harvester Company had record net sales of $693,804,000 in the six months ended April 30, compared with $598,543,000 a year earlier. Net income, however, dropped to $29,427,000 from $31,383,000 and sales and earnings for the quarter ended April 30 fell sharply.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Representatives of the striking International Longshoremen's Association and Chicago stevedoring concerns met with Federal mediators today.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The "Hour of Great Mysteries," which features Joseph N. Welch as host, is expected to present nine one-hour plays next season over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

The nonprofit voluntary hospitals of New York City perform a public service of such magnitude that all the people who benefit by the availability of this service, ready in the hour of need, bear a responsibility for helping to assure its continuation. These hospitals face two emergencies. One is financial, a continuing, indeed a perpetual, problem.

SINGAPORE, May 23 -- The Left-wing Government here is organizing a "work brigade," in an undeclared race with the Communist underground for recruits among Singapore's unemployed -- predominantly Chinese boys and girls.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- A late moderate rally in wheat future left that grain with the only plus signs today in a generally weak market on the Board of Trade.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 -- The United States and the Soviet Union exchanged charges of espionage today when the Security Council took up the U-2 plane incident.

A bacteriologist who has developed an anti-poliomyelitis vaccine that can be taken in a single dose orally yesterday recommended an annual booster shot with the Salk vaccine until his own was cleared for commercial distribution.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 24 -- Volcanic eruptions added to the massive devastation by earthquakes, tidal waves and land-slides in southern Chile today.
It was a whale of a moving day at Coney Island yesterday.

A rather ostentatious little construction shack, equipped with wall-to-wall carpeting, air conditioning and objets d'art, was quickly destroyed on East Sixty-ninth Street yesterday on orders from Mayor Wagner.
An attempt by a snipping conference to obtain Federal Maritime Board approval for a system of providing discounts to certain shippers was vigorously protested yesterday by Isbrandtsen Company, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Cuban Government has notified the United States of its intention to control the passage of Cuban nationals to and from the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 24 -- Foreign Minister Manzoor Qadir reported today that Pakistan had rejected a Soviet protest over the U-2 incident. The protest accused Pakistan of having provided facilities for foreign aircraft for the purpose of collecting military intelligence over the Soviet Union.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,098 persons were injured in 826 automobile accidents hi the city last week. In the same period last year the injured totaled 1,257.
Gov. LeRoy Collins of Florida, a Southern moderate on racial issues, was selected yesterday as the permanent chairman of this year's Democratic national convention.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., "sees no justification" in seeking a return to a Federal subsidy, Juan A. Trippe, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday at the Sheraton East Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 24 -- Following is the text of a letter to Secretary General Hammarskjold from Henry Cabot Lodge, United States representative, on Soviet spies apprehended in the United States:

COOKING for one may sound like a dismal prospect, but many live-aloners will agree that, on occasion, it can be a pleasant experience. The difficulty is in trying to find recipes suitable for single portions. It also is a problem to get variety and interest into a meal for one.
An imaginary interview with Lenin, Russian Communist leader, and Socrates, champion of democracy, will be televised June 5 over Channel 4.

Twenty-one more golfers successfully passed the first qualifying round for the 1960 United States Open golf championship yesterday, completing a field of 469 for the second round of eliminations on June 6 and 7.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- Space officials said today that a faulty battery would silence the Pioneer V satellite in about two weeks. This would end radio contact with the spacecraft at distances up to 50,000,000 or 100,000,000 miles.
Detroit, Mich., borrowed $19,561,000 in the bond market yesterday, to finance school construction and other public improvements.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 24 (AP) -- Bill Hartack, who rode Venetian Way to victory in the Kentucky Derby and fifth place in the Preakness, will ride Celtic Ash in the $100,000 added Jersey Derby Monday, Tom Barry announced today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 25 (AP) -- The people of this island nation, no strangers to natural disaster, today began the task of clearing debris left by giant tidal waves that battered the western Pacific basin from Japan to New Zealand.
Robert Moses became president yesterday of the 1964 New York World's Fair.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The National Congress of parents and teachers was told today that the greatest weakness in American education was the local autonomy of thousands of small school boards.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower appointed today the members of two emergency boards set up to investigate railroad labor disputes.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The monitoring unit planned for the broadcasting industry will not engage in censorship, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission pledged today.

MADISON, N.J., May 24 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill fired a 75, two under women's par, today and won the gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Garden State Women's Golf Association at the Braidburn Country Club.

A program to help less developed countries make rapid gains in commercial fishing and marine transportation while in creasing United States exports was opened yesterday by the Outboard Marine Corporation.
The State Investigation Commission charged yesterday the contractors who built the $18,000,000 clubhouse at Yonkers Raceway in 1958 had defrauded the taxpayers by inflating the construction costs.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, May 24 -- The International Wheat Council said today that world stocks of wheat were sufficient to meet the requirements of world trade at present levels for almost two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 -- Britain and France defended the United States today against the Soviet charge that flights of American reconnaissance planes over Soviet territory constituted "aggressive acts."
CAIRO, May 24 -- Almost all the Egyptian press was in effect nationalized today.
Further declines in deposits are causing New York City savings banks to look more kindly than some months ago toward a 4 per cent dividend rate, a sampling of industry opinion yesterday indicated.
Some of the best known games among slum landlords appeared in court uptown and downtown yesterday. They were here to answer charges of vioating housing and health laws.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You deserve our thanks for the front page notice you have given to the Stevenson proposal to utilize the immense potential of television for a great debate between the Presidential candidates on the vital public issues of our times.
The bare stone steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral will blossom with a colorful floral display on June 7, as it does each year for the annual Flower Mart given by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

American Photocopy equipment The American Photocopy Equipment Company increased the annual dividend rate yesterday to 75 cents a share from 60 cents and declared a third quarter dividend of 18 3/4 cents. The latter is payable on July 1 to holders of record of June 13.
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche told members of the world press yesterday that they could contribute toward world peace by printing more about the great work the United States was doing.
LONDON, May 24 -- The British Government will take an aloof and chilly attitude toward any future proposals for a summit conference by the Soviet Union, authoritative sources reported today.
Better than 8-1 in the betting, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Rare Rice, a 4-year-old son of Olympia, set a track record of 1:22 for seven furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday.
Jersey Central Power Light Company sold $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds yesterday at an interest cost of about 5.26 per cent.
Both sides in the Broadway labor war drew battle plans yesterday.

Problems of production, profits and prices were plaguing the nation's top steel executives yesterday as they prepared to leave their offices and mills for their annual two-day meeting that opens here this morning.

CHILDREN are doers at an exhibit, "Art Education for Every Child," at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. They can play a 'color piano" and create "chords" that are combinations of colors, make string designs on peg boards, and arrange objects on a miniature stage to observe the effects of light on form.
July cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 6 points yesterday but other months declined 3 to 11 points. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 24 -- Adolf Eichmann, captured S. S. colonel who headed the section for Jewish affairs in Hitler's Secret State Police, was spirited from his home in an undisclosed country by Israeli security agents.
TO people who think that the intellectual level of plays about Negroes should be raised: Your attention is directed to Lionel Abel's "The Pretender," which opened at the Cherry Lane last evening.

The intemperance of the Soviet position before the Security Council is of course an echo of Premier Khrushchev's studied insults in Paris.
