ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- A 31-year-old Government bulletin covering tax depreciation for machinery today was called "restrictive" and a deterrent to the technological and economic progress of the American textile industry.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) -- The air carrier industry has joined the barge line industry in opposing a proposed purchase by two railroads of the John I. Hay Company barge line.
DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, today sued the National Broadcasting Company, Jack Paar and Robert F. Kennedy for $2,500,000. He charged libel and slander.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight completed its inquiry on the Federal Power Commission today, as well as public hearings for this session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Eisenhower's report tomorrow night on the collapse of the summit conference will be beamed to the Russian people in seven languages. The White House challenged the Soviet leaders to let their people hear it.

"No High Ground," an account of the race to end World War II, the plans to make and drop the first atom bomb and the flight over Hiroshima, will be published June 6 by Harper. The book has been written by two journalists with the Washington bureau of the Cowles Publications -- Fletcher Knebel and Charles W. Bailey 2d, who had access to many documents, records and message files.
Francis P. Crosby, a 36-year-old stock promoter, and six other men were convicted in Federal Court last night of conspiring to use the mails to defraud the public in stock sales.

CLEVELAND, May 24 -- The 3,000,000-member United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A will be asked tomorrow to support student sit-in demonstrations in the South and to sanction civil disobedience wherever man-made laws on race violates the "law of God."

HAVANA, May 24 -- In words and cartoons, Cuba's revolutionary press has been depicting President Eisenhower as a sinister warmonger and warmly praising Premier Khrushchev for his attitude on the summit conference.

David S. Meister has purchased the five-story warehouse on plot 42 by 56 feet at 70-72 Laight Street, between Greenwich and Washington Streets, on the lower West Side. The Franklin Paper and Twine Corporation, the seller, occupies the property but is moving out.
Deems Taylor's "Peter Ibbetson" will be revived this summer at the sixth Empire State Music Festival. The festival also will present the American premiere of Leos Janacek's "Katia Kabanova."
The Greater New York Hospital Association yesterday commended Harold A. Felix, city Labor Commissioner, for his efforts to avert a strike at ten voluntary hospitals.

MIAMI BEACH, May 24 -- Many of the real estate developments that are being promoted as "retirement villages" fall far short of meeting the community and health care needs of elderly persons, the American Society of Planning Officials was told today.

WASHINGTON. May 24 (AP) -- The Department of Justice urged Congress today to authorize the Administration to sell the shares it holds in the General Aniline and Film Corporation, a multi-million dollar company seized as German property during World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Bucky Walters, the sinker-ball wizard of yester-year, dropped in for a visit with his old buddy, Bill Rigney. The graying manager of the Giants had been resting his intellect before tonight's game with the Phillies. But he brightened instantly in effervescent welcome.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 -- Soviet authorities are jamming some broadcasts of United States speeches in the Security Council but inexplicably letting others get through to Russian listeners.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Republicans assured bipartisan support today for a Senate inquiry into the failure of the summit conference.
YESTERDAY (May 24, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council; appointed members of two railroad labor dispute emergency boards.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Mahomed Ali C. Chagla, India's Ambassador to the United States, said today that his country had no intention of asking the United States Government for financial aid to carry out its ambitious program of birth control.
THE Eastern States contract bridge tournament continued last night with the start of the Commercial and Industrial team-of-four contest, in which fifty-three teams were entered.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate sustained today President Eisenhower's veto of the depressed-area bill.
BABYLON, L.I., May 24 -- A master plan for this South Shore village's growth over the next twenty years was presented here tonight to Mayor Gilbert C. Hanse.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- In a general retreat, the grain futures market posted several losses of about a cent a bushel again today. Trading was active.
The American merchant marine was invited yesterday at a ceremony marking National Maritime Day to help itself by helping the nation in a drive for more foreign trade.

The sensational young Mexican brothers, Pedro and Ricardo Rodriguez, have accepted invitations to drive in the Vanderbilt Cup Formula Junior race on the special Roosevelt Raceway mile-and-a-half course, winding up the June 18-19 program.

The proposal to erect an experimental ultra-high frequency television station in New York City promises to serve a variety of useful purposes; we hope that the Senate will endorse the action of the House in approving the necessary appropriation of $2,000,000.

ONE of the biggest attractions at the National Design Center these days is one of the smallest of its exhibits -- an oval object eight inches long, four inches wide and forty ounces in weight. The item is a new telephone, shown in the New York Telephone Company's display at the center, 415 East Fifty-third Street.

PARIS. The power balance is shifting significantly on both sides of the Iron Curtain. But, whereas in the West the change is more apparent than real, in the East it is more real than apparent, and it is also charged with danger.

A three-way financing plan, still far from complete, was outlined yesterday by the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The center announced that costs for its six-unit project had rocketed to $131,400,000, as against the $75,000,000 initial program in 1955.

DENVER, May 24 (AP) -- Gov. Stephen L.R. McNichols of Colorado said today that Premier Khrushchev virtually admitted the Soviet Union had espionage agents in the United States when he talked last July with visiting United States Governors.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris intimated yesterday that the Board of Estimate would soon hold a public hearing to decide whether to build a gift cafe in Central Park.
PARIS, May 24 -- The French reaction to American politics is about as funny as the American reaction to French politics, which is pretty funny.
James R. Hoffa's plan to seek national master agreements covering all general trucking has run into a snag here.
"I think it's too bad that Off Broadway is being used as the poor man's Broadway, or, as a stepping stone for the big time," H.B. Lutz bemoaned the other day.
CHICAGO, May 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson questioned Harry S. Truman's "memory of events" today.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 24 -- The Soviet Army agreed today to release at once nine Americans and the C-47 Air Force transport forced down Friday by Soviet fighter planes in East Germany.
Princess Edward de Lobkowicz of 164 East Seventy-second Street, widow of Prince de Lobkowicz, was married yesterday morning to Erwin Hoy Watts of this city and Watch Hill, R.I.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 24 -- Five players tied for gross honors in the annual spring tournament of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association, which was marred by two torrential rainstorms at Wykagyl C.C. today.

Welcomed yesterday by Mayor Wagner at City Hall, the Kilmarnock team of Scotland and Bayern-Munchen of West Germany will meet tonight at the Polo Grounds in the opening game of the new International Soccer League.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your generous news coverage and, more especially, your trenchant editorials on the highly controversial proposal to establish a new restaurant-pavilion in Central Park have made a real contribution to the cause of right government.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Vinton Chapin, United States Ambassador to Luxembourg, will probably be named Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, high State Department sources indicated here tonight.
TOKYO, May 24 -- Ambassador Douglas MacArthur 2d rebuffed a Socialist leader's suggestion today that President Eisenhower postpone his visit to Japan.
EVERYONE looks for the winning combination -- none more zealously than Stella loat, the designer of separates whose eye for fashion is as prese as the pleats her skirts are famous for.
MIAMI, May 24 -- Farris Bryant, a lawyer, pledged to maintain segregation and to champion states' rights, won Florida's Democratic run-off primary for Governor tonight.
An unconventional airline terminal in which the airplane is brought to the passenger instead of the passenger to the airplane was opened yesterday at New York International Airport.
JERSEY CITY, May 24 -- Jersey City has lost nearly 27,000 of its population in the last ten years, according to preliminary census figures released today.
United States Government obligations drifted down in price in inactive trading yesterday, but the prime-rated obligations of business corporations and local governments ended the day firm.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Air Force placed a 5,000 pound experimental satellite in orbit today in its program to devise space sentries that would give a speedy warning of surprise missile attacks.
ALBANY, May 24 -- Republican leaders will urge Governor Rockefeller tomorrow to reconsider his decision not to attend the Republican national convention in Chicago in July.

CINCINNATI, May 24 -- The nation's air would be cleaner if more autos had only six cylinders and if car owners kept their engines tuned up. This was the substance of reports delivered today before the flfty-third annual meeting of the Air Pollution Control Association.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Federal Trade Commission raised a novel question today in citing S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., Union Square, New York City, for making false pricing and savings, claims to promote its merchandise.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Administration today asked Congress for a one-year renewal of the "temporary" ceiling on the national debt at a level of $293,000,000,000.
PARIS, May 24 -- Representatives of twenty states met here today to discuss a draft convention for a new economic organization to coordinate growth and development assistance.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 24 -- Three golfers with contrasting backgrounds shared the lead in the Long Island open championship with two-under-par 70's today.
Audrey Hepburn and Sir Laurence Olivier, two of the most sought - after Academy Award winners on the motion-picture scene, were announced yesterday for leading roles in major film productions.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 24 (UPI) -- Tim Holland of Rockville Centre, L.I, playing in the form that carried him to the 1958 semi-finals, reached the third round of the British amateur golf championship today, along with five other Americans.

A DESIGNER who always has something to say and a splendid way of saying at, Jacques Tiffeau (pronounced Teefoe) has done it again. The Tiffeau Busch all collection shown yesterday sparkled with the inventiveness and fine workmanship that makes this young Frenchman a contender for the coveted Coty award.

THE complexities of television journalism were illustrated yesterday when the National Broadcasting Company received upward of 200 complaints over its Monday evening summary of the remarks of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and Henry Cabot Lodge, United States delegate to the United Nations.

YONKERS, May 24 (UPI) -- Season's Go, owned by Frank Cavallaro of East Syracuse, N.Y., and driven by Robert Cherrix, closed with a burst of speed in the stretch to overtake the odds-on favorite, Stormy Dream, and went on to win by a head in the Westchester Pace, the feature tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

MEXICO CITY, May 24 -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee, a world-wide organization dealing with cotton problems of import and export countries throughout the world opened its nineteenth annual plenary conference here today.

MICHELANGELO, the second of the five sons of an obscure Florentine named Lodovico di Lionardo Buonarroti Simoni, died on Feb. 18, 1564. He was 89 years old, perhaps the greatest artistic genius the world has known, an ugly, proud, cantankerous little man who lived all his life in the center of an emotional storm.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 24 -- Voters today approved the Board of Education's controversial plan to replace the Lincoln Elementary School with a $1,300,000 building. The vote was 7,992 to 2,330, or better than 3 to 1.
NEWARK, May 24 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called today for an early summit meeting between the next President and Premier Khrushchev.

The State of California decided yesterday not to go through with the sale of $50,000,000 of veterans' aid bonds, the state's second offering since the policy of marketing $100,000,000 of bonds four times a year was supplanted by one calling for more frequent flotations of smaller amount.

CHICAGO, May 24. (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles made the most of seven singles and thirteen walks tonight to beat the Chicago White Sox, 6 -- 1. The victory enabled the visitors to gain the American League lead.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since we are still picking up the pieces of the summit fiasco and the impression seems to be gaining that the whole sorry mesa probably means a stepping-up of the cold war, it may be well to try to be a little more objective in evaluating the situation.

Once upon a time the meat packers, their profits shaved as thin as a slice of boarding-house bacon, explained that they were using every part of the animal except the pig's squeal. Now it seems that the once profit-rich oil industry is thinking along the same lines.

The Reading Company announced yesterday the election of E. (Earnest) Paul Gangewere as president effective on June 1 to succeed Joseph A. Fisher, 65, who is retiring after nearly thirty-nine years of service with the carrier.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Capital Airlines, which is plagued by financial troubles, shook up its management today in an attempt at a solution. James B. Franklin stepped down as senior vice president for operations to return to flight duty as a cantain.
How effective is truth in advertising?
CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) -- Jim Grant yielded only four hits in pitching the Cleveland Indians to a 7-2 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Sam Jones reversed his 1960 pitching pattern tonight and put the Giants back on top of the National League standings. Going into action here, San Francisco's gangling, toothpick-chewing right-hander hadn't lost in four decisions at home, but hadn't won in three on the road.
LONDON, May 24 -- Stock prices rose today on a wide front. Turnover remained light, however, and, with stocks in short supply, prices were sensitive to even modest demand.
A West Side slum building that was a target of state authorities on Monday has been thoroughly inspected by the city over the last three years, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
BONN, Germany, May 24 -- Chancellor Adenauer disclosed today some of the tactics that he said the Western Allies had jointly prepared for summit negotiations on Germany and Berlin.

The spot May copper position was strong yesterday but the other months on the Commodity Exchange of New York were weak. Short covering prior to last trading day, tomorrow firmed the spot month. Liquidation or the forward months was termed a technical reaction to recent strength.

The boards of the McCrory-McLellan Stores Corporation, B.T.L. Corporation and United Stores Corporation approved a merger agreement yesterday on the basis of an exchange of stock. Their combination into one company to be named the McCrory Corporation would make it the fourth largest in the variety chain field.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., May 24 -- Joe Louis, the former heavyweight champion, took a look today at the present champion, Ingemar Johansson, and made a slight change in his prediction that Johansson would lose the title next month.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate sustained today President Eisenhower's veto of the detiressed-area's bill, a two-third majority being required to override:

MONTAUK POINT, the center of the great fishing grounds on this strip of the coast, is now feeling the strain of the sprinter who has been crouching too long on his mark. It is that way every year at this time.

DETROIT, May 24 -- Along with 34,489 others, the Yankee dropped into Briggs Stadium tonight and found none of the Tigers sitting around feeling sorry for themselves. Rocky Colavito was not brooding, Al Kaline was not pouting and Jimmie Dykes was not fretting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 -- Following are excerpts from speeches at the United Nations Security Council session today:
PITTSBURGH, May 24 (AP) -- With Johnny Podres, a lefthander, pitching an eight-hitter, the Los Angeles Dodgers downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 2, tonight.

The Hogan Faximile Corporation, a subsidiary of the TELautograph Corporation, manufacturer of high-speed facsimiles, computer-readout and event-recorder equipment, has leased a floor containing 22,000 square feet of space in 633 Greenwich Street, corner of Mortem Street Ralph H. Daniel, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., was the broker.
THE keynote speaker at the forthcoming Democratic National Convention has forged his political career with an eloquent tongue and "a blazing smile."

After a series of fits and starts yesterday the stock market eked out a gain. Advances in several individual issues -- notably in electronics -- were much more striking than the market's performance as a whole, although the tempo of trading accelerated markedly from Monday's sluggishness.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Senate Antimonopoly Subcommittee deadlocked today over the terms of a bill to clamp tough new Federal controls on professional baseball. The subcommittee referred the issue to its parent body, the Senate Judiciary Committee.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

KANSAS CITY, May 24 (UPI) -- The Athletics pinned a tenth straight defeat on the Boston Red Sox tonight. Home runs by Jerry Lumpe and Marv Throneberry and the eight-hit pitching of Bud Daley helped Kansas City win, 6-2.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 -- The United States told the United Nations today that Soviet spies working in this country had sought information on everything from atomic submarines to army training manuals.

The Stanford Research Institute, a major applied research organization with headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., has leased office space in the new Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue, at Forty-seventh Street. The lease was negotiated by Paul Bresalier of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building.

CLEVELAND, May 25 (UPI) -- Tito Francona's eleventh inning single gave the Cleveland Indians a 1-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight and ended a pitching duel between Jim Perry and Bill Fischer.

"YOU damned sociologists, you historians who want to get it all nice and fine on paper; you haven't learned how much in this world is determined by non-syllogistic reasoning, or without conscious exploration of a problem with a view to reaching a logical conclusion."
PARIS, May 25 -- European economists formed a working party today to reconcile conflicting views on the organization of a new "Atlantic" economic body by mid-summer.
Trading broadened in United States Government securities yesterday to the largest scale since before the Paris summit talks.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- A charge that railroads had tried to persuade opposing witnesses not to appear was made today at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on the proposed purchase of the John I. Hay Company barge line by two railroads.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 26 -- Singing, flag-waving marchers protesting against the new United States-Japanese security treaty began parading through Tokyo this morning in preparation for mass rallies in front of the Diet (Parliament) building during the afternoon.

David A. Stretch, chairman of Northeast Airlines, Inc., has acquired a 600-share holding of the company's common stock, it was disclosed yesterday by the American Stock Exchange in its latest report on so-called insider trading.

The spot May copper position rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York but the other months declined. Short-covering prior to last trading day, today, steadied the spot contract. Continued liquidation, influenced by declines in London prices, weakened the forward months.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The Vice President's reaction to Adlai Stevenson's criticism of Administration action regarding the recent summit conference raises several questions as to what can be demanded in the name of "national unity."

ART FLICK was singing a nice sweet tenor yesterday about dry-fly fishing on the Schoharie, while Doug Bury carried the crooning bass in a song about the Beaverkill. They were in close harmony, though separated by a range of hills, and so was nearly everybody else who fishes for trout in lower New York State.
Persistent rumors that Roy T. Hurley would resign as head of the $250,000,000 Curtiss-Wright Corporation became a reality yesterday.

It is not too difficult, I think to state the classic goals and purposes of American society We probably cannot improve on the definition of our Founding Fathers: "to form a more pefect Union, establish justice, insure domestic tranquillity, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare and secure the blessings of liberty."

DURING New York's long, comfortable spring, salesmen in air-conditioning departments of stores have been cooling their heels and the potential buyers of the appliances have been living in a fool's paradise.

PARIS, May 25 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay, America's hope in the men's singles of the French international tennis championships, was ousted in the quarter-finals today by Orlando Sirola of Italy, 6 -- 3,15 -- 13, 6 -- 4.

Springtime for Court-Dwellers Let us now, in this springtime month, contemplate the New York courtyard. Neither the areaway nor the airshaft, but the more commodious and occasionally pleasing courtyard hidden hereabouts.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

THE man whose name led most of the rest on the list of the "blackest Nazis" looked across the ruins of Berlin one day fifteen years ago. He turned to a companion, defiance on his effeminate features, and swore that if the war were lost he would commit suicide.

The formation of the Metropolitan Chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame was announced yesterday by Chester J. LaRoche, the president of the foundation, following a meeting at the Hotel Astor.

Eight persons received minor injuries and more than 4,000 passengers were delayed yesterday when the sudden stop of an IND A express train halted traffic to Brooklyn on the Eighth Avenue line south of West Fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower today designated sections of Hawaii recently hit by tidal waves as a major disaster area eligible for Federal relief funds.

Electrie power production rose in the week ended last Saturday to 13,468,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 13,350,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the prior week. A year ago the output was 12,931,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States promise again today to meet its military commitments in Southeast Asia as military leaders of that area noted the danger of Chinese-Communist aggression.
Committees have been formed to arrange the thirteenth annual Blue Grass Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Sept 29. The New York Travelers Aid Society will benefit from the event.

The Grand Union Company has opened nine food markets since March 1, an average of about one every ten days, Thomas C. Butler, president, told stockholders. He spoke at the annual meeting in the Garden State Plaza shopping center at Paramus, N.J.

THE United States has nearly 500 bridge leagues in which teams of four to twelve players, representing business and manufacturing concerns, play a series of matches each year just as baseball and basketball and football teams do.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I, May 25 -- The John Drew Theatre at Guild Hall, this resort community's cultural center, will offer drama, opera, films and jazz this summer instead of only its customary summer-stock plays.

YONKERS, May 25 -- A Party Night at the Yonkers Raceway, annual scholarship benefit of the Cornell Women's Club of Westchester, will take place on the evening of June 8. Dinner will be served in the Good Time Room before the races.

FOR the housewife who cannot find a thing in her cupboard to set her table, there are thirty new French Limoges china patterns at Baccarat Porthault, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street The dinnerware, designed by Ceralene Raynaud, is available for the first time in this country.
A band of Greenwich Villagers won a second skirmish yesterday in their battle to stay in their homes on Macdougal Street.

WHEN five young artists founded the Tanager Gallery in1952 it was a significant innovation: a cooperative gallery that served, as they said, as an extension of the artist's studio. Since then, of course, such extensions have become legion and the public is all too familiar with the "studio" atmosphere that has been adopted for effect even in uptown galleries.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- Though the long-term outlook for the domestic textile industry is for growth of production during the next decade, a decline of relatively short duration is imminent, and profitable operations will largely depend on good market research and sound marketing, it was predicted today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Governor Rockefeller's announcement that he would accept a draft for the Republican Presidential nomination drew as much surprise in Washington today as a foregone conclusion.

Eric Portman admires two new plays and is willing to test them on the summer circuit. The British star said yesterday he did not consider it too much of a burden to appear as George Washington to Howard Fast's "The Crossing" and as a modern-political leader in Ugo Betti's "The Burnt Flower-Bed."

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 25 -- Despite the oil industry's twin problems of overcapacity and overproduction, stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) at their annual meeting here today received an optimistic report on the operations of the company and the outlook for the oil industry, especially over the long period.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 25 (UPI) -- A state tax auditor testified today that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had made no complaint and "promptly paid "additional taxes when informed that he had not listed $7,000 in taxable income for 1956.
Eleven leaders in science, education, industry and government will receive honorary degrees at Columbia University commencement exercises next Wednesday.

A drop of 1,931,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 214,128,000 barrels, compared with 216,059,000 a week earlier and 203,610,000, a year before.

A collection of thirteen recent unrehearsed television talks by Bertrand Russell will be published June 27 by World and will be titled "Bertrand Russell Speaks His Mind." Among the subjects covered by the Nobel Prize-winning philosopher are philosophy, education, religion, nationalism, birth control, the H-bomb, happiness, war and the future of mankind.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Rising food prices lifted the Consumer Price Index to another record in April -- four-tenths of 1 per cent higher than March and almost 2 per cent higher than a year ago.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 25 -- Bob Stuhler, the operator of a pitch-and-putt course and driving range in Flatbush, became the Long Island open golf champion today.

The city of Montreal, Canada, borrowed $28,000,000 here yesterday by the sale of debentures due in 1980. The securities were sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. and Dominion Securities Corporation.
Virgil Thomson, the composer and critic said yesterday that modern music sounded more and more alike, but that the standardization had some virtue.
DETROIT, May 25 -- The Yankees were notably unimpressive in losing, 9-3, to Frank Lary and the Tigers before 12,363 at Briggs Stadium today.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 25 -- Adlai E. Stevenson was named a delegate-at-large to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles today.

The General Acceptance Corporation, Allentown, Pa., announced yesterday the acquisition of the Consumer Finance Corporation of America, which operates twenty-eight offices in seven Western states. The offices have outstanding installment and industrial loan receivables of more than $6,500,000.
The Broadway labor dispute took a turn late yesterday afternoon that appeared to dispel hope for a contract settlement by Tuesday midnight.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System has settled an antitrust suit brought against it by a television station in Tacoma, Wash., that lost its C.B.S. affiliation.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 25 (AP) -- Harriet Robinson's Dream On won the $19,350 Rancocas Stakes at Garden State Park today. It was the third straight victory for Dream On, the choice of the 20,473 fans.
LONDON, May 25 -- Stock prices continued their upswing today as small investors entered the market for high-class equities.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Clint Courtney's pinch single in the ninth inning drove in the run that enabled the league-leading Baltimore Orioles to gain a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.
A $96,000,000 middle-income cooperative apartment development for 5,206 families will be built over the New York Central's Mott Haven yards in the Bronx. Work is expected to start this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Henry Jaffe, a small, effervescent man with ideas, that seem quixotic here, buckled on his esthetic armor today amid the Chinese art and ivory chess sets of his apartment, to tilt with the drab television world at Westerns, private eyes, and situation comedies.
State Controller Arthur Levit staked a claim yesterday to an anonymous treasure -- the dividends received by stock brokers or securities dealers as owners of record for unknown investors.
RYE, N.Y., May 25 -- Robert Moses said yesterday the rail-roads need more help from the Government and public, but "above all they need less whining: and crying and more brains and self-reliance."
PUERTO MONTT, Chile, May 25 -- This is the central city of the region of Chile that spawned the earth shocks felt throughout the Pacific world. It is a shambles.

NORFOLK, Va., May 25 -- The aircraft carrier Saratoga and the West German ore carrier Bernd Leonhardt were in collision thirty-five miles off the North Carolina coast north-east of Cape Hatteras at midnight last night.
Staten Island's tax revolt appeared yesterday to have won at least $10,000,000 in cuts in real estate valuations for 10,000 to 12,000 property owners.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold promised a prompt decision yesterday on a move by the state to enjoin the owners of a West Side slum tenement 'from "continued and repeated violations of law."
LONDON, May 25 -- From now on, it may not be just love and romance when a British boy and girl peer deeply into each other's, eyes in St. Jame's Park. They may be taking a personalality reading.
LONDON, May 25 -- A Church of England booklet on race relations said today that there could be no objection "in principle" to inter-racial marriages.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The plea of officials of the New York City High School Teachers Association for breaking the single salary schedule for teachers (issue May 23) should not go unchallenged, lest its specious plausibility influence some uninformed laymen.

Two lawyers were indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiracy and subornation of perjury in their handling of negligence cases. One of them also was accused of the larceny of $10,757 from insurance companies.
HAVANA, May 25 -- The Government will open a radio campaign in Latin America this week for the declared purposes of defending the Cuban revolution and attacking "Yankee imperialism."
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that he was not committed to Carmine G. De Sapio's re-election as Democratic national committeeman for New York.
NEW CANAAN, May 23 -- Duke, a seventy-pound German shepherd who attacked a woman here on April 7, was banished, today by the Board of Selectmen.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 25 (UPI) -- The management of International Railways of Central America bowed today to demands by dissident stockholders that a special meeting be convened later this year in an effort to end the ten-year strife between the two factions.
YESTERDAY (May 25, I960) SECURITY COUNCIL Heard statements on Soviet complaint.

ST. LOUIS. May 25 (AP) -- George Crowe tonight set a major league record of eleven pinch home runs by blasting the first pitch from Don McMahon onto the pavilion roof. The drive gave the Cardinals a 5-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

Top steel executives insisted yesterday that better times for their industry were just around the corner but they couldn't agree where the corner was situated. Some of the steel leaders interviewed yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute said the present downturn would end in two weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Eisenhower's nominations for places on four regulatory agencies are in trouble in the Senate. The odds now appear to be against action before Congress adjourns.

ONE of the most humorous commentaries ever printed on the subject of a green vegetable appeared in The New Yorker magazine thirty-two years ago.
Mediation efforts will resume today in the four-month-old strike of Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards.

Net sales of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the three months ended on April 30 were $64,633,000, against $63,346,000 for the three months ended on May 2, 1959, it was reported yesterday by Robert J. McKim, chairman of the big store chain.
The cotton futures market opened unchanged to 2 points lower than on Tuesday, held in a narrow range and closed 5 points off to 6 up yesterday. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Since the U-2 spy plane incident, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been taking detailed cloud pictures over the Soviet Union without Soviet objections and without the advance approval of the State Department.
ALBANY, May 25 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he would accept a draft for the Republican nomination for President.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Eisenhower said tonight that in spite of the collapse of the summit conference "we must continue businesslike dealing with the Soviet leaders."
BOSTON, May 25 (AP) -- A noted educator expressed alarm today over "an almost arrogant intellectualism" that he said is tending to make American art, literature, music and science anemic and sterile.

Contractors at two raceways cheated the state by billing for construction equipment listed as in use at both tracks at the same time, the State Investigation Commission charged yesterday. The asserted profiteering took place in 1957 and 1958 at Yonkers and Monticello Raceways, about seventy miles apart.
The International Federation of Newspaper Publishers adopted resolutions yesterday deploring new restrictions on press freedoms in recent months.

NEW YORK, New York, is not necessarily a wonderful town," Garson Kanin seemed to be saying a decade ago when his play "The Rat Race" arrived on Broadway. The situation has not changed appreciably in his movie adaptation, which opened at the Capitol yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- Ecuador and Ceylon appealed to the Soviet Union today not to press to a vote its resolution condemning flights of United States aircraft over Soviet territory.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended May 18;
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The United States announced today that it would fly two complete Army field hospitals and 420 persons to the aid of Chile's disaster victims.

Construction of a three-story over-the-water garage, to be combined with a marina and seaplane base, on the East River at Twenty-third Street will be started within thirty to forty-five days. Completion is expected by next spring.
CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds whipped the Chicago Cubs, 7-1, tonight in a game called because of rain with two out in the eighth inning.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 25 -- Fighting broke out in the Grand National Assembly today. Fifteen members were wounded, by flying desk tops and broken chairs before the fighting between Deputies of Premier Adnan Menderes Democratic party and of the Opposition People's Republican party was halted.

It is none too soon for the impressive array of forces that successfully backed the Erwin-Lounsberry court reorganization resolution last spring to reform their lines and develop their plans to do the same, with added strength, at the next legislative session. Fortunately this will be easier to do in some ways than it was before.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The secretary of the Cabinet carried the Administration's opposition to Federal aid to education into an enemy camp today.
KANSAS CITY, May 25 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox snapped a ten-game losing streak today by defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 5-3.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Seven electrical manufacturers land eleven of their officials were charged today with rigging bids on $1,750,000,000 in sales to the Government and other big customers.
"One-world" Christians from around the earth gathered in the Riverside Church last night to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the Protestant ecumenical movement.
Sometimes advertisers have to live dangerously.

The quickening tempo of this campaign year is signaled by the Democrats' announcement that they have chosen the permanent chairman and the keynote speaker for their Los Angeles convention. Now all they have to do is agree on a Presidential nominee.

CLEVELAND, May 25 -- The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. agreed overwhelmingly today that "peaceable and orderly" civil disobedience was justified when laws favoring racial discrimination '"violate the law of God."
The writer of the following letter is chairman of the Committee on International Policy of the National Planning Association.
A public relations concern of which Joe Louis is vice president has signed a $287,000 contract to promote tourist travel in Cuba among U.S. Negroes.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 (AP) -- The five-hit pitching of Don Drysdale and home runs by Frank Howard, John Roseboro and Don Demeter gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 5-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to stand fast against scheduled reductions in corporation and excise taxes for another year.
Law students who know the letter of the law but cannot handle the letters of the alphabet will have an extra course to take this fall at the New York Law School. It is simply catalogued "English."
After drifting down most of the session, stocks finned in late trading yesterday, but the upturn came too late to avert a modest decline on average.
Nearly 9,000 airline employes who work at New York International and La Guardia Airports and live in Queens are pouring millions of dollars yearly into retail businesses near the fields.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 25 -- Western diplomats friendly to Israel have questioned her jurisdiction in the case of Adolf Eichmann. Israeli officials, however, rejected their objections today.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 25 -- The United States transport forced down in East Germany by Soviet fighters five days ago flew safely out to West Germany tonight.

If parks are for the benefit of the people, then it would seem that the people ought to have some way to be heard on how their parks are to be used. This question arises in connection with the Huntington Hartford gift of a pavilion restaurant for the southeast corner of Central Park, a gift accepted by Robert Moses before he resigned as Park Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The House of Representatives opened debate today on a $975,000,000 school construction bill, with the Administration apparently dangling a compromise before supporters of the bill.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The Giants were floundering badly in late July a year ago, in need of some sort of lift before they disintegrated completely. So they made the desperation move. They called up Willie McCovey, the tall and sleepy-eyed first baseman they had discarded in spring training. Willie had been pounding the Pacific Coast League apart with his hitting, a .372 average and twenty-nine homers. He was worth another look.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd called on officials of the Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy today "to purge their ranks ruthlessly" of what he described as Communits infiltration.

Job opportunities for the poorly educated are shrinking and will shrink faster during the next decade, the United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics warned yesterday. He urged youths to complete their high-school education.

Even though the Berlin problem now seems insoluble, there has been "one comforting aspect of the summit breakdown," Prof. Philip C. Jessup of Columbia asserted yesterday at the third annual forum sponsored by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

The ambitions of the recently formed International Maritime Workers Union were jolted yesterday by a permanent injunction prohibiting the union from "interfering" with the operations of two Liberian-flag vessels owned by the Incres Steamship Company, Ltd.
The New York British Merchant Navy Club marked the completion of the payment of its debt yesterday with the symbolic burning of a $35,000 mortgage.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The State Department said today that a New York wholesaler had shipped United States flags to Haiti for use a dress goods, curtains and scrub rags. It said it was trying to halt the practice.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A House transcript showed today that a private group headed by Edward Litchfield, Chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh, was getting $1,113,000 in United States funds for giving management advice to Iran.

YONKERS, May 25 -- Billy Haughton gained his first victory in a dozen Yonkers starts tonight with Scotch Tape, a brown 6-year-old horse, who scored by a length from Honick Rainbow, driven by Stanley Dancer.
The machine tool industry, whose operations give a clue well in advance to what business and industry are thinking and planning, reported yesterday a sharp drop in net new orders.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and associated underwriters are offering to the public a block of 317,500 common shares of J.W. Mays, Inc., a metropolitan New York area department store. The shares are priced at $22.875 a share.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 -- Archie Moore, the foxy grandpa of boxing, stopped Willi Besmanoff, a German fighter now living in Milwaukee, in the tenth round of their scheduled ten-round fight tonight.

Dr. Weraer Punk Is considered by most German Shepherd fanciers to be the world's leading, authority on the breed. Since 1922, when he first became active with the shepherd, he has judged on three continents and at hundreds of shows.
Television writers on the West Coast rejected yesterday new offer to end their strike, now in the fourth month.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The Giants remained at the top of the National League standing by trimming the hapless Phillies for the second night in a row at Connie Mack Stadium tonight. The score was 5-1. Rain cut the game to eight innings.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 25 (AP) -- Bob Cochran became the only American to make the last sixteen in the British amateur golf championship today. The 47-year-old St. Louis business man decisively defeated two men half his age.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 25 -- Chinese Communist expansion poses a more immediate threat to Laos than it does to Taiwan or the Chinese Nationalist islands, Quemoy and Matsu, the commanding officer of the United States forces here said today.

Webb Knapp, Inc., has signed a contract to buy the nine-story building at 3 East Fifty-seventh Street from St. Luke's Hospital, which acquired the property two years ago from the Stuyvesant estate. The Stouffer chain has a restaurant in the first floor and basement on a lease that expires Aug. 31, 1961.
LOS ANGELES, May 25 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California went a-polling today in downtown Los Angeles to determine whom rank-and-file Democrats want for their Presidential nominee.
A violent ideological dispute between the Soviet Union and Communist China was raging on the eve of the summit meeting and may now have been resolved in favor of Peiping.

Iron Rail's owner, Donald Ford of Louisville, put up a supplementary $500 so that his colt could compete in the eighty-fourth running of the $37,050 Juvenile at Aqueduct yesterday. That investment was even more rewarding than buying a bluechip stock and waiting for the long pull.
DALLAS, Tex., May 25 (AP) -- Federal District Judge T. Whitfield Davidson told the Dallas School Board today to revise its grade-by-grade integration plan or offer an alternate.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 25 -- Three heavy quakes and fresh tidal waves spread panic in southern Chile today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, May 24 -- Joseph Kasavubu and Patrice Lumumba, rival Nationalist leaders, have won seats easily in the national chamber that will choose the first independent Congo Government.

American Photocopy Equipment The American Photocopy Equipment has increased its annual dividend rate to 75 cents a share from 60 cents a share with the declaration of a third quarter dividend of 18 3/4 cents a share.
YESTERDAY (May 25, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Vice President Nixon; made radio-TV speech on summit failure.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 25 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders today rescinded the sale of 93,530,000 of general improvement bonds made March 30 to the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York and associates.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- The first significant rallies of the week pushed corn and soybean futures well ahead today whlla moat grains traded steady to easier.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Sixty-eight defendants, mostly college students, arrested in rioting at the City Hall here nearly two weeks ago, pleaded not guilty today to misdemeanor charges and demanded a jury trial.

MEXICO CITY, May 25 -- Brazil served notice to the cotton-producing world here today that there was a tendency not officially enforced but being officially encouraged in his country to cut back coffee production and replant with cotton.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- Excerpts from a statement by Jerzy Michalowski of Poland in the Security Council yesterday, as published by The New York Times, did not present the complete thought he expressed in his final paragraphs.
On the greensward made famous by such baseball greats as John McGraw, Christy Mathewson and Mel Ott, the International Soccer League made its debut last night.
Maritime labor groups are seeking a new Congressional definition for "an American vessel."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 26 -- An Israeli Government announcement today said that Adolf Eichmarm, the recently captured Nazi accused of the murder of 6.000,000 Jews, seems tranquil and reconciled to his fate.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Vice President Nixon is "looking into" spending in the West Virginia primary election with a campaign eye on Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

As stunning as the victory it scored in the sprint championships May 14 over a Harvard eight that was looked upon as invincible, the Cornell varsity crew that amazed the rowing world on Lake Quinsigamond has been demoted in favor of the junior varsity.

Dublin's third International Theatre Festival will start to roll Sept. 12 and continue through Sept. 25. Nine theatres, with a combined seating capacity of 9,000, have been reserved for more than a dozen offerings. In contrast with the inflated cost of tickets to Broadway shows, a top price, equivalent to $1.75, will prevail.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House of Representatives approved a four-year, $1,300,000,000 school-construction bill today, but wrote in an anti-segregation provision that might doom it.

First-quarter sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. were the highest for any similar period in the history of the nation's largest merchandising company. Earnings were up from the level of a year ago, the report disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 26 -- Adlai E. Stevenson gave President Eisenhower qualified praise today for his address last night on the collapse of the summit conference.
THREE young couples stumped decorating experts at a meeting this week with their total ignorance of what a decorator is and does.
ONE of television's rarest and most rewarding offerings --a program of fine music -- was presented in an outstanding telecast over Channel 2 last night.
CHICAGO. May 26 (AP) -- A few butcher hogs sold at an 11 months high today although the market generally was steady to 50 cents off, with most of the setback on weights over 230 Ibs.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A plan to make the Secretary of State the President's chief officer for all national security affairs -- including overseas military matters -- was offered to the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri charged today that a "complacent" President Eisenhower had subjected the country to "humiliating disaster" in Paris by permitting a steady deterioration of national purpose and military power.

Gabriel Co. Directors of the Gabriel Company took no action yesterday on the common stock dividend normally declared in June. The latest dividend, 15 cents a share, was paid in December. Last February the company announced a policy of omitting cash dividends and considering the payment of a stock dividend at the end of the year, which would have a direct relation to earnings.
The nation's commercial banking system is able to boast net free reserves for the first time in sixteen months.
Sales of Sperry Rand Corporation in the fiscal year ended on March 31 exceeded the billion-dollar mark for the first time. Earnings climbed 35 per cent to the highest level in the company's history.
Actors Equity, its contract negotiations with theatre producers still deadlocked on major issues, said last night that if planned to close a hit Broadway musical Wednesday night.

For years the aim among oil men has been for more reserves Seeking new potential fields became big business, with the oil company giants vying with one another and offering high prices for exploratory rights.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26 -- The Soviet Union asserted tonight that continuance of the United States policy "of military espionage and sabotage against the Soviet Union, a policy of dangerous provocations," would place mankind "on the brink of war."
THREE groups of professionals are responsible for the esthetic discord in today's home -- architects, interior decorators and furniture designers.
RYE, N.Y., May 26 -- A benefit garden party and tea will be given here June 9 by Mrs. Edward Eagan at her home, Happy Harbor. The Westchester Symphony Orchestra will be the beneficiary of the fete.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Relations between the United States and Soviet Union may be strained on the political level, but they are enthusiastic and expanding on the level of science, medicine, the arts and agriculture.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Three national fraternities have been ordered to end racial and religious discrimination in selecting members for their chapters at the University of Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Since its launching on April 1, the weather-watching satellite, Tiros 1, has taken and relayed back more than 20,000 photographs of the earth's cloud cover.

LONDON, May 26 -- Profit-taking after the stock market's recent strong recovery caused small falls among many of the industrial leaders today. The undertone was described as firm, however, and the strength of second-line industrials still left most of the major lists with more rises than falls.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Following a pattern that has become familiar, the Giants completed a three-game sweep over the Phillies tonight.

ONE DAY during this long holiday week-end may well be the occasion for the first picnic of the season. By picnic is meant one of those portable lunches for which all the foods are prepared at home and packed in a basket or a box.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 26 -- The pilot of the United States Air Force C-47, that was forced to land in East Germany last week gave an account today of stern Soviet measures to force down the intruder, followed by friendly treatment during five days of internment.
The State Investigation Commission said yesterday that a sample re-evaluation of $1,000,000 worth of state-financed construction at Yonkers Raceway showed overcharges totaling more than $400,000.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Government's new machinery for establishing radiation safety standards, was criticized today as too flexible and confusing.
EXPECTANT mothers should travel as fast as their conditions permit to Bonwit Teller. One glance at the maternity clothes is as improving as a day's dose of vitamins and nine glasses of milk.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., May 26 -- J. Bud Geoghegan of Crestmont helped Mrs. Irving Sofferman celebrate her birthday today by shooting a three--under-par 68 as they won the team honors in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association's first pro-lady tournament of the season at Cedar Hill.
Trouble has developed with the Midas missile-detecting satellite, the Air Force announced last night.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP) -- The Bryant Heating Special -- a race car that "lost" its driver -- will run in the 500-mile Memorial Day race with a new man behind the wheel.
JERSEY CITY, May 26 -- Ireland's entry, Glenavon of Lurgan (County Down), proved too powerful for the New York Americans tonight as the new International Soccer League moved into Roosevelt Stadium.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 26 (AP) -- Bob Cochran, a 47-year-old paper salesman from St. Louis and the last American in the field, swept through two matches today in brilliant fashion and reached the semi-finals of the British amateur golf championship.

DETROIT, May 26 -- New-car sales for the May 11-20 period were 5.2 per cent above the level in the first ten days of the month, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The mid-May level was the best for the period since 1955.
A SHARP illustration of what happens when landowners rapidly increase the posting of trout waters comes from the experience of Dr. Arnold M. Geiger of 30 East Fortieth Street.
The American electronics industry can meet "any fundamental threat to its existence from foreign competition," without increased tariff protection, John L. Burns declared yesterday.
Anthony (Tony Cheese) Marchitto, a leader of New Jersey longshoremen, was jailed today for refusing to answer questions of the Waterfront Commission.
After a lively start, profit-taking hit a wide segment of the stock market in late trading yesterday. Prices declined slightly on average.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26 -- The Soviet Union was expected tonight to veto a four-power resolution calling for the resumption of negotiations among the Great Powers unless its amendments were accepted by the Security Council.
The Automobile Club of New York yesterday urged motorists planning a long holiday week-end or a vacation trip later to cheek on new bottlenecks and detours.
Kuatter Field, its 600 seats perpetually reserved for minor lawbreakers, was dedicated yesterday at the City Workhouse on Hart Island, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, May. 26 -- Presidential politics appears to be the newest drag on the progress of minimum-wage legislation in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The White House said today that the aerial photograph of a California Navy base that President Eisenhower showed his television, audience last night was taken from a U-2 plane, the type that was shot down in the Soviet Union.

The 209 Sullivan Corporation has purchased the four-story building containing thirty-seven apartments and six stores at 209 Sullivan Place, corner of Rogers Avenue, in Brooklyn. The seller was Max B. Cane. The property, 100 by 100 feet, is near Ebbets Field, which is now being improved with apartments.
A three-for-one split of J.C. Penney Company stock was approved by stockholders of the big retail chain at the annual meeting yesterday. The action had been proposed by the directors on Jan. 7.
LONDON, May 26 -- Jaguar Cars, Ltd., announced tonight that it would soon purchase the Daimler Company, one of Britain's oldest automobile manufacturers. The production of Daimlers will continue.

A sharp shift in the financing requirements of the Federal Government is expected to cut substantially the total requisitions of funds from United States financial markets this year, Dr. Roy M. Reierson, vice president and chief economist of the Bankers Trust Company, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Anthony Krchmarek, identified by House investigators as chairman of the Communist party in Ohio, refused today to say whether he had passed information to the Czechoslovak Embassy in Washington.

A MELANCHOLY young man is wandering around Philadelphia these days in a sad-eyed and heavy-hearted trance. He has been stricken by a disease that has baffled the most learned doctors. He has been nipped by the love bug. The passage of time has brought relief to the stricken on occasion but not always.
The Official Catholic Directory reported figures yesterday showing an increase of 47 per cent in the number of Roman Catholics in the United States in the last decade.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 26 (AP) -- The death toll for south Chile's six-day-old siege of earthquakes, tidal waves, avalanches and volcanic eruptions may reach 5,000, Government sources said today.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 26 -- Governor Rockefeller paid a flying visit to the Nixon country of the Niagara Frontier here today and praised the Vice President -- for being a fine Vice President.
A $1,000,000 advertising and promotion push will be started this summer on behalf of a new cosmetic -- Miss Mantan.
ALBANY, May 26 -- The power of the state to exclude the Communist party from its unemployment insurance program was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

The Memorial Day week-end begins tonight with more than 1,000,000 automobiles expected to clog highways in the metropolitan area, and airlines, railroads and buses operating at capacity.

Short covering in the spot May copper position, which went off the board at noon yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York, raised the contract to new highs for the move. The other near positions closed with slight gains and the deferred months were down.
BRIDGE tournament news in New York City will be complicated today by the fact that two major tournaments will be going on at the same time.
The Public Service Commission granted permission yesterday to the United Parcel Service, Inc., of this city to operate a state-wide parcel delivery service for industrial and commercial companies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26 -- Reports received erratically by Chileans in New York on damage to the country's economy from earthquakes and tidal waves convey one reassuring note. The bulk of the heavy industry remains outside the zone of greatest impact, well to the north of Concepcion.

May, with only twelve days, is nonetheless a month of twenty weeks -- according to a doctrinaire calendar at the Department of Commerce and Public Events. The calendar recognizes only days and weeks for which Mayor Wagner issues proclamations.

PARIS, May 26 -- At the corner of the Avenue des Champs-Elysees and the Rue de Presbourg something new has been added. It is a genuine soda-fountain American drug store -- "Drugstore des Champs-Elysees" -- where a man can buy a bag of popcorn, or get his shoes stoned or, if he wants to insult the French, order a hamburger and a Coca-Cola.

The rat-bitten, chilblained slum dweller, discomfited by cold radiators and broker plumbing, annoyed by loose plaster and nervous about shaky fire escapes, is often haunted by the fear of losing his home through eviction or harassment by his landlord.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Continued cuts in steel production last week produced marked declines in freight and truck loadings, both industries reported today.

PARIS, May 26 (UPI) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., upset the Wimbledon champion, Maria Esther Bueno of Brazil, 6-3, 6-2, today and gained the women's final of the French international tennis championships at Roland Garros Stadium.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 26 (UPI) -- Bob Buhl held the St. Louis Cardinals scoreless except for Bob Nieman's fifth-inning home run tonight and pitched the Milwaukee Braves to a 4-1 victory.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Trade in the grain futures market was unusually dull today and prices of most contracts finished unchanged or fractions up or down from previous closing levels.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Some of us Americans were dismayed when we first read of the plan of President Eisenhower to visit Portugal en route home from the summit. Not only did we feel it inappropriate for our President to pay tribute to the oldest European dictatorship outside Russia, but we felt that his visit would disillusion the nine million Africans under Portuguese rule now struggling for independence.

WEATHER, permitting, this should be a successful holiday week-end. Certainly all the foods traditionally associated with Memorial Day picnics and cook-outs are here in abundance. Chickens for frying and steaks for broiling are specialties in many stores.

YESTERDAY (May 36, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Briefed Congressional leaders on Paris summit conference; met with Japanese officials; asked Congress for $4,328,800 supplemental appropriation for promotion of Federal export trade program; named Dr. Willard F. Libby to General Advisory Committee of A.E.C. and sent to the Senate a list of foreign service promotions; flew to Gettysburg farm for week-end.

A 15-year-old Puerto Rican boy with a wide smile, an outstanding school record and the almost awed affection of his neighbors was shot dead Wednesday night by three youths bent on settling a grudge with his older brother.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Book lovers, when they see the movie "Pepe," now being filmed at the Columbia Studio here, may be puzzled by one scene.

CAPT. JAMES PALMER LUNDY, the Air Force pilot who told yesterday that he and eight others had been well treated in East Germany after his plane had been forced down, comes from what a neighbor described as "a real nice, middle-class, Middle American family."

ALBANY, May 26 -- The New York Central Railroad has served notice on the Chesapeake and Ohio and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroads that the Central expects to be a party to any merger agreement that those roads try to effect and also that the Central would have to be the dominant factor in such a rail complex.

The conciliatory tone of President Eisenhower's address, unfortunately reciprocated in no degree whatsoever by the Soviet Foreign Minister at the United Nations yesterday, emphasizes American determination to keep on with the dialogue of peace so long as it is possible to do so.

YONKERS, May 26 -- Bye Bye Byrd won the $25,000 U.S.A. Pace tonight by half a length over his archrival, Widower Creed, who was disqualified from second and placed third for breaking.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- United States satellites of the Midas and Samoa type, designed as space sentries against surprise missile attacks on this country, in a year or two will make a retired boy scout of such kindred aerial observers as the U-2 airplane. But their advent has also emphasized the lack of a code of international law governing space.

A plot of vacant land, 200 by 150 feet, on the north side of Hempstead Turnpike, 150 feet east of Clement Avenue in Elmont, L.I., has been sold by Robert Hinds to a building client of Norman Katz of Ossip Associates, Inc., brokers.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 26 -- King Hussein said today that "free and fair" elections would be held here by next October if the present calm continued.
HAVANA, May 26 -- A profound debate stirred by the Roman Catholic Church may be developing in Cuba over the role of communism.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 22 points ($1.10 bale) up yesterday, with the far months strong.

IN the little inn in the village of Pyrgos the beds were only pailliasses stuffed with straw and laid on planks. Supper was only beans. After supper their pens "scratched industriously" in silence until the innkeeper's wife broke in.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Capital Airlines, which ranks fifth in size in the industry and first in financial headaches, announced today that it was withdrawing its application for a subsidy of $13,000,000 a year from the Federal Government.
ALBANY, May 26 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that Hulan E. Jack must stand trial on charges of conspiracy and accepting illegal gifts.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The chief of the Army Engineers called today for a reduction in the waste of water and measures to eliminate pollution in lakes and rivers.
The state's mental hospital population continued its downward trend for the fifth straight year, Dr. Paul H. Hoch, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered a thirty-day suspension of some of the business of Reynolds Co., a large stock brokerage and investment banking concern with headquarters in New York.

Derrick of the Pin Oak Stable bad the benefit of a bold ride by Manuel Ycaza in winning the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. Forced to move between horses just after the field rounded the stretch turn, Derrick did exactly that as he went on to score by a length and a half over the Pine Tree Stable's Nasomo.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- John Thomas, the Boston University high jumper, and a rousing battle for the team title are expected to provide the main excitement tomorrow and Saturday at the annual outdoor track championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 26 (UPI) -- Don Jordan of Los Angeles will take the biggest gamble of his career tomorrow night when he risks the welterweight title in this city of chance against Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba.
RABAT, Morocco, May 26 -- King Mohamed V installed a new team of Ministers today headed by his son, Crown Prince Moulay Hassan, and dominated by "king's men."

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Pedro Ramos of the Washington Senators held the Boston Red Sox to five hits tonight for a 5-2 victory. The Red Sox' loss was their eleventh in twelve games.

An American edition of Eugene Heimler's "Night of the Mist," an account of his experiences in Auschwitz and Buchenwald, will be published next Tuesday by Vanguard. In the spring of 1944, the author, then a 21-year-old Hungarian poet, was arrested by the Germans.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 26 -- Two cloak-and-dagger organizations participated in the recent capture of Adolf Eichmann, a senior officer of one of the groups said in an interview tonight. Eichmann is the Nazi accused of having been Hitler's chief agent in the murder of 6,000,000 Jews.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- The head of the Transport Workers Union of America said today there was a "strong likelihood" that 25,000 members would strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad tomorrow. A temporary stoppage hit the road last week.

Baltimore's four-game wining streak, along with its grip on first place in the American League, vanished last night the Stadium. The Orioles ran into an icy-veined Whitey Ford, who was backed by a red-hot Yankee infield.

THE Juilliard School of Music presented its annual commencement concert last night. Oliver Treyz, president of the American Broadcasting Company television network, said yesterday that Federal monitoring of television could not create better programs.

TOKYO, May 26 -- Hundreds of thousands of Japanese demonstrated today against the new security treaty with the United States, the Government of Premier Nobusuke Kishi and the scheduled visit of President Eisenhower next month.

Daily average borrowings of Federal Reserve member banks dropped $153,000,000 to $402,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve-Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined' $40,000,000 to $423,000,000.
KANSAS CITY, May 26 (UPI) -- Dick Brown's two-run homer and tight relief pitching by Gerry Staley gave the Chicago White Sox a 3-1 victory tonight over the Kansas City Athletics.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26 -- A tiny microphone was hidden in a copy of the Great Seal of the United States that had been presented by a group of Russians to the United States Ambassador in Moscow, the United Nations was told today.

The nation's capital stock fire insurance companies showed an improvement in underwriting experience last year, Harry A. Miller, retiring president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, said yesterday.

Business continued to broaden in the bond market yesterday, particularly in United States Government securities. As on Wednesday, the buying orders outstripped offerings, with the result that prices moved up generally by from 4/32 to 6/32.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The treatment of cancer by drugs was described by the United States Public Health Service today as a promising development in the fight against the disease.
CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP) -- Management of the Industrial Rayon Corporation won a victory over a group of insurgent stockholders at a noisy annual meeting here today.

LONDON, May 27 -- Most industrial shares continued their advance in tha stock market today. While most gains were small, there was little sign of the profit-taking that was evident in late deals yesterday.

ATHENS, May 27 (UPI) -- Following is the text of a communique issued by the Turkish armed forces and broadcast from Turkey today. No signature was heard, but the statement was identified as coming from "the voice of your army forces, which you trust."

IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, May 27 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson ame west today for a long week-end of campaigning as the Democratic party's chief apostle of non-partisanship in times of national crisis.
