THE American painter Frank Wilbert Stokes (1858-1955) was an unremarkable Eakins pupil who owes his fame to having become an artist-explorer on hazardous journeys throughout the Arctic with Peary and Amundsen.

Turkey's current crisis was fired by the strong-man comalex of Premier Adrian Menderes. His bitterest critics concede that he has done much good for the country, but even his friends have found him cantankerous and unwilling to allow criticism or advice.
THE Goldman Cup open pair contest that begins today in the Eastern States tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel is billed on the tournament program as "bridgedom's most celebrated regional event."
MADISON, N.J., May 27 (AP) -- Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell interrupted the 103d session of the Newark Methodist Conference today to make a church-wide appeal for aid for Chileans.

THE other night we were watching a play about Elizabeth the Great and Mary Stuart. The characters seemed to be firing chunks out of some history of England at one another. That's the trouble with many historical novels and plays. They are numbingly historical. This is a hazard of metier Paul Bartlett faces -- and surmounts -- in his new book, "When the Owl Cries."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Controller General has decided that a vessel that dives seven miles deep and maneuvers on the ocean floor is not a submarine. Therefore, a Navy officer aboard is not entitled to extra submarine pay.

LONDON, May 27 (Reuters) -- British European Airways officials said today the new Vickers Vanguard turboprop airliners grounded yesterday because of an engine fault had "a fair and reasonable chance" of going into service July 1 as scheduled.

Marc Chagall, already firmly ensconced in art history, is about to make some more. The 72-year-old Russian-born painter arrived in the United States this week on various agreeable errands, among them to receive an honorary doctor's degree from Brandeis University on June 12.
YONKERS, May 27 -- Tie Silk surged down the stretch and won the $25,000 free-for-all mile trot before a crowd of 31,309 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
KANSAS CITY, May 27 (UPI) -- Russ Kemmerer's relief pitching and the clutch hitting of Luis Aparicio led the Chicago White sox to a 7-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The State Department announced today that the small economic aid program in Cuba would be ended within six months.
Thousands of New Yorkers deserted the city yesterday for the Memorial Day week-end, the first of the warm season's three-day holidays.

The Alabama Education Authority is planning the sale of $50,000,000 of bonds on June 12. This will mark the second sale under an authorization of $100,000,000 borrowing to construct, improve and equip public schools and college buildings.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- The operator of Coyle Lines, Inc., of New Orleans testified today that the Illinois Central and Southern Pacific would overwhelm small barge operators on the Gulf intracoastal canal if the railroads were permitted to purchase the John I. Hay Company barge line.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan was indicted Jan. 13 on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice and of three violations of the City Charter. The indictment was dismissed on March 14, as improperly drawn, by a General Sessions judge. On April 21 the Appellate Division, reversing the lower court, found the indictment not defective.

Despite the recent narrowing of ideological differences between Moscow and Peiping in international policy, post-summit speeches by Soviet and Chinese Communist spokesmen indicate that the Soviet line is still softer than that of the Chinese.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered jail cells with telephone service today for two night club owners who had refused to turn their business records over to a grand jury.
ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -- Newspapers have a right to examine records of teachers' salaries and official minutes of school board meetings, the State Education Department ruled today.
TOKYO, May 27 -- Japan and Taiwan completed a one-year trade agreement in Taipei, Taiwan, today that calls for transactions of $65,750,000, each way, the Japanese Foreign Office announced.

On the eve of his retirement a supervising inspector of the city's Buildings Department has been dismissed on charges of giving "incredible, contradictory and deceitful answers" about his personal finances.

THE general who headed the coup that overthrew the Turkish Government yesterday typifies the tradition of the army he heads. He is virtually unknown outside his service, though highly respected in it.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 27 -- When 114 cruising yachts from 123 entries began the Storm Trysail Club's fifteenth and biggest race around Block Island late this afternoon, one of the high-rating boats was left forlornly behind, hard aground off the shoals of Hen and Chickens.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., May 27 (AP) -- St. John's of Brooklyn downed Villanova, 7 -- 2, and Delaware whipped Colgate, 15 -- 4, today in the opening games of the National Collegiate District 2 baseball play-offs.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter indicated today that there had been no Administration policy review of the wisdom of continuing the U-2 reconnaissance flights over the Soviet Union as the Paris summit conference approached.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Larry Sherry relieved Stan Williams in the seventh inning today and preserved a 5-3 victory for the Los Angeles Dodgers over the Chicago Cubs.

The six-story building containing thirty-six apartments at 51 Buchanan Place, northwest corner of Grand Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation, Bernard I. Sandford, executive vice president.

MONTE CARLO, May 27 (AP) -- Stirling Moss of Britain posted the fastest time in today's time trials for Sunday's Monaco Grand Prix auto race, already marred by injuries to Cliff Allison, also a British driver.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- The United States successfully conducted two Aero-bee-Hi rocket shots early today to seek vital new data on the stars.

The establishment of a Federal bureau of intergroup relations to combat prejudice and discrimination was urged here yesterday by Dr. Alfred J. Marrow, chairman of the city's Commission on Intergroup Relations.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The United States gave notice today of its preliminary thoughts on the international tariff negotiations that will take place in Geneva next fall. It published two lists, each of which, named thousands of terns on which the United States negotiators might be prepared to bargain.
The Baltimore Orioles regained first place yesterday by beating the Yankees, 3 -- 2, at the Stadium and an oversized, although perfectly legal, catcher's mitt had more than a little to do with it.

Moses Goodstem, a graduate student at Yeshiva University, has, finally finished his thesis -- after twelve years. It runs twenty-two volumes handwritten in Hebrew. He used hundreds of pencils and pens. His hand is still numb.

Railroads operating west of the Mississippi still generally adhere to the view that their passenger trains are the showcase of their operations, even though this idea is not shared by most of the big Eastern carriers.

The president and the board of directors of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Ossining, N.Y., will give a garden party for residents on the grounds of the home next Saturday afternoon.
After early gains, stocks drifted down yesterday in fairly quiet trading to end mixed.

"The Great Contest: Russia and the West," by Isaac Deutscher, will be published by Oxford University on June 23. It deals with the changes in the Soviet Union and in its policies since the death of Stalin. Mr. Deutscher analyzes the evolution of Soviet society, the nature of the Khrushchev regime, education and the moral and intellectual climate, foreign policy and the implications of "peaceful coexistence and competition" between East and West.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- College students arrested during rioting at the City Hall on May 13 accepted an offer today to be tried by a judge on the basis of police reports.

A BRILLIANT study of the integration problem -- balanced, searching and uncompromising in its pursuit of the fundamental problems besetting the troubled South -- was presented last night by the television team of Edward R. Morrow and Fred W. Friendly over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs took another plunge today, continuing the erratic course they have followed for many weeks.

THE novice can find definitions for most of the cookery terms likely to puzzle her in a good, standard dictionary.. But certain culinary terms such as "cut in" and "pan-broil" are not always included in such tomes.

Korvette-Penn Fruit E.J. Korvette, Inc., and the Penn Fruit Company, yesterday confirmed that preliminary discussions were being held concerning the feasibility of effecting a combination of the two retail organizations.
A Reinhold Niebuhr Professorship of Social Ethics has been established at Union Theological Seminary, the seminary announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 27 -- The Security Council adopted today a revised resolution asking the major powers to resume talks on disarmament but omitting censure of United States reconnaissance flights over the Soviet Union.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 27 -- A new speed record of 2,111 miles an hour may have been set here in a flight May 12 of the X-15 rocket space ship.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- An official of the Central Intelligence Agency was stabbed and beaten early today by a man he said he met last night at a cocktail lounge. Police Capt. Nunzio Bonaccorsy of the robbery detail said that a 22-year-old Negro was being sought for questioning.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: I have just read your luminous editorial "Higher Education's Needs" in your issue of May 10.
More than 600 acres of Flushing Meadow Park in Queens were leased by the city yesterday to the New York World's Fair 1964 Corporation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 (AP) -- The earth-shaking that has killed thousands and remade the topography of southern Chile in a week of disastei continued today amid efforts to relieve the hunger and misery of survivors.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 27 -- Following is the text of a revised resolution introduced by Argentina, Ceylon, Ecuador and Tunisia and adopted today by the Security Council:

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox scored two runs in the eighth inning to beat the Senators, 4-3, tonight. The game was spiced by a scuffle between Pete Runnels of Boston and Canrilo Pascual, the Washington pitcher.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (AP) -- A minor change was made today in Monday's line-up for the forty-fourth 500-mile auto race, but Eddie Sachs, Jim Rathmann and Rodger Ward will still lead the hazardous start in the chase for a third of a million dollars.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 27 (AP) -- Bob Cochran scored a dramatic victory at the thirty-eighth hole over Gordon Huddy of England today and entered the final of the British amateur golf championship.
DETROIT, May 27 -- Resentment by Negro unionists against the pace of integration in organized labor took tangible form here tonight with the founding of the Negro American Labor Council.

Scholarship and Personality Books, booklets, brochures, theses dealing with education keep rolling off the presses in confusing plenty. Among these are some hat deserve and are getting special attention from laymen as well as professional educators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial series on the national defense (May 3, 4, 5) is unquestionably a real public service. However, there are some very serious shortcomings in the logic of your writer which I feel obligated to identify and correct.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On May 19 Senator Thomas Dodd of Connecticut suggested the possibility of a criminal prosecution under the Logan Act of Cyrus Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist, because he had met with Premier Khrushchev at Orly airport and had generally criticized American foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- One of the week's patents explains why Atlas and Thor ballistic missiles do not wrinkle their noses and why, if they did, it would be unfortunate. They have special nose cones devised to prevent buckling or distortion under the extreme heat and pressure encountered on re-entry into the earth's atmosphere.
Burnley's soccer team, the champion of England, makes its American debut in International Soccer League competition tonight at the Polo Grounds against West Germany's Bay em-Munich eleven at 8:30.

Like some other countries perplexed by the growing pains of a new democracy, Turkey has been put under military rule following a coup d'etat by the armed forces which overthrew the increasingly oppressive regime of Premier Menderes. The country is now ruled under rigid martial law by a National Union Committee headed by Lieut. Gen. Cemal Gursel.

New Sunday school lessons of the United Church of Christ are being written to persuade small children to accept the "different" child -- whether he is different because of his clothes or because he is a Negro.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 28 -- The majority of Japanese welcome President Eisenhower's projected visit to Japan June 19-22 despite the current furor over the new United States-Japanese security treaty, Premier Nobusuke Kishi said today.
ONE of the brightest spots in the summer home can be the dining table, according to Gimbels. This store has accumulated such pretty place mats that it advocates keeping the table set all day long.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 27 -- Willie Mays, outfielder for the San Francisco Giants, and his family have moved into a fifteen-room stone house -- one of a colony of ten expensive homes on Croft Terrace in the Lyncroft-Broadview-Wykagyl section of this city.

PUERTO VARAS, Chile, May 27 -- By the trembling light of two candles in the dining room of a lakeside resort hotel here a table of Chileans lifted their glasses toward a party of United States airmen. One Chilean spoke in halting English: "Salud. We are grateful."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 27 (AP) -- A field of eight, headed by Fleet Nasrullah, was named today for the $111,800 Californian, tomorrow at Hollywood Park. A crowd of 53,000 is expected to see the seventh running of the mile-and-a-sixteenth stakes.

The Fabrex Corporation, manufacturer of textiles, has leased 7,500 square feet of space in 463 Tenth Avenue, at Thirtysixth Street, through Williams Co., brokers. The lessees were at 115 West Fortieth Street.
A pre-holiday spirit prevailed yesterday on most New York commodity exchanges and trading was dull. Evening of positions for the long week-end accounted for most of the volume.
Adlai E. Stevenson won another mock political convention yesterday -- this time among New York City high school students.
Spring-cleaning housewives of charitable bent can find themselves thrice-blessed by heeding a call from the women's auxiliary of Presbyterian Hospital.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The fate of Federal school construction legislation appeared today to rest largely with the House Rules Committee and its Democratic chairman, Howard VV. Smith of Virginia.

Ghent, the fourth port of Europe (after London, Rotterdam and Antwerp), is being groomed for a major role when the European Economic Community becomes a reality "a few short years from now," according to Geraard Van Den Daele, director, of the Ghent Port Authority.

A specialist on language disorders estimated yesterday that 5 per cent of the children in the United States suffered from some form of aphasia -- a neurological impairment of the capacity to use words as symbols of ideas.
PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- Darlene Hard, already a finalist in singles, teamed today with Brazil's Maria Bueno and gained the doubles final of the French tennis championships.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 27 (UPI) -- Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba captured the world welterweight title tonight with a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Don Jordan of Los Angeles.
Union employes at Mount Sinai Hospital have voted "overwhelmingly" to authorize a strike at the 1,032-bed institution, their union announced last night.
A Long Island lawyer surrendered yesterday to the Queens District Attorney on charges of selling newborn infants to foster parents for adoption.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- The surprising survival of so much of the American U-2 reconnaissance plane that was forced down in the Urals on May 1 is beine explained in some detail at an exhibition of the wreckage here.

PAPIS, May 27 -- Closer cooperation among France, Britain and the United States was presaged by events at the abortive summit conference. But diplomats and other officials here believe that such cooperation actually hinges on satisfaction of President de Gaulle's desire for nuclear parity with his allies.
A special ninety-minute version of "Victory at Sea" will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company shortly before Dec. 7, in commemoration of the Pearl Harbor attack nineteen years ago.
MERRICK, L.I., May 27 -- Twenty-four students from New York City high schools sampled education in the suburbs today.
MELVIN, Ill., May 27 -- Vice President Nixon hit the campaign trail in earnest today with a swinging attack on three Democratic Presidential opponents.

Adverse critical reactions to the screen adaptation of "Bonjour Tristesse" have not prevented Jean Seberg and FranCoise Sagan from joining forces on a new film.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (AP) -- The first-round leader, Jerry Barber, withstood strong pressure with a two-under-par 69 today and held his lead by a stroke at the halfway point in the $50,000 golf open.

Broadway moved a day closer to a theatre strike yesterday as negotiators failed to arrive at any agreement on major issues. The three-year contract between Actors Equity and the League of New York Theatres, which represents producers and theatre owners, expires Tuesday at midnight.
The rally in the bond market moved forward in confident and emphatic fashion yesterday, mostly on the implications of unfolding statistics of the nation's banking system.
CINCINNATI, May 27 (AP) -- Ed Bailey hit a grand-slam home run in the ninth inning tonight that led the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A bill to restore state voting, taxing, law enforcement and other rights on millions of acres of Federal-owned lands was passed by the Senate today by a voice vote. The measure, backed by the Administration, goes to the House.
THERE is no excuse now for women with limp and wilted hairdos, even if they have just emerged from a jungle. Home permanents, now in their fourteenth year, have reached pushbutton perfection.
ALGIERS, May 27 -- Moslem villagers in small communities all over Algeria balloted today in the first day of departmental elections. Voting will continue tomorrow and Sunday.

BONN, Germany, May 27 -- The repercussions of Israel's capture of Adolf Eichmann, who directed the extermination o 6,000,000 European Jews, are spreading in West Germany.
VILLANOVA, Pa., May 27 -- Villanova loomed as the team to beat for the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America title on the basis of today's deck-clearing trials.
GARRISON, N.Y., May 27 -- A mansion with nine lives has been salvaged from scrap heaps and reconstructed here fifteen miles north of its original site at Crugers.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 27 -- The armed forces seized power in Turkey today and promised free elections.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- Ken Boyer's two-run homer, Ron Kline's pitching and four Giant errors enabled the St. Louis Cards to post a 5-4 triumph over San Francisco tonight. The Cards beat Johnny Antonelli, the Giants' ace leftbander for the first time in two years.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- The prices farmers received for crops and livestock fell fourtenths of 1 per cent in the month ended on May 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Federal housing officials urged Congress today not to increase urban-renewal grants, housing funds for the elderly and Federal mortgage insurance authority. All are proposed in current housing bills.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved changes several city, pension systems yesterday to allow a 2 1/2 per cent increase in take-home pay for 85,000 city officials and employes, beginning July 1.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made a loan equivalent to $5,600,000 yesterday for the development of African agriculture and roads in Kenya. The loan will help finance the continuation of a Government program to establish settled communities of African farmers on individually allocated land, help them organize their farms for the efficient production of subsistence and export crops and cattle, and help provide adequate marketing facilities.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 27 -- The Congolese nationalist leader Joseph Kasavubu, who may become the first President or Premier of the Congo Republic, charged in an interview today that Belgian administrators had provoked the Lulua-Baluba tribal war just to show the world that the Congolese were unready for selfgovernment.
After three years of controversy, the $85,000,000 Warbasse Houses project to be built in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Mayor Wagner has appointed a new Policy Committee on Housing and is considering the possibility of a separate part of Special Sessions Court to handle housing law violations.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 27 -- Cornell and Pennsylvania, the East's two leading contenders for the Olympic eight-oared rowing assignment, will race tomorrow over a two-mile course on Cayuga Lake.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, says that the proposed merger of Trans World Airlines, Inc., and Northeast Airlines, Inc., may be contrary to policies of airline competition fixed by Congress in the Federal Aviation Act.
GENEVA, May 27 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union resumed today the negotiations for a ban on nuclear weapons testing.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Small advances were general in the grain futures market today as dealers evened up commitments for the Memorial Day week-end in light trading.
Relocation problems threatened yesterday to delay indefinitely the construction of the long-sought Lower Manhattan Expressway.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board dismissed today the petition of Capital Airlines for mail subsidy. It also dismissed its investigation of Capital's financial situation.
Some intolerance and many sociological factors effectively exclude Negroes from apprentice training programs and skilled trades in New York, according to the State Commission Against Discrimination.

BUENA VISTA, Colo. -- The trip I am about to describe is not for you if you are the kind of eighty-mile-an-hour motorist who has to get the kiddies to Disneyland by Thursday. I refer to the brand-new Forest Service road from this small summer resort over the Continental Divide to a high valley called Taylor Park.

STOCKHOLM. AT the Stockholm Festival of Music and Drama opening today and running until June 12, paradox is king. Optimistic, middleway Sweden is expressing itself in the theatre, with ruins of cities and of men, with the chill of death and bitter resignation.

VILLANOVA, Pa., May 28 -- Villanova's host forces dethroned Penn State as the team champion today in a stirring finish to the eighty-fourth annual title track carnival of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 28 (UPI) -- Thirty-four giant United States military transports flew hundreds of tons of emergency medical equipment today to the aid of Chilean earthquake victims.

BERN, Switzerland -- Most cities in Europe are a lot older than they look. Switzerland's capital city, however, belongs to that small group of metropolises whose Old World appearance makes them seem older than their years.
A long-standing feud between the city administration and the Rev. James A. Gusweller over a tenement on the West Side was apparently resolved in favor of the priest by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Fleet Nasrullah and his jockey, Johnny Longden, toyed with the opposition today and won by almost three lengths in the $111,300 Californian Handicap at Hollywood Park.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The State Department's experts on Soviet affairs found some reason for encouragement in Premier Khrushchev's report to the Soviet Union today on the failure of the summit conference.

The approach of warm weather heralds a minor peak in the sale of playthings. Outdoor games and toys have begun to move from the stores to consumers. In a month the demand for pools and beach items will be heavy.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The newly organized Negro American Labor Council charted today a battle plan to make the struggle for racial equality in unions as militant as the sit-in demonstrations to end lunch-counter segregation in the South.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 28 (AP) -- Bill Hartack guided Royal Native between horses at the top of the stretch in rallying from last place to win the $27,700 Colonial Handicap at Garden State Park today. The margin was a length and a half over Bug Brush.

THE joint project of Orson Welles and the Columbia Broadcasting System to stage a modern-dress version of "Julius Caesar" in London may never come to fruition. It seems that C.B.S., which must watch its pennies, is willing to spend $250,000 for the show, but Mr. Welles now envisions an outdoor production with great crowd scenes that night cost more than twice this amount.

WHEN New York's drama critics trotted out some of their more lurid adjectives to describe the various facets of Chita Rivera's performance in the new musical, "Bye Bye Birdie" (as a dancer she was "flammable" and "exhilarating," as a singer "gyroscopic" and "witty," as a comedienne "skillful" and, in general, "a canasta of streamlines"), they were commenting on a girl who, at 27, had seemingly made no effort to be any of these things.
PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 28 -- Joe Carr of Ireland scored an 8-and-7 victory over Bob Cochran of St. Louis today to win the British amateur golf championship for a record third time.

FOR the last two weeks the tiny performer's platform in the Village Vanguard, which can seem crowded when it is occupied by only a couple of folk singers and an angry young comedian, has somehow managed to contain the thirteen members of Gerry Mulligan's new concert jazz band.

NEW home owners can establish a part of their greenery quickly by installing water gardens. Waterlilies will lend bright color as well as an exotic touch to the landscaping.

The Victorian architecture and the dark, close atmosphere that once typified funeral establishments are yielding to change. Ministers and congregations, along with owners of the homes, have come to feel that more than one style of design can be appropriate, even in the delicate areas of religion and funerals.
RAWALPINDI, Paris, May 28 -- The Soviet Union is sounding out Pakistan on whether she would accept sizable ruble aid for development plans.
MOSCOW, May 28 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that he still believed President Eisenhower wanted peace and really had not known about spy flights over the Soviet Union.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Among the various comments on the sad events of the summit week -- discussions about unity or criticism, about investigating or covering up disastrous blunders, about chances and tactics of Democrats and Republicans -- there is one aspect of our many-faceted problem which seems to be overlooked although it is, I would think, of supreme importance.
John William of the Merrick Stable had a head the better of Reginald Webster's Count Amber at the end of the $117,000 Withers Mile at Aqueduct yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 28 -- Foreign Minister Joseph M.A.H. Luns, declared today that the Netherlands Government "wants to create with Indonesia a modus vivendi by which the relations between the two countries may be improved."

The military coup in Turkey last week called attention to the problems of democracy in an under-developed nation that is also a key U.S. ally. What follows is a description of Turkey and the background to the coup.

PARIS, May 28 (UPI) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., won the women's singles title in the French international tennis championships today. She overpowered Yola Ramirez of Mexico in the final, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, at Roland Garros Stadium.

The changes have affected the candidates and the atmosphere, and they have brought into new focus two questions: Who will get the Presidential nominations?

PALERMO -- Sicily is no longer only sun, scenery and an encyclopedia of about everything that happened in the last 3,000 years, with an accent on the more remote. The largest, most populous and most varied island in the Mediterranean now offers air-conditioning, satisfactory plumbing, new motels and standardized no-nonsense hotels, car rental agencies and splendid highways where one can still enjoy driving.

To the Art Editor: I SALUTE with gratification, and gratitude, your article of May 8, "Children, Amateurs and Artists," on an aspect of the confusion that exists in our time in the realm of esthetics.

NO one will say just how slender was the thread on which the fate of the New York Philharmonic broadcasts hung. But one thing is now certain. If the broadcasts were in need of saving, it was the letter-writing of the orchestra's radio listeners that saved them.

Disaster in many forms has hit the brave and industrious people of Chile this past week. This nightmare chapter in Chilean history has been the result of earthquakes and associated natural catastrophes in which thousands have been killed and millions have been deprived of their homes and means of livelihood. LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 28 -- A broadly based coalition government wide enough to include extreme Congolese nationalists is being urged as the sole hope of saving the Belgian Congo from anarchy and revolution when this enormous colony achieves independence June 30.

BY now it is pretty well agreed that the United States experienced during the past half century one of its two greatest literary periods -- perhaps its greatest period. The writings of O'Neill Hemingway, Frost, Faulkner, Eliot and some others are recognized throughout the world as masterpieces of contemporary art.

THE British have two articles of faith: (1) that they are the most class-conscious people on earth -- they hold this idea chiefly because foreign visitors tell them it is so; (2) that class consciousness does not exist in the United States, because visiting Americans always point this out.
HAVANA, May 28 -- Two small boys in khaki uniforms and over-sized overseas caps entered the bar of a Havana hotel the other afternoon and timidly approached a table of tourists.

The relatively sharp rise in the Consumer Price Index for April came as somewhat of a surprise. Last month was hardly distinguished by obvious sharp inflationary forces pressing on the economy. LONDON, May 28 -- Around the squat, soot-smudged walls of the Tower of London, a strange procession made its way this week.
SPOKANE, Wash., May 28 (AP) -- Washington State's twenty-seven votes at the Democratic National Convention will be split among all the major Presidential candidates, the Governor said today.

A NEW service which will add Sonotrack coating to processed 8mm Koda chrome movie film has been announced by Eastman Kodak. The company also has announced a combination processing-and-sound-coating service for both 8mm and 16mm Kodachrome film.

PHILADELPHIA -- The Civil War centennial observance does not get under way officially until next year, but interest in this event, one that is expected to attract thousands of tourists, already is making its presence felt.

A troupe of sixty-five Japanese Kabuki actors arrived here yesterday for their first American appearance. The traditional all-male Grand Kabuki will open a three-week engagement at the New York City Center next Thursday.

"WRITE about what you know" is the customary advice for a beginning novelist. It is probably as safe a direction as any in the chancy world of fiction. Unfortunately, the tossed salad of human experience requires considerable selectivity before it conforms to the form and function of a novel.

THE fifth annual Muster Day at Old Sturbridge Village, Sturbridge, Mass., on June 12 will feature a record number of ancient music and marching units. When the Muster Day program was inaugurated as an experiment at the re-created village of over thirty-five buildings, the sole attraction was the colorful Mattatuck Drum Band of Waterbury, Conn., founded in 1767.
RABAT, Morocco, May 28 -- The issue of the evacuation of French and Spanish troops from independent Morocco appears to be moving to a solution.

Numidian cavalry strikes back; African elephants bearing soldier-filled towers on their backs, lumber against the charging Romans.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 28 -- Eighty-nine heifers, heifer calves and young bulls were led up a ramp at the Strathglass Farm today and auctioned to breeders from as far away as Canada and South America.

HAVING given us a masterly study of "The Classical Tradition," Gilbert Highet here reaffirms what we can only call the Great Tradition of poetry. Part of the Blair Farm off Center Street in Nutley, N.J., has been selected for improvement with forty-two dwellings in a project called Sunnyside.

BERLIN. THE repertory of the Komische Oper in East Berlin reflects the lively, wide-ranging tastes of its Intendant, Walter Felsenstein. In the period from May 14 to 25, the following pieces were listed: Mozart's "Magic Flute" and "Abduction From the Seraglio," Kurka's "Good Soldier Schweik," Britten's "Albert Herring," Janacek's "Cunning Little Fox," Paisiello's "Barber of Seville," Puccini's "La Boheme" and "Turandot" and Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, the Republican floor leader, blocked a compromise proposal made by the Eisenhower Administration in the middle of Thursday's House debate on a Federal school construction bill.

TO THE EDITOR: The book offers consumers the facts that allow them to make enlightened decisions. * * * In a country bulging with storage elevators for excess grains, it is nonsense to say we would starve without pesticides.
Some drastic changes have been suggested for a bill now being considered by Congress that would grant tax benefits for self-employed persons who set up funds for their retirement.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28 -- President Tito shifted his position today and blamed United States flights over the Soviet Union for failure of the summit conference.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The unbeaten touring team of Britain and Ireland, Philadelphia's first team and New Jersey's first team won two games apiece today in opening of the the twenty-ninth annual national tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association on the three fields of the Friends Central School.

AFENCE can be more than a property enclosure. With proper placement it can make a terrace private, shield a service area on give new prominence to beautiful plantings. Because a fence rarely changes in appearance from season to season, it is a useful garden ornament.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 28 -- President Eisenhower visited an old-fashioned general store today and went home with a crock of apple butter, dried corn, canned plums and other items. The purchases came to $7.13, and the owners were so excited they forgot to charge him 11 cents sales tax when he paid the bill.

SUCCINCTLY summing up a remarkable post-war development in Western Europe, Soviet Premier Khrushchev said recently of the new bonds between France and West Germany, "It is a marriage without love." He confidently predicted that it would soon go the way of loveless marriages -- quarrel and divorce.

THIS new volume by J.F.C. Fuller, his fortieth book, is more than a biography of the ancient world's foremost conqueror; it is by comparison an appraisal of war and peace in the present day. An effort to acquaint Puerto Ricans with facts about the city's labor market will be one of the main objectives of a new migration conference here this week sponsored by the city and the Puerto Rican government.

The pivotal alliance is the North Atlantic Treaty Organization which bulwarks Western Europe and extends eastward to Turkey.

BENEDICT ARNOLD is so well known that his name is frequently substituted for the common noun "traitor." Not so well known, however, are the details of his treachery nor the military about-face General Washington had to make as a result of his defection.

Currently, there is one in progress that bridges these extremes -- it is a subtle spectacular being played before an almost nonexistent audience hi an out-of-the-way hearing room by the improbably titled Senate Subcommittee on National Policy Machinery.

The Great Lakes district of the Seafarers International Union has won two National Labor Relations Board elections for unlicensed crew members of twenty-two ore and grain ships of two steamship companies. This was announced here over the week-end by the union.

The producer of four present Broadway hit shows suggested yesterday that the city drop its 5 per cent tax on theatre admissions and the money be used to set up a pension fund for actors and other theatrical workers.
