ST. LOUIS, May 29 (UPI) -- Daryl Spencer drove in three runs with a single and a double today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-1 five-inning victory over the San Francisco Giants.

LINDEN, N.J., May 29 -- Ch. Crikora Commation, a black miniature poodle owned by Mrs. J. Donald Duncan of New York, captured best-in-show at the eighteenth annual Plainfield Kennel Club all-breed event today.
After 2,750,000 miles and forty years of globe-trotting, Leo A. Mathews still likes to travel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: J.F. Follman Jr. writes in your issue of May 19 that at two public meetings in which he participated on the problems of medical care for the aged he found that "at neither meeting did a single older person display any interest in the Federal proposals."
The lease on the Seaway Idlewild Hotel at the intersection of the Belt Parkway and Van Wyck Expressway in Queens has been purchased by Seaway Associates, Inc.
MONTE CARLO, May 29 -- Stirling Moss won as he pleased today in the eighteenth Grand Prix de Monaco.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- The forty-fourth 500-mile auto race here tomorrow could be the fastest of all. It certainly will be fast in the early stages, with at least sixteen of the thirty-three starters charging for the pace-setting position and the money that goes to the winner of each lap.

RYE, N.Y., May 29 -- For the second straight day a strong east wind made sailing on Long Island Sound a snappy affair as seventy-eight sloops turned out for the Yacht Racing Association's regatta this afternoon.

Two Lithuanian refugees arrived here yesterday after a fifteen-year struggle to escape from behind the Iron Curtain. They were met at New York International Airport by their 28-year-old son, whom they had not seen since he was 12.
THE intellectual, physical and moral caliber of the armed forces of the United States was examined in an absorbing telecast over Channel 4 on Saturday night.

THE Aqueduct separation center will burgeon today like a lush jungle that's just been lashed by a tropical storm. The attractive greenery of dollar bills will be present in perhaps record profusion, five million of 'em or more. It makes for a breathtaking sight.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The undefeated touring team of Britain and Ireland scored its twenty-third and twentyfourth victories in this country today.

THE impact of travel on the national taste will never be measured with finite accuracy, era it can be imagined. A few of the gastronomic wonders with which the American public seems to have become conversant during the post-war era are the Proveneal stew called bouillabaisse, Spain's paella, the cheese and onion pie known as quiche Lorraine and Italy's pizza -- which is libeled by most American versions.
COPENHAGEN, May 29 -- Hairos II, a Dutch owned horse with a yen for short distances, today trotted off easily with Denmark's Internationalt Mesterskab (international championship).
DETROIT, May 29 -- A successful revolt by women unionists for equal rights temporarily diverted the new Negro American Labor Council today from its crusade against racial discrimination in unions.
DETROIT, May 29 -- On the banks of the Detroit River, a huge, white marble convention arena and exposition building is nearing completion. It is known as Cobo Hall.

AT first thought it would seem doubtful that network television needs more mystery dramas, but last night's debut of a new series, serving as a summer replacement for Dinah Shore on Channel 4, quite possibly could catch on without too much difficulty.

The New Yorker magazine frequently runs little pieces illustrating the selling tenacity of advertising men under the caption "There'll Always Be an Ad Man." It may have to replace it with a new feature called "There'll Always be a Mutual Fund Salesman."
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright questioned today the wisdom of President Eisenhower's taking responsibility for the U-2 flight over the Soviet Union on May 1.
Mayor Wagner was urged yesterday to "give some thought to replacing" Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan.
Roy Wilkins lauded last night the civil rights records of Vice President Nixon and "all the Senator-candidates" for the Presidential nomination with the exception of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson.

TORONTO, May 28 -- Canada's most famous herd of wild horses is to be evicted from desolate Sable Island, where the tough and stunted breed has survived starvation and Atlantic storms for about 300 years.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

RABAT, Morocco, Monday May 30 -- Early returns today from Morocco's first popular elections yesterday indicated that the Left-wing National Union of Popular Forces had Won majorities in the coastal industrial centers while the middle-of-the-road Istiqlal (Independence) party had scored clear victories in inland regions.

Net income of Brazilian Tracition, Light and Power Company, expressed in dollars, amounted to $10,010,061, or 58 cents a share, in 1959, compared with $11,074,300, or 64 cents a share, in 1958, the company has reported.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The annual "rankings of the states" by the National Education Association showed New York today to be the highest spender on public-school education, per pupil enrolled. The state also has the highest estimated school-age population.

TOKYO, Monday, May 30 -- The powerful Japan Teachers Union will appeal directly to President Eisenhower, through the United States Embassy here, to cancel his scheduled visit to this country June 19 to 22.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 27 -- Stocks advanced here last week on sustained demand for international issues, chiefly from large foreign investment trusts. The demand came chiefly from the United States, West Germany and the Netherlands and the stock shortage became an important factor.

CINCINNATI, May 29 (UPI) -- Vada Pinson hit his fourth homer of the season with a runner on base in the ninth today as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 4-to-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. Jay Hook pitched all the way to score his fourth triumph against three losses.

A five-man panel of the National Labor Relations Board will hear arguments tomorrow in Washington on whether it has jurisdiction over seamen aboard foreign-flag ships owned or largely controlled by American interests.
PARIS, May 29 -- The stock market showed great firmness last week.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 29 -- More than 100 leaders and supporters of the deposed Turkish Government were transferred, today to imprisonment on an island naval base in the Sea, of Marmara, well-informed sources said.

The Weyerhaeuser Company has leased office space in 529 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-fourth Street, for occupancy by its boxboard and folding carton divisions through Cuahman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I recently returned from five weeks in South Africa. I had arrived in Johannesburg the day after the Sharpeville shootings.

VIENNA, May 29 -- Chancellor Julius Raab told the Austrian people today that Premier Fernando Tambroni's letter suggesting Italian-Austrian discussions of the South Tyrol question or its submission to the International Court of Justice was disappointing.
A DETERMINED attempt to overlap stage settings and natural backgrounds is only partly successful in "Lileia," a lavishly mounted feature-length ballet feature in color from the Soviet Ukraine.

PITSBURGH, May 29 (AP) -- Vernon Law, with relief from Fred Green, scored his seventh triumph of the year for the Pittsburgh Pirates with an 8-5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. It was the Phillies sixth straight loss.

Sun-seekers who had looked forward to a long Memorial Day week-end of fine weather were greeted here yesterday by cool, cloudy and breezy weather that sharply curtailed the crowds at amusement parks and beaches.
James Thurber, humorist and cartoonist, now blind, was trapped early yesterday in a smoke-filled, burning apartment until rescued by a fireman.

Voters in mid-Manhattan would prefer a reduction in the national debt to either a tax cut or additional Federal spending, according to a survey conducted by Representative John V. Lindsay among his constituents in the Seventeenth Congressional District.
A 9-year-old boy watched in terror yesterday as his father was fatally shot battling a hold-up man in a Ninth Avenue drugstore.

BALTIMORE, May 29 (AP) -- Ronnie Hansen hit a homer and Gene Woodling singled in the winning run in the last of the ninth today as Baltimore defeated Boston, 5 -- 4, in the second game of a double-header.

Diamond producers in Africa are stepping up their efforts to discover industrial and gem stores. De Beers Consolidated Mines, Ltd., is spending about u1,000,000 ($2,800,000) a year prospecting for new deposits in South Africa and other major producers are supporting exten- sive exploration programs, according to Stan Giles, consulting engineer for the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, Ltd., a De Beers affiliate.

Following is the third article in a debate on the general theme of the National Purpose, which is being presented by The New York Times in conjunction with Life Magazine. Subsequent articles witt be written by David Sarnoff, the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, John. Gardner, Clinton Rossiter, Albert Wohlstetter and James Reston. The articles will appear every Monday and Thursday.

A ninety-year-old institution at 60 Beaver Street -- the New York Cotton Exchange -- staggering from Government participation in the cotton business, continues to operate in the hope that Federal legislation soon will ease its trading problems.

THE young Duke of Reichstadt died in the vast palace of Schonbrunn near Vienna on July 22, 1832. The handsome, charming and exceptionally intelligent young man had been ill for many months and had been treated by the two most distinguished doctors in Vienna for a liver complaint But it was tuberculosis that killed the 21-year-old Duke.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 30 -- The agility left in the 24-year-old heels of Roderick Stephens Jr.'s New York-32, Mustang, made her the main winner of the Storm Trysail Club's annual race around Block Island today.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- Elroy Face stifled a ninth-inning rally by Milwaukee and gave Harvey Haddix and the Pittsburgh Pirates an 8-3 victory today.
As the world grows more complicated in this electronic age, so language also must grow more complicated.
Despite the softness of most other metal markets, the proverbially optimistic aluminum industry continues to enjoy booming times. At least that's the way things would appear from facts such as these:

Education for the Retired Education for those who have retired has taken an unusual twist in recent years, with colleges and cultural institutions across the country turning their attention to special programs for our elder citizens.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Dalton Trumbo, who stands at the top of the Hollywood blacklist of movie writers, is the author of the screen play for "The Hot Eye of Heaven," it was learned today.

HAVANA, May 30 -- Small groups of anti-Castro rebels in the Sierra Maestra of Oriente Province and the Escambray mountains of Las Villas Province are growing in size, according to travelers returning here.
HARLECH, Wales, May 30 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire led six other Americans into the third round of the British women's amateur golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Socialist party ended its 1960 convention today with a long debate over its uncertain future.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Jim Rathmann of Miami won the Indianapolis 300-mile automobile race today with the fastest speed in the forty-four times the event has been held.
A significant advance toward establishing the existence of a chemical basis for behavior and intelligence has been achieved by a team of scientists at the University of California.

THE moths are beginning to eat. Even if the weather seems cool, this is their season for gluttony. Miss Rose Finkel, manager of Keystone Cleaners at 313 West Fifty-seventh Street, urges that these precautions be taken:
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians' big innings downed the Chicago White Sox, 4 -- 1 and 9 -- 4, today. A crowd of 45,731, the largest of the season at Comiskey Park, saw the games.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies resorted to home runs to defeat Cincinnati, 6 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header today for their first victory in eight starts. Gus Bell drove Vada Pinson home on a single in the tenth inning of the opener to give the Reds a 5-4 victory.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- A hearing on a proposed purchase of the John I. Hay Company barge line by two railroads entered its second week today with further testimony that such a purchase could put independent barge lines out of business.

ALGIERS, May 30 -- Candidates pledged to support President de Gaulle's policy of self-determination for Algeria won 298 of the 452 seats in departmental general councils in the three-day Algerian election.

BALTIMORE, May 30 (AP) The Boston Red Sox finally whacked the league-leading Baltimore Oriples, 12 -- 3, in the second game of a double-header today. The Orioles won the opener, 7 -- 5, for their eighth straight over Boston.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, May 31 -- Boris Pasternak, noted Russian poet, author of the controversial novel "Doctor Zhivago" and winner of the 1958 Nobel Prize for Literature, died in his sleep last night, family friends reported.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 30 -- The Women's Auxiliary of Phelps Memorial Hospital here is sponsoring an all-day old-fashioned country fair on the hospital grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The brilliant touring squad of Britain and Ireland scored a 16-5 triumph over the United States team today in the concluding feature of the twenty-ninth annual national tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association.

Two of our allies -- Korea and Turkey -- having just gone through revolutions that shook and are still shaking their whole body politic, are now trying to attain a new stability. To that end both are at work devising new constitutions to safeguard the basic principles of their still young democracies. But, because the two countries suffered from what were in essence two oppositive evils, they are going in essentially opposite directions.

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 30 -- The great Deerfield River poisoning project appears now to be a clear success, though some wise old heads hereabout are still wagging gloomily. For this season at least, the trout fishing is much better and there is no reason to withhold credit from the program under which the state killed the fish in the Deerfield last summer and restocked with trout.

In "The Blowing of the Parthenon" the Spanish writer and diplomat, Salvador de Madariaga, takes a look at present-day world tensions and summit meetings. He contends that "summitry" can never resolve the great issues of today, that "relaxation of tensions" and "peaceful coexistence" are contrary to the aims of international communism.
Americans in ten cities from coast to coast differ widely as to the political effects in this country of the episodes of the U-2 intelligence plane and the collapse of the summit meeting in Paris.
ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, May 31 -- The imprisoned Minister of the Interior of the deposed regime of Premier Adnan Menderes leaped to his death late last night.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., raised its sales and earnings in the quarter and fifty-two weeks ended on April 30 over those of the 1959 periods, according to the report of Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, and Ralph Lazarus, president, released today.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 30 -- The board of trustees of the Eleanor Roosevelt Institute for Cancer Research elected General of the Army Omar N. Bradley chairman today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- A group of Capital Airlines-employe-stockholders said today it would go through with its fight to overthrow the airline's board of directors.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Unhappy Mayors are telling the Census Bureau it miscounted their citizens. The bureau is not surprised at the protests -- but it does not agree with them.
The traffic toll rose steadily yesterday as the three-day Memorial Day week-end approached its close.
RABAT, Morocco, May 30 -- Both major parties continued tonight to report a victory in yesterday's local elections.
The murder of a gentle man before the horrified eyes of his 9-year-old son Sunday night in a Ninth Avenue drugstore was an event of coincidence.

SEOUL, Korea, May 30 -- The National Assembly approved today a revised national security law eliminating press restrictions and other disputed features of the measure adopted during the regime of former President Syngman Rhee.

DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- First Chance, owned by the Oak Ridge Farm of Pittsford, N.Y., won the open jumper event at the sixty-fourth annual Devon horse show last night. Adolph Mogavero rode the chestnut mare that bad captured the 1958 Devon jumper championship.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday he would make a thorough investigation into the extent of the use of forged New York State automobile drivers' licenses. He acted after a second man in five days had been arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of possessing a bogus license.
Money, people and a horse combined at Aqueduct yesterday to generate an abundance of superlatives for the sport of thoroughbred racing.

Pacific Coast Properties. Inc., is offering to holders of the common and preferred stock of Food Giant Markets, Inc., and to holders of Food Giant employe stock options, rights to subscribe for 917,835 shares of Pacific Coast Properties common stock at $10 a share.
LONDON, May 30 -- Industrial shares advanced modestly on a wide front on the stock market today.
The Sacco and Vanzetti case, which is to serve as the theme for an opera by Marc Blitzstein and for a semi-documentary television program, also will serve as the basis for a musical drama.

A United States Supreme Court decision is being advanced by a Greek seamen's union as a prime argument for Greek shipowners to sign the crews of their Liberian, Panamanian and Honduran flag ships under Greek labor contracts.
DETROIT, May 30 -- The City Council faces a controversy over its recently passed 1 per ent income tax.
LONDON, May 30 -- The British Army's recruiting program is suffering from a lack of soldiering opportunities abroad.

CHANGE is the order of the summer season. All about town restaurants blossom forth with window boxes and heretofore hidden gardens. Hordes of small children, miraculously concealed through the winter, swarm over sidewalks and city parks, riding tricycles or bristling with baseball bats and other outdoor paraphernalia.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Administration has given some new assurances to Democratic leaders in Congress in an effort to get action on a long-stalled bill to provide upwards of forty more Federal judgships.
The Port of New York's long struggle for parity in rail freight rates with the Ports of Philadelphia, Baltimore and Hampton Roads awaits a decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (UPI) -- Willie Mays scored from first base on Willie McCovey's single and an error in the ninth inning, and San Francisco scored a 5-4 victory over Chicago. The Cubs won the opener, 2 -- 1.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Once again danger and opportunity have appeared together on the world stage.

The fact that Algeria could have an election at all in present circumstances is something of a triumph for the French. Not many more than half the voters turned out. In the rural districts they were brought to the urns in French army trucks. The general atmosphere was listless.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky, Soviet Defense Minister, announced today that he had ordered the nation's rocket forces to strike at any base from which a plane might violate the frontiers of the Soviet Union or of its allies.
The Carnegie Corporation granted $450,000 yesterday to raise teaching standards in the schools and colleges of the rapidly maturing republics of Africa.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 30 -- A seven-member committee began work today on a new Constitution.
PETTY pilferers with high class palates soon may find caviar under electronic lock and key:

JERSEY CITY, May 30 -- After dominating the first half without scoring, Kilmarnock, Scotland's champion, blanked Glenavon of Ireland, 2 -- 0, in an International Soccer League game at Roosevelt Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Harold Watkinson, British Defense Minister, arrived in Washington today to talk to United States officials about plans to reinforce Western military power in Europe.

THE mixed pair championship in the Eastern States contract bridge tournament was won last night for the second successive year by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Levitt of Wilmington, Del. The tournament, which has been under way since May 20 at the Statler Hilton Hotel, will close today.
Telephone service is becoming so complex that a year of planning is required by the builders and the telephone company when a new skyscraper goes up.
PRESSURE from parents who want to make a Harvard man out of trade school material was blamed by student leaders recently for some chronic cases of cheating on high school examinations.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30 (AP) -- When it came to a choice between visiting the Soviet Union and playing baseball here, President Eisenhower's grandson decided in favor of baseball.

KANSAS CITY, May 30 (AP) -- Whitey Herzog hit a homer with two aboard and Marv Throneberry hit one with the bases filled today to lead the Kansas City Athletics to an 8-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the second game of a double-header.
The Citizens Union advised enrolled Democrats yesterday to renominate Municipal Court Justice Herman C. Stoute, who has been refused redesignation by Tammany Hall.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 (AP) -- Gov. John Patterson filed a $1,000,000 libel suit in state court here today against The New York Times and five Negro leaders, including the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Mickey Mantle was mauled and punched by fans while leaving the field at Yankee Stadium at the close of yesterday's double-header with the Washington Senators. He suffered a bruised jaw.
LONDON, May 30 -- Britain will pursue "genuine coexistence" with the Soviet Union despite the summit conference fiasco, Prime Minister Macmillan declared today.

YOGI BERRA, a part-time catcher, was holding court in the dugout before yesterday's double-header at the Yankee stadium. A compulsive conversationalist, he sprays words in the same fashion as he sprays hits -- in all directions and occasionally swings at a bad ball.

MIAMI BEACH, May 30 (AP) -- The United States may have to increase manufacturing efficiency and invent new products to retain its foreign markets, the Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, said today.

AS Richard (Jim) Rathmann eased his sky-blue Ken-Paul Special into Victory Lane at the Indianapolis Speedway yesterday, his chief mechanic threw the Speedway Queen, Rathmann's wife and tradition to one side and wrapped his arms around the driver's neck.

Panorama Sightseeing Yacht Cruise, Inc., will seek an injunction today to prohibit the Park Department from canceling a contract that lets the company use a gangway at the Battery for its cruises around Manhattan.

CAIRO, May 30 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has told Egyptian editors that one reason he took over their newspapers was that some foreign embassies had been attempting to control them through advertising.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Marshal Malinovsky's order that Soviet rockets be fired at bases of any planes that violate Soviet air space echoed ominously in Washington today.
IN "The Grand Tour," the attraction that began last night on Channel 13's "The Play of the Week," Elmer Rice has written a drama about a Connecticut teacher who meets and conquers temptation.
The establishment of a 1,120acre laboratory was announced yesterday by the Department of Sanitation.
MIAMI BEACH, May 30 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America threatened today a union-enforced boycott of Japnese fabrics and finished garments.
POMONA, Calif., May 30 -- Senator Stuart Symington led a parade of Democratic Presidential aspirants today on a quest of California's second-ballot votes in the national convention.

The captain of a Staten Island ferryboat put in a radio telephone call for police aid last night after a group of youths had swarmed over the upper deck snack bar on the trip and grabbed a case of soda pop and all the frankfurters.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP) -- The unofficial final standing in today's 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Speedway, showing speed averages or laps traveled and reasons for dropping out:

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 30 -- Stroked by Ted McCagg, a former Harvard varsity oarsman, the Union Boat Club won the senior eight-oared race on the Travers Island Lagoon course of the New York A.C. today.
Thousands of Americans took time out from the holiday weekend yesterday morning to observe the original purpose of Memorial Day -- to pay tribute to the nation's war dead.

The Jumel Building, a two-story office and store structure at 2042-50 Amsterdam Avenue, at 162d Street, has been purchased by Goldman Brothers and Alexander Di Lorenzo. They plan to remodel the building.

"CHANGE OF LOVE,"* by Vivienne Koch, is a subtle allegory about the wounds intellectuals suffer for their calling and the bows they have to make toward inexorable expediency. It is also, or, I should say, at the same time, a startlingly dynamic story concerning passionate violence.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- Steel mill furnaces are being taken out of operation in some parts of the nation, idling thousands of steelworkers.

MONTE CARLO, May 30 -- In Rome, people seem increasingly nervous about traffic problems during the next Olympic Games Aug. 25 to Sept. 11. Numerous committees have studied the situation at length, but nothing has yet been done.
BELLPORT, L.I., May 30 -- The week-end regatta of the Heliport Bay Yacht Club ended today with six skippers accomplishing sweeps in an event that began the club's fifty-fifth season.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The head of the Textile Workers Union of America criticized the South, giant textile corporations, the Eisenhower Administration, and Vice President Nixon today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 30 -- The Israeli Government Press Office charged tonight that the Jerusalem correspondent of The New York Times had made "shocking suggestions" in reporting the case of Adolf Eichmann, former head of the Gestapo's Jewish section.
DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- The auto industry, with one day's production to go in a month in which it already has built 586,817 passenger cars, is scheduling a June output of more than 600,000 units.

JOHORE BAHRU, Malaya, May 30 -- This former British colony, now nearing its third birthday as an independent country, is in a frenzy of progress and achievement that adds up to one of Southeast Asia's most dramatic stories of quick growth.
NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -- The Reserve Bank of India has reported that an "exceptionally large" amount of foreign capital invested in the petroleum industry was repatriated during 1958.
Mount Sinai Hospital challenged a union's claim yesterday that a majority of the institution's nonprofessional, technical and clerical employes had voted to authorize a strike.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., May 30 (AP) -- Charles Kolb of Silver Springs, Md., drove an Elva to an easy victory today in a fifty-mile race for Formula Junior cars.
The Yankees were on the road to the afternoon's second 2-1 defeat at the hands of the Washington Senators yesterday when quite happily they were detoured by Yogi Berra's fifth homer of the year.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 30 -- Bob and John Sleight's Toy Yot was again the first Lightning to cross the finish line in today's interclub racing on Manhasset Bay.
PARIS, Tuesday, May 31 -- France's Government-run railway system faced the prospect of paralysis today.
POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., May 30 -- Governor Rockefeller marched in a parade and gave an address this morning at the Memorial Day celebration in his home community.
RENO, Nev., May 30 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson is nearing the end of a six-state campaign tour that has unquestionably raised his status as a Presidential contender.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A former United States Senator who owns no General Motors or du Pont stock attended the annual stockholders' meetings of both companies this month.
BOLZANO, Italy, May 30 -- The South Tyrolean People's party strengthened its hold on the German-speaking people of the Alto Adige region in municical elections yesterday.

SUFFERN, N.Y., May 30 -- Michael H. Prendergast, New York State Democratic chairman, signed a Stevenson-for-President petition here today and it let loose a henhouse of political squabbling around the countryside.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Public statements made yesterday by the Senate majority leader and the chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations give higher visibility to the line of demarcation among national leaders of the Democratic party in dealing with the political issue raised by the U-2 episode.
New York City has taken the initial steps to begin a three-year, $2,250,000 comprehensive inventory, of renewal needs in residential neighborhoods and some nonresidential areas.

With less than six weeks to go before the opening of the Democratic convention on July 11, the second session of the Eighty-sixth Congress has little time left to roll up a serious legislative record. It is admittedly operating under a heavy political handicap in this Presidential year because the Democrats in control of Congress have not too much interest in producing legislation for which the Republican Administration might take credit-and vice versa.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his excellent address before the New Jersey Bankers Association, Alfred Hayes, President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, referred to recent increases in term business loans extended by New York City commercial banks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I believe I am one of the few educators in the United States (and as far as I know the only American priest) who has had a first-hand look at the educational system of Russia.

Everyone on both sides of the footlights -- performer as well as playgoer -- is distressed by the prospect of serious labor trouble in the Broadway theatre. The Actors Equity contract with the League of New York Theatres expires at midnight. Tomorrow the members of Actors Equity are legally entitled to strike and may or may not be legally entitled to "harass" the theater, to use their own words, by canceling single performances at random.
Scientists here and abroad are seeking new uses for one of the most sensitive physical research tools ever found.
Television and radio networks, with one exception, have found it more difficult than ever to obtain commercial sponsors for this year's Democratic and Republican national conventions.

RYE, N.Y., May 30 -- Warner Willcox, with his International Class sloop, Stardust, and James M. Mertz, with his new 210, Allegra, were the winners in the two largest divisions of the American Yacht Club's weekend regatta, which ended today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 (UPI) -- The state charged premeditation today in the slaying of a man believed to have been a local Ku Klux Klan official. He was shot by a restaurant owner who had received Klan warnings.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- A makeshift thirty-foot scaffold crowded with 100 or more race fans crashed to the ground today at the Indianapolis Speedway. Its screaming occupants were hurled onto spectators below and two men were killed in the tangle.

Ed Duchini of Power Memorial set a record of 1 minute 53.8 seconds for the 880-yard run yesterday in the sectional track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association. Mount St. Michael and Archbishop Molloy won the team titles.
New schools must be geared to future educational needs, according to a report on school costs issued yesterday.

The four Governors and two Mayors who constitute the Delaware River Basin Advisory Committee have tentatively recommended that a five-member commission be formed to administer the water resources of the Delaware River Basin.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 30 -- The Turfland Stable's Bally Ache won the first modern renewal of the Jersey Derby at a mile and an eighth at Garden State today in a bitter stretch battle with C.V. Whitney's Tompion.
LOS ANGELES, May 30 (UPI) -- Bill White drove in six runs with four hits, including two homers in two innings, ttonight and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 15-3 rout of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The American Jewish Congress took a strong stand yesterday against applying "religious tests" to candidates for the Presidency or any other public office.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 30 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. J. Robert Nelson, dean of the Vanderbilt Divinity School, resigned and a dozen ministerial students threatened to quit tonight in protest against the "flat refusal" of the university administration to re-admit a Negro sitdown leader.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The United States recognized the new Turkish Government today with a statement by the State Department that said:

More than 560 bowlers competing in the American Blind Bowling Association tournament over the past week-end proved that blindness is not an insuperable handicap when you want to knock over ten pins. Bowling at the Mid-City Lanes in the Port Authority Building, the competitors picked up spares such as the 5-6 split, the 4-6-10 split and the 2-4, 5-7 leave.
GENEVA, May 30 -- Scientists of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union completed today an initial discussion on a research program to develop controls for underground nuclear explosions.
MANDALAY, Burma Helping the Burmese preserve some of the world's most esoteric music has become the preoccupation of Mrs. Muriel C. Williamson, a temporary resident of Mandalay.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Stuart Rothman, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, advised N.L.R.B. field officers today to be prepared to crack down on any reported violence in the labor-management field.

ROME, May 30 -- Pope John XXIII announced today a major step toward the proposed ecumenical council of the Roman Catholic Church. He told his Cardinals that next Sunday -- Pentecost -- he would set up a number of study commissions for the general church conference.

YONKERS May 30 -- J Hanover, a 5 year-old filly a the Decoration Day Pace before 26,781 fans at Yonkers Racew tonight. The filly, a fourte time winner last year, assun command at the 'quarter a triumphed easily, in 2:08 2 over a muddy track.

Pointing out that the United States Davis Cup team probably will play before wildly enthusiastic crowds in Mexico City, David L. Freed, the captain of the team, came out yesterday for an end to the "hush-hush" tradition at tennis matches in this country.

THE hands of young magicians may or may not be quicker than the eyes of the youthful audience at a magic show to be presented on Sunday afternoon it the Central Park Mall. The program will present members of the Future American Magical Entertainers and graduates of F.A.M.E.
The Federal Government is encroaching on the authority of city and state over parkways, the heads of the respective systems charged yesterday.
The Anglo-American defense conversations which began in Washington yesterday have both Military and political implications of the highest importance to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
BOSTON, May 31 (UPI) -- Joe Cronin, the American League president, confirmed today that Jimmy Piersall of the Cleveland Indians had been fined $250.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Trade in the grain futures market continued at the slowest pace of the-year today with prices little changed and no decided trend showing either way.

Twenty-one places in the United States Open golf championship were allotted yesterday to the metropolitan area. Eighty-two players will compete for the places in a sectional qualifying test at Mamaroneck, N.Y., Monday.
The Rev. Dr. J. Gordon Chamberlin has been dismissed from the collegium of the Riverside Church, it was learned yesterday.
President Eisenhower's handling of the summit crisis was warmly commended last night by Governor Rockefeller.

Total maximum fines of $200 a day and extended prison terms have been proposed for contractors who clutter the city's streets during building operation. Such far-stiffer penalties than now exist are sought in amendments to the city's Administrative Code sent to the City Council yesterday by May or Wagner.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The fight we are waging in Greenwich Village to keep sixteen families in their homes at 40-42 Macdougal Street has far-reaching significance for the whole city.

The six-story apartment house at 3502 Hull Avenue, corner of Gun Hill Road, the Bronx, has been sold by Brevard Associates to an investing client of Irving Serota, lawyer. The building occupies a plot 175 by 100 feet and contains sixty-eight apartments and seven stores.
CHICAGO, May 31 -- The Textile Workers Union of America endorsed Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts for President today, calling him a "down-to-earth yet far-seeing liberal."
A Stunning Entrance There was never a more stunning stage entrance than the arrival twenty-five years ago this week of the liner Normandie on her maiden voyage to New York.
BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Red Sox beat Washington, 5 -- 1, tonight and climbed out of the American League cellar, vaulting past the Senators into seventh place.
Prices of cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 7 points (35 cents) off yesterday. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange continued small.
Broadway will be dark tomorrow night for the first time since the 1919 theatre strike unless an eleventh-hour truce is signed between actors and producers.
PARIS, Wednesday, June 1 -- Rail transport in France was crippled yesterday by a day-long strike that ended at midnight.

JERSEY CITY, May 31 -- The Hudson County grand jury began investigations today into a municipal land sale and into school purchases in Jersey City. Both cases were presented to the jurors by the Hudson County Prosecutor, Lawrence A. Whipple.

Charles Stark, the director of recreation for the Department of Parks, said yesterday that he saw no reason why Downing Stadium at Randalls Island could not be developed into one of the top sites for track and field meets in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- By catching rainwater, the United States learned conclusively eleven years ago that the Soviet Union had become a nuclear power. Dr. Peter King, 49-year-old associate director at the Naval Research Laboratory, told about the project today after receiving the Distinguished Civilian Service Award, the Navy's highest civilian honor.
The nation's death toll from traffic accidents totaled 367 for the three-day Memorial Day week-end and was only four under the record of 371 fatalities for the 1958 holiday.
Vice Admiral Hyman C. Rickover said yesterday that the United States was floundering in military red tape while the Russians were forging ahead with new weapons.
Following is the text of, a radio and television address yesterday by President de Gaulle of France as issued in English by the French Press and Information Service in New York:

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Tiros I, one of the most successful satellites yet launched by the United States, has scored another technological first by spinning a little faster on a command from the ground.

CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI) -- Shipping concerns resumed contract talks today with the International Longshoreman's Association. They proposed an average 35-cent-an-hour wage and fringe benefit increase designed to standardize hourly pay at three major Great Lakes ports.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 31 -- Wage increases, job Security and improvements in pension and welfare benefits will be sought by the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers in contract negotiations with the General Electric Company.

New security flotations in May were below the level of the preceding month and a year ago. Public offerings of bonds here last month dropped to the lowest total since March, and stock flotations were the smallest since last September.

THERE has been a saying around Washington for years, probably started by a Democrat, that while many of the members of the Eisenhower official family spent most of their time with foot in mouth, Allen Welsh Dulles kept his pipe in his.
Dividend Shares, Inc., had net assets of $254,701,160, or $2.80 a share, as of April 30, Hugh Bullock, president, reported yesterday on last Oct. 31, net assets were $267,612,897, or $2.96 a share.

Better demand for actual copper and higher London prices firmed quotations yesterday on the Commodtiy Exchange of New York. Dealer buying and speculator purchasing offset liquidation and light profit taking.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 31 -- Taiwanese hope that President Eisenhower will urge the Chinese Nationalist Government to insure the placing of Taiwanese parties on the ballot in future elections.
The Bryn Mawr Club of New York has issued invitations for the fifteenth annual theatre party to benefit the Bryn Mawr Alumnae Regional Scholarship Fund of New York and southern Connecticut.
The Department of Parks was ordered yesterday to defend its cancellation of a sight-seeing company's contract to use a ramp at the Battery on its cruises around Manhattan Island.

Florida Power Light Company sold 400,000 common shares to a group headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Kidder Peabody Co. They jointly bid a price of $58.005 a share for the issue.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 -- Three contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination courted California's eighty-one-vote delegation today, just one week before, the primary election.
CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI) -- Gene Freese and Al Smith hit home runs tonight in a 6-4 Chicago White Sox victory over the Cleveland Indians.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 31 -- A small submarine-like craft manned by two frogmen has startled the, waterfront here.

While most women are buying bathing suits, sundresses and shorts, America's designers are busy showing woolly coats, suits and fur-laden dinner costumes. These collections, the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July, attract store executives ecutives and buyers from all over the country to New York's Seventh Avenue.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31 -- At Bamako in the French Sudan last week, African countries held a war council and laid plans for mobilization for action against a common enemy. The foe: a disconcertingly appealing little bird with a red beak, a black collar and beige body feathers, which is often kept as a pet -- the weaverbird.

An East Harlem slum tenement landlord whose ten-year operation in the field is highlighted by eighty-three health and housing convictions was sentenced to a total of thirty days in jail yesterday in Housing Court.

The story of Times Square is told by W.G. Rogers and Mildred West in "Carnival Crossroads," which Doubleday will publish June 24. Illustrated by Otto Soglow, the book begins with "New York's first out-of-town visitor," Giovanni da Verrazano, and moves forward to the present, describing the events that took place in the Times Square area.

WARSAW, May 31 (Reuters) -- An accelerated capital investment program for heavy industry and agriculture has been proposed by Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish Communist party leader, informed sources said today.

GENEVA,May 31 -- The member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) adopted today a United States suggestion for a study of the abrupt flooding of markets by goods from countries with low production costs.

Henry Roy Purcell, accused of fatally shooting a clerk in a Manhattan drugstore on Sunday, will be questioned about a quadruple slaying committed in New Brunswick, N.J., last January, according to Middlesex County Prosecutor Edward F. Dolan.
"STARTIME," the National Broadcasting Company's ambitious and expensive series of Tuesday night entertainments, reached its conclusion on Channel 4 last evening.
The State of California announced yesterday plans for the sale of $93,000,000 of bonds on June 28.
OXFORD, England, May 31 -- Oxford University abolished Latin and Greek as entrance requirements for science students today.

COLRAIN, Mass., May 31 -- One of the unnoticed arts that the strong, hardy American outdoorsman has developed to a high degree in the last few years is the art of sitting down. He has done it by his own preseverance, with the vigilant help of American free enterprise.
NEWARK, May 31 -- Newark has lost more than 43,000 residents in the last decade, according to preliminary census figures made public today.

Undefeated Kilmarnock of Scotland (2-0) and undefeated Burnley of England (1-0) will clash in the feature match of the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds tonight. The kick-off is scheduled for 8:30.
The red dial on a massive compressing machine touched 4,460 pounds before a dull "chunk" and a clatter of falling pieces signaled the collapse of a twenty-four-inch sewer pipe section.

A one-story building at 503 McCarter Highway, corner of Tichenor Street in Newark, has been leased by the Baseil Machinery Company of Newark, manufacturer of tool and die-making machinery. The lease was arranged by the Archie Schwartz Company, brokers, for the owner, the U.S. Novelty Products Company, manufacturer of plastic vacuum-forming machinery.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente drove a bases-filled single to center field in the eleventh inning tonight, giving the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
GENEVA, May 31 -- Soviet experts have objected to seven of the twelve nuclear explosions planned by the United States as part of its program for developing ways to detect underground tests.

Gordon Lee of the Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy, who won the freshman title last year, led five qualifiers into the quarter-finals of the sixth Metropolitan College Tennis Conference tournament, which started yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 31 -- The head of the Camden Police Department's vice squad and a long-time city detective, were indicted by a special Camden County grand jury today on charges of false swearing.
A total of 1,000 persons were injured, in automobile accidents here last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was seven more-than a year ago.
Scores of New Yorkers eat lunch in Central Park every working day, weather permitting, sans le cafe francais.

PARIS, May 31 -- President de Gaulle proclaimed tonight France's determination to search for a relaxation of world tensions, for disarmament and for East-West cooperation "in the service of man," despite the collapse of the summit conference.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Arrangements for President "Eisenhower's journey to four Far Eastern countries, which is to begin June 12, were announced today.
The, Aquarium's weakening pilot Whale that won't eat was force-ted in an emptied pool yesterday at Coney Island.

There is one bill in Congress designed to fill an urgent need about which there is no dispute -- nor any controversy about the way the measure would meet the need. Nor can there be any other bill on which Congress has a less valid reason to delay action, already delayed inexcusably long. We refer to the "omnibus bill" (H. R. 6159) providing for forty-five new judgeships in the Federal Circuit and District Courts.
An unusually heavy invasion of inchworms has been reported from the suburbs, causing consternation in addition to that brought by the tentcaterpillar season, which Is not yet over.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 31 -- Gen. Cemal Gursel said tonight that a special committee was investigating the question of the "guilt" of members of the deposed regime of Premier Adnan Menderes.

SEOUL, Korea, May 31 -- Gen. Sun Yup Paik, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, resigned from the army today. Acting President Huh Chung accepted his resignation and General Paik was placed on reserve status.

The Electric Storage Battery Company's Exide industrial division yesterday announced signing of contracts with most major makers of materials handling equipment for development of its fuel cell as a source of propulsion.

Seventy-one children from the New York State School for the Blind served as navigators last week in the annual rally conducted by the Tonawanda Touring, Club of Batavia, N. Y. There were sixty-four cars in the contest, a record, with the owners driving.

THE trouble with crime is its popularity. Its regular professionals are frequently Joined by new recruits, such as the enterprising innovators who thought up payola. And those of us who are more or less lawabiding are persistent readers of comic books about crime, of newspaper glorifications of mayhem and murder, of detective stories and thrillers and even of gay and inconsequential novels that treat crime as if it were funny.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 31 (AP) -- The Carrier Corporation showed a 25 per cent drop in sales and a net loss of $1,530,000 in the three months to April 30 because of strikes, the company said today.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 31 -- Plans for Long Island's first cancer-detection center were announced today by the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation, Inc.
HONG KONG, May 31 -- Communist China and Outer Mongolia concluded a treaty of friendship and mutual assistance in Ulan Bator today.

Cuneo Press, Inc. Net income of Cuneo Press, Inc., and subsidiaries, in its fiscal first quarter dipped to $177,522, or 17 cents a share, from $196,325 and 19 cents in the 1959 period, John F. Cuneo, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday.
The Wagner administration moved yesterday to extend for five years the tax benefits granted to slum property owners who rehabilitate and modernize their buildings.

A uniform speed limit of sixty miles an hour for trucks as well as passenger cars on the New York State Thruway will become effective today. Tandem trailer, or double-bottom rigs, are not included, however, and there are certain area exceptions to the ruling.
Stock prices gyrated yesterday in active trading. The end result of the day's transactions was a minor loss.
The West Side is changing so fast that nearly half its elementary school pupils transfer out of their schools during a year -- and as many more come in.
LONDON, May 31 -- Modest but persistent demand from private investors for leading industrials caused prices to move up in the stock market here today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 31 -- The three remaining Negro students at the Vanderbilt University Divinity School withdrew today, charging that the expulsion of a fourth Negro "was made at least partially on the basis of race."
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 31 -- Patrice Emergy Lumumba has emerged from the Congolese national elections as the most powerful political figure in the land.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- Five hundred northern California Democrats are expected at a $100-a-plate dinner at the Fairmont Hotel here tomorrow in honor of Governor Brown. Senator Kennedy, Senator Symington and Governor Brown will be the speakers.

The city Housing Authority has eased the requirements for certain applicants who are seeking" apartments in three Harlem developments. The relaxed requirements apply to such persons as foreign college students, college teachers and medical internes.
GERMAN fashions are designed on sunless gray mornings, for women without mink stoles or central heating. They are, solemn clothes by temperament and color. They are warm clothes and affluent clothes.

YESTERDAY (May 31, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Entertained Seato ministers at lunch.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Post Office Department issued today a 4-cent stamp in honor of the sixth ministerial council meeting of the South-east Asia Treaty Organization, which opened here today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- William E. Bufalino, teamsters-designated member of the union monitor board, seized a sheaf of correspondence in the monitors' offices otday.
Pending in the Eighty-sixth Congress are eighteen Senate bills and more than 100 House bills that, if passed, would have a direct effect on advertising.
The city's right to seize and rehabilitate slum tenements was upheld yesterday in a Supreme Court test case involving two deteriorating West Side rooming houses.
BONN, Germany, May 31 -- The Government charged two Soviet diplomats today with having attempted to organize espionage in West Germany.

The New York Philharmonic has announced the appointment of Russell Stanger and Elyakum Shaplra as assistant conductors for the 1960-61 season. The appointment of the third assistant conductor, Gregory Millar, was announced from Vancouver, B.C., last Friday.
Steel production is expected to take another sharp dip this week, partly reflecting the Memorial Day holiday.

Stock transactions last month produced the first advance for any month this year.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved a bill today authorizing $1,580,506,352 for 128 navigation, flood-control and other water-development projects in thirty-eight states.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Supreme Court held today that Texas and Florida own the oil and other undersea resources ten and one-half statute miles from their shores into the Gulf of Mexico.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, the House Republican leader, is scheduled to be permanent chairman of the Republican National Convention.
A 62-year-oJd Brooklyn grandmother who had wanted "official confirmation" that she was an educated woman will receive it at the Columbia University graduation today.

SOME fifteen years ago Branch Rickey spoke glowingly of a kid catcher whose return from service the St. Louis Cardinals were awaiting with unrestrained eagerness. Here would be one of the great ones, the Mahatma predicted. It didn't work out that way, though.
Plans were announced yesterday by two companies to enter jointly the production of tetraethyl lead, tetramethyl lead and antifreeze.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- A National Labor Relations Board examiner held today that both the Ford Motor Company and the United Auto Workers Union were guilty of an unfair labor practice in the discharge in 1957 of Joseph S. Urban for activities in support of the International Society of Skilled Trades.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A special House investigating panel has concluded that the air crash over Rio de Janeiro on Feb. 25 that killed thirty-five naval personnel, including nineteen bandsmen, resulted from plans to aid President Eisenhower's goodwill tour of South America.

The Grand Opera House that Jim Fisk bought in 1869 to appease Josie Mansfield, a show-girl known as the Cleopatra of Twenty-third Street, will be demolished next month for the 2,800-family Penn Station South housing development.
Raul Alicea, 23 years old, of 3614 Mermaid Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday to Second-degree murder in the killing Aug. 10 of Philip Schickler, 65, in his restaurant at 207 East Broadway.

Dr. Linus Pauling, Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, told the graduating class at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Yeshiva University, yesterday that the United States was one of four "backward" nations so far as medical systems were concerned.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The theme of Atlantic unity was emphasized repeatedly by Harold Watkinson, British Minister of Defense, and his aides, as he began a shopping expedition today for two types of long-range ballistic missiles.
The Standard Coil Products Coinpany, Inc., has signed a contract to purchase a majority interest in the Casco Products Corporation for about $3,500,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (UPI) -- Jim Rathmann of Miami tonight became the top money-winner in Indianapolis Speedway history when he collected $110,000 for his record-breaking triumph in yesterday's 500-mile auto race.
PIERRE, S.D., May 31 -- Three public hearings have opened a study here to determine whether navigation on the Missouri River should be extended into the Dakotas.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 31 -- A nonprofit American repertory theatre to be directed and managed by Tyrone Guthrie will be established here.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Backers of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas pushed him toward active open candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination today with a $50,000 coast-to-coast newspaper advertising campaign.
KANSAS CITY, May 31 (UPI) -- Dick Hall's three-hit pitching and Andy Carey's third home run of the season gave a 2 -- l victory to the Kansas City Athletics over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, May 31 -- President Arturo Frondizi asked the Argentine Congress today to vote the death penalty for terrorism. He asked that this be done through a national security law demanded by the armed forces.

YONKERS, May 31 -- Fettle, the Australian entry in, the International Pace series at Yonkers Raceway, has been scratched from Thursday's mile-and-a-half event. This cuts the field, to seven for the first such international pace to be staged in the United States.

Sales of the May Department Stores Company for the quarter ended April 30 rose 4 per cent or $5,795,000 above those of the 1959 period to $146,308,000, Morton D. May, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

HARLECH, Wales, May 31 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire and three of her United States Curtis Cup team-mates scored double victories and gained the quarter-final round today in the British amateur golf championship.
United States Government obligations and high-grade corporate bonds, continued to rise moderately in price yesterday.
Sales and earnings of Marshall Field Co. were higher in the first quarter of I960 than a year before, James L. Palmer, president, reported yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) -- Norm Sherry delivered the big punch with the first grand-slam homer of his major league career as the Los Angeles Dodgers belted the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 8 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Vice President Nixon drew a contrast today between Communist China's strident "Stalinism" and Premier Khrushchev's relative restraint since the collapse of the summit conference.
PARIS, May 30 -- Jules Moch said today that the Soviet Union believed the West could not disarm because the Pentagon was opposed to disarmament.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- Windsor Castle took the lead in the open jumper championship of the sixty-fourth annual Devor Horse Show tonight. The bay gelding was ridden by owner Bob Ballard of Toronto to a half-fault four-horse deadlock in the first round of the handy jumper event.

Advocates of compulsory shipping tracks in the North Atlantic have won a part victory at the current London conference on safety at sea, according to Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

BALTIMORE, May 31 -- Although the left side of his face and his jaw still were sore from the pummeling he took from fans who poured onto the field at the conclusion of yesterday's louble-header with the Washington Senators at Yankee Stadium, Mickey Mantle made light of the incident today.
Five hundred fifty Columbia College seniors and their guests packed Columbia College's Van Am Quadrangle yesterday morning for Class Day.
Governor Rockefeller proposed yesterday an economic union of the Western Hemisphere to stimulate trade.

MONTREAL, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- The economies of Canada and the United States are partly insulated from each other by government restrictions and controls on international trade, the Canadian-American Committee, grouping business experts from the two countries, reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright absolved the Central Intelligence Agency today of responsibility for any of what he called the Administration's "questionable decisions" in the U-2 espionage plane incident.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 31 (AP) -- Negro attorneys said today that they would fight a three-school integration program proposed by the Houston School Board for filing in Federal court.

At least 691 of the 4,640 polling paces in New York City -- and possibly as many as 806 -- will remain closed during next Tuesday's primary election under the state's new "no contest, no primary" law.

"The Millionaire" will soon be down to his last million dollars. Effective in September, the series will be replaced by "My Sister Eileen," a filmed situation comedy to be televised on Wednesdays from 9 to 9:30 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : As the many appeals for children's camp funds circulate, it is well to consider how the boys and girls who cannot leave the city will be spending their time.

Textile manufacturers made it clear yesterday that they would fight to stop efforts to establish standards on fabrics, apparel and home furnishings. Voluntary rules go into effect today. In their move the manufacturers are fighting retail groups sponsoring the standards.

Talk about the "new era," rife a generation ago, is cropping up again in Wall Street. At a press luncheon yesterday, William Kurtz, senior market analyst of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, brokerage concern, identified the secret ingredient that had been added to the economy since the end of World War II.
ROME, May 31 --The "miracle" of Italian economic development was unfolded in the Chamber of Deputies today by Premier Fernando Tambroni during the budget debate.
N.P. Chaddick has been named chairman and president of the U.S. Tire Supply Corporation. He was vice president and sales manager.

The magnitude of mental disturbances among the "normal" population, long hinted at by mental health experts, has been confirmed by a three-year public poll. One in four persons thinks he has had emotional problems serious enough to require professional help, a nation-wide survey has shown.
Horse racing was conducted in comparative calm at Aqueduct yesterday before a mere 24,704 fans. It was the final day of the spring meeting. Today Belmont opens a twenty-six-day season.

With more than 300 hand-picked extras portraying the citizens of a rough Harlem neighborhood, a movie safari for United Artists' "A Matter of Conviction" yesterday started its two-week local shooting schedule.

RANGOON, Burma, May 31 (Reuters) -- Foreign manufactured goods other than British will be allowed into Burma, starting tomorrow, only if the makers have appointed Burmese citizens as their distribution agents.

The nationalization of the Egyptian newspapers is, obviously, a retrograde step since it represents the suppression of what freedom of the press there was in the country. The decree places newspapers and magazines under the control of the National Union, the only party allowed to function in Egypt. While officially it will be the party, not the Government, that will run the press, in reality the two are the same.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies bombarded Lew Burdette for six runs on five hits and two walks in the eighth inning tonight and downed the Milwaukee Braves, 12 -- 7.

MIAMI BEACH, May 31 -- A call for a Democratic ticket head by Adlai E. Stevenson, with Senator John F. Kennedy as his running rate, stirred wild applause today at the convention. of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Ingemar Johansson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, told sports writers at-Dempsey's Restaurant yesterday that he was in better condition now that he was at the same stage of training last year, when he was preparing for his first meeting with Floyd Patterson.
Eastern Air Lines will begin an all-cargo service today between Newark and Atlanta.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- New orders received by manufacturers in April were no greater than in March, after allowance for normal seasonal trends, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The United States and Britain have completed the outline of an agreement to place the United States-designed ballistic missile Skybolt on British aircraft in 1964 or 1965.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower urged today that understanding among nations be spread until the Western alliance need no longer exist as an "exclusive club."

HARLECH, Wales, June 1 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire eliminated two of her American team-mates today to gain the final of the British women's amateur golf championship. The United States amateur champion will play Philomena Garvey of Ireland for the title tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Russia is prospecting for oil and gas "over the greater part" of her territory, according to two Russian oil men writing in an American oil publication.
In a decade the sale of highfidelity phonograph equipment has increased from almost nothing to $50,000,000 a year.

The country's automobile production last month rose 5 per cent above the April level and 11.9 per cent above that in May, 1959. For five months, the industry was 17.4 per cent above the corresponding 1959 period in output.
BANGOR, Me., June 1 -- There is no blinking the fact Maine's Atlantic salmon fishing has been poor so far this year, but there are complications that bring hope to bold hearts, maybe.

Mayor Wagner urged yesterday that Puerto Rican and other migrants "prepare themselves" in skills that are in short supply here. This, he said, would both aid them and cut down supplemental relief costs that the city now pays out to stretch low wages.

The runway requirements of a fifty-ton Air Force plane have been slashed to less than 1,000 feet by a novel exploitation of a little-publicized technique.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The White House said today that Vice Admiral John H. Sides would become commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet upon the retirement of Admiral Herbert G. Hopwood on Sept. 1.
On and off the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, two large stock sales were made.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Mort Sahl, whose success is due, in large part, to his gibes at Republicans from night-club stages, is not worried about the possibility that he may become unemployable if a Democrat is elected President.

When this newspaper was fighting the offshore-oil bill in 1953 we repeatedly called it "one of the greatest give-away programs" in American history; and we reaffirm that judgment today in light of the decision handed down by the Supreme Court on Tuesday regarding the offshore rights of the five Gulf states.
Actors Equity forced the cancellation of "The Tenth Man" last night. This threw the switch that is believed certain to put out the lights of all Broadway playhouses this evening.
The curtain rose at 7:35 o'clock last night on an emergency meeting of the cast of "The Tenth Man" called by Actors Equity. The place was Equity headquarters, 226 West Forty-seventh Street.

The Columbian Carbon Company will enter the packaging field, and expand its printing inks activities through the acquisition yesterday of the principal properties and business of the Ander Chemical Company. The cash transaction involved between $2,500,000 and $3,000,000.
A life combining idealism and intellect as a means of continuing to grow was recommended to the graduating class at Barnard College yesterday by Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president.

Yonkers Raceway, Inc., last year increased its net profit to $3,229,824, or $3.48 a share, from $2,892,452, or $3.27 a share in 1958, the annual report for 1959 disclosed yesterday. The 1958 net included a non-recurring gain of 48 cents a share derived from land condemnation.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The International Monetary Fund told some of its member countries today, without naming them, that time was running out on their supposedly temporary post-war currency restrictions.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Riot charges against more than sixty demonstrators against a House Un-American Activities subcommittee were dismissed today.
LONDON, June 1 -- Britain, traditionally a nation of sea-farers, honored today her historic Admiralty Court and the small French lie d' Oleron, which pioneered in the promulgation of maritime law.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Following the suggestion of a New York City school girl, Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today the designation of the fourth Friday of every September as American Indian Day.
LONDON, June 1 -- A Government-appointed committee has recommended the construction of a 75,000-ton liner with a passenger capacity of 2,270 to replace the aging 81,237-ton Cunard liner Queen Mary.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- Premier Khrushchev rebuked Secretary of State Christian A. Herter today for having implied that the collapse of the summit conference could be attributed to the Soviet leader's failure to meet with President Eisenhower privately in Paris.

THE new Eastern States team champions, winners Monday night (actually, Tuesday morning) of the venerable Curt H. Reisinger Cup in its thirty-first year, are Alvin Roth and William Root of New York, Robert Jordan of Philadelphia and Andrew Gabrilovitch and Richard Freeman of Washington.
Profits of Dresser Industries, Inc., declined in the quarter and six months ended April 30 from the 1959 levels, according to the report issued yesterday.

Dr. John H. Fischer, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, asked yesterday that schools give priority to the "intellectual competence" of students instead of acting as centers of "entertainment, civic development and charitable enterprises."

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Representative Emanuel Celler attacked today a Justice Department decision not to oppose the National Broadcasting Company's acquisition of television stations in Boston and San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield left a distinguished group of clergymen speechless today by dropping a request for higher postal rates on religious publications.
A happy man was Newbold Morris, Commissioner of Parks, yesterday. After more than twenty years as an undergraduate at "Curran University," he has been allowed to graduate.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House of Representatives was aroused today over published charges that some members had spent public funds for high living.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A former advertising writer for a drug company testified today to "jazzing up" a scientific speech by Dr. Henry Welch, former director of the antibiotics division of the Food and Drug Administration.
Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris had several items of good news for the city's public links golfers yesterday.

MADRID, June 1 -- Msgr. Eurelio Escarre, Abbot of Montserrat and a revered figure among Spain's 3,000,000 Catalan Roman Catholics, has protested to Generalissimo Francisco Franco against police brutality during General Franco's visit to Barcelona.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Government drastically cut import quotas for residual fuel oil today but increased slightly quotas for crude oil beginning July 1.

All wool positions fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops dropped 1.1 to 1.8 cents a pound and grease wool declined 1 to 1.5 cents. Trading was active.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 1 -- A 17-year-old Long Island organist and a high school chorus from Tulsa, Okla., performed here tonight to renew a musical partnership that started in the Southwest last year.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 1 (AP) -- Loyalist Democrats sworn to support the national party in the Presidential election won control today of a majority of Alabama's eleven electoral votes.

Following are the texts of the citations read yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, in presenting candidates for honorary degrees to Dr. John A. Krout, vice president, at the university's commencement:
Four hundred and fifty ticket-holders came, to the Booth Theatre last night to see a show. They found themselves in one.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 1 -- Honeymooning ospreys -- big, eagle-like fishhawks -- are giving local power company officials their annual case of the jitters.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (AP) -- Sam Jones hit a double with two out in the ninth and drove in Bob Schmidt with the winning run as the San Francisco Giants gained a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

WARSAW, June 1 -- The police used tear gas and nightsticks Monday to disperse a crowd of about 5,000 demonstrating at Zielona Gora in Western Poland over a religious issue, usually reliable sources here reported tonight.
EPSOM, England, June 1 -- It was a great day for the English today as St. Paddy flashed past a field of favored French and Irish horses and won the Derby.

KlAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 1 -- The leaders of the American, Federation of Labor Congress of Industrial Oranizations were accused today of "Isolationism and reaction" their 'conduct of the labor movement.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller outlined here tonight a five-point plan designed to increase the rate of the United States' economic growth without tampering with the basic tenets of the free enterprise system.

When the first atomic bomb was tested in the desert of New Mexico in July, 1945 -- an event that at the time was one of the greatest of war-time top secrets -- men in far-off Rochester, N. Y., were greatly puzzled to find that straw used as packaging material for photographic film had mysteriously become so contaminated with radioactivity that the film was exposed.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) up to 10 points (50 cents a bale) off yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower told a Boy Scout audience tonight that he and Mrs. Eisenhower stormed at each other twenty-five years ago whether their son, John, should make his fourteen-mile hike alone to qualify as a firstclass Scout.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- Following is the text of a speech delivered by Adlai E. Stevenson today to he convention of the Textile Workers Union of America:

Rising prices prevailed in all parts of the bond market yesterday as a widening field of investment interests cast off indifference and joined in the buying. As in recent trading sessions, United States Government securities were the center of most interest.

In time Bermuda will be important to the United States an Canadian dog exhibitors if the rate of progress developed in a year is maintained. In 1958 the Bermuda Kennel Club's three fall shows drew sixty-seven dogs.
Seattle, Wash., borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday for construction of public schools.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended May 25:
Joe Louis announced yesterday that upon the advice of counselN -- his wife -- he might drop his one-quarter Interest in a public relations concern here.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House Agriculture Committee turned down today the Administration's proposal to give President Eisenhower authority to cut Cuba's sugar quota in the event of an emergency.
Employes of a toy company in Trenton, N. J., raised enough cash yesterday to buy the company and save their jobs.
DEVON, Pa., June 1 -- Grey Aero a gray gelding owned by Frank Imperatore of Cannonsburg, Pa., won the open jumper event at the Devon horse show tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court had hardly finished delivering its opinions in the offshore-oil case yesterday when the politicians from the affected states began reacting for publication.
An East Side physician and two other men were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on Charges of bribing a police sergeant to permit one of the three to go free.
BALTIMORE, June 1 -- Young or old, Baltimore's pitchers Seem to have what it takes to still the bats of the Yankees.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is in the hospital with an attack of acute asthmatic bronchitis, but attending physicians say her illness is not serious.

NEW MILFORD, N.J., June 1 -- Seventeen months ago two members of a car pool began to talk about building a swimming pool for themselves and several of their neighbors here. Last Saturday their dream became a reality -- except that the few families had grown to 325.

Andrew Jackson High won its second straight Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field title yesterday at Randalls Island. The Queens school, which captured the indoor title last season, scored 28 1/2 points, 10 more than the runner-up, Boys High.

A 34-year-old prisoner who worked several years perfecting a petition for his freedom may win his release as a result or a decision yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman. The prisoner is serving a fifteen-to-thirty-year sentence for first-degree robbery as a second offender.

PARIS, June 1 -- The Paris "season," a festival that goes on for twelve months for real lovers of the French capital, got under way today with a bright sun beaming on perfumed streets and President de Gaulle beaming on guests at a garden party.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1 -- A 40 per cent increase in Argentine port charges will soon go into effect to finance a tenyear port improvement program valued at $25,000,000, according to an announcement by the secretary of transportation.
MEXICO CITY, June 1 -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee finished its nineteenth plenary session here this evening in the same disagreement with which it opened nine days ago.

The image of man projected by television, radio and the movies is often "poles apart from the Christian understanding of man and his purpose," a National Council of Churches study commission reported here yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The recent U-2 incident and the imminent orbiting of the observational satellite Samos makes acute the difficulty of reducing international tension while continuing to gather information necessary for national security.

A 14-year-old boy who assertedly stabbed his mother to death Tuesday because she had been too strict with him was picked up last night in Brooklyn after he had ridden subway trains for many hours and wandered through Coney Island's amusement area.

Directors of Decca Records, Inc., yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 30 cents a share. It is payable on June 29 to holders of record of June 15. In previous quarters shareholders received 25 cents.

While most women are buying bathing suits, sundresses and shorts, America's designers are busy showing woolly coats, suits and fur-laden dinner costumes. These collections, the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July, attract store executives and buyers from all over the country to New York. The Times fashion staff is attending the showings and will report trends from, significant designerns. Clothes will be in the stores beginning in late July.

A concerted effort to achieve greater public awareness of this country's role as a maritime nation and restoration of the competitive edge of the American merchant marine in foreign trade was proposed here yesterday.
