"Get a horse!" someone yelled yesterday as five muscular men began to push a reluctant little train that had suddenly coughed and stopped-leaving its twenty-five child riders as stranded as commuters.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 1 -- Senator Stuart Symington outlined today an accelerated Federal health program that he indicated he would adopt if elected President.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Administration has become caught in a legal and diplomatic tangle over how to persuade the Russians that a planned series of underground atomic shots does not have a military purpose.
LONDON, June 1 -- Small selling unsettled the stock market here today and almost all the main groups declined.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Lou Schonfeld of Queens College upset second-seeded John Murphy of Iona in the quarter-finals of the sixth annual metropolitan college tennis tournament yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
The Federal Maritime Board granted a waiver yesterday to States Marine Lines, permitting its affiliates to continue foreign-flag shipping operations.

BOTH the New York Yankees and Mickey Mantle have been profuse with apologies for the outfielder's conduct when the adoring multitude swarmed about him at the conclusion of the Memorial Day double-header. Master Mickey hit no one, they said with virtuous unction. Maybe he pushed someone slightly.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals took command on a two-run double by Daryl Spencer and got another run on Ken Boyer's thirteenth homer in a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

WHEN some people arrive in a foreign port they rush off to the nearest museum, cathedral, dressmaker or tailor. When Mrs. Esther Aresty debarks on alien soil she generally heads for the nearest secondhand bookshop.
The loss of population in several cities was viewed yesterday as a warning of decay that might ruin the cores of metropolitan areas that fail to end traffic strangulation.

The unfolding American debate on National Purpose carries the disquieting implication that our traditional purposes though they served the nation well in the past, have somehow been outmoded if not wholly invalidated. This I do not believe to be true.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called today for a permanent special peace and disarmament agency under the Secretary of State as a "symbol of our determination to lead the world away from madness." It was part of a five-point program that he presented as a "grand strategy for peace."
DETROIT, June 1 (UPI) -- Frank Baumann pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 6-0 victory tonight and dealt the Detroit Tigers their fifth straight loss.
ANOTHER chapter of "The A American Way" has been written by the Bigelow Carpet Company, which has adapted a hand-crafted rug process to mass production.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1 (AP) -- Reliable sources disclosed new details today of the capture in Argentina of Adolf Eichmann by Israeli agents in one of the most dramatic cloak-and-dagger stories of the post-war world.

The opening-day card at Belmont Park yesterday was an artistic success, with the feature race presenting as close and as tingling a finish as any of the 23,291 customers could expect. The favorite players, though, could well have waived the artistic part of the deal in favor of a more practical result -- for their preference wasn't even in the money.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would accept the $1,000 increase in take-home pay for which he is eligible in the fiscal year starting July 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- The big California Democratic mystery drama "Where Do We Go From Here?" transferred its settings to San Francisco today after a sellout, $100-a-seat, one-night stand in Los Angeles.
CHICAGO, June 1 (UPI) -- Beatrice Food Company announced today an international expansion program beginning with the construction of a dairy processing plant in Malaya.
The effects of contemporary social and cultural practices in causing major diseases were explored here yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 1 -- The provisional Government said tonight that 403 Deputies of the majority Democratic party of deposed Premier Adnan Menderes were under arrest and would be investigated for crimes against the state.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (UPI) -- Bob Buhl halted a four-game Milwaukee losing streak tonight when he pitched the Braves to a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and Robin Roberts.
PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP) -- Bob Friend allowed only three hits tonight in pitching the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

The Creative Club, Inc., is sponsoring a gala champagne preview of an exhibition of paintings and sculptures by thirty American artists at the Galerle Norval at 53 East Fifty-seventh Street next Tuesday evening.
TOKYO, June 1 -- Members of the Socialist party in the House of Representatives decided today to resign en masse from the National Diet (Parliament).
SYRACUSE, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller told Republicans here today that he would head the New York delegation at the party's national convention in Chicago next month.
The Bawl Street Journal, the bond community's $l-a-copy satire on life in the financial district, is slated to make its annual appearance today.
Volume three of Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s "The Age of Roosevelt," which will be published by Houghton Mifflin, has been chosen as the September selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.
YONKERS, June 1 -- Seven of the world's crack pacers will start Yonkers Raceway's international series at a mile and a half in the $50,000 International Pace tomorrow night.

Two British actresses, Cathleen Nesbitt and, Vivien Leigh, expressed' their displeasure yesterday with the stand taken by Actors Equity Association in its contract negotiations with the League of New York Theatres.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 1 -- As a result of a two-year study, the Bergen County Planning Board has recommended the drawing up of a highway master plan for the county.
A greater role by universities in domestic and world affairs was advocated yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.

Following are excerpts from the statement "The Church and the Mass Media," presented, yesterday by the National Council of Churches Study Commission on the Role of Radio, Television and Films in Religion:
Stocks backed and filled, yesterday and then picked upt momentum in the afternoon's trading to close with a small gain for the day.
In a rough soccer match in Which players of both teams spent considerable time lifting themselves off the ground, Kilmarnock defeated Burnley, 2 -- 0 at the Polo Grounds last night.

If the decennial United States census shows a reduction in New York City's population it will not be wholly unexpected, although it will be the first time a decade has not shown an increase since 1790. But, loss of population or not, New York City has certainly reached at least a temporary plateau as to people living here.

A store in the building at 300 Park Avenue South, corner of Twenty-second Street, has been leased by the Will Baumer Candle Company, 105-year-old manufacturer of candles with a factory and main office in Syracuse, N. Y. The lessees will move from 15 East Thirty-second Street, where they have been since 1925.

The Columbia-Geneva Steel division of the United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that construction would begin immediately on a major new iron ore mining and beneficiating Operation in Fremont County, Wyoming.

May sales volume in the eight major New York department stores and their metropolitan branches were 2.6 per cent above the 1959 level, a survey yesterday by The New York Times disclosed. The results were not cheering for all retailers.

Nature Minus Bald Spots This is the best season of all in which to celebrate a birthday, especially if a man is of an age at which it is neither desirable nor safe to put a candle on a cake for each year he has managed to survive.
Television film producers met here yesterday with representatives of more than a half-dozen major advertising agencies to discuss the effect of the writers' strike on next season's schedule.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that "probing action" by Communist China was likely following the failure of the summit conference.
Despite New York City's two-year-old Fair Housing Practices Law, there is still considerable discrimination in private housing here, a group of visiting officials learned yesterday.

Alberta Gas Trunk Line Company, Ltd,, announced yesterday that it expected to market in October four separata securities issues aggregating $110,000,000. Of the total, $65,000,000 in first mortgage bonds would be sold in the United States and the remainder of the securities in Canada.

YESTERDAY (June 1,1960) THE PRESIDENT Spoke to delegates to second Atlantic Conference of Young Political Leaders; saw New Zealand Prime Minister Walter Nash; received delegations from West Point and Annapolis; saw Budget Director Stans; visited wife in hospital; spoke briefly to Boy Scouts of America at golden anniversary dinner.

SEOUL, Korea, June 1 (AP) -- Former President Syngman Rhee's Liberal party collapsed today as 104 of the 138 party members in the South Korean National Assembly announced they had become indeepndents.
THE ORGANIZATIONS Actors Equity Association's members are all professional actors. It has a membership of close to 12,000. Eleven hundred are now employed in Broadway productions.
MOSCOW, June 1 -- This capital is beginning to see the results of a trend toward freer economic competition among state enterprises and organizations.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A Senate committee was told today that the United States space agency was trapped in the original lie about the U-2 plane incident because of pressure to put out a statement on the case before policy had been decided.
The collapse of the summit conference has made it clear that the world is "back in the harsher phases of the cold war," Frank Pace Jr., former Secretary of the Army, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Clearing weather over much of the Midwest and the improved outlook for planting brought moderate liquidation in corn futures today and that grain led a rather general set-back on the Board of Trade.

THE drawing collection of Walter C. Baker, familiar in part through loans of individual items in various exhibitions over many years, is now on loan as a unit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Opening today, the exhibition will remain on view until Sept. 4.

The Estate Securities Company, representing Alvin A. Levy and Irving Magot, realty operators, has resold the twelve story loft building at 338-40 West Thirty-ninth Street after an ownership of one month. The building, which was constructed in 1927, contains 40,000 square feet of loft space and is assessed at $275,000.

An issue of $40,000,000 in debentures of the National Cash Register Company, Dayton, Ohio, is being offered to the public today. The offering is being made by investment bankers headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

HAVANA, June 1 -- A Government radio commentator said today the United States Government had put pressure on Joe Louis to force him to withdraw from acting as a publicity agent for the National Institute of Tourism.

Directors of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York voted yesterday to establish $1 a share as the amount of the regular quarterly dividend, something sought by shareholders since the merger in April of last year of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
MIAMI BEACH, June 1 -- The Amalgamated clothing Workers of America accused the Eisenhower Administration today of relying on "inadequate and ill-conceived" policies in its search for peace.

FASHION now belongs to the masses . . . the day of e fashion leader, the great individualist, is gone," Bettina Ballard, fashion consultant and former editor of Vogue magazine, said yesterday. Mrs. Ballard addressed the twenty-third annual graduation luncheon of e Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Dividend increases, always music to the stockholder's ear, have been in diminuendo for two successive months. The Standard and Poor's Corporation, the investment advisory and statistical concern, reported yesterday that but seventy-four companies raised dividends last month, compared with eighty-one in May, 1959.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- The movie industry reclaimed a bit of its original studio from television today with the glee of the Dutch gathering land from the sea.

BONN, Germany, June 2 -- The General Electric Company has lost out in a bid for a dominant place in the reviving West German aircraft engine industry. The board of the Bavarian Motor Works (BMW) of Munich decided last night to turn down General Electric's financial "rescue" offer in favor of an offer by a German company, the Augsburg-Nuremberg Machine Company (MAN).

The New York Post's suit for the right to inspect the records of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority was argued in State Supreme Court yesterday. Justice Louis J. Capozzoli reserved decision in the case.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In the great debate now going on concerning the American spy plane and the break-up of the summit conference, it was to be hoped that high Administration officials would re-examine the very fundamentals of United States policy toward the Soviet Union and other Communist countries.
CHICAGO, June 2 -- The national convention of the Textile Workers Union of America voted today to give Emil Rieve, its former president, an "annual honorarium of $15,000, payable weekly."

BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Washington Senators beat the Boston Red Sox twice today, 8 -- 3 in the opener and 8 -- 7 in the ten-inning second game. The Senators thus climbed to seventh place and dropped the Red Sox to last.

The International Finance Corporation, equity financing affiliate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development [World Bank], announced yesterday that it had made its first investment in Africa.

ADEN, June 2 (UPI) -- British diplomats said today they were checking reports the 65year-old Imam Ahmad of Yemen had died and his son, the Crown Prince, was suppressing the news in order to establish authority over his 5,000,000 subjects in the face of a revolt.

BALTIMORE, June 2 -- The muffled Yankee bats boomed at last tonight, but to no avail The high-flying Orioles, on few er but louder hits, handed the Bombers their third straight defeat, 6-5, before a roaring throng of 42,755 at Memorial Stadium.

Jazz concerts have been booked cheek by jowl with symphony orchestras at Carnegie Hall and with string quartets at Town Hall for many years. But, until last night, they had never broken the leasehold of sports, circuses and rallies at Madison Square Garden.
(June 2, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met With Republican Congressional leaders; saw Labor Secretary Mitchell; played golf; visited wife in hospital.

The curtain stayed down on all Broadway stages last night as actors and producers failed to resolve their differences. The producers pledged they would keep the theatres dark until the contract deadlock over pay and pensions was broken.
UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., June 2 -- The Soviet Union offered a revised proposal on disarmament today.

The six-story building containing seventy-two apartments at 1475 Wythe Place, corner of 172d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $445,000.

Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes Union, which masterminded the strike of the nonprofessional hospital workers last spring, is now taking a vote of its members in ten voluntary institutions as to another walkout. As we have often said before, we now repeat: There should never be a hospital strike-and, while there is no law against it now, there certainly ought to be one.
PARIS, June 2 -- The hidden riches of the Louvre were put on public display today.

ST. STEPHEN, N. B., June 2 -- There is a weather Jonah in residence around here and if the truth ever prevails, the chances are that his name will turn out to be Fred Brisley. But it is very difficult to expose a Jonah, and impossible to exorcise him.

The widow of a man killed in an airplane crash won a new trial yesterday in a $350,000 damage suit in which she was awarded only $24,000. A United States judge ruled she should not have been questioned in the original trial about premarital relations with her husband.
NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., June 2 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells won low-gross honors today in the opening oneday tournament of the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.
WASHINGTON, June 2 --An emergency board recommended today wage increases of roughly 10 1/2 cents an hour a year for a two- or three-year contract covering 4,700 Pan American Airways ground employes.

Broadway's legitimate theatres were dark last night. But under the unlighted bulbs of their celebrated marquees actors, producers and ticket-holders staged unrehearsed shows until just past curtain time.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Truck loadings for the week ended May 28 were slightly below the levels of the corresponding week of last year, while a slight rise was reported from the level of the week before.
LONDON, June 2 -- Britain "stands with her allies" prepared to "defend the just rights of the free world," Prime Minister Macmillan declared today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I have just read your editorial of May 28 "A Hulan Jack Trial" and I feel you have unwittingly (certainly not with intent) advocated a course not only unjust from a moral standpoint but particularly so from a legal standpoint of the present status of the Hulan Jack matter.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- President Elsenhower called today for prompt action by Congress on sugar legislation recommended by his Administration last March.
LONDON, June 2 -- Prices generally moved downward on the stock market here today despite a late rally in a few of the top equities.
OTTAWA, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- The interest rate of the Bank of Canada eased today to 3.17 per cent from 3.26 last week with the sale of $95,000,000 in ninety-one-day Treasury bills.

HARLECH, Wales, June 2 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire Staved off a strong rally by Philomena Garvey of Ireland today for a 4-and-2 victory that added the British women's amateur golf championship to her United States title.

The Mayor's Management Survey making its final report in 1953 declared that "the pension system of New York City requires a systematic and careful modernization." It found not one pension "system," but sixteen, and advised that they be consolidated, reconciled along more uniform patterns and placed on a rational and reasonable basis.

THE Bowes Cup and the Seymour Salt, the prized possessions of the Wardens and Commonalty of the Mystery of Goldsmiths of the City of London, arrived safely, if prosaically, in two leather hatboxes on a plane from London this week.

THE first in what may become a series of intercity bridge matches will be played between eight-man teams representing New York and Los Angeles on Aug. 11 and 12 in Los Angeles, and Nov. 17 and 18 in New York.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 2 -- The committee of military officers who overthrew the Menderes regime last week has set itself up as the supreme voice of Turkey instead of as the Turkish provisional Government.
DETROIT, June 2 (UPI) -- Four New York men charged with eleven counts of mail fraud will get a new trial in September, Federal Judge Frank Picard said today.
A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was murdered in gangland style early yesterday a few hours before he was scheduled to appear as a defendant in court.

Ray Robinson, who is preparing for a middleweight match fight with Paul Fender in Boston a week from tonight, ran into new difficulty yesterday. He was suspended by the New York State Athletic Commission.

IT is nine years now since the publication Of "Lie Down in Darkness," by William Styron, a first novel by a young man then 26 that was received with hosannahs of critical applause. That brilliant and powerful book was sufficiently impressive'for most readers to ignore or forgive its needless complexity of form, its solemn pretentiousness and its sensation- alism.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 12 points (60 cents) up yesterday. The near months were weakest.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders called today for a legislative speed-up. They indicated that President Eisenhower did not like the idea of an extra clean-up session after the political conventions.
SPRING LAKE, N. J. -- Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Maplewood won the low-gross prize in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament today with a 41, 38 -- 79 at the Spring Lake Country Club.

A Baltimore maker of small pleasure boats, Sealander, Inc., has recognized a fact that nearly every outboard skipper knows -- little craft are Ideal for crosscountry cruising expeditions where they can be towed by the family's automobile and launched down, ramps at many an Inland lake or river for fishing, camping or lazy vacationing.
ALBANY, june 2 -- New equalization rates for New York City were announced today by the State Board Equalization and Assessments.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that the library Is considering encroaching on Bryant Park, are we to lose mere of the little bit of green space remaining in the city?
The General Board of the National Council of Churches voted yesterday to back lunchcounter sit-ins and other nonviolent protests against discriminatory laws.

The Federal Reserve supported its easier money policy in the week ended Wednesday by the purchase of $318,700,000 of Treasury bills in the open market, it was disclosed yesterday. At the same time, it permitted the last of its Government securities held under dealer repurchase agreement, some $300,000, to be redeemed.

A machine that sorts checks twelve times faster than by hand has been put in operation by Chemical Bank New York Trust Company. Initially, it will be used to put In numerical account order the 12,000,000 checks drawn each year by the bank's 115,000 special checking account customers.

JOHN DENNIS PROFUMO, the 45 - year - old British Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, is a curious mixture of a gay-young-man-abouttown and an extremely serious politician and foreign affairs student.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The trends toward accelerating consumer installment indebtedness and decelerating business inventory accumulation continued in April, according to official estimates published today.

A new silhouette has appeared in the growing city of the air at Idlewild, Queens. This shadow, which from a distance would never be recognized as a terminal building, belongs to Pan American World Airways.
Southern Electric Generating Company, Birmingham, Ala., borrowed 40,000,000 on the public capital market yesterday at a net interest cost of 5.2461 per cent.

The price rally in the bond market moved forward at an accelerated pace yesterday. United States Government securities advanced as much as 20/32 of a point and high-grade corporate bonds rose up to 1 1/4 points.
A sharp increase in United States defense spending at this time will "play into the Russians' hands," according to Franklin D. Lincoln, Assistant Secretary of Defense.
CAMDEN, N.J., June 2 (AP) -- At dawn on Saturday the Savannah, world's first atomic-powered merchant ship, will glide into drydock at the New York Shipbuilding Yards.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Atomic Energy Commission expects to transfer some of its regulatory control over atomic concerns in New York State to the state before the end of the year.
JERICHO, L.I., June 2 -- A self-employed bulldozer operator unearthed a metal ammunition box today that contained more than $70,000 in cash. The money, in tens, twenties
The Department of City Plan ning has discovered In a recent survey some indications of a population trend back to the city from the suburbs.

EPSOM, England, June 2 (AP) -- Petite Etoile, the champion 4-year-old filly from the stables of the late Aly Khan, decisively defeated two outstanding colts in the Coronation Cup of a mile and a half today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The council of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization ended its sixth annual meeting today. It reported an intensification of "Communist subversion insurgency and terrorism in several countries of the treaty area."
BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- The president of the United Steelworkers proposed today that Congress enact a new fair labor standards law reducing the work week to thirty or thirtytwo hours.

DETROIT, June 2 (UPI) -- Charlie Maxwell's eight-inning home run, his second of the game, led the Detroit Tigers to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight. It enabled the Tigers to break a five-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Federal Reserve System, taking note of diminished inflationary psychology in the economy, let up on one of its main instruments of restraint today. The Board of Governors authorized two of the twelve Federal Reserve banks to reduce their discount rates from 4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent.
GENEVA, June 2 -- The Soviet Union said today that it must be a full partner in the United States' program of underground nuclear explosions designed to test detection techniques.
Copper prices on the Commodity Exchange of New York rose 35 to 72 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on 769 lots of 50,000 pounds each. Volume was the fourth highest of the year.
THE ORGANIZATIONS Actors Equity Association members are all professional actors. It has a membership of close to 12,000. Seven hundred thirty-one are now employed in Broadway productions.

A noted theoretical physicist has proposed that astronomer's search the heavens for darkened stars that might be obscured by gigantic shells of planetary substance that were constructed around them by advanced civilizations.
CHICAGO, June 2 -- Senator John F. Kennedy charged today that the Elsenhower Administration had failed to fulfill the nation's responsibilities as a world power during its eightyear tenure.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today the Security Council debate on the U-2 plane incident showed that "the 'cold war' may be reduced in the United Nations and not necessarily increased."

The Gulf Power Company has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to register $5,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds and 50,000 shares of $100 par cumulative preferred stock. Proceeds of the sale of the securities would be used for expansion and the repayment of bank loans.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A former medical officer of the Food and Drug Administration charged today that "hundreds of people suffer daily and many die" because of the "utter failure" of the agency to police the safety and misbranding of drugs.
The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., may pass under new control.

Texaco, Inc., sponsor of the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts on standard network radio since 1931, is arranging its own special hookup of stations for next season. The special network will consist of from ninety-five to 100 stations, all of which must agree to carry the opera live.
HAVANA, June 2 -- The Auxiliary Bishop of Havana condemned totalitarian methods and called for respect for private property in an address at Villanova University which was published today.
TRENTON, June 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner's proposed income tax on New York-New Jersey commuters is slated to go to the floor of the Assembly for a vote on Monday
The shutdown of the Broadway playhouses last night affected restaurant, hotel and travel business and made other changes in the city's business and social life.
After an indecisive start, stocks rallied yesterday afternoon to score a good gain for the day in active trading.
PARIS, June 2 -- Britain took a tentative step today toward breaking the deadlock between Europe's rival trade blocs.
A West Coast symposium on consumer attitudes has come to the conclusion that neither a national brand nor a private label enjoys a decisive advantage in the battle for sales.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following is an unofficial translation of a cablegram dated May 30 from Premier Khrushchev to the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Sam Rayburn; Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Senate Majority Leader; Adlai E. Stevenson, and Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as made public by Senator Johnson:
CHICAGO, June 2 -- Following is the text of an address today by Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, at the national convention of the Textile Workers Union of America:
NEWARK, June 2 -- A special three-judge panel in Federal Court here today refused for a second time to bar enforcement of New Jersey's Sunday sales ban.

A new monument has been proposed for Washington. Plans were announced yesterday for a 24,000,000 Freedom Shrine to be built on Federal park land overlooking the Potomac River adjoining Arlington National Cemetery.
Two years ago a 50-year-old woman office worker gave up dreaming about Caribbean cruises, caviar, clothing and a car, and began taking cruises, eating caviar and buying clothes and the car.
LOS ANGELES, June 2 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs, paced by Frank Thomas"three-run homer, tonight unleashed their heaviest hitting attack of the season to. defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 10 -- 8.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Representative Gordon H. Scherer accused Representative James Roosevelt today of taking a Communist line in attacking the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The other day anyYoung Man one who happened to Through have been looking a Door down into the street from a certain window in this department might have seen a young man pause, on the opposite sidewalk below, take a firmer grip on the handle of a small brown suitcase he was carrying and, after looking up at the building in front of him, disappear through a doorway.

Medical records from around the world were studied here yesterday afternoon in an effort to find whether stresses imposed on Negroes who move into urban communities were responsible for their higher blood pressure.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 2 -- The 1,500,000-member American Baptist Convention rallied forces today in an effort to defeat proposals that it withdraw from the National Council of Churches.

Twenty Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island men were sentenced and fined yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on charges of defrauding the Government of more than $500,000 by expediting Federal Housing Administration loans illegally.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 14 per cent above the year-earlier levels.

Figures obtained yesterday from representatives of twentytwo Broadway shows on salaries paid to Equity members indicate that ninety-three out of a total of 731 performers were receiving the Equity minimum salary of $103.50 a week.
TANGIER, Morocco, June 2 -- United States policy in Africa is moving toward closer cooperation with France and away from independent action in regions associated with or formerly attached to France.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 2 -- The population of Nassau and Suffolk Counties has more than doubled in the last decade, according to preliminary Federal census figures released today.

Four buildings owned by the Edwin Gould Foundation for Children in the Park Slope secton of Brooklyn were described to the City Planning Commission yesterday as "rat-infested, impainted and uncleaned" and "a serious health menace."

Hermod, a 4-year-old bay gelding by the Irish sire Royal Charger out of the Count Fleet mare Sequence, set a course record at Belmont Park yesterday in winning the Belmont National Hurdle Stakes by three-quarters of a length from Tuscarora.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 (UPI) -- Home runs by Ken Boyer and Joe Cunningham powered the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.

MIAMI BEACH, June 2 -- The convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America voted unanimously today to use strikes, boycotts and other economic weapons to war on import competition from Japan and other low-wage countries abroad.

A new issue of $100,000,000 of general revenue bonds of the New York State Power Authority is slated to be placed on the market on or about June 21. The issue is being negotiated between the authority and a syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Kuhn, Loeb Co. and W.H. Morton Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The official recount will be required to determine how many of Alabama's eleven Presidential electors will be authorized by the voters to cast their ballots in December for any citizen they may choose for President, regardless of which party national ticket carries the state in November.

As has happened so often in the past, the aggressive Soviet policy which scuttled the summit meeting has again had a profound impact on the West. Like Czechoslovakia and Korea, which prompted the creation and expansion of Western defense alliances, the Paris debacle has forced the West to subordinate differences and to close ranks not only over immediate issues but also in the search for a "more perfect union."
DEVON, Pa., June 2 -- Grey Aero, owned by Frank Imperatore of Cannonsburg, Pa., won the open jumper $500 Puissance Stake at the Devon horse show tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A Senate inquiry was told today that the nation's chief defense and foreign policy advisers agreed May 9 that President Excerpts from testimony by Gates are on Page 2. Eisenhower should take responsibility for the U-2 espionage flight over the Soviet Union.
PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) -- How does a 17-year-old boy feel with thirteen major league scouts beating a path to his doorstep?

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 1 -- A Congolese nationalist leader, Patrice Lum umba, charged today that the "highest Belgian officials" were conspiring to thwart his becoming the first Premier of independent Congo.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that Premier Khrushchev was trying to divide the American people but was not going to succeed in his effort. The Senate leader thus characterized a cablegram he and three other Democrats had received from the Soviet Premier.
A contract for the purchase of the seven-story apartment building at 16 to 24 East Ninety-sixth Street, southwest corner of Madison Avenue, has been signed by Fischer-Landis, realty investors.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- The Philippines today broke off negotiations with the United States on a new trans-Pacific civil air agreement after United States negotiators refused several Philippine requests.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A Pentagon official said today that in a communications exercise, the Defense Department merely tested its ability to send and receive military messages to the remotest parts of the world.

The first Actors Equity Association strike against theatre owners began on Aug. 7, 1919. Before it was over thirty days later, it had spread to Chicago, Boston, Washington and other cities in the East and Midwest.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. June 2 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams gave his support today to Senator John F. Kennedy's bid for the Democratic nominatior for President.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A bill that would ban use of color additives in food, cosmetics and drugs if found to induce cancer in humans or animals was approved today by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

THIS Sunday the Long Island Strawberry Auction rolls into action at Riverhead. This should assure an even larger supply of the sun-ripened fruit from near-by gardens. Strawberries are already in enough supply to be one of the more reasonably priced fruits for this week-end.
The police staged a raid at the Sherry-Netherlands Hotel yesterday in a move to break what was termed a vice ring employing teen-age girls.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UPI) -- Bob Rush, a Milwaukee relief pitcher, struck put two batters in the ninth inning with the tying run on second base tonight to preserve a 9-8 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

The administration of travel funds in the House is apparently as loose as the sense of public ethics of a few of its members seems to be. That is the doleful conclusion to be drawn from the disclosure that some Congressmen have been charging up to the public sizable expenditures that look as though by any normal accounting they should have been incurred as private expenses.
Motorists drained 2,475,000 barrels of gasoline from the nation's stocks in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This is the ninth consecutive weekly decline.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 2 (UPI) -- Three seasoned pros and a young newcomer toured the Colonial Country Club golf course in five-under-par 65's today shared the first-round lead in the $30,000 Memphis open.

YONKERS, June 2 -- At a mile and a quarter next week it may be different. But at mile and a half tonight, Widower Creed proved clearly superior to the six others in the field and easily won the first leg of the International Pace Series at Yonkers Raceway.

When President Eisenhower invited Prime Minister Diefenbaker of Canada two months ago to visit Washington and today's date was set, neither man could have known that the summit meeting was going to be a complete failure. It would in any case have been useful to review United States-Canadian relations and to discuss informally world conditions.
The city is going to star paying prisoners a small sum for work for the first time starting July 1, Correction Com missioner Anna M. Kross disclosed yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 -- Ghana urged today that the International Court of Justice end South African control over the neighboring territory of South West Africa.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 21 (Reuters) -- A new Laotian Cabinet, headed by Prince Tiaio Somsanith, former Minister of the Interior, was announced here today.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- The revised Soviet plan for total disarmament, that was forwarded today was the one that Premier Khrushchev intended as his compromise offer to the West at the summit conference.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today a cut-down version of legislation to create new Federal judgeships.

AMID the inky darkness of the theatre district there is one bright gleam -- the "Grand Kabuki," which opened at the City Center last evening. Since they have done us the honor of trekking all the way from Japan, it is fortunate that the blackout does not include them.

The net income of the Minute Maid Corporation rose 30 per cent in the Six months ended May 1 on a sales gain of 29 per cent, over the level of the 1959 period, John M. Fox, president, reported in the semi-annual statement to stockholders.

Tidal waves that struck South America and islands of the Pacific last week were a hard blow to the cultured pearl industry. The disaster, the second within a year, might force many American and foreign dealers out of business, according to trade sources.
Rehearsals proceeded yesterday in Central Park for the free showing of Shakespeare's "King Henry V," despite the Broadway dispute that has closed twenty-two plays and musicals.

With the likelihood that the doubles match may possibly decide the outcome of the Davis Cup challenge round this year, as it has so often in the past, the United States Lawn Tennis Association is giving particular attention this year to the development of a doubles team.

MARSHFIELD, Wis., June 1 (AP) -- The Weyerhaeuser Company, one of the nation's leading forest-products concerns, has purchased the Roddis Plywood Corporation, a joint announcement by the two concerns said today.

Adoption of a plan for combining the businesses of Lynch Corporation, Anderson, Ind, and Symphonic Electronic Corporation, here, has been announced by the companies' directors. The plan, subject to stockholder approval, calls for an exchange of stock.
ALBANY, June 2 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that two Democratic State Senators from Queens could not be denied the Liberal party nomination.

SID Caesar headed the cast of another variety show over Channel 2 last night. Like his programs that preceded it this season, it was in depressing contrast with some of his brilliant comedy efforts of the past.
A sternly phrased Supreme Court Injunction ordered the owners of a West Side tenement yesterday to halt "willful and continuous disregard" of the building and health codes.
A 26 - YEAR - OLD German model, who once worked for $40 a month as an interpreter for a car company, has just joined the slim ranks of the world's best-looking, best-paid models.

BONN, Germany, June 2 -- Eight years after giving its for mal promise, the West German Government has now moved to compensate its citizens for losses caused by wartime Allied seizures of German property.
LONDON, June 2 (UPI) -- Demand for every kind of paper and paper product is on the rise, Sir Eric Bowater, chairman of the Bowater Paper Company, said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 -- Following, as translated from the Russian, is the text of a Soviet letter on disarmament sent to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold by Arkady A. Sobolev, Soviet representative to the United Nations, and made public today by the United Nations:

The Public Education Association, which has been working since 1895 to better the city's schools and colleges will be the beneficiary of the Oct. 6 performance of the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- Suporters of Senators Kennedy and Symington predicted today that Governor Brown would find It difficult to control the California delegation at the Democratic National Convention.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 2 -- Although Henry Dreyfuss will be here and his wife, Doris, will be in San Francisco, they will both hear the Sarah Lawrence College commencement tomorrow at which their daughter will receive a Bachelor of Arts degree.

NORTON, Va., June 2-The father of Francis G. Powers, pilot of the U-2 plane downed by the Russians, said tonight that he had been promised "help" by Premier Khrushchev if he went to the Soviet Union to see his son.

While most women are buying bathing suits, sundresses and shorts, America's designers are busy showing woolly coats, suits and fur-laden dinner costumes. These collections, the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July, attract store executives and buyers from all over the country to New York. The Times fashion staff is attending the showings and will report trends from significant designers.

If Actors Equity succeeds in winning a pension plan and a general wage increase, its achievement will have widespread repercussions for allied theatrical unions. Eight such unions would then expect to obtain similar benefits.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 2 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians snapped Kansas City's fivegame winning streak tonight, 7 -- 6, on home runs by Tito Francona, Woody Held and John Romano.

A new book by Hugh Seton-Watson, author of "From Lenin to Khrushchev" and other works on Soviet affairs, will be issued June 16 by Praeger. Called "Neither War Nor Peace," it gives a history of postwar international relations and an analysis of the underlying problems of the "cold war."

MOSCOW, June 2 -- Boris Pasternak was given a poet's burial today under three tall pine trees on a flowering hill in his beloved Russian countryside. More than 1,000 friends, neighbors, writers, artists and actors came to pay tribute.
ALBANY, June 2 -- Governor Rockefeller insisted today that he was still trying to make up his mind whether to attend the Republican National Convention in Chicago next month.

Retailers' Salute to Lincoln Center Week has been proclaimed by Mayor Wagner to run from today to June 10, more than fifty department stores and retail shops here are cooperating in a window display program featuring Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- W. Averell Harriman recommended today that President Eisenhower swallow his pride and visit the Soviet Union if he received a new invitation.

LONDON, June 2 -- Structural demands of air-conditioning and electronic equipment have placed new limitations on exterior design of tall office buildings, Ely Jacques Kahn, New York architect, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A bill to provide health care for the aged that embodies neither the Social Security principle nor the Administration's private insurance plan neared approval today in the House Ways and Means Committee.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley shot 37, 34 -- 71 today at Glen Daks and won the Women's Cross County Golf Association husband-and-wife championship for the fourth time.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Court of Appeals in effect stripped Martin F. O'Donoghue today of effective leadership of the court-appointed board of monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The next batch of House expense account vouchers opened for public inspection may be screened ahead of time by the House Administration Committee.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Neither Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut nor the Logan Act is anachronistic, as Robert Taber charges in his letter printed May 25. In a recent speech before the Senate! Senator J. W. Fulbright declared:

CHUCK STOBBS, the Senators' artful left-hander, beat the Yankees on Memorial Day, with relief, help from Truman Clevenger, 2 to 1. It was a singular display of tightrope walking because the Bombers had runners in scoring position constantly. If Stobbs was a mite lucky, that fact left him unperturbed.

AS brilliant in color as any painting in the Greenwich Village outdoor art show is the open-air produce market of Louis Balducci, 1 Greenwich Avenue, corner of the Avenue of the Americas. An inviting display of the freshest, the ripest and the finest fruits and vegetables draws 1,700 to 1,800 customers to that market every day.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 2 -- An influx from the metropolitan area has increased the population of Middlesex County by 63.2 per cent since 1950, from 264,872 to a 1960 figure of 432,282, according to census figures released today.
FRESNO, Calif., June 2 -- Senator Stuart Symington campaigned through the California farm heartland today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following are excerpts from the censored transcript of the testimony today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. on the U-2 plane incident and the failure of the summit conference:

CALCUTTA, India, June 2 -- Tibetans have waged heavy fighting with Chinese Communist troops in southern Tibet in recent weeks, according to reports from reliable sources in Gangtok, capital of Sikkim. Hundreds of Tibetans have fled into northern Sikkim in the wake of the warfare.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's Presidential campaign moved into a new phase today with the formation, of a national campaign organization and a hopeful gesture toward New York State.
CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Buyers were scarce again today in the grain futures market and prices slipped Into their broadest setbacks of the week In spots.
State Controller Arthur Levtj injected himself into the Wes Side Democratic primary batti yesterday with a strong ;ier dorsement of State Senator Joh H. Farrell.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- The Textile Workers Union of America declared today that its local at Front Royal, Va., had violated the union's constitution by offering financial aid to a segregated private school.

TWO Hungarians, the late Robert Darvas and his friend Paul Lukacs (who is now a resident of Israel), have a permanent place in bridge literature because of the many hands they have constructed or reported to illustrate card-playing principles.
ROME, June 3 (AP)-Rome, the city of the Colosseum and the Circus Maximus, today unveiled a sports arena that could rival those ancient monuments as a tourist attraction.
Hofstra gained five berths on the thirteen-player Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference all-star team, announced yesterday by the coaches of the eight member schools.

Prices on New York commodity exchanges rose irregularly in dull trading yesterday. Lead, sinc, soybean oil, cocoa and cottonseed oil rose; potatoes, pepper and eggs declined, and price movements in hides, rubber and coffee were mixed.
COMPTON, Calif., June 3 (AP) -- Herb Ellibtt of Adstralia, the world record-holder, cracked the 4-minute mile with ease tonight, 'winning the Compton Relays feature in 3:59.2.

YESTERDAY (June 3, I960) THE PRESIDENT Received stamp album honoring "The American Woman" from Postmaster General Summerfield; met with Cabinet; saw Australian Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies and Canadian Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker; entertained at dinner for Mr. and Mrs. Diefenbaker; vetoed two tax bills because of retroactive, features.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 4 -- The police and students battled briefly but bloodily in the grounds of Premier Nobusuke Kishi's official residence yesterday. The clash took place as campus Leftist organizations staged another massive protest march against the Kishi Government, the new United States-Japanese security treaty and President Eisenhower's scheduled visit beginning June 19.

A couple of young strikers got diplomas yesterday -- not for striking, of course -- but for graduating from the Professional Children's School. That is the forty-six-year-old private school (first through twelfth grade) for child actors.

CHICAGO, June 3 (UPI) -- Stevedore and shipping concerns turned down a new union proposal today that sliced 9 cents off previous demands as negotiations continued in a Great Lakes dock workers' strike.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 3 -- The population of Monmouth County, surging upward with new housing and new industry, has increased 47.8 per cent since 1950.
The steel industry's operating rate in the Youngstown district is scheduled to show a sharp recovery next week, with output rising from 27 to 41 per cent of capacity.
The Department of Parks yesterday restored a contract with Panorama Sightseeing Boat Cruises, Inc. The company will be permitted to resume operations Monday.
Willard R. Booth has been elected treasurer of the Goodyear International Corporation. He will continue to serve as an assistant treasurer of the parent Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
MOSCOW, June 3 -- Premier Khrushchev continued his campaign of scorn and vilification of President Eisenhower, Vice President Nixon and other United States leaders today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Arthur S. Flemming ordered today an investigation by non-governmental scientists into charges that the Food and Drug Administration had failed to assure the safety and proper branding of new drugs.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 3 (AP) -- Johnny Longden, racing's most successful jockey, with 5,413 winners, today said he planned to retire at the end of the Hollywood Park season on July 25.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Premier Khrushchev's outburst against President Eisenhower was regarded generally here today as a calculated attempt to influence the United States Presidential election.
LONDON, June 3 -- The stock market threw off yesterday's dullness, although the demand was selective and light.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- An American heiress has left a million-dollar fortune to ease the plight of European refugees.

Bob Turley failed last night for the fifth time this season to go all the way at the Stadium However, Johnny James and Bobby Shantz supplied the flawless relief pitching the Yankee needed to turn back the late threat of the Boston Red Sox and win, 4 -- 3.

Major offerings of fixed-interest securities of municipalities and private utilities will dominate the new capital market next week. A lively week is in prospect with more than $163,000,000 of securities listed on the calendar.

The wave of mergers and acquisitions in the paper industry shows no sign of slowing. This has been demonstrated in recent weeks with the successful bid of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company to gain control of the United States Envelope Company and the possibility of the acquisition of the Crossett Company by the Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation.

A FEW one-man shows emerge from this week's heavy cluster of groups. At the ACA Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, are paintings by Peter Gilleran, a Michigan artist and winner of the ACA's 1959 competition.

Because of numerous inquiries arising from its suspension of Ray Robinson on Thursday, the New York State Athletic Commission cleared up a point yesterday. It said it would recognize the Robinson-Paul Fender bout at Boston next Friday night as a middleweight championship fight.

FARGO, N.D., June 3 -- Governor Rockefeller arrived here by chartered plane this afternoon and immediately plunged into a special Senate-election campaign that he said would have "tremendous psychological effect across the nation."
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower vetoed today two bills designed to liberalize tax laws covering unemployment levies and charitable contributions.

Anthony (Tony Cheese) Marchitto, a leader on the New Jersey waterfront, ended a week-long stay in the Hudson County jail yesterday when he decided to comply with a subpoena served on him by the Waterfront Commission.

BETTER two acts of "The Cherry Orchard" than none. The first and last aets, were performed yesterday afternoon before, an invited audience of actors by other actors who are still plugging away at their craft at the Institute for Advanced Studies in the Theatre Arts, above the Maidman Playhouse in Forty-second Street.
NEW DELHI, India, June 3 -- Thirty-five thousand Tibetans are reported to have been forced by the Chinese Communists to help build a railroad from China to Lhasa, Tibetan capital.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 3 -- Given the nod by both the weather man and the Federal Reserve System, the nation's top bond executives relaxed to their heart's content here today on the golf courses and beneath the towering trees of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Spies and safecrackers can solve lock combinations by X-ray photography, without leaving any telltale marks on the safe. To thwart such operations, three technicians at the Naval Ordnance Laboratory in Silver Spring, Md., have invented a radiation-proof lock.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 3 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis won the opening tournament of the women's Tri-County Golf Association today.
The bond market chalked up its biggest gains in months yesterday in the wake of the reduction in the discount rate in two Federal Reserve Districts.
EPSOM, England, June 3 (AP) -- Never Too Late won the Epsom Oaks for 3-year-old fillies by a head from Paimpont today in a thrilling finish.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 3 -- Vanderbilt University today accepted the resignation of Dr. J. Robert Nelson as dean of the Divinity School. The position was offered to Dr. Walter J. Harrelson, .dean of the University of Chicago Divinity School.
Cotton futures on the New York cotton Exchange closed 7 points up to 23 points off yesterday A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
MIAMI BEACH, June 3 -- A ranking union leader warned here today that labor was in "grave danger" of losing strength in the next ten years unless it modernized its organizing techniques.
NEWARK, June 3 -- Preliminary census figures today put New Jersey's population at 6,031,821.
PARIS, June 3 -- Four more former French African colonies announced today their intention to seek full independence within the French Community.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- A plan to explain the United States to people in other countries through exchange of tape-recorded "living letters" was announced here today by a group of private citizens.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Continued steel production cuts last week resulted in markedly lower railway car loadings, the Association of American Railroads reported today.
LOS ANGELES, June 3 -- A Republican get-out-the-vote appeal that links Democrats to a softer policy on communism was bitterly assailed today by Gov. Edmund G. Brown.
In business, as in the everyday world, some marriages cause eyebrows to be lifted. The mates seem far too dissimilar ever to lead a life of eternal wedded bliss.

BUENOS AIRES, June 3 -- Kaiser Industries of Argentina has taken a big lead in total sales and profits among Argentine corporations, and officials of the automotive company expect to pass the $100,000,000-a-year sales mark this year.

AALBORG, Denmark, June 3 -- It would be an unhappy day for the Danes if their pigs rose up against them. Hogs outnumber the two-legged populace by about three to one. It is no surprise therefore that pork products should be Denmark's largest food export and that they should take up an impressive amount of space at the Danish Food Fair in Aalborg.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Eight men chosen for distinguished service to boyhood were honored today with scouting's award of the Silver Buffalo.
Hours of acrimonious negotiations failed yesterday to break the deadlock that has closed the twenty-two legitimate theatres on Broadway.
City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Elizabeth, N.J., will open a new "air-dome" branch today in the Elmora section of Elizabeth.

Two six-story apartment buildings at 6 Burns Street and 4 Dartmouth Street, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have been purchased by Title Investments, a syndicate represented by Ralph H. Wiener, lawyer. The property consists of 183 apartments and a private playground.

THOSE stumped for an attractive wedding present might consult Henrietta Tischler at 837 Madison Avenue near Seventieth Street. In her charming second-floor boutique there is no rush and bustle. Mrs. Tischler is happy to sit down and discuss gift ideas with any frustrated shopper; And, although the shop is small, the accessories are well selected.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Hal Woodeshick, pitching his first complete game in the American League since 1958, checked league-leading Baltimore on five hits tonight as Washington won, 4 -- 1, before 11,668 fans.

MOSCOW, June 8 (AP) -- Following, in translation from the Russian, are the texts, of Premier Khrushchev's statement at His news, conference today and his message on disarmament to President Eisenhower and other heads of government, as made available by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

Father's Day Off Mother's Day is over now, and beyond a doubt she enjoyed it. There were flowers, telephone calls, candles, telegrams and a five-course dinner at a restaurant, with black tie service, not kitchen apron.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The National Broadcasting Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to approve changes in ownership of radio and television stations in Philadelphia, Boston, San Francisco and Washington.
The 1,500-watt lights of Ebbets Field, which once illuminated the nocturnal activities of the Brooklyn Dodgers, will soon shed their glare at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
BUENOS AIRES, June 3 -- President ArturoFrondizi bowed to army pressure tonight and said he would ask Congress to place terrorist-ridden Cordoba Province under Federal rule.

The Sunbeam Corporation expects to earn in the present fiscal year slightly more than the $11,865,850, or $3.80 a share, cleared in the fiscal year ended on March 26, stockholders were told at the annual meetiiig yesterday in Chicago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent's discovery, in the issue of May 27, of a cause for the present "critical weakness of our society" in an alleged "obsession with private enterprise" is typical of an unfortunately widespread -- and quite unjustified -- sense of guilt with respect to capitalism, which continues to sweep the nation.
Local and state officials moved yesterday to insure proper voting procedures in next Tuesday's primary election.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- Yugoslav representatives said here that the trade agreement concluded today in Washington reflected their Government's policy of building up reserves to stabilize markets and prices.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 3 -- Administrators of the six-nation European Community bloc are cautiously hopeful about British willingness to consider joining the European Atomic Energy Community and the European Coal and Steel Community.

After the close of the financial markets on Thursday it was announced from Washington that the Federal Reserve Board had authorized two of the twelve regional reserve banks of the System -- Philadelphia and San Francisco -- to lower their rediscount rate from the 4 per cent rate that has been in effect at all the regional banks since Sept. 18, 1959, to 3 1/2 per cent.

Schuyler M. Meyer, president of the Edwin Gould Foundation for Children, said yesterday that the foundation had sought to cooperate with all city agencies concerned with correcting conditions in four Brooklyn houses it owns.
The widow and daughter of artist James Montgomery Flagg will share equally in his estate, estimated at $350,000 for probate purposes, after other bequests and expenses have been settled.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 3 -- The junta governing Turkey charged tonight that officials of the deposed Menderes Government committed atrocities in an effort to conceal the bodies of students killed in demonstrations last month.
After an on-again and off-again performance, stocks closed irregularly higher yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Medical scientists from nine nations ended an unusual conference today on sarcoidosis, a mysterious, often unrecognized disease that can attack any organ of the body.

A group of Spanish-speaking parents of children at Public School 61 in Manhattan have rallied to support a dismissed substitute teacher who, they say, had brought about a remarkable transformation in a class of problem children.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a lifelong New Yorker (until just a few years ago, when I found the city no longer pleasantly habitable) and as originator of the Municipal Art Society's committee on historic architecture, I still take an interest in the esthetic aspects of Manhattan.
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for Federal assistance to areas in which migration has brought large shifts of population.

YONKERS, June 3 -- Prudence Adios, a 5-year-old bay mare driven by Tom Crank, scored a neck victory over the favorite, Uncle Dave, in the Clifton pacing feature before 27,306 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
CLEVELAND, June 3 (AP) -- Ken Aspromonte hit a home run and two singles and drove in three runs tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 6-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
"We're all crying in our beer," a taxicab driver said in the Times Square area last night. "The Mayor should do something."
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Yugoslavia will receive $41,000,000 of United States assistance under agreements announced here today.
MEMPHIS, June 3 (UPI) -- Ben Hogan carded his second straight 66 today for a 132 and a share of the second-round lead in the $30,000 Memphis open golf tournament.

The State Department is looking into complaints that Czechoslovakia has refused to accept for delivery letters bearing United States postage stamps commemorating the 110th anniversary of Thomas G. Masaryk's birth.
Center field at YanKee Stadium was a Sunday School picnic grounds last night. No one littered the greensward, no one used bad language.

SANTA FE, N.M., June 3 -- Senator John P. Kennedy's Democratic Presidential campaign harvested new delegate gains today to push his informal claims of strength above, the 700 vote mark. The Democratic candidate must get 761 convention votes to win nomination.
MOSCOW, June 3 -- Premier Khrushchev has accepted an invitation to visit Cuba, it was announced tonight. The Moscow radio said no date had been set for the visit.

PLANDOME, L.I., June 3 -- Mrs. James Simpson of Southward-Ho scored 45, 45 -- 90 to take low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day Class B tournament at the Plandome Golf Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (UPI) -- Vernon Law became the first major-Mguer to win eight games this season when he pitched the league-leading Pirates to a 3-0 victory over the Phillies tonight. It was Pittsburgh's sixth straight triumph.

The Trade Relations Council of the United States, Inc., a public relations organization representing chemical companies, has leased space in 122 East Forty-second Street through Williams Co. The lessee was at 19 West Forty-fourth Street.
Twenty-two persons were arrested early yesterday in a raid on an all-night hottle club that the police said was used as a "recruiting ground" to entice high school girls into prostitution.

Relocation payments have been made uniform for tenants displaced by city public improvements and site-clearance operations, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday. In addition, benefits will be provided for some classifications of tenants that had not received them before or that had received them only on a limited basis.

Six "soft-sell" salesmen who were able to offer irresistible bargains because their merchandise had assertedly cost them nothing, were arrested yesterday and charged with conspiracy and possession of stolen goods.
Five million Roman Catholic youths here and over the country will kneel in church prayers tomorrow in a day-long petition for "strength of mind and character, especially in adversity."

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 3 -- An investigation of what was described as a nation-wide, multimillion-dollar racket in bootleg records of rock 'n' roll hits is being conducted by Bergen County Prosecutor Guy W. Calissi.
Soviet authorities, in a reversal of academic policy, have opened their research archives to United States graduate students.
Emile Griffith of New York gained a majority decision over Jorge Fernandez of Argentina in their ten-round welterweight fight at St. Nicholas Arena last night. The result almost precipitated a riot.

PARIS. At times the personality of a Foreign Minister is quite as important in measuring a nation's intentions as any policy declarations. This becomes particularly true when a country revises previous attitudes, when opposition parties take power, or when revolution or coup d'etat upsets the established order.
Defense transportation officials were told last night that there would be a "woeful inadequacy of marine transportation." for the armed forces in the event of an emergency.
THE Turkish military men who overthrew the Government of Premier Adnan Menderes May 27 announced from the start that the coup meant no change in foreign policy.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures was somewhat more active today with prices spreading over their broadest range of the week.

THE legendary man who said he didn't know whether he could play a 'cello or not because he'd never tried would feel a shock of recognition on meeting John Henry Cutler. For Mr. Cutler had little knowledge about running a newspaper when he founded The Duxbury Clipper up in Massachusetts ten years ago.
The head of a hospital workers' union offered yesterday to defer any strike action against ten voluntary institutions if an "impartial appraisal" were made.
LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP) -- The Los Angeles-Dodgers met the Chicago Cubs under the lights in the Coliseum tonight.

With the stock market dancing in place this week, brokerage concerns have been trying to catch the rhythm, J.R. Williston Beane reported in its latest comment that "the stock market is saying that over the near term at least there will not be a substantial change in the level of defense expenditures and it is unlikely that the defense group as a whole will soon be in the forefront."
REGINALD ROSE'S two-part documentary drama on the Sacco-Vanzetti case opened last night over Channel 4.
MOSCOW, June 3 -- Van Cliburn, the young American pianist, performed here tonight at the Tchaikovsky Conservatory -- the scene of his 1958 triumph -- and received a sentimental ovation.

A program to improve the appearance and safety of one of the underpasses on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive (East River Drive) will be completed within a month, Acting Borough President Louis A. Cioffi said yesterday.
BONN, Germany, June 3 -- The West German Government has completed a blueprint for a five-year $500,000,000 economic aid program for under-developed countries.

ST. STEPHEN, N.B., June 3 -- A fishing contest on the St. Croix River fell apart today because one of the competitors took an unfair advantage. He fished with two guides in his canoe and the judge, who was also a competitor, disqualified him.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 3 -- Robert Mitchell, a 43-year-old quadriplegic who has been "attending" classes at C.W. Post College through an intercommunication system with his home, will be graduated next Saturday with high academic honors.

GENEVA, June 3 -- The United States and Britain pressed without success today for an explanation of the Soviet Union's about-face on its research program for improving controls for policing underground nuclear explosions.
DEVON, Pa., June 3 -- The Duke of Paeonian clinched the conformation hunter championship of the Devon Horse Show tonight.

Horse racing enthusiasts in the metropolitan region have a fair appreciation of the pastoral charm of Belmont Park, particularly after a long exposure to the utilitarian surroundings at Aqueduct. The trouble is, though, that the pastoral charm doesn't seem to help in the furtherance of the cause of favorites.
KAFR EL BATTIKH, United Arab Republic, June 2 -- In a recent meeting with newspaper and magazine editors, President Gamal Abdel Nasser deplored the attention they were giving to the minutiae of life.

The House Agriculture Committee has voted against the Administration's proposal to give President Eisenhower authority to cut Cuba's sugar quota. Instead, the committee approved a bill that would give the Secretary of Agriculture authority to reduce Cuba's quota if she failed to fill it in any year.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 3 -- At commencement today Sarah Lawrence College conferred Bachelor of Arts degrees on ninety-seven women and Master of Arts degrees on eight others.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A majority of the full membership of the House of Representatives today forced floor consideration of a 9 per cent pay rise for about 1,570,000 Government workers.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York has helped raise money for Representative Burdick, it was disclosed today.
MILWAUKEE, June 3 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves built up a big lead with four homers tonight, then checked a Cincinnati rally in the ninth inning to post a 6-4 triumph over the Reds.
The police harbor squad searched the East River far into last night for the body of a 5-year-old girl who disappeared Thursday night while playing on Randalls Island.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics, taking advantage of their every scoring opportunity, hammered out a 7-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A $325,000,000 Federal-state program of medical care for the needy aged was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
United States exports in April totaled $1,806,000,000, highest for any month in nearly three years, according to a preliminary estimate for the month issued yesterday by the Department of Commerce.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 3 -- Jim DePiro of Branch Brook scored a four-under-par 32, 36 -- 68 at the Hackensack Golf Club today to lead the northern section qualifiers for the state amateur championship.
RANGOON. Villages modeled on Israel's self-defense frontier communities are being set up in Burma.

Two books by and about the poet Ezra Pound, who has been called "controversial and influential," will be published a week apart. On June 13, Regnery will issue "Impact: Essays on Ignorance and the Decline of American Civilization," by Ezra Pound, edited with an introduction by Noel Stock.

While most women are buying bathing suits, sundresses and shorts, America's designers are busy showing woolly coats, suits and fur-laden dinner costumes. These collections, the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July, attract store executive and buyers from all over-the country to New York's Seventh Avenue.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation is considering "going heavier" into the electronics field, but unless it obtains new Government business there is a good chance it may cut back its aircraft manufacturing activities, according to T. Roland Berner, new chairman and chief executive officer.

A Kings County grand jury recommended yesterday the construction of a new jail in Brooklyn to replace the Raymond Street Jail. It said overcrowding caused a "dangerous condition" in the 105-year-old jail on Ashland Place.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 3 -- Mrs. James P. Lee of the Huntington Country Club shot a 38, 38 -- 76 and won the drawing for the first gross prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.
Dr. James E. Alien Jr., State Commissioner of Education, recommended, yesterday that daycare centers for children of working mothers be placed under the supervision of school authorities.
The Brooklyn federal Court jury deliberating the fate of Arthur Lem was locked up early this morning after failing to reach a verdict for the second successive night.
The unbroken series of International crises emphasizes the necessity for a powerful merchant marine, a Federal shipping official declared here yesterday.

THE ORGANIZATIONS The members of Actors Equity Association, who are professional actors and stage managers, total almost 12,000. Seven hundred and thirty-one were involved in the Broadway productions that are now closed down.

The Church World Service, with years of experience in disaster relief, is sponsoring a "Blanket-and-a-Buck" campaign to aid the millions of Chileans who are now facing a winter without shelter. The interdenominational Protestant agency's representatives stress how important a good wool blanket can be to the homeless-it can be used either' as bedding, clothing or even as a tent.
Blackbirds may be fine for pies and kings but they are a growing curse to South Jersey's corn farmers.
Waiter Wood partner of Don Murray in the new independent company preparing to film ''The Hoodlum Priest" in St Lcuis, has disclosed that the organizetion is also planning three other works.

High school prom night in New York City in 1960 is the night a girl turns into a woman before the incredulous eyes of parents and teachers. It is the night a boy becomes a man of the world, and never stops spending. It is a night that begins in the ballroom of a midtown town hotel and usually ends with a dawn ride on the Staten Island ferryboat.

NEWARK, June 3 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson warned today that difficult days were ahead for the United States as a result of Premier Khrushchev's latest "tirade." He said great care would be essential in dealing with leaders of the Kremlin.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 (AP) -- Joe Amalfitano's first major league home run proved decisive tonight as the San Francisco Giants beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 3 -- The United States Supreme Court has affirmed this town's right to impose four-acre zoning restrictions as a means of controlling residential expansion.

The state moved yesterday to dissolve a slum realty corporation whose president is already involved in two other identical actions. In addition, the landlord is under bail of $5,000 set by a city judge.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers won a two-step 4 per cent wage increase from the nation's railroads today.
Broadway performers were not the only artists with problems yesterday. A television actress staged a one-woman walkout on a soap opera Just before airtime.
LONDON, June 3 -- A campaign for quieter nights around London Airport suffered a serious setback today.
The Florida Development Commission sold $3,400,000 of state office building revenue bonds, due from 1965 to 1990, to an investment banking group headed jointly by Smith, Barney Co. and Blyth Co.
Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday fell to a five-month low of 234,749,000 board feet. The week before the figure was 248,430,000 board feet and a year ago, 253,028,000 board feet.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The chances were considered exceedingly slim today that Congress would authorize in this session the building of the controversial Freedom Shrine next to Arlington National Cemetery.

USUMBURA, Ruahda-Urundi, May 22 -- The power of the Watusi giants, who have lorded it over the Bahutu peasants and the Batwa pygmies for at least 400 years in crowded, mountainous Ruanda-Urundi, is at last being cut down by the Belgian Administration.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 3 -- Plans for the new $8,500,000 headquarters of the American Baptist Convention in Valley Forge, Pa., may meet heavy opposition here tomorrow at the denomination's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board held unanimously today that any picketing to force an employer to initiate dealings with a union without the employes' consent was illegal.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Western diplomats said today that the United States, Britain and France had agreed to coordinate their policies more closely in the face of growing vituperation from Premier Khrushchev and the Soviet bloc.
THE long expected utilization of Giacomo Meyerbeer's vast and miraculously intact heritage, containing volumes of diaries and thousands of letters, is finally under way.

BEDFORD, N.Y., June 4 -- The Bedford Garden Club, which was founded in 1911, will have a benefit Four Seasons flower show, plant sale and house and garden tour on Wednesday, June 15, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., rain or shine.
ALBANY, June 3 -- The State Tax Department has nearly completed the job of refunding more than $75,000,000 to 3,100,000 of the 6,100,000 persons who filed income-tax returns this year.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 4 -- The United States Air Force Academy will graduate 223 men at its second annual commencement exercises on Wednesday. Five more will get their degrees later, after making up academic deficiencies.

TOWARD the end of a calamitous season the Broadway theatre suffered the saddest possible calamity on Wednesday evening. "The Tenth Man" was closed as the first move in a labor dispute between Actors' Equity and the League of New York Theatres.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt. -- One of the purest surviving slices of the old rustic and Independent Vermont life is called, locally, the Northeast Kingdom. Bordering on Canada and the northern wilderness area of New Hampshire, this northeast corner, of the state comprises three of its least-traveled counties, a deeply wooded, thinly populated region of mountains and lakes that remains as little known to most Vermonters as it does to the rest of the world.

WHEN boring holes through a panel of hardboard with an auger bit avoid getting a ragged edge on the back side when the bit tears through. To accomplish this, back the panel up with a block of any kind of scrap wood, or lay it flat on top of a board.
