BUENOS AIRES, June 4 (AP) -- Scared and nervous, the son and daughter-in-law of Adolf Eichmann, high Hitler aide accused of complicity in the slaughter of 6,000,000 European Jews, are anxiously trying to avoid the glaring spotlight cast on them in the wake of his arrest.

IN a relatively short period of time, the Communist program for world conquest has changed remarkably -- in scope and in intensity, to say nothing of subtlety. Faced with this new and growing challenge, Western diplomats occasionally look back with some nostalgia to the Stalin era.
STOCKHOLM, May 28 -- When the Swedish Olympic team goes to Rome in August, it will travel on a small part of the profits of a huge Government-owned gambling enterprise.

The Supreme Court's decision last week as to who owned the tidelands of five states in the Gulf of Mexico could immediately affect drastically the treasury of Louisiana in particular and have an appreciable effect on the Federal Treasury.

SAGANESQUE is the word that comes to mind about this first novel. Like the Sagans, It is slight to the point at emaciation. It deals with the same milieu -- dispirited and weary French sophisticates pursuing their elusive identities through empty corridors of pleasure.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 4 (AP) -- Minnesota won a battle of strategy in the eighth inning today, beating Detroit, 5 -- 4, and sweeping into the National Collegiate baseball tournament.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- The Chicago Cubs, seeking their third straight victory over Los Angeles, tonight faced Stan Williams, a right-handed pitcher they had never beaten.

SHORTLY after noon one day last week a group of television executives filed into Studio 6-A of the National Broadcasting Company in the R.C.A. Building. They chatted informally as they took seats in the auditorium facing a stage that was empty except for a piano, a few chairs and several microphones.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- Bryn Mawr College ended a year-long celebration of its seventy-fifth anniversary today by awarding citations for distinguished service to seventy-five alumnae. The citations were presented at a convocation on the campus near here.

MICHELANGELO was hailed in his lifetime as a great poet. Humanists like Benedetto Varchi read his poems to academies, and composers like Arcadelt, Porta and Tromboncino created settings for his madrigals.
MEMPHIS, June 4 -- Ben Hogan's game collapsed in the heat today, allowing J.C. Goosie and Bill Collins to take the lead with three-round totals of 203's in the $30,000 Memphis open golf tournament.

FOR thirty-six years I stood up against a separation case in the New York Post Office and processed letters going to and coming from the four corners of the state. At a minimum required speed of sixteen letters per minute based on 250 work days a year, I may have handled some 70,000,000 pieces of mail.
A new kind of "home movie" was previewed here last week at a two-day conference on the science of family.
Most of the Democratic voters in Queens will have a choice in deciding, in the primary Tuesday, who will rule the party organization for the next two years.
The scarcity of suitable Park Avenue apartment house sites has brought about the rediscovery of its nearest neighbor to the east -- Lexington Avenue.

THE heads of one of America's farthest-flung radio networks gathered in New York recently to discuss the future of the unseen medium. The consensus was that, indeed, the reports of its demise are premature and that, regardless of what's happening on this continent, it's doing fine in Greenland, Kyushu and Korea.

MEXICO CITY, June 4 -- The dream of a deep-water canal connecting the Gulf of Mexico with the Pacific Ocean through the Tehuantepec Isthmus has been brought to the public attention again, this time on a large scale.
MONTAUK, L.I., June 4 -- The annual ceremony of the blessing of the fishing fleet here will take place tomorrow at 5 P.M.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -- Chuck Davis, a left-hander pitched a four-hitter today as Navy's baseball team beat Army's Eastern Intercollegiate League champions, 9-1.

NEW DELHI, India, June 4 -- Acharya Vinoba Bhave, a leading exponent of Gandhi's doctrines of nonviolence, has run into trouble with the police.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The dilemma of Sicily as portrayed by Paul Hofmann is a study in miniature of the world's under-developed areas, complete with the threat of communism waiting to take over if the West should fail.

MADRID, May 29 -- Spanish indignation is erupting here over the national road network, which travelers report to be rapidly breaking up, and over large numbers of uncovered manholes in this capital of 2,000,000 residents.

MONTREAL -- In the St. Lawrence Seaway, Canada and the United States have a touristic hit on their hands. ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- It should come as practically no surprise by now to learn that Florida is not primarily a winter resort. The days when virtually whole areas in the southern part of the state closed down for the summer are long gone.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 4 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson urged here today that the election campaign this year be conducted "without internal warfare."

HISTORY has been moving so fast that one may wonder how many Americans realize, or even remember, that the leader of India spent much of his youth in British jails. During one stretch of imprisonment, from 1930 to 1933, Nehru whiled away his time by writing letters to his young daughter about man's whole history -- enough letters to fill a thousand-page volume, published as "Glimpses of World History."

NO composer of our century has provoked more controversy and discussion than Arnold Schoenberg. It is odd, in view of this, that a biography of the Austrian-born innovator has not appeared in America, the adopted country of his last years, until now -- almost a decade after his death.

With a month gone by since the downing of the U-2 spy plane over Russia, basic investment markets here are at length giving their considered comment on the incident, the collapse of the Paris summit talks and the other alleged consequences.

The giant tortoise, probably the world's oldest living creature, may soon get new help in its fight against extinction.

ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, June 4 -- The professional auto drivers who will race in Monday's Grand Prix here are a serious lot. None drink. Few smoke. There is little partying. Unless the talk is of cars, conversation comes slowly and infrequently.

DALLAS, Tex., June 4 (UPI) -- United States District Judge T. Whitfield Davidson ordered the Dallas School Board todays to put a voluntary "salt and pepper" integration plan into operation in September, 1961.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter expressed his "disgust" today at the conduct of Premier Khrushchev in personally attacking President Eisenhower. The Secretary of State accused the Soviet leader of attempting to degrade the standards of international relations.

Billy Short was not long for the game at the Stadium yesterday. The Yankees' young southpaw stayed around only twelve minutes, failed to retire a batter and was charged with the defeat as the Boston Red Sox beat the Bombers, 8 -- 2.

CONCORD, N.H. -- Among the more recent advances in the elaborate New Hampshire vacation scheme is the realization that something must be done for the children and for the beleaguered, rest-seeking parents who accompany them.

The history of the world's population growth during the past 10,000 years has been reconstructed by demographers with what is regarded as "reasonable accuracy." According to these estimates the population of the earth at the end of the Neolithic Period in Europe (8,000 to 7,000 B.C.) was 10 million; at the beginning of the Christian Era, 200 to 300 million; at the beginning of the modern era in 1650, 500 million; in 1950, 2.5 billion.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., June 4 -- Two boys were killed by a Long Island Rail Road train today as they watched a whale hunt from a trestle over an inlet in this South Shore community.

LONDON, June 4 -- The Atlantic Alliance this week faced a new and different challenge to its effectiveness. For eleven years it has been able to resist both the pressures of Soviet power politics and the divisive tendencies natural to a coalition of independent nations.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 4 -- Communist China broke today its pledge to bombard Nationalist territory only on odd-numbered days and fired 500 shells at the Quemoy offshore islands in the heaviest barrage this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- The Federal Maritime Board is opened hearings at which the Matson Navigation Company is seeking to justify its 12 1/2 per cent increase in freight rates between Hawaii and mainland ports.
An exhibition covering 150 years of American sculpture will be held June 14 through July 24 at Old Westbury Gardens on Long Island.
A roofing company executive expects the roofing business to change more in the next ten years than it did in the last 100.

WARRENSBURG, N.Y. -- Having long since established itself as one of America's richest; playgrounds, the Adirondack Mountain region of New York, like a successful merchant, has now set about the equally serious business of polishing its pedigree.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System, which banned big-money television quiz shows last October, will initiate on July 11 a daytime game show offering cash awards and merchandise to contestants. Although this cannot be adjudged a reversal of policy it does mark the first game show to be accepted by C.B.S. since its president, Dr. Frank Stanton, began a major overhaul of program practices and procedure.

WAYCROSS, Ga -- What may appear to the Florida-bound motorist as an obstacle in his dash to sun, sand and surf is really a natural stopping-off place, one that should appeal to those who admire primitive scenery and perhaps are devotees of fresh-water game fishing.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The State Department tried today to clear up an apparent misunderstanding over visas for Oliver Tambo, deputy leader of South Africa's outlawed African National Congress.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4 -- The United States Military Academy will graduate its 162d class Wednesday morning.
The atomic age has caught up with the annual joint Navy-Army supply mission of military bases in the frozen north in the form of a prefabricated nuclear power plant.
PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh-Philadelphia Phillies game was rained out today and the injury-wracked Phils were thankful for the day of rest.

AT Nikita Khrushchev's press conference on the U-2 incident, he saw so many American newspaper men facing him that he felt impelled to lecture them on their craft.

BASEBALL The Yankees lost to the Red Sox, 8 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday. Roger Maris hit his thirteenth homer and Tony Kubek his fourth for the Yankees' runs. At San Francisco, Jack Sanford of the Giants defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 2 -- 0, with three-hit pitching.

"WHO now reads Boling-broke?" was the rhetorical and (as he meant it to be) derogatory question that Edmund Burke asked less than fifty years after the death of Henry St. John, Viscount Boling-broke.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 4 -- For the twelfth time, Litchfield will hold its annual Open House Day for the benefit of the Connecticut Junior Republic here.
MASSENA, N.Y., June 4 (AP) -- Lewis Gould Castie, who had supervised the United States portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway since construction started in 1954, died here today. He was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A potentially significant move is developing within the International Atomic Energy Agency to establish the first international safeguards on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- The vast region of the Fort Apache Reservation and heavily forested White Mountains in east-central Arizona constitutes a little-known but powerful vacation magnet for motorists driving cross-country.
Oliver Powers, father of Francis Gary Powers, the captured U-2 pilot, has suddenly decided to postpone his scheduled trip to visit his imprisoned son in the Soviet Union. He would not say why.

A deepening leadership crisis in the Kremlin lies behind Premier Khrushchev's latest outburst, in the opinion of Soviet affairs experts. The evidence, including diplomatic reports from Moscow, indicates that Mr. Khrushchev is engaged in a tough struggle for power.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -- The traditional June week began yesterday at the United States Naval Academy. The 798 members of the graduating class will receive diplomas on Wednesday.

No one, it has been said, appreciates the virtues of eggs and cream with the ardor of the French. Certainly, in the field of desserts, no one has employed them with the dedicated industry of French chefs. Whether it is a cocoa-dusted frozen souffle or a cream puff filled with creme Chantilly, the beau ideal belongs to the Gauls.

AT this time of year, when spring is turning the last corners toward the straight summer stretch, New York's principal galleries line up their painters and sculptors in a sort of farewell ceremony honoring the season just past.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- If President Eisenhower were to be a candidate in November the personal abuse of him which Soviet Premier Khrushchev continues to utter in ever-rising degree would almost assure his re-election. That has been the historic reaction of the American people.

The trend in recent years of juggling the various living levels of homes to provide a maximum of usable space has already produced various forms of split-level styling and the raised ranch design. Now it has also been carried into what is best described as a raised Colonial dwelling.

BY using latex foam rubber as a cushioning material, do-it-yourselfers can turn out a professional upholstering job. Widely available through department stores, hardware stores and upholstering shops, foam rubber can be purchased either as fully molded, ready-made cushions or by the foot in various thicknesses and styles.

QUANTICO, Va., June 4 (AP) -- Bob Gutowski and Al Cantello, world record-holders, survived stiff opposition and retained their Marine Corps championships in the pole vault and javelin today as the all-Marine track and field meet ended.
SANTA FE, N.M., June 4 -- The big delegate hunt was on in earnest among Democratic Presidential aspirants this week. They shot for singles, pairs coveys and even bigger flocks.

A small and somewhat battered slab of marble discovered in Greece about a year ago may lay a new foundation for rewriting the history of two of the most famous battles of ancient times -- Thermopylae and Salamis.

THIS is the familiar lament of a one-time radical who has taken the sawdust trail and wants to tell the congregation about his sins and his reformation. The author is a 43-year-old journalist, who has previously written a book on the Hiss trial and a biography of Vice President Richard Nixon.

To the Music Editor: * * * I had not contemplated answering the letter of Aaron Avshalomov about the pizzicati in my string quartet. But since I am writing, let me say this: His strange reversal of Mr. Taubman's point about these is puzzling.

STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -- C. Mahlon Kline's Mystic II carried the top weight of 121 pounds to victory today in the $24,950 Brandywine Turf Handicap. The race was the first of Delaware Park's stakes on grass this season.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 2 -- A Government committee backed by Premier Chen Cheng is working for the adoption of a broad new law designed to encourage large-scale investment in new industry by Chinese here and abroad and by foreign concerns.

TEANECK, N.J. -- After uncomfortably reading Winifred Luten's recent article on how to camp comfort (Travel Section, May 8), my wife and I decided that perhaps the world is ready for our system of camping in elegance.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados -- With an increasing number of British and American visitors retiring here and building homes, this tiny West Indies island has discovered the Value of tourist gold and is taking steps to attract an even greater share of it in the year ahead.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 4 -- A spokesman for the National Unity Committee backtracked today on a communique charging that the overthrown Menderes regime had committed atrocities.

LONDON NEEDLESS to say, Antony Armstrong-Jones, newly fixed in wax, has joined Princess Margaret in the Royal group at Madame Tussaud's, as that venerable establishment sedately keeps up with the times. Keeps up?
Two huge transportation companies -- Pan American World Airways and Consolidated Freightways, a trucking company -- last week established a world-wide truck-air cargo system.

THE Maigret novels of Georges Simenon are always short -- around 50,000 words -- though emphatically "full-length" in plot and in psychological content; and many years ago they used to appear two-to-the-volume.

With summer approaching, the economy is holding steady. Prospects for business in June, July and August are about the same as they were a year ago, even though there is no major strike in the offing. The threat of the nation-wide steel strike was hanging over the economy last year at this time, National income, employment and retail trade are at record levels.

THE 4-cent stamp which Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield recently promised he would issue to direct public attention to the nation's physically handicapped will be released on Aug. 28, he announced yesterday.
Families who have more than their share of problems and seem to defy community health and welfare agencies to solve them have been the source of intensive study in many sections of the state.

STRATFORD, Conn. SUMMER is coming in and soon the voice of Shakespeare will be heard again along the Housatonic. Or to put it another way -- the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre will officially open its sixth season here on Wednesday with a performance of "Twelfth Night," played on a redesigned stage and directed by a new associate producer.

A split-level model containing eight rooms has been introduced at Fanwood, a colony of fifty-six houses on Winding Way, west of River Vale Road in River Vale, N.J. It is one of two split-levels planned at prices starting at $23,500.

BALTIMORE, June 4 -- The Washington Senators scored their fourth straight victory tonight and their second over the Baltimore Orioles. They whipped the league leaders, 7 -- 1, with Chuck Stobbs gaining the decision.
The open lifeboat, which kindles images of epic survival and feats of superhuman endurance at sea, may be relegated to novels and motion pictures in another decade.

CRITICS of American family life who feel that family life abroad generally is on a far higher plane should look at European humor magazines more often. In recent months, particularly, one controversial influence in local homes -- television -- has been revealed as a household troublemaker across the Atlantic as well.

The construction of tall apartment houses is increasing in northern New Jersey, according to a mortgage banker whose concern is supplying funds for a number of the new structures.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- What shall the visitor do when he gets to Maine this year? The answer is as broad as the question. What does the tourist want to do? Name it, and he probably can do it, for more than 200 special events have been scheduled to provide entertainment for vacationists and natives alike.
New York University officials in caps, gowns and multicolored ceremonial hoods will stage a solemn academic procession today at the opening of N.Y.U.'s commencement season.

YONKERS, June 4 -- Tar Boy, beaten only once in six starts this year, paced the fastest mile of the season here tonight when he won the $10,000 Salem by one length in 2:00 2/5.

IN a leisurely, single-day's drive, a motorist from the New York City metropolitan area can combine a visit to one of America's most delightful scenic areas with a trip over one of the nation's first major highways.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 4 -- The 1,500,000-member American Baptist Convention over-whelmingly approved plans today for a $8,500,000 headquarters complex in Valley Forge, Pa. The site is twelve miles from Philadelphia on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.
DETROIT, May 28 -- Automobile air conditioning is becoming more popular.
PETER Shaffer, the British playwright who was introduced to Broadway with the current, prizewinning and delightful hit, "Five Finger Exercise," also has made his debut as a scenarist.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 4 -- Al Oerter's meet-record discus throw of 190 feet 2 1/2 inches was the top performance of the New York Athletic Club's rain-spattered spring track and field games at Travera Island today.

HUNTER COLLEGE will allow any of the orchestras that choose to return to Carnegie Hall next season to do so. In other words, it is being just as gracious to the orchestras in excusing them from accepting hospitality as it was in offering them hospitality in the first place.

Persons prominent in New York society will sail at 7 P.M. Wednesday as passengers aboard the Captain's Paradise. They will spend the evening cruising on the Hudson River if the moon shines. If it rains the trip will take place the next evening.

LONDON, June 4 -- Shakesspeare sipped dry sherry with his Elizabethan cronies in the Mermaid Tavern. Pitt may have shortened his life by over-doing the port. When Edward VII was still Prince of Wales, he traded on his German connections and introduced hock to Britain.

PARKSVILLE, N.Y. -- The Sullivan County Catskill country became one of the most popular mountain resorts because of what its hotel owners happily refer to as the "stay put" vacationist. The transient tourist trade never had been a factor in the great success experienced by resort operators in this thriving upstate New York area.
Royal Native moved with the ease of a champion in taking the $56,900 Top Flight Handicap for fillies and mares at Belmont Park yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- Seven of the nation's Atlas missile installations -- including Vandenberg Air Force Base, 175 miles north of here -- were scheduled to be struck at midnight tomorrow by the International Association of Machinists.
RABAT, Morocco, June 4 -- The Moroccan Government is helping about 20,000 women learn to find places for themselves in this male-dominated Moslem society.

The cut in the discount rate at two Federal Reserve Banks, announced after the close of trading on Thursday, changed the course of the stock market last week. Until this development, stocks had moved irregularly, with strength in selected issues a feature of trading.

TRAFFIC runs one way along Tenth Street in New York if we may believe the exhibition, named after that thoroughfare, that is now on view in this city, "New York's Tenth Street," at the Bolles Gallery, brought us the work of six painters whose points of view are decidedly harmonious, and that is a relief after so many exhibitions it which catholicity and anarchy are confused.

FEW contemporary photographers really know their medium as a craft, and most have never tried to learn it, W. Eugene Smith charged last week. The noted photojournalist, whose devotion to technical precision has become almost legendary, made the statement before an audience of his colleagues and others in one of his rare public addresses.

THE casual bridge player, who is repelled and often bewildered by artificial and fancy bidding systems in which a club bid may mean three aces but a void in the club suit, and a heart bid may mean the kings of diamonds and clubs but not a heart suit, will dote on a new book by Sam Fry Jr., published last week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After World War II a furious controversy raged in Washington regarding the status of America's new Central Intelligence apparatus. Strong arguments were advanced that intelligence activities properly should be centered within the Department of State.

MIAMI BEACH -- Time and tide wait for no man, not even in this Gold Coast resort. Summer tourists who came here last year saw the beginning of a vast $250,000,000 expressway system, which by 1965 is expected to provide a pattern of limited-access routes around Dade County.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. -- Spring was almost rained out in the Adirondack Mountains this year. May was the month of April showers. However, the rain is beginning to pay back with June days of lush greenness.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- The "old folks" are on the march again. California's "senior citizens," who were behind so many of the Golden State's bizarre events of the Turbulent Thirties, have resurged as a reckonable, if transitory, factor in politics, perhaps on a national scale.
The head of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith appealed to the American people last night for a "frank discussion of the injection of bigotry" into the 1960 election campaign.
PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- A team of archaelogists left here this week to resume excavation work at the remains of the 2,800-year-old city of Hasanlu in northern Iran.
The nation's money managers, who have permitted a gradual relaxation of credit restraint since the first of the year, confirmed last week the latest shift to an easier money policy.

IN "The Nunnery," the author of the well-remembered historical of several years back, "Men Like Shadows," has chosen to gamble on a retelling of the story of the suppression of the minor monastic houses and the execution of Anne Boleyn.

ATLANTIC CITY -- The seaside boardwalk, symbol of strolling pleasure to millions of vacationists, will receive its proper accolade this month when Atlantic City celebrates the ninetieth anniversary of the original planked walk laid on the beach in 1870 at the instigation of a fussy hotel keeper and a railroad conductor with a penchant for tidiness.

June ushers in the reign of the rose. Of course, the queen of flowers has a colorful court -- rhododendrons, mockoranges, iris, poppies and annuals also are in bloom. Wild flowers add cheerful notes along the roadsides.

MODERN mulching practices helped me solve the problem of removing about twenty tons of logs and brush from basswood trees cut down and left scattered on my front lawn. No one wanted the wood, even for kindling, but I found that for less than one-third the cost of removal it could be run through a wood chipping machine.
TOKYO, June 4 -- Massive rallies against the new United States-Japanese security treaty and Premier Nobusuke Kishi's Government were staged for the second consecutive day today.

PETER S. BEAGLE makes a striking debut on several counts. With the first two paragraphs of "A Fine and Private Place" a style is established, a personality registered. We meet at once a talking raven, who is taking food (baloney) not to the prophet Elijah but to a retiring man named Jonathan Rebeck.

PLENTY of people over the past fifty years or so, confronted by one concoction or another of the contemporary creative spirit, have asked indignantly, "Do you call that art?" ROANOKE, Va. -- Dedication of a Blue Ridge Parkway bridge next Saturday will weld the last link in a 220-mile portion of the parkway and the Skyline Drive between Roanoke and Front Royal, Va.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Following is the text of an aide memoire delivered to the Foreign Ministry of Cuba by Daniel M. Braddock, counsel of the United States Embassy:
Adlai E. Stevenson hag repudiated what appeared to be an endorsement of Representative Ludwig Teller, who is facing an insurgent challenge for renomi-nation in the Democratic primary here Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA -- This year marks the 160th anniversary of Washington as the nation's capital, but it took a heart-breaking twenty-six years and 1,100 miles of wandering from city to city for the Federal Government to make the 140-mile trip from Philadelphia and settle down in its permanent home.

A ROCK garden contains many nooks and crevices where a collection of attractive mosses will add special interest. Some kind of moss will grow in practically every soil -- acid or alkaline -- in sun or shade.

CHAMA, N.M. -- Salvage archaeology has become a major occupation in New Mexico this year, in the wake of rapid construction on the multimillion-dollar Navajo Dam. This project, to be completed in 1962, will provide irrigation for much of northwestern New Mexico and enable Navajo Indians to build big industries on their long-dry reservation.

A VISIT to the furnishing displays of the British Exhibition, which opens Friday at New York's Coliseum, will be like going home for Americans. They will find the traditional styles that are the backbone of their own design heritage and modern ones so similar to those produced here as to be almost indistinguishable.

SPRING is the time of year when the Moravians sing Bach, and an appropriate and timely disk from Columbia offers Arias, Anthems and Chorales of the American Moravians, recorded last June by the Moravian Festiva Chorus and Orchestra, Thor Johnson conducting, at Winston-Salem, N.C.

BOSTON -- Meandering in Massachusetts might be compared with the delights of renting a rambling old homestead and exploring its many rooms at leisure. And with a new express highway through Boston to the south open this season, motorists may find that visiting "a new room a day" over two weeks is a good way of spending their summer vacation.

ON the evening of June 10, 1935, a New York stockbroker visited a surgeon in a suburb of Akron, Ohio. Both men were confirmed and "hopeless" drunks. In despair and loneliness, they almost inadvertently made a major medical and social discovery.

Israel is the only place where Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi elite guard leader in charge of Jewish extermination under Hitler, should and can be tried for his fiendish crimes, the Rev. Dr. Zev Zahavy said here yesterday.

The year-round availability of family air-raid shelters for such uses as storage closets, photographic dark rooms and wine cellars is said to be gradually overcoming the hesitancy of many home owners to install them.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 4 -- Dr. William St. Lawrence, a pediatrician here and in New York for nearly fifty years, died yesterday in Southampton Hospital after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.
NEW ORLEANS, June 4 -- Louisianans fear that the United States Supreme Court decision of Tuesday will cost the state $309,000,000 now and many more millions in years to come.

PRESUMABLY the alarums and excursions that have beset the theatre in recent weeks will have settled into the dust by next season -- yes, Virginia, there is a theatre, and it will be functioning next season -- and one of the prospects appears to be a transcription from the French of George Bernanos's "Dialogues des Carmelites."

THE tourist who, likes to keep on the move and pack a continent at a time into his sight-seeing jaunts should try a six-week whirl through South America. It is a challenging venture. The special forty-five-day, roundtrip air fare helps keep the cost down and the dollar goes a long way in most Latin-American countries.

MARSHALL, Ind. -- Engraved on a towering sandstone rock beside a trail in turkey Run State Park is the name, "J.J. Robbing," followed by the date, "1890." This rugged tourist, whoever he was, deserves a belated salute; it must have been anything but easy to explore these forests and canyons in 1890.

VISITORS to exhibitions have become accustomed to spotting particularly appealing drawings and finding on them the name of Walter C. Baker as lender. The common denominator of Mr. Baker's collection, which went on exhibition at the Metropolitan last Thursday, is a combination of elegance and romantic sensibility.

LISBON -- This is Prince Henry the Navigator Year in Portugal, and numerous ceremonies and special events, beginning with an exposition opening here on June 10, will mark the 500th anniversary of the death of the eminent patron of early exploration.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 4 -- This growing city began a search this week for new park sites. It now has 480 acres of parkland and needs "at least" 500 more.
Mayor Wagner is expected to sign into law tomorrow the city's controversial milk-dating bill.
HARTFORD, June 4 -- The Republican State Convention will be held here Monday and Tuesday to elect Connecticut's twenty-two delegates to the National Convention in Chicago on July 25.

ST. LOUIS, Mo. June 4 -- A major barge-line operator told an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner this week that a case he was hearing belonged before Congress rather than before the Federal agency.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4 -- With United Nations help, aviation students in Thailand will be taught to fly jet planes.

THE season's last show at the Image Gallery, 100 East Tenth Street, offers the work of four relatively new photographers. Although dealing with similar material, nature and quiet city themes, Miss Carmel Vitullo's pictures are in marked contrast to Leo Varsano's on opposite walls.

TO THE EDITOR: RICHARD SCHICKEL'S review misses the point with a bang. The scene has changed radically from the numb alienated hipsterism of ten years ago, which he seems to admire. It is now much more open, outspoken, imaginative, unmuzzled.
Gradually emerging from its "ugly-duckling" stage, public housing is surprising many communities with its esthetic appearance.

BURLINGTON, N.J., June 4 -- More than 1,200 Burlington County residents were evacuated from their homes today in a Civil Defense drill. All were to spend a damp night in the Pine Barrens in deserted hunting lodges.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much has been said and written about the increasing use to which the President has put the Vice President, not only in the case of Richard Nixon, but even earlier in President Roosevelt's use of Henry Wallace.
NEW DELHI, India, May 28 -- The imposition of ceilings on land holdings, which has been accepted as a basic concept of India's agrarian reform program, has become a subject of bitter controversy.

"WHAT a relief," wrote Bernard Berenson in his wartime journal, "to read a Frenchman on any literary or artistic subject." The implied endorsement is perhaps too sweeping, but one gets the point. There is a clarity of thought, a stylistic elegance, an avoidance of cant in the French approach to art that seldom fails to enchant.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4 -- The Navy lacrosse team rallied in the second half and defeated Army, 10 to 7, today. An overflow crowd of some 5,500 saw the middies clinch the national intercollegiate title.

THE last few months have seen the publication of some the finest Westerns in years -- books like "Comanche Moon," "Kennedy's Gold," "Yellowleg," "The Wild Breed," "Hellsgrin," "Desperate Rider." "The Loner" and others.
NEWARK, June 4 -- The Essex County Juvenile Court handled in 1959 the "largest yearly increase in many years," according to a report released today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- Two native sons have top billing in California's Presidential preferential primary Tuesday. One is without opposition. The other, by general consent, is in no danger.
DETROIT, June 4 -- The automobile industry is planning more new and different kinds of cars for the future.
Eighty-two golfers are scheduled to play in the metropolitan district's sectional qualifying tomorrow for the United States open championship.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- With the testimony of Thomas G. Corcoran, the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight has concluded for the moment its investigation of ethics at the Federal regulatory agencies.

Eighty-four contests for nominations to public office or major positions in the Democratic or Republican parties will be up for decision in New York City in Tuesday's primary election. Elsewhere in the state, seventeen nominations for major public office are at stake.

WILMINGTON, Del. -- Delaware is called the "First State" because it was the first to ratify the United States Constitution. However, it feels that far too many Easterners fail to put Delaware anywhere near that No. 1 position when they come to select a place to vacation or travel.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- New parks, resort facilities, and other recreational attractions are ready along the more than 10,000-mile shoreline of the Tennessee Valley Authority lakes. These lakes have become a national playground within a two-day drive for more than half the people of the United States.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 4 -- Senator John F. Kennedy invaded the political preserve of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey tonight in quest of support from Minnesota's 31-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

THE annual festival of the Royal Danish Ballet in Copenhagen closed on Tuesday, and Isadora Bennett, who will be the company's publicity representative on its second American tour, as she was on its first, has returned with both information and observations on its plans and accomplishments.
Antenino Rocca, the barefoot Argentinian, and Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, won a tag-team match before 14,538 fans attending the exhibition wrestling at Madison Square Garden last night.
Current style preferences among home seekers are leading home builders to turn to new forms of hybrid design, in which they combine exterior and interior features that answer the prevailing demand.

The Wasters AS third item in his rundown of American mores -- "The Hidden Persuaders" and "The Status Seekers" (120,000 and 200,000 hard cover copies) were the first two -- Vance Packard's next book will deal with "The Waste Makers."
Dr. John V.L. Hogan has been elected to the board of the TELautograph Corporation. He is president in charge of engineering of Hogan Laboratories, Inc.

HONG KONG, June 4 -- The recent abortive summit conference and the period of history Just before it convened have shed new light on the present-day nature and policies of the Chinese Communist regime.

STONY POINT, N.Y. -- Those urbanites to whom summer means the call of the open road need not wander far to find it. For here in Rockland County, just a stone's throw from the canyons of Manhattan, is an area that is ideal for hiking and for viewing, at first hand, the wonders of nature.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 4 -- Cotton Blossom IV, Fun and Storm clamped partial holds on the main silverware in the New York Yacht Club sailing today. They were best in their classes in an event that went back 106 years, which put it among the ancients of American sports.
The development of a cooling system that can be integrated with the existing heating plant of an apartment house has made possible the use of individual window units with central air conditioning.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 4 -- President Sukarno returned today from a two-month world tour today amid expectations of an early showdown with his critics.

HOLLYWOOD THE two men sat facing one another in an unsinkable office of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio, craning their necks occasionally over small walls of books, as they plotted the course the H.M.S. Bounty would take on her first voyage across the world's movie screens since 1935.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- The San Francisco Giants won a battle of three-hitters today, beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0, before a crowd of 22,523. The triumph moved them to within a game and a half of the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates.

Governor Rockefeller has proposed a concrete program for increasing this country's rate of economic growth to 5 or 6 per cent annually. He has made plain his belief that this can be achieved without basically altering our present economic system, and his conviction, which we share heartily, that such speedier growth is essential both to meet our domestic needs and to counter the challenge posed by the rapid growth of the Soviet Union's economy.

GENEVA, June 5 -- The Swiss stock markets were exceptionally active all through the past week. Swiss issues got the main play at the outset of the week, but foreign stocks received considerable attention at the close.

The "attitudes" referred to were the steady demonstrations by Premier Castro of hostility to the United States and approval of the acts of international communism.
The Advertising Federation of America yesterday issued a comprehensive manual governing advertising ethics.

Edwin Justus Mayer's play, "Sunrise in My Pocket," has been acquired for off-Broadway presentation next fall by the new producing group, Sunrise Productions, composed of Hans Weigert and Charles Shapiro. The play will be done at the Theatre Marquee in October.

The Kratter Corporation, realty investment concern, withdrew yesterday from negotiations for the acquisition of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation's 260-acre lot in Los Angeles, which it had planned to buy for about $43,000,000.

An issue of $60,000,000 of twenty-year 5 3/4 per cent first mortgage pipeline bonds of the Midwestern Gas Transmission Company, with warrants for purchase of 240,000 common shares, are being offered to the public today by investment bankers managed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation.

YONKERS, June 6 -- Widower Creed, who equaled the world record for a mile and a half in winning the first $50,000 International Pace last week, yesterday drew the unfavorable seventh post position for the second part of the three-race series.

Negotiations between Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres collapsed abruptly early last night when the producers stormed from the bargaining table at the Manhattan Hotel, where an all-night session had been scheduled.
HIGHLANDS, N.J., June 6 -- The missile defense system in the metropolitan area got an electronic brain today with the installation of a complex system called the Missile Master.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points off to 3 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
New York Airways, Inc., started a daily helicopter service for sight-seers here yesterday.

Frank Fernandez led off the bottom of the eleventh inning with a home run and Curtis posted a 1 -- 0 victory over Brooklyn Tech in a Public Schools Athletic League semi-final baseball game at Clove Lakes Park Staten Island yesterday.
Negotiations for the Hilton chain to take over the new Zeckendorf Hotel project have broken down, spokesmen for both sides said yesterday.

The general feeling at Belmont Park before yesterday's program was that an impressive performance by the Cain Hoy Stable's Tooth and Nail in the feature would make him a certain starter in Saturday's $125,000-added Belmont Stakes.
For the first time in its seventeen-year history, the New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., is considering increasing its top price of $3.95 because of rising production costs.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- An authority on polaomyelitis said here today that it was "incontestable" that live-ivrus vaccines were safe for the recipient.
TRENTON, June 6 -- The State Assembly assured New Jersey commuters today that assential rail services would continue.
TOKYO, June 6 -- Japan's Socialist party adopted a resolution today demanding that President Eisenhower cancel his scheduled visit here June 19 to 22.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 6 -- Governor Rockefeller toured the Sullivan County resort area in an open car today. He sported a fancy beret, addressed 2,000 Lions at their state convention, delivered homilies to school children, ate gefuelte fish in front of cameras, and politicked with the Republican leaders and legislators of six counties.

ST. STEPHEN, N.B., June 6 -- Some of the wisest old heads hereabouts do much of their fishing in Sandy Brook, partly because they made it what it is today. What it is today is pretty good: It is full of large brook trout.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The New York law barring convicted felons from holding office in waterfront unions was upheld today by a divided Supreme Court.

PARIS, June 6 -- Events since the Allied armies stormed ashore in Normandy sixteen years ago have transformed Germany from the common enemy into an essential element of European security, France's Foreign Minister said today.
PRINCE ALBERT, Sask., June 6 -- The Diefenbaker image, which captured the prairies in the last Federal election, is figuring only slightly in the provincial electoral campaign.
HARTFORD, June 6 -- Con necticut Republicans gathered in convention tonight to line up behind Vice President Nixon and proclaim hopefully the revival of the party's state organization.

The city is moving to make more specific the qualifications for 350 to 400 city jobs that are appointive and exempt from Civil Service and that will share in a $640,000 pay rise set by Mayor Wagner last April 1 in the 1960-61 budget.
LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- The first freighter to be built here since World War II was launched today.
A troupe of circus aerialists led by a midget took a flyer on high finance and landed yesterday in a police net.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP) -- Rookies led the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-1 victory over the Washington Senators. Chuck Estrada scattered six tonight as hits for his sixth victory.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 6 (AP) -- Machinists struck today at key bases from coast to coast that test intercontinental Atlas missiles and would fire them in a war.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 6 -- Violence broke out between armed political factions in the Oruro mining district today in the wake of Victor Paz Estenssoro's election as President yesterday.

One of the nation's leading tax authorities called yesterday for a re-allocation of tax sources within the United States to protect individual freedom, private enterprise and national economic growth.
East Harlem called a "town meeting" last night to tell Mayor Wagner and commissioners or deputies from fourteen city departments about community needs and possible soltions to them.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You quoted the Peking Review on May 26, saying that the survivors of a nuclear war (presumably Chinese) would rear a glorious civilization on the ruins of capitalistic imperialism. So why, the Review asks in effect, work for coexistence and East-West negotiations?
THE instalment of "Open End" that ran into the early hours of yesterday morning was the comedy highlight of the television season.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Russian Orthodox Church won a complete victory today in a fifteen-year struggle with an American faction of the church for control of St. Nicholas Cathedral in New York.

Tommy Pacheco, a 19-year-old Puerto Rican lightweight, underwent brain surgery early this morning. He had been rushed to Roosevelt Hospital last night after being knocked out in the tenth round of a fight with Benny Gordon of New York at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Alaska, the forty-ninth state, is outrunning all others so far heard from in the 1960 census in percentage increase in population.

Title to the industrial property at East 153d Street and the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx has been taken by John A. Billiard, real estate investor. The property, which was held by the Consolidated Edison Company, was formerly used by the utility for its central repair and maintenance shops.
BOSTON, June 6 (UPI) -- Arthur W. Eckman of Cambridge, Mass., was named president of the Mother Church, The First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston, at the annual meeting today.
PARIS, June 6 -- The weathered, cracked nine-year-old "temporary" buildings at the Palais de Chaillot finally are coming down.
Ten rabbis were ordained last night as a class of more than 100 students was graduated by the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in exercises at Temple Emanu-El.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6 -- President Eisenhower spent the sixteenth anniversary of his launching of the Allied invasion of Normandy in a round of alumni activities at the United States Military Academy.

The world's first offshore sulphur mine -- an immense $30,000,000 steel island seven miles off the Louisiana coast -- was put into commercial production yesterday. The sulphur deposit was discovered by the Humble Oil and Refining Company, which assigned the sulphur rights to the Freeport Sulphur Company.

Short-term interest rates were marked down yesterday in the wake of the reduction of the discount (lending) rate from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent last week in two Federal Reserve districts. Rates on bankers acceptances were cut 1/8 point and on finance paper 1/4 to 1/2 point.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Three West Virginians said today that they had received assurances from Justice Department officials that the Government would be "specially alert" to violations in the general election in November.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to create thirty-five Federal judgeships.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Administration announced today that cities that had persistent high unemployment would receive preference in the placement of Government contracts and Federally financed plants.

The Metropolitan Museum announced yesterday an acquisition of first importance and immediately put it on exhibition. It is "The Fortune Teller," a painting by the seventeenth-century French artist Georges de La Tour.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Hetter told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that there was no plan to cancel or postpone President Eisenhower's visit to Japan this month.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 7 -- The number of foreign physicians comin to this country for hospital training will be sharply curtailed after July 1, Dr. Dean F. Smiley, director of the Educational Council for Foreign Medical Graduates, said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- Social workers of the country proposed a political platform for social welfare here today, and representatives of the Democratic and Republican National Committees gave cautious comment.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 7 -- The Bergen County Board of Taxation was ordered today in Superior Court to equalize the assessed value of taxable personal property as well as real property on the basis of its true value, so that each taxing district would bear its full and just share of the county tax burden.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The United States has politely acknowledged Premier Khrushchev's revised disarmament proposals.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee added $608,000,000 to the defense spending bill today, including funds for a supercarrier.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor announced yesterday that it would hold a public hearing on criminal infiltration on the waterfront.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When the President's trip to Japan was first planned it seemed a fitting climax to the celebration of the hundredth anniversary of Japanese-American relations. The situation has now so changed, however, that it is essential, both for the President's safety and for American prestige, that the visit be postponed.
HAVANA, June 7 -- United States and British oil refineries in Cuba have rejected the demand of Premier Fidel Castro's regime that they refine Soviet crude oil, according to reliable sources.
Double standing by trucks will become legal in New York City in about ten days.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- European and Hollywood royalty met today and neither group was fazed.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today the award of a contract for the development of an ion rocket to power interplanetary space craft.

Twenty-five-year collateral trust bonds of The Pennsylvania Company bearing 5 1/4 per cent interest coupons were offered to the public yesterday at 100.50 to yield 5.214 per cent. The $35,000,000 issue was offered by the First Boston Corporation, Glore, Forgan Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates.

Mayor Wagner stressed the accomplishments of the Jewish Board of Guardians at a ceremony yesterday dedicating the agency's new headquarters building at 120 West Fifty-seventh Street. He praised its advanced program in the field of mental health.

THE ORGANIZATIONS The members of Actors Equity Association, who are professional actors and stage managers, number almost 12,000. Seven hundred and thirty-one were involved in the twenty-two Broadway productions that are now closed.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- Vice President Nixon was making a better showing than Gov. Edmund G. Brown in the California Presidential primary tonight.
Buyers by the thousands began writing orders in earnest yesterday for fall lines of women's and children's apparel.

Rene J. Dubos, author of "The Mirage of Health," published last year by Harper, has won the $5,000 Passano Award for 1960. The presentation is in recognition of Dr. Dubos' "many and fruitful researches in bacteriology and biochemistry."
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 7 -- A 37-year-old physician was charged today with murder in the shotgun slaying yesterday of a colleague in the parking area of St. Elizabeth Hospital.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 7 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association opened a tournament today in memory of Mrs. Jerome Herbert. Her husband donated the Grace H. Herbert trophy in honor of an "outstanding golfer, sportswoman and competitor."
Democratic reform leaders scored a smashing primary victory yesterday over candidates backed by Carmine G. De Sapio on Manhattan's West Side.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Spokesmen for both the World Health Organization and the Pan American Health Organization stressed today that extremely exacting standards had been set up for live virus poliomyelitis vaccine.
BALTIMORE, June 7 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers downed the Baltimore Orioles, 5 -- 2, tonight as Don Mossi held the league leaders to six hits.
PARIS, June 7 -- French intelligence services were reliably reported today to have forged and distributed three editions of the Algerian nationalists' principal publication.
Israel's rapidly expanding merchant marine is expected to reach the 1,000,000-ton mark by 1970. One of the vessels to be added to the fleet in the decade will be a 23,000-ton passenger liner.

American Metal Products Directors of the American Metal Products Company voted yesterday to reduce its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 40 cents. The dividend is payable June 30 to stockholders of record June 17.

The State Banking Board turned down yesterday the application of the New York Savings Bank to advertise and pay 4 per cent in dividends on deposits. Richard L. Maloney, president of the bank, termed the action "ridiculous" and said it was "the same old story of too little, too late."

A Bomarc missile armed with a nuclear warhead caught fire on its pad near McGuire Air Force Base, N.J., yesterday and set off a radiation alarm for a wide area. The Air Force said later that radioactive danger existed only in the launching area.
Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, is to open the British Exhibition at the New York Coliseum Friday in the presence of Vice President Nixon, Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner.
IN answer to consumer demand for do-it-yourself installation kits for air conditioning units, most manufacturers this year are offering their own "portable" units with kits.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators replaced Kansas City in sixth place tonight by beating the Athletics, 7 -- 2. Washington's fifteen-hit attack eased Camilo Pascual to his sixth victory of the season.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 7 -- Placards recommending the hiring of teen-agers for part-time, temporary and summer jobs are being distributed this week in the Five Towns area to promote Junior Dependables.
Below ground, in the East Side subway, the smoke came in sudden black puffs yesterday morning, swallowing up light and choking off breath.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 7 -- Foreign diplomats in Israel privately expressed astonishment today over Israel's explanation to Argentina of the circumstances surrounding the capture of Adolf Eichmann.
Attacks against the Roman Catholic Church by authorities in the Dominican Republic have reached a new peak. The Minister of Justice has recommended the expulsion of the Papal ambassador.
AALBORG, Denmark A NUMBER of Americans have found their way to the Danish food fair now attracting people from all over the world.
Actors and producers involved in the Broadway labor dispute dug in yesterday for what both felt would be a costly and protracted siege.
LONDON, June 7 -- There is a good deal less than meets the eye in British moves toward closer economic and political ties with the European Economic Community, authoritative sources indicated today.
Mayor Wagner repeated yesterday his "strong" belief that the city needed a new zoning law. Piecemeal amendments to the existing 1916 statute will no longer suffice, be asserted.
LONDON, June 7 -- British and Soviet negotiators opened today their annual review of the five-year trade pact their countries put into operation last July 1.
The Citizens Union, one of New York's oldest and most influential civic organizations, proposed yesterday an extensive program for reforming New York's City Charter.

LONDON, June 7 -- A Labor Member of parliament urged the British Government today to reject the "blatant monstrosity" -- an aluminum, eagle with a thirtyrfiye-foot wingspread and a golden sheen -- planned as a decorative symbol for the new United States Embassy here.

"COME Away With Me Lucille -- The Gay Days of Motoring, 1897-1912," is the title of an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. Twelve antique cars and photographs and art work of the period are included in the exhibit.
ALBANY, June 7 -- Governor Rockefeller declared tonight that demands on local government were increasing in spite of expanding state and Federal services.
YONKERS, June 7 -- The Gogo Fann's Lilac Time triumphed by a nose in the featured Kensico Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

A total of 400 policemen assisted at the subway fire yesterday morning. The men, drawn from seven station houses around Grand Central, assisted firemen and victims, rerouted traffic and warned pedestrians from subway entrances.

The radiation hazard from the burning of the equivalent of about 100 pounds of TNT in the nuclear warhead of a Bomarc missile yesterday was limited by the launching shelter in which the accident occurred.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 7 -- Mrs. James Whelan of Springdale, the Garden State Women's Golf Association champion, gained the lead today in the second round of the Elizabeth Goss round-robin tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club.
YOUNG Richard Freeman of Washington must be very tired of having to read, every time his name appears in a bridge report, that he is a former "quiz kid."
A showdown between the Air Line Pilots Association and the Federal Aviation Administrator, E.R. Quesada, appeared to be in the making yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeols threw out a deportation order today against a Korean who once had acknowledged membership in the Communist party.

An October opening for "Nat Turner" has been announced by the Arrow Players at Casa Galicia, 403 West Forty-first Street. Paul Peters is the author of the melodrama, which deals with a slave uprising in the deep South before the Civil War.

A CAN opener may be a bride's best friend, but a little more equipment is necessary to produce a meal to impress the groom. However, the selection of a kitchen trousseau may be a confusing business in the face of the battery of pots and pans displayed on the tables, walls and even ceilings of houseware shops.

Bryan Houston, president of Fletcher, Richards, Calkins Holden, Inc., speaking yesterday of creative advertising, said that it was a deadly sin to allow the lifeblood of an advertisement to be drained out "through a thousand niggling, nibbling changes."

To measure the depth of human emotion that must necessarily surround the forthcoming trial of Adolf Eichmann, one would have to be able to measure the depths of grief and of suffering, the depths of yearning and of bereavement evoked by the memory of the 6,000,000 Jews of Europe for whose fate he is charged with being directly responsible.
BECKENHAM, England, June 7 (AP) -- Earl Buchholz Jr. and Charles McKinley won two matches apiece today in the opening of the Kent lawn tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Governor Rockefeller and President Eisenhower stirred political speculation today by arranging a White House breakfast appointment tomorrow.

LONDON, June 7 -- "Do y'know what I saw at Lord's?" an elderly clubman asked. "Chaps taking off their shirts and sitting there in the sun -- basking in it, dammit. Things aren't what they used to be."
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The July soybean future sank to its lowest price of the season today in the broadest setback of several weeks.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 7 -- Mrs. F.D. Maloney of Meadow Brook carded a 41, 38 -- 79 and won the low-gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day Class A tournament at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today.
Eddie Arcaro enjoyed the calm atmosphere of the links yesterday afternoon, but he was the subject of warm discussion at Belmont Park, nevertheless.

REGINA, Sask., June 7 -- The voters of Saskatchewan will decide tomorrow whether Canada's only Socialist Government will be returned to power or thrown out, after fourteen years, in favor of a Liberal administration.
Dr. Jaime Benitez, chancellor of the University of Puerto Rico, will deliver the commencement address today at New York University.

Merchandise exports of the United States in April of this year totaled $1,806 million, the highest level achieved in any previous month in almost three years, or since May, 1957, when the figure totaled $1,813 million. For the four months of 1960 ended with April, commercial exports show a 22 per cent increase over the corresponding 1959 period, to $6,307 million.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 7 -- Mrs. Jerrold Kurtz of the Harrison Country Club carded 41, 42 -- 83 at Elmwood today to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A tournament in the Westchester section.

Members of the Edgartown, Mass., summer colony will serve as manikins for the annual fashion show July 15 at the Vineyard Country Club in Edgartown. The evening's theme will be "Around the World in Eighty Minutes."

WHITE PLAINS, June -- 7 Representative Robert R. Barry of Yonkers won renomination as the Republican candidate today in the Twenty-seventh Congressional District, which takes in the western half of Westchester County and all of Putnam County.

GENEVA, June 7 -- The Soviet Union put the case of the flight of the U-2 spy plane before the East-West disarmament conference today to back up its demand for the abolition of all foreign military bases.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Justice Department has made its first moves for the appointment of voting referees under the Civil Rights Act of 1960.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that he had sent to Congress legislation to strengthen and expand Federal and Federal-state health and medical programs.
MONTREAL, June 7 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens sent a left wing, Ab McDonald, to the Chicago Black Hawks today in a trade that involved six players.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- Following is the text of the United States note on disarmament delivered in Moscow today:

Directors of the Kendall Company yesterday voted to split the stock two-for-one. The board also intends to raise the 1960 third-quarter dividend by 20 per cent, Richard R. Higgins, president, announced yesterday.

Copper futures dropped 27 to 38 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 495 lots yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Commission house liquidation and profit-taking followed the recent strength in the market.

The concept of an all-occasion fur wardrobe was urged on the fur industry last evening by Alfred C. Thompson, executive vice president of Miller Rhoads, Inc., Richmond, Va., retail store, and president of the National Retail Merchants Association.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 2 -- Joel Brand, the bearer of Adolf Eichmann's wartime offer to barter 1,000,000 Hungarian Jews for 10,000 heavy trucks, said today that Eichmann's trial might shed light on the responsibility of others besides Nazis for the annihilation of Europe's Jews.
MADRID, June 7 -- Spain will adopt tomorrow her first new tariff law in thirty-eight years.
RIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 7 -- Two American Judaic scholars offered separate approaches today by which Jews here and the world over could strengthen their cultural and spiritual life.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- A top utility official said today the reaction of the nation's electric industry to the challenge of atomic power had "fended off what might have become a massive Governmental program."
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Life begins at forty for a new corporate stock or bond issue now-adays. It used to begin at twenty-one.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 7 -- President Oswaldo Dorticos of Cuba got a mixed reception during his one-day visit to Caracas today.
HARTFORD, June 7 -- Connecticut Republicans opened their campaign to regain control of the state today with the politically startling maneuver of advocating a general tax increase.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A group of so-called eggheads closely associated with Adlai E. Stevenson in previous campaigns is planning a formal endorsement soon of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 7 -- Vanderbilt University accepted the resignation of twelve faculty members tonight in a controversy over a Negro student's expulsion.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The 4 1/4 per cent ceiling on Government bond interest rates is up to its old tricks -- compounding confusion. The immediate confusion, which Treasury officials resolved today, is over the Treasury's new offer to exchange four-year notes and eight-year bonds this month for part of a bond issue that will not mature until November of next year.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Agreement is expected within a few weeks on another large sale of surplus commodities to Poland, State Department officials said today.
CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- A Federal jury convicted William Presser, head of the 85,000-member Ohio Teamsters Council today of a charge of obstructing justice.

A deal is pending for the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company to become the sponsor of a current-events program on Fridays from 10:30 to 11 P.M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
TOKYO, June 7 -- The Government prepared today elaborate police protection for President Eisenhower's tour in Japan June 19 to 22.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 7 -- The more than 6,000 local churches affiliated with the American Baptist Convention were called on today to provide special study courses for their members on the principles and methods of communism.
With Casey Stengel back at the helm yesterday after a ten-day absence with a virus infection, the Yankees broke the malign spell the White Sox had cast on them.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rev. George Hagmaier's letter published May 31 urging that "* * * the prestige as well as the pay of our teachers * * * be built up * * *" hints at the reason for such urging being necessary. He writes that "Russia esteems education for what it has done, and can do, for her people."

The fire at the Bomarc missile launching site at McGuire Air Force Base yesterday was the ninth "system accident" involving a nuclear warhead or bomb in the West. In no case has the bomb or warhead exploded.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Minimum-wage bills, tangled in partisan rivalries and business-labor conflicts, inched forward in both branches of Congress today.

TOKYO, June 7 -- Inejiro Asanuma, the tough 205-pounder who plays a major role in the current agitation against the United States-Japanese mutual security treaty, has been discribed by a critic as a man whose "body is too big for his brain."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 7 -- The thirty-ninth annual Greenwich Horse Show will be held on Sunday, from 9:30 A.M., on the property of William Heron at Lower Cross Road and Lake Avenue. Proceeds will benefit the Greenwich Riding Association and the St. Barnabas Guild.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of public facilities to be leased to the State government.
THE PRESIDENT Flew back from West Point; met with leaders of the Jewish War Veterans; saw members of the National Small Businessmen's Association.

The triumph of Dr. Velasco Ibarra in the Ecuadoran Presidential election on Sunday is one of the most significant and interesting events of the year in Latin America. The striking fact is that he defeated the candidates of the traditional Ecuadoran parties, running as an independent with an appeal to the Indian masses against the so-called oligarchy.

RYE, N.Y., June 7 -- A record entry of 408 began play today in the United States Senior Golf Association championship. In addition to exceeding any previous turnout in the fifty-six-year-old competition, the number of starters undoubtedly established a national high for a single day in a major tournament.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
HAVANA, June 6 -- The teacher stood before a third grade class in a Havana public school.
COMPLAINTS are beginning to come in again, as they do each summer, about charter-boat captains who harpoon fish for their own use or sport while paying anglers are aboard their boats.
ST. LOUIS, June 7 (AP) -- Robin Roberts snapped a five-game losing streak tonight by hurling the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Following are the unofficial results of yesterday's contests for nomination to public office, for district leaderships and for delegate to the national conventions. Results are complete unless otherwise noted. Asterisks denote incumbents.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Vern Law, the pitcher with the most victories in the majors this year, yielded four unearned runs in the second as the Chicago Cubs routed the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates, 13 to 2, today.

Jim Rathmann of Miami, the winner of the 500-mile race at Indianapolis on Memorial Day, has entered the Vanderbilt Cup race to be run at the new Roosevelt Raceway auto course on June 19. He will arrive in time to practice for the Formula Junior car event on June 17 and will drive in the trials June 18.

THE summer exhibition of the Museum of Modern Art, opening today, will seem to the glance-and-run visitor to be a cross between a humorous chamber of horrors and a white-elephant sale, filled with the kind of thing banished long ago as "bad taste" in a streamlined age.

Call for Help The Woman of the House obtained some solace from a recent news item about a young man, suspected of car theft, who was apprehended when he sought the aid of a patrolman after finding himself locked out of a purloined automobile.

The Merchants Refrigerating Company has sold its office and warehouse property at 17 Varick Street to an investing client of Philip J. Miller, co-broker in the sale in cooperation with Warren Lott Cruikshank, vice president of the Cruikshank Company, the broker.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington said today that the Government had an "unavoidable responsibility" to help solve labor disputes that jeopardized national security and the country's well-being.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 7 -- Mayor J. Raymond Manahan of Morristown protested today action by the State Highway Department to expedite an express highway that would cut a swath 300 feet wide through this township.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Letters showing that Dr. Henry A. Welch had solicited private business from the drug industry were made public today by the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee.
Tomas (Tommy) Pacheco showed "very slight improvement" at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday after surgery that followed his knockout loss at St. Nicholas Arena Monday night.

IT was soon apparent that Casey Stengel's virus attack had affected neither his voice nor his syntax. The Ol' Perfessor returned to work yesterday after a fortnight's absence and he was so eager to get into uniform that he checked into the still empty clubhouse four hours before game time.
LONDON, June 7 -- The stock market here, pausing for breath after its recent recovery, was stimulated today by yesterday's sharp upswing on Wall Street.

Hornblower Weeks, investment bankers and brokers, have leased about 60 per cent of the forty-seventh floor in the new Chase Manhattan Bank Building, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, for occupancy in the summer of 1961.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7 -- Bob Anderson of Cocoa, Fla., and Bill Carpenter of Springfield, Pa., a pair of Army all-America football players, were honored at the traditional athletic review held in conjunction with colorful June Week festivities at the United States Military Academy today.
A clutch of beatniks was stopped by the police from making a pit out of a Fifth Avenue show window, and thereby hangs a case of constitutional rights.
GEORGE BURNS walked away with his own one-hour show last night over Channel 4 after forty-five minutes of uneven entertainment.

As the market emerged from its recent doldrums on Monday and yesterday, the leader by points on the advance was an oil company, Superior Oil Company (California). One of the highest-price stocks on the Big Board, Superior showed a gain of 30 points on Monday and rose 32 more yesterday, to close at 1,087.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 7 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today he was now "positive" that he was going to win the Democratic nomination for President.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 11 points (55 cents a bale) up yesterday.
New York City will cooperate with the Census Bureau in a campaign to assure a more complete population count here.
CADENABBIA, Italy Only two statesmen can be considered summit winners, and neither attended the aborted Paris meeting. One is Mao Tse-tung; the other Konrad Adenauer.
The bond market winced yesterday from the impact of the Treasury's decision to go ahead at this time with its first advance refunding experiment.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 7 (AP) -- A demand that the Taft-Hartley Act be used to end a strike at four Atlas missile bases was made today. And the company that makes the rockets began to lay off workers in walkout-affected departments.

While most women are buying bathing suits, sundresses and shorts, America's designers are busy showing woolly coats, suits and fur-laden dinner costumes. These collections, the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July, attract store ex- ecutives and buyers from all over the country to New York's Seventh Aveneue.
BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- Cleveland defeated the Boston Red Sox, 12 -- 3, tonight and moved within a game and a half of first-place Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Two youths were ejected, one of them forcibly, from a hearing of the House Committee on Un-American Activities today after having applauded a witness who had denounced the investigating unit.

HALIFAX, N.S., June 7 -- Nova Scotia's Conservative government was returned to power today with increased strength. Observers considered the vote to be an endorsement of Federal policy in the Maritime Provinces.
TORONTO, June 7 (AP) -- Archie Moore will defend his world light heavyweight title against Erich Schoeppner of Germany at the Varsity Stadium here on Monday, July 18.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 7 -- Although Sir John Barbirolli, the British conductor, described Israeli qualms about hearing German songs in their concert halls as "rather silly," he yielded to them tonight.

INWOOD, L.I., June 7 -- The Rockville Country Club quartet of John J. Humm, Jack Sabine, Frank Meyers and Jack Dohoney combined for a 314 and won the Long Island Golf Association team title at the Inwood Country Club today.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 7 -- Attorney General Norman Erbe won the Republican nomination for Governor Monday, unofficial primary election returns showed today.
Several hundred persons were felled yesterday morning when a fire in the Lexington Avenue IRT subway spread smoke through the Grand Central area.
Nat Holman, the dean of the country's basketball coaches, has retired as the head coach of the City College team.

Broadway producers announced yesterday that forty-three stage attractions that had been scheduled to open in the fall had been indefinitely postponed because of the dispute With Actors Equity Association.

The First National City Bank of New York announced yesterday the promotion of three senior officers, effective immediately. Walter B. Wriston, in charge of the bank's overseas division, has been advanced from senior vice president to executive vice president.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored five unearned runs on two hits and three errors in a wild fifth inning tonight and defeated the Dodgers, 6 to 4.
Stocks scored good gains again yesterday and closed at the highs of the day. The rally was not quite as extensive as on Monday but it was still highly encouraging to most of Wall Street.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Grain futures prices showed some indication today of a turn from, or at least a halt in, their slow, steady and rather general decline of the last week.
FOR a man who during his college days was not sure what he wanted to do, John Rutherford Everett has succeeded in doing a lot and in relatively little time.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Surprised Republicans agreed today that Governor Rockefeller's challenge to Vice President Nixon amounted to a declaration of active candidacy for the party's Presidential nomination.
Dr Charles H. Malik, former president of the United Nations General Assembly, told Fordham University graduates yestefday that today's main problem is achieving five kinds of peace.

The Peace Committee of the Organization of the American States has condemned the Trujillo dictatorship in the Dominican Republic in terms that have no precedent in Latin-American history. This will be heartening for all the nations and all the forces in the hemisphere which hold democracy, freedom and human rights to be paramount.

ALBANY, June 8 (AP) -- Sixteen men who were prisoners in Albany County Jail have complained that they watched a 28-year-old fellow prisoner die after prison authorities had refused to give him insulin for diabetes.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Elroy Face's superb relief hurling with the bases filled in the seventh helped the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates snap a threegame losing streak with a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

PARIS, June 8 -- The Paris art world reacted unhappily today to the news that a French masterpiece whose existence never had been officially acknowledged here had been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum in New York.

HAVANA, June 8 -- Premier, Fidel Castro said today that the United States note of protest to Cuba last week was "aggressive and written in crude language." He also repeated his warning that the United States intended to launch an armed attack against Cuba.
NEWTOWN, Conn., June 8 -- Floyd Patterson insisted today that he wouldn't be "gun-shy" in his return heavyweight title bout with Ingemar Johansson on June 20.

De Sapio, the Tammany leader, after the HarrimanHogan defeat in 1958, are appropriate comment on the results of the Tuesday primary election in NewvYork City.
