WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Eisenhower will leave Sunday morning on his goodwill visit to the turbulent Far East.

Nelson of Kingston, Inc., of Kingston, Pa., manufacturer of upholstered furniture, has leased space in the New Furniture Mart, a fourteen-story building to be constructed at 201 Lexington Avenue, corner of Thirty-second Street.

Following is the sixth article in a debate on the general theme of the National Purpose, which is being presented by The New York Times in conjunction with Life Magazine. Subsequent articles will be written by Clinton Rossiter, Albert Wohlstetter and James Reston.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate unexpectedly began debate today on a bill designed to cut surplus production of wheat.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Justice Department will move shortly to counter a state court injunction that bars it from examining voting records in Alabama. It is confident of success. The injunction was issued in Montgomery last Monday.
William E. Boyland, presient of the city Tax Commision, announced yesterday that the assessed valuations for real estate for the fiscal year beginning July 1 amounted to $24,944,418,337, a record.

Mayor Wagner will hold a conference at City Hall this morning to devise plans for city, cooperation with the Census Bureau to find persons missed in the population count here,
Key members of Actors Equity and the League of New York Theatres began hunting quietly for a formula yesterday that might prove mutually satisfactory in ending the Broadway blackout.
PARAMUS, N.J., June 8 -- The revitalized North Jersey Playhouse, whose lights have been dark since Jan. 31, reopened tonight in a new home in the Bergen Mall shopping center here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8 -- In a prelude to the eighth annual Triangle round-robin golf tournament for women, a pro-celebrity event was held today at the Knollwood Country Club. The golf was good, but the autographs were better.

Billy Golembiewski, the slim Detroit bowler, posted his second major tournament victory within two months by winning the Brunswick-Ruppert invitation tourney at Madison Square Garden last night. Golembiewski, who is called Billy Gee, defeated Don Carter, the 1959 winner, in the final three-game match before 3,500.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 8 (UPI) -- An order by the Louisiana Conservation Commission that could sharply curtail development of undersea oil pools in the Gulf of Mexico went into effect today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 8 -- Nine honorary degrees were among more than 2,700 conferred at Rutgers University commencement ceremonies today.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 8 -- Old-fashioned police work in the form of on-the-beat foot patrols was described here today as a major reason why organized gangs or youthful hoodlums have not sprung up in New Jersey cities.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 8 -- An appeal to Congress to pass legislation that would empower the Justice Department "to seek injunctive relief in school desegregation cases was made here today.

The May Department Stores Company increased sales and earnings in the quarter and twelve months ended on April 30, despite unfavorable weather in many areas in late Februray and in March, Morton D. May, president, reported yesterday.

With the steel industry operating at about 62 per cent of capacity this week, there has been much conjecture as to whether the rate might go lower in the next few weeks before an expected upturn in orders is felt in August.
A group of Polish films made after the political upheaval in 1956 have been acquired for American distribution by Thomas Brandon.

The Committee on Civil Rights in Manhattan, Inc., a private citizens' group, announced yesterday that it had had only five reports of discrimination in restaurants in the last seven years. It disclaimed knowledge of any widespread bias in eating places.
HARTFORD, June 8 (AP) -- Thousands of United Aircraft Corporation employes in Connecticut went on strike today. There were scattered instances of violence.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 8 -- Would that the performance were as gay as the costumes and the scenery. The play is "Twelfth Night," which opened the sixth season of the American Shakespeare Festival this afternoon.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 8 -- One-third of Chile's terrain, a ribbonlike stretch 2,600 miles long, is showing ugly scars of the recent earthquakes, tidal waves and volcanic eruptions.
Senator John F. Kennedy will be a guest on "The Jack Paar Show" next Thursday. Whether anyone gets equal time depends on what category the show falls in. Yesterday nobody was certain.
With, perhaps their most convincing all-round performance of this somewhat lackluster season, the Yankees thrashed the White Sox, 6 -- 0, before 30,420 spectators at the Stadium last night.

Continued speculator selling depressed copper yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Scale-down dealer buying absorbed the offers. The market reflected weakness in London. WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The demand which Governor Rockefeller served on Richard M. Nixon today for a pre-convention account of his position on the issues posed by this "new period" in world history is the latest demonstration of an eternal truth in politics.

The year's biggest rally continued to roll ahead in the stock market yesterday. The threeday advance this week has added almost $9,500,000,000 to stock values. This was the largest increment since the three-day period ended on Sept. 25, 1959.

The first chancellor of New York City's municipal college system was appointed yesterday. He is Dr. John R. Everett, 41-year-old president of a small women's college in Virginia.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Housing subcommittee adopted a broad housing bill today as well as legislation to establish a new program of Federal aid for city transit and commuter systems.

LONDON, June 8 -- Industrial share prices turned irregular in quiet trading in the stock market here today.

YONKERS, June 8 -- Widower Creed, who tied the world record of 3 minutes 4 2/5 seconds for the mile-and-a-half in the opening race of the International Pace Series at Yonkers Raceway last Thursday night, is the 8-5 overnight favorite for the second of the three-race set tomorrow night.

About 1,500 persons, including his five sons, attended a memorial service yesterday for John D. Rockefeller Jr. in Riverside Church.

Bond market forces churned in conflicting fashion yesterday with the opening of the subscription period for the Treasury's $5,000,000,000 advance refunding of 2 1/2 per cent bonds not due until 1961. The offer will end on Monday.
Paul M. Butler and Senator Thurston B. Morton, the opposing national party chairmen agreed last night that bigotry would not play a decisive role in the 1960 Presidential campaign.

Jane Fonda, daughter of Henry Fonda, recently made an impressive Broadway debut in the central role of "There Was a Little Girl," which had a brief run. In her next stage appearance, she will be starred in "No Concern of Mine."

Investment bankers are offering today $8,000,000 of 5 per cent twenty-year sinking fund debentures of the Witco Chemical Company, Inc., New York City, at 100. Smith, Barney Co., Inc., and Goldman, Sachs Co. head the offering group.
AN informal proposal to start a national organization to oppose legislation restricting or regulating sporting firearms was offered here yesterday at the National Conference of the Shooting Sports.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- An emergency board recommended today that the railroads and eleven nonoperating unions settle their year-old dispute with a three-part concession to the employes, including a 5-cent-an-hour wage increase.

Governor Rockefeller demanded yesterday that Vice President Nixon make clear his position on urgent national issues in advance of the Republican National Convention.

Guggenheim, the master of Cain Hoy Stable, posted 50 for each of four 3-year-olds. He should have named a fifth colt. It would have saved him $4,950.

The seasonal increase in highway travel lightened the country's gasoline stocks by 1,745,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was the tenth consecutive weekly decline.
The Aetna Life Insurance Company has reached an agreement to acquire controlling interest in the Excelsior Life Insurance Company of Toronto, Ont., for about $5,250,000.

Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union was defeated yesterday by a vote of 52 to 43 in its drive to represent employes of the New York Shipping Association. The final tally was announced by the National Labor Relations Board.

RYE, N.Y., June 8 -- Join Dawson played par golf ane retained the United States Senior Golf Association championship today. The 57-year-old resident of Palm Desert, Calif., posted a 72 at the Apawamis Club for a 36-hole aggregate of 141.

Electric power production fell in the Memorial Day holiday week ended last Saturday to 13,134,000,000 kilowatt-hours, the, lowest level this year. A week earlier output was 13,572,000,000, and in the comparable 1959 week, which did not include the holiday, it was 13,023,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

The ten-story office building at 114-16 East Fortieth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, has been sold by the 114 East Fortieth Corporation to Harry Geisinger, a realty investor. Title was insured with the Title Guarantee Company.

While most women are buying bathing suits, sundresses and shorts, America's designers are busy showing woolly coats, suits and fur-laden dinner costumes. These collections, the American equivalent of the Paris fashion openings in July, attract store executives and buyers from all over the country to New York. The Times fashion staff is attending' the showings and will report trends from significant designers. Clothes will be in the stores beginning in late July.

Machines to teach the entire high school mathematics curriculum, two years each of four foreign languages and a large part of the college mathematics program are to be offered for classroom use a year from September.

Alfred M. Gruenther is president of the American Red Cross. Previously he was supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Orgaization forces, a four-star general in the United States Army.

The Treasury has launched its first experiment in the field of debt managing known as "advance refunding." The target of its operation is the issue of 2 1/2 per cent bonds scheduled to mature seventeen months from now. There are $11,170 million of these obligations in the hands of the public, making it the largest single block of marketable Treasury securities outstanding.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A group of New York Republican House members sought today to undercut Governor Rockefeller by a ringing endorsement of Vice President Nixon for the Presidential nomination.

With Mickey Mantle again the prime mover, the Yankees toppled the White Sox for the third straight time at the Stadium yesterday. The score was 5-2. As a result, the Bombers succeeded the 1959 American League champions in third place.
Yale University's commencement exercises, which will be held Sunday, had an off-campus tryout yesterday in an apartment on the thirty-third floor of the Waldorf Towers.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 9 -- The new military Government has decided to withdraw most of the Turkish brigade maintained in Korea since the outbreak of hostilities there in 1950.

Fourteen officers and salesmen of four Long Island home improvement corporations were accused yesterday in United States District Court, Brooklyn, of having made false statements in Federal Housing Administration applications for home improvement loans.

ELMSFORD, N.Y. June 9 -- The best golf didn't mean the most points in the Triangle round-robin tournament today. Because of the unusual point system adopted, a principal concern for each of the sixteen women professionals in the tourney was how the others in her group of four players performed.

BABY'S first sunning of the season should be no more than two or three minutes. Sun-shine, in small amounts, is beneficial to a child's health, because the sun's ultraviolet rays will supply needed vitamin D, but mothers are cautioned against harmful over-exposure.

PRINCE PHILIP, Duke of Edinburgh, husband to Queen Elizabeth II, is the most titled and experienced public relations man on earth. He married into the business at a memorable ceremony at Westminster Abbey on Nov. 20, 1947.

Art lovers in Paris who are disturbed over the acquisition of a La Tour by the Metropolitan Museum of New York continued their search yesterday to discover why the Louvre let the French mastepriece leave the country, according to reports received here.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy called Administration officials to Capitol Hill today to protest any move to supply atomic submarine secrets to France or the Netherlands.

"John Brown's Body" will begin a limited engagement of eight weeks on June 21 at the Players Theatre, 115 Macdougal Street. Charles Laughton's adaptation of Stephen Vincent Benet's Pulitzer Prize poem will be used.

This strike, which could be a more serious repetition of the forty-six-day strike against seven hospitals a year ago, must not happen.

American corporations remain awash in liquid funds, figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicate. With their quarterly tax payments due next Wednesday, businesses cut their borrowings from New York City banks $129,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the second biggest reduction this year.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Grace Line told the Federal Maritime Board today it could not operate with profit on the Caribbean-Great Lakes trade route. It asked to be permitted to end the service, which has been temporarily suspended.
Mayor Wagner and Arthur F. Young, regional census director, agreed yesterday on a vigorous "Were you counted?" campaign next week to turn up persons missed in the census.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 9 -- The Venezuelan Government has rejected an application by Air France for jet flights to Caracas. The decision was announced today.

Mrs. Henry Obre's Hustle flashed enough speed after the final jump to take the $13,950 Belmont Spring Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. The 5-year-old had a margin of a head over the favored Amateur of the Sanford Stud Farms in the test of about two miles and a furlong.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- A little more confidence was apparent in the grain futures market today and most contracts scored additional small gains on the Board of Trade.

IOWA CITY, June 9 (AP) -- Forest Evashevski, who coached Iowa football teams to national prominence, today was named the university's athletic director.

Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, flew into New York yesterday for a one-day visit to open the British Exhibition at the Coliseum today. He said he hoped the exhibition would enhance friendly relations between the American and British peoples.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt came out yesterday for a Stevenson-Kennedy Democratic ticket to meet what she termed the demands of a troubled world.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 9 (AP) -- President Jorge Alessandri said today he would ask the Anaconda and Kennecott copper companies to increase their investment in Chile by $250,000,000 in the next four years to help in rehabilitation of the country, ravaged by earthquakes.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 9 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Porfirio Herrera Baez denied today that the Dominican Republic was violating human rights as charged by the Inter-American Peace Committee in Washington yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller competed yesterday with twenty-six parades of children as the main attraction of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union's 131st Anniversary Day. Brooklyn and Queens schools are closed on this day each year so Protestant pupils can march in the parades.

New York City's municipal colleges have found their first chancellor, a young, successful and highly regarded educator, Dr. John E. Everett. He will fill an obvious need. The Board of Estimate approved yesterday new taxes by which the city will take in $11,000,000 during the next fiscal year to help make up for the repeal of the 10-cent-a-ride taxicab tax.
BOSTON, June 10 -- A campaign to restrict importations of men's caps and millinery bodies was announced here today by the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 10 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Bell Aircraft Corporation today voted overwhelmingly in favor of selling the company's defense business to the Textron Corporation for $22,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen sought to put the Senate Democratic leadership on the defensive today by calling attention to the legislative backlog.
MIAMI BEACH, June 10 -- A physician's report on a 70-year-old house painter who died twice evoked sharp interest here today at a scientific meeting of the American Geriatrics Society.
A young Chinese man who might have been an American citizen had his father survived the sinking of a heavy cruiser in 1942 faces deportation next week unless special action is taken.
The Department of Traffic is using a proper owl and an ungrammatical cat to promote pedestrian safety these days.

MANILA, June 10 (AP) -- President Carlos P. Garcia said today that the United States had promised to consider a Philippine request to station "defensive" missiles, capable of carrying nuclear warheads, in the Philippines.

"THEY are trying to make an elder statesman of me, but they will never succeed," former President Harry S. Truman recently remarked in reply to a question as to whether he pleaded guilty to the charge of growing mellow and less militant.
This week's spectacular rally in the stock market coasted to a slow stop yesterday. Wall Street was not surprised.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter proposed today an international conference to work out new rules of protocol that would spare foreign ministers the need of engaging in so many ceremonies and international meetings.

BROCKENHURST, England, June 10 -- Fifty years ago yesterday Theodore Roosevelt, accompanied by Sir Edward Grey, then Britain's Foreign Secretary and one of the country's leading bird experts, hiked through wilds of the New Forest to watch English birds.
Long Island University graduated 447 students and conferred five honorary degrees at commencement ceremonies yesterday in the Paramount Theatre in downtown Brooklyn.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 -- About 5,000 Princeton graduates, dressed in gaudy costumes and accompanied by bizarre floats, will march in the fiftieth annual alumni "Parade" here tomorrow.
National Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for an immediate restraining order to stop a proposed merger of Trans World Airlines and Northeast Airlines.

A period largely dominated by offerings of issues of municipalities and their agencies is in prospect next week in the market for the capital. Tax-exempt issues of major proportions totaling about $140,000,000 are expected.
NEW DELHI, India, June 10 -- Two major battles between Tibetans and Chinese Communist troops were reported today in southern Tibet near the Nepalese frontier.
PARIS, June 10 -- Public services throughout France were halted or considerably slowed today by a strike of almost a million civil servants.
CHICAGO, Juns 10 (AP) -- Grain futures prices followed their recent general pattern today with weakness in corn and soybeans and steadiness elsewhere.

EDGBASTON, England, June 10 (Reuters) -- England struck back after being dismissed for 292 and captured five South African wickets for 114 by the close of the second day of the test match today.

Earnings of the Columbia Pictures Corporation rose in the thirty-nine weeks to March 26 to $534,000 from $275,000 in the year-ago period, the company announced yesterday. After deductions for preferred dividends, share earnings totaled 28 cents, up from 8 cents last year.

The Middle States and Middle Atlantic Lawn Tennis Association gained the final round in the thirty-fourth annual Sears Cup women's tennis team competition yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

Fixed-interest securities moved ahead smartly again yesterday as state funds and individuals entered the market in force.
HOUSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Charlie Tidwell of Kansas tied the world record in the 100-meter dash tonight with a 10.1 second victory at the Meet of Champions.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 10 -- Two men were dead and five others missing at sea today. The men had been on a secret scientific project.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets remained at 119.7 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Because of its remoteness, Staten Island "is being shortchanged" by voluntary health and welfare agencies here, Dr. Blanche Bernstein, research director of the Community Council of Greater New York, said last week.
Bryant High defeated Curtis, 3 -- 0, and won its fourth Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship yesterday behind Richie Sanita's fast-breaking curve, at the Parade Grounds, Brooklyn.

The formation of an organization "to present the viewpoint of the airline passenger," keep members abreast of developments in the field of air transport and provide them with flight insurance was announced last week.
An area of 4,000-year-old ruins stretching for more than eight miles was discovered in Pakistan recently by Dr. Walter A. Fairservis Jr. of the American Museum of Natural History.

EVER since the structural fiasco of the Tower of Babel, man has dreamed of the skyscraper. His persistent, starry-eyed pursuit of the super-building has been probably the most enduring architectural romance of history; technological developments have made its realization possible.
The water-pollution situation at fourteen bathing areas in the city remains much the same this year as for the last thirteen years.

MAJOR ISSUES PRESIDENT'S TRIP Any lingering doubts as to the fundamental unwisdom of personal high-level diplomacy have surely been removed by the reception Mr. Hagerty got * * * in Tokyo. * * * So far has the practice of diplomacy deteriorated that heads of state can now become personally involved in questions of face by proxy.
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., June 11 -- Rockland County hospital facilities will be enhanced tomorrow when the 152-bed Spring Valley General Hospital, two miles north of here, opens.

THE Museum of Modern Art's Art Nouveau show, which opened Wednesday, is a very nice double-header, with one of the heads invisible. As a summer exhibition, when traditionally we want something pretty light, it is an entertaining display of objects in a style toward which we have adopted the convenient and effortless attitude of amused superiority for several decades.

LONDON, June 11 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union broadcast today a satiric imaginary telephone conversation between President Eisenhower and his press secretary, James C. Hagerty, on an English-language program beamed to Southeast Asia.

MANY transcontinental motorists are inclined to think of Illinois either as a Vast empty island around Chicago or as one of the Midwestern States that have to be crossed as quickly as possible in the great rush to reach the West Coast.

Retail sales in this area last week were 5 per cent above the 1959 level, according to estimates by leading merchants. Consumer buying presented a spotty picture. Many department stores with heavy inventories of air conditioners and fans reported sales of these goods below those in 1959 because of recent cool weather.

THIS is the week that America's roughriders gallop into action as the annual round of rodeos gets under way across the nation. Twelve states in the West and Midwest have scheduled rodeos this week, and before the summer ends, dudes from Louisiana to Canada will be given the opportunity to witness Wild West shows in their own back yard.
East Harlem, whose residents are of Italian and Puerto Rican ancestry, will take part in a Good Neighbor Week beginning today.

ON the current list of paper-backs are approximately 6,500 titles, ranging from "The ABC Murders" (Agatha Christie; Pocket Books, 25c) to "Zorba the Greek" (Nikos Kazan tzakis; Simon Schuster, $1.75), embracing a massive chunk of the sum of human taste and knowledge.
Post-mortems on the U-2 were still being held this week, and a balanced judgment will have to await the substantiating footnotes of time.
Two top leaders of the Amerian Baptist Convention have endorsed the Roman Catholic hirarchy's view on the separation, of church and state in this country.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 11 -- East Hampton's social calendar this season includes sailing races and golf tournaments, a pet show and outdoor barbecue, fashion shows and opera, art exhibitions and theatrical productions, well-scattered throughput the season so that there will be plenty of time left for swimming, sunning, partying and loafing.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 11 -- Five thousand Princeton University alumni, ranging from members of this year's graduating class to a 94-year-old member of the class of 1888, donned bright orange costumes today and marched through town in the annual reunion Prade.

TRENTON -- The New York City motorist who enjoys a day-long drive through scenic and historic country should find both stimulating and relaxing a tour of the by-ways and less-publicized points of interest in New Jersey.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- More than 80 per cent of Florida's summer visitors arrive by automobile, according to tabulations by the Florida Development Commission. Many of these are family groups: parents who are much younger than the majority of winter visitors and often with one to three or four children of junior ages.

WHAT miracles might have been produced in the electric blender if it had been in existence during the golden age of French cuisine! That is to say, during the era that ended in 1935 with the death of Auguste Escoffier -- "the king of chefs and the chef of kings." During Escoffier's long lifetime, and for several centuries before that, the finest creations were made -- magnificent sauces, entrees and desserts.
Adlai E. Stevenson was reported yesterday to have again expressed a willingness to run for President a third time if the Democratic party should draft him.

"I 'M the father! I'm the father!"cried a blue - eyed golden-haired tot over and over again to her 4-year-old playmates. "I won't play house unless I am." Her declaration to the nursery class of a dozen boys and girls set off a pandemonium of shrill little voices, each exclaiming that he or she wanted to be the father.

IN a spacious triangle of the East Bronx, between the Hutchinson River Parkway and the New England Thruway, on 205 acres of what used to be swamp, mudbank, wasteland and the Hutchinson River, they are putting the finishing touches to the United States of America.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11 -- Lebanon will begin choosing a new ninety-nine-member Parliament tomorrow after an election campaign marked by former President Camille Chamoun's return to active politics.

HARTFORD, June 11 -- The Democratic State Convention will convene here on Friday to name Connecticut's forty-two delegates, each with one-half vote, to the Democratic National Convention opening July 11 in Los Angeles.

In talks and writings, the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board regularly extol the virtues of a free market for funds. Yet, despite repeated appeals, they have declined to remedy a situation that has forced as much as $1,000,000,000 from United States banks to find haven abroad.

Mockoranges, tree lilacs and late rhododendrons form bright backgrounds for June's display of roses. In some gardens hardy waterlilies splash pools with color, while peonies, poppies and annuals accent flower borders. The showy blossoms of the mountain laurel, flame azaleas and hawthorns light the woodlands.

It is no accident that Cus D'Amato, the man who guided Floyd Patterson to the heavy-weight title, has stayed in the background during Patterson's preparations for his rematch with Ingemar Johansson at the Polo Grounds a week from tomorrow.

STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga. -- A long-cherished Southern dream appears to be coming true. It seems assured that not only will there be a Confederate memorial on the huge granite monolith that towers over this little village of 2,000 but also that the mountain itself will be developed into a major tourist attraction.
THE enigma of China has suddenly thrust itself into the center of the world's consciousness with the unexpected and, to some extent, still unexplained miscarriage of the summit conference.
WHITE PLAINS, June 11 -- Census reports for Westchester gave impetus today to a movement for a reapportionment of members of the County Board of Supervisors.
A ranch model with three or four bedrooms has been, opened at Colonial Oaks, a new development off Dunhams Corner Road, East Brunswick, N.J.

EDMOND SOUCHON of New Orleans is a rarity among the amateurs (in the proper sense of the word) of jazz. Now in his sixties and still enjoying an outstanding career as a surgeon, Dr. Souchon has loved and dallied with jazz since his very early boyhood.

The following list of 100 books has been selected by the staff of the Book Review from the approximately 5,000 titles published so far this year. Such a list can suggest only the high points in the main fields of reader interest.
HAMBURG, Germany HANS WERNER HENZE, 35-year-old German composer, has had his third opera, "Der Prinz von Homburg," performed in a brilliant world premiere at the Hamburg State Opera.

NUEVO LAREDO, Tamaulipas, Mexico -- This border city, just across the Rio Grande from Laredo, Texas, is the most popular port of entry for Eastern tourists visiting Mexico. It is about 150 miles straight south by four-lane highway U.S. 81 from San Antonio, Texas, and marks the beginning of the Pan American Highway, most direct and improved route to Monterrey and Mexico City, 770 miles away.

Word from Chile reports that all existing maps of that country are now obsolete as one consequence of the terrible earthquakes of recent weeks. The convulsions of the earth have radically changed much of the coastline as the sinking of the earth has permitted the ocean to penetrate at points into what used to be far inland.

WHEN Andrew Jackson stepped down from the inaugural platform after Martin Van Buren was sworn in as his successor, a shout rose from the witnessing throng, wrote Thomas Hart Benton, such as "power never commanded, nor man in power received.

Venezuela's rejection last week of Air France's application to fly jets to Caracas fits a pattern of protectionism emerging in some South American countries since the advent of the Jet Age, according to some observers.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 11 -- The Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Division of New York City arrived at near-by Camp Drum today to open the biggest summer-training season in the history of the military reservation.

In "Plea for Fairer Ladies" (May 22) Marya Mannes asserted that, at too many plays during the recent theatre season, the audience had been "harrowed, shocked or simply mesmerized by very unpleasant characters doing very unpleasant things and using very unpleasant language."

MONTE CARLO, June 11 -- When he became Prince Sovereign of Monaco upon the death of his grandfather in 1949, Rainier in was 26 years old, pudgy and babyfaced, but a man of bull-like strength and tenacity.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Tri-City Suncoast Fiesta, one of the most ambitious summer entertainment projects ever undertaken in this part of Florida as a tourist lure, will get under way June 25 and continue through July.
Washington was taking a new look at its military power position last week and at its intelligence gathering facilities.
This is the time of the year when reports abound of scouts from big companies besieging campuses to snatch newly-minted graduates, especially in the engineering specialties.

MADISON, Wis., June 11 (AP) -- California withstood a driving finish by Navy today and won a three-college inter-sectional rowing regatta on Lake Monona. Wisconsin, the host school, finished third, about four lengths back.
VIENNA, June 8 -- A Czechoslovak official has disclosed how the under-developed members of the Soviet bloc are paying for their industrial development programs.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Ever since the end of Reconstruction, when Congress abandoned the attempt to enforce Negro rights in the South by bayonet, the courts have been the real instruments of national policy on the racial question.

SOME of the most consistently imaginative and perceptive folk-music field recordings of the last few years have been the work of Samuel B. Charters. This young poet-researcher-musician, motivated by an interest in solving "several esthetic questions about Negro music," has produced a shelfful of LP's on the origins of jazz, country blues and other meritorious projects.

CURT JURGENS, the tall, handsome, multilingual (French, German, English) film star not only is being kept busy on an international scale but also is about to enter independent movie-making. Here last week to dub English dialogue for the German-made historical drama, "Katia," which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will release and in which he plays Czar Alexander II, Mr. Jurgens revealed that he would star in and produce (for his own company, Cinestar) the tentatively titled "The Cage."
KINGS PARK, L. I., June 11 -- This year's Summer Day festivities at St. Johnland Home for the Aged will be reminiscent of an old-fashioned country fair.

THE needle can be a more effective weapon than the axe, a theme which might have suggested one more fable to bring William March's collection to an even 100. While other observers of human comedy beat their breasts and cry against man's stupidity, Mr. March jabs adroitly, and pinks his targets in most vulnerable spots.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, aided by five errors, whipped the San Francisco Giants, 9 -- 5, today before 36,711 fans in Candlestick Park.
New trends in the movement of families into, about and out of New York City are apparent in the incomplete 1960 census figures, business and real estate spokesmen said yesterday.
Each weekday morning on the 8:40 train to New York City from a Westchester suburb, there is a young man who sits alone reading the "Help Wanted" pages.

DETROIT, June 11 -- A drive to obtain signatures in support of a constitutional convention in Michigan has reached the crucial stage. Michigan's unhappy experience last year in trying to obtain sufficient funds to meet state obligations appears to be providing impetus in the drive.
GENEVA, June 10 -- "Old Scratchy is talking about those certain circles again," a Western diplomat said glumly the other day. "You know what that means."

A NEW front walk built of colorful flagstone or slate laid in a bed of cement will make a permanent improvement for any home. Handymen who are reasonably familiar with shovel and trowel will find that the project is not difficult -- though it does require more time and effort than a similar walk built of plain concrete.
TO THE EDITOR: Douglass Cater in "Advice and Dissent About the Best Man" (May 22) does an efficient job of demolishing a Best Man of Straw.

PARIS. UNDER the direction of A. M. Julien, the national lyric theatres of France -- the Opera and Opera-Comique -- are destined for change. When he took over last year in the drastic shakeup decreed by Andre Malraux, the de Gaulle Government's minister for cultural activities, he said that he needed three years to effect reforms.

TO THE EDITOR: If I understand what Professor Jaffe was trying to say -- and I am not at all sure that I do -- in his long reply to my article on the crux of the current Supreme Court split, it was that I had oversimplified the problem.

ALLERTON PARK, ILL., June 7 -- A young German physicist sat in a conference room here yesterday and today and listened to eighty of his peers talking about a whole new field of research that he himself created.
Overcrowding in the city's prisons has been reduced substantially in the six years since Mrs. Anna M. Kross became Commissioner of Correction, but it is still dangerously high.
Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel twice overruled a magistrate yesterday and granted two successive applications for bail in a homicide and felonious assault case.
A walkout of Eastern Air Lines pilots yesterday grounded 104 flights out of major cities in the East, Midwest and South. The line operates approximately 400 flights daily.
The city has conferred scrolls of achievement on ten Puerto Rican residents in a move to aid the integration of the 700,000 persons here who were born in Puerto Rico or who have Puerto Rican parents.

GLEN ELLEN, Calif. -- Here in the picturesque Valley of the Moon, about fifty-five miles north of San Francisco, the state of California is creating an unusual literary shrine and state park. It is the Jack London Historic Monument, which is scheduled to open to the public on July 1.

BOSTON, June 11 -- Sugar Ray Robinson was the greatest fighter of his fistic generation, but he has moved completely into the past tense. A gross caricature of himself in the Boston Garden last night, the sweep-swinging kid of yesteryear was a bumbling and weary old man as he again was beaten by Paul Pender for a fractional share of the world middleweight championship.
BOSTON -- Tourists visiting this dear old aunt of American cities this year should be prepared to see some face-lifting. That is not to say that Boston has the door closed. Far from it.

THE forty-three European travel agents who were wandering about New York City last week made very little impression upon the town because they were less than a drop in the June bucketful of tourists on Manhattan Island.

ASHEVILLE, N. C. -- On the basis of what Publius Syrus, a Roman play-wright of 50 B. C., said in his collection of moral maxims, "No pleasure lasts long unless there is variety in it," visitors to the vacationland of western North Carolina may plan for a fairly long and very pleasant stay this summer.

YORK, Pa. -- This southern Pennsylvania town will hold its third annual "Colonial Days" observance on four successive weekends commencing next week, with a grand finale in September. The celebration is designed to call attention to the fact that York served as the national capital for nine eventful months during the Revolutionary War.
TOKYO, June 11 (AP) -- Six wide-eyed American youngsters mingled with an angry mob of Left-Wing students demonstrating tonight before Premier Nobusuke Kishi's private residence.
BONN, Germany, June 11 -- West Germany, a country only twice the size of New York State, is having trouble adapting its crowded territory to the demands of the air age.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Ten years ago the United States imported not quite $200,000,000 worth of goods from Japan. This year the figure will be something more than $1,000,000,000. For a year now, and for the first time, Japan has been selling more than she buys in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Governor Rockefeller called this week for "plain talk," but he wasn't plain enough himself. His complaint is not really against what Vice President Nixon has not said, but about what he has said. He is not full of admiration for President Elsenhower's leadership, as he indicated in this statement Wednesday, but full of anxiety about it.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 11 (AP) -- About 30,000 Alaskans are expected to turn out here tomorrow to greet President Eisenhower on his first visit to the new forty-ninth state, which has a total population of 223,000.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senate and House Committees are on the verge of approving minimum-wage legislation for floor action.
THE annual flood of tourists has begun pouring out of New York bound for Europe. Soon the returning wave will intensify the perennial war between tourists and customs inspectors.
LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- There's a legend among seafaring men that it's unlucky to fool around with an albatross, Which is said to be the soaring spirit of dead sailors.

IF there is a reluctant reader about the house, the wise parent will lay in -- especially during the summer months -- a few good mystery stories, junior grade. Many a hesitant youngster, a little timid about tackling one of those long books which are heartily recommended as being "good for him," has been eased over the reading hump with the help of a smart detective.

In transforming their concrete back yard into a patio garden Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Weingarten of Manhattan were confronted with several problems. The area was surrounded by stone and brick, necessitating a formal rather than naturalistic design.

YONKERS, June 11 -- Tom Murphy brightened the United States' hopes of retaining the Olympic 800-meter title by ripping off today the fastest half-mile ever run in the East. The powerful 24-year-old Manhattan graduate whirled twice around the eccentrically shaped War Memorial Field track in 1 minute 48.2 seconds in defending his 880-yard crown in the Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

Faith and Reason A FAITH is not acquired by reasoning. One does not fall in love with a woman, or enter the womb of a church, as a result of logical persuasion. Reason may defend an act of faith -- but only after the act has been committed, and the man committed to the act.
New Federal mediation machinery in the maritime field has won approval from both labor and management, Joseph F. Finnegan declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The mass use of live-virus vaccines may eradicate poliomyelitis as a human disease, a conference of specialists reported here today.

QUANTICO, Va., June 11 (AP) -- Bill Nieder, his right knee swathed in bandages, bounced back into action today after a month in sick bay and got off a 62-foot 7-inch shotput. His performance highlighted the final day of the Armed Forces track and field championships.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 -- Bob Nieman's two-out double drove in the tying and winning runs in the ninth inning today as the St. Louis Cardinals scored three times to beat the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 -- 6.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Government published today a special guide designed to dispel some of the confusion surrounding the vast array of man-made "miracle" fibers.

How will the rarified air of Colorado affect the play in the United States Open golf chair pionship this week? Most observers agree that the Rocky Mountain atmosphere will be an important factor. At approximately one mile above sea level, 150 experts will swing into action at the Cherry Hills Country Club, near Denver, on Thursday.
NASHVILLE, June 11 -- Vanderbilt University failed this week to close a widening breach between the faculty and the administration.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The proposed "fair trade" law appeared today to be abandoned until the next Congress convenes.

President Eisenhower embarks today on the most controversial and potentially hazardous enterprise in his long and thus far highly successful series of goodwill missions abroad. He plans to visit four allied countries in the turbulent Far East.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 11 (AP) -- Massachusetts Republicans broke tradition today in their state convention and nominated a wealthy contractor of Italian extraction for Governor and a Negro for Secretary of State.
PLYMOUTH, England, June 11 (Reuters) -- One of four oneman yachts that set sail today in a Plymouth-to-New York race was towed back to Plymouth Harbor tonight with a mast snapped by high winds.
Inspired by the new forty-eight-story Time-Life Building the postwar realty boom in midtown Manhattan is moving west of Fifth Avenue for the first time in nearly two decades.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 11 -- A Family Festival, a fair designed to interest the entire family, will be held at the Peck School on Friday and Saturday.

LONDON. THE thing that one senses most, keenly in scanning the making of motion pictures in Britain today is that London is, indeed, a major crossroads in the international operation and flow of films.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 11 -- More than half the men who first enter state mental hospitals in New York State when over the age of 60 die within a year. A third of them die within three months.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 11 (AP) -- An Atlas missile was sent 5,000 miles down the Atlantic missile range today in a successful first test of the new inertial guidance system. It covered the distance in twenty minutes.

BOSTON, June 11 (UPI) -- A seven-run third inning earned an 8-4 victory for the Chicago White Sox over the Bos Red Sox tonight, after Bos had snapped a seven-game osing streak, 5 -- 4, in a day game.

HAVANA, June 9 -- An estimated total of seventy to eighty Soviet industrial, mining, trade and cultural experts are working in Cuba as the vanguard of what is expected to become a major technical assistance group here.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Vice President Nixon called or Republicans today to discuss their differences over Administration policies and national issues before their Presidential nominating convention.

THE Venezuelan Government is now evidencing great interest in its tourist industry, and in order to create a similar interest on the part of North American travelers, it is offering a bargain in an all-expense, one-week air tour to Venezuela.
The Greater New York Conference of the Seventh-day Adventist Church has opened negotiations to purchase the House of Rest sanitarium in Sprain Ridge, Yonkers.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 11 -- Ch. Mity Cochise of Rednuht (the last name spelling thunder backward) took the best-in-show award at the twenty-eighth. Greenwich Kennel Club event today. The show drew 680 dogs to Yale Farms on a perfect day.

WARNING to Weishmen: Don't hit the Queen or snatch things from her; she won't like it. That notice to Courtiers was posted before 1066. Part of the All That brought from Normandy by William the Conqueror was the notion of an orderly and elegant Court.

THREE men with a sense for the abstract are exhibiting representative examples of their work at the Poindexter Gallery, 21 West Fifty-sixth Street. Many of the prints will be included in a book, "Under the Sun: The Abstract Art of Camera Vision," to be published this fall by Brazille Inc.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., June 11 -- Ramming home three birdies and an eagle on the back nine, Louise Suggs extended her lead in the women's professional round-robin at the Knollwood Country Club today. She fired a 3-under-par 37, 33 -- 70 and lifted her score plus 49 standings after four rounds.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Detailed plans for President Eisenhower's three-day visit to Japan were withheld today as he prepared to leave for the Far East on what probably will be his last major overseas trip as President.
The sharp gain in United States exports in April reported last week by the Department of Commerce was heartening news for a number of reasons.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Barely 60 per cent of those eligible voted at the last Presidential election. Why do so many fail to vote? Indifference, lack of interest in public affairs and just plain laziness is the answer. The average person, when he opens his newspaper, glances casually at the headlines on the front page.

The recommendations of the Presidential emergency board for the settlement of the dispute between the railroads and the eleven unions representing more than half a million non-operating employes deserve national attention for at least two important reasons. In the first place the board's proposals, taken in connection with the recent locomotive engineers' arbitration award and the settlement of the conductors' dispute, suggest an industry-wide wage pattern that gives promise of acceptance all around.

PARIS, June 11 -- Business men all over Europe with any ability to read between the lines were waking up today to the realization that the Continent was going to be split indefinitely into two trading groups.

The committee arranging the visit to Freedomland on Saturday, the day before the official opening of the entertainment center in the Bronx, has announced the patrons who plan to attend the preview, which will benefit the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.

THE hero of Fitzgerald's short story, "Winter Dreams," is a former caddie who, at a very early age, dreamed of beating the pro, becoming rich and having someone else carry the bag. He eventually did become rich, and someone else did carry the bag, but he never forgot his caddie days.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Government accountants today attributed a $16,000,000 loss in a single missile development program to poor planning and duplication.

It is apparent that Casey Stengel has not lost his magic touch. At least, his Yankees have not lost since the 69-year-old strategist resumed command last Tuesday, and one of his moves yesterday figured most prominently in the Bombers' 6-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians at the Stadium.

FORTY years ago this August, 27 million American women gained the right to vote. "Entering the Promised Land" and "A Man's World? No!" were among the headlines proclaiming their enfranchisement. Yet, it is estimated that in the Harding-Cox Presidential election of that year, only about one-quarter of the eligible females cast their ballots.

HAVANA, June 11 -- The Cuban Government seized the American-operated Habana Hilton and Nacional hotels today on the ground that the managers of these luxury hotels had failed to produce enough tourist business.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- Fifty years ago, this thriving Sullivan County village suffered its worst fire. Damage amounted to more than $1,000,000 as seventy-four commercial and residential buildings went up in smoke.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Eisenhower urged leaders of the House of Representatives today to use all their influence against heavy reductions in foreign-aid funds.

American auto racing will return next week-end to the scene of its origin fifty-six years ago. The occasion will be a revival of the Vanderbilt Cup race. A score or more drivers of international note will compete.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 11 -- The most starting stoppers of the Yacht Racing Association season -- 114 -- happily answered the opening guns for today's regatta staged by the Beach Point Yacht Club on Long Island Sound.

RINGKJOBING, Denmark, June 11 -- For nearly three years newspapers in Denmark have been chronicling with delight the travels of Val Peterson, the backslapping United States Ambassador who has paid official visits to almost every town in the country.

The women tennis players from the Middle States Association defeated the Middle Atlantic Association team, 9-0, yesterday in the final of the annual Sears Cup competition at the West Side Club. It was the second straight year Middle States had won the cup.
The newspaper war is over in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. It ended when Robert Spitzer caught Samuel Posner in a candy store trying to take away one of his $1.25 advertising accounts for 30 cents.
GENEVA, June 11 -- The West and the Soviet Union kept an appointment in Geneva this week, but the sad thing was that nobody was sure any more what the rendezvous was all about.

WHEN summer comes in officially next week, it will find thedance world all set for the change. If there are still a few die-hards clinging to their calendar rights, there are others too impatient to wait.
A seafaring adventure of the first magnitude will begin from Newport next Saturday. It is the biennial race to St. David's Head off Bermuda, 635 nautical miles away.

BERLIN, June 5 -- West Berlin feels it has been granted a temporary respite from the pressure of world politics and officials are determined to make use of the breathing spell to cope with the city's growing labor shortage.
A model home with seven rooms, including three bedrooms, has been opened at Edgewood Park, a development at Island Road and Wantagh Avenue, Wantagh, L. I.

NOW that the American Standards Association has recognized the recently eliminated black-and-white film speed "safety factor" as actually the factor of overexposure, the need for an exposure meter is more urgent than ever.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The unwillingness of the House Committee on Ways and Means to recommend an amendment to the Social Security Act to provide hospitalization coverage for aged beneficiaries is most difficult to understand, especially in the light of the long record of statesmanship which that committee has demonstrated in the development of social insurance legislation in this country.

ESPALIERED or trained fruit trees are filling important roles in landscaping by providing design and color for contemporary gardens. The meticulously trimmed branches form leafy patterns against buildings and fences with added features of spring bloom and fall fruit.

Jobs and skilled guidance, rather than the "break 'em up approach," are needed to cope with youth gangs, Mayor Wagner's Juvenile Delinquency Evaluation Project said yesterday.

Following is the text of an article published yesterday in Pravda, organ of the Soviet Communist party, that criticized. Leftist deviationism, as translated from a Russian-Language text supplied in New York by Tass, official Soviet press agency:
CHICAGO, June 12 (UPI) -- Richie Ashburn's two-out single in the tenth inning scored Earl Averill with the winning run and gave the Chicago Cubs an 8-7 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 12 (UPI) -- Sir Leslie Knox Munro, United Nations special representative on Hungary, said today that "no real progress can be made towards disarmament until a start is successfully made in the settlement of the great political problems now distracting the world."

The J.I. Case Company incurred losses in the quarter and six months ended April 30, reflecting a realignment of sales and financial policies plus costs of strikes at its plants in Bettendorf, Iowa, and Racine, Wis.
The gray, wet-dreariness of the city was broken up by bright spots of color yesterday at the music shell in Brooklyn's Prospect Park.

It hardly seems necessary to emphasize the hazards to the public arising from a hospital strike. But last Tuesday's fire in the subway system in the Grand Central area, which felled several hundred passengers with smoke poisoning, offers a good example of the emergency that can arise anywhere in the city and present an instant need for all our resources.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Vice President Nixon said in a letter made public today that the United States, while seeking to promote a "mutually acceptable" Arab-Israeli settlement, must keep on pressing to open the Suez Canal to Israeli shipping and to protect American interests from Arab boycott and blacklisting.
THE deal shown was played in Detroit," but comes to this department somewhat circuitously -- by way of England.
MIAMI, June 13 (UPI) -- A Federal District Judge granted Eastern Air Lines a temporary; injunction tonight aimed at halting a work stoppage by the airline's pilots.
Cotton futures advanced 1 to 13 points (5 to 65 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The new crop months were strongest.
One of the first vending machines to sell a wide assortment of general department store-type merchandise will be available soon in this area.
A sometime proponent of railroad mergers seemed yesterday to be trying to derail the carriers' consolidation movement here in the East, just when it appeared to be heading onto the open track.

Speeches delivered in Peiping last week suggest that Communist China began a partial retreat from "Left sectarian" opposition to Premier Khrushchev in the days immediately preceding Pravda's statement on the subject Sunday.
A new high-powered gun welding process may speed up fabrication of space vehicles, the Republic Aviation Corporation said yesterday.

Almost all hide positions fell yesterday to new lows for the lives of the contracts on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Trading was active and the volume was the fourth largest of the year. Futures closed down 42 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to up 5 on 114 lots (40,000 pounds to a lot).

Canadian National Transportation Canadian National Transportation, Ltd., announced yesterday it had completed stock purchase agreements with four trucking concerns that would extend its highway service over an additional 15,000 route miles in seven Canadian provinces.
Ship engineers yesterday asked for a 5 per cent across-the-board wage increase in base pay and overtime rates.
Nine special television programs reporting on President Elsenhower's current trip to the Far East have been scheduled by the three networks.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Atomic Energy Commission moved today to appeal a Circuit Court decision upsetting its procedures for licensing the construction and operation of nuclear power plants.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower has named six scientists and educators as new members of the board of the National Science Foundation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Directors of the Norfolk and Western Railway Company and the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad announced plans today to merge the two systems into one large, wealthy carrier.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for consumers asserted today that the Administration was proposing to expose consumers to the risk of eating "unwholesome" poultry to save the Treasury 1,350,000 a year.

The New York Giants of the National Football League yesterday accused the Los Angeles Chargers and Ed McKeever, the general manager of the Boston Patriots, with "fraud, deceit, bribery and double-dealing."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare offered major inducements to Congress today if it would go along with the Administration's program of aid to college construction.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas held up a small lamp socket. He said it sold for 25 cents in retail stores but cost the Navy $21.10.

WEST ORANGE, N.J. June 13 -- The Misses Julie Sage, Patricia Kelsey and Katharine Macwithey, all of Llewellyn Park, made their debuts this evening at a dance, at the Terraces, home of Miss Sage's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Lanman T. Holmes.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin accused the State Department today of having improperly bought $89,400 worth of office furniture from the son of Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller.

NICE, France, June 13 -- To win the twenty-one-day, 2,177-mile Tour of Italy bike race, which ended last Thursday, Jacques Anquetil of France survived three flat tires, two broken bikes and one crash, in which forty other racers piled on top of him.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Mrs Eleanor Roosevelt enters any public discussion, including those of a controversial nature, thrice armed regardless of whether she "hath her quarrel just." She has a great name, and a large loyal popular following which envisages her on the lonely peak of human eminence.
NEW DELHI, India, June 13 -- Dada Tashi is a 12-year-old schoolboy in Chapcha, Bhutan, who insists that a miraculous future awaits him. He is determined to become a radio operator when he grows up.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 13 -- The brother team of Herman Barren, the Fenway professional, and Mitch Barron, the Ridgeway Club champion, won the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament today with a best-ball 32, 31 -- 63 at the Hampshire Country Club.

LONDON, June 13 -- Industrials were marked up for the opening of the new account in the stock market here today. But with investors holding off, prices began to come back and by the close gains generally were only in pennies.
NASHVILLE, June 13 -- Vanderbilt University today approved settlement of a threemonth controversy over a Negro divinity student's expulsion on faculty terras it rejected last week.

BUENOS AIRES, June 13 -- President Arturo Frondizi flew to Rome today to begin a thirty-day tour of Europe, leaving the armed forces to mop up an isolated and unsuccessful revolt against the Government by a small army garrison.
HATTERAS, N.C. June 13 -- Nobody around here is bragging very much about the score on the second day of the First International Blue Marlin Tournament, but the fleet hasn't been skunked yet, either.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 13 -- The 17-year-old president of the student organization at Westbury High School has caused consternation by refusing to accept a citizenship award from the local American Legion post because, he said, he cannot respect Legion policies.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- A Florida power executive testified today that there had been nothing sinister about his contacts with Richard A. Mack, former member of the Federal Communications Commission, while a four-way contest for Miami TV Channel 7 was pending.

Net operating earnings of the twenty-five largest commercial banks in the country will be 20 per cent higher in the first six months of 1960 than a year before, according to Leif Olsen, vice president of M.A. Schapiro Co., bank stock dealers.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Young Democratic Clubs called on the nation's newspaper publishers today "to follow the lead of the broadcasting industry's equal-time pledge by offering equal space" for Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates.

Although Jule Styne is primarily a composer, he said yesterday that lyrics are the most important part of a score. Mr. Styne made that observation at| a luncheon-symposium devoted to "The Musical Theatre on Broadway -- Present and Future," which was conducted by the Drama Desk at Sardi's.
After two postponements because of high winds, the Weather Bureau finally got its new storm-detecting radar atop the seventy-story R.C.A. Building yesterday.
ROME, June 13 (AP) -- Ingrid Bergman and Roberta Rossellini were legally parted today.

THE condottieri of the Renaissance were sometimes tougher than the young street gangsters of New York. Many characters in Shakespeare's plays committed more spectacular crimes. But our town's hoodlums can also be a pretty rough lot, as we see from Ira Henry Freeman's excellent new book, "Out of the Burning."*
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : It may well be that Vice President Nixon has not been as specific on a number of issues as even many of his close supporters would like.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 -- Class Day exercises at Princeton University today included the presentation of undergraduate prizes and the commissioning of 119 seniors -- one fifth of the graduating class -- into the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Nelson Stitt, director of the United States-Japan Trade Council, said today that he was complaining to the National Labor Relations Board that the threatened union boycott of Japanese woolen fabrics was an unfair labor practice.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- The Hollywood movie mills, which have been grinding so slowly this year they seemed motionless at times, picked up speed today as screen writers began returning to work.

For the crude oil producer with transportation problems, a Wichita, Kan., engineering company may have the answer. It has designed a refinery so small it can be hauled on a forty-foot truck bed and backed up to a well or crude oil line.
There are more bottlenecks than bottles in liquor advertising.
COPENHAGEN. HABITUES of Oskar Davidsen's restaurant in Copenhagen -- and they number a surprisingly large proportion of Americans -- may be alarmed to hear of a decision to alter the decor.

Government securities and other prime fixed-income investments stayed in good demand yesterday, the last trading session of the period designated for the Treasury's advance refunding of up to $5,000,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent bonds not due until November, 1961.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 13 -- Texas Democrats took what may be a major step today to solidify their ranks behind Senator Lyndon B. Johnson.
A survey of weekly salaries of men and women office workers in the city released yesterday supported the plaint of women that "it's a man's world."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Government's short-term borrowing costs tumbled again today in a further reflection of easier money conditions. The average discount rate on the Treasury's regular weekly issue of ninety-one-day bills was the smallest since August of 1958, and on the companion issue of 182-day bills -- which have only been issued since December, 1958 -- it hit a record low.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 14 -- The police raided the offices of union and student cells suspected of being pro-Communist early this morning in a crackdown on Leftist elements who might foment trouble during President Eisenhower's visit here June 19 to 22.
A teamster local seeking to organize the city's taxicab drivers accused one company yesterday of using "threats and promises" to influence a representation election.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today the mail-fraud conviction of George B. Parr, known as the "duke" of Duval County, Tex., and eight other alleged conspirators with him.
YONKERS, June 13 -- A dapper man walked up to a bank teller here this afternoon and presented a note reading: "Gun in hand. Give me money." He fled with a bag containing, the teller said, $83,903.

President Eisenhower is scheduled to arrive in Manila early this morning (our time) for the first of his visits to four free Asian countries. It is appropriate that these visits should begin in the Philippines.

MANILA, June 13 -- It was conspicuously evident today that Manila is prepared to give President Eisenhower a warmhearted and enthusiastic welcome when he arrives tomorrow for a two-and-a-half-day visit.

A Lame Duck an Old Story If anyone has misgivings about having to fly what flag makers call "a lame duck flag" on Flag Day this year there may be mild consolation for him in a story going back to the time when the flag was very new, so new in fact that it is doubtful whether the details of the story can ever be verified in full.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13 -- Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, conferred Bachelor of Arts degrees on 267 young women here this morning, twenty-five of them with honors. Sixteen were graduated as members of Phi Beta Kappa.

It was opening night for 18,000 playgoers last evening. Nineteen Broadway shows rang up their curtains for the first time since the theatres were blacked out June 2 in a dispute between actors and producers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 6 in reference to the proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway shows a continuation of the slanted viewpoint which The New York Times has indulged in for years in this one regard. You have always quoted and requoted the pros.
The Federal Aviation Agency's proposed rules to reduce aircraft noise at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, were criticized yesterday day by John T. Clancy, Queens Borough President.
YESTERDAY (June 13, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Flying to Manila.
GENEVA, June 13 -- France pledged today that she would not allow the Soviet Union's political courtship to split her from the Western alliance.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Employment rose in May to a record for the month. However, unemployment continued to hover around 5 per cent of the labor force.

EUGENE, Ore., June 13 (AP) -- An astronomer using the 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar has reached thirty-six billion million million miles into space and photographed a speck of light that may provide clues to the origin of the universe.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 13 -- Gary Grossman of Middle Bay and Nick Petrillo of Pine Hollow posted a 31, 31 -- 62 and captured the honors in the Long island Professional Golf Association's amateur-pro tourney at the Hempstead Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower has named new United States Ambassadors to Ethiopia, Luxembourg, Panama and the Dominican Republic, and a new Governor in Guam.

Twentieth Century-Fox has resigned from the Motion Picture Association of America, the trade organization of the major film companies. This was made known yesterday by Fox, which reported that Spyros P. Skouras, president, had submitted a letter of resignation Friday to the M.P.A.A., effective in one year.
LONDON, June 13 -- Britain has given up hope of getting a single Europe-wide market in the near future.
PARIS, June 13 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion arrived today for a week-long visit to France and discussions with President de Gaulle.
ROSELLE, N.J., June 13 -- This being an election year, everyone seems to be getting into the campaigning act -- even bowling proprietors. One such active candidate is Sam Tarlowe.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13 -- A leading United States minerals concern headed by people prominent in United States business and politics is facing strong opposition from Brazilian nationalists and state enterprise to its plans for turning losses from operation of gold mines to profits from iron ore.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 13 (AP) -- Strike deadlines neared for 50,000 aircraft and missile workers as they anxiously watched negotiations involving 30,000 employes of Convair, a division of the General Dynamics Corporation, builder of the nation's only combat-ready intercontinental missile, the Atlas.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 13 -- Groups threatening to create additional provinces in the Congo nation that becomes independent June 30 multiplied today. Belgian authorities, meanwhile, sought to encourage support for a strong central government.
The American Bosch Arma Corporation and DeHavilland Holdings, Ltd. have acquired joint ownership of S.G. Brown, Ltd., Watford, England for cash running into seven figures.
Sanitation Department patrolmen and field supervisors issued 903 summonses yesterday, the first day of the department's city-wide drive against litterbugs.
Steel production this week is scheduled to show a slight increase over that of last week.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The White House announced today that the United States would participate in an international expedition to explore the Indian Ocean, one of the last unexplored areas on earth.

ABOARD PRESIDENT EISENHOWER'S PLANE, En Route to Manila, Tuesday, June 14 -- President Eisenhower was headed for what was expected to be an enthusiastic reception in Manila today after a flight from Alaska across nearly 7,000 miles of the Pacific Ocean.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has decided to put into effect liberalized rules on trans-Atlantic passenger charter flights on June 29.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- A wage increase of eight cents an hour for West Coast longshoremen and nine cents an hour for ships clerks was agreed upon today. The new scale affects about 17,000 members of the independent International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

Dr. Frank R. Kille, Associate's State Education Commissioner, said yesterday that he was "quite satisfied" with the academic records of candidates who will be awarded doctoral degrees on Thursday from the Yeshiva University Graduate School of Education.

The picture of the United States labor force in May, the figures for which have just been released, is the most encouraging presented by any month of 1960 thus far. At 67,208,000, the number of persons with jobs exceeded the total for May a year ago by nearly 1,200,000. The figure for the unemployed, however, while lower than for any earlier month this year, was 70,000 higher than that for May, 1959.
THE late Walter Wyman of Boston, who was an entertaining as well as an original writer on bridge, once remarked that most of the good plays are plays of the queen.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- The head of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks assailed today the recommendations of a Presidential emergency board to resolve a year-old dispute affecting 500,000 workers.
New York Republicans seeking to increase their control of the State Senate pledged yesterday to work for tax relief retroactive to 1960 income.

Direct selling companies are increasing their operations abroad, it was disclosed yesterday by the National Association of Direct Selling Companies. The group is holding its forty-sixth annual convention in the Statler Hilton Hotel.

The attempted military rebellion in western Argentina was so ridiculous and so easily put down that it may actually do good. A small group of die-hard, extremist officers, relatively unknown and with no real following even in San Luis, where they struck, merely proved the weakness of the military traditionalists, or "Gorilas" as the Argentines call them.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The House Appropriations Committee recommended today a $790,500,000 cut in the Administration's request for $4,175,000,000 of new appropriations to finance the foreign-aid program through the fiscal year starting July 1.
A major program to curb abuses of drivers' licenses has been started by State Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults.
MIAMI BEACH, June 13 -- Scientific evidence that for the first time points to a way to vaccinate men and women against conception was presented here today.

YORKTOWN, N.Y., June 13 -- Tom Molinari of Thornwood had rounds of 72 and 71 at the Mohansic golf course today and won the Westchester public links championship by one stroke with 143. Robert Tolf of Scarsdale was runner-up with 73, 71 -- 144.
The Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that it would halt operations at 12:01 A.M. Sunday if 1,350 trainmen carried out their threat to strike at that time.
The New York Blue Cross defended yesterday its request for state approval of a 37.4 per cent increase in premiums to avert further deficits.
Yesterday was a great day for three apes at the Bronx Zoo. They were turned loose on Monkey Island in the Bronx River and promptly headed for the treetops, uttering loud, rolling", hooting' cries.

EMILIO Pucci, the Italian nobleman whose sportswear has become a subtle status symbol in this country, has never (been to Southampton or Sugarbush, Vt. These are only two of the places in the United States where a knowing woman will not venture without several pairs of Pucci pants and bold silk shirts.
Supporters of Vice President Nixon argued yesterday that Governor Rockefeller had been inconsistent in challenging Mr. Nixon to debate on major issues before the Republican National Convention meets.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 13 -- A United Nations mission that visited Ruanda-Urundi said today that Belgium had agreed to hold general elections in the African territory early next year.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee was urged today by business men and Congressional witnesses to approve a House-passed bill designed to encourage private investment in foreign countries.

The five-story store and apartment building at 600 West 176th Street, at the southwest corner of St. Nicholas Avenue, has been purchased by Marion Thomas, a Chicago realty investor from the 600 West 176th Street Corporation, John Reilly, president, John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.

Eben Neal Baty, a retired business man and banker, and his wife recently took a trip through many countries abroad. In "Citizen Abroad," he tells of the tour and of the opinions others have of this country and its foreign policy.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 13 -- A week ago the Yankees were fourth, five and a half lengths behind the first-place team. Tonight, following their 8-4 victory over the Athletics, Casey Stengel's men were in a virtual tie for second with the Baltimore Orioles and only one game behind the pace-setting Cleveland Indians.
A warrant for the arrest of a landlord was ordered in Housing Court yesterday, but execution was put off until today when the landlord's teen-age Daughters appeared to say their father was ill.
LONDON, June 13 -- The International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea adopted today a series of regulations on nuclear-powered ships despite renewed Soviet protests against one of the rules.

HAVANA, June 13 -- Cuba's chief export today is the "Castro revolution," in the opinion of many observers here. This has been denied by Premier Fidel Castro many times and by President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado on his current trip to six Latin-American countries, but the evidence against their denials appears overwhelming.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Supreme Court dismissed today an appeal from a New Jersey decision upholding that state's law against racial discrimination in any housing built with public funds or other assistance. The vote was 8 to 1.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 13 -- An engineering study to determine the potential use of more than 8,000 acres of town-owned land on the South Shore has been authorized by the Town of Hempstead.

A $247,000, fourteen-month program to test for cervical cancer among'women in Harlem was announced yesterday by the Departments of Health and Hospitals. It was described as the largest cancer-finding program ever undertaken here.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (AP) -- Johnny Logan drove in five runs today as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 12-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Countess Adios, the 5-2 favorite, drew post position No. 8 yesterday for the $65,245 Cane Pace, the second leg in the triple crown of pacing.

A novel financing program by which the lease for office space taken by a large life insurance company is used as collateral for a full mortgage has been worked out for the recently completed building at 125 Maiden Lane.
TRENTON, June 13 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner was, elected chairman of New Jersey's delegation to the Democratic National Convention today.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- The grain-futures market resumed its slow general downward trend today with a few small gains giving oats and corn a narrowly mixed range.

"The Plough and the Stars," Sean O'Casey's drama about the Easter Rebellion of 1916, is to become a musical drama. Mr. O'casey has agreed to its musical adaptation by Elie Siegmeister, the composer, and Edward Mabley, who will write the book and lyrics.
The police shot down two bandits in the crowded Times Square and Columbus Circle areas yesterday, killing one of them.
LIBERTY, N.Y., June 13 -- Ingemar Johansson was the poised and confident man of the world at his training camp today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Senate investigators asserted today that bold measures must be taken to shut off a heavy flow of drugs that they said were going to addicted juvenile gangsters in big cities across the nation.

NEWTOWN, Conn., June 13 -- Floyd Patterson stood in the lobby of the sleezy, abandoned roadhouse where he is training for his return match with Ingemar Johansson at the Polo Grounds a week from today. He shook hands with visitors and tousled the heads of the children, unmistakably revealing his fondness for the small fry.
Pete, a forty-year-old parrot accused of using obscene language, was haled into a Brookyn court yesterday, but said nothing that might incriminate him. In fact, he refused to talk at all.
One hundred and thirty persons picketed City Hall yesterday for the right to live as most people do not.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 13 (UPI) -- Devereaux C. Josephs, financier and educator, told 313 graduates at Colgate University today that "future leaders need more courage than caution to cope with the rapidly changing world."
