WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Lawyers who represented anti-Hoffa members of the Teamsters Union in a court action ran into a new obstacle today in their efforts to collect $210,000 from the union's treasury.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Lawyers who represented anti-Hoffa members of the Teamsters Union in a court action ran into a new obstacle today in their efforts to collect $210,000 from the union's treasury.

STANTON, Del., June 13 (AP) -- Taking kindly to a racing surface made sloppy by overnight rain and later intermittent drizzles, Hans Christian carried the blue and white silks of James F. McHugh to a five-length victory today in the War Flower Purse at Delaware Park.
An antitrust suit brought by the Government against Continental Can Company, Inc., to force the company to divest itself of the Hazel-Atlas Glass Company started yesterday in Federal Court here.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Supreme Court wrestled today with the problem of distinguishing gifts from taxable income and decided there was no simple rule to settle every case. In three cases eagerly awaited by tax lawyers the court said the question of what constituted a non-taxable gift was "basically one of fact, for determination on case-by-case basis."
NEW HAVEN, June 13 -- Eight alumni of Yale University were among thirteen recipients of honorary degrees at the 259th commencement today.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Of the many Congressional hazards faced by the Mutual Security Program each year, none is more troublesome to the Eisenhower Administration than the opposition of a tense, fast-talking business man from Monroe, La. Representative Otto Ernest Passman, who likes to call himself "just a country boy," has been wielding a countryman's axe on foreign aid outlays since 1955 as chairman of a twelve-member House Appropriations subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
PATERSON, N.J., June 13 -- Leaders of the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars were at odds here today as to whether worn-out American, flags should be destroyed publicly or in private.

ALGIERS, June 13 -- Eight members of the Algerian Communist party went on trial here today on charges of having given aid to the nationalist rebellion. Newsmen and other spectators were ordered out of the courtroom.

TRENTON, N.J., June 13 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court blocked today a proposed merger between the United Board and Carton Corporation of Jersey Citv and the Interstate Container Corporation of Glendale, Queens.
BIRMINGHAM, England, June 13 (Reuters) -- South Africa put on 120 runs for three wickets today in its second innings, scoring 310 runs and winning the first cricket test match against England.

Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his trip to the Far East. All times are regional. (Wake Island time is sixteen hours ahead and Philippine time twelve hours ahead of Eastern daylight time):
LONDON, June 13 -- American players fared surprisingly well in competition with Australians today in the opening round of the London grass court tennis championships at the Queens Club.
A Chinese whose father was killed eighteen years ago in the service of the United States would be granted citizenship under a bill introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- Fewer imported cars were sold in the United States in April of this year than in April of last year. This was the first time totals have fallen behind year-earlier figures since imports became a factor in the American auto market.
The city's newspapers and television and radio broadcasters indicated yesterday that they would help Federal and city officials in their second census check.

TAMPA, Fla., June 13 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered the International Association of Machinists today to stop secondary picketing immediately against five concerns at the Cape Canaveral, Fla., missile base.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Oliver W. Powers obtained speedy approval today from both the United States and Soviet Union to go to Moscow. He will seek to help his son, who is being held for trial as the pilot of the United States U-2 spy plane downed by the Soviet Union.

Four Fathoms, the 6-year-old, chestnut gelding from the stables of Howell E. Jackson, doesn't win frequently and even when he does, he does it the hard way. Yesterday at Belmont Park, the Jackson color bearer placed first in the featured $5,000 Amityville, but then had to survive a foul claim.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Chinese Soviet bloc maintains a world network of 300,000 operatives in twentyseven, espionage and security services, the State Department reported today.

STONY BROOK, L.I., June 13 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club won the medal in the fifty-eighth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship over the St. George's Golf and Country Club course today.
After wobbling back and forth in an indecisive fashion, the stock market eased yesterday afternoon. On average, the market had a minor loss for the day.
MOSCOW, June 13 -- The Solet Communist party reaffirmed oday another of Premier Khruhchevs fundamental theses. It aid his belief that war was not nevitable had been "scientifially substantiated."

Last Sunday's articles in the Soviet press, commemorating -- eight days early -- the fortieth anniversary of Lenin's key pamphlet "'Left-Wing' Communism: An Infantile Disorder," indicate that Premier Khrushchev and his basic political line have successfully met whatever challenges the Paris debacle last month may have brought.

Ronnie Cohen, a New Rochelle weiterweight, failed to knock out an opponent for the first time in thirteen bouts last night at St. Nicholas Arena, but gained a ten-round split decision over Steve Ward of, Hartford, Conn.
NEW HAVEN, June 13 -- John Loomer Hall, senior partner in the Boston, law firm of Choate, Hall Stewart, died here today at the age of 88.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the United Nations had scored a success with its experiment in sending high-level officials abroad to fill key posts in governments.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your June 2 editorial "No Buses on Parkways" you infer that persons who travel by means other than the private automobile are second-class citizens.
PARIS, June 14 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of President de Gaulle's radio-television speech tonight to the French nation:
A Hungarian refugee who three years ago didn't know horizontal from vertical -- in English -- will be graduated from City College today at the head of the class of engineering students.
A Harlem landlord began serving a forty-day jail term imposed yesterday in Municipal Term Court for health and administrative code violations in an uptown tenement.
YONKERS, June 14 -- Rapid Transit, driven by Hugh Bell, came on in the final one hundred yards to win the $25,765 Bronx Filly Pace before 19,449 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
CINCINNATI, June 14 (AP) -- Two home runs backed the five-hit pitching of Larry Jackson in the 6-3 victory of the St. Louis Cardinals over Cincinnati tonight.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., borrowed $50,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost of 4.74 per cent a year. The money was raised through a competitive sale of thirty-year first and refunding bonds.
Lola Fisher doesn't want to play Cinderella any more.
NEW DELHI, India, June 14 -- Three men are the principal guides of Bhutan in her struggle to enter the modern world.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., June 14 (UPI) -- Francis Gary Powers, pilot of the U-2 plane downed in the Soviet Union, has written his wife a letter asking her to visit him in a Soviet jail and to be with him when he faces trial and possible death for espionage.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- Threatening skies forced the pageantry of Princeton University's 213th commencement indoors today for the first time since 1934.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., June 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and other state officials will participate here Saturday in the dedication of nine new township schools built at a cost of $8,000,000.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 11 points off yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale. The near months were relatively steadier than the far months, which were more or less neglected.

WHEN the United States Open was last played at Denver's Cherry Hills Country Club in 1938, a relatively unknown professional from California, Ray Ainsley, endeared himself to every duffer in America. With one stabbing performance he became their patron saint, their dream prince, their idol.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Women were reminded today of the power they wield at the nation's polling places.

A plan to help defray a part of the cost to producers of the new four-year contract with Actors Equity has been proposed by the New York Ticket Brokers, Inc. If it is adopted, the League is likely to gain $125,000 a year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an independent voter I am concerned with our political state of affairs and lack faith in both Republican national policies and Democratic machines in New York.
The city's first fully automatic parking garage is being built on Forty-third Street just west of Eighth Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Three major airlines obtained a temporary Federal court order today to prevent the spread of a pilots' boycott. Pilots are refusing to fly jets in which a Federal safety inspector occupies the third-pilot seat.

Take a little Antron, mix it with some Estron, add a touch of Avril and sprinkle lightly with Verel; stir thoroughly and rinse in a solution of vat pigments; place in a medium oven and serve with trimmings.
NEW DELHI, India, June 14 -- Many Nepalese traders have been killed by Chinese Communist troops recently in Tibet, a prominent Nepalese said today.

President Eisenhower's tour of the Far East has had a spectacularly successful beginning in the Philippines. At least one million Filipinos lined up between the airport and the center of Manila to bid him a welcome that surpassed anything seen in the Philippines before.
A teller at a Yonkers bank was charged yesterday with conspiring with two other men to stage a fake robbery at the bank to cover an $83,000 shortage in bank funds.
BONN, Germany, June 14 -- An upward revaluation of the Deutsche mark as a solution to West Germany's chronic inflationary export surplus is again under discussion here.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 14 -- J. Walcott Brown shot a four-under par 68 to win the New Jersey Seniors Golf Association spring tournament today at the Spring Lake Country Club.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Army Chief of Staff, warned today that civilian control of the military was imperiled by the lack of clear national policies.
Officers of a distinguished British rifle regiment that was born in America met in reunion here last night.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Two Western Senators urged the Senate today to reject the twelve-nation Antarctic treaty, calling it a giveaway of United States rights and an invitation to the Soviet Union to move into the South Polar area.

The Jake LaMotta-Billy Fox fight of Nov. 14, 1947, drew 18,340 spectators to Madison Square Garden. Among writers, officials and fans there was a belief almost immediately that the bout had not been on the level.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House of Representatives voted today to give the voteless citizens of the nation's capital the right to help elect Presidents and Vice Presidents.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Fallowing is the text of a speech on foreign affairs given by Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, in the Senate today:
YESTERDAY (June 14, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Flew into Manila for three-day goodwill visit to Philippines.
WASHINGTON, June I4 (UPI) -- The House Republican Policy Committee, lining up in support of President Eisenhower, agreed today to fight a threatened sharp cutback in foreign aid funds.
New York warmly welcomed the Japanese training ship Nippon Maru yesterday as she arrived to mark the centennial of the first United States treaty with Japan.

In recent years more coal mines have been closed than have been opened and the dedication of a new mine now is a special event, indeed. Yesterday, the Old Ben Coal Corporation held opening ceremonies for its new mine-Old Ben No. 21 --reported to hold 100,000,000 tons of recoverable sulphur coking coal, the type used in steel making.
The number of persons injured in city traffic last week was 1,194, a decrease of seventy-five from the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.
CHICAGO. June 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

IN 1949 a group of stage and radio personalities in a New York night club were discussing the merits of a cucumber strip as opposed to a sprig of mint in the English drink known as Pimm's Cup. The discussion turned into an argument, the argument into a brawl of such violence that the police were summoned and the adversaries were hauled off to a precinct house.
The stock market eased yesterday in see-saw trading.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's Pirates capitalized on San Francisco errors tonight for a 6-3 victory and increased their National League lead over the Giants to two games.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the United States-Japanese security treaty.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The United States invited the Soviet Union today to send scientific observers to witness a non-nuclear underground test explosion in Nevada next month.
Mayor Wagner made his first public bid yesterday to take over leadership of the state's Democrats.

Shareholders of the Standard Kollsman Industries, Inc., elected Perry Addleman to the board at their annual meeting yesterday. Mr. Addleman was a partner in the management consulting concern of Booz, Alien Hamilton prior to his retirement in 1955.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A Senate committee agreed today to eliminate from the Fair Labor Standards (wage and hour) Act a bit of confusion as old as the law itself. The confusion has been responsible for at least half the litigation brought under the law.

First-quarter gross worldwide income of the United Artists Corporation reached a record of $23,188,000, compared with $19,297,000 in the 1959 period, Robert S. Benjamin, chairman, reported at the annual meeting yesterday at the Astor Theatre here.
HAVANA, June 14 -- A military court today condemned Capt. Manuel Beaton, an officer of the Castro army, his brother Cipriano and Felipe Martinez to death by firing squad.
The City Council backed yesterday a Board of Education request for permission to use an estimated total of $40,000,000 a year in telephone taxes if the Federal Government drops its phone levy.

TO many apprehensive people weary with the strain of enduring the successive shocks of life in the twentieth century, the years 1900 to 1914 seem like the last good years the human race has known. The world, as always, was spectacularly imperfect then, but its problems seemed manageable and certain to be solved soon.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 14 -- Patrice Lumumba, entrusted by the Belgian Government with finding a combination of Congolese leaders able to lead the Congo when it becomes independent June 30, said today that he had a promise of enough votes to head the government himself.

The protest to Generalissimo Franco by 342 Basque priests throws an interesting light on a perennial aspect of Spanish society. The Basque priests denounced police brutality against Spanish political prisoners and the violation of civil rights. The statement concluded with a condemnation of the Franco regime's suppression of Basque cultural rights.
A policeman was killed in a pistol duel with a hold-up suspect in Brooklyn early yesterday in the fourth outbreak of gunfighting in the city within twelve hours.

PARIS. In the heated argument between Soviet Russia and the United States we tend to lose sight of two all-important issues on which the super-powers share a common attitude. The first issue is the nuclear arming of China and other nonatomic states; both Moscow and Washington oppose this.

MILWAUKEE, June 14 (AP) -- The Chicago right-hander, Glen Hobbie, yielded two hits -- a pair of homers by Del Crandall and Eddie Mathews in the eighth and ninth innings, respectively, -- tonight in pitching the Cubs to a 3-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Thirteen major manufacturers of heavy electrical equipment and seventeen of their executives entered pleas today to indictments charging price fixing and rigging of bids in sales exceeding $500,000,000.
MANILA, Wednesday, June 15 -- The old soldier basked in a hero's acclaim yesterday on his return to the scenes of his early career.

PARIS, June 14 -- President de Gaulle renewed and clarified tonight his offer to seek an "honorable" peace with the leaders of the rebellion in Algeria and guarantee them full participation in a future political settlement.
BIRMINGHAM, England, June 14 (Reuters) -- England defeated South Africa, 495 to 395, on the fifth and final day of their first cricket test match today.
With his current stint in Carl Foreman's "The Guns of Navarone" soon to be concluded Gregory Peck is already occupied with three new properties for his independent company, Melville Productions.
The 750-man Deck Scow Captains Union, after being independent for just about two weeks, apparently doesn't like living alone and is shopping around for another parent group.

The former plant of the United Piece Dye Works at Mercer Street and Arnot Place in Lodi, N.J., has been sold by Hendricks, Inc., to the Linlon Realty Company for investment. The George J. Wolf Realty Company of Jersey City was the broker.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 -- Bob Reagan of Worcester Academy scored 38, 36 -- 74 at the Greenwich Country Club today and gained a three-stroke lead for the medal after the first round of qualifying play in the forty-fourth championship tournament of the Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association.

MANILA, Wednesday, June 15 -- President Eisenhower charged today that Communist antagonism "to anything which it cannot control'' was the chief source of tension in the world. The President's declaration was made in an address to a joint session of the Philippines legislature.

A stockbroker, whose Wall Street concern had been restrained from doing business by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was found dead on Monday in his Queens garage, it was reported by the police yesterday.

Six thousand orphans descended on Coney Island yesterday as the annual guests oft he Police Anchor Club. They rode in 100 buses from orphanages throughout the city to Steeplechase Park, where they were entertained without charge.
PEARL HARBOR, June 14 -- A fire and explosion occurred aboard the nuclear submarine Sargo tonight. The submarine was deliberately submerged with the torpedo room hatch open to put out the blaze.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy is already working on his strategy for beating Vice President Nixon in November. While others are still talking about stopping him in July at Los Angeles, he is already confidently putting into operation his plans for the larger campaign.
The city's right to authorize advertising on the outside of buses that pass parks was upheld unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Jake LaMotta, once the world middleweight boxing champion, confessed to Senate investigators today that he had thrown a fight in 1947, two years before he won the title.

DENVER, June 14 -- Undaunted by comments that the course is "too easy" for a National Open championship, the United States Golf Association hid a bag of surprises tonight to make the Cherry Hills Country Club layout tricky.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate Banking Committee approved a slightly pared version of its Housing subcommittee's omnibus housing bill today.

At the very moment when President Eisenhower was flying on a hazardous journey to the Far East to reinforce American relations with our allies there the House Appropriations Committee blithely recommended a 20 per cent cut in the Mutual Security program in an act as potentially dangerous to our foreign policy as it is clearly irresponsible.
HAVANA, June 10 -- The Government is waging a vigorous campaign to dispel growing Cuban doubts about the direction of the revolution.

By 1970 the average American family income -- now about $6,500 a year -- will have increased nearly 50 per cent, according to an investment forecast issued yesterday by Dominick Dominick, investment bankers and brokers.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 14 -- Dr. Carl Keenan Seyfert, Professor of Astronomy at Vanderbilt University, was killed in an automobile collision here last night. He was 49 years old.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 14 -- Discovery of what is believed to be a built-in biological clock in the human body has been reported to the American Medical association's 109th annual meeting here.
For some months now, 100 of the city's fire engines have been streaking through town with sirens sounding as if they had a bad case of whooping cough.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $4,484,089,931 bill for two Government departments today. It also added to research funds for the National Institutes of Health.
A television series on which leaders in public life will debate cardinal issues of the day will be initiated next fall by the National Broadcasting Company.
The possibility of a contest between the New York Central Railroad and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad developed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A new departure in foreign aid was made today with the signing of an agreement by the Development Loan Fund and the Bank of Monrovia. The bank is a wholly owned affiliate of the First National City Bank of New York in Liberia's capital.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- A moderate, steady demand raised feed grain futures today, but other grains and soybeans ranged from steady to weak on the Board of Trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I enjoyed your June 3 editorial "City Pension Confusion," which I hope city officials will not only read but take to heart. The situation in the quasi-public cultural institutions is briefly this:
Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his trip to the Far East. All times are regional. (Philippines time is twelve hours ahead of Eastern daylight time):

Alfred E. Periman, president of the New York Central Railroad, late yesterday afternoon declared open war on two best friends of his old boss, the late Robert R. Young, former chairman of the Central.

A "SIT-OUT" strike of championship bridge players threatens to affect a scheduled intercity bridge match between New York and Los Angeles, to be played in Los Angeles Aug. 11 and 12, the two days before the next national championship tournament.
A month ago the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York placed advertising in newspapers across the state. The ad showed a large picture of a squirrel.
Overcast skies and intermittent rain curtailed yesterday's observance of Flag Day as flags with forty-eight, forty-nine and fifty stars all made an appearance here.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Seventy members of the road company of "My Fair Lady" arrived at National Airport here today from a triumphal eight-week tour of Moscow, Leningrad and Kiev in the Soviet Union.
President Eisenhower's overnight stop in Alaska focused attention on a region that, in the President's words, "constitutes a bridge to the continent of Asia and all its people."
NEW DELHI, India, June 14 -- The Congress party announced plans today for a broad investigation of charges of corruption among high officials.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 15 -- Opponents of Premier Nobusuke Kishi's Government staged another massive but orderly demonstration against the new United States-Japan security treaty today.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 14 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson was named today by the Texas Democratic Convention as its more-than-favorite-son candidate for the Presidential nomination.

ASCOT, England, June 14 (UPI) -- Royal Ascot, Britain's richest race meeting and top outdoor social occasion, opened today with Queen Elizabeth sweeping down the course in an open carriage during a thunderstorm.

The Transit Authority ordered a general tightening up of its inspection procedures yesterday to prevent a recurrence of such fires as the blaze on the IRT subway June 7. As a result of that fire 148 persons were taken to hospitals and several hundred others were felled by smoke.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 14 -- The Democratic member of the Nassau County Board of Elections said today that the Liberal party here "is no longer a legally constituted political party."
HARTFORD, June 14 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors upheld by 4 to 1 today the constitutionality of the state's so-called parochial school bus law.

THOSE close to Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy, president of India's ruling Congress party, consider him a human dynamo. Since the age of 18, Mr. Sanjeeva Reddy, the son of an unschooled farmer, has devoted himself ceaselessly to his party and country.
DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Norm Cash's pinch homer and Jim Bunning's brilliant pitching resulted in a 2-1 Detroit victory tonight over the Boston Red Sox.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Buying interest in the bond market broadened yesterday, with active Treasury issues rising from 4/32 to 10/32 of a point, and prime corporate bonds by about 1/4 point.
Real estate brokers are active in leasing office space in Manhattan buildings.

A device that can give clues instantaneously on when traffic patterns should be changed or when an emergency occurs, or even when more tunnel ventilation is needed, is undergoing extensive testing by the Port of New York Authority.
BALTIMORE, June 14 -- A $3,500,000 container ship was launched sideways today in Chesapeake Bay.

The Commercial Credit Company, Baltimore, the nation's second largest independent sales finance company, announced yesterday that it was entering the European installment credit market. But E.L. Grimes, chairman, explained that the company would operate through established European finance companies rather than direct through its own.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- Pressures are mounting on Gov. Edmund G. Brown to declare his choice for President.
Following are excerpts from Governor Rockefeller's speech last night at the annual dinner of the New York Republican State Committee in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, a pioneer in the field of powder metallurgy, was honored for fifty years of work in the field at a dinner last night of the International Powder Metallurgy Conference at the Biltmore Hotel.

CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored four runs in the rain-splattered first half of the eighth inning -- which lasted 1 hour 42 minutes -- and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 7-- 4, tonight, moving within .001 of the American League leaders.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 14 -- Commuters came home on early trains from New York this evening. "This show biz has upset our lives, but it's fun," one of them said.

Copper futures registered the sharpest price rise in more than a year on record volume yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Quotations climbed 80 to 114 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 1,325 lots, 50,000 pounds to a lot, the highest since trading started on the commodity in 1929.
A $1,036,650-a-year increase in fees charged by the Department of Buildings was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council.

The manufacturer of a weight-reducing tablet was accused yesterday of conspiracy and publishing false advertising. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said the tablet, Regimen, "did nothing, at all for the over-weight."

Mrs. Eleanor Clark French, vice chairman of the Democratic state committee, said last night that Michael H. Prendergast, the state chairman, appeared to be seeking her ouster as a result of criticisms she had made of his rule.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 (UPI) --The Phillies plastered Clem Labine with five hits and three runs in the tenth inning tonight and defeated the Dodgers, 6-5.

A DOCUMENTARY re-enactment of the storybook success of the Little League baseball team from Monterrey, Mexico, which in 1957 won the championship at Williamsport, Pa., made for a warm and absorbing film last night over Channel 4.

HATTERAS, N.C., June 14 -- Four anglers scored today in the third day of the first International Blue Marlin Tournament, a pretty fair total for a rough day but nothing to be excited about in these teeming waters.

"A wonderful, exciting city" is the way Mayor Wagner described New York in launching the seventh annual Summer Festival, the season from now until Labor Day that invites vacation visitors to enjoy the unmatched variety of attractions here.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 14 -- More than 150 women and children bearing signs and placards gathered at Town Hall here today to request the Hempstead Town Board to acquire a park site in the Baldwin area.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- Vladimir V. Matskevich, Soviet Minister of Agriculture, reported today that the nation's farmers had pushed through a successful sowing campaign despite bad weather. "One can figure on a good harvest," he said.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 -- Ten young women, all residents of this community, made their debuts here tonight at a dinner dance given jointly by their parents. The party was held in a pink marquee at the home of Mr. and Mrs. J. Basil Maguire.
MANILA, June 14 (AP) -- following are the texts of a welcoming address today by President Caries P. Garcia of the Philippines and of the response by President Eisenhower:

More than 180 cars, including a record entry of forty Formula Junior racers, will compete on the new Roosevelt Raceway mile-and-a-half course at Westbury, L.I., Saturday and Sunday. The Formula Juniors, with more than a dozen international stars among the drivers, will be in action both days.
BOSTON, June 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has many supporters in the greater Boston academic community, the Massachusetts Stevenson-for-President Committee said today.
RAMSEY, N.J., June 14 -- The pilot of a single-engined plane was killed here today when the craft disintegrated in the air and crashed near a school in which there were 537 children.
For the second consecutive year, a New York City student and a city high school have won top honors in a leading mathematics contest.

On a day as gray as an old mop, Belmont produced a five-race dry spell between winning favorites yesterday, until the 17-20 General Arthur won the featured Kensico by a length and a half over Eurasia.
LONDON, June 14 -- Almost all sections of the stock market here today were dull.
Kentucky borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway, tunnel and bridge construction.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill today to permit the cost of lobbying to be deducted from taxable income. The bill was opposed by the Treasury Department.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy suggested today that the next Administration should try to bring Communist China into the Geneva negotiations seeking a ban on nuclear tests.

STONY BROOK, L.I., June 14 -- All favorites advanced as the first round of the fifty-seventh annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's championship was completed over the St. George's Golf and Country Club today.

BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., June 14 (UPI) -- A Civil Rights Commission member, on hand to investigate complaints on voter registration of Negroes, was struck in the face today by a deputy sheriff in an argument witnessed by Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee.
The trainmen of the Long Island Rail Road served official notice yesterday that they would strike at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 14 -- Emperor Haile Selassie pleaded today for greater African unity. He also denounced the shootings of Africans in South Africa.
PARIS, June 14 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion and President de Gaulle met today for the first time.
A jury was told yesterday that Sidney J. Ungar would testify that Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan had "opened many doors and provided many contacts" for him.
Seven men were charged yesterday by a Federal grand jury with conspiring to steal and redeem through the mails $90,000 worth of soap coupons.
Gluck's "Orfeo," Mozart's "Idomeneo" and Handel's oratorio "Samson" will be given in concert version by the American Opera Society during its 1960-61 season.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 14 -- "I'm right at the peak now, but I'm glad the fight isn't until Monday," said Ingemar Johansson at the conclusion, of his training today. The heavyweight champion of the world spoke freely about his prefight feelings to an eager group of listeners following the intensive workout.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 -- Israel rejected today a compromise proposal under which Adolf Eichmann would be kept in custody in the Argentine Embassy in Tel Aviv pending a decision on the court that should try the former Nazi official.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 14 (AP) -- An airliner with fourteen persons disappeared today and wreckage believed to be that of the missing plane was sighted on Mount Gannett.

LONDON, June 14 -- Ronald Holmberg of Brooklyn and Chuck McKinley of St. Louis, candidates for the United States Davis Cup team, will face each other tomorrow in the third round of the London grass court tennis championship at the Queen's Club.

KANSAS CITY, June 14 -- Next to beating the Athletics in the trading mart, the thing the Yankees do best is beat them on the playing field. If further evidence on tooth counts were needed, it was furnished tonight as the New Yorkers again routed their Kansas City "cousins," 6-2, at Municipal Stadium.
Joe Lanza, a 73-year-old bootblack with an avid interest in scratch sheets, received a horseplayer's highest honor at Belmont Race Track yesterday. He was permitted to bet with other people's money.

FREEDOMLAND, a new amusement center where youngsters can see a re-creation of the Chicago fire, retrace the route of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, and ride through a Civil War battle, will open on Sunday at the intersection of the New England Thruway and the Hutchinson River Parkway, in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The population of New York State increased 11.9 per cent in the last decade to 16,596,507, the Census Bureau reported today.
The city school system plans to add 940 teachers and counselors to its staff next fall.
WHITE PLAINS, June 14 -- The Westchester County Council of Social Agencies was told that voluntary agencies should seek a strong voice in the forthcoming state study of social welfare.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he planned to recommend a 10 percent abatement on state income taxes covering 1960 earnings.

Dr. Frank R. Booth of Elkhart, Ind., a veterinarian, has been for more than forty years a leading breeder of terriers. Almost every week-end he can be seen at a show -- as a spectator, handling one of his dogs in the ring or as a judge.
HONG KONG, June 15 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist party today criticized those who believed imperialism has changed and place hope in diplomatic negotiations with the Eisenhower Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A frightened convict wouldn't talk to a Senate subcommittee today about Frankie Carbo's connection with boxing. But a New York detective did. He told the subcommittee that he believed Carbo, a prisoner on Rikers Island, controlled boxing everywhere in the nation.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 15 (UPI) -- Nine professors at the Vanderbilt University Divinity School withdrew their resignations tonight. The resignations had been offered in protest against the university's refusal to readmit an ousted Negro divinity student.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The Republican National Chairman said today that a plea for a stronger foreign policy by Senator John F. Kennedy reflects the "basic, schizo phrenia" of the Democratic party.
A vast heap of sludge and mud adjacent to a Baltimore copper refinery is stirring considerable interest among producers of so-called "space age" metals.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- A sure way to get art into a film is to hang it on the walls of the sets.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to give $697,000,000 in annual pay increases to 1,570,000 Government workers.

ANYONE planning an automobile trip over a summer week-end would be well-advised to take certain advance precautions. The car, of course, should be checked from headlights to (windshield wipers to make sure everything is in proper running order before the take-off.

JAKE LaMOTTA, who always has fallen several light years short of being one of nature's noblemen, has finally admitted something long suspected. He confessed to Senate investigators that he had been involved in a fixed fight back in 1947 with Blackjack Billy Fox. It was a strange sort of tank job.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 15 (AP) -- Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick, a Negro, head of the History Department at Alabama State College, was dismissed yesterday at the insistence of Gov. John Patterson.
MANILA, Thursday, June 16 -- President Eisenhower said last night that war had become "impossible and preposterous," and affirmed his continued readiness to negotiate with "those hostile to us."
ROME, June 15 -- The Italian film industry indignantly disclosed today that the Government had warned it to stop featuring "unhealthy and scandalous subjects" conducive to national "decadence."

A block of 435,182 common shares of the Brush Beryllium Company, Cleveland producer of beryllium and beryllium alloys, is being offered to the public today at $42 a share. Kuhn, Loeb Co. and McDonald Co. head the offering group.

The Antarctic Treaty, signed in Washington last December, represents the first agreement between the great powers on an inspection system to police a demilitarization plan. It perpetuates the collaboration of the International Geophysical Year, as well as the fragile truce that followed the Antarctic crisis of 1948.
CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI) -- Roy Sievers hit a pair of tworun homers tonight to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 6-4 victory over his old team-mates, the Washington Senators.

THE controversy concerning the scheduled match between eight-man teams representing New York and Los Angeles, to be played at Los Angeles Aug. 11 and 12 and at New York Nov. 17 and 18, yesterday developed into statements by all parties concerned supporting their own positions.

RYE, N.Y., June 15 -- Mrs. Allison Choate and Mrs. Bruce McGhie, both of the host Apawamis Club, teamed for a gross card of 39, 35 -- 74 today for a three-stroke lead in the annual best-ball tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The smashing triumph of Lyndon B. Johnson in the Texas Democratic convention yesterday draws attention to his uniquely fortunate position in the politics of 1960. Of all the aspirants to the Presidential succession he will retain the greatest power, whether or not he gets the party nomination.
THE following dinner menu is offered as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 15 -- Kenya's land problem moved a step nearer solution today.
DETROIT, June 35 (AP) -- Frank Malzone's third hit, a single to right field, drove home the winning run in the tenth inning today as Boston posted a 4-3, triumph over the Detroit Tigers.
A 29-year-old soldier of fortune was arrested here yesterday on a charge of swindling a ship's radio operator with a tale of a lost treasure plane in the jungles of southern Mexico.
Heavy profit-taking weakened copper prices yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The market was influenced by a lack of followthrough buying after Tuesday's sharp advance.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 15 -- In Westchester and Long Island, even works of art are commuting. For the last four years two Scarsdale women have been shuttling samples of the world's arts and crafts between New York City and suburban schools.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Industrial output turned upward in May despite continued cuts in steel production. The over-all figure was up 1 per cent following three months of slackness.

The Democratic state committee, under attack from without and within, will meet here today to elect officers for two years and name a slate of delegates and alternates-at-large to the national convention.

THERE is small doubt that the most notable achievement in the food world within recent memory is the automation of puff pastry. Since the making of this miracle "paste" is well beyond the grasp of most homemakers, the frozen, machine-made product designed to be baked in domestic ovens is most welcome.

One Afternoon in Boston Without the famed east wind blowing, a week-end in Boston at this time of the year can be a time at trial and tribulation despite the best efforts of the natives to make their guests comfortable and put them at ease.
RYE, N.Y., June 15 -- Three proposals for combating problems of suburban growth in this residential city of 14,059 have been rejected.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 (UPI) -- Four Lockheed missile and space division facilities were struck today. Production on the Polaris missile and important satellite projects was curbed drastically.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee approved a $1,365,000,000 housing bill today. It would authorize the elimination of down payments on Federal home loans of up to $13,500 and would reduce down payments on more expensive homes.

Governor Rockefeller has gladdened the hearts of members of the New York Legislature up for re-election in November, and of all taxpayers, with a conditional promise of state tax relief. Since the Governor does not deliver his annual budget message until about Feb. 1, 1961, and the present fiscal year is only two and a half months old, the tuning of his announcement is, to say the least, unusual.
CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- A late moderate buying flurry gave the grain futures market some fairly good gains today after prices had held almost stationary during an early slow trade.

MANILA, Thursday, June 16 (AP) -- The United States Secret Service chief, U.E. Baughman, said today he was not happy about President Eisenhower's plans to visit Tokyo, in view of the bloody new riots there.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The House of Representatives will shortly consider H.R. 12176, concerning the Mexican farm labor importation program.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A House committee completed all but the formalities today on a bill to raise the minimum wage to $1.25 an hour and extend coverage to about 3,500,000 more employes.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (UPI) -- A Business man testified today that he suspected "pressures' had been applied in the award of a Miami television channel to the Biscayne Television Corporation.

"Rigging and favoritism to tailor contract procedures" in favor of one seller of rock salt to the city were charged as public hearings began yesterday before the State Commission of Investigation. The city spends more than $700,000 yearly for rock salt for snow removal.
George L. Cobb has resigned as president and chief executive officer of S.H. Kress Co., variety chain, it was announced yesterday by Paul L. Troast, chairman.

PEARL HARBOR, June 15 (UPI) -- The Navy said today that an oxygen explosion and fire aboard the nuclear submarine Sargo had left one man dead and had caused extensive damage in the after torpedo room.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 16 -- More than 600 policemen and 270 students were injured and at least one person was killed in a violent anti-Government outbreak last night and this morning.
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico borrowed $17,000,000 in the bond market here yesterday to finance public improvements.

KANSAS CITY, June 15 -- An old-fashioned Midwestern rainstorm, suddenly whipped up by a twenty-eight-mile-an-hour wind, ended a crazy-quilt marathon between the Yankees and the Athletics tonight. It was a bizarre finish to a bizarre ball game in which nobody won, nobody losa and nobody had good time.
THE PRESIDENT In Manila on goodwill trip.
The 114th commencement exercises of City College were postponed last night because of bad weather.
GENEVA, June 15 -- The United States charged today that Moscow's new plan for total disarmament would leave Europe at the mercy of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A group of House Democrats organized today to support the Eisenhower Administration's fight to restore a $790,500,000 cut in the foreign aid appropriation.
MONTREAL, June 15 -- Seventeen paper manufacturing companies were found guilty today of having conspired to fix the purchase price for pulpwood. They were fined a total of $240,000.

ADDIS ABABA, June 15 -- A goodwill message from Secretary of State Christian A. Herter assured a conference of independent African states here today of United States support for the principles of the parley.
F.W. Woolworth was picketed on Forty-fourth and Broadway at noon yesterday by Southern Negro students, Broadway actors and Alabama's 1951 winner of the Miss America contest, Yolande Betbeze Fox.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 (AP) -- Dick Groat and Don Hoak led a nineteen-hit attack today as the Pittsburgh Pirates crushed the San Francisco Giants, 14 -- 6. The Pirates thus increased their National League lead over the Gianta to three games, the largest margin of the season in either major league.
The City Housing Authority received approval from the City Planning Commission yesterday to take over and rehabilitate tour deteriorating houses on Prospect Park West in Brooklyn.
A series of ninety-minute dramas based on Bible stories is contemplated by the National Broadcasting Company for next season.

The American textile and apparel industries welcome competition from domestic and foreign sources providing the ground rules are the same for all according to J. Graig Smith, president of the National Cotton Council.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 -- Argentina complained to the Security Council today that "the illicit transfer" of Adolf Eichmann to Israel from Argentina was creating "an atmosphere of insecurity and mistrust incompatible with the preservation of international law."
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Congress approved today a $3,994,000,000 farm money bill carrying funds farm many projects the Administration had not requested. It now goes to the White House.
MANILA, June 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address to a pedal joint session of the Philapine Congress today:

The Geneva talks at both the ten-nation conference on general disarmament and the three-nation conference on nuclear weapons tests have now reached such a complete deadlock that they are on the verge of breaking down. Soviet spokesmen declare that they will resume nuclear weapons tests unless their impossible conditions are met.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 15 -- The American Medical Association voted today to undertake a year-long study of the drug field in the light of current Congressional hearings. The House of Delegates, policy- making body of the association, emphasized that it would be a "study" and not an "investigation."
The Harlem Neighborhood Association told Mayor Wagner last night that there had been a serious decline in private health and welfare services in the area.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A Republican study of the country's defense and economic positions in the "cold war," regarded as an answer to critics of Adminstration policies in these fields, was presented to Vice President Nixon today.
The stock market once again couldn't make up its mind yesterday. For the fourth trading session in a row, prices moved back and forth. The end result was a decline.

Algeria, for obvious reasons, got the headlines in the stories about President de Gaulle's radio talk to the French people on Tuesday evening. Though the President said nothing new on the subject, his remarks carried an earnest friendliness and sincerity that might have some effect on that obdurate situation.
Pepsi-Cola and Coca-Cola are opening a major advertising war in the metropolitan area.

Japanese naval cadets, wearing the flowing robes favored by their countrymen a century ago, paraded up lower Broadway yesterday morning in horse-drawn carriages. The occasion commemorated the first Japanese diplomatic mission to this country, on June 19, 1860.
DENVER, June 15 -- A relaxed but somewhat puzzled field of 150 golfers today awaited the start of the United States Open championship tomorrow.
The Port of New York Authority was ordered yesterday by the House Judiciary Committee to produce all records covering nearly forty years of operations. Subpoenas were served to back up the order.
The Burry Biscuit Corporation realized a 39 per cent increase in earnings in the twenty-eight weeks ended May 4, on a sales gain of 16 per cent, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers pounded three Philadelphia pitchers for sixteen hits and routed the Phillies, 14 -- 2, tonight behind five-hit pitching of Sandy Koufax.
Five men, three of them 22-year-olds who grew up together on the Lower East Side, were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing $257,000 in securities from a Wall Street brokerage house.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 (UPI) -- Carlos Ortiz solved the bobbing defense of Duilio Loi to win a fifteen-round split decision and retain the junior welterweight title at Cow Palace tonight.

SEOUL, Korea, June 15 -- The second South Korean Republic was born today with the passage of a constitutional amendment that replaces the presidential responsibility system with a cabinet system of the British type.
CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, with eight runs in the eighth inning, whipped Cleveland, 13 -- 5, tonight after dropping the opener of a twilight-night double-header, 10 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The Navy warned union and management negotiators for Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards today that the five-month strike on the East Coast wks a "black day" for United States defense.
IF other companies follow Kelvinator's lead, American families will hot have to buy a new appliance every year just to keep up with the Joneses.
MANILA, Thursday, June 16 -- President Carlos P. Garcia believes that President Eisenhower's visit has strengthened the cause of freedom in Southeast Asia.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 -- Auto race driving stars entered in the Rickenbacker Trophy and Vanderbilt Cup contests here Saturday and Sunday were guests today at a luncheon in a garden setting at Roosevelt Raceway.

THE beatniks have rivals for contemporary notoriety in William Murray's new novel, "The Self-Starting Wheel."* His characters live between Madison Avenue and the metropolitan reaches of seacoast Bohemia. They are a forlorn and lurid lot. As Thoreau might have said, they lead lives of noisy desperation.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 15 -- Herbert Seegal fired a 5-over-par 77 on the Century Country Club course today and won the Rothschild Cup in the annual New York City Newspaper-Retail Dry Goods Association annual golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming intervened in the Rockefeller-Nixon competition today by pronouncing the Vice President "a real, genuine progressive in the field of health, education and welfare."

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 15 -- Ingemar Johansson just went through the motions today in a final workout. He boxed three rounds against three different sparring partners and did general exercise, but these professional chores came after the main order of business.
TRENTON, June 15 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a bill today designed to end New Jersey's property assessment problem.
DETROIT, June 15 (AP) -- The Interstate Oil Compact Commission said today foreign oil imports must be kept in balance with domestic production if exploration for new reserves was to be encouraged.

Joseph B. Ball, president and director of the Kroger Company, has acquired 27,758 shares of the company's common stock through a stock option, according to the latest insiders' report of the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright suggested today a possible solution to the problem of Arab refugees as a first step toward ending the Arab-Israeli conflict.
MADRID, June 15 -- The Spanish Government is planning radical fiscal measured to develop "popular capitalism" in this under-developed nation.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., June 15 -- Residents of North Valley Stream and surrounding communities threatened tonight to block runways at New York International Airport and to use high-flying kites to keep planes from flying low over their homes.

Henry Swoboda, a conductor who was born in Czechoslovakia and who is known in this country through European-made recordings, will conduct his first concert in the United States in the Empire State Festival on Aug. 6.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 -- The 17-year-old high school boy who refused an American Legion award here last week has been denied two other awards because of his action.

The confusion of American politics shows up at its best -- or worst -- every four years. It shows up in the party division in Congress; it shows up in the Presidential primaries; it shows up in the actions of the candidates themselves -- and it shows up in the growing fiction of the "non-candidate."
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 15 (AP) -- Perne L. Grissom's Im Willing, with Bill Hartack up, scored over Open View, his former stablemate, in the $17,000 Salvator Mile at Monmouth Park today.
OMAHA, Neb., June 15 (AP) -- Jim Wixson, a sophomore, pitched a no-hitter today as Oklahoma State eliminated North Carolina, 7 -- 0, from the National Collegiate world series.

HAVANA, June 15 -- Capt. Manuel Beaton, a former officer in Premier Fidel Castro's army, his brother Cipriano Beaton and Felipe Martinez were executed by a firing squad at 5:13 A.M. today on the San Juan army firing range outside Santiago de Cuba.

Capezio, Inc., a leading manufacturer of ballet slippers and theatrical shoes as well as women's shoes generally, has leased a floor and one-half in 619 West Fifty-fourth Street. The lessee has plants, in this country and Canada and will move from 318 West Forty-sixth Street.

All but two of the ten upstate cities in metropolitan areas have been generally declining in population while their areas have been gaining heavily, Arthur F. Young, regional census director, reported yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor is expected to be nominated in September for the presidency of the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., inc., the largest predominantly Negro denomination in the country.

THE British crown colony of Hong Kong, its importance as a trade center, its role as a listening post to collect information on Red China and its formidable population problem were the theme of a documentary presented last night by the American Broadcasting Company.
Half a million dollars to build a children's zoo in Central Park has been donated to the city by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman.
Democratic state leaders charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's proposal for income tax relief was politically inspired and would benefit the big taxpayer most.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate voted tonight to abolish the controversial non-Communist affidavit required of college students seeking Federal loans. It acted by a voice vote.
A 50-cent monthly surcharge on unlisted numbers has brought 25,000 hitherto anonymous subscribers into the pages of the new Manhattan telephone directory.

LONDON, June 15 -- The stock market had a sharp setback here today. Falls of a shilling (14 cents) or more in most of the leading lists were reflected in a 5.1 point drop in the Financial Times industrial share index to 320.9.
Eastern Air Lines remained more than 90 per cent grounded yesterday as a pilots' wildcat strike ended its fifth day. Eastern normally operates 430 to 470 flights a day.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- A drive was opened in the Senate today to expand a $40,385,000,000 defense money bill that is already more than $1,000,000,000 over President Elsenhower's budget request.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Allegations by Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba that United States Government officials backed a planned invasion of Nicaragua from Cuban territory are "entirely false," the Department of State said today.
STONY BROOK, L.I., June 15 -- Despite mist and fog this morning, the second round of the fifty-seventh annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's championship was completed today.
TRENTON, June 15 -- Senator John F. Kennedy has been informed that thirty-five of New Jersey's forty-one Democratic National Convention votes will be pledged publicly to him at any time he asks.
BONN, Germany, June 15 -- The announcement, repeated in three languages, roiled out of loudspeakers spotted among the "birds" on the grassy field.
Twenty-five steamship and stevedoring companies here received bronze plaques yesterday from the New York Shipping Association for their efforts in reducing accidents.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended June 8:
CINCINNATI, June 15 (AP) -- Curtis Flood hit two home runs and Ray Sadecki held the Cincinnati Reds to three hits tonight in a 6-0 Victory by the St. Louis Cardinals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 -- Following, in translation from the Spanish, is the text of an explanatory memorandum submitted by Argentina to the Security Council with her complaint on the Eichmann case:

The Elgin National Watch Company cleared $338,000, or 37 cents a share, in the quarter ended on May 22 on consolidated net sales of $8,115,000, J.G. Shennan, president, told the annual meeting at Elgin, Ill., yesterday.

The president of New York Blue Cross promised yesterday that it would watch hospital costs "like a hawk." As he ended his plea at a public hearing for an increase in premium rates averaging 37.4 per cent, J. Douglas Colman said a new formula for reimbursing hospitals would uncover excessive costs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 -- The Soviet Union was reported last week to be expanding its commercial fishing fleet through expenditures of $270,000,000. Jan-Olof Traung of Sweden, of the Food and Agricultural Organization and an expert in the design of fishing vessels, said that the Soviet had contracted for seventy additional fish factory ships at a cost of $3,000,000 each, to be built in East Germany and Poland.
GENEVA, June 15 -- The Soviet Union threatened today to resume nuclear weapons tests unless it could inspect to the last detail any atomic or hydrogen bomb detonated by the United States.

BOXING -- an enterprise in which some men on both sides of the ropes get killed while others get rich -- has attracted to its directorial class an interesting assortment of citizens whose first names are wont to be separated from their last by something in parentheses.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The House subcommittee investigating payola suggested today that the Federal Trade Commission look into "kickbacks and other questionable practices in the popular record industry."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- A Pennsylvania justice told the graduating class at Radcliffe College today that there were things "at which people should lose their tempers permanently."

The four-story office building at 1231 Broadway and the adjoining seventeen-story office and showroom building at 1237 Broadway have been sold by the First Leasing Corporation, a client of Walter Scott Co., to clients of Rapaport Brothers, lawyers.
Cotton futures moved 2 points off to 3 up in quiet trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

A contractor testified yesterday that Sidney J. Ungar had paid him $4,400 for remodeling Hulan E. Jack's apartment and prevailed on him temporarily to conceal the fact with false addresses and false receipts.

HAVE no fear about having your hair done abroad. This message came from the director of Women's Services at Sabena Belgian World Airlines. She went on to say that for very little money, a tourist can have fun in Europe having a set and shampoo in an entirely different atmosphere.

White the New York Central Railroad is fighting the merger trend within its Industry, another kind of rail battla is shaping up. This dispute centers on freight rates -- whether to raise or to lower them?

When we ask ourselves what has happened to our national purpose, we sound vaguely as if, in a moment of absent-mindedness, we had mislaid it. In fact, our first self-conscious impulse is to see where we may have left it.

MANILA, Thursday, June 16 -- New and serious outbreaks of rioting in Tokyo have cast deep shadows over President Eisenhower's plans to visit Japan. There was no immediate reaction from the President or his staff on what effect the events in Tokyo might have on the President's scheduled visit.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 15 -- Patrice Lumumba will tell the Belgian Resident Minister that he is able to form a government when he reports tomorrow on the results of his mission of information.

John J. Delaney, editor of the Image Books division of Doubleday, has received the 1959-60 Marian Library Medal for his work in editing "A Woman Clothed With the Sun," a collection of writings on eight famous apparitions of the Virgin Mary.

Joseph Gavegnano's Errard King Jr., the fourth choice among six speedy 2-year-old colts, slithered through the slop at Belmont Park yesterday and won the colt division of the $37,250 National Stallion Stakes by five lengths from Louis Wolfson's Garwol.

LONDON, June 15 -- Back together as in their early junior years, Earl Buchholz and Chuck McKinley, a pair of 19-year-olds from St. Louis, defeated Australia's crack Davis Cup doubles combination, Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson, in the London grass courts tennis tournament at the Queen's Club today.

Fifteen years of shepherding children through Greenwich Village traffic has won for Patrolman John Warga the title of Favorite Neighborhood Father of 1960. The honor, together with a bouquet of flowers, was presented to him yesterday by members of the kindergarten of the Lower West Side Children's Center.
PARIS, June 15 -- The simmering controversey over the acquisition of a French masterpiece by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York burst out into the open here today.
The Silver Beaver award, the highest honor a Boy Scout council can give an adult leader, was presented yesterday to three New Yorkers for "distinguished service to boyhood."
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that its earnings had plummeted in May to $1,068,000 from $3,283,000 in the 1959 month.

PARIS, June 15 -- An atmosphere of "now or never" for peace in Algeria prevailed here today following President de Gaulle's new call for peace talks with the Moslem rebels and renewed guarantees of political self-determination.

The American Merchant Marine Institute, which is engaged in wage review talks with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, said yesterday that it had rejected a union demand for a 5 per cent across-the-board wage increase in base pay and overtime rates.
MANILA, June - 15 (UPI) -- Following tire the texts of remarks by President Carlos P. Garcia at a state dinner given tonight in hotter of President Elsenhower and of the latter's toast at the event:
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to repeal the 10 per cent Federal taxes on local telephone service, telegrams and travel.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 15 (UPI) -- Three hundred Convair machinists voted tonight to return to work. Union officials rushed to the missile launching site to prepare the way for the midnight shift.

"An Evening with Nichols and May" will be Arthur Penn's next directorial assignment. Heretofore, Mr. Penn has confined his efforts to the dramatic field, having staged three hits in a row, "Two for the Seesaw," "The Miracle Worker" and "Toys in the Attic."
MOSCOW, June 15 -- The Soviet Union formally told Japan today that ratification of the mutual security treaty with the United States could lead to "dangerous consequences."

TUNIS, June 15 -- Algerian nationalist leaders discussed in strict privacy today President de Gaulle's renewed offer to seek peace in Algeria. The rebel military leaders were reported to have been summoned to Tunis for consultation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In 1952 I voted for President Eisenhower. By 1956 I had already begun to feel strongly that the Administration was not living up to its advance billings. That year I abstained from voting for the first time in twenty-six years.

Increased highway travel and farm activity drained 1,973,000 barrels from the nation's gasoline supply last week. The American Petroleum Institute reported stocks on last Friday at 207,935,000 barrels, against 201,508,000 a year ago.

The International Longshoremen's Association will make another legal attempt to recover the treasury and assets of a New York tugboat men's union that disaffiliated from the longshoremen's group in 1954.

The Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation is holding preliminary merger discussions with Saco-Lowell Shops, manufacturers of textile machinery, J.M. Pope, financial vice president of Food Machinery, disclosed yesterday.

THE forty-third season of outdoor concerts by the Goldman Band began on the Mall in Central Park last night, under the direction of Richard Franko Goldman. As in previous seasons, the concerts this summer are a gift to the people of the City of New York in memory of Daniel and Florence Guggenheim.

MISHAWAKA, Ind., June 15 (UPI) -- Dodge Manufacturing Company announced today it had formed a wholly owned subsidiary in Europe and acquired a majority interest in a new operating subsidiary in Mexico.

A $30,000,000 issue of 4 7/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Alberta Municipal Financing Corporation is being offered the public today by investment bankers headed by The First Boston Corporation and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc.

MILWAUKEE, June 15 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs scored six times in the eighth inning tonight for an 8-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves and an even break in a twilight-night double-header. The Braves tallied twice in the ninth to take the opener, 5 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The United States Senate will consider the new United States-Japan security treaty tomorrow. Quick approval is expected.
Bond prices rose again yesterday as the demand for prime fixed-income securities continued to broaden in all parts of the market.

Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his trip to the Far East. All times are regional. (The Philippines is twelve hours ahead of Eastern daylight time, Japan thirteen hours ahead and Hawaii six hours behind):

ABOARD U.S.S. YORK-TOWN, en route to Taiwan, Friday, June 17 -- President Eisenhower sailed today toward Taipei, the Nationalist Chinese capital, to fulfill what remains of his ill-fated Pacific goodwill journey.
NEWTOWN, Conn., June 16 -- Floyd Patterson had to share the spotlight with his one-time manager, Cus D'Amato, in his workout today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's canceled trip to Japan provide ammunition for both sides today as the House debated a foreign aid appropriation for the coming year.
Sidney J. Ungar may be called to the stand today by the prosecution as a witness in the trial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

The president of the New York Society of Architects said yesterday that the city and the Federal Government were planning to put more than $60,000,000 in new buildings in the wrong places in the civic center development near City Hall.
LONDON, June 16 -- Chuck McKinley, riding the crest yesterday, was beaten in singles and doubles today in the London grass court tennis championships at the Queen's Club.
The Department of Marine and Aviation is ready to proceed with the construction of the superstructure of the city's new $10,000,000 pier in Brooklyn.

Neither heat nor the fact that the indoor music season in New York was presumed to have ended about a month ago kept Max Goberman and his New York Sinfonietta from playing an all-Vivaldi concert in Town Hall last night.

STONY BROOK, L.I., June 16 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club led a contingent of the New Jersey players into the semi-finals of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The world-wide alliance against international communism, which of necessity was tightened in its European sector by Soviet Premier Khrushchev's threats against the nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was shattered in Asia for the same cause.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The Senate reaffirmed today its approval of legislation to remove a requirement that college students obtaining Government loans for education must sign non-Communist affidavits.
THE PRESIDENT Left Manila on way to Formosa.

Eugene Robert Black, president of the World Bank, became yesterday -- as far as can be ascertained -- the first man to receive honorary degrees from Harvard, Yale and Princeton in the same commencement season.

SOME novels, while only adequately competent as fictional entertainments, are gruesomely interesting as political pamphlets. "The Fear Makers," by Wilfrid Schilling, discussed in this space a week ago today, is one -- a furious denunciation of the totalitarian mentality which, according to the author, is still characteristic of West Germans, and of the unrepentent Nazis who, also according to the author, are still powerful and may again achieve total power.
The Board of Hospitals has repealed controversial clauses of the Hospital Code pertaining to nursing homes, Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, the Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday.
