Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $26,000,000 to $374,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements decreased $29,000,000 to $432,000,000 from a revised figure a week ago.
The State of Connecticut borrowed $28,880,000 in the bond market yesterday on eleven issues of serial bonds due from 1961 to 1980.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The outlook now is for another solemn political crisis in Asia. At best, the United States has lost "face" in the Far East; at worst, it has lost Japan, but the situation is certainly not hopeless.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Senate passed tonight a $1,247,500,000 omnibus housing bill after having eliminated $134,000,000 in an effort to make it more acceptable to President Eisenhower.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16 -- Baldwin M. Baldwin, a bearded, retired 56-year-old gentleman from Los Angeles, learned today that his famous old blue-hulled yawl Escapade was the scratch boat in the ocean race to Bermuda, which will begin on Saturday.
THERE once was much interborough bridge rivalry in New York. Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Richmond had their teams; only Queens did not participate as a borough.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Following is the text of an "open letter" to liberals from sixteen former supporters of Adlai E. Stevenson urging the nomination for President of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts:
LONDON, June 16 -- The tone improved considerably in the stock market here today but price movements were irregular.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 16 The mother of a high school senior who refused an American Legion award at school ceremonies said today that her son had received wide support for his stand.
The proposal of Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. for a nonpartisan defense administration represents, in Shakespeare's words, "a consummation devoutly to be wish'd."
The procedure in Special Sessions Court has been revised to provide for trials during the summer of cases pending against landlords.
HONG KONG, June 16 -- Communist China is holding firmly to its ideology despite a scolding recently administered by the Soviet Union to advocates of that doctrine.
A generation of Japanese students educated since Wotld War II led the riots that induced the Kishi Government to withdraw its invitation for President Eisenhower to visit Japan.
MANILA, June 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, on the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (AP) -- Bob Skinner's grandslam homer led Pittsburgh to a 10-7 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The triumph lifted the Pirates to a four-game lead in the National League and completed a sweep of the three-game series.
The Democratic State Committee turned down Herbert H. Lehman yesterday as a delegate at large to the Democratic National Convention.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- A limited state and Federal program for health aid to elderly citizens was cleared today for House action next week.
MOSCOW, June 16 -- Soviet exultation at the cancellation of President Eisenhower's trip to Japan was acknowledged in editorials and broadcasts tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The United States Committee for Refugees criticized Congress and the Administration today for what it called the failure of the United States Government to make a "sufficient contribution" to the World Refugee Year.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., June 16 -- A code of ethics for officials and employes has been adopted by this village's Board of Trustees.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Census Bureau said today that the population of the United States was "approximately 179,500,000" on April 1.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 16 -- Dr. Frank H. Bowles, president of the College Entrance Examination Board, urged all secondary schools today to enrich their offerings to meet increasing demands by colleges.

The "spirit of submission" to the totalitarian will that was present in the Nineteen Thirties seems to be absent in the free world today, Herve Alphand, the French Ambassador, told the City College graduating class last night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (UPI) -- An unsuccessful applicant for Channel 7 in Miami, Fla., testified today that he had been cautioned to watch out for pressure from the White House while the Federal Communications Commission was considering the applications.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Sixteen former backers of Adlai E. Stevenson Issued an "open letter" to "fellow liberals" tonight urging them to unite behind Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts as the Democratic Presidential nominee.
Two hundred "experts" on the city's junior high schools met yesterday to discuss ways of changing and improving the educational program being offered in the seventh through the ninth grades.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial campaign against double parking is highly commendable, but when inveighing against the double parker you are blaming the victim of the situation and not the cause.

JERSEY CITY, June 16 -- Nice of France, after playing ties in its first three games, broke into the victory column with a 3-2 triumph over Glenavon of Ireland in an International Soccer League match at Roosevelt Stadium tonight.

TWO of summer's most luscious fruits -- raspberries and blackberries -- are making first-of-the-season appearances here now. Distribution of the berries, which are coming from California, still is limited to a few, scattered shops.

Since March 14, when Huntington Hartford's gift of more than $500,000 to build a "sidewalk cafe" pavilion in the southeast corner of Central Park was announced, this newspaper has received ninety-four letters on the subject from its readers. Seventy-one of these letters have opposed the pavilion; twenty-three have favored it. We have published about a fifth of these, eleven against the restaurant and nine for it.
The Waterfront Commission's investigation of crime on the New York-New Jersey docks got off to a slow start yesterday.
The trainmen's strike against the Long Island Rail Road, set for 12:01 A.M. Sunday, was ordered postponed yesterday.
TORONTO, June 16 (Canadian Press) -- Consolidated Sudbury Basin Mines, Ltd., last night announced plans to amalgamate with Giant Yellowknife Gold Mines, Ltd.

BERLIN, June 16 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the American physicist, said here today that the world should know that if another great war occurred "none of us can count on having enough living to bury our dead."
LONDON, June 16 -- A complete Louis XV silver dinner service, said to be the only one of its kind in the world, was sold at auction today for L207,000 ($579,600).
DETROIT, June 16 -- Sales of new cars in the first ten days of June were the highest for such a period since 1955.

YONKERS, June 16 -- Del Miller drove Countess Adios to a world record tonight in winning the W.H. Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway. The little filly owned by Hugh Grant of Bradford, Pa., and the Armstrong brothers of Toronto paced the mile and a sixteenth in 2:08.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16 -- Albert C. Simmonds Jr., the new president of the New York State Bankers Association, is an uncommon Wall Street banker. Tomorrow, for instance, he is hurrying back from here to the Bronx for the opening of Freedomland.

Savannah Electric and Power Company sold debt securities valued at $8,000,000 in two competitive sales yesterday. The First Boston Corporation and associated investment bankers won both issues. The group bought $5,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds on a bid of 101.72 for a 5 1/8 per cent interest coupon, and $3,000,000 of twenty-five year debentures on a bid of 100.18 per cent for a 5 1/4 per cent coupon.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate completed Congressional action tonight on a constitutional amendment giving citizens of the capital the right to vote for President and Vice President.
TRENTON, June 16 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that as far as he knew the New Jersey delegation to the Democratic National Convention still planned to support him for the Presidency.
The National Broadcasting Company has told advertisers who have subscribed to its medical advertising plan that it is postponing the setting up of its medical radio system.

A drama dealing with the ideological struggle in the world, written and acted by miners from the German Ruhr, will be presented tonight through June 23 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre under the auspices of Moral Re-Armament.
All preconceptions about the American market are being swept away by the unexpected sales successes of a varied range of products in the British Exhibition.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- A new and accidental finding was reported today that challenged a long-held concept concerning the spread of malaria.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Treasury submitted a detailed rebuttal today to the perennial proposal that the Government collect interest on its multi-billion-dollar bank deposits and pay the banks for check cashing, bond selling and other services now performed free.
HAVANA, June 16 -- Two assistant legal attaches at the United States Embassy have been ordered to leave Cuba within twenty-four hours.

CHICAGO, June 16 (UPI) -- The White Sox blasted Truman Clevenger for five runs on six hits in the seventh and eighth innings tonight and beat Washington, 10 -- 4, for their fifth victory in seven games with the Senators this year.
LONDON, June 16 -- The prevailing reaction in British Government circles to the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan is one of relief.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Leading Democrats said today that the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan inevitably involved some loss of prestige for the United States.
GENEVA, June 16 --The United States is under mounting pressure from its Western allies to agree to submit new disarmament proposals to the Soviet Union.
MILWAUKEE, June 16 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves found their batting form during a forty-two-minute rain-forced delay and pulled from behind for a 10-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

Walter Lippmann, author and political columnist, will offer his views on political events and leaders in a one-hour interview program to be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System. It will be presented on July 7 at 7:30 P.M. on the "C.B.S. Reports" series.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 16 -- The abortion laws in the United States cannot be enforced and should be changed, it was suggested here today at the American Medical Association's 109th annual meeting.

With three-eighths of an inch clearance at one end and three-quarters of an inch at the other, the seventy-sixth and final section of the steel framework for the lower deck of the George Washington Bridge was put into place yesterday.

Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, saw Howard Simpson, president of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, at a luncheon yesterday but Mr. Perlman still did not tell Mr. Simpson what the Central was willing to offer B. O. shareholders for their stock.
The Metropolitan Opera yesterday named five European singers, one woman and four men who will make debuts with the company next season.

Premier Khrushchev will roll out the red carpet for an American trade union delegation in Moscow next month. This was the word received here yesterday by the delegation's leader, Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.

JERSEY CITY, June 16 -- The State Supreme Court ruled this week that a buyer of real property is liable for the payment of a commission to a real estate broker if the purchaser, without valid cause, refused to fulfill a purchase contract.
NEW DELHI, India, June 16 -- Two agreements are expected to be signed shortly under which the United States will help India to promote private industrial development.
DENVER, June 16 -- The antics of a fish and unusual experiences by players marked the opening round of the United States Open golf championship today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady to 3 points (15 cents a bale) up yesterday.
The State Education Commissioner reported yesterday that over the last five years 914 small school districts in the state had been abolished through mergers.

"WHEN Dempsey hit Carpentier," said J. Morgan Calhoun, "two things happened. Carpentier went down and the crowd of 80,000 leaped to its feet. I was so busy watching the stands sway and shake that I never did see the knockout. I kept waiting for these wooden stands to collapse. Happily, they didn't."
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court heard arguments yesterday on a labor union's appeal that may have world-wide repercussions in the maritime industry. Decision was reserved.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Continued steel cut-backs, a softening of the lumber business and a delayed harvest of grains affected rail and truck loadings of freight last week.
TUNIS, June 16 -- Well-in-formed Tunisians predicted tonight that the insurgent Algerian nationalist would say "yes" to General De Gaulle's new invitation to them to go to Paris for peace talks.

HATTERAS, N.C., June 16 -- The first International Blue Martin Tournament ended this afternoon in a blaze of action and shenanigans. The individual winner, Esteban Bird of San Juan, P.R., was thrown into the water with Gov. Luther Hodges of North Carolina, and neither complained.
The friendly, but insistent inquiry, "Were you counted?" echoed in some of the most congested sections of the South Bronx yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 16 -- The Congolese Parliament will meet here tomorrow for the first time, but doubt still exists about the make-up of the government that will rule the country after it achieves independence on June 30.
Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his trip to the Far East. All times are regional. (Taiwan is thirteen hours ahead of Eastern daylight time):
TOKYO, Friday, June 17 -- President Eisenhower's visit to Japan has been canceled because his safety here could not be guaranteed.

The voyages of the atomic submarine Skate beneath the Arctic ice are described by the craft's commander, James Calvert, in "Surface at the Pole." Commander Calvert took the Skate to the Arctic in August, 1958, and while cruising beneath the ice surfaced nine times, proving that the Arctic was practical for regular operations.

RYE, June 16 -- Mrs. Allison Choate and Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis carded a 146 and won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association bestball tournament for the second straight year today. They posted a one-under-par 37, 35 -- 72 today to go with their 74 yesterday.

MANILA, June 16 -- The United States will regard any armed attack against the Philippines as an attack against the United States. This renewed assurance was given today in a communique issued jointly by President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines and President Eisenhower.
Beginning this fall, people in Europe will be able to read "today's New York Times today," according to plans announced yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of The Times.

As producing director of the repertory theatre at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Robert Whitehead is quite busy. In addition to that parcel of duties, he is planning sundry entertainments for the Broadway trade.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed an omnibus $1,247,500,000 housing bill tonight:

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 16 -- News of the sudden cancellation of President Eisenhower's trip to Japan apparently startled Chinese Nationalist officials here, although most of them said later they had expected it.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16 -- The New York Legislature is "living in a fool's paradise" if it thinks passage of the Omnibus Banking Law has disposed of the need for a further major revision of the State Banking Law, J. Henry Neale, retiring president of the New York State Bankers Association, said today.
Supporters of Senator John F. Kennedy said yesterday he now had 710 1/2 first-ballot votes of the 761 required to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Two senior analysts spoke to the new New York Society of Junior Investment Analysts yesterday and gave members some basics to ponder. Speaking to the group, whose members represent the younger professional analysts, were Edmund W. Tabell, partner in Walston Co., brokerage firm, and Ragnar D. Naess, of Naess Thomas, investment counseling concern.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 16 -- Five former champions were eliminated in the first two rounds of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today, leaving no outstanding favorite among the sixteen survivors at the Ridgewood Country Club.
The rise in United States Government bond prices came to a halt yesterday after several active new issues of Treasury notes and bonds scored new high prices.

YOU had better have a pretty strong stomach and be prepared for a couple of grisly shocks when you go to see Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho," which a great many people are sure to do. For Mr. Hitchcock, an old hand at frightening people, comes at you with a club in this frankly intended blood-curdler, which opened at the DeMille and Baronet yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Soybean futures were in good demand again today and led another general advance on the Board of Trade.

Desilu Productions, Inc. had a record net income of $811,559 in its fiscal year ended on April 30 on gross income of $23,406,100, Desi Arnaz, president of the television and film producing company, reported yesterday.
Walter Hoving resigned yesterday as president of the Hoving Corporation and as chairman of Bonvit Teller, Fifth Avenue specialty store.
CONCORD, N.H., June 16 (UPI) -- A. Federal grand jury indicted twenty-five persons and three corporations today in a $750,000 stock fraud that allegedly extended across forty-seven states and Canada.
United States newspapers continued to consume record amounts of newsprint last month, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Religious Heritage of America presented its 1960 churchman awards at a dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 8 suggests that Eichmann be tried by an international or a German court rather than by Israeli judges. While I welcome this suggestion, I regret that your editorial does not touch upon other important aspects of this case.
Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, appealed yesterday for a strengthening of the nation's spiritual forces to "bring us into a pathway that will lead to peace."

The refusal of the three large private non-profit hospitals on Staten Island to give staff positions to doctors associated with the Health Insurance Plan calls for a thorough airing and for prompt remedial action.
Many letters and telegrams have been received at City Hall in the last few days protesting the application of a self-styled "Nazi chief" to hold a Fourth of July rally in Union Square.

LONDON, June 16 (UPI) -- The riots that forced the cancellation today of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan were part of a growing worldwide trend toward what worried Western officials called "government by students."

LOS ANGELES, June 16 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers piled up an eight-run lead tonight on a pair of three-run homers by Wally Moon and Frank Howard, but had to hustle to preserve a 10 -- 6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

Peru's highly successful Premier (and newspaper publisher), Pedro Beltran, is now in the United States, where Yale University, at least, recognized that something important has been happening in Peru. Yale has just given Dr. Beltran an honorary LL. D. for his valiant struggle "for individual freedom, democratic government and financial stability."

Financing plans involving $100,000,000 in debt securities and two major business enterprises were made known yesterday. Southern California Edison Company's board of directors approved a plan to issue $60,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds to be sold at competitive bidding about Aug. 23.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate appropriated today about $1,000,000,000 more for defense than President Eisenhower had requested.

DETROIT, June 16 (UPI) -- Frank Bolling's tenth-inning single gave the Detroit Tigers a 6-5 victory over Boston today, after Ted Williams had hit the 499th home run of his major league career in the top of the ninth to tie the score.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- Harvard University conferred 3,067 academic and fifteen honorary degreed at its 309th commencement today.

Stocks moved back and forth in an aimless fashion yesterday. However, it was not a dull market because there was activity. Some 3,540,000 shares were traded, against 3,630,000 on Wednesday. But observers called it a "wishy-washy" market.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A Senate subcommittee obliquely criticized the Administration today for its conduct in the case of the U-2 espionage plane.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Education and Labor Committee of the House of Representatives voted 19 to 9 today to send to the floor a bill raising the minimum wage by stages to $1.25 and extending its coverage.
ALGIERS, June 16 -- Right-Wingers among European settlers and Moslems who advocate the maintenance of Algeria within the French Republic appeared today to have joined in a common front.

The wholesale commodity price index inched ahead to 85.5 on Wednesday from the revised figure of 85.4 on Thursday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 88.1 on June 17,1959.

THIS is definitely the week-end to serve a well-seasoned roast leg of lamb or a mixed grill in which thick loin lamb chops are one of the principal ingredients. Lamb, for the first time since last fall, is now one of the leading offerings at many meat counters.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 -- President Eisenhower has praised the "constructive" policies of the Turkish provisional government in a personal message to the new head of state, Gen. Cemal Gursel.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- Following are preliminary 1960 population figures for the fifty states and the District of Columbia, plus the 1950 figures and the percentage of change during the last ten years:
Chambourg, the next to the outsider, returned $65.40 for $2 straight at Belmont Park yesterday after taking the $17,250 International Steeplechase Handicap by eight lengths before 21,102 fans.
BABYLON, L.I., June 16 -- Preliminary census figures showed today that each of Suffolk County's five western townships had more than doubled its population in the last ten years.

TOKYO, June 16 (AP) -- Following, in unofficial translation, are the text of a statement by Premier Nobusuke Kishi on the postponement of President Eisenhower's visit and excerpts from questions and answers at a news conference held by the Premier:
BAR HARBOR, Me., June 16 (AP) -- Dr. Raymond Garfield Fuller, a sociologist and expert on child labor legislation, died today at a nursing home. He was 74 years old.

The Realty Equities Corporation of New York, a real estate and construction company, has announced its purchase of eleven apartment buildings in the New York metropolitan area in a package deal involving about $3,000,000.
Former President Herbert Hoover said yesterday that the "unextinguishable spark in the minds of men to be free" might save progress and civilization despite the inroads of communism.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 8 and Luis Gallop's letter of June 9 demonstrate once again the peculiar moral obtuseness that afflicts so many when confronted with the "Jewish question," which Adolf Eichmann tried so hard to solve.

MANILA, June 16 (AP) Following are the texts of a joint communique issued today on the conclusion of President Eisenhower's visit and of addresses by him at a joint meeting of Philippine and American Chambers of Commerce and at a public reception:
ASCOT, England, June 16 -- Carrying the colors of the late Aly Khan, Sheshoon drove into the lead a furlong from home today to win the Ascot Gold Cup by a length and a half from Exar.

CINCINNATI, June 16 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals almost dissipated a six-run lead in the seventh inning tonight, but Lindy McDaniel went to the rescue and enabled them to post a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

The city has been billed for $176,599.59 by one company since 1955 for rock salt it never got, a senior accountant for the State Commission of Investigation testified yesterday. Virtually all of this has been paid.
Loans to business concerns by leading New York City banks rose $226,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, largely as a result of borrowing to meet second-quarter income tax payments.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- Attorneys for Dave Beck asked the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today to set aside the conviction of the former president of the Teamsters Union for income tax evasion.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 16 -- A fortnight of hope, heroics and heartbreak begins tomorrow for the varsity aspirants to berths on the United States Olympic track and field squad.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Lucille Ball is happily at work on her first motion picture in nearly five years. And she is bubbling over with plans for her first invasion of Broadway this fall.

Federal air inspectors rode the disputed third pilot seat on jet airliners of American and Pan American World Airways yesterday without encountering pilot refusals to fly such as those that touched off the wildat Eastern Air Lines pilot strike.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended June 11 were 2 per cent above the year-earlier level.

A feeling of relief was doubtless the first instinctive reaction of most Americans yesterday to the news that the President's visit to Japan had been canceled. For many days it had been clear that the tumultuous demonstrations in Tokyo's streets posed the grave danger of physical harm to the President should he go there at this time.

A thirty-two-story office building will be constructed at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-sixth. To be known as 555 Madison Avenue, it will represent an investment of about $7,000,000, including the cost of the land.

Oliver W. Powers, the father of the U-2 pilot being held by the Soviet Union, has written to Col. Rudolf Ivanovitch Abel, convicted Soviet spy, suggesting that he would seek United States permission to exchange the two imprisoned men.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Despite outspoken opposition, the quadrennial meeting here of the Northeastern Jurisdiction of the Methodist Church voted overwhelmingly today to reassign Bishop Newell S. Booth to the Belgian Congo.

Jazz moved outdoors last night to the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, where the first in a projected series of Thursday evening concerts was held. It proved a delightful setting for the light, bouncing music of George Wein's Storyville Stompers.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the start of a long-range study of the city's need for rehabilitation.
The New York Central, a beset colossus if ever there was one, has turned on its smallest tormentors.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Tokyo caused chagrin and vague disquiet in much of official Washington today.

WHAT may irk Premier No- busuke Kishi most, personally, at the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan is the loss of an opportunity for that return match of golf. For the slight, 63-year-old chain-smoking leader of Japan's conservative Liberal-Democratic party is as avid a golfer as the President.
FOR their final bill the Kabuki actors have added a farce to the two principal plays of last week's program.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 16 -- Britain offered today to consider "qualified" membership in the supranational European Economic Community.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), June 15 -- The parents of an 8-year-old Israeli boy have offered to leave him with the religious zealots who are hiding him, the police disclosed today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16 -- John McCleary, who helped Blair Academy win the team title during the 36-hole qualifying round of the forty-forth Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament, today upset Dennis Schanno of Taft, the medalist, as match play opened with two rounds at the Greenwich Country Club.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A labor leader used a nine-city, closed-circuit television hook-up today to announce contract demands on two big electrical manufacturers.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 16 -- Three young women of North Shore society made their bows tonight at dinners and a dance given by their parents at their homes and at the Piping Rock Club here.

CLEVELAND, June 16 (UPI) -- Ron Hansen, bidding for rookie-of-the-year honors in the American League, hit a homer in the eleventh inning to give the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.
KANSAS CITY, June 16 -- The Yankees' longest winning streak of the year, checked temporarily by last night's storm-whipped twelve-inning tie, faded away tonight.

Trading volume in copper futures reached 1,064 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot) yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. This was the fifth most active day since the metal was first traded in New York in 1929.

Jazz moved outdoors last night to the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, where the first in a projected series of Thursday evening concerts was held. It proved a delightful setting for the light, bouncing music of George Wein's Storyville Stompers.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the start of a long-range study of the city's need for rehabilitation.
The New York Central, a beset colossus if ever there was one, has turned on its smallest tormentors.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Tokyo caused chagrin and vague disquiet in much of official Washington today.
TOKYO, June 17 (AP) -- Japanese officials suspect that Tokyo's Left-Wing demonstrations may be partly financed by Soviet dancers and musicians constantly visiting the city.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- The five-month-old television writers' strike ;vas settled today.

PARIS. There is no blinking the fact that the United States has suffered a major blow to its prestige as a result of the inept handling of President Eisenhower's proposed journey to Japan. The President was badly advised by those who counseled him, until the very last minute, to make the trip.

ROCKAWAY, N.J., June 17 -- A fairly generous sampling of Handel's oratorio, "Solomon," was given in the Morris Hills Regional School here last night by the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra and three soloists under the direction of David Randolph.
Mayor Wagner suspended Purchase Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna last night for his refusal earlier in the day to answer questions at a public hearing of the State Commission of Investigation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 17 -- Paul G. Hoffman urged today that East and West unite to achieve an income of $125 a person by 1970 for each of the 1,250,000,000 people in the 100 less developed countries and territories. Their income now averages $100 a person a year, he said.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Fuller and Mr. and Mrs. Renwick W. Hurry gave dances tonight on Long-Island to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Emily Rutgers Fuller and Miss Lucy Washington Hurry, who are first cousins.

YONKERS, June 17 -- Mr. Budlong, the 11-10 favorite, won the Taconic Pace by one and three-quarter lengths at Yonkers Raceway last night. Charlie King drove home the winner before a crowd of 27,800 just after an anticipated shower struck.
A 15-year-old girl jumped into the East River at East Ninety-second Street yesterday and saved her best friend from drowning.

A change in the rent laws was announced by the State Rent Commission yesterday. It will permit all landlords to require new tenants of rent-controlled apartments to pay security deposits of up to a month's rent.

SYRACUSE, June 17 -- Dr. John Gardner, who in 1900 stroked Pennsylvania to its only Twentieyn Century victory, five pickle boat crews and an annual meeting of coxswains helped give the Syracuse Regatta its "unofficial" opening today.

TAPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, June 18 -- Communist China raked Quemoy in a record artillery barrage last night and today, accompanying it with a propaganda offensive against the United States and the Chinese Nationalists.

IF ever there was an irresistible time to become a clothes horse, this fall will be it. Yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, the Fashion Group, Inc., presented its annual round-up of the best American ready-to-wear, which will be in stores this fall.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 -- With the June issue of the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics, just published, a marked advance is recorded in the available data on world trade. The periodical for the first time presents figures on trade for the Communist countries of Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and mainland China, over the last decade.

Tax-exempt bonds will play a dominant role in the market for new capital next week. Major issues of governmental bodies and their agencies are expected to account for more than $275,000,000 of new securities.
The cancellation of President Bisenhower's trip to Japan has caused some changes in TV network schedules.

THE divided city of Berlin was studied again last night by Edward R. Murrow on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2. Apart from interviews with Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany, the program had little fresh material to show or new viewpoints to advance.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Average wholesale primary market prices were unchanged at 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics anounced today.

MILWAUKEE, June 17 (UPI) -- Felix Mantilla, a pinch hitter, lofted a long single to left field with the bases loaded in the twelfth inning and scored Al Spangler with the winning run in the Milwaukee Braves' 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The chairman of the Interstat Commerce Commission told a senate subcommittee today that the agency's rate-making policies did not unfairly favor rail lines over water carriers.

TAIPEI, Saturday, June 18 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today the United States "despite all setbacks" was determined to "press on in search of effective means to outlaw war and to promote the rule of law among nations."
CLEVELAND, June 17 (UPI) -- Ted Williams tonight hit a "wrong-field" homer with one on, and lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians. It Was No. 500 of his career.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A tortuous but clear path has been opened to final passage of a bill giving Federal aid for school construction, it appeared here today.
The Radio Corporation of America may call in millions of dollars of its convertible debentures.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that developments in Japan showed that the United States had failed, "to assess realistically the facts before us and to define realistic purposes and actions to meet them."
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Comnission today opposed legislation drafted in the house to abolish loss leaders -- items sold it a loss in order to lure shoppers into a store.
CINCINNATI, June 17 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted today a former executive of the Briggs Manufacturing Company on charges that he sought to sell Briggs stock he did not possess.
LONDON, June 17 -- The first open demand from within the strife-torn Labor party for the resignation of Hugh Gaitskel as its leader appeared today.
MOSCOW, June 17 -- Soviet scientists have developed an acoustic thermometer to measure stratospheric temperatures by means of sound, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
MOSCOW, June 17 -- A high Cuban official indicated today that he had come to Moscow to begin extensive negotiations for greater trade between Cuba and the Communist nations of Europe.
BERLIN, June 17 -- The East German Communist party rejected today the idea that Communist China's agricultural communes could serve as an example for other Communist countries.

Marcel Pigou of Chartres, France, scored a smashing triumph in his American debut last night with a seventh-round technical knockout over Eduardo Lausse of Buenos Aires in a scheduled ten-round fight at the St. Nicholas Arena.
Plans are under way for a feature film drama called "The Life of Mahatma Gandhi," based on the activities of the late Indian leader.
Mayor Wagner put off decision yesterday after a public hearing on the proposed local law imposing a use tax on trucks and other commercial vehicles.

WARSAW, June 17 -- Work has begun on the 420-mile Polish section of the East European oil pipeline. The pipeline is designed to move oil from the Middle Volga Basin in the Soviet Union to Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary.
CALVERTON, L.I., June 17 -- Eastern Long Island became a classroom today as a three day workshop began for leaders of sportsman-conservation organizations.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 (UPI)-- Francis P. Yockey, a former Midwest lawyer, killed himself today in his jail cell, where he was being held on charges of passport fraud.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- The Yankees sparkled -- really sparkled -- en route to a 4-2 victory over the White Sox at Comiskey Park tonight.
The complaint of Argentina that her laws and her sovereignty have been violated in the Eichmann case cannot be gainsaid, and Premier Ben-Gurion of Israel has virtually admitted as much.

BERLIN, June 17 -- West Germany marked today the seventh anniversary of the workers' revolt in Communist East Germany with pledges of an unyielding struggle for the country's reunification in freedom.

"The Christian Family," from its beginnings in the Garden of Eden to the church weddings of today, will be celebrated tomorrow in the eighth annual San Juan Fiesta of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
PARIS, June 17 -- France's largest student organization came under Government criticism today for its "political" activity against the Algerian war.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17 -- The oldest American intercollegiate sports rivalry -- the Harvard-Yale rowing regatta -- will be staged for the ninetyfifth time tomorrow. The Crimson is a strong favorite.

TAIPEI, Saturday, June 18 (AP) -- Admiral Liu, the Defense Ministry spokesman, said a military hospital used by the civilian population on Quemoy had been hit by nineteen rounds of the nearly 86,000 the Reds hurled.
Francis Peter Crosby, 36-year-old stock promoter and former husband of Denise Darcel, the actress, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and fined $10,000.
DARIEN, Conn., June 17 -- Naute Mia and Cold Climate each won two blue ribbons at the opening of the three-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show today.
Organized labor is swinging sharply toward Senator John F. Kennedy in his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan scored a point yesterday in his court fight to clear himself of the charge of conspiring to conceal the acceptance of gratuities from Sidney J. Ungar.
Work stoppages were threatened yesterday among employes of the Department of Hospitals and five cultural institutions in the city.
KANSAS CITY, June 17 (UPI) -- Bill Fischer's relief pitching led the Washington Senators to a 3-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight. Dan Dobbek drove in two runs with a homer and single.
Thousands of filters never touch the lips of cigarette smokers.

A history of archaeological research in Italy is given by Paul MacKendrick in his new book, "The Mute Stones Speak." It will be published by St. Martin's Press next Wednesday. The book, with 175 photographs, maps and drawings, presents new information on pre-Roman and Roman culture and describes the newest techniques used at recent excavation sites.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- Representative George H. Mahon, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Defense Appropriations subcommittee, said today he saw no "revolutionary change" in the world situation that would affect the military's money needs.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 17 -- Joseph Kasavubu, president of the Association of the Lower Congo, was appointed today to form the first Congolese Government.
HONG KONG, June 17 -- In a dispatch from the "Fukien front," Hsinhua said "innumerable flashes cut through the dark sky" over Taiwan Strait the instant the order to fire was given.

HATTERAS, N.C., June 17 -- This fishing for blue marlin off Cape Hatteras, especially in a tournament, is a complicated business but a man of resolution can beat it if he tries. The thing to do is take everybody's advice.

Volume in domsetic sugar futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was the heaviest of the year. A total of 44,800 tons changed hands. This was the largest volume since Jan. 9, 1957, when 56,300 tons was traded.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 (UIP) -- The San Francisco Giants beat the Philadelphia Phils, 7 to 3, tonight for Mike MeCormick's eighth triumph.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs outlined tonight a program of action in public affairs for the nation's 850,000 federated clubwomen.

The understandable chagrin and distress that Americans feel about recent events in Japan should not obscure our vision of the total Asian scene. That scene is far more variegated and complex than the unhappy news from Japan alone would suggest.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Southern California Aircraft Corporation has received a patent for a machine that automatically tallies paper ballots. The inventors, James L. Fechter and Everett E. Stallard, contend that paper ballots are preferable to voting machines.
The Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 10 points up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
The Federal Aviation Agency toughened its stand yesterday against jet airliner pilots refusing to fly with agency inspectors in the third pilot's seat.

The hearings held by the State Insurance Department on the application of the Associated Hospital Service for rate increases that average 37,4 per cent gave the Blue Cross and hospital managements a good opportunity to argue for the request. It also gave a public forum in which the critics of the rate rise could air their complaints.

Space Travel and an Old Tradition It is natural to assume that virtually everything relating to space travel, to definite preparations for sending a human being beyond the pull of gravity, is new and unique in this generation.

Feature Sports has come up with a smashing shibboleth in trying to "sell" its heavyweight championship fight on Monday night. Bill Fugazy, the supervising director of the firm that is presenting the clash between the titleholder, Ingemar Johansson, and the ex-champion, Floyd Patterson, calls the production the "$3,500,000 fight."

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- A special examiner of the Federal Communications Commission, who is reviewing the award of a television channel in Miami, described actions in his hearing room today as "sinister."
The scene on the seventh floor of the Commodore Hotel yesterday was like fight night at Madison Square Garden in the old days.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday June 18 -- President Eisenhower arrived here today to tumultums welcome.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In face of the darkening world scene, the House of Representatives rolled over opponents of the Mutual Security Program today and passed a strengthened spending bill for the year ahead.

Workers at three more voluntary hospitals have voted to authorize a strike, their union announced yesterday. The balloting, at Lenox Hill, Flower-Fifth Avenue and Beekman-Downtown Hospitals, completed such strike authorizations among union members employed by ten private nonprofit institutions.
KANEOHE, Hawaii, June 16 -- Syngman Rhee, former President of South Korea, is living here in seclusion in a tiny cottage that looks out on the Pacific Ocean.
TOKYO, June 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Chinese Communist Army statement transmitted today by Hsinnua, Communist press agency:
The Board of Education is expected to create three new positions of Deputy Superintendent of Schools next week as part of its administrative reorganization of the public school system.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Limited but significant pressure has developed here for a reassessment of United States relations with Japan.
The three members of the new East Hudson Parkway Authority were sworn in yesterday in the presence of Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The outlook for Federal housing legislation this year has been thrown into confusion by a lastminute public housing amendment to the Senate bill.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- The Soviet Government said tonight that the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan was "diplomatic catastrophe" for the United States comparable to the downing of the U-2 spy plane.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Mediation was resumed today in a dispute that has threatened to halt trains on the Long Island Rail Road.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the domestic trunk airlines today to raise fares by 2 1/2 per cent, plus $1 for each oneway ticket, starting July 1.
LONDON, June 17 -- Ronald Laver, the Australian titleholder, was beaten in the London grass court tennis championship today at the Queen's Club.

John. M. Budd, president of the Great Northern Railway, is hopeful that a merger agreement between his railroad and the Northern Pacific Railway "will be placed before the Interstate Commerce Commission before the end of the year."

LOS ANGELES, June 17 -- A Democratic party platform committee hearing was jarred today by a demand that major governmental agencies and policies be radically overhauled to meet "the deepest peril in the nation's history.''

The Republic of the Sudan borrowed $15,500,000 from The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) yesterday to help finance the completion of the Managil Irrigation Scheme. When the project is finished in 1962, some 830,000 acres are slated to be irrigated and settled by about 50,000 farmers and their families.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Chicago's second annual International Trade Fair will open on Navy Pier Monday. The huge pier has been humming with activity for weeks as workers labored to transform it into a vast bazaar that is expected to attract hundreds of thousands of visitors.

Jazz moved outdoors Friday night to the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, where the first in a projected series of Thursday evening concerts was held. It proved a delightful setting for the light, bouncing music of George Wein's Storyville Stompers.

Following is President Eisenhower's official program during the next days of his trip to the Far East. All times are regional. (Taiwan and Okinawa time is thirteen hours ahead of Eastern Daylight time; Korean time is thirteen and a half hours ahead):
Broadway theatregoers will have to wait until late next season before being able to see Graham Greene's "The Complaisant Lover."
GREENWICH, Conn., June 17 -- John McCleary of Blair Academy captured the championship of the forty-fourth Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament at Greenwich Country Club today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 (AP) -- Manager Bill Rigney of the, San Francisco Giants was under fire today because of the team's slump.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Selling, which included moderate amounts of hedging, profit taking and outright liquidation, weakened the grain futures market shortly before the close of the board of trade today.
CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- Ted Williams, 41, hit the 500th home run of his major league career tonight. "Sure, it was a thrill; it was one of my goals," he said.
Two British sergeants yesterday completed a hike from the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco to New York's Coliseum.

MURRAY BAY, Que., June 17 (Canadian Press) -- The climate for saving and investing is better than it was a year ago, Norman J. Alexander, president of the Investment Dealers' Association of Canada, said today at the association's annual meeting.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 17 (AP) -- Two major settlements were reached today in the aircraft and missile industry.

Stocks drifted down yesterday, but, once again, specialized electronics showed strength. In the absence of a marked trend, investors also favored volatile specialties. In most cases, these issues showed sharp gains.

HARTFORD, June 17 -- Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania chided the Republican patty tonight for having, as he jut it, denied Governor Rockefeller of New York "the right to work" for the Presidential nomination.
LONDON, June 17 -- Share prices drifted lower in the stock market here today.
The British Military Tournament and Tattoo trumpeted, skirled and boomed into Madison Square Garden last night. It had elements of a big parade, a band concert and a circus.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company took firm control of the United States Envelope Company yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 17 -- The Turkish people were told tonight that they faced a period of austerity required to strengthen the nation's economy.
Senator John F. Kennedy made his final appeal for support of the 114-vote New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention in an active day here yesterday.
The Claiborne Farm's 4-year-old Dunce is the highweight and probable favorite in the field of thirteen turf runners named for today's $59,400 Bowling Green Handicap at Belmont Park.
A bill has been introduced in the City Council to allow disabled persons to park in metered curb spaces without paying the usual 10-cent fee.
CINCINNATI, June 17 (AP) -- Bob Will's home run helped the Chicago Cubs score a 3-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

THE principal export of Majorca is books by Robert Graves. Or so it seems, anyway, as one stimulating volume after another comes sailing out of that pleasant Mediterranean island. A fine sample hamper of prime Graves is now available and recommended. It is called "Food for Centaurs."
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- Gene Stephens belted a two-run pinch homer in the seventh inning and lifted the Baltimore Orioles to a 3-1 triumph over the Detroit Tigers tonight before 29,079 fans.
The Japanese crisis should be viewed for what it is, a potential challenge to the United States' strategic position in the Western Pacific.

DENVER, June 17 -- Mike Souchak, with a big grin and a big swing, established a record in the United States Open golf championship today, Souchak scored a four-under-par 67 at the Cherry Hills Country Club and brought his 36-hole total to 135.

Two five-story apartment houses at 1562-64 Third Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street, have been sold by the J.H.J. Realty Corporation to an investing client of Morris Mitchell, lawyer. The buildings occupy a plot 40 by 100 feet. They changed hands in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company, broker.
PARIS, June 17 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel restated today his country's determination to keep and try the Nazi fugitive involved in the war-time extermination of 6,000,000 Jews.

TAIPEI, Saturday, June 18 (AP) -- Presidents Eisenhower and Chiang drove from the airport to the city in an open car amid throngs of cheering and dancing Chinese. The crowds waved American and Chinese flags and shouted greetings to General Eisenhower.

The writer of the following letter was until recently foreign editor of Newsweek and in that capacity visited Japan and established many connections there. He is personally acquainted with Mr. Kishi, Mr. Yoshida, and many other leading Japanese political figures.
NYERI, Kenya, June 7 -- An important development for the future of Kenya is taking place in this area. Europeans and African farmers are cultivating the land successfully side by side.
Marine engineers and their employers took their wage dispute to arbitration yesterday at an all-day hearing that affects all East and Gulf Coast passenger and dry cargo ship operators.

STONY BROOK, L.I., June 17 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood will meet in the 36-hole final of the fifty-seventh annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tomorrow.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has estimated the city's general fund revenue for the fiscal year starting July 1 at a record $795,668,000.

WENTWORTH BY THE SEA, N.H., June 17 -- A further upward trend in business for at least the next six months was predicted tonight by Martin H. Gainsbrugh of New York, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, speaking at the New Hampshire banker's dinner here.
YESTERDAY (June 17, I960) THE PRESIDENT In Taipei, Taiwan. THE SENATE Passed and sent to White House a pay-increase bill for Federal workers estimated at $746,000,000.

GENEVA, June 17 -- The United States instructed its chief disarmament negotiator today to return immediately to Washington for consultations aimed at meeting insistent Allied demands for new Western disarmament proposals.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 17 -- Stripped of virtually every early favorite, the New Jersey Amateur? Golf championship reached the semi-final level today at the Ridgewood Country Club.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to add $50,000,000 to the $915,000,000 space budget requested by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Northeastern Jurisdiction of the Methodist Church elected two more bishops today. They are the Rev. Dr. James K. Mathews of Montclair, N.J., and the Rev. Dr. William Ralph Ward Jr. of Pittsburgh.
NAHA, Okinawa, June 17 -- About 300,000 Ryukyuans are expected to give President Eisenhower an enthusiastic welcome during his visit of an hour and a half Sunday on his way to South Korea.
THE progressive party is a mid-twentieth century phenomenon. Now that servants have disappeared, it is not uncommon in suburban communities for dinner to proceed from house to house with each course.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., June 17 -- Skeletons and artifacts uncovered in West Islip, near the approach to the Captree Bridge, indicate that an Indian Village flourished near the meadow lands 800 to 1,200 years ago.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 17 -- Joseph Scarp and Caesar Mauti of Brookville scored a 33, 36 -- 69, three under par to win the Long Island Golf Association best-ball championship at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, June 18 -- President Eisenhower believes that summit conferences and personal Presidential diplomacy will continue despite the failure at Paris and the collapse of his scheduled trip to Japan.
IN every bridge generation there are some authorities who oppose pre-emptive bids such as three hearts or four spades, made on weak hands for the sole purpose of shutting out the opponents.
Prices of United States Government securities and other prime-risk bonds declined yesterday under the weight of offerings related to profit-taking, Volume shrank.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17 -- If yacht races were the same as horse races, Carleton Mitchell's Finisterre would be the morning-line favorite on past performances for the contest to Bermuda that will begin tomorrow. The gray thirty-nine-foot yawl has won the biennial event two times in a row -- in 1958 and 1956.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said today that the future population of the New York metropolitan area required another major airport in northern New Jersey.

One of the men who have helped the port's vital tow-boat industry grow in the last fifty years resigned from the Daizell Towing Company yesterday. He is John L. Sullivan, vice president in charge of sales.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to give pay increases totaling $746,000,000 a year to 1,570,000 Federal employes. The vote, after eight hours of debate, was 62 to 17.

SOME of Mr. and Mrs. Ted Nierenberg's favorite recipes, all of which are included in the meal shown above, are given here. They were devised by Mr. Nierenberg and have proven successful in many of their parties.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 17 -- The drivers and crews of more than 200 cars checked in today for the eleven races to be run tomorrow and Sunday on the new mile-and-a-half road course at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The new American Football League today filed a $10,000,000 antitrust suit against the National Football League.

A paid informer of the Waterfront Commission testified yesterday that a steamship official had recommended murder as the only way to get rid of an honest Union official in Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States plans to present soon an "omnibus" indictment against Cuba to the Peace Committee of the Organization of American States.
Following are editorial comments by newspapers throughout the country on the cancellation of President Eisenhower's visit to Japan, as gathered by The New York Times and The Associated Press:
SANTIAGO DB CUBA, June 17 -- A new United States-owned refinery, a landmark of Santiago, is preparing for seizure by the Cuban Government.
LOS ANGELES, June 17 (UPI) -- Vernon Law became the first major league pitcher to win ten games this season as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- As the political campaign develops in the coming months, American voters are likely to hear more and more of Herbert George Klein.

Standard Brands, Inc., a leading food processor and distributor, announced yesterday that it had acquired almost 50 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Planters Nut and Chocolate Company for slightly more than $12,000,000.
LONDON, June 17 -- The International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea held its final session here today Without having fully resolved the issues of safety measures for nuclear-powered ships.

The Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation of Eddystone, Pa., and Lima, Ohio, has leased a one-story office and warehouse building to be constructed to its specifications on Route 1, Newark. The lessee will use the building to distribute parts for Cranes, shovels, derricks and other construction equipment.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 17 -- Fairfield County's population has increased 27.9 per cent -- from 504,342 in 1950 to 645,177 in 1960 -- according to preliminary census figures announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Vice President Nixon was reported today, on the eve of four-day trip that will include three Midwest farm states, to be ready to "touch" on the touchy farm issue.

RYE, N.Y., June 17 -- Charles Shaffer of Woodberry Forest in Virginia beat the defender, Hugh Lynch 3d of Georgetown Prep in Maryland, in the final of the Manursing Island Club's interscholastic tennis tournament today.

Yesterday, on the American Stock Exchange, one issue had pretty universal appeal. So much so that trading was stopped several times because of the rush of orders. With volume of 182,600 shares, it was the most actively traded issue.

BUFFALO, June 17 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed tonight that the Federal Government drastically expand its offensive against racial discrimination in employment, housing, the public schools and government itself.
A suit was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday to keep the city from issuing a permit to the American Nazi party to hold a July 4 rally in Union Square.
SEOUL, Korea, June 17 -- The South Korean Government announced today the program for President Eisenhower's visit on Sunday and Monday.

NEWS in toyland is an endearing wooden dachshund from Denmark. It is sixteen inches long, only six and one half inches tall, and is an easy mount for an energetic toddler. This mobile plaything is $16 at Be Seated, 43 Greenwich Avenue.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 18 -- Thousands of Leftist students and unionists continued mass demonstrations against Premier Nobusuke Kishi's pro-United States regime yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A fiagrant transgression of the statutes was committed by me this week! For this offense I was cited with a summons to appear in Magistrate's Court of the City of New York one week hence.

LONDON, June 17 -- The audience that gathered for the season's first performance of "Otello" at Covent Garden tonight was met by the disheartening announcement that Sena Jurinac, the Desdemona, would not appear.

IN the jungle campaign near the Salween River during World War II, there was a lull in the fighting between the Chinese and Japanese forces one day. Before the gunfire resumed, two Americans on the scene -- a war correspondent and an Army major -- met and talked briefly.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 17 -- Meet-record throwing performances by Bill Alley of Kansas and Dallas Long of Southern California distinguished today's opening competition in the thirty-ninth National Collegiate track and field championship.

ASCOT, England, June 17 (AP) -- Silver King outsprinted Sovereign Path in the final 200 yards today and won the sixfurlong Workingham Stakes -- the last big handicap of the Royal Ascot race meet. The time was 1:15.02.
The Washington Square art show is drawing sour notices in Greenwich Village. They run from guffaws to gasps of, "Who are these people?"

For Ages 12 to 16. HUNDREDS of boys and girls around the country who are exhibiting their home-made inventions in regional science fairs will be encouraged -- if they need encouragement -- by the success story of Charles Franklin Kettering.

To the Drama Editor: FINDING myself in New York one evening recently for the first time in many months, I walked over to Times Square in the early dark to get a long-anticipated first look at the George M. Cohan memorial.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 18 -- The Misses Phyllis A. Holbrook, Eleanor Hunt and Toinette Tucker were honored this evening at a large dance given jointly by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Holbrook of Bedford Hills, Mr. and Mrs. James R. Hunt Jr. of Washington and Katonah and Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker Jr. of Mount Kisco.

IN a preface to "The Disinherited," a first novel about the Spanish Civil War, 27-year-old, Spanish-born Michel del Castillo assures the reader that he never was a Communist nor is he now an anti-Communist. The solution to the fundamental problem of "the suffering and the alienation of men by men," he says, "must be found elsewhere than in any political program."
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 18 (UPI) -- Bagdad, ridden by Willie Shoemaker, closed with a rush to win the $54,350 Inglewood Handicap at Hollywood Park today. Fleet Nasrullah finished fourth.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The right to vote, that most basic of democratic civil rights, was finally approved for the citizens of the District of Columbia this week.
One week from tomorrow night Yankee Stadium will provide the setting for a ball game that should bring a nostalgic twinge to New York fans, particularly those of Brooklyn extraction.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 18 -- Massachusetts Bay hardly resembled the Bay of Naples today as George O'Day of Boston sailed to victory with his Wistful in the final tune-up race of the 5.5-meter class prior to the selection series for representation in the 1960 Olympics.

THE latest nosegay from Mary Ellen Chase's garden of eternal verities is destined to reach a limited and, one might almost suspect, a coterie audience. To many "The Lovely Ambition" would appear to be old-fashioned (the author does seem to regard the writing of fiction as an art) and perhaps just a bit dull (since goodness and decency are made not only believable but palatable).

Twenty houses representing all sections of the continental United States and Hawaii, picked for their architectural excellence, share the common characteristic of spaciousness. Whether large or small in overall dimensions, they reflect the primary concern of their designers to provide as much uncluttered living area as possible.

Jack Spagna In the last year New York's Mayor Wagner has had to cops with an increasing number of situations involving maladministration or alleged maladministration of city affairs. There was the controversy over the conduct of the Title I slum-clearance program.
Ira Davis, a former Olympian representing the Philadelphia Pioneer Club, broke the American record for the hop, step and jump yesterday with a leap of 52 feet 6 inches.
Flush doors -- the unpaneled type whose surfaces are flat from edge to edge -- are increasing in popularity.

OUT of a wide experience as a Times reporter, Ira Henry Freeman has written a compassionate and authoritative documentary about juvenile delinquents. The book, based on an actual case-history, is cast in novel form to dramatize its theme.
A total of 6,200 persons paraded in the city yesterday in two Protestant celebraions.

IT is an old-fashioned idea, this putting up of fruits in brandy to make what is popularly called tutti-frutti. And now is the time to take advantage of summer's orchards and berry patches; the rewards will be heady next winter.
DETROIT, June 18 -- Smaller big cars and bigger small cars will be in the center ring in this fall's automotive circus.
DENVER, June 18 -- Golf's man of steel won the United States Open championship today.

VICE PRESIDENT and general manager of Freedomland is Frederich V. Schumacher, whose knowledge of outdoor entertainment has spanned a continent.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- How could anybody "lose" more than 152,000 houses in one year?

MOST people think of air conditioning as a summer-time luxury -- something to be enjoyed only during the hottest weather. Actually it's a year-round necessity. Cooling is but a small part of the story. Air conditioning is just what the name implies: a conditioning of the air.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18 -- Sam Beard of the Great South Bay fleet, sailing Maverick; took the lead today for the Arms-White Trophy after two races in the three-race Star Class series off the Rocky Point Sailing Club.

Store sales picked up noticeably last week as Father's Day approached. Retailers had not been pressing too hard to move merchandise that would please the head of the family on the day set aside to, do him honor. As a retailing event, Father's Day has not quite reached the emotional pitch of Mother's Day.
BERLIN, June 18 -- By the evidence of its ideological twists and its own admissions, the East German Communist party and Walter Ulbricht, its First Secretary, are going through difficult times.
SOMERVILLE, Tenn., June 16 -- White leaders are waging economic warfare to prevent Negroes from becoming a major political force in Fayette County.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- People who come here for summer vacations never lack for something to do. And this summer, even sidewalk superintendents will not be in want of activity. This is because of the restoration of what is believed to be the oldest frame dwelling in New York State.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 18 -- Premier Khrushchev arrived from Moscow by air today to attend the opening of the third conference of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party. He is expected to address the Congress at its first session Monday morning.
DARIEN, Conn., June 18 -- Five of seven championships at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show virtually were decided today. In each case the leader was a point short of victory.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -- This town wears well; its essential character and charm remain intact. Changes have taken place here in the name of progress, but there has been a firm and unrelenting resistance to the challenge of soft-custard, hot-dog and hamburger stands that dot and despoil the tourist landscape elsewhere.

DESPITE the fact that they are obviously well occupied with a variety of film projects, Britain's Boulting brothers have added another production to their bulging dossier. The Messrs. Roy and John Boulting, to put it explicitly, have acquired rights to the tentatively titled "The Gypsum Flower," an original work by John Whiting, an artisan who scored in London with his play, "Marching Song."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- This year marks Fort Lauderdale's greatest effort toward encouragement of summer tourist business. Fifteen hotels have joined in a low-rate, package-plan vacation.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate sat in a bad-tempered mood in an unusual Saturday session today and became embroiled in a fight among Democrats.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Contempt of Congress convictions of two women who balked at answering questions of Congressional investigators were overturned today by the United States Court of Appeals. Similar convictions of six men were affirmed.
An auto-sales plan that a New Jersey dealer has called highly successful was described yesterday as a "mathematical monstrosity" by the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.

CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP) Bob Hale, a pinch-hitter, delivered a sacrifice fly today with the bases filled in the eighth inning for the Cleveland Indians who defeated the Boston Red Sox, 2-1. The Red Sox collected only one hit.

Eiffel Tower THE Eiffel Tower, raised at the cost of fifteen million uninflated francs in 1889, aroused protest from a committee of prominent citizens from Gounod to Dumas fils. Their outraged letter condemned the "Tower of Babel" which would "disfigure and dishonor" the city -- but to no avail.

HATTERAS, N.C., June 18 -- A small clump, or inquiring, of scientists is down here right now fixing to start out in four private, donated boats and find out what blue marlin do, and why and when they do it.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Representative Otto E. Passman, a penny-wise merchant from Louisiana who has terrorized the foreign-aid program for years, was finally beaten in battle this week.

INDOOR comfort is like apple pie. It can be a definite delight or a dismal disappointment.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The largest art exhibit ever brought to the United States from South America will open Tuesday at the Pan American Union.
POINT MUGU, Calif. LIST Twentieth Century-Fox's "Go North" as an example of the improvisation that went on before the settlement of the writers' strike.

NATURAL GAS is five billion years young. To the modern homeowner, natural gas means year-round comfort and convenience. To the nation's industry, it means more useful energy for each dollar than with any competing fuel.

FOUR New York high school students have won top awards in the $11,750 Kodak High School Photo Contest. They are Paul Grebanier, Brooklyn, $300; Dan Burnstein and Claire Simpson, both Manhattan, $100 each, and Thomas Nash, also Manhattan, who won a special $50 award.

The eighteenth and nineteenth centuries are recorded in history as the periods of rugged individualism, but the twentieth century will probably be remembered as the era of standardization, the Rev. Dr. William Berkowitz said yesterday.

MOST people who seek new homes in the suburbs generally are willing to pay a bonus for a wooded tract. All too frequently, though, the forest-type trees on these sites prove of doubtful value -- particularly as front-area specimens.
If you're going to be out of the city on Nov. 8, your chance of voting for President and other offices will depend on the reason for your absence.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 19 -- President Eisenhower received an enthusiastic welcome as he arrived here today on the last stop of his Far Eastern trip.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A compulsory voting plan, as advocated by Henry Waldman in his letter published June 12, is the worst possible way to increase the percentage of people participating in politics.

THANKS to big industrial plants, your household gas bill is a real bargain. In fact, homes and small businesses save many millions of dollars each year because these large plants help "pay the freight" of bringing gas to you.

If he survives things like girls and a gay college life, it is virtually certain that Dick Stockton, a 9-year-old tennis player from the third grade, will bloom in a sport that is notoriously hard on prodigies.

LOS ANGELES -- Tucked away in an unwashed corner of downtown Los Angeles is Olvera Street, a picturesque, block-long arcade. For generations, it has been one of the city's staple tourist attractions, being visited annually by more than 2,000,000 sight-seers.

In Central Park's Memorial Grove, amidst a stand of maples and pin oaks a bit south of the band shell at the Mall, vandals have pried loose and taken away from memorial stones eleven bronze plaques bearing the names of men who fell in World War I at Baccarat and Oise and Aisne and the Argonne Forest.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 18 (UPI) -- Bill Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., edged Pat Smythe, Britain's star woman rider, for first place today and won the Hermitage Prize at Lucerne's international horse show.

BISMARCK, June 18 -- Interest in North Dakota's special Senate election on June 28, already high, will mount tomorrow with the arrival in the state of Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

SYRACUSE, June 18 -- Starting slowly as if it wanted to see what the opposition offered. California settled down to business and scored a stirring triumph in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta today.

The time lag between a new idea in education and its general acceptance by the majority of schools has been put at twenty-five years by the Ford Foundation's research department. Added to the basic conservatism of the profession is the problem in communications; vital experiments are often carried on in local isolation.
OXFORD, England, June 18 -- Oxford University's basketball team, captained by two Americans, left today for a series of games in the Soviet Union.
STANTON, De., June 18 (AP) -- Victoria Park, Canada's top 3-year-old, easily won the $45,950 Leonard Richards Stakes today at Delaware Park and set a track record.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 18 -- Vice President Nixon has begun to put his stamp on the 1960 Republican platform.

ODENSE, Denmark, June 8 -- In a huge new shipbuilding dock near here, a 48,580-ton tanker ordered by a United States concern is taking shape unusually slowly. The pace is dictated by Denmark's shortage of labor.

In spite of rioting which at one time was estimated to involve 300,000 persons, the Kishi Government in Tokyo has stood firm on its new treaty with the United States. There was nothing else it could do unless Premier Kishi resigned or completely reversed his foreign policy. The treaty, voted a month ago by the lower house of the Diet, went into effect automatically, so far as Japan was concerned, at midnight yesterday, Tokyo time.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 18 -- Twenty-three debutantes, including some honored by their parents at fetes during the last ten days, were formally introduced to society tonight at the fourth annual Stamford Junior League Ball at the Stamford Yacht Club.

"Bench-warmers" on a Texas college's football team now get a helping hand from gas infra-red heaters, according to a Southwestern gas utility company. Portable gas-fueled radiant heaters placed behind the team's bench keep players warm without wasting heat on the surrounding air.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- Sun worshipers who visit Port-au-Prince for the first time generally are startled to find an almost total absence of habitable beaches. There are swimming pools aplenty -- almost every hotel has one -- but those kidney-shaped basins are small beer indeed for anyone addicted to sand and surf.
NUEVITAS, Cuba, June 15 -- Separated only by the width of the pier jutting out into the bay, two ships were loading sugar today under burning noontime sun at this little port on Cuba's north coast.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 18 -- Fog so thick that the other end of the starting line could not be seen beset the yachts that sailed in the race to Bermuda today.

"I WANTED to tell everyone the great history and future of our country." Thus does dynamic, 38-year-old C.V. Wood, Jr., explain his response to a "personal challenge" which led him to design and create the world's largest outdoor family entertainment center.
EXCITING things are happening in the kitchen today!
John Guzzwell, who sailed his twenty-foot yawl Trekka alone around the world in four years without an untoward incident, has been voted the Slocum Award by the Slocum Society of Shady Side, Md.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sunday, June 19 -- President Eisenhower and Chiang Kai-shek lashed out today at what they called "the outrageous and barbaric practice of the Chinese Communists in shelling and ruthlessly killing Chinese people on alternate days."

GLOUCESTER, Mass. -- Poets have worked an unintended libel on the North Shore of Massachusetts. By hymning loudly the praises of the rocky shores and completely ignoring the gentle beaches, the bards have created the impression that there are no hospitable spots up this way for bathing and sun-tanning.

ALTHOUGH last week's rain washed away blossoms in many areas, New York City gardens still are a mosaic of color. One thousand geraniums, in shades from pale pink to fire red, blanket Rockefeller Center's Channel Gardens.
