The city's suspended Commissioner of Purchase, Joseph V. Spagna, changed his mind yesterday and announced he would testify before the State Commission of Investigation about the city's buying of rock salt.

NO private collection in this country, or for that matter anywhere, has been more generously put into the service of the public than that of Mr. and Mrs. Roy R. Neuberger. It is now on view at Knoedler's for the benefit of the American Federation of Arts (admission is sixty cents) and will remain there through Sept. 9 as part of the "New York Is a Summer Festival" program.

NEW CITY, N.Y., June 18 -- Spring Valley, where the population increased from 4,492 in 1950 to 6,427 in 1960, has become the largest village in Rockland County, according to preliminary census figures announced today.
A TINY gas flame, weatherproof and more automatic than sunshine, has taken the "blues" out of washday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 18 -- Only one contest is scheduled in the sixteen Suffolk County villages that will hold summer elections next Tuesday.
HONG KONG -- Come to Hong Kong, but be sure you have a confirmed hotel reservation. This is the word going out to the United States from travel agents in this British Crown Colony.

ORAL POLIO VACCINE -- Dr. Dorothy M. Horstmann of the Yale School of Medicine told the International Conference on Live Poliovirus Vaccines in Washington that studies by herself and three associates in Costa Rica suggest that a series of three oral doses of live polio virus vaccines, rather than only one dose, appear to be more effective in building immunity against all three types of polio viruses.
Dr. Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday that the United States should not yield to its allies' pleas for "new look" disarmament plans to match the propaganda punch of sweeping new Soviet proposals.

THE first novel by Henry Morton Robinson since his 1950 success, "The Cardinal," is a magnum -- although hardly a magnum opus -- of sour-mash bourbon called "Water of Life." A family chronicle-cum-industrial success story, it sets forth an array of information about the distilling business from the latter part of the nineteenth century to the coming of Prohibition.

No single formula is enough to account for the disasters that have assailed the position of the United States in the world in the past few months. ONE advantage of raising perennials and biennials from seed is that it is possible to have the named varieties and exact colors wanted. This usually is not true when plants are bought in spring from a roadside stand or garden center.

AUTOMATION isn't confined to heavy industry. It can be found right in your own home. Just look around you at the thermostats, timers, and other controls that are performing modern miracles for better, easier living.

One day last week, two men wearing glasses, stripped to the waist and a bit paunchy about their middles, struggled against the tides in an inlet of Eastchester Bay in the Bronx. They paddled heroically but their canoe waddled most unprofessionally.
Bernard P. Day, a New York real estate auctioneer and broker, says he broke the law on a recent visit to Australia. Without a license, he auctioned off some lots in the suburbs of Sydney.

WASHINGTON -- Togetherness in a tent, or family camping, is a form of economical vacationing that has gained ground rapidly in recent years. Recreation authorities estimate that as many as 12,000,000 families may be on the march with tents and/or camping trailers this year.
A Federal judge issued a restraining order against Long Island Rail Road trainmen yesterday, forbidding a strike for five days.
BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- David Michel Torino, Argentine newspaper publisher who had been imprisoned by former President Juan D. Peron, died in Salta last night of cancer at the age of 72.

Anti-segregation housing laws adopted by four states and two cities -- New York and Pittsburgh -- in the last few years are considered a potent educational force for modifying racial and religious prejudice, rather than a revolutionary move.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Fredrick M. Eaton, chief United States disarmament negotiator at Geneva, arrived here today for consultations on how to make the Western proposals more attractive.

PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, June 18 (AP) -- Arnoid Palmer and Sam Snead head the American challenge against teams from twenty-nine other countries in the eighth international golf championship and Canada Cup matches opening over the Portmarnock links Thursday.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Charlie Maxwell, after twice fouling off bunts in attempting to move two runners along, belted a home run that lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.

The stock market took a breathing spell last week after a spectacular advance in the preceding period. Prices swayed back and forth, ending in an indecisive pattern. Although some sharp advances were registered by a few drug and electronic shares, the "blue-chip" issues came under pressure as a result of profit-taking.
TO THE EDITOR: We read with great interest Harold C. Schonberg's excellent article on Robert Schumann's 150th anniversary ["After 150 years, Applause for Schuman," June 5.]
MINEOLA, L.I., June 18 -- Thirteen villages in Nassau County will hold elections on Tuesday, but only three will have contests.

SAINTES-MARIES-DE-LAMER -- For anyone who has been touring France, its cities, its gaieties, its museums, chateaux and churches, and suddenly feels an overwhelming desire for open spaces, sun, the cry of birds in a wide sky, and a solitude virtually of the prairies, the Camargue is the place.

AFTER reading zillions of routine plotted "straight" novels equipped with hello-goodbye dialogue, predictable heavies, Stag Magazine sex, and all the other histrionic garbage that almost assures said books best-sellerdom, it is always a pleasure to read a Jack Kerouac novel, even if it is not among that author's best work.

NAIROBI, Kenya. AN all-time high was reached last year in the African safari business which since the war has become a major industry, with America providing nine customers out of every ten. Despite rising demand, however, safari magnates in Nairobi, where most East African hunts begin and end, are worried men.

Nikita Khrushchev's arrival in Rumania yesterday indicates that he has decided to make his first major post-summit task the shoring up of the Soviet Union's position in Eastern Europe, the Achilles Heel of the Communist world. Communist rule was imposed upon this area in full severity less than a decade and a half ago, and less than four years ago the events in Poland and Hungary showed how precarious this Moscow rule was.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The short, sharp recession of 1957-58 hit bottom two years and two months ago. Production, employment and personal income have long since recovered the ground they lost in the slump and moved on to new records -- but unemployment is another story.
As the distinctiveness of New York's skyline grows, so does that of its sidewalks.
HONG KONG, June 9 -- Stringent state control of food grains from the harvested stalk to the dinner table is the purpose of a new movement undertaken by the Chinese Communist regime.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter published in your issue of June 12, Dr. Leo Szilard rebukes The Times for expressing the view that the latest Soviet disarmament proposal contains "a stipulation that disarmament controls be subject to the veto."

FOR some years Hugh Fosburgh has been writing novels about the back country in the Adirondacks, the only true wilderness left in the East. These deceptively quiet novels have been cherished by readers who know good writing and appreciate a non-clinical view of humanity.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 18 -- Richard Howell sailed Echo to victory in a sixteen-boat International Class fleet today as ninety-six skippers turned out for the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound's session.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The United States expelled two Cuban diplomats today on charges of espionage, racial agitation and other "highly improper" activities.
